https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/19/busin.body_text: **********Mattel Inc. said that it had sold Ringling Brothers-Barnum & Bailey Combined Shows Inc. for $22.8 million to a family that had owned the circus and has been in its management for 26 years. **********Two members of the family, Irvin Feld and his son, Kenneth, said that the deal included the circus, Ice Follies, Holiday on Ice and the new Walt Disney's World on Ice. **********The transaction also includes a Las Vegas nightclub act called ''Beyond Belief.'' **********The acquisition involves more than 1,200 performers and employees, 500 circus animals and 98 railroad cars.  Irvin Feld was a record and music promoter and music store chain owner before becoming involved with the circus in 1956. In 1967, he and a brother acquired the company's total assets from the Ringling and North families for $8 million. Two years later, the circus became a publicly held corporation, and in 1971 the company was sold to Mattel for $50 million in stock.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/24/world.body_text: **********Harold H. Saunders, former Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs, said today that the withholding of aid from Israel ''might be necessary at some point in the future.'' **********''Israel and the United States have been on a collision course for two years now,'' Mr. Saunders said in a broadcast over the Voice of America. **********''We haven't had a serious discussion about our differences. **********Mr. Saunders, who ran the Bureau of Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs during the Carter Administration, is a senior fellow at the American Enterprise Institute for Public Policy Research. **********He said the invasion of Lebanon raised questions about Israel's use of American-supplied weapons that were restricted by law to defensive uses. **********''Congress may have to consider changing the law, if it is found to be unenforceable,'' he said. In the short run, he said, ''The withholding of aid to Israel might be necessary at some point in the future.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/22/busin.body_text: **********Large gains were reported yesterday in the quarterly earnings of makers of small computer systems, many of them used in homes. But companies making larger computers did not perform as well because the recession and high interest rates dampened business orders. **********Apple Computer, a leading maker of personal computers, reported an 83 percent increase in net income for the first quarter of fiscal 1982, ended Dec. 25. And Wang Laboratories Inc., a leading maker of small business syste ms, said earnings in its second quarter jumped 32percent. **********Prime Computer Inc., however, reported flat earnings for its fourth quarter last year, while the Harris Corporation said earnings for its second quarter had plunged 42 percent. Both companies concentrate on relatively large computers for businesses. **********Apple's gain reflected heavy Christmas buying of the Apple II system, which was heavily promoted late last year as a family computer and contains programs for as video games and budget planning. **********Apple's earnings rose to $13.6 million, or 24 cents a share, on revenues of $133.6 million. In the comparable period last year, Apple reported earnings of $7.4 million, or 14 cents a share, on revenues of $67.6 million. **********Ulric Weil, a principal at Morgan Stanley & Company, argued that earnings would have been higher except for a rise in research and development expenses, which almost doubled from the similar period last year, to reach $7.9 million. ''These expenditures dampen earnings immediately, but they speak well for the future as far as new product announcements,'' he said. ''No one in the personal computer spends as much for research as Apple, and that's a good sign.'' **********Second-quarter earnings at Wang rose to $25.2 million, or 41 cents a share, on revenues of $273.4 million. This compares with net income of $19 million, or 33 cents a share, on revenues of $201.7 million for the similar period last year. The increase was attributed to strong sales for office automation systems. Orders for all Wang products increased 34 percent, according to Mr. Weil. **********Harris reported that net income in the quarter ended Dec. 31 dropped to $19.7 million, or 63 cents a share, on revenues of $426.6 million. In the similar period of 1980, net income was $34.2 million, or $1.11 a share, on revenues of $386.4 million. **********William R. Beckleam, a vice president at Kidder Peabody & Company, said the earnings had been hurt by sluggish semiconductor sales, weakened by overcapacity and declining demand. ''The orders are not there,'' said Mr. Beckleam. Sales and earnings in every division other than semiconductors rose. **********Fourth-quarter earnings at Prime Computer increased 4 percent, to $10.5 million, or 35 cents a share, on revenues of $99.6 million. For the similar period of 1980, net income was $10 million, or 33 cents a share, on revenues of $85.4 million. **********For all 1981, Prime reported a 20 percent increase in net income to $37.7 million, or $1.25 a share, on sales of $364.8 million. In the previous year, Prime earned $31.2 million, or $1.07 a share, on revenues of $267.6 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/04/busin.body_text: **********FOR the Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation, it was a stunning defeat. Less than two weeks before its annual meeting, the company found out that Alan E. Clore, a British investor, was waging a proxy fight for control of the ailing mining and chemicals concern. Almost before Gulf Resources's top executives could catch their breath, they were ousted in one of the fastest proxy contests on record. **********Mr. Clore's victory and its modest price tag of $1.5 million did not escape notice on Wall Street, where he captured the attention of many professionals and investors who rarely give faltering companies such as Gulf Resources a second glance. In short order, merger and acquisition specialists, along with disgruntled shareholders, began to wonder whether they, too, could take over a company with the expenditure of so little money and so little time. **********Indeed, in the wake of the Gulf Resources contest, many Wall Street analysts expect a new wave of proxy fights, in which dissident investors, rather than trying to buy a company outright, will seek to wrest the reins from management by winning shareholder support for new corporate strategy. **********''I think Gulf Resources was a tremendous eye-opener,'' said Stephen Schwarzman, a partner at Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb. ''All these businessmen are trying to buy companies and getting rebuffed by management, and here's this guy from Britain who moves in quickly and gets control, relatively cheaply. That deal tells you something has changed.'' **********Most of what has changed is the business climate. As long as stock prices remain severely depressed and high interest rates make it difficult to finance an acquisition, analysts believe that dissatisfied investors, particularly those with large stock holdings, will find the proxy fight an increasingly popular tactic for winning control of a company. **********In fact, a significant upturn in the number of proxy fights is already apparent, according to Georgeson & Company, a leading firm in the business of soliciting shareholder proxies. Its figures show that there have been 11 major battles so far this year, including Gulf Resources and the pending Global Natural Resources fight, compared with with only 17 for all of 1981 and the same number in 1980. **********Though Gulf Resources is the most dramatic example, similar proxy wars have brought new management to several other companies. Last spring, 33-year-old Neil Leist won control of American Bakeries, the nation's fourth-largest commercial bakery. A few months later, after a bitter two-year contest, Michael Buchsbaum took over Holly Sugar.  Last year's successful proxy fight at Penn Central was more limited.  Instead of trying to gain control, dissidents sought only to block Penn Central from completing a $1.4 billion merger with Colt Industries. **********Because shareholders usually differ on what constitutes salvation, most proxy fights stir up considerable ill will. In this year's fight for control of the Tosco Corporation, for example, management charged that dissident Kenneth Good, who was trying to get Tosco to pull out of the Colony Oil Shale Project, was obtaining nonpublic information on Tosco through his girlfriend, the director of the Colorado Department of Local Affairs. By the May annual meeting, the confrontation had become so heated that Tosco management disconnected Mr. Good's microphone when he began personal attacks on the officers. **********Bitterness, however, is almost inevitable in any battle to take over a corporation, whether it be by a proxy challenge or by a tender offer.  Yet, the proxy routehas a singular advantage: it is relatively inexpensive. In asking shareholders to vote for a new slate of directors, or to oppose a management decision, the dissident shareholder must only win support of a majority of those who return their proxy ballots. The costs of waging such a battle tend to be limited to legal and advisory fees as well as advertising costs. **********In most cases, the dissident investor has already purchased a substantial block of shares himself and may be able to win his fight by merely enlisting a handful of other large stockholders.  Mr. Clore had accumulated more than 15 percent of Gulf Resources's stock in the seven months before its May 11 meeting, while Mr. Good spent more than a year acquiring his 8.8 percent share of Tosco. **********''In a proxy fight, the shares you do buy, you buy at close to the market price, and of course you don't have to buy as many shares as you do to get control of a company through a tender offer,'' said Brian Young, the vice president in charge of mergers and acquisitions at First Boston. **********Although proxy battles can be an inexpensive way to gain control of a company, financial experts stress that they will not replace tender offers. **********While individual stockholders may be satisfied with taking over the board, they say, most corporations want to acquire, not just control, other companies. And for most large corporations, proxy fights are too long and their outcome too uncertain to be an attractive option.  The Gulf Resources fight took only two weeks, but most contests involve months of battling, with allegations of mismanagement and fraud bandied about in court, in newspaper ads, and in mailings to shareholders. These knock-down, drag-out battles are, in large part, why the tide turned in favor of tender offers in the early 1960's. **********''In the 40's and 50's, you had a lot of proxy fights,'' said Martin Lipton, a takeover specialist with the law firm of Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz. ''Then in the 60's, everyone turned to tender offers, which are quicker, neater and cleaner,'' he said, recalling an era when tender offers were relatively free of regulation.  ''But,'' he continued, ''for individual investors, activity in proxy fights is being significantly revived this year. Most have been in the smaller companies, but I'd expect 10 or 12 fights this year at companies with market values over $50 million.'' **********The current faltering economy is a perfect environment for proxy contests. Stock prices are depressed, with many companies barely clinging to survival. And, as a general rule, proxy fights are more apt to take place in the less successful companies. **********''When a company is performing badly, it's easy to convince shareholders a new team would do better, even if the problems were due more to the general business climate than to bad management,'' said Mr. Schwarzman, who added that large pools of money are now being formed to buy stakes in vulnerable companies. **********Many people feel that the market is so bad right now that, as one takeover expert puts it, ''nearly every company seems like a real dog.'' So aggressive, disgruntled shareholders - Victor Posner and Carl Icahn are repeatedly mentioned as examples of the kind of investor likely to be alert to the possibility of waging a proxy fight - may find it the right time to try to leverage a minority interest into control of a major corporation. **********Often the investor's purpose in waging a proxy war is to gain control with the idea of liquidating the company, or parts of it, for a quick profit. Indeed, the campaign promise that won Gulf Resources for Mr. Clore was that he would consider ''redeployment of some or all'' of the company's assets. **********MR. CLORE'S battle began on April 23, a Friday night, when he called from Paris to tell his lawyers at Willkie, Farr & Gallagher that he wanted to wage a proxy fight for Gulf Resources in time for the company's annual meeting, just 18 days later. The proxy fight the lawyers organized that weekend was a triple triumph: they won, they won fast, and they won against one of the kingpins of the takeover bar, New York lawyer Joseph Flom. **********Ousting the mangement of a publicly held corporation may be relatively inexpensive, but it is not simple. In addition to marshalling the majority of votes, the challenger faces many legal and procedural hurdles, from getting Securities and Exchange Commission approval for every proxy solicitation, advertisement or announcement he wants to put out to getting the shareholder list so that votes can be solicited. **********The Gulf Resources contest broke all rules for speed. ''The generally accepted wisdom is that you have to begin making a proxy fight six to eight weeks before the annual meeting if you're going to have a chance to unseat the management,'' said Mr. Lipton, who vies with Mr. Flom for the distinction of being the country's top takeover lawyer. ''I can't think of another case in which a dissident group won in such a short time.'' **********Even Kenneth Bialkin, the senior partner at Willkie Farr, who spearheaded Mr. Clore's fight, was uncertain that Gulf Resources could be won so quickly. ''We had no program, no slate of directors, no public relations firm, no investment banker, no proxy solicitor and no team of lawyers,'' he said. But Willkie Farr entered the battle and mapped its strategy during the first weekend. **********The firm realized that the institutional investors who held the majority of the stock would be unhappy with the company's recent performance: Gulf Resources lost $77.9 million in 1981 after closing down lead, zinc and silver mining operations. **********Most people familiar with the company, however, say the main impetus behind the shareholders' desire for change was the fact that management had rejected a $42-a-share offer from Placid Oil two years ago as inadequate and the stock had fallen below $10 a share in the first quarter of 1982. **********The Willkie Farr lawyers made that resentment a prime element of their strategy: ''We decided there was already so much discontent with the management of Gulf Resources that we didn't need to make specific charges of mismanagement or get into personal attacks,'' said Stephen Flood, who worked with Mr. Bialkin. **********In order to get quick S.E.C. clearance and be as litigation-proof as possible, the Clore group's proxy solicitation was designed to avoid controversial statements. Simplicity, the lawyers thought, was the key to speed. On Monday, April 26, they called the S.E.C. to say they were planning a fight and ask for accelerated treatment. The next day, they filed disclosure forms and the fight was on. **********Between Monday and Friday, the lawyers had to find at least eight people to run for Gulf's 14-member board of directors in order to gain control. **********Appealing to a sense of adventure, Mr. Bialkin said, was the only way to find recruits on behalf of a foreign client for a proxy fight that was sure to involve litigation - against Mr. Flom, who is no shrinking violet. One director-designate, Sheldon Atlas, was recruited late at night when he ran into Mr. Bialkin in the elevator of the Central Park West apartment building where both men live. **********By Friday, the Willkie Farr lawyers had filed their proxy solicitation with the S.E.C., naming a slate of seven directors, along with a notation that an eighth name would be forthcoming. **********The time problem remained serious, though, in part because of New York Stock Exchange rules on voting by the brokerage houses and other institutions which hold most of the stock on behalf of the owners. Under the rules, the broker who holds the stock must mail proxy solicitations to the real owner and then await voting instructions. But if, 10 days before the annual meeting, the broker knows of no proxy fight and has received no voting instructions, he can go ahead and vote as he pleases. Willkie Farr solved this problem by taking out full page newspaper ads to publicize the fight. **********The Willkie Farr lawyers could not get the proxies out to shareholders until the weekend because of another 10-day rule.  Corporations are required to make their shareholder list available for inspection at corporate headquarters during the 10 days prior to the annual meeting - again, beginning Saturday, May 1. Often there is some legal squabbling about exactly how available the list must be. **********A specialized photographer was sent to Texas to take two pictures of the list Saturday; one was developed immediately to check legibility, and the other was developed directly onto mailing labels so the solicitation could be mailed immediately. There was a mild faceoff: The Willkie Farr lawyers said the management expected them to show up with Mr. Clore's power of attorney, which would have been technically deficient, and were ''waiting at the door to turn us away.'' But because the photographer had a power of attorney from a shareholder of record he was admitted. **********EVEN though the shareholder list was not made the object of litigation, the Gulf Resources proxy fight had, in typical fashion, already become mired in lawsuits. ''You know when you go into one of these that everything imaginable is going to end up in court,'' said Irwin Jacobs, who is still involved in litigation arising from his unsuccessful fight for Pabst. Mr. Jacobs, who is now trying to take over Pabst through a tender offer, said he had heard the phrase 'scorched earth,' describing takeover lawyers' tendency to use every possible device to destroy the opposition, too often to be surprised by the array of lawsuits. **********The week before the annual meeting was largely taken up with the litigation. The nominated directors were to give testimony, including Mr. Clore, who arrived in the United States Thursday night for the first time since the fight began. The meeting May 11 was anticlimactic. It lasted a calm 20 minutes, with proxies coming in right up until the polls closed. When the vote was counted and certified, Mr. Clore's Committee for New Management had won 3,371,814 votes, against the old management's 2,859,977. **********Although a sweet victory for Mr. Clore, the Gulf Resources battle is an ominous warning for other beleaguered managements. ''I already know of at least five proxy fights coming up in major corporations, one of them in the Fortune 500,'' said Arthur Long of D.F. King & Company, a major proxy solicitation firm.  ''More and more blue chip companies are going to have problems because shareholders are feeling caught. Next year, there's going to be a whole shooting gallery of proxy fights.'' HOLD IN TECH FOR ALIX **********Rites and Rituals of the Proxy Game **********STEP 1: Dissidents, dissatisifed with a company's management or direction, file a 14-B form with the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosing their intent to wage a proxy fight. **********STEP 2: Dissidents make a formal request to the company for a copy of its shareholder list. Typically, the company resists, the parties go to court and the dissidents usually prevail. **********STEP 3: A strategy is developed for contacting shareholders on the list, particularly those whose stock is held by brokerage houses. The dissidents decide which issues to raise with shareholders. **********STEP 4: Proxy ballots and other sollicitation materials are sent to shareholders in anticipation of the company's annual meeting. **********STEP 5: Direct personal contact is made with large shareholders, and as many small shareholders as possible are reached through telphone calls and letters. **********STEP 6: Dissidents go to annual meeting with their votes, where ballots are counted and certified, making sure that only the shareholder's last ballot is recorded. To win, one side must get at least 50 percent of the proxy ballots returned.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/01/world.body_text: **********Two leading Italian bishops have spoken out against plans to install nuclear missiles in Sicily and sided with American bishops condemning the nuclear arms race. **********Announcing a New Year's Eve peace march in Milan, Bishop Dante Bernini of Segni, president of the justice and peace commission of the Italian Bishops' Conference, and Bishop Luigi Bettazzi of Ivrea, president of Pax Cristi, an international Roman Catholic peace movement, said: **********''We express our solidarity with the American bishops who have denounced the immorality of the unrestrained atomic arms race, and we share the perplexity of those who fear the start of atomic rearmament in Europe with the installation of missiles in Comiso as well as the exploitation of the South.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/18/busin.body_text: **********The General Refractories Company said it expects a one-time charge to 1982 earnings of $37 million because of a restructuring of its domestic refractories and building products businesses. **********The company also disclosed that its principal domestic bank lenders have agreed to extend their $27 million loan agreement with the company for 90 days past its scheduled expiration on Jan. 1. **********General Refractories said the loan extension would allow additional time for final negotiations to complete the structuring of a new term loan agreement.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/25/world.body_text: **********The Organization of African Unity begins preparations for its annual summit meeting next week, contemplating a past year of division and ineffectiveness that threaten its survival as the spokesman for a continent. **********The organization is also confronted with an uncertain year ahead under the chairmanship of Libya's unpredictable leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, who will assume the post at the meeting in Tripoli. **********African foreign ministers open their preparatory discussions in Tripoli on Monday, and the summit meeting begins Aug. 5. Thus the foreign ministers have at least a week in which to come up with ideas for resolving the most serious split in the organization's 19-year history, a dispute over Western Sahara. **********The rift opened in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, in February when 26 African nations decided at a foreign minister's meeting to admit the Polisario guerrilla front as the organization's 51st member, representing Western Sahara. The decision prompted a boycott of the gathering by 19 nations under the leadership of Morocco, which administers Western Sahara and is fighting a war against the Polisario insurgents. O.A.U. Policy Prejudged **********The decision to admit the Polisario Front raised the question of whether the guerrillas fulfilled the O.A.U.'s membership criteria requiring newcomers to be sovereign in their own lands. **********It also prejudged the organization's policy toward Western Sahara.  At last year's summit meeting in Nairobi, Kenya, the organization called for a referendum so the people of Western Sahara could decide for themselves how they wanted to be ruled. **********The decision prompted such a fierce division between O.A.U.  members supporting Morocco and more leftist nations backing Polisario that two subsequent ministerial meetings were disrupted by boycotts. **********The crisis is bound to come to a head in Tripoli, because the organization's rules require a quorum of two-thirds of its members for a meeting to be legal. Morocco and at least 11 other nations have indicated that they will not attend the meeting, and Rabat is leading a campaign to prevent a quorum. 34 Needed for Quorum **********A quorum would be formed by 34 members, so Morocco needs to persuade at least 18 nations to boycott the meeting. This would reduce the gathering to an illegality unprecedented in the O.A.U.'s history and would belie the organization's title and aspirations. **********Robert Ouko, the Kenyan Foreign Minister, said before leaving for Tripoli that he believed the foreign ministers' meeting would form a quorum. Still in question, however, is the the summit meeting's ability to muster enough heads of state if the foreign ministers make no progress toward a settlement. **********A failure, Western diplomats said, would mean at least a temporary collapse of the organization and a severe lessening of its ability to represent an African viewpoint in international gatherings. It would also cap a year of embarrassments for the organization's current chairman, President Daniel arap Moi of Kenya. Chad Initiative a Failure **********The main initiatives undertaken during Mr. Moi's leadership have been on Western Sahara and Chad, where the organization deployed its first peacekeeping force. But the presence of the 3,500-man Chad force, made up of soldiers from Nigeria, Senegal and Zaire, was not enough to enforce a political settlement or to prevent rebels from overrunning the Chadian capital of Ndjamena and forcing President Goukouni Oueddei to flee. **********Some Western diplomats have attributed the organization's failures this year to indecisiveness by the Kenyan leadership. But that assessment ignores a fundamental weakness in the organization: Like other international bodies, it lacks an effective form of censure against members that flout its directives and thus has little power beyond appeals to good will and African solidarity. **********The organization was created in 1963 as a symbol of an emergent continent's aspirations for a pan-Africanism that would prove stronger than the colonialism its new rulers were replacing. **********But with the colonial foe routed or reduced in influence, the organization increasingly resembles a collection of sovereign nations whose interests coincide only on broad issues, such as abhorrence of white minority rule in South Africa or the need to end South Africa's domination of South-West Africa. Credibility Its Only Resource **********The organization's role has been to provide a symbolic cohesiveness for the continent, not to create practical projects, for which economically troubled Africa does not have the resources. Its credibility is its stock in trade, African diplomats said, and that credibility is now in jeopardy. **********It is for this reason, the diplomats said, Nigeria, in particular, has embarked on a diplomatic campaign to save the Tripoli meeting.  ''It is not the issue of Polisario that motivates us,'' a Nigerian official said, ''but the principle of the survival of the organization.'' **********Another argument is that the organization is Africa's only emblem of solidarity and its collapse would open the way for a re-enactment of the 19th-century European scramble for influence on the continent, this time embroiling East and West.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/23/busin.body_text: **********The International Monetary Fund issued an annual report today noting ''widespread dissatisfaction and concern'' with global economic conditions. **********It warned that lasting prosperity would come only if governments showed the ''patience'' and ''courage'' to stick with restrictive anti-inflationary policies. **********The report of the 146-nation lending agency urged members not to yield to political pressures that would dissipate the hard-won progress against inflation through an ''untimely resort to expansionary policies.'' **********Published two weeks before the annual meeting of the fund in Toronto, the report commented: ''Whatever the cost of preventing another damaging flare-up of inflation, it would be less painful than the arduous adjustment process that would almost certainly follow'' a resurgence in inflation. Meeting Also Involves Bank **********The fund's annual meeting will also involve the I.M.F.'s sister institution, the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, which is informally known as the World Bank. **********The I.M.F. report came during a debate in the United States on whether the Federal Reserve Board should ease credit to stimulate the economy and to reduce the current 9.8 percent rate of unemployment.  This debate revolves around several bills introduced in Congress that would require the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates. In recent weeks, the central bank has acted on its own to let interest rates fall. **********The fund, saying that 1982 would be another weak economic year globally, warned that unemployment was likely to continue to rise in both industrial and developing countries even if inflation were brought under control. It said part of the trouble lay in ''inflexibility'' in the structure of wage rates. **********As an example of flexibility, the fund cited what it called ''a noteworthy feature of the Japanese system'' - the large share of labor earnings in the form of bonuses that are linked to profitability of employers. **********The I.M.F., which lends money chiefly to developing countries hurt by a decline in foreign-exchange earnings, reported that slack world trade was increasing strains on the finances of the third world. **********The pressure on export earnings of the poorer countries coincides with greater selectivity by commercial banks in lending to the poor countries, according to the report, which was written before the financial problems of Mexico reached a crisis last week. **********Mexico was the latest of a number of countries seeking to reschedule the payment of foreign debts because of shrinking foreignexchange reserves and to obtain emergency assistance from the I.M.F. 'Adjustment Policies' **********The report suggested that for the ''continued availability of substantial financing'' - both from the fund and commercial banks - countries should show that they are willing to adopt ''appropriate adjustment policies.'' Adjustment policies generally mean politically unpopular belt-tightening, including the curbing of food subsidies and other government payments. **********Such topics are at issue now in talks between the fund and Mexico over the conditions for a $4.5 billion loan.  The report said that for the first time since 1975, there was no growth in the volume of overall world trade in 1981, and it said the volume may decline this year. Problem of Protectionism **********On top of the weak trade, it said, protectionist measures by the industrialized countries ''would be particularly injurious to the trade prospects of the developing countries,'' whose foreign earnings have been severely affected by the decline in the prices for primary product. **********On economic prospects for the United States, the I.M.F. analysts took a position similar to most American economists in forecasting a ''modest economic expansion'' during the second half of 1982 because of some rebuilding of inventories and the effects on consumption of the July 1 reductions in tax rates.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/27/busin.body_text: **********Lawyers and consumer groups representing the thousands of workers involved in asbestos-related lawsuits reacted angrily today to the Manville Corporation's decision to file for reorganization under the bankruptcy laws and vowed to block the move. **********''This appears to be an attempt to avoid their responsibility, and we're prepared to go into the bankruptcy courts and challenge Manville on this,'' said Michel F. Baumeister, an attorney at the New York firm of Kriendler & Kriendler. **********James Vermeulen, executive director of the Asbestos Victims of America, a consumer group, said: ''Manville's trying to do what Chrysler and New York did - get the taxpayers to bail them out. But they're guilty, and they shouldn't be allowed to do this merely because the law says they can.'' **********There are about 16,500 cases pending against Manville in which the claimants contend that the company provided inadequate information about the physical danger of working with asbestos and insufficient protection against the hazards. The Position of Other Suits **********Industry analysts emphasized that Manville's action today would not affect the thousands of asbestos-related lawsuits still pending against more than 400 other companies. In the past, attorneys representing asbestos claimants have been criticized for seemingly clogging the courts with cases and endangering companies, but failing to win adequate compensation for the victims. **********Michael Mealey, editor of the Asbestos Litigation Reporter, estimated that there were about 30 major law firms and hundreds of attorneys across the country acting as plaintiffs in asbestos-related litigation. **********''They've got just one less pocket to reach for - a pretty big pocket,'' Mr. Mealey said, ''but the litigation will move forward. I just don't see asbestos attorneys folding up their tents and moving away because of Manville.'' **********Manville's action, industry observers said, could also increase pressures on Congress to act on some form of legislation that would remove from the courts the thousands of lawsuits still pending. **********Earlier this year, hearings were held on a bill sponsored by Representative George Miller, Democrat of California, that would establish a Federal system using industry contributions to provide payments to victims of asbestos-related health problems. So far, however, the idea has garnered little support in Congress. **********Representative Miller said today: ''It's a fairly ruthless act on the part of Manville to escape liability to a lot of injured and diseased workers they have responsibility for. We're in the process now of assessing whether we will try to move the legislation immediately so additional companies cannot escape liability.'' Possible Threat to Others **********Ester Foer, a spokesman for the Asbestos Compensation Coalition, an industry-led group seeking new Federal legislation, also warned that without legislation to limit the impact of such suits, other companies might be forced to file for bankruptcy. **********The coalition is circulating a proposal in Congress that would establish a Federal trust fund to compensate victims, with contributions to the fund coming half from the Federal Government - whose World War II shipyard operations are said to have been responsible for a substantial portion of the asbestos problem - and half from the asbestos companies. **********This legislation, however, has been opposed by many asbestos claimants and by the Association of Trial Lawyers of America, because it would cut off the workers' right to sue the companies and to seek punitive damages, which they view as an important deterrent. **********Among lawyers currently involved in litigation against Manville, there was considerable skepticism about whether the deluge of damage suits was the principal reason for the company's decision to file for protection under Chapter 11. **********Harvey Weitz, a lawyer with the New York firm of Schneider, Kleinick & Weitz and a former president of the New York State Trial Lawyers Association, said: ''I'm really astounded. It seems to me that if they had a problem and dealt with the lawyers en masse through a committee system, they could probably have worked out a structure situation whereby there would be periodic payments to claimants. I just think the whole thing was mishandled.''

But it was unfortunate that the article was written only from the perspective of the Big 8, without any mention of accounting firms outside that group. **********I believe the Economic Recovery Tax Act of 1981 will have a greater positive impact on mid-sized national firms and smaller regional and local accounting firms. These firms, which employ more than 75 percent of the nation's certified public accountants, usually devote higher proportions of their practices to tax work - in our case, well over 30 percent, compared with an average of less than 20 percent for Big 8 firms. **********Yes, the Big 8 are wooing small business now with t heir ''small business departments.'' https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/29/busin.body_text: **********New orders for machine tools, a barometer of the economy's wellbeing, fell 41 percent in February compared with the period last year, the National Tool Builders' Association said yesterday. **********Machine tool orders generally improve when the economy has already started to recover from a recession. Accordingly, industry executives said, new orders would have to increase for two consecutive months before they felt confident a recovery was in progress. **********''After the sizable rise in machine tool orders in January, the report of February's activity is particularly disappointing,'' James A. Gray, president of the association, said. **********''We have bottomed out basically, but the width of the valley is yet to be determined,'' said Clifford Meyer, president and chief operating officer of Cincinnati Milacron Inc., the nation's largest machine tool producer. 20 Percent Decline **********New machine tool orders in February were down 20 percent, to $163.8 million, from $205.2 million in January, and were 41 percent less than the $280.1 million in orders received during February last year. Thus far this year, machine tool orders are down 35 percent, to $369 million, from $570.8 million in the first two months of 1981. **********''The industry is skidding along the bottom of the trough,'' said Patrick McCarthy, a spokesman for the Bendix Corporation, the nation's second-largest producer of machine tools. Most analysts expect orders to follow an erratic path until late this year. **********Mr. McCarthy pointed out that orders from the oil industry continue to be strong, while orders from the auto industry and smaller machine shops remain depressed. Bendix has laid off about 600 employees, or 10 percent of its workforce, in the last six months, he said. **********Most machine tool companies have a large backlog of orders that carry them through slow periods. However, new orders have been coming in at such a slow rate that many companies are beginning to work through their old orders. The industry backlog dropped to $2.9 million in February, from $3.1 million in January. In February 1981, the backlog in orders stood at $5.2 million. **********''Beyond the middle of the year you will begin to see a significant effect on the companies if orders don't pick up,'' said Eli S.  Lustgarten, an analyst with Paine, Webber, Mitchell Hutchins Inc. Prospect for Improvement **********As an indication that things might get better soon, Mr. Meyer, of Cincinnati Milacron, said that his company had experienced a significant increase in customer inquiries about new equipment. ''I think this indicates that there is a large pent-up demand,'' he said. ''There is a great deal of interest.'' **********Machine tool orders can be expected to increase when factory utilization begins to pick up significantly. In February, capacity utilization stood at 71.8 percent, a slight increase from January but still below December's level of 73 percent. **********The decline in foreign orders increased substantially last month.  In February, orders from abroad dropped 64.7 percent, to $14.6 million, from $41.4 million in February 1981. Japan is the largest importer of American-made machine tools, accounting for more than 30 percent of the market, followed by West Germany, Britain and Switzerland. **********Domestic orders last month fell 37.5 percent, to $149.2 million, from $238.7 million a year ago.  Shipments of machine tools dropped 14 percent in February, to $359.4 million, from $422.1 million last year. Shipments declined 6.3 percent from January. Thus far this year, shipments are down 8.4 percent, to $743. million, from $811.1 million during the first two months of 1981.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/30/busin.body_text: **********Summoned from across the nation, more than 50 attorneys representing thousands of plaintiffs in asbestosrelated personal injury suits against the Manville Corporation flew to this plush South Carolina beach resort over the weekend. After two days of preliminary strategy planning and briefings on bankruptcy law procedures here, the session was to continue in New York on Monday. **********The preliminary conference, which ended today, was planned by the Barnwell, S.C., firm of Blatt & Sales so plaintiffs' lawyers could begin mapping a course of action to address what attorneys here called Manville's ''fraudulent'' bankruptcy petition. **********Manville executives said when they filed last Thursday for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws that the cost of the 16,500 damage claims pending against the company could not be met and that the company's total liability could reach $2 billion. The effect of the filing has been to suspend the suits and avoid the filing of new ones. **********But the attorneys here said Manville's action was unwarranted.  ''They're a solvent firm,'' said Ronald Motley, a partner with Blatt & Sales and a leading attorney in the asbestos action. ''It's nothing but a perversion of the bankruptcy laws.'' Mr. Motley's firm represents 3,000 plaintiffs in asbestos-injury cases, 90 percent of them against Manville. **********Exposure to asbestos can cause asbestosis, a lung disease that can be disabling or fatal, and cancer. The suits filed against Manville, the largest single asbestos maker in the world, contend that the company did not make the risks known to workers or take proper precautions against the diseases. **********Many of the lawyers here said that the suddenness of Manville's bankruptcy petition and their own lack of familiarity with the intricacies of bankruptcy laws had delayed and handicapped the group's response. **********''Before this thing I didn't know how to spell bankruptcy,'' said one attorney, speaking for many of his colleagues. ''I think we all know how to do that now.'' **********Among those giving legal briefings here were Robert Evans, a New Haven attorney with experience in the field of creditors' rights, and Philip Lacey, a bankruptcy expert and professor at the University of South Carolina Law School. **********Mr. Evans told the lawyers there were several factors he considered unusual in the Manville bankruptcy petition. First, he said, was the lengthy explanation Manville included in the petition, giving its reasons for seeking reorganization. **********Second, Mr. Evans said, only 20 of Manville's 51 subsidiaries included on the bankruptcy petition were listed as seeking reorganization; the other 31 are not involved. ''They selected a portion out for reorganization,'' he said. ''They did not file an action for all of their assets. I've never seen anything quite like it.'' Suits Against Officers, Holders **********Later, in the strategy sessions, the attorneys debated several legal moves to force Manville to begin dealing with the asbestos lawsuits. **********Mr. Motley and other attorneys said they were considering suits against John H. McKinney, chairman and chief executive officer of Manville. And attorneys were considering separate suits against Manville's directors and possibly against its shareholders.  Congressional leaders also will be asked to support the group's actions, the attorneys said. **********But the first item of business, Mr. Motley said, will be to seek to dismiss Manville's bankruptcy petition. The group also will try to set up an information network so its actions can be made known to thousands of plaintiffs scattered across the country. **********Nearly every attorney told of the sudden and dramatic effect the action had had on the lawsuits. Mr. Motley, for instance, said he was taking depositions last week in Louisiana when word of the Manville petition reached him. ''The attorneys for the defendants simply packed up and walked out,'' he said. ''I don't blame them.  They weren't going to be paid.'' **********Tom Taft, an attorney from Greenville, N.C., who represents 40 plaintiffs, recently settled a case for $800,000, the second-largest asbestos settlement on record. He said his client - the family of a 38-year-old college professor who had been exposed to asbestos when he was a shipyard worker two decades earlier and who had died of the rare lung disorder mesetheliona - collected more than half the settlement from Manville before the company's petition was filed Thursday. ''They had some concern about whether they should settle or not,'' said Mr. Taft. ''I think now they're pretty pleased they did.'' **********Many of the attorneys will leave here tonight and reconvene for more sessions in New York on Monday to complete their planning.  The group already has dispatched paralegal assistants, one from Mississippi and one from Tennessee, to be in United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York by early Monday morning.  There they will collect information about the court and copy Manville's file.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/17/busin.body_text: **********The Hewlett-Packard Company introduced a desk-top computer yesterday that it said was far more powerful than other machines of its size on the market. **********The machine is capable of handling 32 bits, or pieces, of information at a time. By contrast, most desk-top or microcomputers, such as the Apple II, process only eight bits at a time, while even newer, more powerful machines such as the I.B.M. personal computer can handle 16 bits at a time. **********The number of bits that can be processed is important because it determines the machine's speed in such applications as generating graphic displays, and because it determines how much information can be stored in memory and retrieved. **********''We all knew that 32-bit microcomputers inevitably had to come, and here they are,'' said Ulric Weil, computer industry analyst at Morgan Stanley & Company. **********The 32-bit machines are not likely to make major inroads in the business and consumer-oriented microcomputer market because of their high price and lack of software, the instructions that tell the machines what to do. In addition, 16-bit machines, which cost a few thousand dollars, are likely to have more than enough power for many applications. **********Hewlett-Packard's system, which has a starting price of $28,250, will instead be aimed at engineering and scientific work, such as computerized product design. Hewlett-Packard said that each engineer could have his own computer, rather than having to share time and capacity on a larger system. **********In a separate announcement yesterday, the Data General Corporation, competitor of Hewlett-Packard, announced its smallest and least expensive 32-bit computer, a machine about the size of a small filing cabinet with a starting price of $27,500. It will be aimed at office as well as engineering applications. **********The Hewlett-Packard computer is the first product to use the company's 32-bit microprocessor, often called a computer on a chip, which was first described by the company in early 1981. The Intel Corporation and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, however, have also developed 32-bit microprocessors, meaning that other 32-bit computers are likely to appear on the market in the future.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/19/world.body_text: **********An advance squad of Lebanese troops arrived here today, but Israeli forces that moved in on Friday to keep peace between feuding Lebanese Christian militiamen and Moslem Druse refused to leave. **********An Israeli captain said his forces would remain until they were ''absolutely certain that the Lebanese Army could control the fighting.'' **********The officer said the area, 10 to 15 miles southeast of Beirut, had been quiet for the last three days because of the Israeli presence. **********The decision to send Lebanese troops to this area, which has been controlled by Israeli troops, was made Sunday at a meeting of local politicians and President Amin Gemayel, who left shortly thereafter for New York. Plans for full deployment of the Lebanese troops were apparently held up by the continued Israelil presence. Israelis Entered 4 Villages **********Israel moved tanks and troop carriers onto the sandbagged front line between the Christian and Druse Moslem quarters of Kafr Matta and into three other mountain villages on Friday to end days of artillery and machine-gun exchanges. **********Despite a 150-year history of Druse-Christian strife, the mountain area here was said to have been largely calm for about eight years until Israel allowed in the Lebanese Christian militiamen and upset the power balance. **********The fighting has put Israel in a delicate position. Israel is allied with the Lebanese Christians in its invasion of Lebanon but has a significant Druse population at home. **********A Lebanese lieutenant in Kafr Matta said the army could not enter the town until Israel pulled out. He said the advance unit would stay overnight and see if the Israelis ''are still here tomorrow.'' **********Lebanese policemen said that in four days of fighting last week before the Israelis moved in, about 15 people were killed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/29/busin.body_text: **********The Allegheny Beverage Corporation of Baltimore, one of the largest outside shareholders in the Wickes Companies of San Diego, has announced that it had arranged to borrow up to $600 million in behalf of Wickes so that the California holding company would not have to sell any operations that are currently profitable or may become so. **********The board of Wickes, a number of whose subsidiaries are in the troubled housing industry, has appointed a committee to study the plan. **********Wickes has already made arrangements for three divestitures. **********It has a loan agreement for $580 million that expires July 31.Allegheny is making the offer, Morton M. Lapides, its chairman and president, said last Friday, because such financing would relieve Wickes from the pressures of that debt. **********That company, according to its announcement, ''believes the proposed financing would provide better terms than the present Wickes loans and make unnecessay the sale of profitable or potentially profitable operations.'' **********Allegheny, which has Pepsi-Cola, Dr Pepper and Schweppes bottling operations, also has units in food service, building maintainance and coin-operated laundries. It owns 4.2 percent of Wickes common shares, or about 595,000.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/24/busin.main_headline: NONUNION SHOPS SPUR GAIN IN SOUTH
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/24/busin.print_headline: NONUNION SHOPS SPUR GAIN IN SOUTH
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/24/busin.body_text: **********Construction executives in the South like to boast that the 100-mile stretch of pine-covered countryside between here and Charlotte, N.C., probably has more builders per square mile than any place in the United States. **********Builders here have thrived on the Sun Belt's boom during the past two decades. And lately, this expansion has continued for quite a different reason: The companies are not bound by union contracts to hire union craftsmen. **********Many clients believe that nonunion builders can offer better prices, so while the rest of the construction industry flounders in deep recession, Southern companies are as entrenched and healthy as the kudzu vine that creeps over and around every Southern pine in its path. **********Construction industry giants such as the Fluor Corporation and the Bechtel Group, which have traditionally been unionized, have been acquiring building concerns or setting up subsidiaries that are not unionized. **********Two of the largest companies in Greenville, Daniel International and Yeargin Construction, were acquired in the late 1970's. Daniel's Profits Up Sharply **********Fluor paid $230 million for Daniel, which analysts thought was high at the time. They have changed their minds. Last year Daniel's profits jumped 21 percent, to $54 million. Yeargin was acquired by the Perini Corporation of Framingham, Mass. **********''Virtually every large contractor has or is looking for 'merit shop' capability,'' said Hugh Rice, vice president of Fails Management Institute, a consultant to the construction industry. ''I see nothing but an ever-increasing move toward merit shops. If you are a merit shop and large, you have a very marketable commodity.'' **********What the construction industry means by a ''merit shop'' in the industry is a system under which the contractor sublets jobs - to electricians and plumbers, for example -to the lowest qualified bidder regardless of whether that bidder is unionized. While salaries for craftsmen, unionized or not, will generally be comparable, union wages for unskilled workers are higher. Union Wages Spurred Shift **********The shift to this low-bid system in the construction industry began in the 1970's when clients found that strikes by unionized employees sometimes caused the price of a project to rise dramatically. As union wages rose, some clients turned away from union contractors. **********''There was a period when a lot of workers abused the system, and utilities and others broke away,'' said a spokesman for the Building and Construction Trades Department of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, who asked not to be identified. He maintained, however, that in recent years the unions had taken measures and had blunted the growth of the low-bid system. **********The unions have started drives in such places as California and the Pacific Northwest. And strikes, one of the main complaints of clients using union shops, are occurring less frequently. The unions have started to sign project agreements, which virtually rule out the possibility of a strike. **********In addition, the unions have the advantage of a large, trained work force that contractors can easily tap by going to the hiring hall. A low-bid contractor depends on the local labor pool and trains its own workers. Some industry executives believe that because work has been scarce for the past couple of years, these contractors have had the advantage of drawing from the pool of unionized craftsmen. Price Advantage Cited **********''The merit shop should always be less expensive,'' said Buck Mickel, chairman of Daniel, who asserted that although there was a clear price advantage, clients did not make their decisions solely on price. **********Certain segments of the market, such as companies that constuct downtown office buildings, are still bastions of union contractors.  And clients often decide in these cases that it would be a mistake to put a low-bid system in the middle of the union's territory. **********Sometimes clients build with the system because they want to keep the unions out of the plants once they are up. ''The people who are moving to the Sun Belt want to keep their factories nonunion, and so they begin by building nonunion,'' said Dan Knise, a director of the Associated General Contractors of America, a trade association that was historically a union group but now has a membership split evenly between union and nonunion contractors. **********The recession has exaggerated the advantage of the low-bid system.  As companies try to hold down spending, they are either postponing work or looking for less expensive contractors to do the building. In 1981, contractors using the low-bid system performed 63 percent of construction in the United States, up from 59 percent in 1980, according to Associated Builders and Contractors. Union Jobless Rate High **********''Merit shops will always be a threat, particularly in this time of heavy unemployment,'' the spokesman for the building unions said. He added that unemployment in unionized shops was averaging 20 percent, and in some local unions was as high as 80 percent. **********Mr. Mills of Yeargin said that in little more than five years the ratio of construction work along the Gulf Coast done by nonunion workers had shifted to 80 percent from 20 percent. He said he expected the same to happen in the Southwest and Northwest. ''Certain companies have just had all they are going to take of the unions,'' he added. **********While their Southern counterparts have opened up new markets for Fluor and Perini, the affiliation with internationally known companies has also given the Southern builders new leverage, and they are expanding rapidly. **********''I really believe that eventually everything will be merit shop,'' said Earl Mills, president of Yeargin, which is now a part of the Perini Corporation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/14/busin.body_text: **********The British Treasury announced from London today that Britain and Argentina had agreed to mutually lift financial restrictions tonight, but the Argentine Government denied that an agreement exists and said it was studying the proposal. **********Lifting the sanctions, which were imposed during the Falkland Islands war, would free more than $1 billion in Argentine funds frozen in British banks and would open the way for Argentina to begin making overdue payments on an estimated $5 billion borrowed from British banks. No payment on this debt has been made since the Falkland crisis started last spring, and British bankers say that about $200 million in interest payments is past due. **********The British announcement said that lifting the sanctions reflected British concern over Argentina's huge foreign debt and the problems it is having making debt payments on time. The Treasury said it welcomed ''Argentina's current approach to the International Monetary Fund and wishes to facilitate an appropriate early agreement between the Fund and Argentine authorities'' for an emergency I.M.F. loan. **********Restrictions on Britons **********An agreement between Argentina and Britain would also end restrictions that have been placed on British companies operating in Argentina and on British citizens living here. Since the war this summer, they have been prohibited from sending money overseas or selling assets, which are valued at $4 billion to $5 billion. **********The Argentine Economics Ministry said in a communique that the British proposal was ''spontaneous and is not a consequence of any previous accord with our Government.'' But the communique sounded an optimistic tone, echoed by senior Argentine officials, who said that the sanctions might be mutually lifted in a few days. **********(Monday night the British Treasury acknowledged a delay in lifting the sanctions. Reuters quoted the Treasury as saying the delay stemmed from legal procedures the Argentine Government must take. The sanctions were to have been lifted at midnight Monday, London time, according to the original Treasury announcement, issued early in the day.) **********Julio Gonzalez del Solar, president of Argentina's central bank, said in an interview: ''We are studying the British suggestions with the utmost interest. It would ease our dealings with the international banks and be alleviation for them, too.'' **********A particular snag, he said, consists of complications involving Argentine laws on ending the restrictions. Most of them were established by presidential decree and may have to be ended the same way. **********Lifting the financial sanctions, however, would not affect the trade embargoes still in effect between Britain and Argentina, Buenos Aires officials said. Diplomatic relations between the two countries also remain broken. **********The Economics Ministry statement tied a move to end the trade sanctions to Argentina's aspirations to obtain sovereignty over the Falklands, saying that ending the sanctions ''would create better conditions for negotiations'' in the coming United Nations debate over the islands. **********Officials of Argentina had promised in the past that they would use the frozen funds in Britain to repay their British loans, but there were no statements here or in London today as to whether such a repayment was still planned. **********In addition to its British debt, Argentina has been in danger of default on much of its nearly $40 billion in total foreign debt, much of it short-term. Argentina is already $2 billion behind on its payments to all its creditors and is scheduled to repay $12 billion by the end of the year. **********The administration of President Reynaldo B. Bignone has been trying to refinance some of the short-term debt and has opened negotiations with the International Monetary Fund for a possible standby loan.  But international banks and the I.M.F. have been reluctant to lend Argentina money until the financial dispute with Britain is settled. **********In a related development, the Argentine Government today announced it was imposing price controls on industrial products and was devaluing the peso's commercial exchange rate by 5 percent. The commercial rate covers imports and export transactions, and the devaluation raises the rate for these transactions from 25,570 pesos to the dollar to 26,850. **********The devaluation also requires importers and exporters to carry out 15 percent of their transactions at the exchange rate in the financial market, which is 39,000 pesos to the dollar. The effective devaluation of the commercial exchange rate thus averages 12.1 percent. **********The move was intended to spur exports and is a step toward unifying the country's diverse exchange rates. It is a move also favored by the International Monetary Fund, but officials here declared they were not trying to court I.M.F. favor for a standby loan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/23/busin.main_headline: Commodities; Selling Silver Bars To Public
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/23/busin.print_headline: Commodities; Selling Silver Bars To Public
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/23/busin.body_text: **********THERE were two ways of looking at last week's surge in the price of silver bullion, which raised the metal by $1.535 an ounce, to $7.78, based on Friday's close of the spot August Comex futures contract. **********One view was that silver was now back to its price of late 1981, when it was still falling from its record level of $50.30, set Jan.  21, 1980. **********The other view was that silver took off from that level in the fall of 1979 and didn't stop climbing until it reached its record price.  While not even the most courageous silver bull today thinks the metal will cross the $50 mark in the foreseeable future, two of the major houses in the precious metals industry believe there are enough sound reasons why the metal should interest investors. **********They are Handy & Harman, a leading fabricator of silver and other precious metals, and J. Aron & Company, the giant commodities brokerage house acquired last year by Goldman, Sachs & Company, investment bankers. This Wednesday, J. Aron will start marketing silver bullion made by Handy & Harman to the public through banks, brokerage houses and other retail dealers for the first time. **********More important, J. Aron promises to create a highly liquid two-way market in their bars in which the buy-sell spread would be narrower than is commonly the case in precious metals bars, the company said. **********Given the fact that a number of their competitors, such as the Engelhard Corporation, the Mocatta Metals Corporation and Johnson & Matthey, also offer silver bullion, what prompted the Handy & Harman-J. Aron entry into this market at this time? **********The question was first addressed to M.H. Townsend, chairman of Handy & Harman, who said last week: ''Until a few months ago, we thought the 1979-80 boom and bust in silver had ended the public's interest in the metal as an investment for a long time. Then we became aware that there was once again a rising demand for silver from all kinds of people.'' **********Renewed interest in silver bullion began mounting after its price dropped to a recent low of $4.24 an ounce last June 21 and grew substantially as interest rates began to fall soon afterward. **********While falling interest rates made it less expensive for the trade to carry inventories, it also encouraged buying by ordinary investors. Why? The yields on competitive investments such as money market funds, Treasury bills and various bank certificates of deposit became less attractive. Indeed, it was the high yields on short-term investments as much as anything else that had tarnished the appeal of precious metals. **********This factor, combined with the recent string of insolvencies among a number of financial institutions and fears that others will be adversely affected by their inability to recover huge loans made to Mexico and other foreign countries, has once again prompted many investors to look upon precious metals as a financial security blanket. **********But Mr. Townsend noted, ''We also were aware that we had no expertise in dealing directly with the public. Since our company was founded in 1867, it has basically been a fabricator of silver in many forms to the manufacturing trade. We couldn't see ourselves dealing with hundreds, perhaps thousands, of banks, brokerage houses, coin shops and other potential outlets.'' **********Robert E. Burke, Handy & Harman's vice president-marketing, joined in: ''It then ocurred to us that J. Aron, with whom we have been doing business for many years, had the distribution expertise we lacked because they deal in all sorts of commodities. While J. Aron doesn't deal with the public, they are well connected with banks, brokers and other who do.'' **********At J. Aron, Morris A. Sandler, vice president, described his house's part in the new venture: ''First off, we will only deal in bars of 100 troy ounces that are .999 fine, the top grade in the trade. Buyers of smaller bars usually pay higher premiums in percentage terms. We expect our markup to be about 3.5 percent above the daily Handy & Harman quote, which is the standard in the silver market. The brokerage houses that will retail the bars, such as Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith and Shearson/American Express, will charge a fee that should be competitive. We expect many other brokerage houses to carry our bars, as well as banks all across the nation.'' **********Mr. Sandler added that buyers need not take physical delivery of the seven-pound bars from the retailers, but instead could have them stored in vaults in Delaware, which would save on sales taxes. **********Herbert J. Coyne, J. Aron's chairman, said that, ''while nobody knows how much silver was being held privately, Delaware depositories were believed to hold almost as much of the metal as West Point.'' **********The vaults at the military academy hold most of the Government's stockpile of 139.5 million ounces. The rest is at the San Francisco mint. More important to investors and traders has been the steady drop in exchange-licensed warehouse stocks of the metal since last March, when investors began to re-enter the market. **********Last March 1, the combined stocks at the three key markets - New York's Commodity Exchange, the London Metals Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade - totaled 128.4 million ounces, of which 78.3 million were at the Comex. By Aug. 9, the total stocks, in rounded figures, had dropped to 114.4 million and last Monday they stood at 111.5 million. Of that amount, 61 million were in Comex-licensed warehouses, 36.6 million in London, and 13.8 million at the Chicago Board of Trade's warehouses.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/20/world.main_headline: GEMAYEL ASKS U.S. TO WEIGH INCREASE IN PEACE UNIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/20/world.print_headline: GEMAYEL ASKS U.S. TO WEIGH INCREASE IN PEACE UNIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/20/world.body_text: **********President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon asked President Reagan today to consider expanding the size and scope of the international peacekeeping force in Lebanon to help bring about an early withdrawal of Israeli, Syrian and Palestinian forces, a senior State Department official said. **********Mr. Reagan, according to the official, agreed to give ''serious consideration'' to the request, which could lead to an increase in the number of American marines assigned to the force of American, French and Italian troops. The combined force now numbers 3,400 men. **********Although the two-hour session at the White House and a later meeting involving senior aides were described as having gone well, there was no optimism at the end of the day among American officials that there would be a rapid solution to Lebanon's problems. 'Difficult Negotiation' Foreseen **********Reporters were told by the senior State Department aide that large problems lay ahead in trying to work out a formula for ending the Israeli, Syrian and Palestinian military presence in Lebanon. **********Taking into consideration not only the talks with Mr. Gemayel, but last week's discussions here with Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel, and talks held in Damascus with Syrian officials, the official said, ''It will be a very difficult and complicated negotiation.'' **********He reaffirmed that the United States would play a central role in trying to find an acceptable formula, and that it would stick to a target date of the end of this year. But it seemed that the differences among the parties had been sharpened by Mr. Gemayel's visit, rather than diminished. Israelis Want Security Pact **********These are the main problems, as outlined by officials at the end of the day: **********- The Israelis are insisting on signing a ''security agreement'' with Lebanon as a first step toward a peace treaty, as a condition for the withdrawal of their forces from all of Lebanon. Mr. Gemayel indicated to the United States today that he would have ''a serious problem'' signing not only a peace treaty but also a security agreement with Israel, because this would cause him trouble with other Arab nations.  He is counting on the Arabs to provide Lebanon with billions of dollars in reconstruction aid. **********- There is no consensus on how to bring about the withdrawal. The Syrians, who have 30,000 troops in Lebanon at the request of the Arab League, say they will withdraw but only after Israel, an ''invader,'' pulls its troops back. Israel demands that the Palestine Liberation Organization's 8,000 troops leave first, with Syria and Israel to pull their troops out simultaneously after the proposed security agreement with Lebanon is signed. The P.L.O. has not said when it wants to depart. **********- The Israelis want no international peacekeeping force in southern Lebanon, only Lebanese forces. But the Lebanese made clear today that they did not believe their army was able to deploy itself around the country now. They would prefer that a combination of the 7,000-man United Nations force and an expanded American-French-Italian force assume larger responsibiities, not only in the south but in other parts of Lebanon as well. Differing Perceptions **********At the root of the problem, the senior American official acknowledged, is the different perceptions that Israel and Lebanon have of each other. **********The Israelis, he said, believe that by their defeat of the P.L.O.  and Syria they have given the Lebanese Government a chance, for the first time in seven years, to unify the country. They want, he said, to cooperate openly with Mr. Gemayel's Government - in effect, to be regarded as ''liberators'' of Lebanon. **********But Mr. Gemayel left the impression with the Americans that while the Lebanese at one time may have appreciated the Israeli actions, they now increasingly regard the Israelis as ''occupiers'' and do not want to be seen signing any agreements with Israel, the official said. **********According to the State Department official who briefed reporters after this morning's two-hour meeting at the White House of the two Presidents and their top aides, Mr. Gemayel ''raised the possibility of an expanded role and expanded force'' for the American, French and Italian troops. Mr. Gemayel said he hoped that these forces would remain in Lebanon until the last Israeli, Syrian and Palestinian fighter was withdrawn. Response by Reagan **********Mr. Reagan responded, the official said, by saying, in effect, ''We hear you, we appreciate that our troops are so well received, that you believe they are so important, and all these matters will have to be given serious consideration.'' **********No specific numbers were discussed, the official said, but other Lebanese have asked that the three-nation force be raised from 3,400 men to as many as 20,000. An American official said there was no specific request that the United States contingent be enlarged. But if there is to be an increase in the total strength, the American force would almost inevitably have to be raised from its current 1,200 marines, officials said. **********In the talks today, there was discussion about expanding the role of the three-nation force beyond its limited assignment in Beirut.  The American marines are currently restricted to the international airport. There was discussion, officials said, of the force's assuming a role in the Bekaa Valley, in eastern and northern Lebanon, where Syrian and Palestinian forces are situated, and in the south, where the Israelis are. Pullout Called 'Shared Objective' **********Mr. Gemayel, in his remarks to the press after meeting Mr. Reagan, said he was committed ''to the immediate removal of all foreign forces from our soil and to work hand in hand with all sectors of Lebanese society to build a nation in which all citizens have equal privileges, rights and responsibilities.'' **********Mr. Reagan said that the ''particular focus'' of the talks was on ''our shared objective of prompt withdrawal of all foreign forces from Lebanon.'' **********There was considerable discussion during the day of Lebanon's need for large-scale help in rebuilding the country and its economy. Some Lebanese have talked of a need for as much as $10 billion to $15 billion. **********But the United States, committed at present to about $100 million in the current fiscal year, has no intention of initiating a largescale aid program of its own, the senior official said, and this is recognized by the Lebanese. Rather, they will be helped primarily by the World Bank, to which the United States will contribute, and by Saudi Arabian and other Middle Eastern investors, including Lebanese.  Reconstruction Discussed **********Mr. Gemayel met this afternoon with A.W. Clausen, president of the World Bank, and they discussed the role the bank would play in the reconstruction effort. A World Bank spokesman said it was agreed that as a first step a mission would be sent to Lebanon next month to ''identify the needs and map out the assistance process.'' **********Later, Mr. Gemayel - the first Lebanese President to make an official visit to the United States - conferred with Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger on future American military assistance to Lebanon. A Pentagon team has just returned from a survey trip and is drawing up its report. **********Mr. Gemayel was said to have assured the Americans that his Government was making efforts to insure security for every person in Lebanon. He defended the recent crackdown in West Beirut as necessary to eradicate ''terrorism,'' which he said was ''a cancer'' in the Middle East, a senior official said. **********Gemayel Leaves U.S. **********WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP)-President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon left Washington for Paris tonight after a two-day visit to the United States.

In Belfast, which apparently suffered the worst violence, a police spokesman said rioters pelted officers with gasoline bombs, attacked the central police station and gutted a factory and restaurant.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/02/world.body_text: **********The legal basis of United States support for Britain in the dispute with Argentina over the Falkland Islands was touched upon though not spelled out Friday by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. But legal experts said that international law appeared to justify the action. **********Argentina's military occupation of the Falklands on April 2 - a move to enforce its longstanding claim to sovereignty over islands that have been British dependencies - was an apparent violation of a United Nations Charter provision prohibiting the use of force to resolve territorial disputes, according to one legal scholar. **********The scholar, a professor of international law, said that under the 1945 United Nations Charter Britain had the right to defend the islands and Argentina had the obligation to bring its claim to the islands before international authorities before using force. **********The charter also would seem to impose a general obligation on all 160 signatory nations to come to the aid of a victim of aggression.  This would appear to be the primary basis, in the present crisis, for United States support of Britain, the scholar said. **********The 1949 North Atlantic Treaty limited the obligation of NATO signatories to mutual defense against aggressive attacks in Europe or North America, but some legal experts said the spirit if not the letter of that pact also supported the United States decision. **********Britain has not appealed to the United Nations in the Falklands dispute, and neither the Security Council nor the General Assembly has invoked action to resolve it. ''But even if nothing has been said,'' one scholar noted, ''the parties to a treaty are obliged to see that its terms are upheld.'' **********Argentina's claim to the Falklands, the scholar said, ''doesn't justify the use of force'' under the United Nations Charter. ''Peace is the primary concern,'' he said. ''In this view, peace is more important than justice.'' **********Until Friday, the United States had been officially neutral. In announcing support for Britain and military and economic sanctions against Argentina, Mr. Haig noted Argentina's ''failure to accept a compromise,'' and added, ''we must take concrete steps to underscore that the United States cannot and will not condone the use of unlawful force to resolve disputes.''
