https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/19/busin.body_text: **********The Federal National Mortgage Association, the nation's largest purchaser of home loans, yesterday reported from Washington a fourth-quarter loss of $70.7 million, or $1.20 a share, in contrast to net income of $700,000, or 1 cent a share, in the fourth quarter of 1980. The loss was attributed to the high cost of funds. **********For all of 1981, Fannie Mae, as it is popularly known, reported a loss of $190.4 million, its first yearly loss ever. The comapny earned $14.2 million, or 23 cents a share, in 1980. **********The 1981 results include a previously reported reduction in the allowance and provision for conventional loan losses. Excluding these reductions, the 1981 loss would have been $217 million. Rising Short-Term Rates **********Since short-term interest rates have risen well above the yields on the mortgages it holds, Fannie Mae, along with many thrift institutions, has been paying more for its money to purchase mortgages than it has been earning on its portfolio. **********The company, which is Government-sponsored and whose shares are traded on the New York Stock Exchange, said it issued $9.3 billion in commitments to purchase residential mortgages last year, up from $8.1 billion in 1980, and purchased $6.1 billion, down from $8.1 billion. Fannie Mae has more than $60 billion in assets. **********Commitment fee income for 1981 rose to $112.6 million from $58.6 million in 1980. Fee income was $57.8 million in the fourth quarter, up from $31.9 million in the previous quarter and $10.8 million in the fourth quarter of 1980.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/10/busin.body_text: **********Armco Inc. said yesterday that it had delayed indefinitely a $671 million expansion of its facilities to manufacture steel pipe and tubing for the oil and gas industry. **********This decision against adding 450,000 tons of new capacity ''until we are confident that economic conditions will warrant resumption'' is further evidence that the boom market for oil industry pipe and tubing, needed mostly for exploration, has slowed considerably in recent months as oil prices have fallen. Armco accounted for about 6 percent of the 4.2 million tons of steel pipe and tubing shipped by the domestic steel industry in 1981. **********Armco's expansion program, which would have been completed in 1984, consisted of $343 million for a new finishing facility at Gulfport, Miss.; $290 million for a pipe plant at Ashland, Ky., and the rest for additional investment in an existing plant at Ambridge, Pa. 'Market That Is Declining' **********''They are looking at a market that is declining and at the very high cost of money,'' commented Peter Marcus, an analyst with Paine Webber Mitchell Hutchins. ''It's a very high-risk, single-product outlay.'' **********Scott Aiken, an Armco spokesman, said the expansion was being postponed because of poor economic conditions. He added that Armco -the nation's fourth-largest steel producer, after U.S. Steel, Bethlehem and the Jones & Laughlin subsidiary of LTV - was also reviewing the rest of its $560 million capital investment program. **********''Everything is under continual review now,'' he said, adding that the company's steel operations were using only about 60 percent of capacity because the demand for steel in general has declined during the current recession. How Market Has Grown **********Since 1979 the market for pipe and tubing has grown more than 75 percent as rising oil prices stimulated exploration. In the last year this segment of the business was responsible for the profitablity of the steel industry. Since the price of oil and gas has weakened, however, oil companies have started to use the pipe they already have rather than purchase additional supplies. **********Most analysts estimate that shipments of pipe and tubing in 1982 will decline as much as 25 percent.  Construction of Armco's proposed plants was scheduled to begin in April. Mr. Aiken said that some site work and engineering had started and that the engineering work would continue. **********The only other major expansion in sight for pipe and tubing is a $650 million project planned by the United States Steel Corporation.  That program is being financed by the oil companies that would purchase the products. A spokesman for U.S. Steel said yesterday that its expansion project was proceeding without delay. **********In yesterday's announcement, Armco said it would go ahead with a $90 million outlay for a continuous caster at its Ashland plant.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/11/busin.main_headline: LAKER HINTS AT A NEW AIRLINE VENTURE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/11/busin.print_headline: LAKER HINTS AT A NEW AIRLINE VENTURE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/11/busin.body_text: **********Sir Freddie Laker all but announced plans today for a new cut-rate service even as his Laker Airways empire began to break apart. **********A formal announcement was expected as soon as Thursday of a fresh effort, perhaps to begin a ''People's Skytrain,'' a slimmed-down version of the no-frills, low-cost service Sir Freddie introduced in 1977. **********Since the shutdown last Friday of Laker, burdened with $359 million in debts, Britain has witnessed an outpouring of popular support and emotion on behalf of Sir Freddie. Most notably, some $6 million in mostly small contributions has poured in from dismayed supporters. **********''There's no doubt about it; Sir Freddie wouldn't say anything like this unless he is 100 percent certain,'' a Laker spokesman said. ''I understand that Sir Freddie is hoping to be able to announce details tomorrow.'' Charter Businesses Sold **********The success of a new venture by Sir Freddie, who is 59 years old, is likely to depend on his ability to persuade financial backers that such an enterprise could succeed. It also did not appear that there were any legal obstacles to starting a business so soon after the Laker bankruptcy. Tonight, Sir Freddie was reported discussing possible financial support with Roland Rowland, chief executive of Lonrho Ltd., a British mining conglomerate. **********In a move that saved an estimated 322 jobs, Sir Freddie today sold his two holiday charter businesses for $8.4 million. Arrowsmith Holidays was sold to Greenall Whitley, a 200-year-old British Brewery, for $7.5 million, while Laker Air Tours went for $930,000 to Saga Holidays, an English company specializing in holiday charters for the elderly. **********The two new owners were quickly given approval by Britain' s Civil Aviation Authority to begin operations. British officials have been eager to keep the tour companies in operation to prevent losses by vacationers of prepayments. **********As for a new airline, sources close to Sir Freddie said today that he believed the venture could start within a month on four American routes, to New York, Los Angeles, Miami and Tampa. Using Laker Equipment **********A new service would reportedly use at least four of the 11 groundedLaker DC-10's and up to half of Laker Airways' more than 2,000 staff members. The effort to start an airline would involve raising enough money to buy these aircraft from Laker creditors.  Laker also owns three Airbuses, four BAC-111's and two Bo eing 707's. **********However, some experts, noting the large losses being made on trans-Atlantic routes by all carriers, predicted that Sir Freddie's new venture might be forced to focus on charters and tours, a more profitable business. **********Sir Freddie himself was silent today and reported to be meeting with financie rs in an effort to raise needed money. In addition, Sir Freddie would have to persuade civil aviation authorities here to transfer the necessary licenses to his new venture. **********''I can't say anything officially but these things are obviously not far from Sir Freddie's mind,'' said Mrs. Robyn Flood, the Laker publicity manager. ''Freddie fought for 12 years to get these licenses and he is not going to let them go,'' she said. Role of Contributions **********In part, Sir Freddie's new business would be supported by the contributions, many of which have been going to a ''Freddie Friendly Fund'' organized by Kay Hardy, a Sussex hotel owner, and Colin Raworth, a West London shopkeeper. Britons by the hundreds have been dropping into branches across the country of Lloyds Bank, where the fund's account has been opened. **********Because of potential legal complications, Sir Freddie has appealed to the public to delay donations until a proposal is developed. ''I do not know as yet the amount of support which any new venture may require and because of that, I would ask that no further contributions be sent in for the time being,'' he said Tuesday night. **********Laker employees, whose jobs are in jeopardy, have also been active. On Monday, several busloads of nattily dressed flight attendants and other staff members demonstrated outside 10 Downing Street, the office and residence of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who has refused Government aid to Sir Freddie. **********''The decision not to provide state funds for Sir Freddie was for the sake of the future of private enterprise,'' said Cecil Parkinson, chairman of Britain's Conservative Party, in a speech today. ''Far from helping the private sector thrive and flourish, a state handout would have been greatly damaging to the morale and spirit of entrepreneurs up and down the country.'' **********Today, six of Sir Freddie's grounded flight attendants announced that profits from a record they made this week as ''the Laker Girls'' would be given to the fund. The record is called ''Let Us Fly.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/03/busin.main_headline: September Orders Up By 0.7%; Durables Drop; Inventories Off
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/03/busin.print_headline: September Orders Up By 0.7%; Durables Drop; Inventories Off
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/03/busin.body_text: **********New orders for the manufactured goods of American companies rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in September, the Commerce Department reported today. **********While the gain was seen as too modest to indicate any major shift in the economy, the factory orders are considered a leading indicator of the direction of the economy because they are likely to be translated into later production and, theoretically, into sales. **********The advance from August's revised 2.7 percent decline was concentrated in orders for nondurable goods such as food- and oilrelated products, with orders declining for durable goods such as cars, the report said. **********'Somewhat of a Mixed Bag' **********''It's still somewhat of a mixed bag,'' Robert Ortner, the Commerce Department's chief economist, said of today's report, ''but it's a heck of a lot better than the uniformly poor reports we were getting earlier this year.'' **********In September, the orders report said, manufacturers' inventories of unsold goods dropped eight-tenths of 1 percent, to $272.2 billion, the ninth drop in the last 10 months and the biggest decline since May, with the decrease again mainly in nondurables. **********If manufacturers were expecting a substantial recovery from the recession, they might be expected to be starting to build up inventories rather than continuing to whittle them down. However, Mr. Ortner said, ''I suppose business firms are not yet persuaded that it's wise to carry larger inventories.'' Increase to $155.5 Billion **********In all, the report said, orders rose to a seasonally adjusted $155.5 billion in September. Orders for nondurable goods rose 1.5 percent, to $82.6 billion, including a 3.8 percent gain for petroleum products and a 3.1 percent increase for food products. **********Orders for durable goods declined one-tenth of 1 percent, pulled down by a 20.2 percent decline in orders for military goods. Without that negative impact, orders for durables would have risen 1.5 percent. **********Mr. Ortner said the decline for durables should be considered significant for the overall economy only if one expected military orders to remain down - an unlikely prospect in light of the Reagan Administration's efforts to increase military spending. **********Orders for nondefense capital goods, including heavy machinery, were up 4.7 percent for the month, and Mr. Ortner said that this ''possibly is the first step'' toward a recovery in business investment in general later on. Favorable Factors Cited **********''The orders are at a relatively low level and we need further increases,'' he added. He would not predict that such increases would come every month from now on, but he did say that ''the drop in interest rates and the run-up in the stock market are favorable developments.'' **********The report included these other details: **********- Total shipments declined less than one-tenth of 1 percent, to $158.6 billion, leaving the ratio of inventories to shipments at 1.72, down from 1.73 in August. **********- The decrease in orders for durables included declines of 10.3 percent in transportation equipment - mostly airplanes, autos and parts - and 3.1 percent for primary metals such as steel. There was a gain of 6 percent for nonelectrical machinery and one of 4.4 percent for electrical machinery. **********- August's 2.7 percent drop in orders was revised slightly from the 2.8 percent estimated a month ago.  The new figures are also subject to later revision.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/16/busin.body_text: **********Almost seven years after Congress mandated a national securities market, Wall Street is gearing up for the first crucial test of that system. But the experiment is drawing stiff opposition from brokers, who say that the new system may cut sharply into their profit margins. **********The system, developed by the National Association of Securities Dealers and scheduled to begin March 1, allows the automatic execution of over-the-counter stock transactions. It will be linked with the current Intermarket Trading System, which routes orders among the New York, American and several regional exchanges. **********In addition, firms trading in certain O-T-C stocks will be subject to a new transaction-reporting method that, among other things, requires them to report price and volume information on trades almost immediately. **********But the system has garnered sharply critical reviews from brokerdealers, and because of its technical complexity, N.A.S.D.  officials concede its initial run may even be delayed past the March 1, deadline. **********''Many of the traders are highly upset by this development because they feel picked upon,'' said John McCarthy, manager of the O-T-C trading department at Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc., **********''We still don't have a national market system, as Congress intended - a good system where all orders could be executed in a simple place.'' **********Peter J. DaPuzzo, executive vice president in charge of O-T-C trading at Shearson-American Express Company, was more emphatic: ''I see this as the beginning of the end of the way we do our business.'' **********The new system will begin reporting on 43 O-T-C, including such well-known issues as Apple Computer, MCI Communications, Pabst Brewing and Tandem Computers. Firms trading in these issues will be required to report the price and volume of each transaction within 90 seconds of execution. **********As a result, data on the most recent sales price and volume, highs and lows and cumulative volume will be available throughout the day.  And instead of the current practice of publishing the best bid and ask prices, newspaper stock tables will include high, low and actual closing prices. **********The primary complaint among broker-dealers are the new reporting requirements. Currently, traders in the over-the-counter market tally their volume at the end of the day and report only the best bid and ask offers. But the new system requires that they report each trade, thus exposing their trading activities to competitors and customers. **********Disclosing such vital information would disrupt their business, say traders, because they do not charge commissions. Instead, they make money on the difference between bid and ask prices - a spread that can be measured in fractions for active stocks or can run to several points for seldom-traded issues. **********At Merrill Lynch, for example, Mr. McCarthy predicts that the firm will be forced to increase its clerical staff in order to comply with the new reporting requirements. **********Perhaps more important, Mr. McCarthy said, the firm's traders will be spending considerably more time in monitoring price and volume movements in stocks they make markets in and those of their competitors. **********''We're going to either have to find more people to trade our stocks, or drop some of them,'' Mr. McCarthy said.  Another complaint is that the new system does not provide any method of insuring that a ''limit-order'' entered with one broker will be executed if a trigger price is reached with another broker.  Limit orders are left by customers with brokers or an exchange specialist to be executed when a stock's price reaches a certain level. **********The Securities and Exchange Commission has recommended that the nation's stock market's develop a ''central file'' that would electronically pool and display limit orders from all markets. But the new system fails to address this problem, traders say. **********James B. Raphalian, senior vice president and manager of the O-T-C trading department at Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis, said the lack of a systematic limit order system may prove detrimental to investors: ''When a limit order is already in the market, and a stock trades at a discount or premium, how is the investor going to be protected? What is the moral obligation of the person who has it?,'' Mr. Raphalian, said. He added, ''No one would say that the system is no good, the point is that it's premature as far as having any of the bugs worked out.'' **********Gordon Macklin, president of the N.A.S.D., the self-regulatory organization developing the new system, concedes that considerable discontent exists among many brokers. **********''It's always difficult to find anyone intersted in buying new equipment and changing their way of doing business, and given this, you have a very uneasy environment,'' Mr. Macklin said, adding, ''it would be very hard to fault any of the individuals in this controversey, because they're doing what they do best -representing their economic interests. Remember, we're not building a hospital or charitable institution here.'' **********The S.E.C. is closely monitoring the progress of the new system because it will be the most comprehensive test so far of the effect of dropping restrictions on trading exchange-listed stocks away from exchange floors. Those restrictions are viewed by many as the primary obstacle to a national market system for securities that Congress mandated in 1975. **********The national market idea, first conceived by the S.E.C. more than a decade ago, envisions a nationwide system that would permit all investors and their brokers to execute instant trades in whatever market offers the best price for a particular security.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/10/world.main_headline: BRITONS STAGE NEW LANDING BUT THE COST IS CALLED HIGH
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/10/world.print_headline: BRITONS STAGE NEW LANDING BUT THE COST IS CALLED HIGH
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/10/world.body_text: **********British troops have staged a major new landing in the Falkland Islands but have suffered heavily in the process, correspondents' reports and military sources said tonight. **********A sizable force has been established at Fitzroy and at Bluff Cove, 12 miles southwest of Stanley, the Ministry of Defense reported. It said that at least 6 and possibly as many as 11 of the Argentine warplanes involved in trying to disrupt the landing were shot down.  They were reportedly intercepted and hit by Harrier jump-jets. **********In disclosing sketchy details of the action on Tuesday, the ministry said that the 2,800-ton frigate Plymouth and two 5,674-ton landing ships, the Sir Tristram and the Sir Galahad, had been damaged by enemy bombs, with five British troops suffering wounds. Much Darker Picture **********But a dispatch from Michael Nicholson of Independent Television News, who witnessed one Argentine attack painted a much darker picture. The Sir Galahad burst into flames, with black smoke pouring from her hold, he said, after ammunition boxes and fuel tanks blew up. He said a large number of British casualties had been incurred, with many men burned, and indicated that the ship had been abandoned. **********Another report suggested that the casualties were worse than those suffered in the sinking of the destroyer Sheffield on May 4, in which 20 men were killed and 24 hurt. **********Tonight military sources said that the Sir Galahad had probably sunk, and the Defense Ministry confirmed that casualties had been minor in air attacks at Lively Island and in Falkland Sound but "much heavier" in the raid off Fitzroy. The two landing ships were hit off Fitzroy and the Plymouth was hit in the sound, farther west. Argentina Assertions Denied **********The ministry strenuously denied Argentine assterions that the Plymouth had been sunk. **********It was not clear whether the losses would delay the long-awaited attack on Stanley, but senior officers conceded that Tuesday's attack was clear evidence that Britian had not yet established full air superiority. The shortcoming could complicate that battle for the capital, analysts believe. **********In a television interview, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said it was "almost impossible" to say when the British attack on Stanley would come. But she added that she hoped the assault on the Falkland capital, where about 7,000 Argentina troops are surrounded by the British, would not be "too distant." **********"The time when the military commander moves is up to him," she said. "He is there. He knows the positions. He knows exactly how much he has to move before he makes the final assault. We can't fight a battle around the Cabinet table. He must fight it on the spot." **********Mrs. Thatcher repeated her assertion that a quick and honorable surrender of the Argentine garrison could easily be arranged, and that only such a surrender could prevent a battle for Stanley.  Despite her past offers, she said, she had seen "no sign whatever" that the enemy commander, Brig. Mario Menedez, was interested. **********In another development, the Denfense Ministry said that the Americanowned supertanker Hercules, hit by a bomb in the South Atlantic on Tuesday, had been ordered in a radio message moments earlier to head for and Argentine port. If it did not, the message said, "you will be attacked in 15 minutes." **********The message, the minisry said, was preceded by the call sign of an Argentine radio station, believed to be in Ushuaia, and was addressed specifically to the Hercules, using her call sign. It was repeated for 13 minutes over an international distress frequency, according to the ministry spokesman, Ian McDonald, and was monitored by the British hospital ships Uganda and Hecla, which were operating at the time in the same area, about 500 miles northeast of the Falklands. **********In a telex message to the ship's Italian agents, the 220,117-ton tanker's master said none of his 28 crew members had been hurt. He reported that the ship had been attacked twice and had been "slightly damaged" by a bomb dropped in the first of the attacks fromwhat was described as a high-winged, four-engine, propellor-driven aircraft. **********The only planes known to be involved in the Falkland conflict that meet that description are Argentine C-130 transports, one of which dropped a bomb on a British tanker on June 2 without causing much damage. **********Information released during the night by the Defense Ministry, amplified by on-the-spot reports today, considerably altered previous assumptions about British troop movements. It had been thought, on the basis of background briefings by military officers here, that most of the Fifth Brigade had arrived in the mountains just west of Stanley. **********It had also been thought that the Second parachute Battalion, which took Darwin and Goose Green, had moved rapidly on to Fitzroy and Bluff Cove, a pair of small settlements on the southern track across the upper part of East Falkland. **********In fact, today's developments make clear, most of the 3,500 men of the Fifth Brigade who began coming ashore at San Carlos Bay remained there, with some Grukha units moving into the interior of the island and others reaching Mount Kent, the forward base near Stanley. Most of the Paratroopers remained at Darwin and Goose Green, patrolling. **********Late last week, an advance force of the Fifth Brigade moved out along the southern track. Last Saturday, from Swan Inlet, about halfway to the capital, the brigade commander, Brig. Tony Wilson, made a telephone call from a public booth, dropping a British 50-pence coin into the slot. He called a house in Fitzroy as a longshot, and to his astonishment a Falklander named Reg Binney answered. The brigadier asked whether any Argentine troops were there. **********"Yes," answered Mr. Binney, "but they're not her today." **********"I think I'll join you then," Brigadier Wilson told him. **********"That seems a good idea," came the reply. "You'd be welcome." Vital Bridge Seized **********The commander called on the helicopters to ferry some of his men from Port San Carlos to Fitzroy. They seized the vital wooden bridge across the Fitzroy River, which had been damaged by retreating Argentines. **********Others were flown to Lively Island, south of Choiseul Sound, and loaded there into landing ships for an amphibious invasion near Fitzroy and Goose Green to conserve time. Meanwhile, the Ghurkas, armed with kukri knives as well as rifles, moved along the ridge above the new beachhead, silently attacking enemy observation posts. **********It was this operation, not a series of commando raids, as believed then, to which Mr. Nicholson was referring on Monday when he spoke of "extraordinarily daring" activities. And it was this operation that was interrupted by Tuesday's Argentine air raids.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/20/world.body_text: **********Twenty-two children fathered by Americans during the Indochina war arrived in Hong Kong today.  The children are the third such group to be flown from Vietnam for homes in the United States this year. **********Their travel arrangements were speeded up so they could be home for Christmas. **********''I don't think they really know very much about what Christmas is about,'' said George Wagner, a refugee official accompanying the youngsters and 12 relatives allowed out of Vietnam. **********The children, aged from 8 to 16, left Ho Chi Minh City Thursday for Bangkok and stayed at a refugee camp southeast of the Thai capital. **********The Hanoi Government has scheduled another flight for Jan. 27, which it said was timed with Tet, Vietnam's Lunar New Year celebration.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/19/busin.body_text: **********Interest rates rose slightly in quiet trading yesterday, as securities dealers tried to reduce inventories at a time of modest investor demand and high financing costs. **********The increase in rates came in the afternoon, and quickly reversed earlier declines. The rate for three-month Treasury bills, for example, was 12.65 percent early in the day, but rose to 12.86 percent by closing. In the long bond market, the 14 percent Treasury issue due 2011 closed at about 103 1/2 to yield 13.5 percent compared with 104 17/32 around midday. **********''The volatility of the market has scared a lot of people, who just don't want to do anything while prices jump around,'' said one institutional salesman at a government securities firm. While yesterday's fluctuations were mild compared with the most hectic trading sessions, dealers said price changes could easily have been much greater because trading volume was so light. In the past six weeks the 14 percent Treasury bond has fluctuated between 94 3/4 on Feb. 10 and 105 on March 5. 10.61% for Certificates **********Among new issues, the Treasury sold $5.25 billion of new one-year bills at an average rate of 12.509 percent, which later rose to 12.66 percent in trading after the auction. Based on the bill sale, new one-year tax-exempt savings certificates may be offered starting Sunday at a yield of 10.16 percent, down from 10.79 percent since Feb. 21. The 14 1/8 percent Treasury notes due in two years were offered at 99 22/32 to yield 14.27 percent compared with an average of 14.14 percent at Wednesday's auction. **********Amid conflicting predictions about the course of the economy, credit demands, and money supply, many market participants said they preferred to wait on the sidelines until they were more confident about the direction of interest rates. **********For example, Donald L. Raiff, vice president at the Northern Trust Company, Chicago, said he expected short rates to fall two or three percentage points in the next three of four months, but added that ''this is one of those times when you want a balanced position in the market before the Fed's Friday money supply announcement.'' **********In such an uncertain environment, analysts said the cost of financing inventories was an important reason for lower prices yesterday. Overnight repurchase agreements - which are an important way securities firms borrow - cost about 14 1/4 percent using Treasury issues as collateral, a level where financing costs exceeded yields on issues held in inventory. Overnight Rate **********The cost of financing inventories is closly related to the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market, which was at 14 7/8 percent most of the day. That rate was higher than many dealers expected, and contributed to the drop in prices. **********In the tax-exempt market, a $60 million issue of Aa-rated Sacramento, Calif., Municipal Utility District electric revenue bonds was offered by a Blyth Eastman Paine Webber group at yields ranging from 8.25 percent in 1983 to 11 percent in 1992 and slightly more than 12 percent in 2002. **********Because California issues have special appeal to California investors, underwriters said the Sacramento ''muds'' could be sold with yields considerably lower than other like rated electric revenue bonds of issuers outside the state. For example, earlier this month an Aa-rated issue of San Antonio electric revenue bonds was publicly offered with a 13.5 percent yield for bonds due 2001, and in secondary market trading since then the yield has increased slightly. **********Following are results of yesterday's auction of new one-year Treasury bills:

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/02/busin.main_headline: TRANSAMERICA TO BUY FRED S. JAMES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/02/busin.print_headline: TRANSAMERICA TO BUY FRED S. JAMES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/02/busin.body_text: **********The Transamerica Corporation, one of the nation's leading insurance companies, has signed an agreement to buy Fred S. James & Company, the big insurance broker, for about $300 million, both said yesterday. **********Terms call for Transamerica -owner of the Transamerica Occidental Life Insurance Company, Budget Rent-a-Car and Transamerica Airlines - to offer shareholders $33.50 a share for James's roughly nine million shares outstanding. **********Analysts said the move could spur interest among other big financial service concerns, such as Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Sears, Roebuck and American Express, to move into the insurance brokerage business. **********Word of a bid for James spread through Wall Street last week, with the stock spurting $2.375 a share, to $27.50, just before 11 A.M.  last Friday, when James halted trading in its stock pending an announcement. Reports had spread that both Sears and Merrill Lynch were buying the company. **********After the official announcement that Transamerica was the buyer, James ended the day at $32.875, up $5.375, in brisk trading. Corroon & Black, another big insurance broker, advanced $1.25, to $26.75, largely in sympathy with the news. **********James, one of the world's largest insurance brokers, has reported that its net income for the first six months of 1982 fell 9 percent, to $8.9 million, or 99 cents a share, from $9.8 million, or $1.08 a share (restated) a year earlier. Revenue rose slightly, to $123.6 million from $122.6 million in 1981. The company, with more than 400,000 clients, has 80 offices in the United States and 18 overseas. **********Unlike insurance agents, which represent insurance companies in the sale of insurance, brokers represent the consumers in their purchase of insurance and attempt to package policies and place coverage to the best advantage of these clients. **********Investor interest in insurance brokers was heightened last September when Ryder System, the truck-leasing company, bought 4.9 percent of Frank B. Hall & Company, an insurance broker based in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., as part of a plan to buy at least 15 percent for investment purposes. Suspecting a takeover attempt, Hall bought Jartran, a Ryder competitor, thus creating a potential antitrust conflict. Ryder now has 9.5 percent of Hall and a Federal court in Chicago has rebuffed efforts by Hall to prevent Ryder from buying more. **********Charles A. O'Malley, James's 65-year-old chairman and chief executive, said in a telephone interview that the Ryder situation was ''a real hair raiser'' and that this and other factors put James on the defensive initially. **********But Mr. O'Malley said: ''We soon began to feel that the way to go is to become part of a bigger organization. Then the decision was, which one.'' **********Last spring Transamerica, which is based in San Francisco, bought a 3.5 percent interest in Chicago-based James. While the two companies were ''getting to know each other,'' Mr. O'Malley said, James was ''looking at other opportunities,'' which he declined to mention.  ''We came to the conclusion,'' he said, ''that we intended to make a move outside our operation, that we were on the threshold of a huge change in the industry'' and wanted to be a part of it. **********In a telephone interview, James R. Harvey, 48, president and chief executive of Transamerica, said the deal ''allows us to add some very highly specialized insurance services.'' **********He noted that last summer Transamerica had sold the United Artists Corporation to the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Film Company for $380 million. The bulk of the funds for the James venture, he said, would come from that deal, with the balance to come from general borrowing. **********The Transamerica-James deal appeared to have developed originally out of an earlier one involving the Prudential Insurance Company of America. As related by John Lathrop, vice president of the First Boston Corporation, which represented Transamerica, Prudential had asked First Boston to sell a small insurance services company owned by Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc. Transamerica had been approached as a potential buyer and noted at the time that it might be interested in a fairly large insurance broker. Coincidentally, James was also a First Boston client. As put by James's Mr. O'Malley, ''it was a mutual approach to each other.'' **********A joint news release said James had granted Transamerica an option to buy up to 1.65 million shares from the company at $33.50, a device used to discourage other bidders. Mr. O'Malley, the announcement added, would continue in his present post and join Transamerica's board.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/17/jobs/.print_headline: THE NATIONAL EMPLOYMENT OUTLOOK; THE SOUTHWEST
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/17/jobs/.body_text: **********THE jarring recession that has hit the oil industry has clouded whatu ntil recently seemed a bright outlook for geologists, petroleum e ngineers and other major occupations in the Southwest. Similarly, t he slump in the semiconductor industry has brought substantial l ayoffs in the Dallas area. **********But manpower experts generally say the downturn is cyclical and that the long-run prospects for this region are fundamentally good.  ''In the longer term, we see strong demand for technical occupations,'' said Sharon Cohany, an economist with the regional office of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics in Dallas. ''The economy is still stronger here than in many other parts of the country.'' **********Still, demand has slackened dramatically. The Texas Employment Commission reports that only 30,000 new jobs were created in the state over the last year, compared to 90,000 in the comparable 1978-79 period. And while there was an average of 1.5 applicants per job opening in 1979, this year the figure was 3 people per opening. **********Hardest hit have been oil and electronics production workers. Now, however, higher-paid workers are also coming under pressure as large oil companies retrench and smaller ones fold. Dorothy Roddy, head of Roddy and Associates, a technical and executive-search company that serves the oil and gas industry, has seen a dramatic change in just one year. Last year, she said, landing a job for a qualified engineer might take three days to three weeks; now it takes 30 to 90 days, and salaries have leveled off. **********Dale Crumbaugh, a labor analyst with the Houston office of the Texas Employment Commission, said that drilling engineers with less than 10 to 15 years' experience were finding the going rough, with the picture about the same for geologists and computer personnel. **********There is no agreement here on how long the slump will last, but few experts are optimistic about a speedy recovery, given continuing softness in oil prices. The Houston office of Manpower Inc., providers of temporary help, takes a quarterly survey of 300 companies in the Houston area. ''Nobody I have talked to feels much will change until April, and it will be slow,'' said Ron Kapche, president. ''But by next fall things will be much better.'' **********Most analysts agree that the long-range outlook is good for geologists, engineers, mechanics, health specialists, computer experts and other technically oriented jobs in the Southwest. Mr.  Crumbaugh, for example, expects a growing demand for oil and gas accountants versed in the complexities of excess-profits taxes, depreciation allowance and such. The employment commission forecasts that 6,800 petroleum engineers will be working in Texas by 1985, up from 4,700 in 1978. **********''I still see some very high-paying job offers for engineering students coming out of college,'' said Sharon Cohany of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. ''That leads me to believe that employers in the oil industry are looking to the long term. They know we are still very oil dependent. They are saying this recession does have an end.'' Robert Reinhold

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/05/busin.body_text: **********The Grumman Corporation said today that its net income in the fourth quarter of 1981 dropped 73.5 percent, to $2.7 million, or 12 cents a share, from $10.2 milli on, or 78 centsa share, in t he comparable period of 1980, mainly because of a $30.8 million loss on its troubled Flxible bus subsidiary. **********The company, the nation's fourth-largest aerospace and defense manufacturer, said that it had fourth-quarter sales of $522.8 million, up 5.1 percent from $497.3 million in the last quarter of 1980. **********Aside from the loss on Flxible, the company said its earnings were depressed by a fourth-quarter increase of $7.3 million in interest expenses and by the $4.2 million it spent in its successful battle against the LTV Corporation's $450 million takeover bid. **********For all of 1981, Grumman's net income dropped to $20.4 million, or $1.45 a share, from $30.6 million, or $2.35 a share, in 1980. Sales for the year, however, increased to $1.95 billion from $1.76 billion the year before. **********The 1981 figures reflected a 19 percent increase in military and commercial aircraft sales and a 51 percent increase in operating profits. Company officials said these increases reflected greater parts sales to the Navy for the E-2C aircraft, as well as modifications for the EF-111A. They also said that they increased profit margins on the company's premier project, the F-14 fighter aircraft. Flxible Problems Depress Results **********But John C. Bierwirth, Grumman's chairman, said the 1981 results had been severely depressed by the Flxible subsidiary's operating loss of $68.9 million, an increase of $61.2 millon over the 1980 figure. He also said that another factor was the company's consolidated interest expense of $53 million, $25.9 million more than in 1980. **********''The bus problems were more far-reaching than we anticipated and cost far more than we ever expected,'' Mr. Bierwirth said.  Grumman changed the name of the bus to ''Metro'' late last year but that did not cure the company's financial headaches. Last fall, the New York Metropolitan Transportation Authority threatened to hold up payments of $20 million or more on its fleet of 837 Flxibles after cracks appeared in the frames of some of those buses. Grumman repaired the damaged vehicles at no cost to the authority.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/02/world.body_text: **********Defense Minister Borje Andersson resigned today from the Social Democratic Government of Prime Minister Olof Palme. Mr. Andersson said he wanted to spend more time with his family. **********Sweden's Ambassador to the United Nations, Anders Thunborg, 48 years old, will succeed Mr. Andersson, Mr. Palme said. **********''I am more tied to my home than I was aware of,'' Mr. Andersson said in explaining his resignation. ''This has caused rising discontent for myself and my family.'' **********Mr. Palme surprised many officials when he picked the 52-year-old local politician from the northern steel city of Borlange as his Defense Minister after his election victory in September. **********Known as a left-of-center member of the Social Democratic Party, Mr. Andersson was never a Member of Parliament. His resignation came as a surprise.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/28/busin.body_text: **********year-old native of Hungary, whose company is already considered the world's largest producer of photovoltaic cells, the type that convert sunlight to electricity. **********In October, the Solarex president broke ground for what he calls the world's first solar breeder. If all goes well at the 95-acre site in nearby Frederick, Md., the breeder is expected to begin turning out solar cells toward the end of the summer. **********In contrast to the nuclear breeder, about which there has been considerable controversy, the solar breeder would be ''clean'' - producing minimal waste material, and truly self-renewable. ''In a nuclear breeder you eventually run out of fuel,'' said Dr. Lindmayer. ''It's not a true breeder. A true breeder is one that doesn't run out of fuel.'' **********Most of the $6 million for the project was put up by Standard Oil of Indiana, for which Solarex designed a $300,000 solar powered gas station near Chicago. Indiana Standard, which like many in the oil industry is spreading its energy bets, has acquired roughly 26 percent of the Solarex stock since 1978. **********The south roof, the side of buildings receiving the most sunlight, will be slanted to the ground at a 40 degree angle and covered with 3,120 large panels, each with 72 cells, for a total of 224,640 cells and a cost of $3 million. The plant would produce 1,000 cells an hour or over 2 million a year. Each cell would in turn produce a little less than a watt of electricity, with potential applications ranging from powering entire villages to lighting up a railroad crossing signal. **********Raymond A. McFarlane, director of advanced facility development for Solarex, contends that solar cells can produce residential electricity more cheaply than utilities over an 11- to 15-year period: Roughly 3 cents a kilowatt hour compared to current utility costs in Maryland of roughly 8 cents. **********''You have to make a big front end investment with solar cells,'' said Mr. McFarlane, who spent 25 years at RCA as an electromechanical engineer. ''But if somebody is patient enough to use them for 20 years, solar cells will be cheaper over the long run.'' **********Dr. Lindmayer emigrated from Hungary in 1956 and eventually became director of physics at COMSAT Laboratories, working on producing solar cells for use in space. He set up Solarex in 1973 with Peter Varadi, a co-worker at COMSAT, who is currently Solarex vice chairman. **********In 1974, around the time of the Arab oil embargo, Dr. Lindmayer came up with the idea for the breeder. But, he said, ''most people didn't know what I was talking about. I had to fight against a prevailing attitude that it takes 30 to 40 years to recover the energy used in manufacturing a solar cell.'' **********The breeder is, admittedly, not cost-effective yet. But Dr.  Lindmayer contends that it will take only 10 years to recover the initial $6 million investment and that the original solar panels will be churning out more cells for another ten years at minimal cost. **********That's if all goes well. But there are potential hazards. For one thing, Solarex is counting on semicrystalline photovoltaic cells, made by casting silicon into cubes and sawing the cubes into square cells. That process would be a lot easier than making traditional single crystal cells, which must grow from a seed crystal, but it's still a new technology. **********Then too, there is the question of whether the strict waste heat management that the company has incorporated in the solar breeder will work. The idea is to use heat generated by the factory's machines to heat and cool the building. If it doesn't, there may be a power problem. The breeder will not be connected to the utility grid at all, although a diesel generator will provide emergency backup power and lead-acid batteries will have the capacity to store enough electricity to run the factory for four days. **********Still, Dr. Lindmayer foresees a sparkling future for the breeder.  Eventually he hopes to export entire solar factories, providing enough electricity for 25,000 square feet of assembly type workspace. **********''Just as we have prefabricated housing,'' Dr. Lindmayer asked.  ''why can't we have a prefabricated industrial building with the power attached to it?'' **********Lyndon Stambler

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/08/world.body_text: **********A coalition of Nicaraguan exile leaders who are running a paramilitary campaign against the Sandinist Government in Managua made a public appearance today. **********The group, called the Nicaraguan Democratic Front, issued a proclamation at a news conference in Fort Lauderdale that was, in effect, a call to arms to citizens of Nicaragua. **********In an effort to broaden their base of support, the leaders stressed that they opposed the policies of Gen. Anastasio Somoza Debayle, the Nicaraguan leader who was overthrown by the Sandinists in 1979. He was assassinated in 1980 in Paraguay. **********''Until 1979, we suffered under a dynastic family dictatorship,'' they said, ''and now we are under a collective totalitarian dictatorship, both of them corrupt, exploitative and murderous.'' **********Paramilitary groups commanded by the group have indirectly received aid from the Central Intelligence Agency, according to American officials. The aid has consisted of money and military equipment passed to the groups through intermediaries, including Argentina, the officials said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/10/world.main_headline: Zia Defends Flogging As an Islamic Practice
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/10/world.print_headline: Zia Defends Flogging As an Islamic Practice
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/10/world.body_text: **********President Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan yesterday defended his country's practice of flogging criminals, saying that the practice is allowed both by Islamic law and ''the civil law which was inherited from the British.'' **********Mr. Zia, who said in Washington Wednesday that ''there is a style of flogging,'' was asked at a luncheon of the Foreign Policy Association in New York to explain the difference between ''flogging with style and flogging without style.'' **********He replied that the question should be directed to the Prime Minister of Britain. **********Flogging, Mr. Zia went on, ''is not a matter of degradation of a human being, but a matter of deterrence.'' Mr. Zia said that flogging with style meant that the practice was strictly regulated to avoid permanent physical harm. ''How long the whip should be, where the person should be struck and where the body should be placed,'' were all carefully determined, he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/18/busin.main_headline: ESTEE LAUDER: THE SCENTS OF SUCCESS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/18/busin.print_headline: ESTEE LAUDER: THE SCENTS OF SUCCESS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/18/busin.body_text: **********Blue is the color of the headquarters of the Estee Lauder group, from the midnight blue elevator banks to the blue walls, blue carpets and blue-and-white overstuffed sofas of the reception area. Blue is the personal trademark of Estee Lauder, as pink was Elizabeth Arden's. And just as surely as Mrs. Lauder has nailed her color to the company's mast, she has stamped her personal imprint on the group, by some measures the most successful cosmetics company in the United States. **********Last week, with a fanfare it normally reserves for a new body lotion, the group announced some executive changes. Leonard Lauder, the 49-year-old president, also became chief executive officer; his brother, Ronald Lauder, 38, executive vice president, assumed the additional title of chairman of the company's substantial overseas operations. **********As befits a cosmetics business, however, there were signs that the changes were mainly skin-deep. Although the entire family granted one of its rare interviews to publicize the promotion of the ''sweet boys,'' as their fond mother described them, Mrs. Lauder also made it clear that she is not stepping down anytime soon from her active chairmanship, nor is her husband, Joseph, withdrawing from management of the group's factories. ''What we are doing is setting the stage for the next 20 years,'' said Ronald Lauder. **********Indeed, it is perhaps the family's proudest boast that the younger and older generations have worked together long and well, almost from the founding of Estee Lauder Inc. by Mrs. and Mr. Lauder in 1946.  Today, Estee Lauder is a household word. Its Youth Dew is one of the nation's top three selling fragrances. The group has approximately 10,000 employees worldwide. **********It accounts for an estimated 30 to 50 percent of department store sales of cosmetics and fragrances. And Mrs. Lauder, a blonde, hazeleyed woman on no specified side of 70 (''Age?'' she hoot ed, when the subject was broached. ''You're kidding.'') has outlived her rivals: Charles Revson of Revlon, Helena Rubinstein and Elizabeth Arden. ''I'm the only one left,'' she said last week. ''Thank God.'' **********More precise measures of the group's success are harder to obtain.  It is still privately held by the senior Lauders, their two sons and their four grandchildren. But the rest of the industry and Wall Street, which watch it closely, estimate that revenues currently approach $1 billion. The figure is neither confirmed nor denied by management. Leonard Lauder says only that the group has had a compounded annual growth rate of 20 percent in its 36 years. **********Profits are an even more speculative matter, but the picture is decidedly less rosy: Estee Lauder's profit margins are believed to fall below the 5 percent mark. The primary reason, suggested Jack L.  Salzman, an analyst for Smith Barney Harris Upham & Company, is that the company was built on a pattern of discounting. The technique is known more elegantly in department stores as purchase-with-purchase or gift-with-purchase, in which customers who buy a certain amount receive additional items at reduced prices or free. ''It's a very expensive proposition,'' Mr. Salzman said. **********Related to that is Estee Lauder's heavy reliance on department stores. ''There's a fallacy that if you sell through department stores, you're better off,'' said Mr. Salzman. In fact, he added, ''prestige department stores set the tone, and they make the manufacturers pay for it'' by, for example, offering more and better discounts. **********That is the choice that the Lauders made from the first, and to which they have adhered. The company's strategy has always been to sell top-of-the-line products through top-rated outlets, for top dollar, rather than through drug stores and discount chains like Woolworths and K marts. **********Over the years, the Estee Lauder group has enhanced its appeal through a combination of line extensions, genuine new-product introductions and savvy positioning. The company now has four divisions: the original Estee Lauder; Clinique, a hypo-allergenic line, gaining quickly on Estee Lauder; Aramis, men's toiletries, and Prescriptives, a high-tech skin-treatment line. In addition, the group is growing rapidly overseas, which accounts for half of its sales. **********In large measure, the company has got where it is through the considerable energy and creative talents of Mrs. Lauder, who still has a copy of her first order, for $1,045.44 from a Philadelphia distributor in 1946. **********It is difficult to determine the extent of her involvement now, but her presence at the group's offices is hard to ignore. She loses little time in ushering a female visitor into her private marbledand-mirrored bathroom and painting her with Country Market and Regatta, two recently introduced Estee Lauder cosmetics lines. **********Mrs. Lauder frequently visits the group's offices and retail outlets, and when she is in New York, comes to work daily at the group's headquarters in the General Motors Building. (Because Lauder and Revlon are major tenants, wits call it the General Odors Building.) **********She denounces rival products - ''Lancome is nothing,'' she said, of the French cosmetics company regarded as one of the Lauder group's toughest rivals. She complains that competitors raid the group for staff, hoping to poach its creativity, but to no avail. ''After three, six months, they run out of my ideas,'' she declared. She has unswerving faith in cosmetics, and unstinting praise for her own.  ''It gives you a finished, clean, natural look,'' she said of her make-up. ''You can't wash your face with soap and go out. That's not natural.'' **********In the group's creative matters - color, fragrance, even advertisements - Mrs. Lauder appears to have the final word. She lays claim to an almost sixth sense in fashion, foreseeing a future season's colors and a line of complementary cosmetics. She says she can see and feel fragrances as well as smell them. **********When she retreated to Palm Beach last winter, she regularly summoned the group's researchers south. (''How can they judge colors when New York is so gray and dreary?'' she asked.) ''If my mother calls and makes a valid point, it's accepted,'' said Ronald Lauder.  ''And 99 percent of the time, it's a valid point.'' **********As a marketer, analysts say, the company has performed superbly. It diversified early into other product lines, under different names - Aramis in 1964, Clinique in 1968, Prescriptives in 1979 - that have allowed the group to compete with itself for customers and to take up more square footage of prime department store space than any other cosmetics company. It has positioned the two other women's divisions carefully, to avoid cannibalizing the original Estee Lauder business; Clinique is identified with health, Prescriptives with the space-age and science. **********The image is supported by the use of a single model for each of those divisions. Since 1971, for example, advertisements for the main division, Estee Lauder, have used a single model, Karen Graham, to project the requisite elegance and sophistication.Only recently, as Miss Graham began to project a certain maturity, too, did the company bring in Shaun Casey, a model in her 20's, for more youthful lines such as American Desert. **********''The Estee Lauder advertisements have not changed in 20 years,'' boasted Leonard Lauder. ''They're styled carefully. The hair, dress, settings are exactly right.'' They provoke strong demand not only at cosmetics counters, but also for featured jewelry and furniture. ''We get hundreds of letters after each ad, asking, 'Where'd you get that breakfront? That table'?'' said Mr. Lauder. **********While it has kept the images consistent, the group has simultaneously spawned numerous new products and variations within each line. Clinique, Aramis and Estee Lauder have their own shampoos and fragrances. Last autumn, the Estee Lauder division introduced European Body Spa, a line that includes no fewer than 10 new products, including a body buffer, a foot cream and a bust conditioner. **********Such brilliant and successful marketing has made the group the darling of the stores - and of the buyers, too. According to an annual survey by Smith Barney, the group leads all popularity polls for servicing the retailers. That is just fine with the Lauders, who scorn the mass-merchandising route taken by Charles Revson. ''The fewer stores we sell, the more successful we are,'' said Leonard Lauder. ''We roll things out very, very slowly.'' Although the Lauder lines are in only a handful of stores in the Dallas-Fort Worth area, for example, sales per capita exceed New York's, where the distribution is wider. **********But the relationship cuts two ways. To increase their department store sales, the Lauders in the 1950's pioneered a posher form of discounting, through gift-with-purchase offers. The group's sales soared, but so did the stores' and customers' expectations. Thus, the Lauder group and its competitors were forced into a costly round of gift-with-purchase and purchase-with-purchase discounting. **********''Department stores now demand these,'' said Mr. Salzman.  Furthermore, by foregoing chain and drug stores, he added, the Lauder group not only sacrificed bigger volume, with consequent economies of scale, but also lost outlets where competition is less fierce and advertising expenses more fairly shared. By now, the group may be a prisoner of its marketing strategy, unable to branch out without incurring the wrath of the department stores, Mr. Salzman noted. **********With its outlets limited, industry analysts say, the next logical area of growth for the group to enter is hair-care products. The group is including a hair laboratory in its new research-anddevelopment facility, near its largest factory, in Melville, L.I. But any product to emerge must bottle a technological breakthrough, according to Leonard Lauder. ''The business has been dominated by the mass-marketers: Procter & Gamble, Bristol-Myers,'' he said. ''They give good value. Women aren't waiting for a new shampoo.'' The group's major efforts will remain in skin care, he added. **********For the Lauder group, as for a number of packaged goods companies, the potential is far greater overseas. Starting in 1960 with sales to Harrods in London, the group now does half of its volume - though substantially less of its profits - abroad in 75 countries, and sales should grow by 30 percent this year, Ronald Lauder predicts. **********He is enthusiastic about opportunities in Spain, France, Australia, Japan. In many countries, it is perceived as a prohibitively expensive line. The answer, he said, is not to cut prices, but to ''position it in a broader market,'' through heavy advertising and other forms of promotion. ''We'll make Estee Lauder a household word throughout the world,'' he vowed. **********Not everything, however, that the Lauder group touches turns to gold. It has been faulted for its handling of Aramis, its line of men's toiletries, where its sizeble lead has been reduced by the entry of a number of new, higher-priced products. But the family emphasizes that it is in the cosmetics business for the long term, and is prepared to invest accordingly - a determination made more feasible by its private ownership. But can the group outlive its dynamic founder? **********''Mrs. Lauder is like a conductor of a great symphony orchestra,'' said Leonard Lauder, using the impersonal form to speak of his mother in business discussions. ''The challenge is to orchestrate so that it goes on and on, without a stop.'' XX-BOX WITH LAUDER adv18 c. 1982 N.Y. Times News Service **********OTHER EMPIRES: REVLON, ARDEN, RUBENSTEIN Of the great entrepreneurs of the American beauty business, only Estee Lauder survives. And of those individuals' cosmetics empires, only Mrs. Lauder's group continues in much its original form. **********Mrs. Lauder's archrival, Charles Revson, who built the Revlon empire from a Depression-era nail polish distributorship, died in 1975. Under his successor, Michel Bergerac, Revlon has been transformed into a $2.4 billion company that derives half of its revenue from health-care activities. In addition to its lipsticks and nail polish, Revlon makes medical instruments, contact lenses and ethical pharmaceuticals. **********After years of record growth, however, Revlon's earnings fell 9 percent last year, to $175 million. A major factor was the stronger dollar, which reduced Revlon's income overseas. But analysts suggest the company was also hurt by fierce competition, a mature domestic market for cosmetics and difficulty at absorbing its many health-care acquisitions. **********Behind the red door at Elizabeth Arden, however, things are looking up. Four years after the death in 1966 of Elizabeth Nightingale Graham, its Canadian-born founder and sole owner, the company was sold to Eli Lilly & Company, the large pharmaceutical concern. **********Its $271 million cosmetics business has not consistently been a star performer for Lilly. Recently, however, sales have benefited from such best-sellers as Chloe fragrance, Visible Difference and Millenium, a skin-care line akin to Estee Lauder's Prescriptives. **********The venerable Helena Rubinstein Inc., whose Polish-born founder died in 1965, has had the spottiest history. The cosmetics manufacturer was bought for $142 million in 1973 by the Colgate-Palmolive Company. **********When the acquisition kept losing millions, Colgate sought to sell it - first to the Kao Soap Company of Japan, then to L'Oreal S.A. of Paris. It was finally sold two years ago to Albi Enterprises, a privately company, for $20 million. **********For sheer sales growth, the reigning beauty queen may be the founder of Mary Kay Cosmetics, formed in 1963, where sales spurted last year by 41 percent, to $235 million. But prices are moderate and distribution is door-to-door, thus excluding Mary Kay Ash from Mrs.  Lauder's exclusive club.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/08/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Bobbie Brooks Inc.  Appoints President
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/08/busin.body_text: **********Maurice Saltzman, 63 years old, will step down as chief executive officer of Bobbie Brooks Inc., a leading women's apparel concern that he co-founded in 1939, around May 1, the end of the fiscal year, the Cleveland-based company announced. Although he will continue as chairman, Mr. Saltzman will be succeeded as president and chief executive officer by Lawrence Halpern, 47, currently president of the corporation's Bobbie Brooks division. **********Bobbie Brooks filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code on Jan. 15. Shortly afterward it entered into a factoring arrangement with the Meinhard-Commercial Corporation, whereby Meinhard will advance funds to the garment maker against invoices. **********In a telephone interview, Mr. Halpern said he would ''concentrate on the word control - to control the business for profitability and return on investment, rather than the desire to obtain more sales.'' He added that he would also work ''to make sure we are meeting the needs of the customer.'' **********According to Mr. Halpern, ''The Chapter 11 really revolved around our trying to leverage our business too highly in an interest rate situation too powerful for us. The banks could not agree on a new financing package and we had no choice but to look for protection. We are now really closing down those areas whose sales are not viable.'' **********Mr. Halpern, by coincidence, started his career in 1958 working for the Securities and Exchange Commission in the area of corporate reorganizations. Two years later, he went to work for Girltown, an apparel producer that was later acquired by Genesco Inc. when Mr.  Halpern was president. Before joining Bobbie Brooks to head its largest division, he served three years as president of the Fay's Closet divison of Leslie Fay Inc. **********Mr. Salzman worked for Lampi Fashions before establishing Bobbie Brooks, principally on borrowed money, and becoming its president. In 1967, he was elected chairman and again assumed the president's title nine years later. **********Mr. Halpern said that he intended ''to be out on the retail level, working with the stores, working with the salesman, making sure that the product goes out in the right manner. There's a lot of caution out there -and if I was a retailer, I'd be cautious too.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/01/world.main_headline: MRS. KIRKPATRICK SEES REAGAN OVER HER QUARREL WITH HAIG
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/01/world.print_headline: MRS. KIRKPATRICK SEES REAGAN OVER HER QUARREL WITH HAIG
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/01/world.body_text: **********Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the United States delegate to the United Nations, who is admittedly at odds with the Administration's pro-British policy over the Falkland Islands, met for 40 minutes today with President Reagan to discuss her point of view, White House officials said. **********The unusual holiday session at the White House was at Mrs.  Kirkpatrick's request, the officials said. In response to questions, one official said that as far as he knew Mrs. Kirkpatrick had not resigned or been asked to do so. **********Mrs. Kirkpatrick, who has had heated differences with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. on several matters, said on Sunday that she had had a serious dispute with him last week over the Falklands policy. **********According to the officials, William P. Clark, the White House national security adviser, was the only other aide present during the session today. **********The differences between Mrs. Kirkpatrick and Mr. Haig over the Falklands have been over her view that it was wrong for the Administration on April 30, after Mr. Haig's mediation role had failed, to side publicly with Britain in the crisis. Contacts With Argentines **********Beyond the substantive disagreement over whether the United States should have been neutral or sided with Britain, Mrs. Kirkpatrick and Mr. Haig have also been quarreling over her diplomatic activity in connection with the crisis. **********She has kept up friendly contacts, State Department officials said, with Argentine officials at the United Nations at the same time that the Argentine Foreign Ministr, Nicanor Costa Mendez, was sharply attacking the United States in the Organization of American States. **********Mr. Haig was also reported by aides to have been very upset by Mrs. Kirkpatrick's expressing optimism on a television interview program in April that Mr. Haig, then shuttling between London and Buenos Aires as a mediator, would succeed in resolving the dispute. **********At that time, Mr. Haig had ordered the State Department not to characterize his mission in any way and above all not to create expectations that an agreement was likely. When he received word in London about her optimistic interview, he was said to have expressed anger. Neutrality at Issue **********Mrs. Kirkpatrick's basic complaint, officials said, is that Mr.  Haig and his top advisers have no solid grounding in Latin American affairs, and have not properly taken note of Argentina's historic claim to the Falklands. **********Mrs. Kirkpatrick said Sunday in an interview that there has been ''a big debate'' in the Government over whether to remain neutral between Argentina and Britain or to side with Britain. **********''I have leaned to the neutral side,'' she said.  Mrs. Kirkpatrick has been a major supporter within the Administration of the policy of improving relations with Argentina after the severe strains of the Carter Administration. **********On the day of the Argentine invasion of the Falklands, Mrs.  Kirkpatrick was the guest of honor at a dinner at the Argentine Embassy in Washington, a dinner also attended by Deputy Secretary of State Walter J. Stoessel. She said that her going ahead with the dinner had been approved by the department, but the move was criticized by some columnists and members of Congress because it left the impression that Washington was uncritical of the Argentine moves.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/12/busin.main_headline: Uniroyal Inc.  Names Chief For Finance
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/12/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Uniroyal Inc.  Names Chief For Finance
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/12/busin.body_text: **********John R. Graham, who joined Uniroyal Inc. in February as financial vice president, has been named chief financial officer. He succeeds William J. Crane, 61, who becomes vice chairman, and who has decided to take early retirement in 1983 after 45 years with the company. **********Mr. Graham, 52, was previously vice president and chief financial officer for the Planning Research Corporation in Washington, which provides engineering, computer and other services to government and industry - everything from gantry engineering for the space shuttle launching to cost-control programs for Saudi Arabia. **********Mr. Graham said he had been hired at Uniroyal, which is based in Middlebury, Conn., with the idea that he would eventually become chief financial officer. ''This company has done a lot of pruning and trimming and reorganizing,'' he said. ''But it doesn't just cut the tie and bring in a new player.'' **********Mr. Graham said that Joseph P. Flannery, Uniroyal's chairman, decided that, ''instead of just having Bill retire, this should certainly be a cautious move - you can't afford any gaps in knowledge and experience. Bill and I will have a year and a half together to make sure we don't miss anything.'' **********Mr. Crane joined Uniroyal as an office boy at the Chicopee Falls, Mass., tire plant in 1938 and moved through various accounting and financial management posts. He will continue on the executive, finance and strategy committees of the board. **********Mr. Graham joined the Planning Research Corporation in 1980 after six years at the Sikorsky division of the United Technologies Corporation, where he was senior vice president, finance. Before that he was treasurer at Heublein Inc., where he worked from 1967 to 1974 and earlier was an officer at the Hartford National Bank and Trust Company. **********He is a graduate of the United States Merchant Marine Academy and went to sea before deciding that ''mostly, the good things are on the beach.'' He then earned an M.B.A. degree from Harvard.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/24/world.main_headline: American Asks Moscow To Release Her Husband
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/24/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; American Asks Moscow To Release Her Husband
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/24/world.body_text: **********The American wife of a Soviet hunger striker appealed to the Communist Party and the Soviet Parliament today to allow her husband to leave the country. **********''Because of his physical condition, if action is not taken soon Yuri will die,'' said Elena Kusmenko, a Baltimore nurse married to Yuri Balovlenkov. **********Her husband, 33 years old, an unemployed computer programmer, has not eaten for 75 days.  His wife, who is in the Soviet Union on a 10-day visa, spent the day at the party's Central Committee and the presidium of the Soviet Legislature, where she left letters appealing for a reversal of the decision to keep Mr. Balovlenkov in the country. She said she was surprised that her letters had been received since those institutions generally do not accept appeals from foreigners. **********On Thursday, Sergei Petrov, another Russian who is trying to join an American wife, called off a hunger strike after 51 days.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/29/world.print_headline: Iraqi Leader Dismisses Entire Ruling Council
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/29/world.body_text: **********President Saddam Hussein of Iraq dismissed all members of his ruling Revolutionary Command Council and eight Cabinet ministers, the Bahrain-based Gulf News Agency reported today from Baghdad. **********The shuffle of the Iraqi leadership was reported one day before Iraqi troops are scheduled to complete their withdrawal from Iranian territory occupied in the 21-month-old Iran-Iraq war, and a day after a meeting of Mr. Hussein's Baath Party in which half the 14-member party leadership was removed and President Hussein was unanimously re-elected as secretary. **********Among those dropped from the Cabinet was the Oil Minister, Tayih Abd al-Karim.  The Revolutionary Command Council, the supreme political body in Baghdad, announced a cease-fire June 10 in the war, and President Hussein announced June 20 that he was withdrawing his forces from Iran, effective Wednesday. **********The Gulf News Agency listed eight names as outgoing members of the Revolutionary Command Council and said President Hussein had appointed a new, nine-member council, with himself continuing as chairman. The names of the new ministers were not immediately available. **********The Baghdad radio said Iranian troops continued to harass the Iraqi forces today as they proceeded with their withdrawal and that four Iranians and two Iraqis were killed in clashes.
