https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/07/world.main_headline: HAIG'S SPEECH ON AMERICAN NUCLEAR STRATEGY AND THE ROLE OF ARMS CONTROL
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/07/world.print_headline: HAIG'S SPEECH ON AMERICAN NUCLEAR STRATEGY AND THE ROLE OF ARMS CONTROL
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/07/world.body_text: **********Following is the text of a speech delivered at the International Club by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. before Georgetown University's Center for Strategic and International Studies and made public by the State Department: **********It is a melancholy fact of the modern age that man has conceived a means capable of his own destruction. For 37 years mankind has had to live with the terrible burden of nuclear weapons. From the dawn of the nuclear age, these weapons have been the source of grave concern to our peoples and the focus of continuous public debate. Every successive President of the United States has shared these concerns.  Every administration has had to engage itself in this debate. **********It is right that each succeeding generation should question anew the manner in which its leaders exercise such awesome responsibilities. It is right that each new administration should have to confront the aweful dilemmas posed by the possession of nuclear weapons. It is right that our nuclear strategy should be exposed to continuous examination. **********In debating these issues, we should not allow the complexity of the problems and the gravity of the stakes to blind us to the common ground upon which we all stand. No one has ever advocated nuclear war. No responsible voice has ever sought to minimize its horrors. **********The Only Strategy **********On the contrary, from the earliest days of the postwar era, America's leaders have recognized the only nuclear strategy consistent with our values and our survival - our physical existence, and what makes life worth living - is the strategy of deterrence. The massive destructive power of these weapons precludes their serving any lesser purpose. The catastrophic consequences of another world war - with or without nuclear weapons - make deterrence of conflict our highest objective and our only rational military strategy in the modern age. **********Thus, since the close of World War II, American and Western strategy has assigned a single function to nuclear weapons: the prevention of war and the preservation of peace. At the heart of this deterrence strategy is the requirement that the risk of engaging in war must be made to outweigh any possible benefits of aggression. The cost of aggression must not be confined to the victims of aggression. **********This strategy of deterrence has won the consistent approval of the Western peoples. It has enjoyed the bipartisan support of the American Congress. It has secured the unanimous endorsement of every successive allied government. **********Deterrence has been supported because deterrence works. Nuclear deterrence and collective defense have preserved peace in Europe, the crucible of two global wars in this century. Clearly neither improvement in the nature of man nor strengthening of the international order have made war less frequent or less brutal.  Millions have died since 1945 in over 130 international and civil wars. Yet nuclear deterrence has prevented a conflict between the two superpowers, a conflict which even without nuclear weapons would be the most destructive in mankind's history. Requirements for Deterrence **********The simple possession of nuclear weapons does not guarantee deterrence. Throughout history societies have risked their total destruction if the prize of victory was sufficiently great or the consequences of submission sufficiently grave. War, and in particular nuclear war, can be deterred, but only if we are able to deny an aggressor military advantage from his action and thus insure his awareness that he cannot prevail in any conflict with us.  Deterrence, in short, requires the maintenance of a secure military balance, one which cannot be overturned through surprise attack or sudden technological breakthrough. The quality and credibility of deterrence must be measured against these criteria. Successive administrations have understood this fact and stressed the importance of an overall balance. This Administration can do no less. **********The strategy of deterrence, in its essentials, has endured. But the requirements for maintaining a secure capability to deter in all circumstances have evolved. In the early days of unquestioned American nuclear superiority, the task of posing an unacceptable risk to an aggressor was not difficult. The threat of massive retaliation was fully credible as long as the Soviet Union could not respond in kind. As the Soviet Union's nuclear arsenal grew, however, this threat began to lose credibility. Concept of Flexible Response **********To sustain the credibility of Western deterrence, the concept of flexible response was elaborated and formally adopted by the United States and its NATO partners in 1967. Henceforth, it was agreed that NATO would meet aggression initially at whatever level it was launched, while preserving the flexibility to escalate the conflict, if necessary, to secure the cessation of aggression and the withdrawal of the aggressor. The purpose of this strategy is not just to conduct conflict successfully if it is forced upon us, but more importantly to prevent the outbreak of conflict in the first place. **********Flexible response is not premised upon the view that nuclear war can be controlled. Every successive allied and American government has been convinced that a nuclear war, once initiated, could escape such control. They have therefore agreed upon a strategy which retains the deterrent effect of a possible nuclear response, without making such a step in any sense automatic. **********The alliance based its implementation of flexible response upon a spectrum of forces, each of which plays an indispensable role in assuring the credibility of a Western strategy of deterrence. At one end of the spectrum are America's strategic forces, our heavy bombers, intercontinental missiles and ballistic-missile submarines.  Since NATO's inception, these forces have been the ultimate guarantee of Western security, a role which they will retain in the future. Role of Conventional Forces **********At the other end of the spectrum are the alliance's conventional forces, including U.S. troops in Europe. These forces must be strong enough to defeat all but the most massive and persistent conventional aggression. They must be resistant and durable enough to give political leaders time to measure the gravity of the threat, to confront the inherently daunting prospects of nuclear escalation and to seek through diplomacy the cessation of conflict and restoration of any lost Western territory. The vital role which conventional forces play in deterrence is too often neglected, particularly by those most vocal in their concern over reliance upon nuclear weapons. A strengthened conventional posture both strengthens the deterrent effect of nuclear forces and reduces the prospect of their ever being used. **********Linking together strategic and conventional forces are theater nuclear forces, that is, NATO's nuclear systems based in Europe.  These systems are concrete evidence of the nature of the American commitment. They are a concrete manifestation of NATO's willingness to resort to nuclear weapons if necessary to preserve the freedom and independence of its members. Further, the presence of nuclear weapons in Europe insures the Soviet Union will never believe that it can divide the U.S. from its allies or wage a limited war with limited risks against any NATO member. Averting a Third Rescue **********The strategy of flexible response and the forces that sustain its credibility reflect more than simply the prevailing military balance. Western strategy also reflects the political and geographical reality of an alliance of 15 independent nations, the most powerful of which is separated from all but one of the others by 4,000 miles of ocean. **********Deterrence is consequently more than a military strategy. It is the essential political bargain which binds together the Western coalition. Twice in this century, America has been unable to remain aloof from European conflict but able to intervene in time to prevent the devastation of Western Europe. Neither we nor our allies can afford to see this pattern repeated a third time. We have, therefore, chosen a stategy which engages American power in the defense of Europe and gives substance to the principle that the security of the alliance is indivisible. **********What U.S. Is Trying to Do **********During the past decade the Soviet Union has mounted a sustained buildup across the range of its nuclear forces designed to undermine the credibility of this alliance strategy. Soviet modernization efforts have far outstripped those of the West. The development and deployment of Soviet intercontinental ballistic missiles now pose a serious and increasing threat to a large part of our land-based ICBM force. A new generation of Soviet intermediate range missiles are targeted upon our European allies. **********In the last 10 years, the Soviets introduced an unprecedented array of new strategic and intermediate range systems into their arsenals, including the SS-17, SS-18 and SS-19 ICBM's, the Backfire bomber, the Typhoon submarine and several new types of submarine-launched missiles and the SS-20 intermediate range missile. In contrast, during this same period, the U.S. exercised restraint, introducing only the Trident missile and submarine and the slower, air-breathing cruise missile. What Reagan Has Done **********In order to deal with the resulting imbalances, President Reagan has adopted a defense posture and recommended programs to the U.S.  Congress designed to maintain deterrence, rectify the imbalances and thereby support the Western strategy I have outlined. **********His bold strategic modernization program, announced last October, is designed to insure the maintenance of a secure and reliable capability to deny an adversary advantage from any form of aggression, even a surprise attack. **********The President's decision, in his first weeks in office, to go ahead with the production and deployment of the Pershing 2 and groundlaunched cruise missiles, in accordance with NATO's decision of December 1979, represents an effort to reinforce the linkage between our strategic forces in the United States and NATO's conventional and nuclear forces in Europe. A response to the massive buildup of Soviet SS-20's targeted on Western Europe, this NATO decision was taken to insure that the U.S.S.R. will never launch aggression in the belief that its own territory can remain immune from attack or that European security can ever be decoupled from that of the U.S. Relationship of 3 Kinds of Forces **********The improvements we are making in our conventional forces - in their readiness, mobility, training and equipment - are designed to insure the kind of tough and resiliant conventional capability required by the strategy of flexible response. **********It is important to recognize the interrelationship of these three types of forces. The requirements in each category are dependent upon the scale of the others. Their functions are similarly linked. The Soviet Union understands this. That is why they have consistently proposed a pledge against the first use of nuclear weapons, an idea which has achieved some resonance here in the West. **********NATO has consistently rejected such Soviet proposals, which are tantamount to making Europe safe for conventional aggression. If the West were to allow Moscow the freedom to choose the level of conflict which most suited it and to leave entirely to Soviet discretion the nature and timing of any escalation, we would be forced to maintain conventional forces at least at the level of those of the Soviet Union and its Warsaw Pact allies. The Consequent Costs **********Those in the West who advocate the adoption of a ''no first use'' policy seldom go on to propose that the United States reintroduce the draft, triple the size of its armed forces and put its economy on wartime footing. Yet in the absence of such steps, a pledge of no first use effectively leaves the West nothing with which to counterbalance the Soviet conventional advantages and geopolitical position in Europe. **********Neither do Western proponents of a ''no first use'' policy acknowledge the consequences for the Western alliance of an American decision not to pose and accept the risk of nuclear war in the defense of Europe. A ''no first use'' policy would be the end of flexible response and thus of the very credibility of the Western strategy of deterrence. In adopting such a stance, the United States would be limiting its commitment to Europe. But the alliance cannot function as a limited liability corporation. It can only survive as a partnership to which all are equally and fully committed - shared benefits, shared burdens, shared risks. Perpetuating Inequality **********Another concept which has recently attracted interest is that of a freeze on nuclear weapons. While being sensitive to the concerns underlying this proposal, we have had to underscore the flaws in such an approach. A freeze at current levels would perpetuate an unstable and unequal military balance. It would reward a decade of unilateral Soviet buildup and penalize the United States for a decade of unilateral restraint. As President Reagan stressed last week, such a freeze would remove all Soviet incentive to engage in meaningful arms control designed to cut armaments and reduce the risk of war. **********Much of the argumentation for a nuclear freeze revolves around the question of how much is enough. Each side possesses thousands of deliverable nuclear weapons. Does it then really make any difference who is ahead? The question itself is misleading, as it assumes that deterrence is simply a matter of numbers of weapons or numbers of casualties which could be inflicted. It is not. Who Is to Be Deterred **********Let us remember, first and foremost, that we are trying to deter the Soviet Union, not ourselves. The dynamic nature of the Soviet nuclear buildup demonstrates that the Soviet leaders do not believe in the concept of ''sufficiency.'' They are not likely to be deterred by a force based upon it. **********Let us also recall that nuclear deterrence must work not just in times of peace and moments of calm. Deterrence faces its true test at the time of maximum tension, even in the midst of actual conflict.  In such extreme circumstances, when the stakes on the table may already be immense, when Soviet leaders may feel the very existence of their regime is threatened, who can say whether or not they would run massive risks if they believed that in the end the Soviet state would prevail. **********Deterrence thus does not rest on a static comparison of the number or size of nuclear weapons. Rather, deterrence depends upon our capability, even after suffering a massive nuclear blow, to prevent an aggressor from securing a military advantage and prevailing in a conflict. Only if we maintain such a capability can we deter such a blow. Deterrence, in consequence, rests upon a military balance measured not in warhead numbers but in a complex interaction of capabilities and vulnerabilities. Pick up first add **********The Military Balance **********The state of the military balance and its impact upon the deterrent value of American forces cast a shadow over every significant geopolitical decision. It affects on a day-to-day basis the conduct of American diplomacy. It influences the management of international crises and the terms upon which they are resolved. **********The search for national interest and national security is a principal preoccupation of the leaders of every nation on the globe.  Their decisions and their foreign policies are profoundly affected by their perception of the military balance between the United States and the Soviet Union and the consequent capacity of either to help provide for their security or to threaten it. **********More important still, perceptions of the military balance also affect the psychological attitude of both American and Soviet leaders, as they respond to events around the globe. For the foreseeable future the relationship between the United States and the Soviet Union will be one in which our differences outnumber points of convergence. Our objective must be to restrain this competition, to keep it below the level of force, while protecting our interests and those of our allies. Our ability to secure these objectives will be crucially influenced by the state of the strategic balance. Every judgment we make and every judgment the Soviet leadership makes will be shaded by it. Complicating Soviet Calculations **********Thus the Soviet leadership, in calculating the risks of subversion or aggression, of acquiring new clients or propping up faltering proxies, must carefully evaluate the possibilities and prospects for an effective American response. Soviet calculations must encompass not only American capabilities to influence regional developments, but American willingness to face the prospect of U.S.-Soviet confrontation and consequent escalation. American leaders, for their part, must go through comparable calculations in reacting to regional conflicts, responding to Soviet adventurism and seeking to resolve international crises in a manner consistent with U.S. interests. **********Put simply, our own vulnerability to nuclear blackmail, as well as the susceptibility of our friends to political intimidation, depends upon our ability and willingness to cope credibly with any Soviet threat. A strong and credible strategic posture enhances stability by reducing for the Soviets the temptations toward adventurism at the same time that it strengthens our hand in responding to Soviet political-military threats. Arms Control and Deterrence **********In no area of diplomacy does the military balance have greater effect than in arms control. Arms control can reinforce deterrence and stabilize a military balance at lower levels of risk and effort.  Arms control cannot, however, either provide or restore a balance we are unwilling to maintain through our defense efforts. **********Just as the only justifiable nuclear strategy is one of deterrence, so the overriding objective for arms control is reducing the risk of war. The essential purpose of arms control is not to save money, although it may do so. Its purpose is not to generate good feelings or improve international relationships, although it may have that effect as well. Arms control's central purpose must be to reinforce the military balance, upon which deterrence depends, at reduced levels of weapons and risk. **********On Nov. 18, President Reagan laid out the framework for a comprehensive program of arms control designed to serve these objectives. He committed the United States to seek major reductions in nuclear and conventional forces, leading to equal agreed limits on both sides. The Steps U.S. Has Taken **********Last week he reviewed the steps we have taken.  In Geneva we have put forth deailed proposals designed to limit intermediate range nuclear forces and to eliminate entirely the missiles of greatest concern to each side. This proposal has won the strong and unified support of our allies. **********In Vienna, we are negotiating, alongside our allies, on reductions in conventional force levels in Europe. These negotiations have gone on without real progress for over eight years. Because we are now facing diplomatic atrophy, we must urgently consider how to revitalize East-West discussions of conventional force reductions and stimulate progress in these talks. **********Our highest priority, in the past several months, has been completing preparations for negotiations with the Soviet Union on strategic arms. Here, too, we will be proposing major reductions to verifiable, equal agreed levels. Here, too, we will be presenting detailed proposals when negotiations open. **********The prospects for progress in each of these areas of arms control depend upon support of the President's defense programs. This imperative has been caricatured as a policy of building up arms in order to reduce them. This is simply not true. As President Reagan's proposals for intermediate range missiles make clear, we hope that we never have to deploy those systems. But we must demonstrate a willingness to maintan the balance through force deployments if we are to have any prospect of reducing and stabilizing it through arms control. 2 Examples of the Pattern **********Negotiations in the early 1970's, on a treaty limiting antiballistic missile systems, provide an historic example. At the time, the Soviets had already built a system of ballistic missile defenses around Moscow. The United States had deployed no such system. Arms control offered the only means of closing off an otherwise attractive and expensive new avenue for arms competition.  Yet it was not until the American Administration sought and secured Congressional support for an American ABM program that the Soviets began to negotiate seriously. The result was the 1972 treaty limiting antiballistic missile systems, which remains in force today. **********This same pattern was repeated more recently with intermediate range missiles. For years the Soviets had sought limits on U.S.  nuclear forces in Europe but refused to consider any limits upon their nuclear forces targeted upon Europe. Only after NATO took its decision of December 1979 to deploy U.S. Pershing 2 and groundlaunched cruise missiles did the U.S.S.R. agree to put its SS-20 missiles on the negotiating table. The Morality of the Issue **********In the area of strategic arms, as well, there is little prospect the Soviet Union will ever agree to equal limits at lower levels unless first persuaded that the United States is otherwise determined to maintain equality at higher levels. It is, for instance, unrealistic to believe that the Soviet Union will agree to reduce the most threatening element of its force structure, its heavy, multiwarheaded intercontinental missiles, unless it is persuaded that otherwise the United States will respond by deploying comparable systems itself. **********For many opposed to reliance on nuclear weapons - even for defense or deterrence - the issue is a moral one. For those who first elaborated the strategy of deterrence and for those who seek to maintain its effect this issue is also preeminently moral. A familiar argument is that, in a nuclear age, we must choose between our values and our existence. If nuclear weapons offer the only deferrent to nuclear blackmail, some would argue we should submit rather than pose the risk of nuclear conflict. This choice, however, is a false one.  By maintaining the military balance and sustaining deterrence, we protect the essential values of Western civilization -democratic government, personal liberty and religious freedom - and preserve the peace. In failing to maintain deterrence, we would risk our freedoms while actually increasing the likelihood of also suffering nuclear devastation. Avoiding the Extremes **********As human beings and free men and women, we must reject this false alternative and avoid the extremes of nuclear catastrophe and nuclear blackmail. In the nuclear age, the only choice consistent with survival and civilization is deterrence. **********An eminent theologian once described our age as one in which ''the highest possibilties are inextricably intermingled with the most dire perils.'' The scientific and technological advances so vital to our civilization also make possible its destruction. This reality cannot be wished away. **********Americans have always been conscious of the dilemmas posed by the nuclear weapon. From the moment that science unleashed the atom, our instinct and policy has been to control it. Those who direct America's defense policies today share completely the desire of people everywhere to end the nuclear arms race and to begin to achieve substantial reductions in nuclear armament. **********Confronted by the dire perils of such weapons, America has responded in a manner that best preserves both security and peace, that protects our society and our values and that offers hope without illusion. The strategy of deterrence has kept the peace for over 30 years. It has provided the basis for arms control efforts. And it offers the best chance to control and to reduce the dangers we face. Not Automatic Nor Cheap **********Deterrence is not automatic. It cannot be had on the cheap. Our ability to sustain it depends upon our ability to maintain the military balance now being threatened by the Soviet buildup. If we are to reinforce deterrence through arms control and arms reduction, we must convince the Soviets that their efforts to undermine the deterrent effect of our forces will not succeed. **********The control and reduction of nuclear weapons, based on deterrence, is the only effective intellectual, political and moral response to nuclear weapons. The stakes are too great and the consequences of error too catastrophic to exchange deterrence for a leap into the unknown. The incentives for real arms control exist and we have both the means and the duty to apply them. **********Let us be clear about our objectives in the nuclear era. We seek to reduce the risk of war and to establish a stable military balance at lower levels of risk and effort. By doing so today, we may be able to build a sense of mutual confidence and cooperation, offering the basis for even more ambitious steps tomorrow. But above all, we shall be pursuing the ''highest possibility'' for peace.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/11/world.print_headline: OUTSKIRTS OF BEIRUT BOMBED AS ISRAEL WARNS THE SYRIANS TO LEAVE BEFORE CITY FALLS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/11/world.body_text: **********Israeli warplanes and gunboats struck on the southern outskirts of Beirut today, and Israeli leaflets were dropped over the capital saying, ''In a short time, we will capture the city.'' **********The leaflets offered Syrian forces two safe routes from the city and warned that resistance would be ''tantamount to suicide and cause unnecessary bloodshed.'' **********At the same time, Israeli tanks and planes continued to exchange fire with the Syrians in the Bekaa Valley near the strategic road leading from Beirut to Damascus. Reporters who traveled the road today saw ruined automobiles, burning gasoline tankers and other signs of fierce exchanges in the area which was, on Wednesday, the scene of Syrian-Israeli dogfights in which Syrian missiles were destroyed. **********In Damascus, Syria's Information Minister, Ahmed Iskander Ahmed, said that Syrian troops would continue to fight in Lebanon ''for our Palestinian and Lebanese brothers and for our basic national security.'' (Page A14.) 25-Mile Zone Reported Cleared **********The chief Israeli military spokesman, Brig. Gen. Yaakov Even, said today that Israeli troops had cleared hostile forces out of a zone 25 miles north of the Israeli border zone in which Palestinian guns had been within range of Israel.  Clearing the 25-mile zone, Prime Minister Menachem Begin said Sunday, was the key objective of the invasion. **********The general also said Israeli planes downed 25 MIG's and 4 helicopter gunships over Lebanon, bringing the reported total to 61 MIG's and 5 helicopters since Sunday with no losses acknowledged by Israel. He added that Israeli fighter-bombers had attacked four Syrian antiaircraft missile batteries that he said had been moved into Lebanon during the night. The Israelis said Wednesday that they had destroyed all 19 batteries previously set up in the Bekaa Valley. (Page A12.) **********Palestinian sources here reported that they were still resisting the Israelis in the southern coastal cities of Sidon and Tyre and in the coastal town of Damur about nine miles south of Beirut. **********Reports from Lebanon tonight indicated that the Israelis were aiming heavy fire from Baruk at an area known as Mdeireij, a key intersection on the Damascus-Beirut road. **********There were also reports that the Israelis were still trying to move northward from areas in south central Lebanon. The strategy appeared to be aimed at isolating the Syrian troops in the Bekaa Valley as well as to cut off Beirut from the rest of Lebanon. **********At 10 A.M., as the fighting entered its fifth day, leaflets were dropped over Beirut urging the Syrian forces based in the city, along with Syrian-backed Palestinian guerrillas, to leave. **********The message, from Comdr. Amir Drori of Israel's Northern Command, was addressed to Brig. Mohammed Omar Halal of Syria. It said the Syrians should leave along designated routes because they were outmanned. The leaflet promised safe passage but also warned, ''In a short time, we will capture the city.'' There were no signs tonight that the offer for safe passage had been accepted. **********The leaflets heightened a fear here that the Israelis were poised to strike at Beirut, a fear that has grown steadily as the invasion force moved northward along the Mediterranean coast. **********Early today, Israeli jets attacked Palestinian refugee camps and installations in Beirut's southern suburbs. The airport, which has ceased operations, was also struck. Israeli gunboats bombarded the coastal road and the village of Khalde, which is situated near the airport, was also attacked. **********Wafa, the Palestinian press agency, said that Israel tried unsuccessfully last night to secure the southern port of Sidon, the scene of vicious battles between Palestinians and Israelis, but that the resistance was continuing. **********A spokesman for one Palestinian group, the Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine, said the Israelis also bombed Palestinian camps in the vicinity of the northern port city of Tripoli. **********Although the Israeli attacks continued on several fronts, the focus today was on the shellings and raids just south of the capital.  Early this afternoon there were fierce bursts of shelling and the roar of Israeli jets as the Palestinian camps of Sabra and Burj al-Barajneh, both just south of Beirut, were struck. Palestinian Quarter Struck **********Also struck today was a Palestinian quarter near the Arab university there. The Israeli attacks, and others, have sent Palestinian refugees streaming into Beirut to find shelter. **********The attacks were closest to Beirut when a district called Burj Abu Haidar was hit. It is located just north of an avenue called Corniche Mazraa, which unofficially is the boundary between Beirut proper and the city's southern suburbs. **********Beirut's coastal seafront has been declared a war zone by Palestinian guerrillas. Today it was filled with militiamen and Syrian soldiers on the lookout for Israeli gunboats. **********Lebanese political sources said tonight that earlier in the day an Israeli fighter plane was struck during the coastal attacks and that the pilot was seen bailing out over the Mediterranean Sea. **********The continuing air and land battles -as well as the Israeli threat to make Beirut itself a battleground - kept nearly all residents of Beirut indoors today. Water and Bread Shortages **********Shops were closed; streets were empty, except for militiamen, and some people left western Beirut to go to the city's eastern portion, which is controlled by Christian militiamen. **********Beirut continued to be plagued by water power and bread shortages.  Some people were hopeful that diplomatic pressure - particularly from President Reagan, who has called for a cease-fire - might deter the Israelis from attacking the city. **********Even as diplomatic efforts were under way, however, the mood here was skeptical and fearful as Palestinian guerrillas dug in along the sea and dispersed to firing stations all over the city.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/13/busin.body_text: **********New, nonresidential construction has declined for some time, but the weakening demand for the office space gained during the latest up cycle has been slow to show itself. That is beginning to change. **********Interviews with representatives of Coldwell, Banker & Company, the nation's largest commercial real estate broker, in Los Angeles, Chicago, Washington and New York, disclosed that demand for office space is slack, that vacancy rates are up and that rents are flat to down slightly from levels at the end of last year. **********''This is definitely the year of the tenant,'' said George Voris, of Coldwell, Banker's Washington office.  In Washington, Mr. Voris said that the vacancy rate has risen about 400 percent since the first of the year, to around 5 percent, and rental rates have come down as much as $2 to $3 a square foot, he added. **********The situation does not seem as grim in midtown Manhattan, although rents have stabilized and the vacancy rate has risen nearly 50 percent since the first of the year. **********''Things are slower, but this is still a good market,'' said John Cousins, Coldwell, Banker's resident sales manager for midtown commercial real estate. ''Vacancies are on the rise, but they are still less than 4 percent of available space, which is a manageable level.'' **********Coldwell, Banker representatives in Chicago and Los Angeles also acknowledged sharp - though tolerable - increases in vacancy rates.  While landlords had not begun to slash rents to attract tenants into new construction, other forms of discounts are being offered in both cities. **********''Some real deals are being cut with presublet space,'' said Jeffrey Barrett, resident manager of Coldwell, Banker's Chicago office. **********In Los Angeles, Allan Aufhammer, a Coldwell, Banker sales representative, said landlords are offering tenants two or three months of rent-free space as a way to fill recently completed buildings.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/20/busin.main_headline: Talking Business with Roger J Marzulla of Mountain States Legal Foundation Free Market Philosophy
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/20/busin.print_headline: Talking Business with Roger J Marzulla of Mountain States Legal Foundation Free Market Philosophy
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/20/busin.body_text: **********The Mountain States Legal Foundation, a five-year-old nonprofit law firm in Denver, gets a substantial part of its support from business sources. Unlike older public interest law groups, with their liberal orientation, Mountain States is part of a counterwave of public interest firms that bring a free market philosophy to court.  James G. Watt, the former president of Mountain States, was appointed Secretary of the Interior last year, and Roger J. Marzulla replaced him. The Reagan Administration shares Mountain States' views on many public land questions the foundation has addressed, so Mr. Marzulla thinks it has an opportunity to tackle broader issues such as business regulation and tax policy. Recently Mr. Marzulla, 34 years old, discussed the foundation's work. **********Q. What does the Mountain States Legal Foundation do? A. It does something absolutely crucial: It defends free enterprise, which we have tended over the last 20 years or so to downgrade. The fact is that civil liberties in this nation are dependent upon economic liberties, and the only economic system which is consistent with democracy is the free market system. If the Government controls the means of production, if it controls the way in which you make your living, then you cannot expect the Government to avoid controlling freedom of speech, freedom of religion and so on. **********Q. Has your focus changed since Mr. Watt left Mountain States? A.  We've taken on a number of additional issues. When Mr. Watt started as the only lawyer, he obviously didn't have the resources we have now, with 13 lawyers. There's a preconception that all we are involved in is the environment and that the Sierra Club is our only adversary, but that isn't so. We have a docket of 40 to 50 cases.  Our mandate is to defend the free enterprise system, private property rights and individual liberties against excessive Government intrusion. **********Q. Has the change in Administrations affected your program? A.  Primarily, it has put us on the other side of the counsel table.  During the last Administration, we were primarily engaged in bringing lawsuits to challenge the new regulations that were promulgated. Now the Adminstration's actions are being challenged by others. Our job now is more often to defend the Administration's actions. **********Q. What do you see as your most pressing issue? A. The use of the public lands. The Western United States is actually more than 50 percent owned by the Federal Government. Most of the mineral and energy resources of this nation are located in precisely that same area, and the Government has not been a good steward of those lands in terms of utilizing those natural resources. We become involved in cases where we see the Government going awry. Ultimately I would like to see privatization of a substantial portion of those lands. I believe those lands would be better taken care of in the hands of a rancher or an individual utilizing them for housing or for mineral development. Obviously, I'm not talking about the areas that have significant wilderness potential. **********Q. What kinds of cases are you involved in right now? A. The most significant business case we are working on right now is a challenge to the crude oil windfall profits tax - I should say the so-called windfall profits tax, because what it really is is an invidious severance tax. What that tax means is that if the American populace gets upset with a particular industry, it can take away that industry's profits. And if that can happen to oil, it can happen to any other industry. **********Q. Wouldn't the views of big business be well represented in court even if Mountain States didn't exist? A. When you talk of big business, you're talking about business with sufficient clout to be part of the system. We represent small business, like the mom-and-pop grocery stores that don't have the resources to be heard. Our view is that government regulation of things like trucking or communications ought not to occur. That puts us at odds with big business - those with the permits. There are many situations in which we do not take the same position as big business.  Tamar Lewin

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/02/world.main_headline: A CEASE-FIRE STOPS BIG BEIRUT BATTLE LASTING 14 HOURS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/02/world.print_headline: A CEASE-FIRE STOPS BIG BEIRUT BATTLE LASTING 14 HOURS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/02/world.body_text: **********Israeli forces bombarded Palestinian guerrilla positions and residential areas of west Beirut by land, sea and air for 14 hours today in the fiercest shelling of the besieged Lebanese capital since the Israeli invasion began June 6. **********The Israeli onslaught began at 3 A.M. and came to a halt shortly after 5 P.M. when a cease-fire arranged by the special American envoy, Philip C. Habib, went into effect. At least 70 people were killed and more than twice that number wounded in the barrages, security sources said. **********Israeli tanks tried to advance on Palestinian positions and refugee camps just south of Beirut International Airport and along the coastal highway leading from Ouzai to Beirut. Israelis Reach Terminal Building **********The Israeli armored units, which were already in control of the airport runways, managed to drive on the runways into the terminal building and a short distance down the road leading toward the city.  This left them only a few hundred yards from the biggest Palestinian refugee camp in west Beirut, Burj al Brajneh. **********But according to Palestinian sources and the state-run Beirut radio, the guerrillas were able to keep a toehold in the airport area and blocked the Israeli advance from Ouzai toward Beirut. **********Lebanon's President, Elias Sarkis, was quoted by the Beirut radio as remarking that the large-scale Israeli raid had come ''at a time when negotiations for the evacuation of the guerrillas were moving ahead.'' **********A three-way meeting had been scheduled for today between Palestinian, Lebanese and, indirectly, American officials, to discuss a timetable for withdrawal of the Palestine Liberation Organization fighters from west Beirut. The meeting was canceled, but Mr. Habib told Lebanese officials he hoped to reschedule the talks for Monday. **********P.L.O. officials said they believed that the Israeli raid had been intended to put more pressure on them to pull out from west Beirut unconditionally and immediately and that it reflected Israel's frustration at not having been able so far to obtain a withdrawal. **********The officials said that while they wanted the negotiations to go forward, the Palestinians had proved their ability to stand up to the Israelis and would continue to stick to their demands for what they consider an honorable withdrawal from west Beirut, preceded by a disengagement of forces and deployment of international peacekeeping troops. **********While the fighting raged around the airport, Israeli gunboats and artillery bombarded wide areas of west Beirut containing no guerrillas or even Palestinians, leaving whole neighborhoods devastated. **********So many buildings were set on fire in the southern suburbs of west Beirut that the entire area was engulfed in a huge black cloud of smoke through which not a single building could be made out. By late afternoon the sky, which had been perfectly clear, was full of black and white clouds. **********The Beirut radio said that at least 50,000 Israeli shells landed on west Beirut. The P.L.O. press agency said that Israeli fighterbombers had flown more than 165 sorties in a daylong wave of divebombing raids on Palestinian camps, gun positions and residential areas. **********P.L.O. officials were jubilant over the ability they said their fighters had shown to hold off the advance by Israeli tanks in a bitter firefight. Lebanese Angry at U.S. **********Lebanese Government officials involved in the negotiations with Mr. Habib over a guerrilla withdrawal are growing increasingly exasperated with what they describe as the Reagan Administration's inability to exert any pressure or control on the Israelis, even on so small an issue as getting the water supply for west Beirut turned on again. **********''The tail is wagging the dog and has been from the start,'' said Saeb Salam, the former Lebanese Prime Minister who has become the main intermediary between Yasir Arafat, the head of the P.L.O., and Mr. Habib. Mr. Salam gave as an example today's efforts to arrange a cease-fire. **********''I started calling Habib at 8 A.M. asking for a cease-fire,'' said Mr. Salam. ''I had Hani al-Hassan of the P.L.O. with me at the house all afternoon and they were ready anytime. Habib called me back and said he had a provisional agreement from Israel for a 2:30 P.M.  cease-fire. Then he called me back and said that wouldn't work; how about 3 P.M.? I said 'O.K.' Just before 3 P.M. he said it would have to be 3:30. Finally he called back and said the Israelis would agree to a cease-fire at 5 for certain, so it was 5 P.M.'' **********Mr. Salam described Mr. Habib as ''rather embarrassed on the phone'' at his inability to get the Israelis to agree to a ceasefire on a day when crucial negotiations had been planned with Mr. Habib himself. **********The Israeli attack on west Beirut began at 3 A.M. when Israeli tanks, moving down from around Shuweifat and the southern end of the eastern and western runways of the Beirut airport, began pushing toward the Palestinian refugee camps. **********Another group of Israeli armored personnel carriers and tanks tried driving through the Palestinians' front lines at Ouzai. The Ouzai attack, according to Palestinian military sources, was completely halted. **********In the airport, however, the Israelis were able to move into the terminal area and down the road a few hundred yards toward the Cocodi traffic circle, where they were halted by a combined force of Palestinian guerrillas, Syrian troops and Shiite militiamen fighting alongside the Palestinians. The Syrians were members of a Syrian force that had controlled the Cocodi area - a former amusement park near the airport - and who had remained in Beirut. **********A Palestinian military official said the guerrillas had used three main tactics to hold the Israelis back.  First, they kept up a steady barrage of ''area fire'' from their Katyusha rocket launchers on the Israeli armored units moving through the open ground around the airport. The official conceded that the effect of the Katyushas was negated somewhat by the fact that Israeli planes kept trying to knock them out all day, and consequently they had to be fired from the more protected built-up areas, which made accurate aiming difficult. Artillery Fire Concentrated **********Second, the guerrillas concentrated heavy 130-millimeter fire on the advancing columns. The 130-millimeter artillery pieces, the Palestinians' largest, still have not been destroyed by the Israeli planes. **********Finally, and most effectively, the official said, the guerrillas let the Israelis approach to within short range of their rocketpropelled grenades, RPG-7's, which they said were very effective in close-quarter fighting. **********The Palestinian press agency, Wafa, said that more than 80 Israeli soldiers were killed or wounded in the airport battle and that 30 Israeli armored personnel carriers, tanks and other vehicles were knocked out. **********Israeli gunboats, which bombarded the west Beirut coastline, approached close to the shore near the Ramlet el Baida beach but came under heavy fire and made no attempt to land troops. **********Apparently as a diversionary tactic, the Israelis also opened up with tank and artillery fire at the Museum and Galare Saman crossing points between east and west Beirut. At least 10 civilians were killed in Christian east Beirut when the guerrillas returned the fire, security sources said. **********It was west Beirut, however, that bore the brunt of the destruction. Hundreds of buildings throughout the southern suburbs of Fakhani, Bir Hassan and Corniche Mazraa, not to mention the Palestinian refugee camps, were pockmarked with shell holes, gutted by fire, riddled with shrapnel or completely destroyed. **********A drive through Fakhani and the Corniche Mazraa thoroughfare found buildings with their balconies torn loose and left dangling, their windows blown out and gaping holes in their walls. One building, with most of the facade blown away, looked like a big doll's house, with all the bedrooms and living rooms open to view.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/17/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Heublein Backed On General Cinema
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/17/busin.body_text: **********A Federal court order cleared the way today for Heublein Inc., the international food and beverage company, to buy more stock in the General Cinema Corporation. The two companies have been engaged in a takeover battle. **********Heublein, based in Farmington, Conn., has already purchased 380,800 shares, or about 3.8 percent, of General Cinema.  The United States District Court issued a temporary restraining order against the Federal Trade Commission, which had earlier said that Heublein could not purchase more General Cinema stock until April 2. **********The suit, which was filed on Monday, contended that the commission had not raised any objections on antitrust grounds to a merger of the two companies. In addition, the commission has given General Cinema approval to buy more Heublein stock. **********General Cinema, which is based in Boston, has purchased 2.1 million shares, or about 9.7 percent of the shares outstanding of Heublein.  It has said it plans to buy at least 15 percent of Heublein's stock and possibly as much as 49.9 percent. **********The soft-drink bottler and movie theater chain operator purchased more than 1 million shares of its own stock last week and its board has approved the purchase of another 2 million shares. **********Heublein had sales totaling $2.1 billion last year. General Cinema recorded sales of $825 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/09/busin.body_text: **********A Federal judge today denied a request from the McDonald's Corporation for a temporary restraining order that would have barred further airing of a Burger King advertising campaign against McDonald's Big Mac hamburgers. **********Chief United States District Judge C. Clyde Atkins refused to halt the ads after hearing arguments and viewing exhibits for almost two hours this afternoon, ruling that the nation's biggest fast-food chain had failed to prove that it had been harmed by the ads. **********McDonald's chief counsel, Gary Senner, admitted that Burger King's commercial contending that McDonalds' regular hamburgers are ''20 percent smaller'' is true, but he said the intent of the ad is ''false and misleading.'' **********McDonald's filed suit three weeks ago in an effort to keep Burger King's new $20 million ad campaign from starting. A hearing is scheduled in November on a motion for a permanent injunction.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/12/busin.body_text: **********Most top management people in magazines come up through advertising sales or circulation. **********Packaged goods is rare enough to cause a special look. **********S.H. Price, a 43-year-old known as Steve, is joining Newsweek Inc.  on Jan. 18 as executive vice president and general manager of the magazine's domestic edition. **********He is coming in from General Foods, where he has been a corporate vice president since 1977 and general manager of the beverage division since August 1980. He started with the company in 1960 with degrees in economics and industrial engineering and took a leave of absence to get an M.B.A. with distinction from Harvard University.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/07/busin.main_headline: Business World; New President Named At Sonat Subsidiary
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/07/busin.print_headline: Business World; New President Named At Sonat Subsidiary
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/07/busin.body_text: **********Sonat Inc., the renamed Southern Natural Resources Inc., has appointed N. Thomas Williams, 48, president of its Southern Forest Products subsidiary, based in Birmingham, Ala. At Southern Forest Products, which has more than 800,000 acres of timberland and operates paper mills, he succeeds Ronald L. Kuehn, 46, who, as previously announced, has become president and chief operating officer of the parent company. **********''We're in a very poor housing-start market and there are a lot of competitive pressures on our industry,'' Mr. Williams said in a telephone interview. ''The demand for plywood and lumber today is such that we have a number of our mills shut down. But we look, as markets improve, to get them back in operation.'' **********Mr. Williams had previously been with the Rust Engineering Company for eight years before joining Sonat in 1968 as a senior engineer at one of its units. He became vice president for engineering of Sonat, a position he will retain, in 1980. **********Mr. Kuehn, a lawyer, had been associated with Allied Artists Industries until 1970, when he came to Sonat as assistant secretary. He was appointed executive vice president and president of Southern Forest Products last year. **********''We're basically in a commodity business and as such, we're tied into the general economy of the country,'' Mr. Williams said. ''And we are mildly optimistic on the housing start situation.'' **********As for the possibility that Sonat might divest itself of Southern Forest Products, Mr. Williams noted that ''this is one of our five basic businesses and we certainly look forward to staying in the business in better economic times.'' He added, ''But anything is available for a price and we've always taken that position in looking at our assets.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/20/world.main_headline: FOES OF RIGHTIST LEADER IN SALVADOR TO WEAKEN HIS POWERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/20/world.print_headline: FOES OF RIGHTIST LEADER IN SALVADOR TO WEAKEN HIS POWERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/20/world.body_text: **********Christian Democratic politicians and some top military officials in El Salvador have taken a series of steps aimed at weakening the power of Roberto d'Aubuisson, President of the Constituent Assembly, and his rightist National Alliance Party. **********Although there has been no official announcement yet, it was reliably learned that President Alvaro Magana dismissed the Minister of Health, Col. Fernando Berios, two days ago. **********The Health Minister, a close associate of Mr. d'Aubuisson, had reportedly privately criticized the President and let it be known that he favored Mr. d'Aubuisson for the presidential post. **********On Thursday Miguel Muyshondt, another minister from Mr.  d'Aubuisson's party, which is known by its Spanish acronym, Arena, was embarrassed when all 8,000 employees of the Ministry of Agriculture walked out demanding higher wages. The employees of the Government tourist agency, which is also headed by an Arena member, have said they will join the work stoppage on Monday. **********The strike, though banned by a two-year-old decree, is the largest of its kind in recent Salvadoran history. The main movers behind the walkout, according to one member of the Government, are the opposition Christian Democratic Party. The party leadership, the sources said, is seeking to promote social pressure against the Arena forces who oppose the moderate economic and social changes on which the continuation of vast United States military and economic aid hinge. 200 Peasants Demonstrate **********Moreover, a group of 200 peasants demonstrated in the town of Santa Tecla, near the capital, last Wednesday denouncing the ''halting of the agrarian reform'' efforts and ''the corruption'' among officials involved in the program. **********Although a shakeup in the armed forces on Nov. 8 has been officially described here as a ''routine rotation,'' diplomats said the shift of seven top commanders also involved ''questions of loyalty'' to the Defense Minister, Gen. Jose Guillermo Garcia, who supports the United States. **********One diplomat here said that doubts had been raised about the loyalty of Col. Nicolas Carranza, now moved from the politically sensitive state communications agency, where he had security responsibility. to the Government electricity company. The army high command, according to this diplomat, believes that information intercepted by the agency was ''being provided to people other than Government officials.'' Colonel Carranza is close to Mr. d'Aubuisson, who proposed him as president of the nation after the March elections. **********Diplomats familiar with the inner workings of the Government here also said that in August and September military officers close to Mr. d'Aubuisson, a former major in the national guard, had tried to gather enough support among the officer corps to vote General Garcia out of office. One well-placed diplomat said that ''these were weeks of tension and pushing and shoving'' among the military. ''They got some votes against Garcia, but remained quite short,'' he said. ''If they have succeeded it would have been a democratic coup.'' **********Since then in Salvadoran political circles there has been much comment about tensions between General Garcia and Mr. d'Aubuisson. 'Absolutely No Differences' **********In an interview today Mr. d'Aubuisson denied these reports, saying there were ''absolutely no differences'' between him and the Defense Minister. He said that the report about an attempt to gather votes against General Garcia was ''absolutely untrue.'' This and the ''many other rumors spread against me,'' he said, are part of a campaign ''to discredit me.'' **********''On the contrary, I have seen a lot of companionship these days in the security forces,'' he said.  He also dismissed as ''rumor'' the maneuvers by his political opponents to weaken his power in the Constituent Assembly. Although the army high command and the United States Embassy are the determining factors in Salvadoran politics, the assembly is important because it is the scene of intense political bickering as a new constitution is being written. **********Sources close to the President's office said that one maneuver being planned by the Christian Democratic leadership was to vote Mr.  d'Aubuisson out of his assembly post. Failing this, the opposition would try to remove the Assembly Vice President, Maria Julia Castillo, a member of the National Conciliation Party and a supporter of Mr. d'Aubuisson.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/29/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene; Call to Hire 'One Person'
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/29/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene; Call to Hire 'One Person'
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/29/busin.body_text: **********PRESIDENT REAGAN'S proposal to solve the unemployment problem by urging every American business to hire ''just one person'' did not exactly get off to a flying start this week, as it collided with Bethlehem Steel's announcement that it was eliminating the jobs of nearly 10,000 workers in Lackawanna, N.Y., and Johnstown, Pa. **********Unfortunately, Bethlehem is not an isolated case. The Bureau of National Affairs reports that hiring projections for the first quarter of 1983 are the lowest recorded since it began to survey employers on the job outlook in 1974. Its new survey finds that only 9 percent of the employers who responded plan an increase in their production work forces in the first quarter of the new year. If anything, the survey results were biased on the optimistic side, since only companies still in business could respond. **********Interpreting Mr. Reagan's proposal, Edwin Meese 3d, the President's counselor, said: ''This may really involve in some cases not letting someone go that they might have to, by staggering work hours or something like that. That's what the President is talking about.'' **********But businesses, struggling to survive, are trying to put their balance sheets in better shape by cutting payrolls. The Bureau of National Affairs finds the proportion of companies with workers on layoff at a record level, with layoffs more common among employers with fewer than 1,000 workers than among larger companies. While the pain may be more widespread in small businesses, it may be more intense in heavy industry. Nearly half of the steel industry's 450,000 workers have been laid off, probably half of them permanently. **********Clearly Mr. Reagan found the simplicity of his hire-one-worker proposal appealing, because, he said, ''There are more businesses in the United States than unemployed.'' According to the Census, in 1977, the last year for which data are available, there were 14.7 million businesses in the United States, and last month there were less than 12 million unemployed workers. But 11.3 million of the businesses were proprietorships, most of which have no or few employees. **********For Mr. Reagan, it is not just a question of numbers, which are not his strong point, but the ''neighborly spirit'' of the thing. He seems to see unemployment as what economists call a ''microeconomic'' problem, in which every individual and business can solve the problem on his, her or its own initiative. Solutions involving Government are decried as ''quick fixes.'' **********A reporter last week reminded Mr. Reagan that he had spoken on various occasions of his father's losing his job during the Christmas holidays during the Great Depression, and asked the President what he thought his father's and mother's reactions would have been if the Congress of that period had passed a $5 billion bill ''that would have gotten him back to work right away when you were little.'' **********Mr. Reagan replied, ''Well, I've always thought my father, God rest his soul, had the common sense that he would know that temporary fixes wouldn't work.'' **********But when his father finally did get a job, Mr. Reagan added, ''it happened to be for the government.'' He and the county supervisor of the poor, the President said, ''shared a secretary and were in charge of the help - they called it relief in those days - for the people in our community.'' **********Yet his father believed in free private enterprise. He went around town, Mr. Reagan said, lining up private jobs for the unemployed, who would come into his office and say: ''When is it going to be my turn? When do you get to my name again? It's been a long time since I've had some work.'' **********''And guess what?'' the President asked rhetorically. ''The Federal Government then intervened and figured it out that they couldn't take that work, because if they took that work they were denied relief. **********''So they were forced onto permanent relief,'' he said. ''They couldn't work.'' **********However, when President Reagan took office, a person on welfare - Aid to Families with Dependent Children - could keep $30 plus onethird of his or her earnings without loss of welfare benefits.  That provision, ironically enough, was knocked out by the celebrated tax act of 1981, which made earnings from work by a welfare recipient subject to taxation at a 100 percent rate. **********Unemployment certainly has its ''micro'' as well as its ''macro'' aspects. But the big determinant of employment and unemployment is the course of the national economy. The decline of gross national product at an estimated annual rate of 2.2 percent in the final quarter of 1982 almost certainly means higher unemployment, no matter how much neighborly spirit businesses may feel. There is simply no substitute for effective monetary and fiscal policies to get the economy growing more strongly again, to get unemployment down.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/19/busin.body_text: **********The GTE Corporation, citing increased revenues in its telephone operations, said its third-quarter net income rose 13.8 percent, to $199.1 million, or $1.11 a share, from $175 million, or $1.03 a share, in the similar period last year. **********GTE, the nation's second-largest phone company after the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, said its revenues rose more than 9.2 percent, to $2.98 billion, from $2.73 billion. **********The company said that telephone rate increases were a major factor in improved telephone operation revenues and net income. https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/28/busin.main_headline:
ECONOMIC AFFAIRS;
A PROPOSED FLAT RATE FOR FAT CATS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/28/busin.print_headline:
ECONOMIC AFFAIRS;
A PROPOSED FLAT RATE FOR FAT CATS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/28/busin.body_text: **********NOW that the Reagan program of supply-side miracles is bogged down i n recession, controversy and red ink, it is time for a bright new i dea to capture the fancy of journalists and divert the attention of v oters. What will this new fad be? A good guess is that the ''Flat T axers'' will replace the ''Supply Siders'' on the hit parade of e conomic slogans. **********In the next few months, of course, the debate about taxes will revolve around finding the economic equivalent of a perpetual motion machine: A tax measure that stimulates the economy without raising the deficit. **********The net effect of the two most current tax proposals - the gasoline tax cum road building program and moving up the 1983 tax cut - is unclear but will probably raise both the deficit and unemployment in early 1983. **********Whatever the merits of current proposals, the long-term question about the fundamental structure of our tax system will surely reemerge next year, and the flat tax will be one of the leading proposals. **********In preparation for this assault on the nation's coffers and common sense, the following is a quick review of the forces.  The ''flat tax'' represents a complete overhaul of personal and business income taxation, replacing the current system of graduated tax rates with a single uniform tax rate applicable to all income. **********Although there are numerous half-baked flat-tax plans, the most sophisticated version, and the one I will use as a model, has been elaborated by Robert Hall and Alvin Rabushka, economists from Stanford University. **********The Hall-Rabushka proposal has four features. First, all businesstype income (rents, profits, etc.) is taxed as it flows through companies and partnerships and is completely excluded from personal income taxes. Second, the personal tax system includes all labor income (including fringe benefits) and disallows all deductions. Third, all capital gains and losses are excluded from income at every level. Finally, all business and personal income (above exemptions for individuals) is subject to a uniform 19 percent tax. **********Discussions of a flat tax, and comparison with the current tax system, generally focus on issues of the breadth of the tax system, incentives, simplification and distribution. **********Breadth of the tax system. The most important and politically most problematic feature of the flat tax would be to include in taxable income a wide variety of sources of income that are currently sheltered from taxes. For example, a comprehensive flat tax would not allow deductions or exclusions for interest, for state and local taxes on home mortgages, for charitable contributions, or for fringe benefits. The flat tax proposal would also tax income currently buried in the underground economy - items like baby sitters' wages or under-the-counter plumbing jobs - an idea that is more fantasy then reality. **********Incentives. The second key feature of the flat tax is the contention that lower tax rates will provide the incentive for people to work harder, save more and innovate faster. Including both business and personal taxes, income today is taxed at rates anywhere from zero to 75 percent. And there is little doubt that high tax rates, say from 50 percent on up, induce tax avoidance or may simply discourage work or savings. **********By lowering average marginal tax rates from the current 30 percent range to 19 percent, flat taxers argue that there will be an explosion of work effort and innovation. Mr. Hall and Mr. Rambushka estimate, for example, that the gross national product will be 9 percent, or $270 billion, higher than otherwise at the end of the decade following the implementation of their proposal. Impressive if true, but don't bet on it.SIMPLIFICATION. One of the major arguments of flat taxers is that i t will simplify the systems. The Hall-Rabuska proposal provides a v ery innovative way to simplify business taxes. **********As concerns the personal tax, it is simply incorrect that the flat tax will itself allow an enormous simplification. Many complexities arise from requirements for verification or from the need to differentiate between different types of income, not from the graduated tax structure. **********Base broadening might allow some simplification (thus, the tedious capital gains calculation could be eliminated). On the other hand, some base broadening (including the value of fringes and free meals in income, or documenting baby sitters' wages) would add considerable complexity. But replacing the broad-based graduated personal tax with a flat tax generates no simplicity - it merely facilitates the arithmetic. **********Distribution. As Mr. Hall and Mr. Rabushka admit with charming candor when discussing effects on income distribution, ''Now for the bad news.'' This Strangelovable comment is reminiscent of the mythical American general advocating bombing the Russians into the stone age. After describing the Soviet wasteland, he adds, ''Now for the bad news - New York will be a pile of rubble.'' **********The main bad news about the flat tax, then, is that it would lead to a wholesale redistribution of after-tax income from middle income groups to the rich. As shown in the accompanying table, those with incomes below $50,000 would find themselves paying higher taxes, while those above that point would receive tax reductions, huge ones at the top. **********Those at the very high end, with incomes of $1 million or more, might well begin to salivate in anticipation of a reduction of almost three-quarters of their 1984 taxes and an increase in their after-tax income of 45 percent. By contrast, a family with $25,000 of income will see its taxes rise 18 percent. **********In reviewing these considerations, what is a reasonable way to weigh the competing arguments on the flat tax?  The first point is that the central objective of tax reform should be to broaden the tax base. By eliminating special tax treatment - such as for charitable contributions, homeowning, saving and medical care - tax rates can be lowered considerably on normal occupations and investments. Base broadening will also promote simplification by removing the requirement to separate different categories of income or consumption. **********Second, once the base is broadened, the further gain in simplification or incentives from a flat rate is highly uncertain.  There is no professional consensus on the boost our economy will receive from lower tax rates, with estimates ranging from nil at the low end, to the Hall-Rabushka estimates at the high end. Today's economic malaise has many roots, but progressive taxation is surely not the major contributor to the decline of the West. **********In the end, then, the decision to move from a graduated to a flat tax must rest on a value judgment -whether we find progressive taxation just, and whether the uncertain costs of high tax rates are too high a price to pay for the equality we receive. **********In my view, the political benefits from perceived fairness and justice of a progressive tax system are far too important to be sacrificed for the small and conjectural increase in material well being proffered by the flat taxers.

Mills - to consolidate its advertising in a single agency. **********The brands are Love's Baby Soft Fragrances and Mudd, a facial cleansing mask, both previously handled by the Jan Zwiren Advertising Agency in Chicago; Pamprin, a menstrual pain reliever; Corn Silk face powder, and Sun-In hair lightener. **********''We feel basically that great advertising is our single most important leverage point with these consumer products and we need it across the entire line,'' Mr. Mills said.
