https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/08/world.body_text: **********As soldiers with automatic weapons stood guard, Guatemalans voted today in elections for President, Vice President, members of Congress and municipal officials. **********Guatemalans say that if the elections are not tainted by fraud, as they have frequently been in the past, and if the army allows the people's choice to assume the presidency of Central America's most populous country, there is a possibility they could lead to a peaceful solution to the civil war here. **********At gas stations, schools, commercial arcades and municipal buildings, people waited in block-long lines for five or six hours before having their identification cards checked and receiving the three large paper ballots, one for President and Vice President, one for the national Congress and the third for municipal officials. Elections 'Our Last Chance' **********''The elections are our last chance and everybody knows it,'' said a political leader. It is an assessment heard often here, from Guatemalans and United States officials. **********Guatemala's leaders are also aware that an honest election is a prerequisite for the United States military aid that they consider crucial if they are to defeat a leftist-led revolution that appears to be as strong as the one in neighboring El Salvador. **********Four presidential candidates, all conservatives who have vowed to destroy the leftist guerrilla movement, are vying to succeed Gen.  Fernando Romeo Lucas Garcia. The winner will take office for a fouryear term beginning July 1. **********General Angel Anibal Guevara, the former Minister of Defense, is backed by the Army High Command, which in 1974 and 1978 imposed its candidate amid charges of fraud. He also has the backing of the ruling Revolutionary and Institutional Democratic Parties and the new National Unity Front. **********Former Vice President Mario Sandoval Alarcon is the stridently anti-Communist candidate of the National Liberation Movement. He sponsored rightist paramilitary squads in the 1960's and says that he controls a ''private army'' of 5,000 men. **********Gustavo Anzueto Vielman, a United States-trained architect, is the law-and-order candidate of the Authentic Nationalist Party, which is dominated by Gen. Carlos Arana Osorio, Guatemala's President from 1970 to 1974. His supply-side economic platform proposes eliminating all but a few of the country's some 54 taxes. **********Alejandro Maldonado Aguirre is the nominee of the National Renovation Party and the Christian Democratic Party. Mr. Maldonado, a former Guatemalan delegate to the United Nations, is regarded as the least conservative of the four candidates. Candidate's Aide Is Slain **********By late this afternoon, there had been no reports of violence related to the voting in this agricultural and industrial city of 80,000 120 miles west of the capital. But the ''no holds barred'' campaign, as one diplomat characterized it, in which candidates accused opponents of murdering supporters, wore bulletproof vests and traveled in armored cars flanked by heavily armed body guards, ended with more bloodshed. **********The chief of security for General Guevara was killed when a bomb destroyed the armor-reinforced vehicle in which he was traveling.  Another person was also killed in the blast Saturday morning and six were injured. General Guevara's campaign manager was assassinated Feb. 6. **********And Saturday night, the house of Mr. Sandoval Alarcon, was riddled with automatic weapons fire. No one was injured.  Voting is obligatory for all literate Guatemalans 18 years of age and older. Failure to vote is punishable by a fine equivalent to $20 or two days in jail. **********At 11:15 A.M., a 28-year-old mason who had been standing in line for five hours on the outskirts of this city, hunched over a small table next to a stucco-covered adobe brick building and scratched an X over the symbol representing the party of his choice. After voting, he dipped a finger in an indelible substance that is read by a special hand-held instrument being used to prevent people from voting twice. Long Wait for Voters **********He was only the 92d person to vote here since the polls opened at 7 A.M. More than 300 people leaned against or sat on the brick wall that ran along a now dry field of harvested corn stalks. Many women, a few in the traditional brightly colored hand-woven skirts, held umbrellas to shield them from the midday mountain sun. **********At 13 voting tables set up at a vocational school, one eight voting places in the city, 160 to 192 people had voted by 1:30 P.M. No one was allowed to enter the polling places after 6 P.M., but the tables remained open until midnight to allow those already in line to vote.  Counting of the votes was not expected to begin until later today. **********Asked why he endured the tedious wait in order to vote, a 49-yearold government electrician who had been standing in the sun for four hours said, ''It's an obligation.'' **********In the 1978 presidential elections, abstentionism was about 65 percent; in the municipal elections two years ago, it approached 80 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/12/busin.main_headline: HOW TO PICK THE STANDOUTS, STANDBYS AND CYCLES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/12/busin.print_headline: HOW TO PICK THE STANDOUTS, STANDBYS AND CYCLES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/12/busin.body_text: **********Although everyone is agonizing over prospects for a slow economic recovery, what may be less than ideal for business and the population as a whole may be just what the stock market needs. A slow recovery is unlikely to reinflate the economy, and gradual growth may keep interest rates at a level low enough to provide a sustained recovery. **********That would be good news for investors, who are already savoring a strong stock market. Now they can expect a spurt in corporate profits. **********In 1983, after-tax profits may be up as much as 15 percent, following a 15 percent decline in 1982. Moreover, it is likely that per- share earnings for the Dow Jones industrial average of 30 of the nation's premier blue-chip companies will jump 26 percent or so, to $120 in 1983. In 1982, Dow earnings will be about $95. **********Assuming no rise in the current price/earnings ratio of 10 for the Dow - since 1960, the multiple has ranged from 6.2 to 22.9 - the blue-chip average could reach 1,200. Chances for further market profits in the months ahead would be good. But now that the market has risen more or less indiscriminately, investor selectivity becomes a critical concern. There are several ways to go. The investor can ride the ''cyclical'' roller coaster, buying shares of companies whose profits rise and fall with the economy. Or he can climb aboard the ''cyclical growth'' train, buyings stocks of companies whose profits advance from recession setbacks to successively higher levels with each economic expansion. **********Other investors will fly the ''classic growth'' airliner, those companies offering a reasonably certain 10 to 15 percent growth in earnings each year. Or the investor can embark on the rocket of ''high growth'' and pray the mission is not aborted. **********Cyclical Stocks **********A modestly advancing economy may do little for the profits of cyclical companies and even less for their shares. Leon Cooperman, market strategist at Goldman, Sachs, wrote in September that a broadbased commitment to cyclicals was ''premature'' and added that evidence of an economic recovery was important before investors took the plunge. In whatever cyclical area, the strongest companies are, of course, safest. **********In the transportation group, highly leveraged airlines have been a favorite trading vehicle in the past. But slow economic growth will restrain traffic gains, curtailing revenue increases. **********On the other hand, moderating inflation helps airlines keep their operating costs in line. Lower interest rates reduce the cost of carrying their heavy debt. Those ameliorative factors could provide dramatic changes in profitability with only modest revenue gains.  Delta is a perennial favorite among major carriers. The regionals Southwest and Frontier are favored by Wall Street. **********Automobile companies are considered by many to be among the best of all cyclicals since their fortunes are tied to the brightening outlook for increasing consumer spending. For months now, Wall Street has been recommending shares of both General Motors and Ford, and their shares have already risen sharply. **********Chrysler, which may be coming back from the brink of bankruptcy, is considered an interesting speculation. Chrysler's break-even point has been dramatically lowered so that relatively small gains in revenue would bring sharp gains in profit. Peter Lynch, portfolio manager for the top-rated Fidelity Magellan Fund, considers Chrysler to be one of the most attractive cyclical plays. He is especially impressed with the company's $1 billion cash trove. The stock has more than doubled this year, however. **********The near-term outlook for capital goods companies is less clear.  Deere and Sundstrand could excel. James R. McCann, an analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds, cites Sundstrand's leadership position and a proven ability to gain market share. But he recently reduced the stock from a buy to a hold for the near term after paring his current earnings estimate. He still favors the shares for the long term. Wall Street analysts had been expecting $3.75 a share this year, which would be the first drop in a decade, reflecting weak power transmission and commercial aerospace orders. **********Railroad shares, long-favored by the investment community as natural resource plays because of large holdings of mineral-bearing lands, are, generally speaking, believed to be relatively unattractive holdings in the present disinflationary environment.  Robert Long, who follows the rails for the First Boston Corporation, believes the most leveraged carriers should do well in a modest economic recovery. **********The steel industry, the essense of so-called smokestack America and the very backbone of industrial production, is deeply troubled today. James Lack, a Boston-based financial consultant, says that careful analysis of steel company income statements and balance sheets indicates that on an inflation-adjusted basis some steel companies do not operate profitably, even in good times. **********He said: ''I agree with the analysts who charge that long-term borrowings are being used to pay dividends in some instances. Perhaps the most telling comment about the industry came with U.S. Steel's acquisition of Marathon Oil. That was clearly a decision by management to reduce drastically its dependence on steel.'' **********Major chemical companies are part of smokestack America and so need a recovery of major proportions for enhanced profitability. Current modest growth prospects may not bring them major market gains. **********Richard A. Derbes of Oppenheimer & Company says that a lot of companies with exposure in autos and housing may do well since ''we expect major jumps in production even though, historically, the numbers may be small.'' He adds: ''We've been recommending PPG Industries, which is certainly a cyclical. But two-thirds of PPG's sales relate to autos and housing.'' **********Housing starts are expected to reach 1.6 million units annually by 1984, up from about a million units in 1982, reflecting lower mortgage rates and heavy pent-up demand. If the rates stay down, there could be major growth in the housing and building materials markets. But it is probably too early to seek share gains here. **********Home builders will be a more direct beneficiary of improving trends. The well-financed Ryland Group and Ryan Homes are being talked about. **********Specialty companies such as Standard Brands Paint and Lowe's Companies, a 231-unit retail building materials concern, are widely mentioned. But Jim Walter, Owens-Corning Fiberglas and Armstrong World Industries, all troubled with asbestos-related litigation, remain out of favor. **********On the other hand, savings and loan stocks, which will benefit in any developing housing boom, have already moved up sharply -as much as 200 percent, says Jerome Baron, who follows the group for First Boston. He is looking for further advances based on the expectation of continued moderate interest rates through 1984. **********Retail companies, expected to be early beneficiaries of a pickup in consumer spending, have advanced sharply. Federated Department Stores and J.C. Penney are called quality long-term commitments. Wal-Mart is growing faster than other discount chains. Toys 'R' Us is a standout specialty chain. Revco Drug and Rite Aid are being written up among drugstore companies. **********Utility companies have benefited from disinflation and lower interest rates. American Telephone and Telegraph, soon to be a former utility, is favored as it prepares to spin off operating companies while retaining its highly regarded Western Electric technology and Bell Laboratories. **********Cyclical Growth Stocks **********The rising profits offered by cyclical growth companies in successive economic recoveries make them continually popular.  Broadcasters lead the cyclical growth companies because their airwave franchises produce high cash flow. These companies usually commit limited sums to capital expenditure since it is not necessary to make constant additions to plant. Moreover, broadcast asset values tend to grow at rates well in excess of inflation. **********Capital Cities Communications, Cox Broadcasting, LIN Broadcasting and Storer Broadcasting have been successful and have good prospects.  Storer and Cox are heavy participants in cable television, whose long-term prospects are bright. Meanwhile, they are spending heavily on wiring within their separate cable franchises. **********Some cyclical growth issues combine both airwave and newspaper franchises. Among these are Gannett, Harte-Hanks Communications and Knight-Ridder Newspapers. Edward Dunleavy of Salomon Brothers has had a buy recommendation on Gannett for a year. He believes U.S.A. Today, the chain's new national daily newspaper, is somewhat risky. But he thinks management ''has the discipline'' to discontinue U.S.A. Today if it is not successful. ''Early results are favorable,'' he said, ''but it's too soon to say if it will succeed.'' **********Natural resource companies, once a favorite inflation hedge, have fallen victim to moderating price increases. Companies with large timber holdings were highly valued by investors as recently as 18 months ago. Everyone thought timber would continue to appreciate because of the scarcity factor. Now that inflation has eased, such holdings could lag. **********But Chad E. Brown of Kidder, Peabody notes that both Weyerhaeuser and Georgia-Pacific have done well in the bull market. He believes they will continue to do so if interest rates keep coming down since the housing outlook will be improved. Georgia-Pacific's new management has cut the dividend, ''an indication of a more conservative outlook on housing,'' Mr. Brown said. On balance, he added, ''that's a favorable development.'' **********Inflation comments apply to oil shares, too. Many oil stocks produced tenfold gains and more after the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries raised the price of oil by a factor of 10 in the 1970's. Performance in the last 18 months, during a period of temporary oil glut, has been dismal. It is the rare oil company that has Wall Street's blessing today. **********Still, Shell Oil has its fans, as does Standard Oil (Indiana). Both have substantial reserves, heavy cash flow and good refining capability. Analysts have little enthusiasm for the international oils for now. **********Gas production companies have considerable gas on hand. It is widely assumed the excess will not be worked off until 1984. Oil service companies may not impress investors for many months to come.  Halliburton and Schlumberger, old favorites, have lost popularity. **********In the lodging industry, shares have rallied sharply and modest economic growth means further gains could be difficult. La Quinta Motor Inns, a San Antonio-based chain, sold at 20 times earnings recently. Analysts are impressed with its five-year annual profit growth of 27 percent. **********President Reagan's reluctance to cut back on planned defense spending increases is a plus for investors in se-lected defense shares. Analysts emphasize electronic specialists such as Loral and Tracor. Among major contractors, Boeing may be suspect due to dependence on weak commercial airline orders. **********The recent upswing in Atlantic City casino profitability has focused attention once again on gaming industry shares after two years in a stock market backwater. Golden Nugget is considered a well-managed casino company since it produces the industry's best profit margins. **********In the fast food area, Steven A. Rockwell of Alex. Brown & Company says the group outperformed the market in 1982 but underperformed it in the summer rally. **********''The reason the stocks have done well this year is the disinflation scenario that brings down food costs and controls labor costs,'' he said. ''Both these developments help margins. On the sales side, disinflation means more disposable income and greater demand for fast food restaurants.'' So far, there has been no increase in sales, he added. But he expects the sales to pick up sometime during 1983, and that could well carry the stocks higher, he concluded. **********In the service company sector, A.C. Nielsen has been regarded as a quality holding. Its prospects for continued success reflect the company's dominant market position in the field of television ratings. **********The financial services sector ranks among the most promising industry groups. Many believe these issues will move out of the cyclical growth category to become classic growth companies in this decade. **********Analysts are beginning to focus on insurance, bank and brokerage companies as potential market leaders. The few remaining independent brokerage firms are expected to get careful scrutiny as possible takeovers in the years ahead. **********In insurance, the Kemper Corporation, a casualty insurance company, has become a financial services supermarket with the recent acquisition of Prescott, Bell & Turben, and Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards, stockbrokers. Aetna and Travelers, among multiple-line companies, are in many institutional portfolios. Jefferson-Pilot and U.S. Life are leaders among life insurers. **********Shearson/American Express, Sears, Roebuck and Transamerica have become diversified financial service companies and get Wall Street attention. **********Banks are benefiting from an improved interest-rate environment but are suspect due to concerns over credit quality. Earlier weakness in some bank shares reflected concern over Mexico's possible default on loans from United States banks and other troubling international financial developments. **********Citicorp and Morgan are said to be quality major bank holdings. The regional Sun Belt banks, particularly those in Florida and Texas, get the most attention in view of their impressive growth potential.  Barnett Banks of Florida and Texas Commerce are analyst choices, as is Valley National of Phoenix, Ariz. **********Classic Growth Stocks **********The so-called nifty fifty growth stocks dominated institutional portfolios in the 1960's and early 1970's. For years, these shares carried excessive price/earnings multiples. The high multiples persisted long after the general market slumped in 1970 and 1971. But in 1973 and 1974, most of these isssues were dumped by institutions.  One disappointing quarter was enough to start the move. **********For almost a decade, these classic growth issues have taken a back seat as institutions have focused on smaller high-growth companies.  But the Nifty Fifty are beginning to find favor again. Many believe large-capitalization growth issues will be market leaders all this decade. **********The Nifty Fifty's fall from favor reflected the realization by institutions that these companies could not in fact control their own destinies. They could not continue to post 15 percent earnings growth no matter what the economic environment, the institutions concluded. **********The oil crisis proved this point emphatically. Raw material costs soared and profit margins were squeezed for such stalwarts as Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, Procter & Gamble, Eastman Kodak and Merck. Their shares were heavily sold. **********But these enterprises have adjusted. They have dif-ferent cost structures now, but new products and methods have restored growth.  P.& G., whose margins dropped in part due to higher raw material costs following the oil crisis, has introduced new products and has adjusted pricing to cover its added raw material costs. Recently, its return on equity has rebounded along with profits. **********In the beverage sector, Coca-Cola is the choice. But its acquisition of Columbia Pictures last June dismayed fans who liked Coca-Cola as a pure play in the highly profitable beverage business, which Coke dominates. The company's 1983 earnings are expected to rise 12 percent. **********Drug companies, such as Abbott Laboratories, American Home Products and SmithKline Beckman, offer classic growth opportunities.  Hospital supply and hospital management began doing exceptionally well with increased government emphasis on medical services years ago. Johnson & Johnson, despite the Tylenol setback, remains a leader and is expected to regain earnings momentum quickly. Similarly, American Hospital Supply and Baxter Travenol offer solid growth prospects. **********International Business Machines, the industry leader in mainframe computers, has recovered its glamour image with institutional investors to a degree. That reflects in part its accelerating earnings growth. But this is a short-term factor. I.B.M. is so big that its fortunes these days have become more reflective of the economy. **********The mainframe computer business is becoming a mature industry and market saturation is approaching. Moreover, minicomputers from such aggressive manufacturers as Digital Equipment and microcomputers from Intel and others are so powerful these days that they are chipping away at I.B.M.'s bread-and-butter mainframe market. **********Two companies dominate in the entertainment and leisure area: Warner Communications and Walt Disney Productions. Warner has become a diversified entertainment company whose acquisition of Atari in 1976 added spectacularly to earnings. Disney is no longer in the high growth phase of the 1960's and 1970's but has solid prospects for satisfying earnings gains. **********High Growth Stocks **********No sector of the stock market is so appealing, so seductive, so fraught with peril yet so full of promise as the high growth area.  High growth is virtually synonymous with high technology though an occasional company without it offers the hoped-for 25 percent annual growth. **********Microprocessors, computer software, telecommunications, robotics, biotechnology and medical technology are major areas of high growth.  Companies that offer smaller computer systems with specialized applications often excell. NBI, a word processing company based in Denver, has shown 40 percent annual earnings growth over five years.  Tandem, known for durable terminals, has had five-year average growth of 45 percent a year. The older Wang Laboratories has provided 35 percent annual earnings growth, and Computervision, a computer graphics leader, has done well. **********After serious market setbacks last year and early this year, these and many other high-technology companies have roared back and are believed to be richly priced by those who fear high growth will falter. **********The telecommications sector offers MCI and Mitel, which have muchrooming sales and earnings.  Genentech, though public, has not fully emerged from the developmental stage. Its modest profits to date represent consulting income and not earnings arising out of its gene-splicing efforts. At present, Genentech, has not produced earnings growth, much less the 25 percent growth expected by investors in the high growth area.  However, the approval of Humulin, an insulin derived from human sources, may begin a flow of profits that could be impressive over time. Eli Lilly is marketing the new substance, and Genentech earns royalties. **********Investors monitor these and other technology companies carefully.  Competition arrives quickly and can change prospects dramatically.  BESIDES PROVIDING Wall Street with ample opportunities for investment, the computer age enables analysts and money managers to sift through a myriad of data on thousands of companies in search of only those stocks that meet certain investment criteria. Considering the speed with which this can be done and the varied combinations of criteria that can be fed into a computer, it is no wonder that the so-called bargain stocks do not remain undiscovered for long and that Wall Street is called an efficient market place. **********In pursuit of value, for instance, an analyst might ask the computer to screen out those stocks that are selling at a price below their equity, or book, value per share. Since equity is what remains after a company's liabilities are subtracted from its assets, this measure indicates which stocks are good buys based on their company's current net worth. **********To narrow that list of stocks even further, the analyst might ask the computer to screen out only those that also have most recently shown earnings high enough to result in a return on equity of at least a certain percentage. **********The four stock tables in this section are based on screens that answer some of the most topical investment questions of the day. One focused on earnings growth. Another sought out stocks with the strongest dividend growth. A third screen concentrated on stocks with low price/earnings ratios. And the fourth culled out the stocks that have been the best performers for the year to date. **********The tables were compiled by Media General Financial Services, a diversified communications company, from its data base of 3,800 companies listed on the New York and American Stock Exchanges or traded over the counter. Stocks trading for $1 or less were not included in the screenings. Trading prices are taken from the closing of Nov. 17, and the published lists include only the top performers in any given category. **********Investors should not purchase a stock just because it is listed on one of these tables, however. Far more analysis is required and an investor should consult his broker. The computer screens merely narrow the field when certain standards are set. The data by which the stocks are selected is, by necessity, historical. Current earnings and financial data that have yet to be reported may have taken a turn for the worse. An investor should ask, for instance, why a stock is trading at a relatively low level. **********The first table (Page 37) lists the stocks with the most impressive earnings growth in recent years. Many investors favor such stocks on the theory that if history repeats itself they will be ahead of the game. To be named, a stock first had to show positive and increasing earnings for the last five years. **********It also had to have an average annual growth rate for that period of at least 20 percent. In addition, all the stocks listed had to have a profit margin on sales of at least 10 percent and an aboveaverage return on equity of at least 13.5 percent for the last 12 months. **********To a large portion of the market, though, earnings growth is only important if it insures rising dividends. That is why Table 2 (Page 38) places its emphasis on stocks with the highest annual dividend growth rate in the last five years. To be included, the dividend growth must have been consistently positive for each of the last five years and the latest annual dividend has to offer at least a 5 percent yield on the current trading price. To monitor earnings strength of these high-dividend stocks, the rate of return on the latest 12-month earnings is also included. **********For those investors who like the best of both worlds, high returns and low prices, there is Table 3 (Page 46). Here, the first priority was to search for stocks with an above-average return on equity of at least 13.5 percent for the last 12-month reporting period. In the period of disinflation and relatively slow economic growth that is predicted, an historically high return on equity is important because it shows a company is productive and can make the most of what it has. Beyond that, a dividend yield of at least 5 percent was specified. This was aimed at insuring an investor a tangible return on his investment while he waits for the stock's price to appreciate. **********Also requested as measures of value for Table 3 were a trading price of no more than 80 percent of common equity and a price/earnings ratio (trading price to latest 12-month earnings per share) that is equal to or less than the average 8.8 of large stocks listed on the Big Board. Since the price-earnings ratio is actually a reflection of investors' perception of future earnings growth, a relatively low ratio signals that either the market is not expecting earnings growth to at best be average or it has not fully recognized the company's potential. **********The goal, of course, is to end up with a winning stock, such as those found on Table 4 (Page 50). The stocks listed there have scored the best performance for the year to date. While some investors like to climb aboard the biggest gainers and hope they continue to outperform the market, there are not many money managers who have stayed at the top of the charts by investing that way. Even if earnings prospects are still bright, the question that must be asked is whether the market has already discounted that growth. If so, a stock's best days may be behind it. Fred R. Bleakley

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/05/busin.body_text: **********The biggest cotton harvest in 30 years has just been tallied in the nation's Sun Belt farmlands, which stretch westward from South Carolina to the fertile fields of the central San Joaquin Valley in California. **********But there is little rejoicing among the growers. The large 1981-82 crop is rolling headlong into a market made sluggish by high interest rates and slack consumer buying. As a result, prices have plunged well below the break-even point, and the coming season for farmers looks even worse. **********''I'm negative right now,'' said Fred L. Starrh, general manager and one of seven partners in SVG Farms Inc., a major cotton producer in the San Joaquin Valley. **********In the main, many Western growers suffered heavy losses last year and face a particularly difficult time this year because they are heading into a new planting more deeply in debt. **********''Their general economic condition is pretty lousy,'' said Gene Lundquist, a vice president of Calcot Ltd., the cotton marketing organization that sold 2.3 million bales of cotton last year for its 3,800 members. There are 480 pounds to a standard bale. **********The Reagan Administration's answer to the cotton growers' plight is to have them pare their cotton acreage by 15 percent next season to qualify for farm subsidies. The idea is that a smaller cotton crop would reverse the price drop. **********Mr. Starrh said that the acreage cut made sense for farmers in Texas and the Southeast, where few bills are run up on idle land, largely because they do not have the cost of irrigation. He said, however, that he would not comply with the acreage plan, even though it could bring him $50,000, the maximum subsidy. **********Mr. Starrh said he would lose more by leaving the land idle than by growing cotton and selling it at depressed prices. **********Most Western farms, like SVG, are large and highly mechanized.  Moreover, irrigation has transformed the desert, which surrounds SVG's 7,000 acres, into the world's richest cotton fields. The annual cost of that lush soil for SVG is about $300 an acre, whether it is farmed or not, Mr. Starrh said. **********SVG Farms (the name is taken from its original activity, Shafter Vegetable Growers) averaged more than 1,100 pounds of cotton an acre on 4,000 acres last year, more than double the national average, which was just shy of a record at 545 pounds an acre. **********The farm turned away from vegetables to cotton, alfalfa, hay, wheat and almonds because prices for those crops were more attractive throughout most of the last decade. Drought Aided Prices **********SVG ''just about broke even'' on $5.1 million in crop revenue last year, Mr. Starrh said. That was after two profitable years, when drought narrowed the harvest elsewhere and cotton prices reached 92.5 cents a pound. **********In general, California cotton growers need about 73 cents a pound to cover their costs. With the current price mired at around 62 cents, and December futures pegged at 72 cents, growers would be happy to slash their new cotton planting in favor of crops that have a more favorable price outlook. **********But such crops are difficult to find. ''The whole commodity price complex is in the doldrums,'' Mr. Starrh said. ''We may have a slight reduction, but our cotton planting is going to be about the same.  What are the alternatives?'' Mr. Starrh placed part of the blame for agriculture's tailspin on the Federal R eserve Board's monetary policy, which he believes contributed t o high interest rates, and on the State Department for foiling effor ts by American farmers to develop export markets, including tho se in Soviet bloc countries. **********''I don't understand how we can continue to be used as a major weapon in international diplomacy and have our markets disrupted as they have been,'' Mr. Starrh said. Pondering the weak commodity prices, he added in disgust, ''The basic solution now is for somebody else to have a disaster.'' Long-Term Outlook Hopeful **********Despite low prices and anxious times, long-term patterns look good for cotton. Consumers are buying more cotton clothing and linens, compared with synthetic fibers, due in part to the introduction of no-iron, all-cotton shirts and sheets. The jeans fad also was a boon. **********Most growers made money in 1979 and 1980, enough to recover from sharp losses caused by heavy rains and a plant bug infestation that ruined crops here in 1978. The extra cash allowed them to pay off debt. **********As a result, ''there are not likely to be many bankruptcies, despite the squeeze'' on growers' profits, said Everett E. Welch, an agricultural lending officer with the Security Pacific Bank. **********''Top management and good soil are key ingredients to good farming,'' he said. ''If someone in that category can't meet a loan, you just carry it over.'' He added, however, that another year of depressed prices might force some growers out of business. **********The large farms weathered the ups and downs in the 1970's by borrowing on the sharply rising value of their land. SVG Farms, for instance, has borrowed an average of $2,000 an acre, up from $300 an acre 25 years ago, according to Mr. Starrh. Farm Prices a Factor **********He said he regretted borrowing against the land. ''It doesn't make sense to draw off your equity in order to live,'' he said. But political pressure against rising farm prices will bind the growers' fate even more closely to the value of their lands, he said. **********Calcot, the biggest broker of California cotton, estimates that domestic consumption will be stagnant at an average of 5.8 million bales this year, the same as last year, but predicted that it would be rising at an annual rate of 6.2 million by December. **********Large textile manufacturers such as West Point-Pepperell, J.P.  Stevens and Burlington Industries are the biggest users of cotton fiber. High interest rates caused the mills to trim inventories and orders through 1981. **********Exports for the 1981-82 season are expected to rise to 6.1 million bales of the total crop, put at 15.7 million bales by the Department of Agriculture. Industry sources, more optimistic, are predicting exports of 7.1 million bales. That crop, the rise in exports notwithstanding, is thus expected to result in a surplus of 3 million to 4 million bales.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/27/world.main_headline: TWO GROUPS IN U.S. CONTEND EL SALVADOR VIOLATES CIVIL RIGHTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/27/world.print_headline: TWO GROUPS IN U.S. CONTEND EL SALVADOR VIOLATES CIVIL RIGHTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/27/world.body_text: **********The American Civil Liberties Union and the Americas Watch Committee accused the Salvadoran Government today of a systematic denial of human rights, including dozens of politically motivated murders each week and the widespread use of torture. **********In a 275-page report designed to persuade the Reagan Administration not to continue military assistance and sales to El Salvador, the groups also accused the Government there of responsibility for the disappearance of more than 600 people, of repressing the Catholic Church and of suspending freedom of the press. **********Continued American aid to El Salvador depends on certification from President Reagan that El Salvador is trying to foster human rights and is working to end torture and murder by elements of its armed services. **********''The violations of human rights taking place in El Salvador are not aberrations,'' the report said. ''Rather, they are selectively directed against those perceived as opposing the country's economic and political system.'' **********In a statement with the report, the A.C.L.U. said it ordinarily concentrated on rights cases in the United States but became involved in this debate because American involvement was so significant in ''civil liberties violations'' in El Salv ador . The Americas Watch Committee is a private organization that moni tors human rights in theWestern Hemisphere. Most Common in Rural Areas **********The report said American support for El Salvador had increased during the period of greatest violation of human rights.  The groups said violence and repression were most prevalent in rural areas and said that ''torture of the most brutal kind'' was common in El Salvador. They said ''arbitrary arrests'' were widespread and the right to fair trails had been abrogated. **********''The revolutionary governing junta of El Salvador, both by commission and omission, is responsible for a widespread and systematic pattern of gross violations of human rights,'' the report concluded. **********Meanwhile, the State Department made public a statement from last week's Salvadoran Episcopal Conference supporting elections.  According to the State Department, the statement said: ''We see in the approaching elections, scheduled for March 28 of this year, a faint glimmer of hope, a possible beginning of a solution to the present crisis of the country.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/10/busin.body_text: **********A controlling interest in Filmways Inc. was purchased yesterday by an investor group led by Orion Pictures.  Troubled Filmways, whose film division lost over $20 million in the six months ended last Aug.3l, had been seeking a buyer since last October when it hired the investment banking firms of Wertheim and Company and Bear, Stearns and Company to help in the search. Several bids, including an offer from Macro Communications and the Reliance Group, have fallen through in recent months. **********The complex transaction gives the new group, which also includes Warburg, Pincus Capital Corporation and Home Box Office, a Time Inc.  subsidiary, l3.3 percent of Filmways stock an d keeps Filmways separate from Orion. Orion, whose own movies have not done well recently, was formed in the spring of 1978 by the former top management team at United Artists, which had left in a dispute with Transamerica, parent of United Artists. Orion has been releasing its films through Warner Brothers but has been kn own to be eager to acquire a distribution network of its own. Fi lmways has the nation's seventh-largest film distribution network, wi th 16 branch offices in the United States. Executive Posts Filled **********Arthur B. Krim, Orion's board chairman, has been elected chairman of Filmways. Eric Pleskow, president and chief executive officer of Orion, will fill the same roles at Filmways. The other Orion principals, William Bernstein and Mike Medavoy, were elected vice presidents of Filmways. **********The four Orion executives were also elected to an expanded Filmways board as was John L. Vogelstein, president of Warburg Pincus Capital Corporation, an investment banking firm affiliated with the First National Boston Corporation. **********The deal includes payment of $16 million for $10 million principal amount of Filmways 10-year subordinated notes and 200,000 shares of Filmways voting preferred stock. Filmways simultaneously entered into a production financing and licensing agreement with HBO, the largest pay-television programmer. **********Richard Bloch resigned as chairman and chief executive of Filmways, but will remain on the board.

Transport Minister Haim Corfu, a member of Prime Minister Menachem Begin's Likud bloc, said in a radio interview that the Government would ''abide by the court's decision.'' https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/01/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; TOP OFFICERS ARE SHIFTED AT VENTURE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/01/busin.body_text: **********Julian Seeherman, the 52-year-old vice chairman of Venture Stores Inc., has been appointed president of the discount-store chain, effective Feb. 1. **********In addition, Thomas A. Hays, 49, the current president, will become chairman, while continuing as chief executive officer. The changes follow the resignation of Thomas F. Rafferty, 58, after more than five years as chairman. Venture, a division of the May Department Stores Company, is based in St. Ann, Mo. **********''What we're going to do is focus on quality discounting,'' Mr.  Seeherman said. ''We believe that discounting in our context is the alternative to department store shopping. The young customer, no matter what the economic conditions are, is interested in merchandise that has style and value.'' **********Mr. Seeherman spent 23 years with Abraham & Straus and was executive vice president when he left in 1977 to become president and chief executive officer of the Consumers Distributing Company, a catalogue showroom chain owned by May. After May sold Consumers the following year, Mr. Seeherman transferred to Venture as vice chairman. **********Mr. Hays, a certified public accountant, joined Venture in 1969 as vice president for finance and operations after working for four years as vice chairman of the Diners Club International. Before assuming his current position last year, Mr. Hays spent six years as chairman of the Hecht Company, another May division. **********''The single most important thing anybody can do is to be alert to the fast-changing mood of the market,'' said Mr. Seeherman, who will be responsible for merchandising and sales promotion. ''My major function is to try to see that we have an organization that understands change and can be responsive to it.'' **********According to Mr. Seeherman, technology will be one of the key considerations at the 45 Venture stores in 1982. ''Anything that can help people save time and live in a complex society, whether it is a radio clock alarm, a videotape recorder or a microwave oven, will be important,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/19/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State George P. Shultz, returning to Washington today after 12 days in Europe, has asserted that his chief goal for 1983 is to find a way to bring about an expansion of the world economy. **********Although Mr. Shultz says he also gives high priority to settling problems with the Soviet Union and to bringing about a solution in the Middle East, he has made it increasingly clear that he regards the state of the American and international economies as of probably overriding, basic importance. **********In a meeting with American reporters late Friday, Mr. Shultz said he was less concerned now about the difficulties caused by large debt problems in countries such as Mexico, Brazil, Argentina and Yugoslavia and more worried over the increasing tendency of countries around the world to impose austerity programs to solve their debt problems. **********These programs, often under the auspices of the International Monetary Fund, call on countries with debts to cut back sharply on imports and to try to increase their exports. Mr. Shultz said these ''austerity-type programs'' are not helping the countries to expand their economies. **********Economic Expansion the Key Aim **********''Out of it all, I think, I'll express my own view that we ought to have as our objective for 1983, economic expansion,'' he said.  ''We want an expansion in 1983, and setting that objective clearly in our sights is important.'' Mr. Shultz, who was Secretary of Labor, director of the Office of Management and Budget and Secretary of the Treasury, all under President Nixon, was formerly dean of the business school at the University of Chicago and is a strong advocate of free trade. He has given more attention to economic issues in his five months as Secretary of State than any predecessor in recent history. **********On his European trip, Mr. Shultz began to speak out much more openly about his concerns over the world economy. He said he was aware that this was a field normally the preserve of the Treasury Secretary, Donald T. Regan, but explained that he and Mr. Regan were old friends and seemed to have a basic understanding on the need to foster an expansion of the world economy. Conference Proposed by Regan **********Mr. Regan, in a meeting with reporters in Washington on Dec. 6, said the groundwork had to be laid for some type of international meeting devoted to this question of expanding the world economy, but he added that such a meeting would ''take a lot of time because these problems are not easy to solve and as yet I don't think there has been any focus on it.'' **********Mr. Shultz, who has not endorsed Mr. Regan's plan for discussing a new global conference, said that he had met with some leading political figures in Britain at lunch here on Friday and that he and the others agreed that the idea of a new Bretton Woods type of international meeting ''isn't a good idea unless you have something that you are pretty secure about to meet about, and at this point ideas are hardly formulated at all.'' The international conference held at Bretton Woods, N.H., in July 1944, resulting in the creation of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, is regarded as a financial landmark. **********''There is a sense that there is a problem out there and that we need to define it and figure out what it is,'' he said, ''and then depending upon how you define the problem, you may be led to some types of solutions or institutional rearrangements that you think will be more helpful.'' Meeting of Top Aides **********A senior aide to the Secretary said that he called an unpublicized meeting of his top advisers at the State Department last month and told them that he regarded the world economic problem, particularly the tendency toward austerity and away from expansion, as the most critical issue. Mr. Shultz pointed out, in the meeting, that because of the large debts incurred by many countries, international banks were becoming more reluctant to extend new loans and the countries themselves were under pressure from the International Monetary Fund to cut back on foreign expenditures and to export more. **********Meanwhile, the opposite problem exists: the chief industrialized countries, facing their own recessions, with high unemployment, are under political pressure also to import less and export more. But with all countries practicing the same austerity, it becomes virtually impossible to find new markets abroad. **********The problem is to find a way for all countries to export more as well as import more - in other words to expand their economies - Mr.  Shultz reportedly told his aides. But he said he had no solution to this vexing question, and he called on people in the State Department to start coming up with ideas. A Shift in Emphasis **********In part because of Mr. Shultz's interest in economic affairs, and his expertise, as well as the fact that major problems in the Western alliance are often now in the economic sphere, allied foreign ministers are discussing in much more detail issues that used to be talked about mainly among finance ministers and bankers. **********Francis Pym, the British Foreign Secretary, said at a news conference Friday that he and Mr. Shultz had discussed world economic problems, a subject that Mr. Shultz had also talked about at dinner Friday night with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/13/busin.body_text: **********A compound that keeps blood from clotting my prove valuable in treating stroke and accident victims. The compound is disclosed in patent 4,318,904, granted this week to Elliott N. Shaw and Charles A. Kettner, who did their research at Brookhaven National Laboratory on Long Island. **********Called a tripeptide anticoagulant, the substance is obtained from amino acids. It is described as extremely potent in inactivating thrombin, the enzyme that plays a crucial role in blood clotting.  Accident and stroke victims often require treatment with anticoagulants to prevent further damage from blood clots. Another possible use is in diagnostic tests of blood samples. **********The Research Corporation, a New York foundation, is offering licenses to industry under its agreement with Associated Universities Inc., which operates the Brookhaven Laboratory.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/21/world.main_headline: BRITAIN VOWS AN INQUIRY ON FERRY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/21/world.print_headline: BRITAIN VOWS AN INQUIRY ON FERRY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/21/world.body_text: **********The Government promised an investigation today into complaints of missing life jackets and jammed lifeboats aboard a ferry that sank after a collision in the icy North Sea, killing five people. **********An air and sea search continued for a sixth man from the ferry that collided with another ferry Sunday night.  In the House of Commons, Trade Minister Ian Sproat said there would be an inquiry into charges that the ship was not prepared for an emergency and that a far worse disaster was averted only because the ship sank so close to shore. **********64 Rescued From the Sea **********The Townsend Thoreson shipping line's 4,263-ton European Gateway, bound for Rotterdam from Harwich and Sealink's 3,200-ton train ferry Speedlink Vanguard heading to Harwich from Belgium collided two miles off the east coast of England. **********Pilot boats, battling high seas and gale-force winds and lighting their way with flares, picked up 64 passengers and crew members of the sinking European Gateway out of the sea. **********''We got the boats over the side, but they were shackled by a piece of wire at the top,'' said Stewart Bell, a passenger aboard the Gateway. ''There was no way you could undo them. It was impossible.''  'They Just Smashed Up' **********''People were jumping into the lifeboats and then as the ship started to come over, the water was banging the boats against the ship and they just smashed up,'' Mr. Bell said. **********''It wasn't possible to get into the lifeboats; they seemed to be stuck and soon the ship was leaning too far,'' Joop Josee of the Netherlands said. ''I ran to my cabin for a lifejacket, but there wasn't one there.'' **********A 200-foot gash was torn in the Gateway's side, and her engine room was flooded in the collision.  Within 30 minutes, the drive-on car ferry keeled over and settled on its side in 30 feet of water. The Vanguard managed to limp into harbor despite her shattered bow. **********A Townsend Thoreson spokesman declined to comment on the charges but said an inquiry into the incident had been started. He also declined to comment on criticism that the ferry design was unsafe.  Twenty-eight drive-on ferries have sunk since 1968, and naval architects have voiced concern over the vessels' stability. **********A Government inspector arrived in Harwich, 60 miles northeast of London, to investigate why the two ferries, both equipped with radar, collided in good visibility.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/01/busin.main_headline: WORLDWIDE OIL OUTPUT DECLINED 6.2% LAST YEAR
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/01/busin.print_headline: WORLDWIDE OIL OUTPUT DECLINED 6.2% LAST YEAR
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/01/busin.body_text: **********World production of crude oil fell 6.2 percent in 1981, with OPEC nations accounting for most of the decline, Petroleum Information International, a petroleum newsletter, said yesterday. The Houston publication said that 1981 output dropped by 3.6 million barrels a day, to 55.58 million, from 59.23 million in 1980. **********The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries absorbed most of the drop: Daily OPEC production fell 15.9 percent, to 22.55 million barrels, from 26.83 million in 1980. In 1974, OPEC produced 68 percent of the oil pumped in non-Communist countries; last year, its share was 54.4 percent, the journal said. **********Non-OPEC production outside the Communist countries rose 3.2 percent, to 18.87 million barrels a day, from 18.27 million the previous year, the newsletter said. **********Communist countries raised their combined daily output by twotenths of 1 percent, to 14.16 million barrels, from 14.12 million.  The Soviet Union remained the world's largest oil producer, with an average daily output of 11.94 million barrels, followed by Saudi Arabia, 9.64 million; the United States, 8.58 million, and Mexico, with 2.31 million barrels a day. **********Production in Africa showed the steepest regional drop, falling 24.8 percent, to 4.54 million barrels daily, from 6.03 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/10/world.body_text: **********A brother of one of the Roman Catholic nuns killed in El Salvador 14 months ago said last night that the State Department had told him that six members of the Salvadoran National G uard would be indicted today in the killings. **********The brother, William P. Ford, said the State Department said in a telephone call that the six soldiers ''have been discharged from the National Guard, accused of the crime and will be indicted and brought to court tomorrow.'' **********The indictments would mark the first court appearance of any suspects in the murders of the four American missionaries, three nuns and a laywoman. **********On Dec. 4, 1980, the bodies of the four were discovered in a shallow dirt grave 25 miles southeast of San Salvador, the capital.  Last April six Salvadoran members of the National Guard were arrested as suspects in the slayings, and last month two more guardsmen were arrested, although news of their arrests was not released by the Government at the time. **********Mr. Ford said he had been told that those to be indicted included four of the six arrested in April and the two arrrested last month.  It was not clear what happened to the two from the original group who apprently are not to be indicted today. **********Last night a spokesman for the State Department refused to comment on the report that indictments would be returned today, and would only read from a prepared statement issued yesterday morning that said, ''We understand that the investigation is all but complete.'' The statement added that ''such details could not be made available if this case were being handled in the United States and similarly they cannot be made available in a judicial proceeding in El Salvador.'' **********Mr. Ford, a Wall Street lawyer, said he believed that more senior members of the Salvadoran military were involved in the murders, but that their involvement would never be discovered. ''It does seem odd that it took 14 months to bring eight or six lower-ranking enlisted men to court,'' he said from his home in Montclair, New Jersey. ''The whole thing doesn't ring true.'' **********Three days after the four missionaries disappeared from a pickup truck in San Salvador in December 1980, their bullet-ridden bodies were found on the edge of a dirt road about 10 miles from the capital's airport. Local peasants told reporters that they had heard automatic weapons being fired late at night on the day the four were reported missing. **********The four who were killed were Sister Dorothy Kazel, 40 years old, of the Ursuline Order, and Jean Donovan, 27, the lay missionary, both from Cleveland; Sister Ita Ford, 40, of Brooklyn, and Sister Maura-Clarke, 46, of Belle harbor, Queens, both of the Maryknoll Order, which has its headquarters in Ossining, N.Y. **********The Federal Bureau of Investigation has assisted the Salvadoran Government by conducting both fingerprint examinations on a van used by the slain women and ballistics tests on six rifles it received from the Government. The results of the test were forwarded to the Salvadoran Government. **********Last month, Alan D. Romberg, a spokesman for the State Department indicated that the Reagan Administration was happy with the pace of the investigation and said that a solution to the case was near. Mr.  Romberg's statement was issued a week before the Administration was due t o notify Congress that El Salvador was improving its human rights record , a certification that was necessary for American aid tothat country to continue.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/26/world.main_headline: IRAQ ADMITS ITS FORCES HAVE YIELDED KEY PORT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/26/world.print_headline: IRAQ ADMITS ITS FORCES HAVE YIELDED KEY PORT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/26/world.body_text: **********Iraq acknowledged today that its forces had retreated from the Iranian port city of Khurramshahr in the face of Iranian attacks. **********The withdrawal from Khurramshahr, the only major Iranian city captured by Iraqi forces since the war began in September 1980, means that the Iraqis have now been driven out of Iran's southwestern oil-producing province of Khuzistan, save for isolated pockets along the border. **********The only other pieces of Iranian territory still held by Iraqi ground troops are the historically disputed border strips around the northern towns of Qasr-i-Shirin, Gilan and Mehran in the foothills of the Zagros Mountains. Iraq's President, Saddam Hussein, has little left to show for the thousands of Iraqi lives and billions of dollars expended on the war. **********One leader of Iran, which proclaimed its ''great victory'' in Khurramshahr on Monday, made it clear today that the eviction of Iraqi troops from Khuzistan in no way signaled an end to the Persian Gulf conflict. Hussein's Overthrow Vowed **********The Speaker of the Iranian Parliament, Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, said in a speech that the Iranian Government would not consider the war to be over until all Iranian territory was liberated and President Hussein overthrown. He warned neighboring Arab Persian Gulf countries not to stand in Iran's way. **********''We warn Saddam's supporters that we have no designs on their territory or any other lands,'' he said, ''but we will not stop at anything to secure our rights, and our greatest right is Saddam's downfall.'' **********The Teheran radio quoted an Iranian military communique as saying that Iranian long-range artillery had pounded positions on the Iraqi side of the border, damaging a petrochemical plant and killing at least 50 Iraqis. **********An Iraqi military spokesman in Baghdad was quoted by the Iraqi press agency early in the day as saying that Iraqi forces began their withdrawal from the now devastated port of Khurramshahr on Sunday and completed their retreat to the border this morning. A later communique asserted that Iraqi forces had killed 2,711 Iranians and captured others in fighting north of Khurramshahr. Troops Said to Leave Gear Behind **********The retreat from the port city, judging from news film shown last night on Iranian television, did not seem to have been orderly.  Iranian television showed piles of captured Iraqi boots and uniforms. The announcer said the clothing belonged to Iraqi soldiers who shed their battle garb to swim across the Shatt al Arab waterway to Iraq. **********Khurramshahr is on the eastern bank of the Shatt al Arab, which divides the two countries at the head of the Persian Gulf.  Iranian forces are now within easy striking range of Basra, Iraq's second largest city, which lies about 20 miles west northwest of Khurramshahr, also along the banks of the Shatt al Arab. **********In an apparent attempt to explain the Iraqi retreat after 20 months of fighting, the Iraqi military spokesman said his country's main task in the war all along had been to inflict the heaviest possible losses and defend Iraq from the ''aggressive and expansionist plans'' of the Iranian regime of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. **********This explanation is in contrast with previous statements by President Hussein, who insisted from the beginning of the war that Iraq was out to restore its ''rights'' to full sovereignty over the 70-mile-long Shatt al Arab and to recover 144 square miles of disputed territory along the border to the north. A Record of Survival **********The military defeat would appear to leave the Iraqi leader vulnerable to some move against him from within the ruling Baath Party. But President Hussein has a record of surviving in Iraqi power struggles. He is widely believed to have crushed almost all the centers of opposition to his rule outside of the Government. **********Iran now appears to be bent on making sure that neighboring conservative Arab gulf states do not rush to President Hussein's aid now that he is so exposed. **********Foreign ministers from the Gulf Cooperation Council, a six-member grouping of Arab oil states comprising Saudi Arabia, Qatar, Oman, Bahrain, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates, will be meeting in Riyadh, the Saudi capital, on Sunday in an effort to formulate a unified Arab stand on the Iranian-Iraqi war, basically in support of the Baghdad regime. **********The Iranian Foreign Ministry issued a statement today warning that reconvening of the council ''will entangle the attending parties in a deadlock from which they might not be saved if they try to take measures against the recent victories of the Islamic Republic of Iran.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/07/busin.body_text: **********Declining prices and sluggish international economic conditions resulted in a drop in trading volume in commodity futures last year, the first such decline since 1968. However, according to figures compiled by ACLI International, a commodity service firm, the drop was not enough to prevent overall activity in the futures markets from experiencing another year of growth. **********Last year, trading for perishable and nonperishable commodities fell 8 percent, to 70 million contracts. At the same time, however, conditions that led to a decline in commodity activity - volatile interest and foreign exchange rates, to name two - sparked a sharp uptick in financial futures activity. **********As a hedge against sharp movements in financial markets, 29 million financial futures contracts were traded last year, a 74 percent increase from 1980 levels. That more than compensated for the decline in commodity trading, and pushed overall volume up 7 percent from 1980 levels, to 98 million contracts. **********While the growth was impressive, last year's performance was well below historic averages, said Gregory Kipnis, ACLI's director of research. **********''Between 1960 and 1980, activity in the futures markets expanded at a compound annual rate of 17 percent,'' Mr. Kipnis said. ''The decline in commodity futures activity is a sign of the times.  However, this is an innovative industry, and the existence of comparatively new products like financial futures allowed these exchanges to avoid experiencing a year of negative growth.'' **********Introduced in the mid-1970's, financial futures trading has been an area of exceptionally rapid growth. According to ACLI's statistics, it took until 1973, or more than 100 years, for volume in traditional commodity futures trading to reach 25 million contracts a year. By contrast, it has taken less than 10 years for trading in financial futures contracts to go over that level.

The computers, made for Burroughs by Convergent Technologies Inc. of Santa Clara, Calif., will be available in June. **********The computers will be sold by Burroughs's direct sales force to large corporations for office automation and by third-party dealers and retailers to small businesses. **********To reach a new audience of first-time computer users, Burroughs will conduct its first nationwide television advertising campaign this summer and in July will open its first retail stores in New York, Chicago, Atlanta and Houston. Late in the fall, it will open retail outlets in Toronto, London and Paris. **********William D. Easterbrook, an analyst with Kidder, Peabody & Company, predicted that the company would sell tens of thousands of the computers, known as the B-20 family, each year. ''I think it's going to help the company significantly,'' he said. **********Burroughs and some of the other manufacturers of large computers, such as the Sperry Corporation and Honeywell Inc., have been slow to move into the market for small computers. Burroughs is also following on the heels of such computer makers as the International Business Machines Corporation, the Xerox Corporation and the Digital Equipment Corporation in opening retail stores.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/20/busin.body_text: **********A 1976 Pontiac went first. Sky blue. 57,387 miles. ''Ice-cold'' air-conditioning. Clean body. A crinkly-faced man took it for $2,025. **********''Let's go on to the '78 Bonneville,'' the auctioneer barked.  ''Beautiful car. Looks brand new. Got over 100,000 miles on it. Runs like 3,000. With air. Open that door and take a lookee. Three thousand ... three-three ... now six ... now seven ... three-seven ... now eight ... now a half ... I've got 38 and a half ... Okay, 38 and a half.'' **********It's Thursday, so it must be auction day at Pete Murray's Northway Exchange, about 12 miles north of Albany. They sell used cars here.  Car dealers and reconditioners haul in vehicles they don't want and gavel them off to other dealers who just know they can move them for a profit. Nobody from the general public gets through the gates. **********The sick economy has twisted the life out of the new car business, but spiffy-looking used cars are cherished items. And one of the main places for dealers to find them is the auction, where used cars still move the way new cars once did. Pete Murray has got one of the biggest around. It opened in 1965. Every Thursday morning at 11:30 sharp he starts selling cars, and before he stops about 700 vehicles have gone on the block. **********The auction is held in a low-slung, buff-colored building set on 40 acres. There are four lanes: one for 1980 and newer cars, one for 1978's and 1979's, one for 1977's and older and one for imports and small trucks. At the end of the day, the X category parades through, consisting of big trucks, bulldozers, buses, motorcycles and occasional boats. **********A seller pays $20 to bring in a car, $10 more if the car is sold.  The buyer chips in a fee ranging from $15 for a car bought for less than $495 to $50 for a car fetching more than $10,000. A good auction, dealers say, can net its owner into six figures a year. **********Pete Murray was trying to straighten up his desk, but that was impossible. He is a florid, perky man of 57 with an ingratiating smile. He has trouble keeping track of things. At the moment, he was facing an audit with the Internal Revenue Service and was unable to recall some past transactions. So he was hunting for a hypnotist to see if that would jog his memory. **********''I've lost two pair of glasses in a year,'' he said. ''I'll try to find them, too.'' He took a couple of phone calls, and then talked auctions. ''Many years ago, when one dealer was hurting for money, he had to sell his vehicles to a wholesaler and there was nothing competitive about it and he never knew what the fair value was,'' he said. ''Now, using auctions, we're the stock market of the industry. **********''All together, there are perhaps 200 auctions in the country and they handle more than three million cars,'' he continued. ''The first auction was in 1938, in Leesville, S.C. Still going. After the war, auctions sprang up all over - in any old tobacco shack or barn. They had an awful reputation, a place to get rid of bad cars. In the late 50's, the car factories started running auctions of their leased cars and the image began to improve. Today, the factories tell their dealers to use the auction. **********''The profit today if you want to keep your business alive is in used cars,'' Mr. Murray said. ''That's where the demand is.'' A 1978 Skylark, 39,805 miles on it, rumbled down the B lane.  Dealers nudged each other and nodded, and glances flicked up and down the car. Maybe 500 dealers had shown up today, coming from as far away as Virginia and Florida. **********''It's the image that's the main thing,'' whispered Tim Anspach. He is 95, and walks with two canes. He used to run horse auctions in Omaha, then started the first used-car auction in New York. Now, he still runs a dealership in Albany and patronizes Pete Murray's auction. **********''You got to create the image,'' he said. ''The tires got to be clean. The wheels have got to sparkle. It's image that gets the car sold.'' **********On the B lane, Ralph Tambasco of Tambasco Auto Sales in Amsterdam, N.Y., yawned and gazed moodily at a misbegotten '73 Camaro. He felt the upholstery. He hadn't bought any cars yet, but expected that he would. **********''I'm looking for intermediate four-doors with reasonable mileage,'' he said. ''Under 50,000 miles is reasonable.'' How do you know what to buy? he was asked.  ''If you know anything about cars, you open the door and you know,'' he replied. ''You've got that sight sense. It's the same as a meat man. And you always look at the guy you're buying from. If you've never done business with a guy, you don't buy a toothpick from him.'' **********By the rules of the auction, a buyer has 39 minutes after he takes a vehicle to check it out before the sale is final.  To aid dealers, there's a twisting quarter-mile test track at the rear of the property, with one turn tilted at a 30-degree angle so a dealer can tear around and see if the car's got brakes or if the gearbox is pathetic. A seller is expected to be forthright about any bugs in his car, but just in case, there is Norman Guay. **********Mr. Guay is a husky man with the demeanor of a minister. He is the auction's arbitrator. He works out of a cramped office with a desk and two chairs. People who come in for arbitration, however, usually stand and fidget. **********''I would say at a 700-car auction that I would get maybe 38 cases,'' Mr. Guay said between tussles. ''What we do is, if it's a valid complaint - and a valid complaint means something major like a noise in the engine or transmission malfunctions or play in the drive lines - then I have a mechanic take the car out. If he agrees, then I call the seller in and tell him what we've found and see if he wants to negotiate the price down with the buyer. The buyer has the right to reject the car or adjust the price. About 90 percent of the time we have a price adjustment.'' **********A stoutish dealer came in, saying that the car he hoped to sell had been doing a steady 80 miles an hour on the interstate - then, just now, had started spewing oil. **********''I'll announce it as a noisy engine,'' he said.  ''No, you won't,'' Mr. Guay retorted. ''You'll sell it with a bad engine.'' Some 600 cars have been offered on the block on this particular Thursday, Aug. 12; most sold. Some of the weirder vehicles now rattled down the lane. A burgundy 1926 Model-T Ford, spitting smoke.  A 1960 General Motors school bus. It had bad brakes. No odometer. It looked fed up. **********Peter Murray uncorked his cajolery: ''You can start your own school! Paint it blue and you can have your own Baptist church! It's got bad brakes. But, gee, look at that thing go! A cheap motor home!'' **********A sinewy man with close-cropped hair bid $500.  ''Sell the thing,'' Mr. Murray said. ''I don't dare let it go through again. It'll never make the corner.''
