https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/26/busin.main_headline: LOBBYISTS TAKE AIM AT F.T.C. ANTITRUST RULES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/26/busin.print_headline: LOBBYISTS TAKE AIM AT F.T.C. ANTITRUST RULES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/26/busin.body_text: **********WASHINGTON CHAIRMAN James C. Miller 3d's booming voice could be heard far down the corridor as he delivered a mock pep talk to his top Federal Trade Commission aides. The final legislative battles against the roving bands of lobbyists in ''white coats and stethoscopes'' now deployed throughout Capitol Hill will be muddy and hard, he told his troops, but victory over the nation's doctors could nevertheless be theirs. **********The fiercely contested issue of whether doctors and other statelicensed professionals should be given immunity from increasingly energetic F.T.C. regulation, however, is only the most visible of a half dozen similar efforts by business and trade groups to carve out special niches of antitrust immunity. **********Should they succeed, consumer activists predict higher prices and, in some instances, reduced consumer choice as well.  ''If doctors can fix prices and restrict advertising, there will not be any price competition in health care,'' says Jay L. Angoff of Congress Watch, a group founded by Ralph Nader. Without making any attempt to quantify what the doctors' proposed F.T.C. exemption might do to swell medical costs, Mr. Angoff predicts that the nation's $287 billion health-care bill last year would rise significantly. **********Beer prices too may move up if wholesalers in that industry get their way. They want to protect their members from the pricing tactics of big, often distant, competitors - ''transhippers'' - who pounce on an area and cream off supermarket and other big customers by offering to sell beer on razor-thin margins. **********Richard B. Thornburg, director of legislative affairs for the National Beer Wholesalers Association, said his group was inspired by the example set by soft-drink bottlers, who two years ago obtained legislation barring the Government from breaking up exclusive distributorships. **********The surge in exemption activity has been bolstered by the stiffer competition caused by the recession and by the far-reaching deregulation of such fields as airlines and trucking. **********These challenges may also in part be inspired by the Reagan Administration's effort to curb Government regulation, and the fact that antitrust enforcement has shifted focus and may also - at least in the eyes of business - be somewhat less vigorous. Another factor, analysts said, was the rise of the political action committee in the 1970's, which permitted business to raise money for political purposes more readily than before. **********In addition to the beer wholesalers and the fight over F.T.C.  immunity for professionals such as doctors, the bills now before Congress involve the following: *********** The National Football League, which is seeking a Federal antitrust exemption similar to the one long enjoyed by major league baseball. *********** Agricultural cooperatives, which want existing antitrust exemptions broadened so the F.T.C. would have to get permission from the Secretary of Agriculture to prosecute anticompetitive behavior. *********** The maritime industry, which seeks expanded immunities to allow carriers to pool revenues, share cargoes, cut overcapacity and control access to ports. *********** Credit unions, which want exemption from F.T.C. regulation, to put them on the same footing with banks and savings and loan associations. **********Most of these initiatives involve exemption only from the commission. The industries fighting against F.T.C. jurisdiction would still be subject to general antitrust attack by the Justice Department which shares enforcement of the Clayton and Sherman antitrust acts with the commission. Moreover, some industries, such as banks, are highly regulated by other Federal or state agencies that watch for anticompetitive behavior. **********Still, some analysts see a disturbing trend in the various attempts to win immunities.  ''The antitrust law is certainly gray at the margin,'' said Mr.  Miller, noting that recent shifts in its ''intellectual underpinnings'' are a large factor in the host of efforts to escape F.T.C. scrutiny. The changed antitrust climate is probably best reflected in the Administration's more relaxed attitude toward conglomerate and vertical mergers, where companies are not direct market competitors. This has led some to conclude that the attitude might affect requests for specific immunities from the F.T.C. **********The current assault on the commission represents a continuation of the effort to clip its wings, which was begun two years ago. Congress then gave itself veto power - first employed this summer to block a new used-car sales rule -over F.T.C. regulations. Mr. Miller, an economist and former deregulation chief for the Reagan White House, believes some of the current legislation involves a legitimate effort to reduce regulatory uncertainties. But the chairman has strenuously resisted the assault by doctors, which is expected to come to a vote this week in the House of Representatives. JOINING the F.T.C. and Congress Watch, in unaccustomed alliance against the measure, which is tied t o the commission's three-year reauthorization bill, are the N ational Association of Retired Persons, the American Nurses A ssociation, the National Association of Chain Drug Stores and the W ashington Business Group on Health, a corporate group worried about t he cost of employee health-care and insurance plans. **********They are supported by six former heads of the Justice Department's antitrust division - Sanford M. Litvack, John H. Shenefield, Donald I. Baker, Thomas E. Kauper, Edwin M. Zimmerman and Donald F. Turner - who wrote Mr. Miller to declare: **********''While the professions do have certain unique characteristics, those engaged in the sale of professional services are clearly engaged in commercial activity. We see no reason why Federal laws that protect against restraints of trade and monopolistic or deceptive practices in our free market economy should not apply to the sale of professional services.'' **********The legislation would also cover perhaps 15 other professions, including accountants, lawyers and architects, but it is the doctors who have been the principal supporters. Many lawyers and accountants, in fact, oppose it. **********Joseph F. Boyle, chairman of the American Medical Association, which is the main force behind the anti-F.T.C. legislation, stressed the doctors' view that the issue is not mainly about economics.  Federal bureaucrats, he insisted, are not qualified to intervene in physicians' business by seeking to review, for example, the guidelines offered by local medical associations for physicians' fees. **********''The question is whether you have an agency involved in standardsetting,'' Dr. Boyle said. ''The extension of this would seem almost endless.'' **********The role of industry political action committees is also increasing.  ''There's an awful lot more money accumulated to gain access'' to legislators, asserted Philip L. Verveer, a lawyer who specializes in antitrust matters for Pierson, Ball & Dowd, a Washington law firm. **********And Robert D. Tollison, director of the F.T.C.'s bureau of economics, said that he thought this private financial muscle was threatening the adequate policing of anticompetitive behavior. **********''At some point,'' he argued, ''that tide's got to stop.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/03/world.main_headline: LEBANESE POLICE TAKE CONTROL OF WEST BEIRUT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/03/world.print_headline: LEBANESE POLICE TAKE CONTROL OF WEST BEIRUT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/03/world.body_text: **********Lebanese Government security forces assumed exclusive control of the western sector of Beirut today for the first time since the civil war of 1975-76. **********The green line separating the largely Moslem western and Christian eastern sectors was opened by Prime Minister Shafik al-Wazzan, who said he wanted to hear no more of east and west. **********The Prime Minister presided as piles of sand were bulldozed away from the so-called Sodeco crossing on the green line. By afternoon, residents of the west who had not visited the east since 1978 were able to drive into east Beirut. **********''No Kalashnikovs,'' one resident of west Beirut kept saying, referring to the Soviet-designed assault rifles used by the Palestinian guerrillas before their evacuation from west Beirut.  ''This is the first day since 1975 there are no Kalashnikovs.'' **********Earlier in the day, armed members of the Sunni Moslem Mourabitoun militia could be seen wandering about, and later, a firefight broke out, apparently between Shiite Amal militiamen and a group of Kurds.  But for the most part, west Beirut appeared disarmed, and people were out in the streets. **********The withdrawal of the armed militiamen from the streets was part of a decision reached Wednesday by the leftist National Movement and the chief of the Mourabitoun, also a leftist force. Government police have now taken their places in accordance with a security plan approved by Mr. al-Wazzan. **********The security plan was part of the agreement negotiated by Philip C. Habib, the special American envoy, that also resulted in the withdrawal of the Palestine Liberation Organization. **********(Reuters, quoting the International Red Cross, said that 56 wounded Palestinian guerrillas would be evacuated Friday by sea to Greece.  They would be leaving two days after the official end of the withdrawal.) **********Mr. Habib left today for a vacation and said he would return soon.  This has been interpreted to mean before the installation on Sept.  23 of the new Lebanese President, Bashir Gemayel. **********The independent daily An Nahar, citing sources close to the outgoing President, Elias Sarkis, reported today that he had urged President Reagan in a letter to have Mr. Habib negotiate the removal of Syrian and Israeli troops. **********Now that Mr. Habib has left, the job of trying to mediate falls to Morris Draper, a State Department official who has seved as Mr.  Habib's deputy. Both diplomats received Lebanon's Order of the Cedar on Wednesday. **********Mr. Draper's first task may be to resolve a dispute between the Lebanese Government and Israel over the reopening of Beirut International Airport. Damaged by the war, the Israeli-occupied airport has reportedly been repaired enough to handle some commercial flights. Israeli planes have been using the airport for the last few days. **********But still it has not opened, and Lebanon's Minister for Public Works, Elias Herawi, said Tuesday that the opening would require a ''political decision.'' **********The Lebanese were said to be resisting Israeli demands that an Israeli be present in the control tower, that aircraft manifests be checked by Israelis, that an office of El Al be opened at the airport and that Israeli military facilities be maintained there. **********In another development, the Cabinet announced that Lebanon would be represented at the Arab summit meeting opening Monday in Fez, Morocco, by Joseph Abu Khater, a Minister of State. The Lebanese had urged postponement of the meeting on the ground that no top leader could be present while the country was still so close to a crisis. **********In other decisions, the Cabinet voted $1 million to clean up and repair west Beirut's streets, piled with garbage and heaps of sand.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/04/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS DIGEST; THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1982; The Elections
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/04/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices, buoyed by the election, soared to new highs. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 43.31 points, its biggest one-day advance on record, and closed at 1,065.49, its highest closing level in history. The Big Board's composite index and Standard & Poor's index also set records. Volume was 137 million shares in the fifthbusiest session ever. Analysts said Wall Street regarded the election outcome as a mandate to Washington to keep interest rates under control. (Page A1.) The Dow, though it is the world's most closely watched market indicator, has its critics on Wall Street.  (D1.) **********Many businessmen and private economists viewed the election results as an opportunity for midcourse corrections in economic policy. Despite Democratic gains, however, they did not see a repudiation of President Reagan's program. (D1.) Analysts predicted key compromises in a spirit of pragmatism. (D1.) Voters approved most of the 178 bond issue proposals on ballots across the country. (D12.) **********The Economy **********Sales of the Big Three auto makers rose 9.1 percent in the last 10 days of October. Chrysler's sales were up 40.1 percent, while Ford's rose 6.3 percent and G.M.'s 4.7 percent. Analysts said the gains were about what they had expected. (D1.) Ford has lowered to 10.75 percent the interest rate it charges to finance car purchases. (D4.) **********The Social Security trust fund will borrow $1 billion tomorrow to make sure it can cover this month's $12.2 billion of benefit payments, the Treasury said. Until now, the fund had been able to draw down its balance to finance its growing operating deficit.  (A17.) Companies **********Steven J. Ross, head of Warner Communications, designated a company official as ''overseer of a secret cash fund'' containing $170,000 in bribes, a Federal prosecutor said. He was addressing jurors at the fraud trial of the official, Solomon Weiss. A Warner spokesman said Mr. Ross denied knowing of any such fund. (D1.) **********Hanna Mining reported a $17.1 million loss in the third quarter, contrasted to earnings of $8.6 million a year ago. NLT lost $3.3 million, in contrast to earnings of $37.7 million, while American Standard's net dropped 49.2 percent. (D3.) **********Kuwait has withdrawn from talks with Gulf Oil over a takeover of the company's refining and distribution network in Europe. (D5.) International **********The I.M.F. approved a $1.1 billion loan to South Africa over the objections of many third-world countries. Opposition to the proposal was reportedly the widest ever. The U.S., which voted for it, condemned South Africa's racial policies but argued that the fund's lending rules must be applied impartially. (D1.) **********Canada, caught up in a severe economic crisis, now faces two crippling labor disputes. One could shut down Chrysler. The other, a lockout of longshoremen, has closed seven West Coast ports at a cost of more than $8 million a day. (D4.) **********Italy will act as intermediary between the U.S. and France in an effort to resolve an impasse over trade sanctions against companies involved in the Soviet pipeline. It will try to win over the French to an American proposal for restructuring East-West trade. (D14.) **********Poland and its Western bankers signed an accord that phases repayment of 95 percent of its 1982 debt over eight years. (D15.) Markets **********Prices of fixed-income securities declined in late trading after early gains. Rates on short-term money market instruments were slightly higher at the close. (D12.) The dollar rose against major currencies, while gold prices fell $5, to $426, in New York. (D14.) Cattle and pork futures prices rose sharply in active trading. (D14.)  Today's Columns **********Oil companies are developing offshore drilling structures that will go deeper and withstand harsher climates than ever before. One project will seek oil in ocean depths of more than 6,000 feet, while others aim to work amid Arctic ice packs. Technology. (D2.) **********Acton has sold its food business as part of a strategy to concentrate on its cable television operations. Word of its plan seems to have awakened interest in its shares, which have been active and rising. Market Place. (D8.)

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/05/busin.body_text: **********''We missed a call. You guys stink!'' Prudential Bache Securities had just lost a trade to another brokerage firm, and William Schlicher, senior vice president of institutional stock trading, hurled his insult across the floor to the block traders, who ignored it for the 10th time yesterday. **********As the bull market continues its stampede down Wall Street, the traders are thundering, too. Yesterday, with volume reaching a record level of 149.4 million shares, including a phenomenal 46.6 million traded in the first hour alone, the excitement in trading rooms reached fever pitch. From the opening bell until noon, ''we were totally swamped,'' said Mr. Schlicher, 39 years old, who plainly relishes the pace. ''We were really hopping.'' **********An Elusive Seller **********All day long, Mr. Schlicher and his colleagues were on the phone - to the block traders across the room, to Prudential Bache's traders on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, to some institutional clients. It was a cacophony of orders, laments, demands and pep club cheerleading, carried across the crowded, noisy room by loudspeaker. **********''We wanna buy K Mart, let's go!'' Mr. Schlicher bellowed across the room. The traders had heard that there was a seller in the market, but had been unable to locate him. **********''You guys, let's not lose track of this one,'' William Bee, who trades in banks, health-care and drug company stock, boomed.  ''Chemical Bank, we still have a buyer.'' **********''First he won't buy what I tell him to buy,'' Richard Farrell, a trader in 200 leading industrials, complained about a floor broker.  ''Then he overbuys.'' **********''How much are you short?'' Mr. Schlicher asked.  ''That's what I'm figuring.'' ''On the H!'' A trader is summoned to the telephone line that goes to the firm's main room near the floor.  Like H (and J and K), many of the references are in code. ''Cha, Cha, San Fran'' - Charles Sciascia, the over-the-counter liaison, had a telephone call from Prudential Bache's San Francisco office.  ''Pick up Loose Wheels'' - Lucille Savino, a clerk on the floor of the exchange, wanted to talk to a trader. **********The trading room was a study in perpetual motion. Mr. Schlicher lit another cigarette and drummed his desk. Mr. Bee tugged at his mustache. Mr. Farrell rarely sat down. Clerks chewed toothpicks and pens. Come lunchtime, they wolfed down soft drinks, pretzels and cookies, with a cigarette between courses. **********Mr. Schlicher, a two-and-a-half-pack-a-day man, pulled out $10.  ''Who needs cigarettes besides me?'' ''Me.'' ''Me.'' ''Me.'' Hot on Sohio **********To everyone's regret, the lunchtime lull lengthened into afternoon, and the two mad hours were not repeated. As the traders sat and waited, Mr. Farrell announced that another brokerage firm had sold 100,000 shares of K Mart. **********''You guys stink!'' Mr. Schlicher informed the block traders. Like everything else in the trading room, his anger was temporary. ''Hi, pal,'' he said to a caller. ''Oh, tiptop today.'' **********''Chief, chief,'' Thomas Heck, a trader in oil and transportation stocks, said urgently to Mr. Schlicher, still on the telephone. ''I got to talk to you.'' Shortly after 2 P.M., with Mr. Schlicher's goahead, he bought 100,000 shares of Standard of Ohio at 37 1/2. The next task is to find a buyer. Meanwhile, Sohio stock has begun to drop. **********''Sohio, we're hot,'' Mr. Schlicher said over the loudspeaker. ''We missed K Mart, let's go.'' By 3 P.M., with the market down nearly 3 points, the traders have grown bored with their unwonted leisure. ''It's dead, dead,'' Mr.  Schlicher complained. **********''I'm falling asleep,'' Mr. Heck said.  ''Yesterday went so fast,'' Mr. Farrell recalled.  A clerk, sent out 15 minutes before for coffee and soft drinks, has still not returned. ''Where'd he go for the Pepsi, Chicago?'' Mr.  Schlicher said. **********The sarcasm deepened. Mr. Heck, who earlier had looked in vain for a private seller for Texas Oil, informed the block traders that he was able to buy the stock more cheaply on the market. ''I would like to thank you for not finding a seller at that silly price I was offering,'' he said. **********But in the last half-hour, with the market ''tanking'' - falling - tension mounted again. ''Nineteen minutes of jeopardy,'' Mr. Bee said. Sleepless Night Ahead **********''It's been an excellent commission day,'' Mr. Schlicher summed up. ''We lost some money in trading for our own account.'' Prudential Bache has held onto some large blocks of stock, a fact that will trouble him until trade opens today. ''Absolutely I lose sleep,'' Mr. Schlicher said. ''Absolutely I take it home with me, wake up at 2 A.M.'' **********At 3:42 P.M., Mr. Heck, who had been studying his Quotron intently, noted that the Dow had fallen to 1,049.85. ''How disgusting,'' he said. Sohio, however, had recoverd to 37 1/8. **********''Come on, Sohio, come on,'' Mr. Schlicher said.  ''It's up one-eighth, what do you want?'' Mr. Heck said.  ''A quarter.'' At 3:54 P.M., Mr. Heck groaned. Sohio had dropped to 36 3/4.  Finally, 4 o'clock. Sohio has closed at 37. The Dow Jones industrial average has closed down 15.27 points.  ''They can't hurt us anymore, guys,'' Mr. Schlicher said.  ''They can't get me until tomorrow,'' Mr. Heck said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/30/world.main_headline: BRITONS VENTING THEIR ANGER AT THINGS ARGENTINE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/30/world.print_headline: BRITONS VENTING THEIR ANGER AT THINGS ARGENTINE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/30/world.body_text: **********When a tape of a pre-Falklands Royal Variety Gala was recently broadcast on television, viewers were treated to the entire 90-minute spectacle - with one exception. Elaine Page's performance of ''Don't Cry for Me Argentina,'' from the musical ''Evita,'' was eliminated. **********''As one of the songs had to be cut, we thought it would be silly for Elaine to sing Argentina in case it might be misconstrued,'' Tim Rice, the lyricist, told reporters. **********As this country moves closer to a stepped-up military confrontation with Argentina, Britons have been venting - in conversation and in highly symbolic actions -their unhappiness about the South American nation's actions. **********Going beyond import curbs, for example, Argentine food was banned from restaurants in Government buildings at Westminster and Argentine corned beef was removed from the shelves of 500 supermarkets. A liquor store in Chelsea poured its supply of Argentine wine down the drain. Internment Hardly Considered **********And as the possibility of more military action grows, consideration is being given to what would happen to Argentines in Britain. Few expect that Argentines would be interned, particularly because there is no law to permit it. But officials pointed out that powers do exist for specific individuals to be detained if they are suspected of sabotage or other offenses. **********For Britons, the antagonism toward things Argentine represents part of the struggle to recapture the self-respect lost when the Falkland Islands were so easily occupied. David and Andrew Banks, for example, were fined the equivalent of $90 each for throwing two cans of corned beef at the Argentine Embassy in Belgravia. **********''We just had to do it,'' said Andrew Banks. ''The invasion hurt my pride.'' Other Britons have been booing Argentine-born soccer players as they set foot on the field. **********To some extent, Britons have been aroused by the provocative actions of their Government, such as the breaking of diplomatic relations and the ban on Argentine trade. Last week three Argentine yachtsmen, arriving in England at the end of a round-the-world race, were quickly expelled by the Home Office. World Cup Spot in Doubt **********A few days earlier, Neil MacFarlane, the Sports Minister, urged British sports organizations to call off any matches planned to take place in Britain against Argentine teams. In addition, a Government committee is considering whether England should withdraw from the World Cup soccer tournament to be held in Spain this summer. **********''In present circumstances, I would urge British sporting bodies not to complete any bilateral fixtures against their Argentinian counterparts scheduled in the U.K. and to refrain from issuing further invitations,'' Mr. MacFarlane said in a statement to Parliament. **********The evident tension has left Britain's fragmented Argentine population nervous and uncomfortable. Only a few thousand Argentines are thought to be living in Britain and many of those are married to Britons or otherwise part of the British community. **********No incidents have been reported and most Argentines say they are being treated cordially by their British hosts. Nonetheless, nearly all of them are so sensitive about their new-found prominence that they refused to discuss their experiences. Friends Keeping Their Distance **********''Some Argentinians here are finding their friends keeping their distance,'' said Raoul Fain-Binder, an Argentine journalist here.  ''The jingoism and that sort of thing that you see in British papers is also very disturbing.'' **********Regardless of their political sympathies, Argentines here are unhappy about the continuing attacks in British newspapers of the Argentine Government, the Argentine economy, the administration of the Falklands and just about anything Argentine. ''Forced out at gunpoint,'' proclaimed the Daily Mail a few days ago in recounting the departure of a group of islanders. **********''I feel isolated, particularly without an embassy and an ambassador,'' said one young Argentine student. ''I don't hide my nationality but I don't go out as much.'' **********A number of Argentines have had difficulties with their personal finances, as a result of a Bank of England action to freeze Argentine deposits in Britain. The action was not intended to reach individuals but many were affected by the initial confusion. In addition, suspension of a no-visa agreement between Britain and Argentina has made travel far more difficult. 'People Look Twice' **********''Argentine residents here are just trying to go about their business normally,'' said Alan Tabbush, chairman of the Anglo-Argentine Society. ''People, of course, are sensitive. Now when a man says he's an Argentinian, people look twice.'' **********Some of the repercussions have seemed almost silly. The National Rifle Association here has decided to change the name of its 33-yearold ''Argentina Shooting Match'' to ''The N.R.A. 300 meters match.'' And a newspaper suggested that Prince Charles dismiss his Argentineborn polo pony groom even though he has a British passport, is married to an Englishwoman and was hired before the crisis began.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/20/world.main_headline: PORTUGUESE COALITION STARTS ITS SEARCH FOR A NEW PREMIER
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/20/world.print_headline: PORTUGUESE COALITION STARTS ITS SEARCH FOR A NEW PREMIER
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/20/world.body_text: **********Portugal's right-wing coalition Government began seeking a new Prime Minister today after the resignation of the Social Democratic Party leader, Francisco Pinto Balsemao, after almost two years in the job. **********Announcing his decision earlier today during a meeting of his party's national leadership, Mr. Balsemao said he had been betrayed by opponents within his own movement and other members of the threeparty coalition. **********Mr. Balsemao, 45 years old, became Prime Minister in January 1981, after his friend and predecessor, Francisco sa Carneiro, was killed in a plane crash. He resigned briefly in the summer of that year but formed a second Government when the Social Democrats failed to put up an alternative candidate. **********His statement pointed to a split in the Democratic Alliance coalition, which faces a crucial test over his successor.  The Social Democratic Party is the largest group in the coalition, which also includes the more conservative Christian Democrats and the tiny Monarchist Party. **********The alliance has held a clear majority in Parliament since January 1980. A general election is not due until 1984.  Today the Socialist and Communist opposition called on President Antonio Ramalho Eanes to dissolve Parliament.  In his statement today Mr. Balsemao said he had long ago decided to step down in order to dedicate himself to the Social Democrats, but a setback suffered by the party in local elections on Dec. 12 appeared to have precipitated his resignation. **********The alliance only dropped five points in the voting and maintained its hold on the local government structure. But, by scoring big gains at the expense of the Social Democrats, the Christian Democrats increased the strain within the coalition. **********The three leading candidates to succeed Mr. Balsemao are former Prime Minister Carlos Mota Pinto, who held office for six months in 1979, Finance Minister Joao Salgueiro and Joao Mota Amaral, head of the Azores regional government. **********The decision on whether to appoint a new alliance government or call early elections will be made by Mr. Ramalho Eanes after Mr.  Balsemao formally presents his resignation on Monday. **********In northern Portugal, rioting erupted today when authorities tried to repeat local elections canceled last Sunday after protesters stormed polling stations in the small town of Vizela in support of demands for their own local council. **********Today hundreds of residents, summoned by church bells and fire alarms, again wrecked polling booths and tore up voting slips after defying riot policemen with shouts of ''this is not Poland.'' The police charged the demonstrators but later left the town. **********The problem at Vizela is mainly economic. It has also caused friction within the alliance as the monarchists support the town's claims, while the Christian Democrats oppose them.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/12/busin.main_headline: DOW IS OVER 1,000 FIRST TIME IN YEAR
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/12/busin.print_headline: STOCKS SOAR AGAIN; DOW IS OVER 1,000 FIRST TIME IN YEAR
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/12/busin.body_text: **********In the fourth day of an exuberant stock market rally, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 25.94 points yesterday and closed above 1,000 for the first time since mid-1981. **********The rise in the average reflected the growing conviction that interest rates will continue to decline.  The Dow average, which measures the performance of the stocks of 30 major corporations, finished at 1,012.79, its highest close since April 28, 1981, when it ended at 1,016.93. If it were to continue the pace of the last four sessions - rising a total of 110.96 points -the Dow average would break the record high of 1,051.70 well before the end of the week. That record was set on Jan. 11, 1973. **********Seldom Above 1,000 for Long **********The Dow average broke the 1,000 mark on several occasions during the first six months of the Reagan Administration, going as high as 1,024.05 on April 27, 1981. But it is a barrier that often convinces investors to sell and as a result, it has seldom remained above 1,000 for long. **********Trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday climbed to 138.5 million shares, the second highest ever. The record was set last Thursday, when 147.1 million shares changed hands. **********The volume of stocks bought and sold yesterday was considered particularly impressive because many of the nation's banks and companies were closed in observance of Columbus Day. 'Confidence in the Economy' **********President Reagan hailed the market's rally, telling a cheering Republican audience in Irving, Tex., that ''the surge reflects increased money market confidence in the economy.'' **********Analysts attributed the market's strength yesterday primarily to a statement Saturday by Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve, confirming a more lenient monetary policy. Mr. Volcker said that, while the Federal Reserve would continue to combat inflation, ''that policy does not imply continuing pressures on interest rates.'' Mr. Volcker's statement shores up the conviction of many economists that the Federal Reserve will encourage a further decline in interest rates to buttress the nation's faltering economy. The Federal Reserve sets the scene for lower interest rates by increasing the amount of money that banks have available to lend. **********''The remarks of Mr. Volcker on Saturday indicate that interest rates will continue to move lower, and that's what stimulated the market today,'' said Ralph Acampora, vice president of Kidder, Peabody & Company. **********Lower interest rates attract investors to stocks by reducing the yields on competing investments, such as bank savings certificates and money market funds. **********The other leading market indicators yesterday also made large gains. The New York Stock Exchange composite average, which includes all the common stocks traded, advanced 1.91, to 76.91, its highest close since Aug. 14, 1981, when it ended at 77. **********The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 3.42, to 134.47, its best closing since April 27, 1981, when it finished at 135.48.  For the Dow, which is generally considered the market's bellwether indicator, the 1,000 level is considered important mainly for its psychological effect on investors. The average last closed above that benchmark figure on June 23, 1981, when it reached 1,006.66. **********''There is a good chance that the Dow's move above the 1,000 mark today is for real and, unlike previous attempts, that the Dow will spend more time above 1,000 in the future than below it,'' said William M. LeFevre, market stragetist of Purcell, Graham & Company. **********He based his optimism on the fact that both inflation and interest rates were declining at the same time. Since the early 1970's, when the Dow first closed above 1,000, interest rates would decline periodically while the nation's economy generally experienced a rising rate of inflation. **********Nevertheless, breaking the 1,000 barrier had its sobering affect yesterday. The Dow dropped back in the final hour of trading, after having advanced by 34 points at 3 P.M. from Friday's close. The heavy trading put the tape that records transactions behind more than 30 minutes at the close. For a while during the day, it had been behind as much as 42 minutes. **********Falling interest rates have been the main reason for the market's record two-month surge. Since Aug. 12, the Dow has climb 235 points.  Heavy institutional buying by pension, union and bank funds as interest rates declined has led the market's sharp advance, especially in the last four sessions. The large-capitalization issues have posted the biggest gains. **********The market's advance yesterday was broadly based, with advancing issues on the Big Board outnumbering declining stocks by more than a 5-to-1 ratio. The best performers again were the stocks of the bluechip corporations, technology and transportation companies. **********In the blue-chip category, American Express climbed 4 1/8 points yesterday, to 57 7/8; General Motors 3, to 53 1/2; American Telephone 1 1/4, to 62 3/4; Merck 2, to 82 1/2, and International Business Machines 2 1/8, to 83 1/4. **********Among the stocks that make up the Dow industrial average, Procter & Gamble since the beginning of this month has gained 12 1/2 points, to 111 1/2; Eastman Kodak 12 1/4, to 95 1/4; Minnesota Mining 10 1/4, to 75 3/8, and I.B.M. 9 1/4. **********The smallest gainers in the group during this period included U.S.  Steel, which advanced only 1/8, to 18; Woolworth 1 1/8, to 31, and Bethlehem Steel 1 3/8, to 17. Energy Issues Gain **********The energy issues, which have lagged the market since the start of the rally, are now beginning to participate. Texaco rose 2, to 32; Exxon 1 3/8, to 30 5/8, and Standard of California 3/4, to 31. The energy issues had been under pressure for many months because of the oil glut and declining prices. **********Among the stronger technology issues yesterday, Texas Instruments soared 5 7/8, to 107 5/8; Digital Equipment 5 3/8, to 94 7/8, and Honeywell 3 3/4, to 90 1/2. **********The heavy volume in the last four sessions continued to buoy the brokerage stocks, which derive much of their profits from high volume. Merrill Lynch added 3 3/8, to 46 7/8; Paine Webber 2 3/8, to 29 3/8, and E.F. Hutton 1 1/2, to 39. **********On the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index added 4.95, to 304.09, while its option contracts volume rose to a record 364,132 contracts. **********In the over-the-counter market, the Nasdaq composite index was up 3.42, to 202.31.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/27/busin.body_text: **********J.P. Stevens & Company reported yesterday that net income for the quarter ended May 1 jumped 83 percent, to $5 million, or 35 cents a share, from $2.8 million, or 19 cents a share, for the same period last year. Sales, however, fell to $472 million, compared with $510.8 million last year. **********A spokesman for the New York-based textile manufacturer said that although the second quarter's net earnings ''exceeded the depressed results of a year ago,'' they were ''by no means at acceptable levels. In general, the poor market conditions of the first quarter continued throughout the second quarter.'' **********Incoming orders in many of the company's businesses, he said, were below those required to maintain full manufacturing schedules, causing substantial curtailment of operations during the period.  Further curtailment was required to control inventories 17 percent lower than last year's. **********For the first half of the fiscal year, J.P. Stevens reported net earnings of $7,173,000, or 50 cents a share, well above last year's $5,338,000, or 37 cents, for the same period.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/24/busin.body_text: **********Gordon R. Hjalmarson said yesterday that he planned to resign as chairman and chief executive officer of the SFN Companies, one of the nation's largest book publishers. **********Mr. Hjalmarson (the ''j'' is silent), 56, said he was resigning for personal reasons and that he would stay on until the company found a successor. **********SFN, of Glenview, Ill., is a publishing holding company that was formed in 1980 by Scott, Foresman & Company. Now, along with Scott, Foresman, it operates such subsidiaries as Southwestern Publishing, the Silver Burdett Company, the Fleming H. Revell Company and University Park Press Inc. **********The company publishes elementary, high school and college tests, along with trade, medical and religious books. Mr. Hjalmarson, like many another in the textbook business, started as a teacher. **********He joined Scott, Foresman as president and a director in 1973 from Houghton Mifflin, where he was vice president and director of the educational division. When SFN was formed, he became chairman and chief executive. A spokesman said Mr. Hjalmarson would stand for reelection to the board at the annual meeting Aug. 25. **********The company recently reported lower sales and earnings for its fiscal year, ended April 30. Earnings were $27.6 million, or $2.43 cents a share, down from $35.9 million, or $3.08 a share, a year before. Sales declined to $251.1 million from $270.8 million. A spokesman said earnings in the prior year were helped by an extraordinary gain from the sale of a trade book house and that the outlook for fiscal 1983 earnings was ''quite good.'' **********The company yesterday announced an increase in its quarterly dividend to 29 cents a share from 27 cents, payable Sept. 8 to holders of record Aug. 12. Daniel F. Cuff

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/15/busin.main_headline: Advertising; British Air Switches To Saatchi
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/15/busin.print_headline: Advertising; British Air Switches To Saatchi
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/15/busin.body_text: **********SAATCHI & SAATCHI COMPTON WORLDWIDE has landed the British Airways account for the entire planet. Current annual billings are about $28 million, according to the airline. **********The carrier was known to be reviewing its worldwide relationship with Foote, Cone & Belding Communications, following a corporate reorganization instigated by Sir John King after Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher installed him as chairman of the Government-owned airline. Saatchi & Saatchi Garland-Compton, the British publicly held agency that is the controlling member of the Saatchi & Saatchi Compton organization, is also the agency for Mrs. Thatcher's Conservative Party. **********F.C.B. Communications, also a public company but with headquarters in New York, is an American corporation even though its London office first started working for B.A. in 1948. The account has been called the ''heart of the F.C.B. international operation.'' **********''I think British Airways probably chose us because they thought it appropriate that the nation's flag-carrying airline should have a British advertising agency rather than an American one,'' said Simon Mellor, assistant to Charles and Maurice Saatchi. He added that the current theme, ''Fly the Flag,'' probably would be scrapped in favor of a best-in-the-world theme. **********''It looks like a political act of which we are the victims,'' John E. O'Toole, chairman of Foote, Cone, said of the switch.  In London, Bill Barry, head of F.C.B. there, remarked: ''We are proud to stand by our work. We are sad that Sir John King appears to have so summarily dismissed one of the airline's main pillars in its flight for the future.'' **********But there is no doubt that the Saatchi & Saatchi operation is the fastest growing and hottest shop in England. It is also the largest, a position generally held by American agencies in the past. And under its umbrella are the S.& S. Garland-Compton organization and the Dorland agency, both of which will be handling different divisions of the reorganized client, while Compton Advertising will do the American part of the job. **********Its main divisions are the European; Intercontinental, which takes care of the rest of the world, and Holidays, a tour packager.  F.C.B., which will continue doing the work for three months, has handled the airline in some 80 countries. S.S.C.W. has offices in 44 countries and probably will not be adding to them. **********The victorious agency, one of a number of British-based shops interviewed by the carrier during the last three months or so, has three airlines on its client list and each had been informed of the possibility of the British Airways move. They are British Caledonian, KLM and Air New Zealand. **********In disclosing the new account on this side of the ocean, O. Milton Gossett, chairman and chief executive officer of Compton in New York and chairman of S.S.C.W., said he considered the new account another indication that the Compton-Saatchi merger last March creating a $1.3 billion shop was a wise move. He said that the combined operation has won some $50 million in new billings since then, not counting B.A. **********While the New York office of British Airways, having checked with its London office, insisted that the total worldwide billings of the account would be $28 million, Saatchi & Saatchi's London office put the figure at $42 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/11/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices of the Baldwin-United Corporation and the MGIC Investment Corporation tumbled after MGIC postponed a shareholders' vote on its proposed $1.2 billion acquisition by Baldwin-United. **********In trading on the New York Stock Exchange, Baldwin-United common stock plunged $6.125 a share to close at $61.25, while MGIC stock fell $2.375 to wind up at $48 as one of the most active issues of the day. **********Neither issue traded Tuesday because of an imbalance of orders for the stocks following publication of an article in The Wall Street Journal that Baldwin-United may need to use a $600 million bank line of credit to help foot the merger bill. **********MGIC said it postponed a special shareholders' meeting in Milwaukee without taking a vote on the merger in order to give Baldwin-United time to seek approval of financing of the merger plan from state insurance regulators. MGIC, based in Milwaukee, is the nation's largest private insurer of home mortgages.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/25/busin.main_headline: OFFICIAL AT A.T.& T. STRESSES NEW LINES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/25/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; OFFICIAL AT A.T.& T. STRESSES NEW LINES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/25/busin.body_text: **********When the American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced a change in its upper management organization last week - placing its four most senior officers in charge of overall corporate planning and giving each of five executive vice presidents responsibility for a distinct business segment - attention was focused on Charles Marshall. **********Mr. Marshall, a 52-year-old former president of the Illinois Bell Telephone Company, was appointed an executive vice president, effective Feb. 1, after serving as A.T.& T. vice president for only about three months. He will be in charge of ''Baby Bell,'' the name that many use to refer to the Bell subsidiary that will be established to handle operations in unregulated businesses. **********In typically diffident Bell fashion, Mr. Marshall downplayed his appointment when reached at his Basking Ridge, N.J., office. He noted that he had been A.T.& T.'s vice president and treasurer before becoming president of Illinois Bell in 1977 - placing him on the ''president's group'' level of corporate vice presidents and subsidiary presidents for more than five years. In addition, he said, his assignment to create, head and run Baby Bell was simply an example of placing an executive with recent line experience at the top of a prospective national line organization. **********This organization ''makes as much sense now as it did two months ago,'' Mr. Marshall said. Under a proposed antitrust settlement announced this month by Bell and the Justice Department, 22 regional Bell operating companies are to be divested. ''The real driver behind it all is competition.'' **********What will Mr. Marshall concentrate on in his new responsibility?  ''I just got the job,'' he responded, ''but clearly what we'll want to do is follow our technology and bring our customers the newest type of communications.'' **********Mr. Marshall started his career at Illinois Bell in 1953, where he spent many years, interspersed by two previous tours of duty at A.T.& T., before first becoming a vice president. The only other Bell unit on his resume is the Southwestern Bell Telephone Company, where he was once a vice president. **********The mission that has been given to all A.T.& T. executive vice presidents, Mr. Marshall observed, was to operate their own segments and keep the office of the chairman informed about proposed policy changes. ''They're using each of us where our talents are best directed,'' he added.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/14/world.main_headline: NORTH KOREANS BAR A U.S. MEETING WITH G.I.
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/14/world.print_headline: NORTH KOREANS BAR A U.S. MEETING WITH G.I.
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/14/world.body_text: **********United States officials accused North Korea today of being ''unreasonable and inhumane'' for refusing to allow an American soldier to speak with his Army superiors and relatives about whether he had defected to the Communist nation. **********In a terse exchange during a public session of the Korean Military Armistice Commission, North Korea again ruled out any meeting between representatives of the United Nations Command and Pfc. Joseph T. White of St. Louis. **********The 21-year-old soldier was reported missing on Aug. 28 in the demilitarized zone at the border between North and South Korea.  Officials said he had been seen crossing into the North near the Panmunjom truce camp after leaving his unit in the buffer zone. North Korea later said he had defected. **********The demand for a face-to-face meeting to determine whether Private White had defected or was being held captive was made by Col. Patrick Brady of the United States Army, the United Nations Command's secretary of the Korean Military Armistice Commission, in a meeting with his North Korean counterpart, Col. Kim Ryon Ki. **********Colonel Brady also urged that the North Koreans allow Private White to telephone his family. But the request was swiftly rejected. 'No Further Consideration' **********''Your continuing discussion of this subject deserves no further consideration,'' Colonel Kim said. ''It is well known to the world'' that Private White defected to the North, he said. **********North Korea has maintained that the American soldier defected to protest the continued presence of the 40,000 United States troops in South Korea. In repeated North Korean broadcasts he has been quoted as saying he went over to the North voluntarily. **********Colonel Brady declared, however: ''Pfc. White's language and accents are not spontaneous and obviously un-American in style.  Further, much of what Pfc. White has said is contrary to truths well known by all Americans, regardless of their political beliefs. **********''You are denying White his right to speak for himself to the U.N.C.,'' Colonel Brady said, ''and therefore this course of action must be defined as both unreasonable and inhumane.'' **********The soldier's mother, Kathleen White, said in an interview from St. Louis that she was determined to press for contact with her son.  ''I'm not going to lose hope,'' she said. ''We want to talk to him, and if he's there of his own free will, why won't they let him talk?'' **********If Private White did defect, he was the first American soldier to do so in 17 years.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/21/world.main_headline: SYRIA SAID TO RAZE PART OF REBEL CITY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/21/world.print_headline: SYRIA SAID TO RAZE PART OF REBEL CITY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/21/world.body_text: **********Syrian tanks are methodically leveling vast areas of Hama, the nation's fifth largest city, as they continue to battle rebels led by Moslem fundamentalists, according to residents who have escaped the besieged city. **********Thousands of people are believed by diplomats here to have been killed and wounded in the fighting, which has gone on nearly three weeks. **********Tanks backed by artillery and as many as 12,000 troops, Baath Party militiamen and plainclothes intelligence officers have reduced much of the ancient part of the city to rubble, according to diplomats and Western journalists here. Wounded Reported Unattended **********According to an account by a young man who escaped the city Tuesday night, the stench of corpses hung over the city. He said many bodies were buried under collapsed buildings and other dead and wounded were unattended in the streets because of the heavy firing. **********Many residents have not been out of their houses in more than two weeks because the troops were shooting at anything that moved, the young man said. His account was similar to those pieced together by diplomats of at least six embassies here. **********The Government has declined to give any details of the fighting.  The Minister of Information, Ahmed Iskander Ahmed, has described the reports circulating among diplomats as the ''stuff of dreams.'' **********The fighting is the largest uprising in the 12-year-old Government of President Hafez al-Assad, but diplomats here believe that the President, backed by his brother, Rifaat, commands a security apparatus still capable of controlling the country. **********Nevertheless, these diplomats say the Government appears to be faced with a determined opposition in the outlawed, fundamentalist Moslem Brotherhood organization, which could serve as a spearhead to other discontented but unorganized elements of society. **********Just how determined the opposition is was shown again Thursday afternoon when a man tried to drive a truck full of explosives that was disguised as a magazine delivery van into the new 10-story building housing the Ministry of Information and the Baath Party newspaper. **********He was cut down by machine-gun fire and the explosives went off prematurely, blowing the facade off the building but causing no deaths. Moslem Brotherhood organizations abroad took responsiblity. **********The incident was only the latest in a chain of terrorist strikes by the Brotherhood that began with the massacre of more than 60 artillery cadets in Aleppo in June 1979 and has included assassinations of Government officials and Soviet advisers. Last November a huge car bomb went off in the crowded Azbakiyeh neighborhood of Damascus, killing more than a hundred people. Shorty afterward, diplomatic sources here say, a large, eight-wheeled truck was discovered packed with explosives near Omayyad Square, a major landmark. How Fighting in Hama Began **********Intelligence agents, hard-looking young men in blue jeans and leather jackets or windbreakers cradling Soviet-made assault rifles, are a fixture on Damascus streets and have been noticeably strengthened in the hillside neighborhood of President Assad's palace. In the last week they have added hand grenades, pistols, aprons of extra ammunition clips and walkie-talkies to their equipment. **********The fighting in Hama, diplomats say, was sparked by long-simmering resentment of the Alawite-dominated Government of President Assad among the Sunni Moslem majority. The city has a reputation as both a center of Sunni orthodoxy and a thorn in the side of the Government. **********Accounts pieced together from diplomatic reports and residents indicate that the fighting began on Feb. 2 when 300 or more regular Syrian soldiers of the 21st Mechanized Infantry Brigate, 3d Armored Division, a heavily Alawite unit stationed near Hama, tried to raid a Moslem Brotherhood arms cache. **********The unit was surrounded and wiped out as it attacked the hideout, according to these accounts. A Western diplomat said he monitered a military radio broadcast reporting 300 deaths among the soldiers.  Several diplomats heard reports that the insurgents donned the uniforms of the dead soldiers, possibly giving rise to accounts that army units had deserted. City Is Sealed Off **********The troops were acting on a tip that the Moslem Brotherhood was stockpiling arms for a major operation, possibly involving dissident military personnel, according to some sources. An East European diplomat said the arms - including piles of antitank rockets and automatic rifles - had been brought in from Jordan and the money had been supplied by Iraq. **********With a call to rebellion from the minarets of the mosques, the fighting spread, and residents attacked Government and Baath Party buildings and killed party members and security officers. The Government sent in more troops, including the 47th Independent Brigade and units of the special troops commanded by Rifaat Assad.  The fighting has continued since. **********The city has been sealed off and no one is allowed to leave or enter. The Government has reopened the main road between Damascus and Aleppo, which skirts the city, but has kept Hama isolated. Western journalists have been warned not to go to the area. Market and Old Part Are Hit **********According to the young man who escaped Tuesday night and the accounts of others, the ancient Hadhir district, where the rebels barricaded themselves, has been destroyed, as has the souk, the traditonal market place that in Hama dealt mainly in wool and cotten. **********At least three mosques have been destoyed, according to accounts reaching Damascus.  There is no electricity, very little food and water and no telephone communication, the young man said, adding that soldiers had been looting homes and the souk. The young man, a member of a Sunni merchant family, said he was able to escape because he had a relative in the security forces. **********Thus far, the trouble in Hama does not appear to have spread to other cities such as Aleppo, Latakia or Homs, where there have in the past been Sunni outbursts against the Alawite-dominated Government.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/21/busin.body_text: **********The Army announced yesterday that it had awarded to the Electronic Data Systems Corporation a 10-year contract to install and operate what will be one of the Government's biggest data processing networks. The contract's value is estimated at $656 million. **********The contract, the largest ever awarded by the Army for data processing, will connect 42 Army posts to a nationwide network of data processing centers. **********Electronic Data won the contract over the International Business Machines Corporation and the Computer Sciences Corporation.  Government contracts, a new market for Electronic Data, account for 20 percent of the company's revenue, which reached $454 million in the last fiscal year. **********The new setup, called Viable, will enable Army posts to send financial, supply and personnel information to five regional data processing centers that Electronic Data will build in the next few years. Each Army post has been using 20-year-old, stand-alone computers, which do not connect posts with other computers in the Army system. **********The Army ''desperately needed'' the network, said Col. Clinton H.  Black, project manager for Viable with the Army's Computer Systems Command, because the current system, which was obsolete in the 1960's, is ''overloaded and unreliable.'' **********The data centers will be situated in or near Atlanta; Killeen, Tex.; Monterey, Calif.; Radcliff, Ky, and Washington.  Electronic Data, based in Dallas, will set up a project headquarters in Washington. It plans to employ about 700 workers on the project. **********Electronic Data's chairman and majority shareholder, H. Ross Perot, has frequently been in the spotlight for such actions as an unsuccessful effort to fly supplies to American prisoners in Vietnam.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/08/busin.main_headline: Talking Business with Frank Barnako Jr. of video group; Video Cassette Developments
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/08/busin.print_headline: Talking Business with Frank Barnako Jr. of video group; Video Cassette Developments
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/08/busin.body_text: **********The video cassette retail industry seemed to spring up overnight.  In the last few years more than 6,000 stores opened to sell and rent prerecorded tapes of movies. But now the business faces an uncertain future. **********Movie producers have raised prices and in some cases will only rent tapes, not sell them, to retailers. Last October a Federal court in California declared home videotaping illegal. And Congress is considering revoking the copyright law's First Sale doctrine, which lets a dealer buy a tape and then rent it to customers countless times without paying extra royalties to the movie studio. **********The video copyright question is a key issue at the Summer Consumer Electronics Show, now under way here. Frank Barnako Jr., president of the Video Software Dealers Association, a six-month-old trade group, discussed the prospects facing his industry. Mr. Barnako owns the Video Place, a five-store chain in the Washington area. **********Q. A few months ago dealers were up in arms about plans by the movie studios to only rent tapes. What has happened since then? **********A.  The number of new titles coming in rental-only has slowed to a crawl. I think the number of dealers picking up titles that were rental-only has also slowed to a crawl. Dealers have seen they can survive without blockbusters. Studios have seen their cash flow significantly reduced. The rental-only programs are slowly fading away. **********Q. What are the chances that Congress will levy a royalty on the sale of blank videotapes and video cassette recorders? How would that affect dealers in prerecorded software? **********A. If the Supreme Court agrees to hear the appeal of the California case, nothing is going to happen in Congress. If the Court won't hear it, I think there will very likely be a royalty. Our biggest concern is the revocation of the Right of First Sale. That permits us to buy a tape and do what we want with it. An amendment in the Senate bill would take this away and give the studios a monopoly forever. If that happens, 95 percent of our members will have to go out of business or drastically change the way they do business. **********Q. Isn't the existing situation unfair to studios? Should retailers be able to buy a tape and rent it over and over and over again without reimbursing the studios? **********A. The studios don't have to sell it. They have the right now to say this is rental-only. **********Q. Is there a shakeout starting among video software retailers? **********A.  I'm feeling it. If you talk to a distributor, you'd probably hear that the number of refused c.o.d. shipments is higher than three months ago. A refused shipment means that a dealer has a good business on the weekend and calls up on a Monday and orders four ''Star Wars'' and three ''Time Bandits,'' and by the time the tapes arrive on Wednesday he can't pay for it. **********Q. How many of the dealers will not last? **********A. It's fair to say that 30 to 40 percent of the guys are looking around and hoping to hear someone say, ''I want to buy you out.'' **********Q. If dealers can't buy everything, does that mean they will stop carrying tapes made in Sony's Beta format and carry only the more popular VHS format? **********A. On some titles I'm not sure about, I've passed on Beta. So Beta does have a bit of a problem, but I don't think it's serious. **********Q. Do you see a market developing for the videodisk? **********A. No. It doesn't do enough. My experience with videodisks has been disappointing. We've tried cutting prices. We've tried disk giveaways. We've tried $50 rebates. It just doesn't sell. **********Q. ABC recently said it would broadcast pay TV at night to subscribers to record on video cassette recorders. Does that and other forms of pay TV threaten software dealers? **********A. They are competition for a finite resource: your time. The new options will increase hardware sales - no question about that. In the software area, they have to keep putting new products out in video cassette form if we are to do well.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/26/busin.main_headline: TINY COPIER MAKER TAKING A BIG STEP IN DEAL WITH CHINA
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/26/busin.print_headline: TINY COPIER MAKER TAKING A BIG STEP IN DEAL WITH CHINA
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/26/busin.body_text: **********In the copier industry, dominated by giants, Otto A. Clark and his company, the Clark Copy International Corporation, are minuscule: Clark Copy has only 23 employees and 300 stockholders. Total sales last year barely exceeded $1 million, and it spent only $1.2 million on research and development. **********But this nondescript, five-year-old company, which makes paper copiers and cassette tape-copying machines in a cramped factory outside of Chicago, has beaten the world leaders in the paper copier business - Xerox, Olympia, Minolta, Sharp - to a lucrative 20-year contract with China. **********''I never even heard of the company before this,'' said Eugene G.  Glazer, a stock analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ''Now they're the talk of the town. This contract may not put them on the Fortune 500 list, but it's an awful lot of business.'' Indeed, the deal with China could bring Clark Copy $65 million in sales during the contract's life. **********But the real question, some analysts say, is whether the company can meet the terms of its production contract, or whether it has gotten in way over its head. Undercutting the Competition **********The machine that may make Clark Copy a household name - at least in China - is the CMC 2000, an unspectacular-looking plain-paper copier that makes 18 copies a minute and requires no warm-up time. Because the 75-pound machine employs the latest technology, Clark Copy is able to undercut the prices of most similar machines by almost half: The CMC 2000 sells for less than $2,000. **********''It's the fastest, the smallest, the most efficient and the least expensive paper copier in the world,'' boasted Mr. Clark, the company's 56-year-old founder and president. **********The CMC 2000, named after his daughter Catherine Marie Clark, is a no-frills machine that is made of only 200 parts and takes two hours to assemble, compared with more than 2,000 parts and 20 hours for assembly for other copiers, Mr. Clark said in an interview. **********Instead of using a conventional photographic lens costing $175, Mr. Clark said, his copier uses a $35 fiber-optic lens. It employs a $5 belt to transfer images to paper, instead of a $270 drum, which uses more energy to heat the image as the transfer is made. **********''It would cost the large companies twice as much to make the same machine because of their large overhead,'' he said. Terms of the Contract **********According to the terms of the contract, which was signed April 10 in Peking, Clark Copy will manufacture and deliver 1,000 assembled copiers, and the parts for another 5,000 machines, which the Chinese will assemble. This phase, which will bring the company $5.5 million in revenue, will begin with the delivery of 50 assembled copiers and the parts for another 200 in September. The company will then ship 100 assembled machines and the parts for 500 others each month. **********In the second phase of the contract, Clark Copy will be expected to train Chinese technicians, who are then to manufacture in the following three years 200,000 copiers at a new plant in Kweilin for domestic sale and export. This stage will bring Clark $60 million, or $300 per machine. **********Clark Copy will also upgrade the paper copier over the years, reducing its size ''so it will be able to fit inside an attache case,'' Mr. Clark said. The company will also sell to China the technology to its cassette tape copier machine. **********Although the company has made plans to hire an additional 100 workers by June and raise $7 million through stock issues and debt, some analysts harbor doubts about whether the company will be able to handle the contract. Doubts Expressed **********''The Chinese Government may be left holding the bag,'' Dean Witter's Mr. Glazer said. ''This company doesn't have a track record.'' **********However, Mr. Clark, who has started two paper copier businesses in the past and sold them both, has more confidence.  ''There's no doubt in my mind that we can,'' he said.  Winning the contract, Mr. Clark asserted, was no fluke.  ''This is a 50-50 partnership, and the Chinese know it,'' he said.  ''You can't do business in China on a simple buy and sell basis, like most multinationals. You have to show a commitment to stay, and establish a close human relationship.'' **********Clark's Shanghai-born export manager, David Yao, did the company's bargaining, Mr. Clark said, adding, ''That didn't hurt us any.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/21/busin.main_headline: LOANS FOR SOUTH AFRICA ASSAILED IN U.N. REPORT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/21/busin.print_headline: LOANS FOR SOUTH AFRICA ASSAILED IN U.N. REPORT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/21/busin.body_text: **********A United Nations study sharply critical of the International Monetary Fund's loans to South Africa has languished unpublished for more than a year, according to U.N. officials. **********The study charges that loans from the monetary fund have helped South Africa maintain its system of apartheid and have contributed to that country's military buildup. In addition it concludes that the I.M.F. has treated South Africa more favorably than other African countries and has ignored declarations by the General Assembly and Security Council that South Africa's occupation of Namibia is illegal. **********Jean Gazarian, director of General Assembly Affairs in the office of the Secretariat, said he could recall no other instances in which a United Nations report of this nature was not published as an official document and translated into the U.N.'s official languages.  He called the treatment of this report ''very strange'' but said he did not know what had happened. **********Special Panel's Project **********The study was commissioned by the Secretariat at the request of the Special Committee of 24. Its jurisdiction includes overseeing the carrying out of United Nations declarations on decolonization. **********Frank Abdulah, chairman of the Special Committee of 24, declined to say why the report had not been translated and disseminated like other U.N. studies. **********''I think you had better ask the United States Government that,'' said Mr. Abdulah, who is the chief representative to the United Nations from Trinidad and Tobago. **********The Reagan Administration, seeking to improve relations with South Africa, has allowed high-ranking South African military officers to come to the United States and has adopted a more flexible policy regarding sales of nuclear materials to South Africa. **********But Joan Dickie, an information officer at the United States Mission to the United Nations, rejected the idea that the United States had influenced any decision not to publish the report. ''We are not members of the Committee of 24,'' she said. ''We have no power to influence what the committee publishes or does not publish.'' **********The I.M.F.'s representative to the United Nations declined to make any public comment. Request for a New Loan **********The study has acquired new significance because South Africa recently requested a $1.1 billion loan from the monetary fund. A resolution opposing the loan was introduced by Guinea in the General Assembly yesterday. **********According to the study, some $543 million in South African drawings from the I.M.F. from 1975 to 1977 ''helped to pay increases in South African defense expenditures.'' During that period, South Africa's military outlays increased by $450 million, the study found. **********''Defense expenditures leading to budget deficits, budget deficits leading to inflation, inflation leading to balance-of-payments problems - that is the indirect path by which South Africa arrived at the I.M.F.'s door,'' the report said. ''In addition there was the direct increment to the balance-of-payments deficit caused by rising arms imports.'' **********The study charged that I.M.F. loans to South Africa have ''demonstrated to the world financial community that, despite increasingly violent confrontations between the majority black populations and the white minority Government in South Africa, the I.M.F. would continue to support the status quo and the white authorities.'' Share of Credits Analyzed **********Without I.M.F. loans, and the potential for future loans, the report continued, South Africa would be faced with the ''domestic financial and political costs of its controversial racial policies and of its illegal occupation of Namibia.'' **********During recent years, the report charged, South Africa received a ''disproportionate share'' of I.M.F. credits that went to African nations. As an example, the study noted that Nigeria, a nation of comparable economic stature, was a current net contributor of $592 million to the I.M.F. last year while South Africa had a net debt of $10 million. **********The report was sharply critical of the monetary fund's agreement in 1969 to buy gold from South Africa at the official price of $35 an ounce. The report said this decision was ''ostensibly'' for the purpose of stabilizing the world price of gold, but it added, ''In practice, the decision worked to aid South Africa and to destabilize world gold markets.''
