https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/20/busin.body_text: **********President Reagan today criticized the Federal Reserve Board because of the recent spurt in the nation's money supply, and, going further, took a neutral stand when asked if Paul A. Volcker, the board's chairman, should resign. **********''I can't respond to that because the Federal Reserve System is autonomous,'' the President said at a news conference, when asked if he agreed with recent calls for Mr. Volcker's resignation. ''There is no way I can comment on that,'' Mr. Reagan added. **********The President also said that the recent jump in the money supply, to an annual rate of growth far above the Federal Reserve's targets, ''sends, I think, the wrong signal to the money markets.'' He added that this signal had contributed to the recent stall in the decline in interest rates. **********'A Little Caution at Work' **********''I think there's a little caution at work, and perhaps a part of that is waiting to see what the Federal Reserve System is doing,'' the President said, in trying to explain why businesses are not investing significantly in response to the tax cuts and other incentives in his economic program. **********Aides to the President, right after the nationally televised news conference, sought to play down the impact of Mr. Reagan's remarks about Mr. Volcker, who is the architect of the tight monetary policy that has led to high interest rates. David Gergen, the senior White House spokes man, said that the President was not intending to avoid an endor sement of Mr. Volcker.  ''It was strictly a statement of neutrality,' ' he added. **********When asked why Mr. Reagan did not endorse Mr. Volcker, as he has in the past, Mr. Gergen said that the President did not intend the statement of neutrality to carry the implication that he did not endorse Mr. Volcker. Indication of Support **********Just a week ago, when Representative Jack F. Kemp, a Republican from upstate New York, suggested that Mr. Volcker resign, Larry Speakes, the deputy press secretary, indicated that the President supported Mr. Volcker's present policy. **********The statements today by Mr. Reagan and his aides added to the general confusion about the Administration's stand on monetary policy. Since last summer, the Administration has criticized the Federal Reserve for being both too tight and too easy in its control of the money supply - on both occasions attributing high interest rates to these factors. **********Nevertheless, the President's economic program endorses the Federal Reserve's general goal of slowly reducing the growth rate of the money supply over time. **********Before the President's news conference, the Federal Reserve's tight monetary policy and the Administration's economic policies were attacked by three winners of the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, James C. Tobin of Yale University, Wassily Leontief of New York University and Lawrence R. Klein of the University of Pennsylvania. **********All three suggested, in testimony before the Joint Economic Committee, that the current tight Federal Reserve policy was one of the key blocks to renewed growth and said that the Federal Reserve should ease its tight grip on the money supply. Mr. Tobin said that the only real route to a recovery in 1983 and 1984 was not tax increases and spending cuts to reduce the budget deficits, but ''an easier monetary policy.'' During the news conference, the President defended his economic policy in the face of the present recession by contending that the rise in unemployment, which is now expected to top 9 percent, had begun during the Carter Administration.  Administration officials could not say where the President got his figures for such a conclusion and did not defend the assertion. **********''I realize there's been an increase in unemployment,'' the President said. ''It's been a continuation of an increase that got under way in the last several months of 1980.'' **********''It was increasing very much more in the last six months of 1980,'' he added. Peak in October 1980 **********According to figures from the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the unemployment rate, which reached a peak in 1980 at 7.6 percent in October, was declining at the end of the year and into 1981, falling to 7 percent in July. It climbed to 8.9 percent last month. than in December 1980. The President also incorrectly said that the average unemployment rate in 1981 was 8.1 percent and, in 1980, 7.4 percent.  The correct Labor Department figures were 7.6 percent in 1981 and 7.1 percent in 1980. **********But Mr. Reagan was correct that, on average, there were one millionmore people w orking in 1981 compared with 1980.  Repeating h is statements that his program will lead to economic recovery and a decline in unemployment, the President said: ''I have the greatest sympathy, I think anyone does, for those who are unemployed.'' **********''But the people today have a lower interest rate than they had when we started,'' he went on. ''The inflation rate is sizably lower.'' **********And, Mr. Reagan added, ''we have in place a program now that is just getting under way that is designed to reduce the unemployment and to resolve these problems that are so bothersome today.'' Business Tax Cuts Defended **********The President also defended his business tax cuts, which were designed to spur new business investment, against recent Government figures showing that new investment is not increasing. It was in making this defense that Mr. Reagan said that the recent spurt in the money supply had helped stall the interest rate decline. **********The President said that the halt in the fall of interest rates was one of the reasons that businesses had not been investing in new plants and equipment in response to the business tax cuts. ''I don't think they have failed,'' Mr. Reagan said. ''I know that a great many industries have the plans all ready for modernization and expansion.'' He specifically cited the steel industry. **********But, he added, ''they want to be more sure that interest rates and inflation are going to continue coming down a s they have been.'' In making this comment, the President acknowledg ed what many outside economists have been contending about the Rea gan program - that the Federal Reserve's tight monetary policy, by k eeping interest rates high, could stop the investment boom that is the heart of the Administration's recovery program. **********Leading business executives, including top Reagan supporters, have said that they would not make a major push for new investment until they were sure that the economy was growing strongly again and the recession was over. Reflection of Regan Remarks **********The President's comments about the spurt in the money supply reflect remarks made recently by Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan.  Through a spokesman tonight, Mr. Regan said that ''the President did not mean to imply any change in attitude toward the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board; he was merely expressing his concern over the growth of the money supply in the last 10 to 12 weeks, a concern shared by the Federal Reserve.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/04/world.main_headline: VIETNAM AND CHINA ENGAGING IN RENEWED VERBAL HOSTILITIES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/04/world.print_headline: VIETNAM AND CHINA ENGAGING IN RENEWED VERBAL HOSTILITIES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/04/world.body_text: **********A series of border incidents during the Lunar New Year holiday last month has prompted new recriminations between China and Vietnam, which have been on hostile terms since their border war three years since their border war th ree years ago. **********Today The People's Daily accused Hanoi of hypocrisy in proposing a cease-fire on three recent occasions and then instigating 44 ''military provocations'' during the 10-day holiday that the Chinese call Chunjie and the Vietnamese call Tet. **********The article by Ji Ying of the New China News Agency charged that a Chinese peasant was killed and two others wounded along the rugged border of the southern provinces of Yunnan and Guanxi between Jan. 18 and 28. ''The Vietn amese authorities ''The Vietn amese authorities never tire of talking about their desire for pe ace, yet they have failed to show it in their actions,''the article s aid. **********Propaganda Coup by Hanoi **********The charges come only a few days after Vietnam scored a propaganda coup by encouraging the new Secretary General of the United Nations, Javier Perez de Cuellar, to agree to mediate in the Chinese-Vietnamese border dispute. Mr. Perez de Cuellar assured Pham Van Dong, the Vietnamese Prime Minister, that he was ready to help ''contribute to a peaceful solution.''Mr. Perez de Cuellar has combined with Vietnam's public truce offers to put China on the defensive. The People's Daily took note of the Vietnamese proposals on Dec. 28, Jan. 14 and Jan. 30, and charged that Vietnam had circulated them at the United Nations ''in an attempt to achieve maximum benefit from this propaganda stunt.'' **********Some Peking-based diplomats have speculated that China must be particularly annoyed because it helped Mr. Perez de Cuellar obtain the post by its adamant opposition to another term for Kurt Waldheim. **********China told Vietnam last September that there could be no negotiations before Vietnamese forces pulled out of Cambodia. The Chinese have also contended that a truce is superfluous because the Vietnamese are to blame for the border hostilities. Convenient Point of Pressure **********''As long as Vietnam refrains from making any future military provocations or incursions into Chinese territory,'' The People's Daily said today, ''the question of fighting back simply will not arise and peace and tranquillity will prevail in the border area, festival or no festival.'' **********While it is almost impossible to determine who is at fault from the verbal exchanges, the Chinese have found the border a convenient point of pressure on Vietnam at a time when Hanoi is trying to buttress its client regime headed by Heng Samrin in Phnom Penh.  According to Western intelligence reports last year, the Chinese were tying down up to two-thirds of the Vietnamese Army, which might otherwise be available for duty in Cambodia. **********Peking also seems aware that any agreement with Hanoi would be interpreted in Asia as a softening of China's opposition to Vietnamese occupation of Cambodia, particularly when other Southeast Asian nations are trying to promote a coalition of resistance movements there. China continues to champion the ousted regime of Pol Pot. **********But some diplomats here feel that Vietnam, realizing that China does not want to talk, may find it advantageous to press publicly for a truce while embarrassing the Chinese with border incidents. Five Violations Cited **********The Chinese press has been specific about at least five violations that it said took place recently. On Jan. 18 the Vietnamese were accused of shelling a village in the Hekou Autonomous County of Yunnan Province. On Jan. 22 Tan Jianmao, a commune member in Guanxi Province, was killed while traveling to visit relatives in a nearby village. **********On Jan. 25, the Chinese charge, Vietnamese fired at and broke up a holiday celebration in the Guanxi town of Congxin, while firing into the Hekou area on the same day for three hours. The next day, the Chinese assert, two civilians in Yunnan were wounded by Vietnamese mines. **********The Vietnamese had previously said that Chinese troops fired across the border or intruded into Vietnamese territory on more than a dozen occasions between Dec. 28 and Jan. 13. Paracel and Spratley Islands **********The quarrel has extended to conflicting claims of sovereignty over the barren Paracel and Spratley Islands in the South China Sea. These scattered reefs and atolls have taken on value because of the possibility that oil may be found in the area. **********Last month the Chinese press buttressed Peking's claim with a long historical study seeking to show that the Chinese had been there first. Vietnam responded by publishing a ''white paper'' and a long magazine article supporting its claim to the islands. **********So me conflicting reports are mirror images of each other. On Jan.  15 China announced that it had freed seven Vi etnamese soldiers captured while ''intruding into Chinese terri tory to conduct reconnaisance and sabotage,'' as well as four grateful Vietnamese fishermen whose boat sank while illegally in Chinese waters. At the same time, China said, 11 Chinese ''illegally captured and detained''were returned by Vietnam. **********On the same day, Vietnam announced that it had released ''11 Chinese captured while illegally intruding into Vietnamese territory'' o n spy missions, and that 11 Vietnamese ''kidnapped whileworking on Vi etnamese territory by intruding Chinese soldiers'' were handed back t o Vietnam.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/21/world.main_headline: IN CONGRESS, THE INVASION HAS ERODED ISRAEL'S ALMOST AUTOMATIC SUPPORT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/21/world.print_headline: IN CONGRESS, THE INVASION HAS ERODED ISRAEL'S ALMOST AUTOMATIC SUPPORT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/21/world.body_text: **********After six weeks of war in Lebanon, Israel's support in Congress has been significantly eroded to what some members describe as its lowest point. But in their view it has not reached the stage where substantial numbers would oppose further American aid to Israel. **********In more than a score of interviews, both Republicans and Democrats in Congress warned that an Israeli assault on west Beirut could bring a change in support for Israel and lead to moves for legislative retribution. **********Already, both critics and long-time supporters of Israel talk freely of ''a wave of revulsion'' caused by pictures of civilian casualties in Lebanon and of a shift in the almost automatic support Israel has enjoyed in Congress. They say there is frustration at the use of American arms by an ally that feels unrestrained in taking actions that jeopardize United States interests in the Middle East. **********Anger Directed at Leaders **********Both in Congress and in the Reagan Administration, the frustration is directed at Prime Minister Menachem Begin and Defense Minister Ariel Sharon. Leading members of Congress repeatedly draw a distinction between their support for Israel and disagreement with Mr. Begin's policies. **********The Administration has been careful to mute its irritation with the Begin Government. But senior officials say President Reagan and his aides have been particularily chagrined in recent days over the Israeli effort to cut off water, power, food and the movement of Red Cross officials into west Beirut, all widely reported on television and in the press. **********''It could turn out to be, if it continues this way, Israel's Vietnam,'' said Senator Charles H. Percy, Republican of Illinois, the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. **********Representative William S. Broomfield, Republican of Michigan, the ranking Republican on the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said: ''We're going to have some real problems on future legislation unless there is a clarification on the use of American arms. Israel is going to have a lot of work to do to restore the support they have had. It has been severely affected. For the first time we are getting letters saying, 'Why don't we do something?' '' **********Some members of Congress, including steady backers of Israel, say the mood of displeasure with Israel is already sufficient for a sizable group to endorse a cutoff in shipments of cluster bombs to Israel, because their use is controversial in combat where there are heavy civilian casualties. 'A Vehicle for a Reprimand' **********''If there were a vote on that, it's the kind of thing that could carry,'' said Senator Christopher J. Dodd, a Connecticut Democrat who has consistently backed Israel. ''It provides a vehicle for a reprimand. That would satisfy those who are critical of Israel without significantly altering our basic relationship.'' **********Others, like Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., a Delaware Democrat and an outspoken supporter of Israel, have privately warned Ambassador Moshe Arens that Israel will face difficulties in sustaining its previously unassailable and largely uncritical support for high levels of economic and military aid. **********No aid program for Israel is due for a Congressional vote until late fall, probably after the November elections. Congressional leaders consider foreign aid generally too unpopular to bring to a vote before the election. The prevailing view is that a vote on aid to Israel toward the end of the year will be affected more by later developments than by the current critical mood. **********''The Israelis have made some serious mistakes as it affects their relations with us and the West,'' said Senator Henry M. Jackson, a Washington Democrat who has been one of Israel's staunchest supporters, ''but the final judgment will only come when one knows what the final results will be in Lebanon.'' **********There are backers of Israel, like Senator Dodd and Representative Jonathan B. Bingham, Democrat of the Bronx, who contend that the current displeasure with Israel amounts more to ''rhetorical criticism'' than any substantive shift of support. **********But Senator Jackson and others, like Senator John Glenn, Democrat of Ohio, suggest that deeper damage may have been done. They cite accumulating displeasure in Congress that Prime Minister Begin has undertaken a series of actions that many regard as offensive use of American weapons supplied for defensive purposes, without apparent regard to the effect on American links to the Arab world. They mentioned Israeli air attacks on an Iraqi nuclear reactor and on Palestinian areas around Beirut last year as well as the invasion of Lebanon. **********Before the Israelis moved into Lebanon on June 6, the House Foreign Affairs Committee approved the Administration's request for $1.7 billion in military aid and $785 million in economic aid for Israel in 1983, and at the urging of Senator Alan Cranston, Democrat of California, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee increased the economic aid level to $910 million. **********Mr. Cranston's aides estimate that the $125 million aid increase would not pass the committee today. Ambassador Cites Support **********Ambassador Arens said many of Israel's traditional supporters remained unshaken by recent events, citing conversations with such Democratic Senators as Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, Gary Hart of Colorado, Howard M. Metzenbaum of Ohio and Carl Levin of Michigan, and Republicans like Rudy Boschwitz of Minnesota and Steven D. Symms of Idaho. **********Few of them, however, have spoken out on Israel's behalf, either during floor debate or during the recent confirmation hearings of Secretary of State George P. Shultz. **********While careful to reassert American commitments to Israel and its security, Mr. Shultz was unusually outspoken for an unconfirmed appointee in criticizing the Begin Government's policy of establishing settlements in the West Bank and removing elected Arab mayors there and in the Gaza Strip. Moreover, he commented pointedly on the civilian casualties in Lebanon, saying, ''We cannot accept the loss of life brought home to us every day on our television screens.'' **********In the midst of diplomatic negotiations with the Begin Government, the Reagan Administration has kept its frustrations private. Except for a current holdup of a shipment of cluster-type artillery shells for Israel, the Administration is allowing American economic and military aid to Israel to continue. Since the Lebanese hostilities began, however, the White House has delayed formal notification to Congress of a new order of F-16 fighter-bombers, due in 1983. **********Sharp criticism of the Begin Government has become increasingly common in Congress. ''The love affair with Israel from the time of Golda Meir is gone because of Begin,'' said Senator Paul E. Tsongas, Democrat of Massachusetts. ''How can I be concerned about human rights in El Salvador and the Soviet Union and not speak out on Lebanon?'' **********In the House, Representative Jim Wright, the majority leader, said he had not discerned any deep shift of opinion ''that would shake the longstanding and special relationship with Israel, and I find no sympathy with the Palestine Liberation Organization.'' **********But, he went on, ''many members feel that Begin tends to be hostile, rigid and inflexible, and that makes it more difficult to see a solution to the Palestinian issue.'' Need for Arms Is Questioned **********In the months ahead, Israel could find its military aid challenged because of its prowess in Lebanon. Representative Mickey Leland, a Texas Democrat, said he had come back from Lebanon feeling that Israel's military supremacy was so unchallengeable that future military aid should be subject to ''closer scrutiny'' on the ground that it might not be needed to preserve Israel's military superiority over the Arabs. **********Eight other Representatives, led by Mary Rose Oakar, an Ohio Democrat of Syrian descent, and Nick J. Rahall, a West Virginia Democrat of Lebanese descent, have introduced a resolution calling for a halt in all American military aid to the Middle East if it is determined that American equipment is being used for aggressive purposes. **********''By killing Lebanese, the Israelis have given other parts of the Middle East a voice,'' said Senator Charles McC. Mathias Jr., Republican of Maryland. ''I think when they crossed the Litani River and went beyond the P.L.O. sanctuary in southern Lebanon into Lebanon proper, at that point the Israelis changed something in the atmosphere here.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/07/world.main_headline: FEW IN HONG KONG SEEK DEMOCRACY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/07/world.print_headline: FEW IN HONG KONG SEEK DEMOCRACY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/07/world.body_text: **********In Hong Kong's colonial system of government, a relative handful of Britons have complete control, even though 98 percent of the city-state's five-million-plus residents are Chinese. **********Yet with the negotiations over Hong Kong's future just under way, begun two weeks ago when Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain met in Peking with Chinese leaders, the vast majority of the British crown colony's people want to retain the British administration without any real changes for the foreseeable future, according to public opinion polls. **********Under the present setup, the Governor, Sir Edward Youde, in consultation with the executive and legislative councils, makes all policy decisions. Though there are some Chinese members of the two councils, they are all appointed by the British administrators, not elected by the populace. **********The system of government is, in many ways, as contradictory and anomalous as Hong Kong itself - a colony in an anticolonial era.  For example, when Mrs. Thatcher was in Peking, Hong Kong was engaged in its largest exercise of democratic expression in its history, the election of representatives to so-called city district boards. These boards have been established as a vehicle for gathering views from the people on matters of public concern. Reluctance to Vote **********Despite a big get-out-the-vote effort by the Government, only 12 percent of the two million people eligible to vote bothered to exercise their privilege. **********''The Government is pushing people to the polls,'' acknowledged Joseph Cheng, a professor of political science at Hong Kong's Chinese University and a leading critic of the Government. ''It is the people who are reluctant to vote.'' **********There are several reasons for the apparent political apathy in Hong Kong. With more than 40 percent of the population immigrants and the colony's future uncertain, there is a sense of impermanence to Hong Kong that makes people less inclined to be politically active. **********Moreover, even the Government's harshest critics describe British rule as a ''benevolent dictatorship.'' In the mid-1970's, for instance, the Government established statuatory holidays. In 1979 and 1981, rent control legislation was enacted. In both cases, social programs were enacted by government fiat that the labor unions were too weak to push for and the business community resisted, according to political experts. Hands-Off Government **********In addition, Hong Kong is renowned for its brand of hands-off government with low taxes, and public-sector spending and services, while expanding, is kept to a minimum. **********Because of the Government's limited scope, some residents are not particularly anxious to have a voice in shaping its activities. ''The Government does very little for us,'' said Shirley Woo, a 25-year-old office worker, who did not vote in the district board elections.  ''Why should we care about it?'' **********Rising wages and living standards afforded by Hong Kong's rapid economic growth and a policy of giving the Chinese elite appointed positions in Government have also blunted demands for a more democratic system. **********However, the portion of Hong Kong's population that is seeking more direct participation in Government, though still a minority, is growing. About 60 percent of all residents are under 30 years old, and their levels of education and expectations are higher than their parents, many of whom were refugees. Talks on Hong Kong's Future **********One force that should heighten political awareness, analysts say, is the Peking-London negotiations over the future of Hong Kong after 1997, when the lease covering 90 percent of the colony's land runs out. **********China has stated that it will reassert its sovereignty over all of Hong Kong by 1997. Britain says that the 19th-century treaties that created the colony are still valid, though they can be altered. **********For years, it has been understood that the Peking leadership would not permit Hong Kong to become an independent, self-governing state, or ''a third China,'' Taiwan being the second. This has allowed Britain to run Hong Kong without opening the Government up to elected representatives from the local Chinese community. **********Now, one likely compromise in the British-Chinese talks appears to be a long transition period, up to 40 years, during which the British presence is gradually phased out. Presumably, local Chinese would then be phased in. ''It's very clear that there will be a transition period,'' Mr. Cheng said. ''There can be no excuse for keeping local Chinese out anymore.'' System Characterized as Relic **********As a first step, Mr. Cheng thinks that there should be elected representatives on the legislative council within five years.  Many British Government officials here agree. In private conversations, they are among the first to characterize the present system as a relic of a bygone era. But first, they emphasize, an agreement must be worked out with China, preferably within a year to restore business confidence by removing uncertainties about Hong Kong's future. **********So for the time being, the British administration must remain as the reassuring symbol of the ''stability and prosperity'' in Hong Kong that Peking and London agree are key objectives of the current negotiations. **********''This benevolent dictatorship isn't 100 percent what I'd like, maybe not even 80 percent,'' said Ronald Li, chairman of Hong Kong's Far East stock exchange. ''But 60 percent is better than a lot of the alternatives.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/18/world.body_text: **********Two Italians and their Sherpa guide reached the top of the world's third-highest peak, the 28,208-foot Kanchenjunga. The Ministry of Tourism said today that the group climbed the north face of the mountain in northeast Nepal and reached the summit May 6. The Italians were identified as Reinhold Messner and Gottefried Mutschlechner.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/24/world.main_headline: LEBANON'S PREMIER DEFENDS HIS ARMY'S ROLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/24/world.print_headline: LEBANON'S PREMIER DEFENDS HIS ARMY'S ROLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/24/world.body_text: **********Lebanon's Prime Minister today denounced an Israeli statement that Christian militiamen were sent into two Palestinian refugee camps here last week because the Lebanese Army had refused to take them over. **********''The Lebanese Army refused, in view of the policy of the Government, to be the instrument of Israeli policy while the Israelis were surrounding the camps,'' Prime Minister Shafik al-Wazzan said in an interview. **********A similar point was made in a separate interview by Col. Michel Aoun, the commander of operations for Lebanese troops in West Beirut. He said the army had not refused to enter all Palestinian refugee camps, noting that Lebanese troops had gone into the largest of them, Burj al Brajneh, early this month and had collected many weapons. **********Both men were commenting on the remarks made in the Israeli Parliament by Defense Minister Ariel Sharon during a debate on the massacre of hundreds of Palestinians in the Sabra and Shatila camps last Thursday and Friday. He said that on Sept. 15 the Israelis had asked the Lebanese Army to enter the camps and clear them of weapons and guerrillas. **********Asserting that he himself had refused to discuss the matter with the Israelis because ''the invasion of Beirut was illegal,'' Mr.  Wazzan added: ''If the army had agreed to go in and remove the arms, and the Israelis had then gone in and killed people, everyone would have blamed the Lebanese Army and the Lebanese Government.'' **********The Prime Minister, who is expected to submit his resignation Friday to the newly inducted President, Amin Gemayel, said the Government had wanted to assert control over Sabra and Shatila on something closer to its own terms than the the ones proposed by the Israelis on the day they invaded West Beirut. **********The International Committee of the Red Cross said today that it had completed its count of bodies in Sabra and Shatila and that it had found a total of 294. It said many more remained but that it wold leave the recovery of the rest to the Lebanese. **********A Red Cross spokesman said four bodies were found today at a sports stadium where both Israeli troops and Lebanese Christian militiamen interrogated survivors of the massacre last Saturday. **********The spokesman said they were the bodies of former employees of Gaza Hospital, which is inside the camps just south of the stadium. The bodies, he said, had been identified as those of employees of the Palestinian Red Crescent Society who were arrested Saturday morning by Christian militiamen. **********Colonel Aoun, who declined to be quoted directly, made several points in addition to his description of Lebanese troop actions in Burj al Brajneh. He said in his office at the Museum Crossing on the Green Line that divides the city that the army was in a delicate position, being small and caught between powerful military and political forces. He said the army was an adjunct of the Government and stressed that it respected international conventions against killing civilians. **********The Prime Minister said he had pursued careful plans to extend Government control gradually throughout the city and to get the right-wing Christian militias in East Beirut to give up their arms as the Lebanese leftist and Moslem militias had done in West Beirut.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/14/busin.main_headline: ROLLINS UNIT DESIGNATES CHIEF IN AUG. 2 SPINOFF
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/14/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; ROLLINS UNIT DESIGNATES CHIEF IN AUG. 2 SPINOFF
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/14/busin.body_text: **********William B. Philipbar Jr. will become the chief executive officer of Rollins Environmental Services Inc. on Aug. 2 when the Wilmington, Del., hazardous waste disposal company spins off from its parent, the RLC Corporation. **********Mr. Philipbar, 56, has been with RLC for 10 years, the last seven as president of Rollins Environmental Services. **********He is hoping to broaden the scope of the company once it ceases to be a subsidiary. **********''We're in a capital-intensive business, and as a separate company we might have better access to the equity market,'' Mr. Philipbar said, adding that he was interested in expanding the company's waste disposal sites in Texas, Louisiana and New Jersey. ''We're also looking at the possibility of heat recovery. Our high temperature incineration process gives off a lot of heat, which could be recaptured as steam or electricity.'' **********He continued, ''With a separate company, I'll be much more on my own, and choosing new directions will be more of a personal challenge.'' **********Mr. Philipbar, who lives in Dover, Del., earned a bachelor's degree in chemical engineering from Cornell University in 1951 and an M.B.A. from Rutgers University in 1961. Before joining Rollins Environmental Services, he worked for Tenneco Chemical for 10 years.  Before that, he worked for Exxon.  Isadore Barmash

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/22/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Judging Risk In Municipals
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/22/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Judging Risk In Municipals
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/22/busin.body_text: **********NEW YORK CITY has drawn up plans to lay off at least 3,300 workers and to leave thousands of other positions unfilled. New Jersey is struggling to come up with some new sources of tax revenues. Indeed, in cities and states across the country, governments are scraping to find ways of cutting costs and raising revenues to bring their budgets into balance. **********For many investors, this walk along a financial tightrope poses a tricky question. Municipal bonds are still offering tax-exempt yields in the 10 percent range and, now that interest rates have plunged, the rates look particularly attractive. But are they safe? **********In general, municipal bond experts say yes. Cautious investors may want to be more quality-conscious than usual, they advise, and stick only to the highest-rated bonds - those rated AAA. But few, if any, defaults are expected, and specialists predict that virtually all of these bonds will continue to pay interest. **********''This is a unique opportunity to buy municipal bonds, because rates have shot up again because of a lot of technical reasons, including the fact that are so many issuers coming to market now,'' said Robert Dennis, manager of the MFS Managed Municipal Bond Trust, a $150 million mutual fund. ''Things would really have to be pretty catastrophic nationwide for a major state or city to come close to default.'' **********Hyman C. Grossman, a municipals specialist at Standard & Poor's, one of the leading rating agencies, concurred. ''Cities and states, as such, don't go bankrupt, although they can default,'' he said.  ''But I think cities have learned that the penalties of default are quite severe. What I think will happen is that there will be some close calls. By and large the municipalities will pay, but we will be in for a year or two of strain.'' **********Richard J. Franke, president of John Nuveen & Company, a municipal bond firm, also believes the risks to investors are not overwhelming. ''We came through the 1969 recession and the 1974 recession all right, and I don't think this cycle will be any different or any worse,'' he said. ''It is simply a case of municipal bodies coming to grips with what they have to do. There is always a lag -a period when the deficit might grow - because politicians don't want to cut back services and do want to get re-elected. But as their credit ratings are put under pressure, they will do what they have to do.'' **********The bigger risk for investors, experts say, is buying municipal issues whose credit ratings are subsequently lowered. There have been widespread rating reductions among municipals in the past two years, and experts predict there will be many more. In such cases, the municipalities generally keep paying interest, but their lower credit ratings usually translate into lower prices for their bonds in the market. **********''Washington State is a good example,'' said the municipals chief at one major Wall Street firm who asked not to be identified. ''I am convinced Washington will keep paying its debt. But its credit rating has been reduced several times in the past year or so. And, suddenly, the bond you paid $100 for originally may be worth only $92, because of a reduced credit rating.'' **********But even this risk may be worth taking now, municipal specialists say. Most experts are predicting that municipal rates will fall, producing capital gains for municipal bond holders. And such gains could outweigh any losses suffered because a bond has been downgraded. **********Investment experts note that municipal investors who wish to be as cautious as possible have several options.  One option is simply to diversify their municipal holdings.  Following that option might be easiest for an investor with about $100,000 to place in municipal bonds, a sum that could buy a variety of issues. This approach, though, still requires a lot of study or good advice to pick quality issues. **********For investors with less money, however, probably the best approach is to invest in a mutual fund or a unit investment trust. These investments offer the opportunity to share in a diversified pool of municipal bonds, chosen by a someone who follows the municipal markets closely. **********That is not to say, of course, that such funds never hold bonds that run into problems. But even if one or two municipalities in the portfolio were to run into difficulty, they would represent only a fraction of the investor's holdings. **********''Diversification always limits your risk,'' said Alan Lerner, a senior vice president and credit market expert at Bankers Trust Company. ''But whether it limits it enough is another question.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/20/busin.main_headline: Lionel and 2 Units In Chapter 11 Filing
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/20/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; Lionel and 2 Units In Chapter 11 Filing
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/20/busin.body_text: **********The Lionel Corporation, a diversified producer and retailer of electronics equipment and toys, announced yesterday that it and its wholly owned subsidiaries, Lionel Leisure Inc. and the Consolidated Toy Company, had filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code. **********The company previously reported that it expected to report a loss for the year ended Dec.31, 1981, because of a disappointing Christmas selling season in its toy supermarket operations and high interest expenses. **********In the first nine months of 1981, Lionel lost $12 million on revenues of $166.9 million. In the corresponding period in 1980 the company lost $4.4 million on sales of $129.2 million. Earlier this month, Lionel omitted its regular quarterly dividend of 5 cents. **********Lionel said that its 82 percent owned electronic components manufacturing unit, Dale Electronics Inc., was not affected by the bankruptcy proceedings. Dale Electronics last week reported earnings of $4.65 million for the year, or $1.29 a share, on revenues of $77.4 million. **********Lionel said that the losses offset record sales and earnings at Dale.  Lionel said it was advised late last week that its banks, as a group, would not continue to provide the short-term funds necessary to finance its toy retail business. It added that further discussions this week with certain of the banks were unsuccessful. **********The company repaid all its unsecured short-term bank debt totaling $85 million in December. But it said that with substantial trade debt and other obligations due, it and its two toy retail subsidiaries were forced to seek protection from creditors. **********The company's stock yesterday was traded for the first time in more than a week on the New York Stock Exchange. It opened down 3 3/4 points, at $4 a share, before the exchange again halted trading in the issue. **********Lionel previously sold its electric train unit to General Mills Inc.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/11/world.main_headline: NEW SAINT IS INSPIRATION FOR THE MESSAGE OF HOPE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/11/world.print_headline: NEW SAINT IS INSPIRATION FOR THE MESSAGE OF HOPE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/11/world.body_text: **********For Roman Catholics and non-Catholics alike, the Rev. Maksymilian Kolbe, who was canonized yesterday by Pope John Paul II, has become an inspiration for the message of hope over despair. **********Father Kolbe's canonization was unusual in that his cause was followed not only by Roman Catholics but also by all those who suffered at the hands of the Nazis. **********Father Kolbe was one of 2,801 priests, nuns and monks to be killed by the Nazis in Poland in World War II. He sacrificed himself at Auschwitz by volunteering to take the place of an inmate who had been chosen as part of a group of 10 to be killed in retaliation for the escape of a prisoner. **********By his sacrifice, Father Kolbe became known as a priest of extraordinary courage and faith. His elevation to sainthood was seen as an important denunciation of the Nazi horrors by the Roman Catholic Church. 2 Departures From Procedure **********The circumstances of Father Kolbe's death were recognized by the church as significant enough that at least two departures were warranted from the normal procedure that confers sainthood. **********One distinction was that the Pope waived the general requirement that verifiable miracles be attributed to the candidate. The Rev.  Ambrogio Sanna, who promoted the cause of Father Kolbe, said the Pope had made an exception on the ground that ''the martyr's life and death were of such evident holiness.'' **********The other distinction was that Pope Paul VI personally conducted the rite of beatification - the conferring of the title ''blessed'' - which is the step preliminary to sainthood, on Oct. 17, 1971. Under regular practice, a cardinal would have conducted the ceremony, but Pope Paul broke with tradition in order to underscore the meaning of the event for the wider world. **********''Millions of beings were sacrificed to the pride of force and madness of racialism,'' Pope Paul said that day. ''But in that darkness there glows the figure of Maksymilian Kolbe. Over that immense antechamber of deaths, there hovers his divine and imperishable word of life: redeeming love.'' 'Brightest and Glittering Figure' **********In the same dedication, Pope Paul called Father Kolbe ''perhaps the brighest and glittering figure to emerge from the darkness and degradation of the Nazi epoch.'' **********He was born in 1894 in a small Polish village.  From early childhood he showed an absorption with spiritual matters. At age 10, he had related to his mother a vision in which the Virgin Mary asked him to select one of two crowns, a white one that stood for purity and a red one that signified martrydom. He reportedly said, ''I choose both.'' By age 13, he had set his sights on the priesthood. **********He was often ill in his early years, but his illnesses appear to have deepened his religious convictions. Though he was confined with tuberculosis for four years, he seems to have spent much of that time cultivating inner spirituality. **********After completing basic schooling in Poland, he left for Rome to study at the Gregorian University, a Jesuit insitution, where he earned doctorates in theology and philosophy. **********Ordained by the Franciscans at age 21, Father Kolbe finished his studies in Rome and within two years undertook an initiative that signaled the direction his life and work would take. **********Turning from scholarly pursuits, he founded, in 1917, the Militia of Mary Immaculate, an evangelistic organization dedicated to converting the world to Roman Catholicism. In this bold act, he showed the penchant for individualism, fearlessness and intense devotion to Mary that would mark his vocation until his death at age 47. 'We Can Convert the Whole World' **********He would tell his brothers in 1938: ''Of ourselves we can do nothing, but with the help of the Immaculate One we can convert the whole world. Yes, I tell you we will cast the world at her feet.'' **********As a young priest fresh from Rome, Father Kolbe returned to Poland to work on his own toward the fulfillment of his personal goals. A key factor in the growth of his mission was his publication of a monthly magazine, Knight of the Immaculate, which eventually reached a circulation in the hundreds of thousands. **********In 1927 he furthered the movement significantly by founding a monastery at Niepokalinow, 25 miles southwest of Warsaw. In the 1930's, the monastery was a bustling community of 700 friars and workers engaged in a variety of enterprises, including medicine, dentistry, printing, broadcasting and farming. In 1939 when Hitler attacked Poland, the monestary became a haven for refugees. Strongly opposed to the Nazis, Father Kolbe was arrested in February 1941 on the suspicion of being an enemy of the Third Reich and was sent to Auschwitz. **********Though ravaged by the war and postwar policies in Poland, the monastery continues its work, a monument to its founder.  Father Kolbe poured his prodigious energies into building the community into a force that would combat what he saw as the enemies of atheism and warfare. In taking on this mission, he relied on a theology that, in certain respects, sounds outmoded to many Roman Catholics influenced by the thinking of the Second Vatican Council.  His view of Mary takes on a particularly strange cast to many modern Catholics. **********Father Kolbe's writings contain an exalted concept of Mary that some critics say has been amended by the theological pronouncement of Vatican II. In particular, emphasis at the Council was placed on Mary's role as an intercessor who is subordinate to the Trinity, though just below Christ in rank within the church. **********Theology aside, the memory of Father Kolbe's many acts of mercy at Auschwitz have soared above all other considerations. Of the 10 prisoners condemned to die by starvation, he was the last to perish, meanwhile caring for the agonies of the others and encouraging them with words of Christian hope. The Nazis, in need of the hut where the prisoners were being kept, had to inject carbolic acid into the priest's arm to complete the reprisal. **********The act of martyrdom became the cornerstone of the heroic virtues that raised him to the attention of the church and the world.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/25/world.body_text: **********Guerrillas freed seven more hostages today, and the Government said it expected the rebels' weeklong occupation of the Chamber of Commerce building to end early Saturday. **********The release of two brothers this afternoon and five other Honduran businessmen late in the evening left 32 people captive, less than a third of the original number. **********''It is most likely that the terrorists will leave the city tomorrow,'' said Amilcar Santamaria, a presidential spokesman.  Earlier, the local radio station reported the Government had sealed off the international airport because the guerrillas would be permitted to fly out of the country. It was not immediately clear where they might go. **********There has been speculation that the 10 guerrillas occupying the building would be granted safe passage in return for releasing their remaining prisoners.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/19/busin.body_text: **********A war of words has erupted between Eastern Airlines and Pan American World Airways over Eastern's acquisition of most of Braniff International's Latin American routes. **********Eastern officials have made public a letter written by Pan Am's chairman, C. Edward Acker, dated May 10, that tells his employees to make Eastern ''regret that they ever obtained'' the Latin American routes awarded by the Civil Aeronautics Board. **********The letter was written before Braniff International filed for bankruptcy and announced that Pan Am was suing Braniff for breach of contract. Pan Am officials insist the letter was nothing more than an effort to motivate their employees. **********Eastern's president, Frank Borman, seized the opportunity to motivate his own employees.  He sent a copy of the letter to 37,000 employees, with two paragraphs - saying Pan Am was the better airline and Eastern would regret ever winning the Latin American routes -outlined in bold.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/11/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Rosy Outlook At Matrix
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/11/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Rosy Outlook At Matrix
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/11/busin.body_text: **********THE Exxon Corporation ran into a problem about a year and a half ago with huge compressor pistons used in its North Sea oil and gas operations. They were breaking too often, bringing operations to a halt until the pistons could be replaced. **********The problem was turned over to company engineers, who devised a computer program that could convert stress points in the pistons to color photographs, with different colors representing different stresses in pounds per square inch. **********Soon Exxon's engineers found a way to change the configuration of the pistons and the materials used in them so that today the pistons are working satisfactorily. **********Helping Exxon accomplish this is the little-known Matrix Corporation of Northvale, N.J.  Matrix manufactures camera-like devices that take computer information and transfer it to black-and-white or color film. Now, with Polaroid set to market instant 35-millimeter slides within a year, Matrix will be adding the Polaroid device as a new option to its own equipment and is looking forward to a ''significant increase'' in sales to customers who not only want good photographs but also want them quickly and cheaply. **********Matrix, which is traded on the American Stock Exchange, reported sales in the fiscal year ended Aug. 31 of $26 million, up 33 percent from $19.6 million a year earlier. Net income, meanwhile, jumped 42.1 percent, to $2.7 million, or 85 cents a share, from $1.9 million, or 65 cents a share. Sales for the second fiscal quarter ended Feb. 28, 1982, rose 57 percent, to $9.1 million, from $5.8 million a year earlier, while profits climbed 70 percent, to $952,000, or 29 cents a share, from $559,000, or 18 cents a share. **********Last October, at a time Matrix shares were quoted at $18, F.  Eberstadt & Company recommended the company ''strongly.'' And last March, Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith changed its recommendation from ''O.K. to buy'' to ''buy.'' Yesterday, the stock closed on the Amex at 22 3/4, down 3/8. **********In its report, Merrill Lynch said it based its revised opinion on ''continued strong fundamentals.'' It said that for the near term it saw no negative impact on the company's fundamentals because of the economic environment, and it forecast a sharp rise in company profits for the full year. This strong outlook, it added, suggested the company's ''ability to sustain above-average growth during the recession period.'' **********Davis Skaggs & Company, a San Francisco brokerage house, in another favorable recommendation noted that Matrix's sales in the last two and a half years rose at a compound annual rate of 38 percent and were complemented by an earnings growth rate of more than 50 percent a year. It forecast that Matrix's growth rate in the next two years would top 50 percent annually. **********In a current report, Value Line's special situations service, for sophisticated investors, is also recommending it. ''Over all,'' Value Line said, ''we expect Matrix's sales to grow 30 percent to 35 percent annually for the next three to five years, to about $100 million, by 1984 to 1986.'' It said such earnings, should they develop, suggested that the market price for Matrix could rise substantially in the same period. **********The Matrix device has broad applications. Hospitals and clinics use it in diagnostic scanning; Honeywell, to get pictures of new electronic circuits, and the University of Miami weather service, to study hurricanes. **********As explained by Franklin G. Bishop, president of the company, a Matrix machine produces photographs fed from a scanning device to a computer to a television screen, and from the TV screen to film.  Unlike the typical TV screen, however, this screen is exceptionally sharp, with the pictures taken from it just as sharp. **********But, until Polaroid's new 35-millimeter instant slide is available, the process continues to be relatively expensive or timeconsuming. Currently, for example, an 8-inch-by-10-inch Polaroid print can be made almost instantly with the Matrix device but costs $7.50, Mr. Bishop noted. And a user might have to take many photographs, at $7.50 each, before finding one suitable for his needs. **********With the new Polaroid process, however, a roll of 35-millimeter Polaroid film can be shot and processed quickly and cheaply. Once an acceptable slide is found, it can either be projected on a movie screen, used to make color prints (at a cost of roughly $1.50 each for the 5-by-8 size) or to make Xerox color copies, although few such machines are available because the demand has never developed. **********The State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Company had owned 7 percent of the company's stock but sold it about two weeks ago at $19 a share, Mr. Bishop said. Kemper Financial Services owns 6 percent of the stock, he noted. Company officers and directors hold 21 percent more, with Mr. and Mrs. Bishop owning 8 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/02/world.body_text: **********Senator Larry Pressler said today that he found ''a great deal of skepticism'' about the prospects for a new strategic arms agreement when he met with the Soviet official who will head the Soviet delegation to the talks in Geneva. **********The South Dakota Republican, who is chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee's subcommittee on arms control, said that the Soviet official, Viktor P. Karpov, and other senior Soviet officials sharply questioned President Reagan's sincerity in agreeing to the new talks that will begin June 29 and in calling for reductions in the two sides' strategic arsenals. In particular, the Senator said, the Soviet officials said that they considered it ''not a very realistic judgment at all'' to expect a new pact before the end of Mr. Reagan's Presidential term in 1985. **********Mr. Pressler, a strong supporter of Mr. Reagan's military policies, said that the Soviet attitude seemed to be captured by a jesting remark made to Mr. Karpov by Viktor G. Komplektov, chief of the Foreign Ministry's American department. The Senator said that after the Soviet officials had waved away his remarks about Mr. Reagan's wanting an early agreement, perhaps in as little as 18 months, Mr.  Komplektov turned to Mr. Karpov and said: ''You've just got a 10-year job.'' **********A skeptical tone also was struck in the first Soviet press commentary on the announcement of a starting date for the Geneva talks. The official press agency Tass, in an article by its military affairs commentator, Vladimir Bogachyov, said that while Mr.  Reagan's agreement to resume negotiations was ''a step in the right direction'' it was to be hoped that it was not solely a gesture to placate public opinion before the President's trip to Western Europe, which begins Wednesday. **********On the positive side, the commentary said that ''one should welcome'' Mr. Reagan's commitment that the United States will not ''undercut'' previous arms agreements with the Soviet Union so long as the Kremlin does the same. **********Senator Pressler said that Georgi A. Arbatov, director of the Institute of the United States and Canada, had used the word ''extremists'' to describe President Reagan's team of arms negotiators, including Edward L. Rowny, named to head the strategic arms delegation in Geneva. But the Senator said that Mr. Karpov, Mr.  Rowny's opposite number, had said that the two men had ''a great deal of mutual respect'' despite past disagreements on arms control issues.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/05/busin.body_text: **********The assets of 174 money market funds, including two new ones, rose $133 million in the week ended Wednesday, to $186.36 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. The institute said that individual investors accounted for the modest increase, while institutional investors moved money out of the funds and into shortterm securities to get higher yields. **********The average seven-day yield for major funds during the period, as reported by Donoghue's Money Fund Report, slipped to 13.29 percent from 13.47 percent the week before. The average 30-day yield rose to 13.17 percent from 12.98 percent. By comparison, six-month money market certificates offered by banks and saving institutions pay up to 13.693 percent. **********The Investment Company Institute said that 97 general purpose funds, including one new one, gained $423 million in assets, to reach $59.23 billion. The general purpose funds tend to be used by small investors. **********Assets at the 41 funds handled by broker dealers, including one additional one this week, rose $143 million, to $96.43 billion.  Assets of the 36 institutional funds, following their trend this year, fell $433 million, to $30.70 billion. **********---- Funds table, page D11.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/17/world.main_headline: U.S. EMBASSY IN ARGENTINA DENIES IT IS SEEKING TO UNDERMINE JUNTA
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/17/world.print_headline: U.S. EMBASSY IN ARGENTINA DENIES IT IS SEEKING TO UNDERMINE JUNTA
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/17/world.body_text: **********The United States Embassy here has been accused by Argentine newspapers of trying to undermine the ruling junta in the Falkland Islands crisis, but it responded today by denying any ''inappropriate conduct.'' **********The embassy's unusual statement followed publication here of accusations that the United States Ambassador, Harry W. Shlaudeman, and other embassy officials had met with opposition political leaders in an attempt to ''destabilize'' the military Government led by Gen. Leopoldo Galtieri. **********The newspaper accusations cited unidentified sources high in the military Government. Argentine journalists and Western diplomats said the sources for the accusations were leading officers in the junta. **********''The United States Embassy flatly denies any inappropriate conduct,'' the embassy statement said, ''and has no real idea what this is all about.'' **********The accusations raise a potentially dangerous issue when relations between Washington and Buenos Aires are already strained because of United States support for Britain in the Falkland conflict. A number of United States diplomats, businessmen and journalists have received threats, and the embassy has evacuated some dependents. **********In military action, the Argentine high command acknowledged that British warplanes damaged two Argentine transport ships today in an attack in the channel between the two main Falkland islands. It said one of the ships had been set afire but did not mention casualties. Ship Is Believed to Be Lost **********An earler communique said British jets today attacked Darwin, 50 miles west of Stanley, the capital of the Falklands, and Fox Bay, 25 miles to the south. The communique said the attacks were ''without consequences and were repelled by our forces stationed there.'' **********Senior officers also said today that a missing interisland supply ship had probably been sunk, with its more than 30 crewmen lost.  The Argentine officers said the ship, the Isla de los Estados, could have been the one that the British said they blew up Monday night in the Falkland channel. **********Concerning diplomatic efforts to settle the dispute, Foreign Minister Nicanor Costa Mendez tonight criticized the delay in mediation at the United Nations while Britain's negotiators conferred back in London. ''What bothers me most,'' he told reporters here, ''is not the question of the recent British attacks but the delay in the negotiations, the refusal to accept a normal and reasonable dialogue, which is due entirely to the intransigent position of Great Britain.'' **********Mr. Costa Mendez, heartened by the European Common Market's delay until Monday of a vote on extending trade sanctions against Argentina, said he hoped that the embargo would not be renewed. He said it would ''help in the peace negotitions'' if the Common Market did not support British ''military action'' by renewing the sanctions. **********The campaign here against the American Embassy is directed only at the embassy, and it may involve divisions within the military on the attitude toward the United States. The navy has been the service most angered at the United States for its support of Britain in the crisis. But some leaders, including President Galtieri, have gone out of their way not to criticize the United States, particularly since the two-day visit last week by a special envoy, Vernon A. Walters. Galtieri Says He Is Saddened **********In a television interview today, General Galtieri said he was greatly saddened by the United States support for Britain. ''I have had the opportunity of being close to and living with the American people, and I know what they feel,'' said the general, who took an advanced engineer officer's course at Fort Belvoir, Va., in 1960. **********La Nacion, a daily close to the Government, reported in a frontpage article today that some senior members of the Government were pressing the junta to file an official protest note with the State Department regarding Ambassador Shlaudeman. **********La Nacion, Clarin and La Prensa, the three largest newspapers in the country, have reported that military leaders complained to Mr.  Walters about Mr. Shlaudeman and other embassy officials during the special envoy's visit here. They said Mr. Walters replied that he would carry the complaints back to Washington. Said to Meet With Peronists **********There have been persistent newspaper reports here for two weeks that Ambassador Shlaudeman had met with opposition Peronist leaders, even though the Peronists are more anti-American and nationalistic over the Falklands than the military. **********Western diplomats here say that since the Falkland crisis began the United States Embassy has cut back on its normal contacts with leaders of different sectors of Argentine society, including opposition political and labor leaders. It cut back even further after the Reagan Administration announced two weeks ago that it was siding with Britain in the conflict. **********Sources close to Mr. Shlaudeman said the Ambassador had not met with any opposition leaders since Argentina seized the Falklands April 2. **********The sources said Mr. Shlaudeman, who was deputy chief of mission in Chile in 1973 when President Salvador Allende Gossens was overthrown in a military coup, has been sensitive to charges that the United States aided that coup. They said he had assiduously sought to avoid even the appearance of any such involvement ever since. **********Mr. Shlaudeman was Ambassador in Peru before coming here in 1980, the year the Peruvian military handed power to a democratic Government. **********One Western diplomat said the accusations against the embassy were part of an attempt by some members of the Government to find ''a scapegoat'' in the Falkland crisis. The country is united behind the militarry in the fight to hold onto the islands, but the rejuvenated political parties have made it clear that they expect to share government power after the crisis ends. Some parties met last week to discuss future presidential candidates.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/24/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS DIGEST; WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 24, 1982; The Economy
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/24/busin.body_text: **********Consumer prices rose 0.5 percent in October, the Labor Department reported. The increase was slightly larger than officials had expected, but not enough to upset a projection that inflation will be down to about 5 percent for the year. (Page A1.) Prices in the New York area rose 1.5 percent. (D3.) **********Factory orders for durable goods fell 4.9 percent in October, to a seasonally adjusted total of $69.7 billion, the Commerce Department reported. Analysts said that the decline, the biggest in a year, indicates further declines in overall industrial production, which would keep unemployment high. (D1.) **********President Reagan asked Congress to approve a five-year, $32.9 billion plan to repair roads and bridges and to aid mass transit projects. The Government's 80 percent share would be financed by a four-cent rise in the gasoline tax. Although the bill would create 320,000 jobs, Mr. Reagan insisted it is not a jobs program. (A1.) **********Curbs on the duration of television commercials were removed by a Federal judge, raising the possibility that eventually curbs on content might be removed too. Broadcasters, though they consented to the action, strongly objected to it. The Government had accused the industry of violating antitrust law by setting the curbs. (A1.) **********The Federal Reserve should continue to tolerate over-target growth in its money supply measures, according to Martin S. Feldstein, President Reagan's chief economic adviser. (D7.) International **********The Common Market has rejected U.S. demands that its members phase out farm export subsidies totaling $8 billion a year. The move clouds the outcome of the world trade conference that opens today in Geneva. The export subsidy issue is one of several dividing the allies, who are seeking to check spreading protectionism. (D1.) **********The Pope issued orders apparently meant to limit the Vatican's financial activities. The move comes as a panel of 15 cardinals is studying the ties between the Vatican and Banco Ambrosiano, a private bank whose collapse left outstanding about $1.4 billion in loans accompanied by letters of patronage from the Vatican bank. (D1.) **********China's state airline will buy 10 Boeing 737-200 jetliners for $160 million as part of an effort to overhaul its outdated fleet. (D4.) Companies **********Gustave M. Hauser announced he will resign as chief of Warner Amex Cable Comunications. The 53-year-old industry pioneer said he did not want to work for another company. Analysts, surprised by the move, speculated that there might be dissatisfaction over the direction of the company and its recent losses. (D1.) **********Gulf Oil and Exxon reduced wholesale heating oil prices. Analysts said that the reduction was spurred by an unexpected drop in demand and that further decreases appear likely. https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/20/busin.main_headline: DOLLAR'S FALL WILL LAST INTO 1983, ANALYSTS SAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/20/busin.print_headline: DOLLAR'S FALL WILL LAST INTO 1983, ANALYSTS SAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/20/busin.body_text: **********After a run-up that lasted nearly two years, the value of the dollar on foreign exchange markets has begun to slide. While the dollar is expected to remain strong, the decline is likely to continue well into 1983, according to economists, traders and foreign exchange experts. **********Since early November, the dollar has dropped by more than 12 percent against the Japanese yen, 6 percent against the West German mark and 7 percent against the Swiss franc. Nevertheless, the dollar is still overvalued, analysts say. A year ago, for example, the dollar was trading 11 percent lower against the yen and 8 percent lower against the mark than at Friday's close on New York foreign exchange markets. **********''The dollar is likely to weaken over the next 12 months, but it will still be strong,'' said Lars H. Thunnell, a vice president at the American Express Company. Significance for Exports **********The decline is not steep enough yet to suit American exporters, whose products have grown uncompetitive in world markets. Even if the dollar's drop continues, experts say, it will be another six months at least before the drop could generate a turn in export orders.  Despite the lag, few denied that both the domestic and international economy would profit from a cheaper dollar. **********''At this point everyone is trying to reduce imports simultaneously,'' said Ann Parker Mills, a vice president at the Irving Trust Company. ''A cheaper dollar, particularly against the yen, is very positive in terms of an offset to protectionist pressures.'' **********Two main factors are driving down the value of the dollar, according to currency specialists: rising current-account deficits and a change in Federal Reserve Board policy. **********After posting surpluses during the first and second quarters of the year, the United States' current account balance, which includes trade in goods and services as well as dividend and interest payments, has turned sharply negative. In the third quarter, it fell to a deficit of $4.2 billion. That gap is expected to widen, and some economists say 1983's deficit could easily exceed the record $14.7 billion in 1978. **********Current-account deficits are an important determinant of exchange rate values because they increase the net supply of a currency on the market. When the United States imports more goods and services than it exports, the supply of dollars is increased in foreign exchange markets, suggesting that supply is greater than demand and forcing down the price of the dollar. **********''At this point, the final move by the United States into what could become a record current-account deficit is the key thing determining the value of the dollar,'' said Paul L. Newhart, manager of foreign exchange at the Dupont Company. Shift in Fed Policy **********Most experts acknowledge that America's deteriorating trade position will be an increasingly important factor determining future exchange rate movements. However, many say that a shift in Federal Reserve policy - and the Administration's support of that change - is the main reason for the dollar's current and expected further decline. **********Over the past two years, the Fed's anti-inflation policies have kept interest rates high relative to those elsewhere, pulling large amounts of foreign money into United States capital markets and pushing the value of the dollar ever higher. As long as the Fed was perceived as maintaining its tight money approach, interest rate differentials continued to be the key in determining the value of the dollar. **********Perhaps the best example of the strength of the Fed's credibility occurred in the third quarter, when substantial declines in interest rates failed to prevent the value of the dollar from rising to record levels. Now, however, the focus is beginning to shift. **********''The importance of interest rate differentials began to wane after the Fed would no longer concentrate'' on growth of M-1, a measure of the nation's basic money supply, said Jonathan Francis, director of foreign exchange forecasting services at Wharton Econometrics. ''But it was not until early November that the markets began to believe it, and expectations were changed.'' **********Jonathan Lopatin, a member of Bank of America's financial markets advisory service group in New York, agrees with that view.  ''There has been a tremendous shift in attitudes about the dollar in the last few weeks,'' Mr. Lopatin said. ''Up until then, the monetarism of the Fed was the anchor against which traders turned a blind eye. Now, for the first time in a long, long time, the markets are turning their attention to other variables, like rising current account deficits.'' Indirect Market Intervention **********The reasons for a shift in Fed policy were compelling, said W.H.  Bruce Brittain, a vice president at Salomon Brothers. **********''With the rest of the world waiting for the American economy to recover, the Fed is the only institution capable of doing something about the slowdown in the domestic economy and also reducing the debt burden of the developing countries,'' Mr. Brittain said. ''The only way they can do that is to pump up the liquidity of the American banking system. It is in response to that change that the dollar has weakened since November and is likely to decline further through the first six months of 1983.'' **********An apparent change in attitude on the part of the Reagan Administration about the severe economic problems created by the strong dollar - and the way to solve them - may also be playing a part in the market's shifting psychology, Mr. Francis said. The Administration, which remains committed in a rhetorical sense against intervening in foreign exchange markets, may in practice be doing something else. **********''Monetary officials say their position on intervention in foreign exchange markets remains unchanged,'' Mr. Francis said, ''but the loans extended to Mexico and Brazil during the third quarter represent an indirect form of market intervention, because by extending those loans the authorities are stabilizing the peso and the cruzeiro. The major reason why the dollar is likely to fall next year is that the Administration finally recognizes what its policy of tight money has actually done to the international economy,'' **********With the exception of the French franc and the Italian lira, most experts agree the dollar is likely to weaken generally against other major currencies, and particularly against the yen, which could rise another 10 percent by the end of 1983. Despite the slide, the sharp reduction in the domestic inflation rate and the relative stability of America's political and economic climate make it unlikely the dollar will be oversold next year.
