https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/18/busin.main_headline: GULF OIL IS PLANNING $5.1 BILLION MERGER WITH CITIES SERVICE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/18/busin.print_headline: GULF OIL IS PLANNING $5.1 BILLION MERGER WITH CITIES SERVICE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/18/busin.body_text: **********In a $5.1 billion deal that would be one of the biggest corporate acquisitions on record, the Gulf Oil Corporation said yesterday that it planned to buy the Cities Service Company. **********The agreement, announced jointly by the two oil giants, was viewed on Wall Street as an effort to frustrate a takeover of Cities Service being attempted by the much smaller Mesa Petroleum Company of Amarillo, Tex. Cities Service has opposed the Mesa attempt. **********A Gulf-Cities Service combination would be exceeded in value only by the $7.2 billion purchase of Conoco Inc. by **********A sharp rise in interest rates depressed the prices of stocks and gold. Details in Business Day E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company last summer and the United States Steel Corporation's $6 billion acquisition of the Marathon Oil Company this year. **********It would create the nation's seventh-largest industrial corporation, only slightly smaller in terms of sales than the Ford Motor Company. Gulf is the nation's sixth-largest oil company and the ninth-largest industrial concern; Cities Service is the 20th-largest oil company. **********The acquisition by Gulf, which has unsuccessfully sought to buy other oil companies in the past, would also raise Gulf's ranking in the oil industry to fifth place. The Justice Department said almost immediately that the venture would be reviewed by the Federal Trade Commission for possible antitrust problems. **********It would be the first important test of new Government antitrust guidelines announced Monday by both agencies, but sources close to both companies said that they thought they had a strong case to present. **********As proposed, Gulf will offer shareholders of Cities Service $63 a share for their 80.4 million shares, or about $5.1 billion. About 51 percent of the stock would be purchased for cash and the balance for Gulf Oil securities. Cities Service stock did not trade on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday because of the pending announcement.  The closing price Wednesday was $37.75. **********Even if Mesa was defeated, however, the company would profit handsomely on the 4.1 million shares of Cities Service that it held before its takeover offer. The holding represents 5 percent of Cities Service stock. Mesa's Yearlong Pursuit **********Mesa's chairman, T. Boone Pickens Jr., who is state campaign chairman for Gov. William P. Clements of Texas and one of the more colorful figures in the oil industry, had been in pursuit of Cities Service for the past year - over the objections of the company. **********By late last month, after it became convinced that Mesa was closing in, Cities Service decided to act first. It offered $17 a share for a 51 percent controlling interest in Mesa and, after attracting 41 percent of Mesa's stock, raised the offer to $21 a share to encourage stockholders not to take the stock back, at a time that it was selling in the open market at more than Cities Service was offering. **********Mesa responded earlier this month with a proposal made only to Cities Service's executives, offering to pay $50 a share for a 51 percent interest. When officials showed no interest, Mesa went directly to Cities Service stockholders. This time Mesa offered only $45 a share and said it could purchase only 15 percent, reserving the right to buy more if it got additional financing. **********Shareholders left no doubt that they were interested in Mesa's $45 offer -with many gambling that Cities Service would invite in another company to stave off Mesa, at a better price. **********By midnight Wednesday, the deadline for Mesa to guarantee that it would accept Cities Service shares, about 34.6 million of the company's 80.4 million shares had been turned in for payment. By early yesterday, an additional 1.2 million shares had arrived. Thus, 44.5 percent of Cities Service's shares were sent in on an offer seeking only 15 percent. **********Terms of Mesa's offer provide that Cities Service stockholders are permitted to take back their shares until June 25, and unless someonetops Gulf's offer, shares sent to Mesa are expected to be transferred to Gulf. Definitive Agreement Signed **********In a brief announcement of the proposed combination, James E. Lee, chairman of Gulf, and Charles J. Waidelich, chairman of Cities Service, said that they had signed a definitive agreement for Gulf to buy Cities Service at $63 a share. **********They said Gulf would buy 51 percent for $63 in cash and the balance for ''fixed-income securities,'' valued at ''no less than $63.'' Cities Service also granted Gulf an option to buy 14.5 million shares of the company, or some 15 percent of the total outstanding if exercised, for $913.5 million in cash. Cities Service gave no guidance on what it might now do about its bid for Mesa, saying only that the offer was progressing and that it would continue to review it. **********Gulf is the first major oil company since Mobil to attempt a takeover of another sizable oil company. Mobil's efforts to acquire Conoco and Marathon were thwarted by antitrust problems. Gulf, which is based in Pittsburgh, has attempted several times to play a role in a number of oil takeoversbut without success. It lost to U.S. Steel, for example, in a bid to buy Marathon. **********Harold H. Hammer, Gulf's chief administrative officer, said that Gulf had studied Cities Service some time ago, that he and Mr. Lee had been telephoning Mr. Waidelich ''almost every day for the last few weeks'' and that ''they kept saying they wanted to stay independent - until yesterday.'' **********He said that Gulf currently had a $3 billion line of credit from a bank group headed by the National Westminster Bank of London and the Bankers Trust Company of New York. **********Asked whether Gulf would face any antitrust problems in buying Cities Service, which is based in Tulsa, Okla.,he said there might be ''a slight market overlap'' in the sale of gasoline. He said Gulf did not regard the problem as critical. **********As to why Gulf wanted Cities Service, he said that its main attractions were its oil and gas reserves and undeveloped acreage.  Cities Service has 287 million barrels of crude reserves plus 2.7 trillion cubic feet of natural gas. Cities Service's oil lands, largely undeveloped, amount to 12.4 million acres. **********Mr. Pickens, Mesa's chairman, said of his fight for Cities Service, ''We threw a party and it was expensive,'' but he added, ''We'll be back.'' **********He declined to say he was capitulating, but said that ''Gulf's making a good buy at $63, if they get it.'' He called the bid ''a pretty strong offer.'' His company's 4.1 million shares of Cities Service, he said, had cost $44 a share, thus giving Mesa a possible pretax profit of nearly $80 million. It began accumulating its stake early last year. **********The remarks seemed to rule out any serious challenge to Gulf's exceptionally favorable offer. At $63, the bid was close to the $78-a-share value of the company set by John S. Herold Inc., oil appraisers, of Greenwich, Conn., if the company was broken up and sold. **********As viewed by oilmen, Cities Service never really wanted to be taken over by any company, not even Gulf, agreeing to the dealonly when it seemed that Mesa might win. It declined to negotiate with Mesa on any terms, apparently because Mesa was determined to take it over even without the company's endorsement and seemed likely to replace Cities Service's top executives with Mesa officials.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/05/busin.body_text: **********Albert J. Wein, 57 years old, has been named president and chief operating officer of Steelmet Inc., a leading secondary metals company with headquarters in Pittsburgh. He succeeds Joseph F.  Rooney, 53, who resigned to pursue personal interests. **********Alan Amper, 58, a co-founder of the corporation in 1961, continues as chairman and chief executive officer. **********Speaking of his industry - which recycl es s crap by recovering wastematerials and preparing them to be used again by metal consumers - Mr. Wein said yesterday that ''it is coming o ff one of the most difficult years.'' Then he added: ''I've seen good times, and I've seen bad times. Let's hope we see better time s.'' **********According to Mr. Wein: ''The outlook for the industry is more optimistic than it was six months ago, as most people feel there could be an improvement in the economy in the second quarter and perhaps in the second half. How much is real optimism and how much is wishful thinking is another thing.'' **********Before joining Steelmet soon after its establishment, Mr. Wein had been with the Tube City Iron and Metal Company, where he rose to vice president. He became a vice president of Steelmet in 1962, senior vice president 12 years later and executive vice president about two years ago. **********Mr. Rooney had been president of the Eastern Stainless Steel Company before coming to Steelmet in 1979. Soon afterward, he was appointed president. **********As he assumes the presidency, Mr. Wein said: ''I will retain those customers I have been calling on. The business really consists of two things: the relationship with customers and internal management. I think the customers are the lifeblood of the business.'' Leonard Sloane

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/28/busin.body_text: **********Cutting the Budget **********As Congress starts packing for its Easter recess, differences over the Administration's 1983 budget remain unresolved. Congressional and private analysts agree that some concessions from the White House are probable. **********But they say that cuts in defense and entitlement programs are not likely to be of a size to drastically alter the Administration's budget, or reduce the Federal deficit below the $100 billion level in fiscal 1983. **********The sense of urgency about the economic dangers of 12-digit deficits is not as strong as it once was on Capitol Hill, says Jonathan Neuberger, an economist with the Washington Analysis Group.  Inflation is falling rapidly and Treasury borrowings during the first half of this fiscal year have been lower than anticipated, easing worries about the impact on the credit markets. **********The sanguine approach may be jolted this spring, Mr. Neuberger says. Tax refunds in the second quarter may be much higher than normal, raising Treasury borrowings far above current levels. The July tax cuts and increases in Social Security payments are likely to push the Treasury's needs even higher in the third quarter, he says, setting the stage for a possible collision with rising corporate credit demand.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/25/world.main_headline: QADDAFI WILL VISIT GREECE THIS WEEK
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/25/world.print_headline: QADDAFI WILL VISIT GREECE THIS WEEK
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/25/world.body_text: **********Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, is making an official visit to Greece on Friday in an attempt to establish a bridge with Western Europe and to blunt American efforts to isolate him internationally. **********It will be Colonel Qaddafi's first official visit to a country that is a member of North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Common Market. **********For the governing Greek Socialists, the reserved acceptance of Colonel Qaddafi's overtures represents an attempt to win economic advantages and to prove their claim of following a policy independent of the West. **********An official of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou's Government stressed that the Libyan leader had asked to be invited to Greece.  The official, who asked that his name not be used, said that Athens had planned to delay the visit as long as possible but that acceptance became much easier after the Libyan leader's official visit to Austria last month. Western diplomatic sources said NATO and the Common Market did not favor the visit, ''because it helps give Qaddafi respectability.'' **********Ex-Regime Delayed Visit **********Former Foreign Minister Constantine Mitsotakis said his conservative Government had also accepted a Qaddafi visit ''in principle'' but had kept it in abeyance. This was in line with the policy of the Common Market, which unlike the United States favors maintaining some contacts with Libya. **********Mr. Mitsotakis said the Socialists ''committed themselves to Libya so much in the past that they now find it impossible to resist Qaddafi's pressure.'' This was a reference to the openly pro-Libyan declarations by the Socialist Party while it was in opposition, which led to several reports that it was being financed by Libya. **********The Government dismisses such allegations, saying the Qaddafi visit should be seen as part of Greece's effort to expand its already close relations with the Arab world, a policy initiated by the former conservative Governments. ''But whereas the last Government wanted only economic relations with the Arab countries, we want closer political ties,'' the Government official said. ''We see ourselves as the bridge between the Arabs and Europe.'' **********Despite the Qaddafi visit - and the lavish welcome recently given Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, and the granting of full diplomatic status to the P.L.O. -the Government asserts it is being careful not to unnecessarily upset its NATO and Common Market partners. **********''Greece's policies are not really that different from other Western countries,'' the official said, recalling the Common Market's support for the establishment of a Palestinian state.  ''Greece is just playing an avant-garde role with the Arabs, which should not be misinterpreted. We have made it clear from the start that the security and existence of Israel has never been put into question by Greece.'' Difficulties Persist **********The drive to establish closer economic relations between Greece and Libya began with a economic cooperation agreement in 1976. But practical difficulties have persisted, and Athens will no doubt seek to resolve them during Colonel Qaddafi's visit. **********Among the difficulties were the failure of attempts to set up a direct shipping line between the ports of Piraeus and Benghazi and a joint fishing and trading company. Furthermore, Greek fishing trawlers are constantly harassed by the Libyans, and Greek sailors have been jailed for many months after venturing into the 200-mile territorial waters claimed by Libya. **********Of greater concern is that Tripoli has not paid the hundreds of millions of dollars owed to Greek engineering companies that have fulfilled contracts in Libya. The Libyans have offered to pay in oil, an offer Greece rejects because Tripoli is calculating its crude oil at much higher prices than those of the international market. **********Diplomatic sources say Libya is now seeking a package deal, by which Athens would provide agricultural products, pipelines, construction materials and light arms in return for Libyan oil and more engineering contracts. Greece appears unwilling to accept such a deal, since oil supplies are now plentiful. Trade Totals $300 Million **********Despite the difficulties, diplomatic sources say Greece still attaches considerable importance to its economic ties with the volatile Arab nation. Total trade between the two countries last year approached $300 million, and Libya is the second largest Arab importer of Greek goods after Saudi Arabia. Moreover, the Greek engineering companies in Libya represent a major investment and source of employment, the sources say, and Prime Minister Papandreou still hopes to convince his guest to make substantial investments in Greece despite Libya's growing economic difficulties. **********Walter Buchholz, of the Arab-Hellenic Chamber of Commerce, acknowledges that the Socialist Government's appeals for financial aid from Libya, Iraq and Saudi Arabia have brought no results so far. As a result, Greece has had to borrow from the West. **********Diplomatic sources see several other political and diplomatic advantages for Athens in Colonel Qaddafi's visit to counterbalance the disadvantages of displeasing the West. The trip will help give Mr. Papandreou's Government a look of support for the third world.  This, in the face of his unwillingness to pull Greece out of NATO and the Common Marekt, helps placate the left wing of his party and the pro-Moscow Greek Communist Party, whose leader made an official visit to Tripoli this month.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/07/busin.main_headline: THE NATIONAL BANK OF MERRILL LYNCH
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/07/busin.print_headline: THE NATIONAL BANK OF MERRILL LYNCH
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/07/busin.body_text: **********BOUNTIFUL, Utah, is a tranquil farm community of barely 40,000 people. It is also the home of the Utah Bank and Trust Company. Utah Bank's deposits, now some $41 million, have slid about $1 million in the last two years. Morris H. Atwood, the president, says he isn't sure who has been rustling his long loyal checking account customers but high on the list of suspects he puts Merrill Lynch & Company, the financial services firm that offers customers high-yielding moneymarket funds with check-writing privileges. **********So Mr. Atwood and Utah's other small-town bankers set out to do what thousands of their big-city brethren have pondered doing for a couple of years. They set out to stop Merrill Lynch. The bankers went to their friends in the Legislature and got an amendment to a pending bill to put Merrill and firms like it under the wing of the state banking department. That in turn would have just about put Merrill out of the checking-account business in Utah. However, Merrill and its allies in the securities industry lobbied fiercely against the amendment, and succeeded in killing it. **********It was the most serious assault yet against Merrill Lynch's exceptional new service and it could well be the last. Wall Street's biggest stock broker has progressed so far into the business of commercial banking and other financial services that nothing seems likely to stop it. Today, with some $23 billion in its Ready Assets money fund, the nation's biggest, and $13 billion in its more flexible Cash Management Account, Merrill's holdings of deposit-like client funds exceed the domestic deposits of Citibank by $16 billion. And unlike most bank checking accounts, both of Merrill's pay substantial interest. **********In what see med like grudging recognition of this fact, Walter B.  Wriston, board chairman of Citibank, remarked before a Senate banking committee last fall, at a time of higher interest rates, ''The genie will never go back in the bottle.  People know the difference between 17 percent and 5 percent, and so the whole system has to adjust to it.'' **********More to the point Mr. Wriston said, in a somewhat inaccurate remark, Citibank had been at it since 1812 while Merrill had been at it ''almost 24 months.'' In fact, Merrill has been at it since 1975, with its Ready Asset fund. **********It was been a year ago that Donald T. Regan, the man who built the modern Merrill Lynch, left Wall Street to run the Reagan Treasury, leaving the firm with his then little-known heir, Roger E. Birk.  Questions soon arose whether any successor could sustain the competitive verve that characterized the Regan tenure. **********Perhaps it would be too early, after one year in office, to conclude one way or the other whether Mr. Birk has succeeded. But Merrill's relentless pursuit of new products to offer has paid off generously in new sales. Revenues soared nearly 34 percent last year, to $4.04 billion. Thus business grew better than three times the rate of inflation. **********Profits, on the other hand, fared badly. Net earnings rose a mere 1 percent, to $203 million, in effect a decline after accounting for inflation. Merrill, however, can argue that some of its new services made things better than they might have been. Not so long ago, commissions on the sale of stocks and bonds were the bread-and-butter business of Merrill Lynch. Last year, because of the decline in stock market trading, Merrill's commission revenues fell 8.9 percent, to less than $1 billion, the first downturn since 1977. What buoyed Merrill was the same phenomenon that undid so many others - high interest rates. Merrill's high-rate money market funds helped keep profits from falling further, and its interest income, largely from loans to customers to maintain margin accounts, surged 62 percent, to $1.8 billion. Such other new businesses as investment banking and insurance also helped earnings. But real estate has been operating in the red. **********The post-Regan test for Merrill, however, hasn't really begun. For a couple of years, Merrill was largely alone among the big brokers in building a financial services department store. Its success in revealing the vulnerability of banks to such initiatives has since whet the appetites of some formidable challengers - Prudential, American Express and Sears, Roebuck. The Pru bought Bache, American Express landed Shearson and Sears got Dean Witter, all with the idea of going after the same well-heeled client that Merrill discovered. **********What's next on the Merrill menu?  ''Nothing of size,'' Mr. Birk said in an interview. ''We recognize our role as a financial intermediary. Its emphasis, he stressed, would be ''packaging and convenience.'' Its Cash Management Account, he said, was ''nothing more than services done all over the place that we combined.'' **********As for the new packaging he expects his competitors to start, he remarked, ''Making sure that two and two makes five is not an easy thing to do. If it were, we would have had competition before now.'' **********Then, too, once deregulation comes, he said, some of the top 20 banks will move into Merrill domains, building financial supermarkets of their own. Merrill, he said, would now have to work harder but deregulation should create more business for all. **********What about Merrill buying a bank or a savings and loan company?  It's illegal to buy a bank, he said, and while he had been offered a chance to buy thrift institutions ''we haven't had enough interest to respond.'' However, he added, ''We might be interested in providing checking accounts - maybe - we haven't drawn that conclusion.'' And, anyway, he noted, the laws barred that now. Checks that Merrill offers with its money funds, he said, were written on banks, not Merrill Lynch. **********The distinction is important. Unlike a bank, Merrill can't use the money in its money funds. If it could one day, the $36 billion in them might become the basis for one of the biggest lending operations in the world. **********In the meantime, its ties with banks are strong. In the six years ended in 1980, Merrill raised well over $5 billion for them, from helping sell 800,000 shares for BancOklahoma to a $200 million debt issue for Citicorp. **********In a well-worn quotation from the highly quotable Mr. Wriston about his idea of what a bank ought to be, he once said that ''Don Regan runs it and it's called Merrill Lynch.'' **********The Chase Manhattan Bank's president, Thomas G. Labrecque, thought truth serum might get an admission. ''Roger Birk is doing a super job running things now,'' Mr. Labrecque told The Redbank Daily Register of his neighbor on the Jersey shore, ''but they know, and they would admit it under sodium pentathol, that they are doing banking.'' **********In hearings on money funds last fall, Jake Garn, Utah's senior Senator, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee and friend of the banking industry, said he had remarked to Mr. Regan sometime earlier that neither he nor anyone else had gotten a mortgage from Merrill Lynch.'' **********Senator Garn said that Mr. Regan replied, ''Not yet.'' **********A SKING Merrill's new chief if the company was going into mortgage lending, Mr. Birk told the Senator, ''It's an area we're studying.'' He said Merrill was already working with thrift institutions throughout the country ''to try and provide mortgage financing of various types'' and that ''sometime in future'' it would give serious consideration to granting primary and secondary mortgages. **********Mr. Birk made good the other day on Mr. Regan's remark. It introduced, in characteristic Merrill Lynch style, a second mortgage that really isn't one from a strictly legal definition but enough of one to give bankers pause about Merrill's further move into consumer lending. **********Under a typical second mortgage, homeowners can borrow funds from the equity in their property but can lose the house to the lender if they default on payments. In hard times the lender could be stuck with homes that might be a millstone. Merrill Lynch, on the other hand, which can't grant loans under banking laws, will instead allow homeowners to tap a portion of the equity in their home, at roughly 18 1/4 percent interest now, but in case of default, homeowners would lose their home to someone other than Merrill Lynch. **********Test marketing now under way in southern California's highly risky housing market provides for Merrill Lynch to package the loan-like instruments into investment-size bundles for sale to pension funds, insurance companies and other big investors. **********Under an employee relocation program with leading corporations, Merrill Lynch buys homes from transferred individuals but collects only a fee for the service. Unlike the typical lender, who might have to take heavy losses in a down market, any profits or losses on the resale of the house goes to the employer. **********In what could yet be a booming new business for Merrill Lynch, it also collects a fee for finding a furniture mover and a real estate broker's commission for helping the employee buy a new home where he's going. **********To help tie the package together, Merrill Lynch has built up a string of 23 real estate firms in 35 major housing markets and 8,000 sales people, making it the largest company-owned residential real estate firm in the country. **********By 1985, according to Dakin B. Ferris, the newly named chairman of Merrill's real estate and insurance group, it hopes to be selling homes in all 50 states, with a sales force of more than 15,000. **********Asked why Merrill Lynch is buying real estate firms at a time few people are buying homes, he quickly responds, ''The only time you can buy them is when the market's terrible. And we wouldn't be buying them if we didn't expect the market to be better over a period of time.'' **********MERRILL LYNCH'S top executives, many of whom come from blue-collar backgrounds and have spent the bulk of their careers with the company, like to think of themselves as ''A Breed Apart.'' So woven is the concept into their own thinking that they found no difficulty transforming the idea into a national advertising slogan. **********Moreover, where Merrill Lynch under Mr. Regan meant unbending oneman rule, Mr. Birk's year-old command seems to be much more relaxed.  At the top sits Mr. Birk, chairman and chief executive of Merrill Lynch & Company. A billing supervisor's son, he was brought in by Mr. Regan over several top contenders seven years ago while only 44 years old to become president of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, its big brokerage arm. **********The following year, at a time Mr. Regan's departure seemed distant, George L. Shinn, then Mr. Birk's superior as president of the parent company, was offered an opportunity to run another big Wall Street house and took it, becoming board chairman of the First Boston Corporation. Mr. Regan soon left no doubt that Mr. Birk would get the top job at Merrill if he ever left it. **********Putting his own stamp on management, Mr. Birk late last month tapped William A. Schreyer, president of the brokerage firm since 1980, to become president of the parent company. Thus, t he backslapping, sales-oriented son of a former Merrill Lynch manager moved into wh at was clearly the No.2 spot. **********Below that, the picture seemed less certain, although there were signs suggesting part of the pecking order.  If those who report to the top man are any guide, and some Merrill watchers contend that they are, below Mr. Schreyer, 54, the list would include Mr. Ferris, at 56 the oldest of the top echelon, and Robert P. Rittereiser, 43, executive vice president of the parent company. Completing the seven-man top command are Daniel P. Tully, 50, and Edmond N. Moriarty, 53, son of a construction superintendent, both presidents of key Merrill Lynch operations, and Charles H. Ross, 44, like Mr. Rittereiser, an executive vice president of the parent company. **********However, with Mr. Birk only 51, the exercise seems academic. Joel Rosenthal, a Merrill watcher for the Wall Street house of Jesup & Lamont, said in a bullish report on the company that only a handful of the top 50 in Merrill Lynch still have the same job they held four years ago.   AT A GLANCE Merrill Lynch All dollar amounts in thousands, except per share data         Three months ended   Dec. 31, 1981   1980       Revenues   $1,115,150   $835,382       Net income   54,835   51,719       Earnings per share   $1.37   $1. 35              Year ended   Dec. 31, 1981   1980              Revenues   4,038,182   3,022,473       Net income   202,874   201,069       Earnings per share   $5.14   $5.45       Main Lines of Business Contribution to 1981 revenues          Commissions   22.8%       Interest   45.4%       Principal Transactions   10.9%       Investment Banking   8.6%       Other   13.3%       Total assets, Dec. 31, 1980   $13,246,000       Stock price, Feb. 5, 1982       N.Y.S.E. consolidated close   34 5/8       Stock price, 52-week range   44 1/4-28 5/8       Employees, Dec. 31, 1980   31,704       Headquarters New York City

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/21/busin.body_text: **********Abbott Laboratories and Takeda Chemical Industries of Japan announced plans to develop in the United States, Canada and Latin America an antidiabetes compound discovered by Takeda. **********Takeda's joint venture with Abbott will also market the drug in these countries. **********Separately, the Upjohn Company said that it had acquired the rights to develop and market the Takeda drug worldwide.  Human tests on the drug, known as ADD-38-78, will start this fall, and marketing awaits Food and Drug Administration approval, said Jan AufderHeide, a spokesman for Upjohn. Unlike other antidiabetes drugs, ADD-38-78 does not stimulate the pancreas to secrete more insulin, but seems to allow the receptor cells in the body to use insulin more efficiently, she said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/22/busin.main_headline: BONN SEEKS SHIFT ON GAS CURB
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/22/busin.print_headline: BONN SEEKS SHIFT ON GAS CURB
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/22/busin.body_text: **********West Germany said today that it had begun talks with the United States in an effort to get it to reverse its decision to widen restrictions on the use of American-developed equipment in a projected natural gas pipeline between Western Europe and the Soviet Union. **********The Government spokesman, Klaus Bolling, said that West Germany was not ruling out the option of taking the matter before the International Court of Justice in The Hague. **********Mr. Bolling characterized the Government's reaction to the Reagan Administration's announcement as one of ''concern'' and ''dismay.'' And he described the decision as ''a contradiction to what was agreed on and discussed at the world economic summit meeting'' earlier this month. **********Limits of Reasonableness **********This was a reference to a statement at the conference in Versailles, France, that trade with Eastern Europe was to be pursued within the limits of economic reasonableness. **********The vigor of the Government statement here, read at a news conference, contrasted with the rather more relaxed approach in Paris, Rome and London, where no official declarations were made. **********Some diplomats and politicians thought the intensity of the German reaction perhaps reflected the Government's interest in turning attention away from internal difficulties. **********Mr. Bolling re-emphasized the Government's determination to go ahead with the transaction, which is the biggest East-West contract ever signed. Delay of Two or Three Years **********If the construction schedule for the pipeline were met, deliveries of Siberian natural gas would begin in 1984. But Mr. Bolling said that a West German expert had estimated that the denial of licenses could delay the project by about two or three years. **********Extending the export ban, originally imposed on the Caterpillar Tractor Company and the General Electric Company, to European licensees primarily affects companies making gas turbine blades under license to G.E. The blades are needed for the construction of gas turbine engines that would be essential in compressing gas at stations along the pipeline. **********The companies affected in Western Europe are AEG-Telefunken of West Germany; John Brown & Company, a British engineering company; Nuovo Pignone, a state-owned company in Italy, and Alsthom-Atlantique of France. **********Mr. Bolling said that West Germany, while talking to Reagan Administration officials in Washington, also planned to discuss the matter with its European counterparts. One possible reason for the intensity of the German reaction is that the AEG-Telefunken subsidiary involved in the transaction, like the parent company, has grave financial problems. **********Mr. Bolling stressed that the American decision would ''enormously complicate international contractual obligations'' concluded before the imposition of martial law in Poland - the event that led the United States to impose the sanctions originally.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/13/world.body_text: **********Two members of the Afghan Cabinet have been relieved of their duties but they will remain Deputy Prime Ministers, the Kabul radio reported today. **********The radio, monitored here, said the future duties of Gul Dad, Minister of Higher Education, and Abdul Majid Sarboland, Minister of Information and Culture, would be exclusively to advise the Prime Minister. **********The changes were made ''to improve the affairs of the Government and increase the effectiveness of state affairs,'' the radio said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/22/world.body_text: **********A white woman who belongs to the African National Congress received a 10-year sentence for high treason today, on the ground that her membership in the banned group amounted to participation in a conspiracy to overthrow South Africa by violent means. **********The woman, Barbara Hogan, a 35-year-old researcher with a background in social anthropology, is the first person to be convicted of treason in South Africa without having been implicated in any specific act of violence. **********At her trial she admittted to having helped to organize consumer boycotts in support of striking black trade unions and to writing several reports on labor matters that were smuggled out to the exiled leadership of the African National Congress. **********She pleaded guilty to membership in a banned organization, a crime under South African law, but denied any other criminal activities.  The finding by Justice A.P. Van Dyk that membership in the group was itself tantamount to treason will, if it is accepted as a legal precedent, have the effect of drastically stiffening the penalties for belonging to the movement. **********Making this point, Miss Hogan's lawyer, George Bizos, followed the normal practice in South African courts of applying for permission to appeal against both the treason conviction and the sentence. Justice Van Dyk promptly turned down the application, which means that the conviction will stand unless the Chief Justice of the Appeals Court accepts a petition to hear the case.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/01/world.main_headline: EASIER NATO STANCE ON MISSILES HINTED
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/01/world.print_headline: EASIER NATO STANCE ON MISSILES HINTED
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/01/world.body_text: **********Officials of the Atlantic alliance gave signs today of increased readiness to seek a compromise solution in negotiations between the United States and the Soviet Union about intermediate-range nuclear missiles in Europe. **********Without any major change in policy, there were new accents in tone and approach in discussing the United States bargaining position in the arms talks in Geneva, which were adjourned today until late January. **********The differences were ones of degree, but they were apparent in exchanges between officials and reporters on the first day of three days of meetings here of defense ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. **********Until now, the public position of the alliance on the intermediate-range missile issue has been total backing for the socalled ''zero solution'' proposed by President Reagan last fall.  Roughly stated, it proposes that the United States forgo its plans to deploy 572 Pershing 2 and cruise missiles in Western Europe beginning in December 1983 if the Soviet Union will totally scrap its current arsenal of 324 SS-20 missiles, targeted in the main on Western Europe. **********Compromise Proposal Foreseen **********Although United States negotiators have never said as much, it has long been assumed that some kind of compromise proposal involving a reduction in the number of Soviet missiles in return for reduction in the NATO deployment would develop in the course of 1983. **********Today, after a meeting of NATO's nuclear planning group, the organization's general secretary, Joseph M.A.H. Luns of the Netherlands, said, ''The United States never said it was the 'zero option' or nothing.'' **********The remark attracted attention because Defense Minister John Nott of Britain, while restating his country's readiness for deployment on schedule if the talks in Geneva failed to produce concrete results, repeated several times in conversations with reporters that the alliance was interested in Soviet proposals even if they did not mean acceptance of the ''zero solution.'' **********''If the Soviets propose something less,'' Mr. Nott told a small group, referring to a proposal that would mean Soviet retention of some SS-20's, ''then we'd welcome it and we'd look at it in a constructive spirit.'' Weinberger Defends Arms Talks **********When Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger was asked later at a news conference if the United States was thinking of an alternative to the ''zero solution,'' he replied, ''What I'm not prepared to do is to undercut our negotiators in Geneva.'' **********Mr. Weinberger also defended the seriousness of the talks there, now under way for a year, saying, ''I wouldn't characterize them as ones in which nothing has happened.'' **********''Positions have been refined and developed,'' he said. ''This has been going on in a serious way.'' The tone of the nuclear planning group's communique appeared similar to that in the remarks by Mr. Luns and Mr. Nott. The statement said the ministers ''welcomed the fact that the United States remains prepared to give full consideration to any serious Soviet proposals'' on arms control agreements. **********Mr. Weinberger had restated that the United States, after some problems involved in the testing of the Pershing 2, was on schedule with development of the weapons for deployment. ''This,'' he said, ''won't interfere with the negotiations at Geneva, and we hope they will succeed.'' **********On other issues, the defense ministers offered support for President Reagan's decision to go ahead with the deployment of MX strategic missiles. **********''In the face of a significantly increased Soviet threat,'' their statement said, ''the ministers stressed the importance of maintaining the effectiveness of NATO's strategic nuclear forces from the standpoint of deterrence and stability. From this standpoint, the significance of the recent decision on MX basing which was designed to enhance the survivability of NATO's strategic nuclear forces was emphasized.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/30/busin.main_headline: Talking Business with Clark of Baker International; Rise Foreseen In Oil Demand
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/30/busin.print_headline: Talking Business with Clark of Baker International; Rise Foreseen In Oil Demand
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/30/busin.body_text: **********At age 55, E.H. Clark Jr. has been chief executive of Baker International for 17 years and made millions for himself and the diversified oil service company with his shrewd assessments of trends in global oil pricing. **********Acting on his conviction that Middle East oil prices would soar, Baker International had made its acquisitions and plant expansions before the oil shocks of 1973 and 1979-80 and was ready to capture market shares amid the drilling booms that followed. Its profits have grown 39 percent a year, on average, since 1971, and Baker has become one of the largest companies in oilfield service. **********Mr. Clark, a mechanical engineer, discussed the future of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, oil prices and the oilfield service industry recently here at Baker's headquarters. **********Q. Do you agree that OPEC's days are numbered? A. Not at all. The people who believe OPEC will fall apart are the same shallow thinkers who said the first oil embargo was a hoax. OPEC's future hinges on how demand for energy returns after the recession. They can't cut production enough to sustain current price levels with a permanently reduced world demand. I don't believe that has happened. **********Q. But aren't conservation and the oil glut working against OPEC?  A. Energy consumption is down because of the current mix of production in the gross national product, not because of conservation. Housing, steel, autos, metals - the highest users of energy per unit of G.N.P. - are the most depressed sectors of the economy. Are we going to make a lasting improvement in energy consumption by allowing these basic industries to be permanently flat on their backs? I can't see that. The business recovery will bring these industries back. Rising energy demand will follow. **********Q. When do you expect this to occur? A. Toward the end of this year. **********Q. What are the Saudis up to? A. The Saudis said last year that they would hold at $34 a barrel for 18 to 24 months, or until they became the highest-priced producer in OPEC and the market would no longer buy from them. The Saudis will try to hold that price, with their rather dramatic production cutbacks. **********Q. Is the Saudi warning to oil companies not to stop buying Nigerian oil consistent with that? A. Absolutely. Saudi Arabia intends to be the producer of last resort. As such, they are prepared to control their production rate based on demand. There is a relatively free market out there. If the overall production rate is higher, the Saudis will cut back, leaving other OPEC members free to participate. The Saudi market price will be highest, so all others will be bought first. The average price will be lower than the Saudi price. **********Q. What happens if OPEC does splinter? A. The overhang of Arab reprisals against the Saudis over such a miscalculation is intense.  You're going to see nations starving and revolution. Promises have been made, for instance in Nigeria, that couldn't be kept with oil at $15 a barrel. Iran said it would bomb Saudi oilfields if the price fell to $15 a barrel. **********Q. What has been the impact of the oil glut on your customers? A.  We're seeing some weakness, but nothing inconsistent with our projections. About 95 percent of our business with drillers is in the medium and deep-well area. And that still looks very favorable. **********Q. What about major, fast-growing companies like Baker, Halliburton, Smith International, Global Marine and Schlumberger? A.  None of this shakeout is going to spill over to our major customers, contractors with the deeper rigs. Unfortunately, Wall Street paints everybody with the same brush. It doesn't make sense. We're even yeastier about the future than we were. We've increased capital spending to about $2.6 billion for the five years ending in 1986.  That's up from $2.2 billion for the 1981-85 cycle.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/11/busin.main_headline: OIL-DEAL MAKER LURES INSTITUTIONS INTO SEARCH
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/11/busin.print_headline: OIL-DEAL MAKER LURES INSTITUTIONS INTO SEARCH
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/11/busin.body_text: **********The age of the robber barons is long gone, and the world will rarely see again anything like the $1 billion personal fortune that John D.  Rocke feller squeezed out of his hapless competitors. But big money is stil l being made in the United States, and by and large the new wealth, l ike Rockefeller's fortune, still flows out of the ground. **********Among the new energy entrepreneurs, few have risen as far as fast as Bruce Heafitz, the cheery, red-bearded 41-year-old chairman of Heafitz, Widmann, McMahon & Gardner, a firm t hat finances independentoil and gas operators. **********Only seven years ago, Mr. Heafitz was living in a third-floor walkup at Third Avenue and 35th Street with a pregnant wife and a 3-yearold daughter, his bank account overdrawn and his net worth nil. **********Today, he measures his wealth in the mid-eight figures. He is one of the largest individual clients of the elite old law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell, and a benefactor of the Peabody Museum of Harvard, his alma mater. Some time ago, the walk-up was exchanged for the requisite East Side cooperative. **********Takes Buses and Flies Coach **********He still takes buses and flies in economy class, but he also presides over spacious new offices at Park Avenue and 59th Street, decorated in defiant shades of lavender - an individual touch seldom seen in the beigey suites of corporate America. **********''I'm no smarter than other guys,'' said Mr. Heafitz, who still speaks of his success with a mixture of pride and awe. ''The difference is that I'm more willing to take risks.'' **********Mr. Heafitz made his first big leap in 1974, when he left a job in mergers and acquisitions at Merrill Lynch to work as a financial adviser to several small independent oil companies. In return, they were able to send some promising deals his way. **********Using $20,000 borrowed from family and friends, Mr. Heafitz made his first investment in three oil wells, and one of them, in which he had a quarter interest, came in. At then-current prices of $6 a barrel, that meant that the fledgling investor stood to earn about half a million dollars a year, proving that, even before the decade's historic price increases, oil could be a fantastically profitable business. The Well Goes Dry **********The trouble was that the well went dry 10 days later, after Mr.  Heafitz had bought that new co-op, laid out almost $15,000 in completion costs on the well and accumulated almost $50,000 in new debts. **********But several hundred thousand dollars' worth of debt and 26 dry holes later, Mr. Heafitz, a dedicated crapshooter, finally hit it big with some heavy oil in California, purchased in 1975 when it was worth 10 cents a barrel and sold two or three years later when it was valued at $10 a barrel in the ground. **********''I was in the right place at the right time,'' he says now.  To pay the grocer during the lean years - when, a friend says, ''Bruce was making calls out of pay phones on the street'' - Mr.  Heafitz held a succession of jobs with various investment banks and brokerage houses, leaving frequently with little regret on either side. ''Bruce had to go out on his own because he couldn't hold a job anywhere else,'' his partner, Roger M. Widmann, joked over a recent lunch, as Mr. Heafitz beamed agreement. ''I'm not a big company man,'' he admitted. **********By early last year, Mr. Heafitz finally had his own operation in place, set up to invest his, his partners', and institutional money in oil and gas deals. Heafitz Widmann likes to call itself a financial intermediary, rounding up skittish institutional funds for lending to independent oil companies. How Independents Raise Funds **********The independents, who drill 90 percent of the exploratory wells in the nation with only 70 percent of the money spent on exploration, have traditionally obtained operating funds from their own cash flow; from banks, which can only lend on the basis of proven oil reserves; from selling or trading some of those reserves to other oil companies, or from selling limited partnerships in drilling funds to wealthy persons seeking tax shelter. **********In recent years, ever so tentatively, institutional investors have also begun to dip their toes into the oil exploration business. Last year, oil and gas firms are estimated to have raised $30 billion in 1981 for exploration, with roughly $1.4 billion of that from institutions, compared with almost no institutional money only three years ago. **********Mr. Heafitz was one of the first persons in the oil business to persuade risk-adverse institutions such as pension funds to dip their toes into oil, and to finance drilling costs by lending to independents against such assets as unt@ested acreage. **********His timing was not exactly perfect. With energy in plentiful supply, and analysts now predicting a drop in the real price of oil, ''I'm beginni ng to wonder whether I helped give birth to an industry that is alrea dy dying,'' Mr. Heafitz said. Much of Heafitz Widmann's energies last year went into trying to raise $200 million for a limited partn ership called American Oil and Gas Investors, which finally close d last October at $144 million. Discouraging Climate **********De spite the discouraging climate, the firm did manage to obtain commitments from such conservative institutio ns as the Minnesota State Board of Investment, Mutual of New York , New England Mutual, Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association an d the pension funds of, among others, I.B.M., Atlantic Richfield, the Bell System Trust, Gulfand Western and Boise Cascade. **********Heafitz Widmann is the managing general partner of American Oil and Gas Investors, and by spring the firm hopes to close a sister fund, Amgo International, with roughly $100 million raised from European institutions. **********''Amgo is our goldfish bowl'', Mr. Heafitz said recently. ''If it does well, we'll do well.'' The principals of Heafitz Widmann polished their skills in attracting institutions into direct oil and gas deals at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, where Mr. Heafitz was working in 1979. In that year, he and Mr. Widmann, his boss and a senior vice president at Donaldson, put together a group of investors for exploration of 2.9 million acres of land in the vast Williston Basin leased by the Standard Oil Company (Indiana). **********Looking for more operating room, Mr. Heafitz left Donaldson after the Williston deal and began to try to attract a group of investors in oil and gas royalties he had purchased on some 16 million acres in the continental United States. Realizing he needed to put together his own team for the effort, he lured Mr. Widmann and Edward T.  Gardner, a stockbroker, away from Donaldson and brought in Michael E. McMahon from Morgan Guaranty. Staff of 22 and 7 Partners **********The new corporation now has a staff of 22 and 7 partners, including Thomas Kellogg, who was involved in petroleum lending for 22 years at Morgan Guaranty. **********The Harp Royalty Trust closed successfully last year at $98 million. Participants in the limited partnership include the pension funds of Owens-Illinois and Commonwealth Edison. The First National Bank in Minneapolis and Citicorp also put in money on behalf of several pension clients. **********In the past year, a number of other money managers and institutions began to try their hand at similar lucrative ventures. Most notably, Henry Schroder Wagg & Company in London placed $100 million, raised from a Who's Who of British pension funds and insurance companies, in direct oil and gas deals in the United States. **********Prudential Insurance announced its intention to place $200 million of its general account money in oil and gas deals over the next few years, with the possibility of developing a separate account for pension clients. Several major banks are now putting pension clients directly into oil and gas, and at least one, Continental Illinois, has even begun to lend to independents on unproven acreage.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/05/busin.body_text: **********Gold, which has been falling steadily for many weeks, broke through a new barrier yesterday, falling $7.25 an ounce in London, to $346.50. It was the first time in two and a half years that gold has gone below the $350 level. **********Analysts said that gold's price had been driven down, and would probably continue to be driven down, by heavy selling by the Soviet Union, South Africa and several of the members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries - all seeking foreign currency to pay for imports. The OPEC nations in past years had invested some of their oil revenues in gold. **********''A number of nations are faced with economic difficulties,'' said Bette Raptopoulos, a senior metals analyst with Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc., the brokerage firm. ''The Russians need hard currency for large imports of grain. In addition, nations that have in the past been selling oil to raise the money they need for imports have been hurt now that oil prices have dropped.'' **********Analysts said that in addition to weak oil prices, high interest rates have been depressing the price of gold because they make it costly to borrow money to purchase gold. **********Gold, which had reached a high point of more than $850 an ounce in London in January 1980 and was at $401 at the start of this year, had not been below $350 an ounce since September 1979, when it went as low as $322.90 an ounce in London. Other Market Reactions **********Gold has lost more than $14 in the past two days.  In Zurich, the metal fell to $348.50 an ounce, down $5 from Wednesday. In final trading in London, gold dropped to $344.25, or $2.25 below the afternoon fixing of $346.50. In Hong Kong today, gold opened at $345.33. **********With the $350-an-ounce barrier breached, some analysts said that the price was likely to decline ''toward the $300 level.'' In New York, gold for delivery this month fell $6.70 an ounce yesterday, to $343.90 on the Commodity Exchange of New York, and in later trading, was quoted at $343.50 an ounce at the Republic National Bank, down $7.25 from Wednesday. **********''In the last few weeks gold really began to move down rather steadily,'' Miss Raptopoulos said. ''It has been a bleak economic scenario. There is less of the feeling that the recession is going to be corrected as quickly as was earlier anticipated,'' Sales by Soviet Union **********She said that the Soviet Union had sold gold not only to help pay for much-needed grain imports but also to help finance its military operations in Afghanistan. In recent weeks, the Russians have arranged credits to purchase grain abroad, underlining the lack of foreign currency available to Moscow for such imports. **********The Russians account for 23 percent of world gold production, second only to South Africa, which accounts for about 50 percent of world production. Miss Raptopoulos noted that in recent months South Africa had also been selling steadily because it needs hard currency to pay for imports. **********In London yesterday it was reported that some heavy sellers in recent days have included Iran, Iraq, Libya and Indonesia, all members of OPEC. **********Who is buying? Several analysts said that Japanese buyers had been stocking gold in anticipation of tax law changes that will require people who own gold to disclose holdings acquired after Jan.1, 1983.  The Japanese reportedly purchased 150 tons in 1981. It was also reported that some foreign central banks might have bought some gold to support the metal's market price. Bargain hunters also have been buying, analysts said. **********James E. Sinclair, general partner of the Sinclair Group Companies, which specialize in foreign exchange and metals, said: ''The great drama of gold is over. Gold will experience another drop in the fall. I still don't recommend purchase of futures contracts but I do recommend that our customers can put one-third of what they intend to commit in gold into the physical gold market at prices between $330 and $360.'' ---- Silver and Dollar Down By The Associated Press **********Silver prices tumbled on international markets yesterday, dropping below $7.50 an ounce. The value of the dollar also fell sharply in moderately heavy trading. **********Trading was described by one London dealer as ''extremely volatile.'' Prices of precious metals are under pressure because of high interest rates, which make bullion purchases more expensive to finance, and declining inflation in the United States. **********The price of silver fell to $7.498 on New York's Comex, down 16.2 cents from Wednesday. Silver fell 19 cents an ounce in London, to $7.505, the lowest price since April 1979. **********The dollar's only gain came in Tokyo, edging up to 235.80 Japanese yen, from 235.70 Wednesday.  Here is how the dollar fared in the United States, compared with Wednesday: 2.3545 West German marks, down from 2.3695; 6.0325 French francs, down from 6.05; 1.86 Swiss francs, down from 1.87. The dollar fell to 234.95 Japanese yen from 236.48, and to 1.216 Canadian dollars, from 1.2242. **********The British pound sterling strengthened to $1.8354 from $1.8145. In Europe, the pound gained almost half a cent, to $1.82725 from $1.82325 Wednesday. **********Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with Wednesday, included: 2.368 West German marks, down from 2.3703; 1.8772 Swiss francs, down from 1.881; 6.05625 French francs, down from 6.0615; 2.596 Dutch guilders, down from 2.6; 1,275.15 Italian lire, down from 1,275.45, and 1.22125 Canadian dollars, down from 1.22485.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/08/world.main_headline: SCHMIDT FRUSTRATED BY REGIONAL PARTY VOTES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/08/world.print_headline: SCHMIDT FRUSTRATED BY REGIONAL PARTY VOTES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/08/world.body_text: **********Three Social Democratic regional party conventions passed motions on security and nuclear weapons issues today that disavowed or contradicted the programs that won a vote of confidence for Chancellor Helmut Schmidt in Parliament on Friday. **********The regional groups' actions, compounded by a new spate of charges and countercharges in the Government coalition of Social Democrats and Free Democrats, undermined the impression of stability that Mr.  Schmidt said he sought to create by calling the confidence vote. **********The confidence motion dealt mainly with the Government's new program of economic stimulants, but it specifically included the Chancellor's foreign and security policies as well. As a result, the balloting in the regional conventions, summoned to prepare for a national party convention in April, had the character of gestures of dissatisfaction with Mr. Schmidt's leadership. **********Vote Against NATO Plan **********The most striking case came at the Lower Bavaria-Upper Palatinate convention, where the group, despite pleas by Peter Glotz, the Social Democratic Party's national manager, recommended that West Germany withdraw from the NATO plan to deploy middle-range nuclear missiles in Western Europe at the end of 1983. The alliance plan, often referred to as the ''two-track decision,'' provides that deployment is to go ahead if there is no favorable outcome in the current Geneva talks between the United States and the Soviet Union. **********The Lower Bavaria-Upper Palatinate group is one of the smaller regional party bodies, but the country's third largest, in the Lower Rhine area, voted in Essen tonight in favor of an immediate moratorium in the stationing of American and Soviet missiles and an ''immediate halt to the preparations for deploying'' American Pershing 2 and cruise missiles in West Germany. **********The Essen convention, which was addressed by Chancellor Schmidt, did not withdraw its support for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization plan as a whole, but its recommendations disavowed Mr.  Schmidt's stance in two areas. His Government has said that a moratorium would serve only to freeze Soviet superiority in intermediate-range missiles, and that halting preparations to deploy American missiles would remove a stimulus for the Soviet Union to negotiate seriously. West Westphalia Defeats Proposal **********A similar motion was passed by the Palatinate regional party organization at a meeting in Pirmasens.  In Dortmund, where the largest regional body, known as West Westphalia, was meeting, a moratorium proposal was defeated after a long floor fight and at the urging of Willy Brandt, the party chairman. **********But the Dortmund convention, the fourth of the weekend, expressed weakened confidence in the United States' interest in avoiding deployment by tacking an amendment to its security motion, roughly supporting t h e line of Mr. Schmidt, which said it would be invalidated ' 'if the Western side drags out the negotiations and doesnot pursue th em constructively enough.'' **********Support for Mr. Schmidt's program of economic stimulants, aimed at creating jobs and bringing new investment, faced difficulties in the coalition itself. **********Housing Minister Dieter Haack, a Social Democrat, criticized a segment of the program that would loosen rent controls in order to make house and apartment buildings more attractive to investors. The measure is a favorite project of the Free Democrats, and their party spokesmen replied angrily today to Mr. Haack. **********The Free Democratic Party Chairman, Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, offered what was taken as a warning that continued bickering could quicly bring down the coalition. **********''Whoever talks the economic program down,'' he said, ''is talking down jobs, and in so doing, is talking apart the coalition.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/17/world.body_text: **********Reports reaching the State Department's Agency for International Development have estimated that as many as 600,000 people have been affected by the Israeli attack against Palestinian strongholds in Lebanon. **********A situation report compiled by the agency said that 350,000 people had been affected in the south by the fighting, although exact numbers of people left homeless are unclear. A.I.D. officials said that many Lebanese are, if not homeless, in need of food, water and medical supplies. **********Damage in Lebanon was listed as ''severe.'' In the Shouf mountain area southeast of Beirut, where there are many Palestinians, a partial estimate of the homeless was placed at 16,000. **********There was no estimate in the report of the total number of dead and wounded as a result of more than a week of fighting. A preliminary figure of wounded in the cities of Sidon, Tyre and Jezzin was listed at 3,400. **********''Priority needs have been identified as medical supplies and personal items such as soap and blankets,'' said the report. ''Food will be needed. Tents may be needed later. Needs have not yet been quantified.'' Aid for 300,000 Families **********The report noted that Lebanese authorities had requested United Nations humanitarian assistance for 300,000 families, or as many as 1.5 million people. **********A.I.D. officials as well as Congressional sources emphasized that, with fighting still engulfing parts of Lebanon and lack of access to air and sea transport facilities, it was virtually impossible to carry out a major humanitarian effort. Beyond this, officials said, the ongoing fighting made it extremely difficult to assess the scale of damage so far to Lebanon. **********It was learned that President Reagan is scheduled to announce shortly the appointment of W. Peter McPherson, the administrator of the Agency for International Development, as coordinator for United States relief in Lebanon. **********Mr. Reagan has announced that the United States Government would provide up to $5 million in immediate medical supplies and food aid and has submitted a request to Congress for an additional $20 million in emergency relief. Aid May Exceed $50 Million **********Congressional aides as well as Administration officials predict that Congress may raise the figure to $50 million, or possibly more, because of the severe damage in Lebanon. **********So far, the only other United States aid to Lebanon since the Israeli attack has been $25,000 in disaster relief from the State Department. Of this, $20,000 was granted to the American University Hospital in Beirut. **********Within Congress there was some confusion about the Administration's $20 million aid request for Lebanon. Rep. Clement J. Zablocki, Democrat of Wisconsin, who is chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, formally submitted a bill today embodying the Administration's request, and it was disclosed that the panel's subcommittee on Europe and Middle East, would hold hearings Thursday afternoon on the Lebanese situation as well as policy in the Middle East. Senator Kasten Is Critical **********Similar hearings are scheduled next Monday by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. Sen. Robert W. Kasten Jr., Republican of Wisconsin, and chairman of the Appropriations Committee's Foreign Operations subcommittee, criticized the Administration and his colleagues for seeking legislation and hearings on aid to Lebanon. **********Mr. Kasten, in a statement, said the Administration's formal request was ''puzzling,'' since the money sought could have been taken immediately from other foreign assistance programs, and then replaced. **********Mr. Kasten urged the Administration and Congress to ''abandon time-consuming efforts at new and additional legislation which is unnecessary.'' 'New Middle East Alignments' **********Meanwhile, Senator Rudy Boschwitz, Republican of Minnesota and chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee's Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs panel, and Representative Jack Kemp, Republican of New York, sent a strongly worded letter to President Reagan, urging the Administration to ''take advantage of the new Middle East alignments to press ahead with the Camp David process and to encourage other nations, freer than ever from P.L.O. intimidation, to join in that process.'' **********The two said that the P.L.O. had been ''discredited,'' and that the Administration should ''make it clear to those on the West Bank, to the Jordanians and to other nations with a stake in a peaceful settlement, such as the Saudis, that true moderates should join in the peace process.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/12/busin.main_headline: THE MARKET FOR CUSTOM BUILT HOMES ON STATEN ISLAND
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/12/busin.print_headline: ABOUT REAL ESTATE; THE MARKET FOR CUSTOM BUILT HOMES ON STATEN ISLAND
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/12/busin.body_text: **********At a pace of 100 to 200 houses a year, the production of custombuilt houses is proceeding in far-flung locations in New York City's least-developed borough, Staten Island. **********High mortgage rates and a lack of city sewers in the southern part of the island haved limited tract development for buyers with average incomes. Thus, custom construction has become a relatively strong market. **********In the wooded terrain off Ocean Terrace in the Deere Park section of Todt Hill, close to the College of Staten Island, Aaron Luwisch is developing custom homes on 16 quarter-acre lots. Buyers have been spending $350,000 to $700,000 for houses with upward of 3,500 square feet of space. **********In Eltingville, off Arden Avenue, large custom-built houses have begun to fill entire streets. A sign on a tree reads: ''Ironwood Estates. Will build to suit.'' The builder, Henry Lieberman, has 22 lots on which he builds custom houses, generally under 3,000 square feet, that sell for $200,000 and up. He builds about a dozen a year, he said. **********Along Raritan Bay in the Huguenot section, on land with a spectacular water view toward Sandy Hook, Salvatore Nicolosi and his partners are offering 38 lots for sale for custom development. The site includes the 18-acre Arbutus Lake. Lots are selling for about $10 a square foot, or between $135,000 and $300,000. **********''The most prevalent pattern,'' said Randy Lee, a real estate lawyer, ''is that buyers seek out a builder who has land and make a deal through a broker.'' Development sites are regularly advertised in the daily Staten Island Advance. **********Land prices for custom construction vary greatly. In Annadale, Eltingville and Huguenot, a 100-foot-by-100-foot ''builder ready'' plot - with building plans approved - usually costs $40,000 to $50,000, specialists say. Custom houses on such lots, with the land, sell for $225,000 and up, depending on what the buyer puts into it.  The many elaborate houses recently built indicate that the higher bracket is more common. **********In the exclusive communities of Todt Hill and Emerson Hill, on high land in the center of the island, plots usually run between $100,000 to $155,000. With a fine view, prices are higher. New homes built there start at $400,000, including the land. Recent houses have been built for more than half a million dollars, brokers and lawyers say. **********The new housing on the hills is usually built on ''infill'' lots in communities already mostly developed with expensive houses. On Ocean Terrace on Todt Hill, one vacant parcel of 13,000 square feet is said to have sold for $200,000 a few months ago. The house is under construction. And at 90 Flagg Place in Dongan Hills, a house with 12,000 square feet of living space is being constructed speculatively by a builder named Carmine Lombardi. He is asking $950,000. **********To the south the terrain grows more like southern New Jersey, with sandy soil. It was here, planners feel, that an unusual opportunity for superior subdivision planning was lost 10 years ago when the State Assembly voted down the ''South Richmond plan'' put forward by former Mayor John V. Lindsay. It had passed the Senate with strong support from Senator John J. Marchi of Staten Island. **********The legislation would have established an authority with power to condemn undeveloped land that was mapped for streets during the 1920's. Most of the streets were never built, and ownership of the land is dispersed. These mapped but unbuilt ''paper'' streets tend to freeze subdivision patterns into a rigid grid with excessive pavement. Condemnation would have cleared the way for better planning. **********Yet it is not planning policy but the lack of city sewers in many areas that has dominated the development picture. Arden Avenue in Annadale is the southern boundary of the sewer system, and tract housing stops there abruptly. Since health rules require builders to install septic tanks in unsewered land, much of the new development is on 100-foot-by-100-foot lots, the minimum needed for septic tanks, even though the zoning in most cases permits a higher density. **********Accordingly, the more attractive sites are being developed with houses up to 4,000 square feet on land that was once expected to be utilized for middle-income tract development. Jansen Street, off Arden Avenue, is an example of a street gradually being filled with high-priced customized single-family houses. Another is a development called Woodrow Woods, along Woodrow Road near Rossville Avenue in Huguenot, which Harry Kantor is building. **********Tract development occurs only when the builder has so large a project that he can put in a private sewage treatment plant, or when he can hook into an existing private plant with excess capacity. **********Business and professional people are said to be the main purchasers of the new custom houses. Since the Staten Island Expressway and Verrazano Bridge provide easy access to Brooklyn, the buyers tend to come either from there or from Staten Island.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/10/world.main_headline: SUHARTO DUE IN U.S. TODAY ON STATE VISIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/10/world.print_headline: SUHARTO DUE IN U.S. TODAY ON STATE VISIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/10/world.body_text: **********Indonesian officials hope that the state visit of President Suharto to the United States, due to begin Sunday, will be able to smooth over some of the tensions that have grown over the last year between Washington and Jakarta. **********Mr. Suharto's stay in Washington, where he will be given a state dinner Tuesday night, will follow a visit to White Sulphur Springs, W.Va. After Washington, the Indonesian leader is to visit Miami, Houston and Honolulu before flying to Seoul, South Korea, on Oct. 15. His wife, Tien, and Indonesia's Foreign Minister, Mochtar Kusumaatmadja, are among the delegation. **********Indonesia and the United States have coinciding views on many of the major world issues and both share fears of Communist expansion in Southeast Asia. **********Indonesia has recently sought more private foreign investment to help keep its economy growing rapidly in the face of declining oil revenues. U.S. Is Key Weapons Supplier **********The two countries' other mutual interests are extensive. Indonesia exports about 350,000 barrels of oil a day to the United States and depends heavily on American technology and economic expertise. It also buys most of its advanced weapons from the United States, and has sided both with the United States and with Indonesia's neighboring anti-Communist nations in calling for the withdrawal of Vietnamese troops from Cambodia. **********However, some American-Indonesian tensions have developed over the last year and officials say that both countries now want to set matters straight. **********One problem has been that the United States has had no ambassador in Jakarta for nearly a year. The Reagan Administration's first choice, Morton I. Abramowitz, was reportedly rejected by President Suharto, who makes all of his Government's most important decisions. **********The precise grounds for the rejection are still not clear, but the episode left much bitterness in Jakarta and at the State Department. Development Aid at Low Level **********A face-to-face meeting between the two Presidents might enable them to settle on a candidate, officials said.  Indonesian leaders have also felt slighted by relatively low levels of American economic and military assistance. Development and food aid amounted to less than $100 million this year and the ceiling on military credits was $40 million. **********The prevailing argument in Washington has been that Indonesia's oil revenues make it a less than needy candidate for aid. Jakarta has replied that world recession, an oil glut and depressed prices for its tin, rubber, coffee and other exports make Indonesia needier by the day, and could threaten its domestic security. **********The private foreign investment that Indonesia seeks has been disappointing despite the Government's easing of nationalistic tax laws and other legislation. Inquiry on East Timor Urged **********A group of United States members of Congress, anticipating President Suharto's visit, have called for an investigation of reported food shortages and human rights abuses in East Timor, the former Portuguese island colony that Indonesia invaded in December 1975 and later annexed. **********State Department officials, like the Indonesian Government, have asserted that the situation in East Timor has improved greatly in recent years. But the issue could easily arise in talks between President Suharto's delegation and Administration officials. **********Many Western scholars have said in recent years that although the Indonesian economy as a whole has soared under the increasingly autocratic rule of President Suharto, his political support - especially among poor and landless peasants, jobless or underpaid city-dwellers and a growing and often democratically inclined middle class - remains shallow. Several American Government experts on Indonesia have lately expressed the same view. Political currents across Indonesia, these experts say, remain unclear.
