https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/17/world.body_text: **********President Reagan's special envoy in the negotiations for Israel's final withdrawal from the Sinai Peninsula arrived in Cairo from Israel today. **********Deputy Secretary of State Walter J. Stoessel Jr., who came for two days of talks with President Hosni Mubarak and other key Egyptian officials, said in an airport statement that ''I am hopeful that my visit and recent meetings between Egypt and Israel will result in the resolution of present difficulties.'' **********Israel, which has returned about two-thirds of Sinai to Egypt under the terms of the Camp David peace treaty, is scheduled to returned the rest of the peninsula by April 25. Egyptian Returns With Stoessel **********Earlier today, Egypt's Deputy Foreign Minister, Boutros Ghali, flew to Israel with a personal letter from Mr. Mubarak to Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel. **********Mr. Ghali returned to Egypt aboard Mr. Stoessel's plane late this afternoon and told reporters that the two had begun discussing the obstacles that Egyptian and Israeli officials have been attempting to resolve in recent days.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/06/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene; The Sanctions A nd the Allies
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/06/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene; The Sanctions A nd the Allies
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/06/busin.body_text: **********THE Polish crisis - and the efforts of President Reagan and Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany to coordinate their political and economic positions on how to deal with it - needs to be seen as a critical element in a larger agony, which is the 1980's equivalent of the severe testing that the world faced in the 1930's.  It failed that last test miserably. **********Yesterday's meeting between Mr. Reagan and Chancellor Schmidt, despite efforts to paper over cracks in the wall, dramatized their differences on how to respond to the crisis - and how to prevent it from wrecking the Western alliance. **********Mr. Reagan, holding the Soviet Union responsible for the military crackdown on the Poles, has imposed sanctions on the Soviet Union.  But Mr. Schmidt, asserting that Moscow was not the prime mover against Poland, wants to take a less aggressive line - one that will permit German trade with the Russians to continue. This dispute long antedates the Polish crisis. At the Ottawa summit conference last July, a principal fight between the American and German leaders was over the export of high technology to the Russians, as well as over the planned Siberian natural gas pipeline to supply West Germany and other European countries. **********Today, the United States appears to be hoping that the Polish upheaval can be exploited to brea k the Soviet grip on Eastern Europe,if this count ry can only make it too costly for the Russians or theirsupporters in the Polish Army to try to break the workers' and the church's resi stance. **********But many European critics contend that policies intended to sustain and worsen chaos in Poland will only make it more rather than less likely that the Russians will tighten their grip on Poland and the other satellite countries, a grip that could be broken only by war.  These critics also contend that efforts to weaken the Polish economy, by withholding food supplies or balance-of-payments support, are likely to be counterproductive in weakening the will of the Polish people to resist. The Polish people are starving, but the army is in no danger of starvation. **********The British newspaper The Guardian warns that the Polish people must not be treated as ''dispensable pawns'' in Western strategy, adding: ''The line between penalizing General Jaruzelski and penalizing ordinary Poles is thin and gray, for however one views it, it is the ordinary Poles who will suffer.'' The same arguments, the newspaper maintains, apply to a deliberate severance of bank aid to Poland, insisting that a nation bankrupt and in default would be a two-edged crisis - and one for Western banking itself. **********But the United States has made clear to the Europeans that it expects support for its economic sanctions, and this week leaders of the Common Market, meeting in Brussels, pledged that they would do nothing to hamper American sanctions against the Soviet Union.  However, they took no initiatives of their own. **********Chancellor Schmidt has stressed his belief that the greater danger to the alliance comes not from political differences over Poland but from the economic slump in the West, with rising unemployment intensifying pressures for protectionism and other beggar-my-neighbor policies. The Germans have long made plain their view that mistaken United States economic policies, resulting in high interest rates, are the source of sluggish growth and rising joblessness throughout the industrial world. **********But the Reagan Administration contends that it is persistent inflation that is responsible for the West's economic troubles, and that its tight-money policies, however painful during the transition, are breaking the back of inflation, bringing down interest rates and setting this country and its neighbors back on course to stable growth. **********While sharing the goal of bringing down inflation - a passion in which the Germans feel they need no instruction - Chancellor Schmidt and his Economics Minister, Count Otto Lambsdorff, insist that the Reagan Administration's approach, by relying so heavily on monetary restraints, is simplistic and brutal, both toward the American labor force and toward the members of the Western political and economic alliance. **********If pursued doggedly, they contend, the Reagan Administration's mixture of monetary, fiscal and military policies will keep the industrial world in a state of high interest rates, stuttering growth and chronic unemployment. This, Mr. Schmidt warned yesterday, might cause a plunge into a worldwide depression. **********Stagnating productivity and climbing unemployment do not stem from inflation alone but from a complex of different factors, whether in the United States and Western Europe or in Poland and other Communist countries. **********A disruption of trade, stemming from the efforts of nations to protect themselves against hig h unemployment and economic disorder, would intensify the danger of a world economi c breakdown.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/14/busin.body_text: **********CBS Inc. announced yesterday that its net income had dropped 68.5 percent in the third quarter, to $18.5 million, or 66 cents a share, from $58.7 million, or $2.11 a share, for the same period in 1981.  It cited the recession, retrenchment in its record operations and its unsuccessful cable television business. **********The company said its revenues for the quarter dipped 2 percent, to $958.1 million, from 973.6 million during last year's third quarter.  ''Our financial results for the third quarter reflect both difficult business conditions and the effect of important steps we have taken to reposition our businesses,'' the company's president, Thomas H. Wyman, said.. **********The earnings statement added that while broadcast group revenue rose 9 percent, profit declined, ''reflecting the impact of sharply higher first-year costs associated with new contracts for television sports events, expanded news programming'' and its new network radio service directed at young adults. **********Revenue from the record group dropped 21 percent. During the quarter, CBS Inc. decided to close its recorded-music plant at Terre Haute, Ind., which entailed a one-time charge to income from continuing operations of $5.6 million. **********The company also announced in the quarter that it was discontinuing CBS Cable, a cable television programming service - a step that is resulting in a loss from discontinued operations of $10.2 million. Time Inc. **********Time Inc., the diversified communications and forest products company, said that its third-quarter net income rose 79.6 percent, to $35.2 million, or 55 cents a share, from $19.6 million, or 32 cents a share, during the 1981 period. **********The 1981 figure, however, reflected a loss of $19.2 million, after taxes, mainly from costs of closing down The Washington Star. Income from continuing operations slipped 9.3 percent, to $35.2 million, from $38.8 million in the third quarter last year. **********Third-quarter revenues rose 8.5 percent, to $877.1 million, from $808.5 million in last year's third quarter.  ''The principal cause of the decline,'' said J. Richard Munro, Time Inc.'s president and chief executive officer, ''was the continued depressed state of the forest products industry.'' **********Mr. Munro said magazine and book publishing profits were down, but that video group profits were up. Gannett Company **********The Gannett Company said it had record third-quarter net income of $42.9 million, or 81 cents a share, up 4.4 percent from $41.1 million, or 76 cents a share, in last year's third quarter, when there were more shares outstanding. **********Third-quarter revenues rose 10 percent, to $368.1 million, from $335.6 million during the same period in 1981.  Gannett's chairman and president, Allen H. Neuharth, said: ''Although we have yet to see an upturn in the general economy, we expect Gannett's steady record of improvement in revenues and earnings will continue modestly through the balance of the year.'' **********During the third quarter, Gannett began publishing a daily newspaper, USA Today, for national distribution. The company publishes 121 local newspapers and owns radio and television stations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/16/world.body_text: **********Teheran newspapers quoted a member of the Iranian Parliament today as having said that former Foreign Minister Sadegh Ghotbzadeh had planned to blow up Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's house with rockets. **********The legislator, Movahed Savoji, was quoted as having told a rally in the city of Qum on Wednesday that the former minister had rented a house 150 yards from the Ayatollah's residence for that purpose. **********Mr. Ghotbzadeh was arrested in Teheran last week and Iranian judicial authorities have accused him of leading a monarchist group plotting to kill Ayatollah Khomeini. According to the newspapers, Mr. Savoji said the monarchist group under Mr. Ghotbzadeh's direction had placed explosives in the house that were meant to go off before the rocket attack. **********Mohsen Rezai, commander of Revolutionary Guards who arrested Mr.  Ghotbzadeh in his house, said the former Foreign Minister had been arrested while smoking opium, the newspapers said. Mr. Ghotbzadeh faces a firing squad if convicted in the plot.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/05/world.print_headline: ARGENTINA AND CUBA SIGN TRADE PACT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/05/world.body_text: **********Argentina's Foreign Minister signed a $100 million trade agreement with Cuba Thursday night to underline the new friendship that has sprung up as a result of the Falkland crisis. **********But before leaving here today for Caracas, Venezuela, the Argentine official, Nicanor Costa Mendez, told reporters he had not discussed Cuba's offer of military aid to Argentina. ''We have excellent diplomatic and commercial relations,'' he said, ''but the military question is not of my competence.'' **********Mr. Costa Mendez, who appealed Thursday for support for Argentina at a meeting of third world nations professing nonalignment, also said he was ''very surprised and astonished that the United States has given Britain arms and assistance to kill our people.'' **********Fidel Castro, the Cuban leader, said at an informal news conference Thursday night that he was sure the 94-nation Nonaligned Movement would adopt a resolution favorable to Argentina. He described the Argentine Foreign Minister's speech as ''excellent, clear and rational.'' Allies' Ranks 'Weakening' **********''I don't question the right of Argentina to recover their territories using the methods that all peoples have always used,'' he said. **********''Even if the United Kingdom recovers the islands, they have not won the battle of the Malvinas,'' he continued, using the name by which the islands are known in Latin America. ''Support for Argentina grows by the day, while the ranks of the allies are weakening.'' **********But no agreement has yet been reached on the exact phrasing to be used on the Falkland issue in the final conference document.  Argentina's sovereignty over the islands is expected to be reaffirmed, but Jamaica and other Commonwealth countries have resisted efforts to describe Britain's move to recover control of the islands as ''aggression.'' **********Many African and Asian delegates expressed surprise at the unusually radical stance adopted by Mr. Costa Mendez on Thursday on numerous third world issues. Not only did he sharply criticize South Africa and Israel and express support for the Palestinians, but he praised the struggles of Algeria, India, Cuba and Vietnam ''for liberation.'' **********Argentine diplomats said the Foreign Minister had made a clear effort to appeal to the strongly anticolonialist sentiments of many members of the Nonaligned Movement by placing Argentina's claim to the Falklands within the context of a colonial struggle. Argentine journalists accompanying Mr. Costa Mendez also remarked on the unusual sight of a senior member of Argentina's strongly anti-Communist regime being embraced publicly by Mr. Castro. **********Mr. Castro, who met Mr. Costa Mendez on three separate occasions during his 36-hour visit here, told reporters last night that he had supported Argentina's claim to the Falklands for ''30 or more years'' and that he was filled with ''admiration'' by the ''very clean and elegant way'' in which the islands were seized April 2.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/09/busin.body_text: **********A Federal court in Alabama sent a sobering message last week to g overnments in default on bonds owned by Americans. Ruling in a classa ction brought against China in 1979, Judge U.W. Clemon of the D istrict Court, Northern District of Alabama, held that China must r etire at face amount bonds issued 71 years ago. China has been in d efault on the bonds since 1930. The judge also ruled that interest m ust be paid up to the date of payment. **********The award totals $41,313,038. It covers only a small number of the defaulted bonds at issue - the 5 percent Hukuang Railways Sinking Fund Gold Bonds of 1911, and an even smaller fraction of all Chinese bonds in default, many of which are held in Europe. **********But 300 persons included in the class action now have much improved hopes of realizing substantial sums on their Hukuang bonds.  Specifically, each holder in the class action owning a 100 bond was awarded $4,617.22 and each holder of a 20 bond was awarded $923.44. **********China made no appearance at the court sessions. Its embassy in Washington returned the summons and other official papers to the court on May 16, 1980 - a month after they were served. **********The Chinese Government claims judicial immunity under international law as a sovereign state and said through officials in the United States in a brief note to the court that it did not accept the suit.  Further, the note said, China recognized no liability incurred by ''successive reactionary governments'' of the past and will not pay their debts. **********On the other hand, China is said to have paid claims in recent minor suits involving commercial matters. Some observers believe China may attempt a private settlement with the group involved in the Alabama case to avoid embarrassment over any efforts by the court to seize Chinese property. Some American judgments against other nations have led to seizures of airplanes, ships and their cargoes, real estate and bank accounts. **********The Chinese note to the court said that if the nation's property were seized, it would reserve the right to take corresponding measures. **********W. Eugene Rutledge of Birmingham, Ala., attorney for the plaintiffs, said that if the judgment survived any petition to vacate that China might file, ''We will take every measure we can to collect.'' **********Mr. Rutledge argued that China was buying computers and other equipment in this nation and should, therefore, expect to be held accountable for debts. **********China is one of several nations in default on dollar bonds issued decades ago. They include the Soviet Union, Cuba, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Rumania, Bulgaria and Bolivia. **********Prof. Hubert Park Beck, professor emeritus of the City University of New York, said the Alabama decision represented a breakthrough.  Mr. Beck, who owns some Hukuang bonds, is an authority on foreign bonds in default, having worked in the field for more than a quarter of a century. He is also chairman of the Russian Dollar Bondholders Committee of the U.S.A. **********He added that he believed the China case set a precedent: It was the first case he knew of in which a foreign nation had been held responsible for defaulted loans offered publicly in the United States. The Alabama case, tried under the Foreign Sovereign Immunities Act of 1976, also strengthened a case begun this year against the Soviet Union, he concluded.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/29/busin.body_text: **********The Mesa Petroleum Company said that it had bank commitments for credits of $1 billion to be used in part for a pending takeover bid for the General American Oil Company of Texas. **********It said up to $400 million, now unsecured, would be used for corporate needs other than to buy securities on credit. **********In addition, it said it would use $325 million, secured by oil and gas properties, to buy securities on credit, including those of General American, and $275 million, secured by the General American shares it holds, to buy only General American shares. It has bid $40 a share for 13 million shares. **********General American, attempting to block Mesa's bid, is offering to buy back some of its shares for $50 each. **********---- DALLAS, Dec. 28 (Reuters) - The Meadows Foundation said it had voted to tender its 6.6 million General American shares to Mesa ''solely for the purposes of preserving all of its options.'' **********The foundation, which holds about 26 percent of General American's stock, said that it still viewed Mesa's offer as inadequate and that the decision to tender should not be viewed as an acceptance of it.  It said it reserved the right to withdraw its shares from the Mesa offer before the withdrawal deadline.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/19/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene; A Reformer For Both Blocs
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/19/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene; A Reformer For Both Blocs
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/19/busin.body_text: **********AT a time when economic policies seem to have become principally political and ideological weapons to be used in combat by politicians and their agents, it may be useful to remember the contributions of Abba P. Lerner, one of the greatest economists of this century. **********Professor Lerner, who died three weeks ago in Tallahassee, Fla., at the age of 79, always called the issues as he saw them, whatever special economic or political interests were involved. And he always pursued the broad interests of humanity, seeking to base his advice on scientific fact and logic. **********He did not care whether he was labeled a Socialist or capitalist, and he was actually something of both. He regarded such labels as capitalism and Communism as misleading and, even worse, corrupting of scientific thought on how to help people advance their own welfare freely - and at the same time advance the well-being of the society as a whole. What Mr. Lerner sought to serve was what he called ''everybody's business.'' **********But, with devastating clarity, he saw that people had to have a personal stake in serving other people's interests: He regarded that as the genius of the profit system. He could be excoriating to Marxists who parroted the doctrine that production should be ''for use and not for profit.'' **********He once caricatured the student who ''preaches his parables'' denouncing capitalist waste and folly as one who sips ''his coffee, the radio turned low, comfortably seated near a well-stocked refrigerator in a warm elevator apartment, with hundreds of thousands of items for him to drink or wear or read or play with, waiting to be picked up at nearby stores or to be delivered to him in response to a telephone call.'' **********A passionate lover of freedom, and one who practiced it in his personal and professional life in a time when academic rigidity and snobbery exacted a heavy toll from nonconformists, Mr. Lerner did not believe in the fashionable ideologies celebrating free enterprise and denouncing all uses of government as inevitably an incursion into freedom and a distorting force in advancing social welfare. **********The true heroes of the maximization of freedom, he contended, were not the classical economists who, he said, ''merely discovered the nature of the operations of the price mechanism in harnessing the private interests of producing and providing things that people wanted.'' **********He thought the true heroes were the pre-classical political economists who made it possible for the system to work, going back to ''ancient solons who developed the institution of private property and then corporate property, who established the rule of law that gave security to property and the freedom of individuals to move and to trade.'' **********As one who thoroughly understood the market and the price system, Mr. Lerner criticized the ''stupidities of sentimental Socialists or anticapitalists who had no understanding of the complex and subtle machinery that made modern life possible, and who had eyes only for flaws in the operation of the economy of the present and wished only to contrast with idealized utopias of the future.'' **********He sought to convert Communists and Socialists both in the West and behind the Iron Curtain to an appreciation of the use of markets to make their societies more efficient and free. He sought to prove that Socialism could rely almost entirely on the market mechanism as the greatest promoter of human welfare yet discovered. **********His thinking has had an impact on the efforts of economic reformers in Hungary, Yugoslavia and Poland to develop ''market socialism.'' It is conceivable that the new Soviet leader, Yuri V. Andropov, a former Ambassador to Hungary, might yet try to put into effect such market reforms in the Soviet Union. **********But Mr. Lerner was also a reformer of capitalism. An early student and expositor of John Maynard Keynes, he went on to develop his own ideas of ''functional finance'' for solving the problems of depression or inflation - or the two together in what he called, more than a quarter of a century ago, ''inflationary depression,'' which is now known as stagflation. **********He warned that attempts to stop what he called a sellers' inflation, resulting from excess market power of labor, business or cartels, by restrictive fiscal or monetary measures would only bring about a depression. Then attempts to cure this depression by expansionary monetary or fiscal policy would only restore inflation. **********He concluded that the problem of inflationary depression could not be solved just by manipulating monetary and fiscal policy. He tried to solve it by developing a plan for reorienting the tax system so that those who increased their prices or raised wages faster than the rate of productivity growth would find their tax burden increased, thereby giving self-interested people a stake in preventing inflation. **********Once again, Mr. Lerner was trying to combine self-interest and freedom with a social interest. His works - especially his masterpiece, ''The Economics of Control'' - will reward fresh study. **********He did not get any of the glittering prizes. All he got was respect.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/23/busin.body_text: **********THE American Coal Foundation, created a year ago by both the management and labor of the industry to promote the use of coal, will institute its first $1 million advertising campaign, largely on television, next week. **********The theme is ''Rediscover coal. The modern energy miracle that's old as the hills.'' Although the advertising is consumer-oriented, the target is a very special kind of consumer: the upscale, community leader type.  And, judging by the media selection, the coal people also believe it is a male since the single 30-second spot will be running largely during sports telecasts or cablecasts. **********The spot will run for the first time on Dec. 29 during the showing of the Liberty Bowl in Memphis, on the Entertainment and Sports Programming Network, or ESPN, on cable. Yesterday Curt Thomas, senior vice president and general manager of the Pittsburgh office of Marsteller, flew in - video cassette in hand - to preview the commercial. The agency, a subsidiary of Young & Rubicam, had won the account in a full-fledged competition that started out with 50 agencies getting questionnaires and ended with three or four finalists and full-fledged speculative presentations, for which there was no compensation. **********The commercial Mr. Thomas carried so protectively to New York is the finished version of the rough spot that the agency showed to the foundation's operating committee and board to win the account. **********At first glance it appears to be another spot for still another detergent with this huge package dominating the quiet countryside.  Except this time in addition to being printed with ''New miracle energy discovery'' and ''Giant economy size,'' the box is labeled ''Coal.'' - ''Available. Abundant. Affordable. American.'' **********And the announcer's voice intones, ''And now we have ways to keep it clean.'' The agency and the foundation it represents must walk a fine line since under its charter the foundation may not do any grass-roots lobbying. So the advertising is intended, in Mr. Thomas's words, ''to promote the advantages of coal to the American public.'' But it will not be issue oriented. **********So it would seem that television would be the ideal way to go for 30 seconds' worth of mood or image and not too many potentially controversial hard facts - a commercial that will leave a viewer of the ''public activist'' stripe with a positive rather than negative attitude toward the use of coal as an energy source. **********The three-month television effort, which will use up 95 percent of the budget, will run largely on the networks during sports and news programming although additional spots will appear during Sugar Bowl and Gator Bowl coverage on WTAE-TV in Pittsburgh, which is a very important market in coal circles. **********Just as a corporate image campaign has as one of its goals the stimulation of the company's own work force, the foundation wishes to excite its various components - mine operators, the United Mine Workers union, and the various suppliers to the industry. **********Additionally, as Mr. Thomas noted, it is hoped that the commercials will stimulate those industry organizations that may not have contributed to the advertising program to do so. **********The only print advertising in the campaign will be a full-page four-color ad scheduled for next Wednesday in Gannett's USA Today newspaper that has a guaranteed circulation of 200,000 in six markets. On top of that, the agency has also prepared a 60-second radio commercial built around the music track of the television spot and it is being supplied to the foundation membership for local use. **********Asked to comment on the coal industry's communications plans, David Keto of the staff of the National Resources Defense Council, an environmental law firm in New York, said he wanted to make three points: Energy conservation is a cleaner alternative than coal burning. Coal is basically a dirty fuel and the use of coal-burning technology is not always required. And the environmental impact of coal burning cannot always be mitigated through technology. **********A theme line suggestion for both industry and consumer: ''We dig coal.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/04/world.body_text: **********The pipeline that carries Iraqi crude oil to the Lebanese Mediterranean coast was blown up by an explosion today. **********The Government-controlled Radio Lebanon reported that the explosion, which it called sabotage, started a huge fire that was raging hours after the blast occurred in the northern district of Akkar at a point three miles south of the Syrian border. **********Mohammed Yusef Beydun, the Lebanese Minister of Petroleum and Industry, said pumping of the oil was discontinued pending repairs on the damaged pipe. **********Fire brigades from Beirut and Syria were enlisted to help put out the blaze, which began when spilled crude burned as a result of the explosion. **********The pumping of Iraqi petroleum to the Lebanese seaport of Tripoli, about 50 miles north of here, was resumed only a week ago after an interruption of six years due to the Lebanese civil strife and later to the Iraqi-Iranian war. Lebanese Tanker Attacked **********A Lebanese registered tanker came under artillery bombardment Saturday as it was being loaded with 150,000 thousand tons of Iraqi crude at the Tripoli terminal. The shelling caused a fire on the ship's deck that was quickly extinquinshed. The tanker has sailed to Greece to undergo repairs. **********The pipeline runs about 20 miles inside Lebanon from the Syrian border to Tripoli. Iraqi crude oil is also being pumped to the Syrian terminal of Banias on the Mediterranean via a 900-mile-long pipeline from Kirkuk in northern Iraq. **********It was not immediately known who was behind today's explosion, but there was immediate speculation that activists supporting the Iranian religious leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, may have been responsible. **********Pro-Khomeini activists and groups supporting the regime of the Iraqi President, Saddam Hussein, have been fighting their own miniwar on Lebanese territory. **********The destruction of the Iraqi Embassy here by a powerful explosion last month was attributed to this feud. Thirty-eight people, including the ambassador, were killed in the blast. **********The Iraqi Government was planning to increase its oil exports from Tripoli by 200,000 barrels a day because of its need for additional funds to finance the war with Iran, which is now in its second year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/14/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Lisbon Defeats Move To Legalize Abortion
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/14/world.body_text: **********The conservative coalition Government gained a victory on Friday when Parliament defeated a Communist-sponsored bill that would have legalized abortion in this predominantly Roman Catholic country. **********The measure, introduced in the 250-member Chamber of Deputies nine months ago, lost by a vote of 127 to 105, with some members abstaining or not present. **********The defeated bill would have allowed abortions in the first three months of pregnancy in cases where the mother's life was endangered, if the fetus was found to have a ''life threatening'' disease, if the parents were judged financially unable to raise another child, or if the pregnancy resulted from rape. **********Under the current law that remains in effect, penalties for abortions range from two years to eight years in prison.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/14/world.main_headline: INTRUDER AND QUEEN REPORTEDLY CHATTED ABOUT ROYAL FAMILY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/14/world.print_headline: INTRUDER AND QUEEN REPORTEDLY CHATTED ABOUT ROYAL FAMILY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/14/world.body_text: **********The lawyer of the man who sneaked into Queen Elizabeth's bedroom said today that his client spent ''just over 10 minutes'' talking with the Queen about the royal family before a chambermaid led him away. **********After visiting his client at Brixton Prison, the attorney, Maurice Nadeem, said in a television interview that 30-year-old Michael Fagan had been to Buckingham Palace ''twice - no more,'' despite press reports he had broken into the royal residence as many as 12 times. **********Asked by Independent Television News if Mr. Fagan had explained why he did it, the lawyer said, ''Yes, he wished to see Her Majesty the Queen.'' **********He said Mr. Fagan and the Queen talked about her family, and the Queen mentioned her eldest son, Prince Charles. The conversation ended when a maid came into the room and Mr. Fagan was taken away, Mr. Nadeem said. New Version of Security Lapse **********The Standard newspaper offered a new version of the palace security lapse, which has caused a furor in Parliament and the press and among the public. **********The paper said the 56-year-old Queen used her bedside telephone to raise the alarm when awakened by the intruder at about 7 A.M. Friday, but the palace police officer failed to realize the urgency of her message because she was so calm. **********''The first person to enter her room was a chambermaid 10 minutes after the intruder got in,'' The Standard said. ''Police arrived another eight minutes after that - when the chambermaid had already led the man away. The chambermaid handed the man over to a footman.'' **********The Standard explained the security lapse by saying an armed policeman had gone off duty outside the royal bedroom at 6 A.M., when members of the Queen's personal staff arrive for work. **********The British Broadcasting Corporation reported that the Queen tried to push a ''panic'' button in her room but it had failed to go off.  Asked about the two reports, a Scotland Yard spokesman said, ''We are not prepared to discuss either of them.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/21/busin.body_text: **********It was the best-selling cigarette in America. With great hoopla, it made the big move over ''The Hump,'' as its nemesis, Camel, was known, during the 1930's. For people now in their 20's and 30's, this was often the brand their fathers and mothers smoked. Who can forget its sponsorship of ''Your Hit Parade,'' or that catchy string of letters - L.S./M.F.T. ''Lucky Strike Means Fine Tobacco.'' **********By now, Lucky Strike has sold more than a trillion ''sticks,'' but like an aging movie star whose best roles are only memories, the brand faded from the limelight decades ago. A chart of its market share over the last three decades would show a line heading straight down. Strangled by filter products, the cigarette that in 1931 controlled 39 percent of the market now clings tenuously to a dwindling eight-tenths of 1 percent. **********In the world of consumer marketing, however, it is believed that a good name ought never die, and so the American Tobacco Company, which makes Lucky Strike, is betting what it calls ''big bucks'' that it can bring the magic back with a new low-tar filtered rendition.  Billboards are steadily cropping up across the nation heralding the rebirth: ''Lucky Strikes Again.'' **********A Cautious Introduction **********Lucky, however, has been striking at a cautious pace. The cigarette was first tested in Binghamton, N.Y., and Spokane, Wash., last November. When it recently wended its way to New York and Detroit, its penetration had only reached 40 percent of the country. ''We want to know that what we're doing is working,'' explained Thomas Hays, executive vice president of American Tobacco, which also makes Pall Mall, Carlton and Tareyton brands. **********According to Mr. Hays, the new brand has captured more than half a percent of the market in many cities and a full percent in some.  John Maxwell, an analyst with Lehman Brothers, reckons that viability in the frenzied cigarette industry, congested with some 200 brands, seems to begin at half a percent, which roughly translates into manufacturer revenues of $65 million. **********''It's one of the few new brands that have taken off in a while,'' said John Schiro, division general manager of ARA Services, a Binghampton vendor. ''Lucky has a good name. You ask people what L.S./M.F.T. means and they'll tell you.'' **********Indeed, a key reason why American Tobacco, a unit of American Brands, thinks the new Lucky will be a hit is because the name still rings a lot of bells. The first thing the company did almost two years ago was to determine if people remembered Lucky. To the surprise of the company, a remarkable 98 percent of smokers 35 and older knew the name and an even more amazing 97 percent of the younger set recognized it. The 'Toasted' Cigarette **********Lucky Strike was introduced in 1916, borrowing its name from a tobacco brand first used in 1871. Since the tobacco was refined by a cooking process, sales experts hit upon the idea of touting it as ''It's toasted.'' The notion became a famous Lucky slogan, and billboards boasting a toasting fork dotted the country's highways. **********The new smoke began a meteoric rise. Heavy advertising played a pivotal role. Among the Lucky themes: ''Luckies Use Only Center Leaves -The Center Leaves Give You the Mildest Smoke;'' ''With Men Who Know Tobacco Best, It's Luckies 2 to 1.'' **********To further spread brand awareness, the company turned to such things as a cigarette-rolling exhibition in New York and began in 1930 to sponsor the ''Lucky Strike Radio Show,'' which eventually starred the likes of Frank Sinatra and Phil Harris. Television was its next battleground. It backed ''The Lucky Strike Theater,'' ''Your Hit Parade'' and ''The Jack Benny Show.'' **********Originally, the Lucky Strike package was green, but during World War II the chromium needed for the green coloring became a valued war commodity. So, in 1942, the package became white with a red bull's eye, and the company got enormous mileage out of a ''Lucky Goes to War'' campaign. The L.S./M.F.T. slogan also was introduced at this time. Rise of the Filters **********It was all great while it lasted, but increasingly smokers became dismayed about all that tar the cigarette produced. The death knell for the big brands of the day - Camel and Chesterfield among them - was sounded in the early 1950's with the arrival of filtered cigarettes. **********One statistic succinctly tells the story: In 1953, filters controlled less than 10 percent of the cigarette market. In 1957, they had captured more than half of it. Along with its nonfiltered brethren, Lucky Strike commenced its long downward ride. **********Since the old Lucky Strike has been foundering for nearly three decades, what took American Tobacco so long to whip up a filtered version? Actually, the company made a couple of dismal stabs at it, but committed the mistake of failing to capitalize on the popular name. **********In 1956, it introduced a filtered cigarette called ''Hit Parade.'' It went nowhere, not being helped much by the fact that two years later the television show ''Your Hit Parade'' vanished. ''Hit Parade,'' the cigarette, disappeared in 1962. Then, in 1971, the company tried ''Lucky 10's,'' another flop that was finally scrapped last year. **********A jumble of magazine ads blanket Tom Hays's desk. He wanted to illustrate how the new Lucky Strike was trying to stand alone among its competitors. The cigarette is aimed at 21-to-35-year-old male smokers, so the key brands it has to battle are low-tar filtered versions of Marlboro, Winston and Camel. The Macho Problem **********Lucky tested three ad strategies. One was a nostalgia approach.  Consumers yawned. Then it tried a macho slant. The problem here was its rivals were big on macho. Mr. Hays nodded at a Marlboro ad of a cowboy on a horse romping through Marlboro country and a Winston ad of two construction workers. He pointed to a Camel ad of a man wading through a stream, a grave look on his face. ''How do you out-macho this?'' he asked. ''You'd have to go to outright killers.'' **********So it settled on an upbeat ad depicting a man in the foreground of a recording studio popping a Lucky out of a package, while three musicians drag on their Luckies in the background. **********''Through the scene here, you can see it's time to light up because they've just finished recording a song,'' Mr. Hays said. ''We show the man up front, but he's also a leader since there's a group behind him.'' **********The younger smokers Lucky is chasing often buy their packs out of vending machines, and so American Tobacco is making sure it snuggles in a lot of columns. The way to do that is the standard cigarette strategem of paying inducements. **********Vendors are being offered $4 a year per machine for each column of Lucky Strike filters. Stocking for the first time also gets them a free carton of filters as well as a bonus carton of Pall Mall reds.  Another $2 can be had for applying a sticker onto the machine pointing out Luckies. If a fresh sticker is put on six months later, another $2 arrives. **********To create a fresh wave of excitement, American Tobacco has dispatched fetching young women to dole out hundreds of thousands of samples on street corners, as well as in bars and discotheques. **********How sweet Lucky's comeback is, though, may in the end be determined by the luster of the name. ''Today there's a greater interest in antique cars and early American quilts,'' Mr. Hays remarked. ''So there's more interest in these older brands.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/20/world.body_text: **********Fears are growing here in northern Lebanon that once the Beirut crisis is over, the Israelis will begin a drive against the Palestinians in the north and in the Bekaa Valley in the east, with the Lebanese again caught in the middle. **********With Israeli armored detachments deployed deep in northern Lebanon, such fears are being expressed by Lebanese officials, local residents, Palestinians and the Greek Orthodox bishop. **********The Israelis are viewed as intent on pushing the Palestinians out of all of Lebanon, even at the risk of clashes with the Syrian Army, which controls the northern and eastern sectors. **********In recent deployments the Israelis moved to the peaks at Aqura, 22 miles south of here, and then reportedly to the Bsharri area, 16 miles southeast of here. From Bsharri, Israeli artillery can strike at Tripoli, with its half a million inhabitants, and control the road running eastward across the central Lebanon range into the Bekaa Valley. (Adding to the anxieties of the Lebanese in Tripoli was a warning voiced Thursday by Israel's Defense Minister, Ariel Sharon, that Israel would not tolerate harassment by Palestinians under Syrian protection in northern Lebanon.) While the Israelis have moved northward from the Beirut area, Syria has also strengthened the position of its forces around Tripoli, and brought in Syrian reinforcements and troops of the Syrian-controlled Palestine Liberation Army into villages around Zgharta, four miles to the southeast. The Tripoli area appears a likely Israeli target in the view of Lebanese political sources. They say there are two Palestinian refugee camps -at Al Baddawi, two miles northeast of Tripoli, and at Nahr Al Barid, six miles beyond - with a combined population of 25,000. **********There has been an influx of Palestinians fleeing from Beirut and southern Lebanon in advance of the Israeli invasion forces.  Palestinian guerrillas can be seen in the camps, but most of them seem to have fanned out and taken positions in the surrounding olive groves. **********Palestinian sources refuse to give any indication of the strength of their fighting forces, but Lebanese experts believe the total may be as high as 7,000. Villages Being Asked for Help **********Furthermore, the Syrians have brought Palestine Liberation Army troops here by bus and left them in the Zgharta area without vehicles or logistical support. The troops are said to be soliciting help from the villagers. Many people are said to be fleeing because they fear the Israelis will attack. **********Another reason why it is feared this area will come under attack is that it is the center of Lebanese Christian and Moslem groups favorable to Syria and opposed to Israel and to the Lebanese Christian alliance headed by Bashir Gemayel, who is seen here as an Israeli collaborator. Mr. Gemayel is a candidate in the presidential election due to be held in Parliament on Monday. **********There is no strong military force in the area to challenge the Israelis since most of the groups are splintered. Only the Syrians have any significant armed strength, and they are believed eager to avoid a confrontation with the Israelis after the losses the Syrians suffered in June in the Bekaa Valley. North Is Cut Off From Beirut **********The Israelis, by cutting the Beirut-Damascus highway, preventing the main Syrian force in the valley from going to the aid of the besieged Palestinians and Syrians in west Beirut. The Syrians and the Palestinians in the north are also cut off from Beirut, by the Israeli-backed Lebanese Christians. **********Syrian forces entered Lebanon in 1976 under a mandate from the Arab League to put an end to a civil war, and they still control northern Lebanon and the eastern slopes of the central mountain range and the Bekaa Valley. **********Diplomatic quarters say they do not expect a confrontation between the Israelis and the Syrian forces, which are estimated at 60,000, but believe that Israel will demand a Syrian pullout as the main condition for its own withdrawal from Lebanon. **********Syrian forces are spread out all over the Bekaa Valley and eastward from the village of Sofar on the Damascus road and south to the region of the Karaun hills. Estimates of the number of Palestinian guerrillas in the Bekaa Valley have ranged from 2,000 to 15,000. Syria Restraining Palestinians **********Syria has reportedly made it clear that it does not want those guerrillas to strike at Israeli forces from the Syrian-controlled area. At the same time, Syrian officials in Damascus have said privately that they cannot be held responsible for Palestinians throughout northern and eastern Lebanon. **********Lebanese here say they fear that, as in Beirut, they would suffer the most from any Israeli offensive in the north. Unlike Beirut, Tripoli does not seem to be a city prepared for war. There is little armed presence in Tripoli, which last year succeeded in getting the Syrian forces out of the city center. **********Many Lebanese here, among them former President Suleiman Franjieh, believe that the United States has a long-term plan to partition Lebanon into a mini-Christian state, under Israeli protection, and a Moslem state, where some 600,000 Palestinian refugees would be forcibly settled. Franjieh Denounces Israelis **********''Every night I pray that the Israelis will come here, because our mountains are easier to defend than the Bekaa,'' Mr. Franjieh, a 72-year-old Maronite Christian, said in an interview at his mountaintop retreat at Ihdin, 17 miles southeast of here. **********He said he hoped the Israelis would attack Syrian territory ''because it will cost them a lot.'' In such an event, he said, Syria's friendship treaty with the Soviet Union would come into play. **********Mr. Franjieh, who has been talked about as a possible presidential candidate with the support of Moslems and Syrians, declared that he would not agree to enter any election ''under the bayonets of the Israelis.'' **********The Moslem leader in Tripoli, former Prime Minister Rashid Karami, denounced Mr. Gemayel's candidacy and said the Moslems will boycott the election set for Monday. He said he did not believe that the Israelis would attack here because of the negative reaction of world opinion to what he described as ''the barbaric destruction of Beirut.'' Greek Orthodox Fears Clashes **********However, the Greek Orthodox Bishop of Tripoli, Metropolitan Elias Kozban, expressed concern that the Israelis might clash next with the Palestinians and their Lebanese allies here. The Bishop, who is a naturalized American, said the French, American and Italian peace force should be brought to Tripoli as well until the Lebanese Army can protect the area. **********Palestinian representatives also talked about possible Israeli attacks. However, Col. Abu Fawaz, an officer of Al Fatah, the main guerrilla group, said that while the Israelis would probably stage air strikes on Tripoli, he thought ''their tanks won't dare to come.'' **********He said the Palestinians had evidence that the Israelis had moved armored vehicles into positions along the central mountain crest in the region of Aqura. He declined to give any indication as to the number of Palestinian guerrillas in the area but said all organizations were represented and ''nobody is leaving.'' **********The rightist Lebanese Christian radio, Voice of Lebanon, has also reported Israeli tanks and trucks moving into the Aqura mountain area. **********The colonel said Palestinian relations with the local Lebanese were ''good because they realize they are targets like the Palestinians.'' **********However, visitors to Tripoli have found evidence of tension resulting from takeovers by Palestinians of some apartments and stores.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/01/world.main_headline: Mitterrand Winds Up His Stay in India
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/01/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Mitterrand Winds Up His Stay in India
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/01/world.body_text: **********President Francois Mitterrand of France toured central and southern India today at the end of a four-day visit that officials say has succeeded in establishing special ties between India and France. **********He left for home later. The French President has cultivated relations with India since taking office in May 1981, and sees this relationship as a cornerstone of his policy with the developing countries. **********Mr. Mitterrand visited ancient cave temples at Ellora in central India today and then flew to the southern city of Bangalore to tour an aircraft factory and address the Indian Institute of Sciences. **********In Bangalore he visited the Government-owned Hindustan Aeronautics Factory where French-designed Alouette helicopters and British-French Jaguar strike aircraft are being assembled.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/04/world.body_text: **********Thieves took a painting by Pieter Bruegel, the Elder, valued at more than $1 million from a London museum Tuesday, and today museum officials blamed Government spending cuts for the incident. **********The picture, called ''Christ and the Woman Taken in Adultery,'' was painted in 1565 and is considered one of the masterpieces of the Flemish school. **********It was part of a $100 million collection bequeathed to the Courtauld Institute in 1978 by Count Antoine Seilern, an Anglo-Austrian. **********Prof. Michael Kitson, the institute's deputy director, said in an interview that security in the gallery was ''considerably less complete than we would have liked.'' There are no electronic alarms attached to the paintings, as there are in most major West European art museums. **********Only a handful of guards are on hand to protect the Seilern pictures, which are known as the Princes Gate Collection after the London street on which the Count lived, and the equally rich collection of Impressionist paintings owned by the Courtauld. The holdings of the institute, which is part of the university of London, are valued at more than $200 million. **********''Like everyone else, we have felt the tremendous pressure from the Government on universities in this country to economize,'' Professor Kitson said. ''We have not been able to employ adequate staff, and more sophisticated measures are out of the question. As a result of this, security will have to be considerably tightened up, but the cost will cause us tremendous problems.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/21/busin.print_headline: Advertising; Life Sets Campaign To Spread Good Word
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/21/busin.body_text: **********Unlike the old Life, which died going head to head with television, the new Life is thriving in a world of its own as the only consumer magazine with the large format. **********No longer does it try to supply the news to the masses on a weekly basis and vie with TV for the packaged goods advertiser. Gone is the eight million circulation. Now the monthly has a guarantee of 1.3 million and a much higher quality buyer. **********Soon it will be undertaking an ad campaign, a first of its kind since the 1979 comeback, that will seek to spread the word of the good Life, of its quality and its audience. It will run in sister publication Time and in The New York Times Magazine, according to Charles A. Whittingham, publisher. His agency for all advertising is Geer, DuBois. **********The ads in this campaign, backed by about $500,000, will each have as illustration the picture of the magazine open to some outstanding photograph or feature. **********The headline will be ''America's great sense of'' entertainment, art, science or whatever, and the tagline will be ''America's great sense of Life.'' The magazine's name will be its usual white-on-red logo. **********It is that logo that supplied the color motif to the magazine's trade advertising for the last two years. This advertising is the brainchild of Gilbert Lesser, Life's promotion director and a very strong graphics man, who also designed the well-known posters for the plays ''Equus'' and ''The Elephant Man.'' **********All of these ads are white-on-red two-page spreads. The first year, the theme was ''Nothing is bigger than Life,'' promoting the page size. Last year, each ad went after a specific advertiser that was not in Life and landed half of them. The 1982 version of the trade ads will go after entire categories by using research that shows how much Life readers spend in such categories. **********Once again, the graphics are big and bold. It will also run in The Times Magazine as well as in the advertising trade press and in the business publications of each featured category. **********Last year, Life had $23 million in advertising revenues, as estimated by the Publishers Information Bureau, but Mr. Whittingham does not satisfy easily.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/05/world.body_text: **********The United States said today that it had expelled the senior military attache in the Soviet Embassy here on espionage charges. **********A State Department spokesman, Sondra McCarty, said in response to an inquiry that the attache, Maj. Gen. Vasily I. Chitov, had been declared persona non grata and had left Wednesday. **********Asked the reasons for the expulsion, Mrs. McCarty said on ly that the attache had been expelled ''for activitie s inconsistent with his diplomatic status.'' **********A Government official outside the State Department said the general had ''some kind of United States Government material'' in his possession when arrested by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation after a car chase last weekend. **********According to the State Department's Diplomatic List, a directory of foreign diplomats stationed here, General Chitov headed the Soviet Embassy's military attache's office, which also includes half a dozen assistant attaches. In addition to this office, which represents the Soviet Army, the embassy also has offices of air attaches and naval attaches. **********When asked whether the State Department was concerned over the possibility that the Soviet Union might expel an American in retaliation, Mrs. McCarty said, ''I don't want to speculate on that.'' It has been common practice for such retaliations to occur. **********Another official said that the Government had not formally announced the expulsion because it wanted to avoid retaliation against a member of the United States Embassy in Moscow. **********During the 1950's, Soviet diplomats were regularly asked to leave the country after being accused of spying under diplomatic cover. An equivalent number of American diplomats were forced to leave the Soviet Union at that time. **********The arrest of General Chitov was said to have occurred last weekend after a car chase through Washington. The Police Department said it had no knowledge of such an incident. United Press International said the chase had occurred in suburban Virginia, but local police departments there declined to say whether the chase had occurred in their jurisdictions. It is not unusual for the Federal Bureau of Investigation to engage in such activities without telling the local police. The F.B.I. declined to comment. **********The official outside the State Department, who would speak only if left unidentified because of the sensitivity of the matter, said that General Chitov was not part of an espionage ring and that the arrest and expulsion marked ''the beginning and ending'' of the situation.  He would not describe the nature of the material General Chitov was supposed to have had. **********A man who answered the telephone tonight at the Soviet Embassy said in reply to questions about the case: ''I have no information about it. Please call tomorrow morning.'' **********There have been similar incidents involving United States and Soviet diplomats in the past. Because of diplomatic immunity, the suspected transgressor has generally been expelled instead of being prosecuted. **********In the most recent reported incident, in 1978, three Soviet citizens were arrested in the United States after having allegedly paid $16,000 for Navy secrets. One of the three was a diplomat assigned to the Soviet mission to the United Na tions in New York City and was expelled. The other two, however, were United Nations employees without diplomatic status and had to stand trial. **********They were convicted and sentenced to long prison terms. Before being imprisoned, however, they were allowed to return to the Soviet Union as part of an exchange in which five dissidents were released from Soviet jails and allowed to come to the United States.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/15/busin.body_text: **********The most dramatic change in the new merger guidelines is probably the adoption of the Herfindahl index, a mathematical standard for determining when an industry is so concentrated that mergers will be anticompetitive. **********The Herfindahl index is more finely calibrated than the former standard, which differentiated only between industries in which the four largest companies had more than 75 percent of a market and those in which they did not. The Herfindahl index looks beyond the four largest companies to every company in an industry, calculating the sum of the squares of every company's market share. **********Thus, in an industry served by 10 companies, each with a 10 percent market share, the index would be 1,000, derived by squaring 10 ten different times and adding the results together. If the index is that low or less, the Government, under its new guidelines, would usually not challenge any merger in the industry. **********With the Herfindahl index, one company with a 35 percent market share would by itself push the index to 1,225, even if the other companies in the industry each had less than a 1 percent market share. **********If an industry's Herfindahl index is more than 1,800 - roughly equivalent to a highly concentrated industry under the old standard -the Justice Department will look closely at mergers that add more than 50 points to the concentration index. The number of points a merger adds is equal to twice the product of the merging companies' market shares. **********Thus, a company with a 7 percent market share merging with a company with a 4 percent market share would add 56 points - 7 times 4 times 2 - to the concentration index, and would be subject to Justice Department scrutiny. **********Under the new guidelines, the department would probably challenge those mergers that added more than 100 points to industries with an index exceeding 1,800, and would not challenge those that added fewer than 50 points. **********In industries with a Herfindahl index of 1,000 to 1,800, the department is unlikely to challenge mergers that add fewer than 100 points. **********Under the new guildelines, the Justice Department will ordinarily not challenge any mergers in the least concentrated industries, those in which the sum of the squares of all the companies' market shares is less than 1,000.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/11/busin.body_text: **********NEARLY two years after Harvard University thought it had surmounted the long regulatory delays and legal challenges that have added about $100 million to the cost of a large co-generation power plant, a Massachusetts court has once again put the facility's future in doubt. **********In a ruling in September, the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court said the state's Department of Environmental Quality Engineering, which had held more than three years of hearings on the project, erred when it failed to consider the possible carcinogenic effects of particulates that might be emitted from the plant's smokestack. The court ordered the agency to hold further hearings. **********The 73-megawatt plant, which would be diesel-powered, is in the Mission Hill section of Boston, and the suit that led to the court order was brought by local residents and the neighboring town of Brookline. **********Co-generation plants achieve about 30 percent greater efficiency than conventional power stations by recycling hot exhaust fumes and excess steam to produce more energy. The process requires unusually high combustion temperatures, resulting in increased emissions of some pollutants, depending on the fuel used. **********The prospect of further hearings is sending a ripple throughout the utility industry. ''It should alert other potential co-generator builders that we anticipate problems if they burn diesel fuel in cities,'' said Glenn H. Lovin, chairman of the International Co-Generation Society, a Washington clearing house for energy-saving technology. **********According to Mr. Lovin and other industry analysts, most new cogenerators, except those in isolated industrial areas, now use cleaner fuels, such as natural gas. ''Harvard's problems have become well known,'' he said. **********Harvard has repeatedly considered burning gas instead of oil, which is technologically possible with the diesel engines. But the idea was rejected because the university could not get sufficient guarantees of a steady supply of gas. **********The university began constructing the plant in 1976 to supply heat and chilled water to Harvard Medical School and 13 teaching hospitals. But installation of the diesel generators was delayed by court order for nearly three years, while the Department of Environmental Quality Engineering sought to establish standards for safe levels of nitrogen dioxide emissions, which can cause pulmonary and respiratory illnesses. **********In 1980, the agency resolved the nitrogen dioxide issue by ordering Harvard to curb operations. So far only the chilled water and steam facilities are operating. And legal fees, high interest rates and the cost of continued purchases of power have pushed cost estimates from an original level of $150 million to $260 million. **********In September, the court supported rulings issued by the Department of Environmental Quality Engineering. But to the surprise of both Harvard and state officials, the court said the question of the carcinogenic effect of particulate matter - as distinct from respiratory effects - had been improperly excluded from consideration. **********''It's really not an issue,'' said Robert Scott, the director of Harvard's financial systems. The Federal Environmental Protection Agency ''considered this problem in great detail a few years ago, and chose not to establish a standard,'' he said. ''If Massachusetts decides that these emissions are a risk, there is a serious problem for American cities, for the economy and for the power production industry, because these same materials are in the exhaust of cars, trucks, and buses.'' **********But Daniel G. Partan, a Boston University law professor and chairman of a Brookline committee studying the plant, says Harvard is trying to turn the issue into a broader one to advance its own cause. ''This is a question of the exposure of large numbers of people in the Boston area,'' where diesel emissions are already high, he said.  ''The judgment reached in this case does not translate into a judgment on other diesel engines of a different output in a different location.'' **********One place where those judgments are likely in the next few years is New York, where small diesel co-generators have been suggested to provide power supplies for large buildings. Indeed, since Harvard began its project the Federal Government has created incentives to make co-generation even more attractive. **********But while co-generation may be the wave of the future in cities, diesel co-generators are not. Speaking privately, Harvard officials have been heard recently to speculate whether less efficient engines such as turbines, or alternative fuels such as gas, might save years of regulatory headaches.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/03/world.body_text: **********The Vatican radio today condemned the phenomenon of test-tube babies, saying that scientists had ventured into the realm of immorality. **********Reporting on a recent condemnation of the practice by the Roman Catholic bishops of Australia, the radio said: ''From both the moral and social point of view, it is unacceptable that human embryos are taken from their natural place to become frozen or destroyed.'' **********''The desire to have children is deeply human and the efforts to find scientific means to satisfy this desire are admirable,'' the radio said, referring to the decision of the Australian bishops.  ''But they felt an obligation to conclude that test-tube fertilization is unacceptable.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/26/world.main_headline: SOCIALISTS WIN A BIG MAJORITY OF MAYORAL RACES IN GREECE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/26/world.print_headline: SOCIALISTS WIN A BIG MAJORITY OF MAYORAL RACES IN GREECE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/26/world.body_text: **********Greece's governing Socialist Party has elected mayors in the overwhelming majority of cities and towns around the country, according to final results of municipal elections made public today. **********The Greek Communist Party, however, claimed to have played a ''decisive'' role in the Socialist victory and emerged from the elections in second place, edging out the conservative New Democracy Party in the number of mayors elected. **********Socialist candidates won 173 mayoral posts out of a total of 276, against 45 for the Communists, 44 for New Democracy and 14 for independents. **********This was a major gain for the Socialists and the Communists and a serious loss for New Democracy. In the last municipal elections in 1978, New Democracy elected 150 mayors against 70 for the Socialists and 33 for the Communists. Two Parties in Electoral Pacts **********Final returns were not in today for the nearly 6,000 smaller communities where voting was held, but the Socialists were believed to have won in most of them because they had worked out local electoral pacts with the Communists in many cases. **********The big tally for the Socialists followed gains they made in last year's parliamentary election, when Andreas Papandreou's Panhellenic Socialist Movement was swept into power with 48 percent of the national vote. **********In the first round of voting in the municipal elections, held on Oct. 17, the Socialists were well ahead of their rivals but fell 10 to 12 percentage points below their popular vote last year in the main urban areas. This was seen as a natural erosion after a year in government. **********In Sunday's runoff voting, the Socialists came out with a clear victory, helped by Communist support in races where there was no Communist candidate. **********Socialist candidates, with Communist backing, won over New Democracy rivals in the key cities of Athens, Piraeus and Salonika, while Communist candidates, with right-wing support, defeated Socialists in Patras and Larissa and in Canea in Crete. Voting Age Lowered **********The relatively strong Communist showing was attributed in part to a certain amount of dissatisfaction among leftists with the Socialist Government, but also in part to the eligibility of half a million new voters following a change in the voting age from 20 to 18. **********It was also clear that in municipalities where Communist and Socialist candidates competed in the runoff, the conservatives generally voted Communist. **********''We're afraid of the Socialists' concentration of power,'' one New Democracy voter explained.  In a statement last night, Prime Minister Papandreou hailed the Socialist victory, calling it ''a strong confirmation of the people's confidence in the work of the Government for change.'' **********On the other hand, Evangelos Averoff-Tossizza, the New Democracy leader, said that a large number of Socialist mayors had been elected with Communist support. He declared it was ''particularly troubling'' to note that the Communists had increased in strength perceptibly under the Socialist Government.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/01/busin.print_headline: TUNISIA STRUGGL ES TO DEVELOP FISHING
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/01/busin.body_text: **********Increased poaching by Italian fishing boats, the authorities here complain, is undermining Tunisia's efforts to develop its fishing industry. **********There have been numerous incidents. In November, a Tunisian coast guard vessel seized a Sicilian boat on charges of illegally fishing in Tunisian territorial waters. The vessel, the 199-ton Maria Bernadette, had been seized earlier in the year on the same charge, and was released only after Italy paid a $100,000 fine. **********Shortly after the second arrest of the Maria Bernadette, Algeria announced that it had seized a Sicilian fishing trawler, the Michele Asaro, because the vessel had been found fishing less than 15 miles from the Algerian port of Bone. Western diplomats in Tunis say that Algeria at one time was holding five Sicilian trawlers, Tunisia at least a dozen and Libya three. **********The Tunisian fishing fleet, based in small ports like Bizerte, Sfax, Mahdia and Sousse, currently takes in close to 100,000 tons of fish annually. The World Bank says that with a more modern fishing fleet, Tunisia could quadruple the catch. Plans for Diversification **********Eager to expand and to diversify into areas such as canning, Tunisia recently signed agreements with several Japanese shipping companies to buy new trawlers. The Japanese Government is also sending fishing technicians and experts to map fertile fishing areas. **********The authorities in this Mediterranean port say that nearly all of the boats they have seized, as well as the vessels captured by Algeria and Libya, were registered in Mazara del Vallo, in southwestern Sicily. **********The seizures have prompted a fresh flurry of diplomatic activity, with Italian officials traveling to Tunis, Tripoli and Algiers to negotiate the release of the vessels. As a result of diplomatic efforts by Italy, Tunisia released 12 Italian boats in June after receiving $700,000 in fines. **********Senior Western diplomats in Tunis say that the fishing war in the Mediterranean dates back two decades. But the situation has worsened in the past two years as catches have become poorer because of spreading pollution, which has forced Sicily's 15,000 trawlers to range farther from their bases. The Mediterranean, according to environmentalists in Tunis and Rome, is becoming less fecund for fishing as enormous amounts of effluence from France, Italy and Greece are discharged into it each day. Territorial Waters Disputed **********The controversy appears to be exacerbated by questions about territorial waters. The generally accepted limit is 200 miles from the shores of a country. Italy has sovereignty over numerous small Mediterranean islands such as Pantelleria, and some Sicilian captains have reportedly argued that the 200-mile limit extends from the shores of these islands. **********Some Western environmentalists and fisheries experts say that o nly sardines can be found near shore in large quantities, while mackerel,tuna and othe r fish must be sought in deeper waters. **********In Bizerte a local fisherman, Moncef Habibe, pointed out to sea, where local boats dotted the horizon. ''Sometimes we see Sicilian boats,'' he said. ''The boats come right up to our boats, and their people even laugh at us and say, 'What can you Tunisians do, eh?' '' **********Tunisia has a shortage of vessels to patrol its waters. The navy has one frigate, four large patrol craft and ten coastal patrol boats, according to the International Institute for Strategic Studies in London. Restraint in Libyan Waters **********''What is happening is that the Sicilian boats come and grab our fish, thus depriving Tunisian fleets of what should rightfully be their catch,'' said Ahmad Chamkhi, a fishing entrepreneur in Mahdia.  ''Sadly, Tunisia's navy doesn't have enough boats to go about catching these people who intrude on our waters.'' **********The Sicilian crews seldom take such chances in Libyan waters, according to Western diplomats in Tunis.  That is because, as one European envoy put it, the Libyans ''play it rough.'' Libyan gunboats patrol the Mediterranean and Sicilian sailors have reported that Libyan crews fire warning shots frequently at their vessels. Unlike Tunisia and Algeria, which hold the Sicilian boats but generally release their crews, the Libyans usually arrest the Sicilians and put them on trial.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/06/busin.main_headline: Hood, Hope of Tulsa Wins Shakey's Account
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/06/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; Hood, Hope of Tulsa Wins Shakey's Account
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/06/busin.body_text: **********Hood, Hope & Associates, based in Tulsa, Okla., and the largest ad agency in the state, has been appointed the national agency for Shakey's, the Dallas-based fast-food chain, and will be taking over from Chiat/Day in Los Angeles. **********The agency is elated, according to Mark Owens, public relations director, because it was in competition with seven other agencies that were all from Texas, just like the client, and whipped them all. **********Shakey's, a subsidiary of Hunt International Resources, has 500 restaurants in 50 markets and pizza is the specialty. It will spend $2 million for national advertising, with the main competitor Pizza Hut, a Pepsico subsidiary that serves pasta dishes as well as pizza. **********Although it was recently reported that all of Pizza Hut's advertising is handled on a regional basis, it does indeed have a national advertising program, which has been assigned to Foote, Cone & Belding, Chicago, since 1976. It is now promoting ''panned pizza,'' sort of a deep-dish delight, as well as take-out, and is using network television. **********The company has 4,000 outlets in all 50 states and half of them are owned by franchisees. The national ad budget came from a 2 percent assessment on each unit's sales. To augment this, the new franchise agreement calls for an additional 2 percent for regional advertising. **********According to Allan Kaplan, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, company sales have reacted positively to the improved product and service and the increased advertising. ''Real sales'' were up about 2 percent last quarter. That was on top of a strong gain last year, he said, but from a fairly low base. Still, it was better than most of the industry.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/16/busin.body_text: **********The Securities and Exchange Commission has reached a settlement of a civil complaint filed in Federal District Court that charged that a former Banker's Trust Company official and two former Government lawyers used inside information to profit illegally from the attempted takeover of the Brunswick Corporation by the Whittaker Corporation. **********Without denying or admitting the S.E.C.'s allegations, the three individuals agreed to disgorge themselves of profits gained through trading of stocks and options during the attempt. **********Named in the complaint were Martin W. Cooper, former assistant vice president of Banker's Trust; James D. Hutchinson, a former Associate Deputy Attorney General with the Justice Department, and William J.  Chadwick, a former administrator with the Labor Department. **********The S.E.C agreed Wednesday to a similar agreement in a separate case involving a vice president with another of Whittaker's banks, Credit Suisse. **********Mr. Cooper agreed to pay $30,849.26, Mr. Hutchinson agreed to pay $71,910.96 and Mr. Chadwick agreed to pay $32,008.56 for the profits he gained and $25,301.93 for profits gained by a friend he advised. **********Robert Carlson, a lawyer for Mr. Cooper, would not comment. Lawyers for the other men could not be reached. A spokesman for Mr. Chadwick said he was out for the day. Mr. Hutchinson was also out of his office.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/27/busin.body_text: **********Canada has joined the European aircraftbuilding consortium, Airbus Industrie, for development and production of a short- and intermediate-range airplane, Airbus said today. **********Airbus said it had signed a memorandum of understanding with the Canadian Government associating de Havilland Aircraft with the consortium's A320 aircraft project. **********The planned A320 plane will be a two-engine, 150-seat passenger aircraft designed to replace the aging short-haul fleets of the world's airlines. **********Airbus Industrie - the world's second-biggest builder of widebodied jets after the Boeing Company - already manufactures the larger A300 and will shortly begin production of a smaller craft, the A310. **********It has become the Boeing's largest competitor for commercial aircraft.  The Canadian Government-owned de Havilland is seeking up to a 10 percent share in the A320 program, Airbus said.  Last week Canada said it would seek to become a partner in the project with an investment of about $500 million (Canadian). The Canadian dollar is worth about 79 cents in United States currency. **********Other partners in the consortium are British Aerospace, France's Aerospatiale, West Germany's MBB and Spain's Casa. Fokker of the Netherlands and Belairbus of Belgium are associate partners.
