https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/26/busin.body_text: **********Their pianos have been known for exquisite craftsmanship and quality of sound since 1853, and change, when it has come, has tended to be orderly, precise - and quiet. Thus, when CBS Inc. announced last week that Peter M. Perez, the respected president of its Steinway & Sons unit, had resigned ''to pursue personal interests,'' the news of the thinly disguised ouster struck like a discordant note. **********''I don't think Peter Perez had an enemy in the musical business,'' said John Browning, a prominent American pianist. ''It looks like a strong-arm type of thing to me.'' **********In a sparsely worded release issued last week, CBS, Steinway's corporate parent since 1972, stated only that Mr. Perez had left to direct his family's business and investment holdings. CBS named as his replacement 40-year-old Lloyd W. Meyer, who most recently had been president of Gulbransen Industries, the organ maker, which is also part of the CBS family. Clarification Refused **********John McLaren, the president of CBS's musical instruments group, would not be pinned down on his reasons for switching presidents, other than to insist that they were sound ones and for the good of Steinway. **********For his part, Mr. Perez said in a recent interview, CBS is being less than truthful. He is not devoting full time to any family business, he contends, because he owns only a few stocks. In any event, he insists, he did not leave of his own accord. Mr. Perez says that Mr. McLaren handed him a letter of resignation to sign and made it clear that the only option available was to be dismissed. **********While that scenario still begs the question of 'Why?', other Steinway sources, who requested anonymity, said that Mr. Perez was given four reasons for being replaced: he did not nurture a good working relationship with the Steinway family, especially Henry Steinway, the piano maker's former chairman who now acts as a consultant; he was a ''publicity hound''; he failed to improve product quality, and he was ''born with a silver spoon in his mouth.'' Consolidation Strategy Cited **********Mr. Perez, however, maintains that other - more significant - factors led to his discharge. He suspects, he said, that his removal is part of a strategy to resuscitate the troubled Gulbransen unit.  Whereas Steinway has been making money, Gulbransen has not been doing well. In order to breathe new life into Gulbransen, Mr. Perez says, CBS intends to combine certain aspects of the two. **********''I think this violates our time-honored mission of directing all our time to building the best piano,'' protested Mr. Perez, a polite, soft-spoken man of 42, in an interview from his home in Connecticut. **********''I think I see CBS trying to capitalize on the Steinway name with this very ill-suited marriage with Gulbransen organs. Yes, they're both keyboard, yes they're in the music business, but they're very dissimilar products. It just doesn't make sense.'' No Link, CBS Says **********Mr. McLaren contends that no marriage between the two units is in the works, although he confirmed that Gulbransen's headquarters in Deerfield, Ill., is scheduled to be closed in favor of unspecified smaller quarters. According to Mr. McLaren, Gulbransen's fortunes have nothing to do with Mr. Perez's departure. **********Mr. Perez, who is away job-hunting this week, said he feared most that the peerless quality of the Steinway pianos might ultimately erode, especially if CBS decides to have Mr. Meyer preside over both companies, a decision it has not yet made. Mr. Perez was known for putting in long days at the Steinway offices and factory in the Long Island City section of Queens. **********Indeed, the quality of Steinways had already come in for some criticism in recent years. Materials do not match past quality. Fewer good technicians are available. Nobody has been saying that anyone else makes a piano better than Steinway, but some have grumbled out loud that Steinways do not seem to be up to snuff anymore. Quality Is Debated **********Periodic debates have also flared over whether the Steinways coming out of the American factory were equal to those emerging from the company's plant in Hamburg, West Germany. **********During Mr. Perez's three-and-a-half-year tenure, though, many in the concert business feel that important strides have been in upgrading the Steinway line. CBS, for its part, has been generous in channeling cash into the concern. **********''I'm just terribly afraid that this decision is one that's leading us down a very slippery path,'' said a Steinway employee who asked not to be identified. **********According to Mr. Perez, Steinway in 1981 had its best year since 1941, garnering more than $7 million in pretax profit on sales of more than $50 million. On the other hand, he says, Gulbransen lost some $5.5 million on $7.5 million in sales. ''That's not too easy a trick,'' he said. CBS would not comment on the results of either company. Chairman Remains Silent **********John Steinway, Steinway's chairman and the great-grandson of the piano maker's founder, chose to remain silent on the management change when reached in London, where he was attending a weekend performance by Vladimir Horowitz. **********A number of Steinway dealers responded with bewilderment and unease to the top-level shift.  ''I think at first we were all ready to cut our wrists and bleed all over the place,'' said Skip Daynes, the head of Daynes Music Company in Salt Lake City, which has been a Steinway dealer for 120 years. ''Peter Perez is one of the best piano men I've ever met.'' **********''I'm shocked to death,'' said Bill Mattlin, the president of Mattlin-Hyde Pianos in Cleveland. ''I thought the world of Peter Perez.'' **********''The product has been better than ever under Peter Perez,'' added another dealer. ''As far as I knew, he was doing a good job.'' Similar dismay was voiced by some Steinway artists.  Mr. McLaren, for his part, said he believes that the tempest will soon subside. He has chatted with the top 25 or 30 Steinway dealers and anticipates no strains in their relationship, he said. ''There's no individual whose presence or absence rocks that relationship,'' he said. **********Amid all this, Mr. Perez says he cares most about the fate of the piano. ''I pray the quality won't decline,'' he said. ''I just see a dilution of effort when you're not thinking every minute of every day of making it a little bit better.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/04/world.body_text: **********Wild camels, which are considered on the verge of extinction, have been found in northwest China, the official New China News Agency reported today. The camels, a taller, thinner ancestor of the domesticated two-hump camel, were found in Dunhuang county in Gansu Province and in the northeastern part of the Xinjiang Uygur region during a survey last summer and fall, the agency said. It did not say how many were seen.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/28/busin.body_text: **********The Burroughs Corporation said it would sell a new entry-level computer system of smaller size and higher performance in its mediumto large-scale computer line. **********The company said production of the B-5920 had begun at its Mission Viejo, Calif., plant and deliveries would start in the fourth quarter. **********Prices will start at $180,000, it said. **********The B-5920 offers 3.1 million bytes of integrated circuit main memory and can be used as a stand-alone system or as a remote part of a distributed processing network, the company said. **********In a separate announcement, the Memorex Corporation subsidiary of Burroughs introduced the 3260 series magnetic tape subsystems for its Galaxy package. The company said the new tape subsytem uses large-scale integrated electronic components to reduce space requirements, and is fully compatible with the I.B.M. 3803/ 3402 tape drive subsystem.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/14/world.body_text: **********Seven people were killed in a severe storm that pounded Jordan's capital for six hours. Authorities said today that at least 12 others were seriously injured or missing in the storm Wednesday. https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/27/world.body_text: **********Following is the text of the resolution approved unanimously today by the Security Council: **********THE SECURITY COUNCIL, REAFFIRMING its Resolution 502 (1982) of 3 April 1982, NOTING with the deepest concern that the situation in the region of the Falkland Islands (Islas Malvinas) has seriously deteriorated, HAVING HEARD the statement made by the Secretary General to the Security Council at its 2,360th meeting on 21 May 1982, as well as the statements in the debate of the representatives of Argentina and of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, **********CONCERNED to achieve as a matter of the greatest urgency a cessation of hostilities and an end to the present conflict between the armed forces of Argentina and of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, **********1. EXPRESSES appreciation to the Secretary General for the efforts which he has already made to bring about an agreement between the parties, to insure the implementation of Security Council Resolution 502 (1982), and thereby to restore peace to the region; **********2. REQUESTS the Secretary General, on the basis of the present resolution, to undertake a renewed mission of good offices bearing in mind Security Council Resolution 502 (1982) and the approach outlined in his statement of 21 May 1982; **********3. URGES the parties to the conflict to cooperate fully with the Secretary General in his mission with a view to ending the present hostilities in and around the Falkland Islands (Islas Malvinas); **********4. **********REQUESTS the Secretary General to enter into contact immediately with the parties with a view to negotiating mutually acceptable terms for a cease-fire, including, if necessary, arrangements for the dispatch of United Nations observers to monitor compliance with the terms of the cease-fire; **********5. REQUESTS the Secretary General to submit an interim report to the Security Council as soon as possible and in any case not later than seven days after the adoption of this resolution.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/19/busin.body_text: **********ASK people about the National Geographic Society, and the usual t opics come up. The yellow-bordered magazine with the fancy p hotographs. Maps. Coffee-table books. Television specials on g orillas or gems or some such thing. **********Then ask George E. Moffat, director of advertising for National Geographic magazine. He talks about something quite different. He talks about trouble. **********''We've had one of our roughest years ever,'' said Mr. Moffat. ''If things aren't turned around, you'll talk to someone else if you call here next year.'' At the magazine, which generates more than 60 percent of the society's gross income, advertising revenues fell 30 percent in 1982, to about $22 million. Mr. Moffat said the recession had scared off advertisers. **********And the bad news for the society does not end there: *********** The magazine's circulation dropped in 1982, the first year that had happened since the Depression. Though the decline was comparatively slight, 250,000 out of a total circulation of 10.7 million, it nonetheless worries top brass at the society. *********** Only 84 percent of the society's members renew their memberships these days, down from a renewal rate of more than 90 percent in the 1970's. *********** The society's membership fee, which includes a subscription to the magazine, was recently raised to $15 a year, from $13.50. That marks the third increase in three years, and some staff members expect it might lead to a further drop in renewals. **********Yet with nearly $290 million in assets - including some of the priciest real estate in Washington, its home town - the 94-year-old society remains one of the richest nonprofit groups in the country.  Officials say those assets insure the society's long-term health. **********And whatever the current trouble, Gilbert M. Grosvenor, the society's president, said he remained optimistic. Mr. Grosvenor, 51 years old and the fifth member of his family to lead the society, said that, after a ''very dismal'' period caused by the stagnant economy earlier this year, ''we're doing O.K. now.'' Unless the economy further deteriorates, he said, ''1983 will be a good year for us,'' due largely to major retrenchment. **********In 1981, the society had overall revenues of $272 million.  Membership dues accounted for $134 million. Scientific research grants took $2.5 million. Income of $13 million from the society's investments helped offset a $9 million operating loss on the magazine. The society is in good enough shape that it will pay for its new $30 million Washington headquarters in cash. **********Many financial analysts who follow the publishing ventures of the society said the society's future is secure, as long as it overcomes its current membership and advertising difficulties. Even competitors admit they share the optimistic forecast. **********''Sure, the Geographic may be having problems,'' said Don Moser, editor of Smithsonian magazine, a glossy history-and-science journal published by the Smithsonian Institution (circulation 2 million).  ''But I doubt the problems are very serious. There are a million ways they could cut costs if it were necessary.'' **********To an extent, it already has beennecessary. Mr. Grosvenor said belt-tightening at the society would continue. A hiring freeze was imposed. Accounting procedures were redesigned. To the chagrin of staff members who had grown accustomed to prime rib at 30,000 feet, workers have been barred from first-class air travel. ''Me included,'' said Mr. Grosvenor. By slicing travel costs, the society saved $1 million in 1982. **********But cost-cutting has been coupled with a bid to raise revenues.  The society is hoping, for example, that a new high-demographic edition of the Geographic, will bring in new advertising dollars. **********Set to make its debut next month, the new edition has been informally dubbed Big G. It will carry the same editorial material that appears in the larger-circulation national edition but boast cheaper ad rates and a more selective audience: readers in 36 of the nation's most affluent metropolitan areas. **********The average Big G reader, according to the society, will have a median household income of $30,900, versus $28,800 for the national edition. Financial analysts say that difference can mean a lot to Madison Avenue. **********John S. Reidy, who follows the publishing industry for Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., said Big G could entice new advertisers, including some who had long wished to reach only the Geographic's wealthier readers. ''I have confidence,'' he said. PERHAPS more important, the new edition might also win back a dvertisers who, because of the recession, were frightened away by t he eyepopping cost of ads appearing in the full run of the m agazine. (National Geographic's drop in advertising revenue this y ear wasn't typical of the industry. According to the Magazine P ublishers Association, major consumer magazines posted a 5 percent a d-revenue rise for the first 11 months of the year over the same p eriod in 1981.) A one-page color ad in the magazine's full run costs$ 117,100, compared with $54,000 in Big G and $33,400 in Smithsonian. T he society is planning to start other editions aimed at special d emographic groups. **********These efforts are directed more to advertisers than readers. After two generations of circulation growth for National Geographic - circulation rose 50 percent in the last decade -the society seems more concerned about having a stable number of readers than in expansion. ''I think there's an ideal circulation for every magazine,'' Mr. Grosvenor said. ''It's entirely possible that at a circulation of between 10 million and 11 million, growth would stop for us.'' He said, however, the society does not intend to watch the numbers fall any further. **********The society is changing in other ways. The magazine's coverage has been broadened and its graphic design brightened. The cover of the October issue, for example, highlighted an article on silicon chips.  Some readers found the story a far cry from the magazine's traditional fare of animal and country profiles. **********The society has begun experimenting with new fund-raising techniques. It has shifted much of its promotional budget for membership from a direct-mail campaign to television commercials.  Television has worked well, the society reports, in finding new subscribers for World, its seven-year-old magazine for children. **********Mr. Grosvenor said the society's future would be largely electronic. Within five years, he said, National Geographic articles and collections of some of the five million photographs in the society's archives could be available on laser disks for use in homes and schools, creating new, potentially large revenues.The society is also looking into television.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/29/busin.body_text: **********Massey-Ferguson Ltd., the financially troubled farm-implement maker based in Toronto, reported yesterday that its loss more than tripled in the second fiscal quarter, ended April 30, to $25.7 million, from $8 million a year earlier. **********The loss came on a 23 percent decline in sales, to $558 million, from $720.7 million in the 1981 quarter. The company states its results in United States dollars. **********For the six months, the company said, its loss widened to $99.2 million from $89.4 million in the first two quarters of 1981. The results came on a 16.8 percent decline in sales, to $1.04 billion, from $1.25 billion in 1981. Chairman Is 'Encouraged' **********Nonetheless, Victor A. Rice, chairman and chief executive officer, said he was ''encouraged'' because the company had managed to reduce inventories, operating costs and administrative expenses. **********However, with no improvement expected in farm equipment sales, he added, the company's tractor plants in the United States would remain closed until the autumn and a curtailed production schedule would be continued at its Canadian combine plant. **********On Thursday, the company's directors omitted the monthly dividends on preferred stock. This step gives banks and some other institutional holders of about $200 million series D preferred shares the right to exercise options for guarantees provided by the governments of Britain, Canada and the province of Ontario under terms of a $715 million refinancing plan worked out last July. Volkswagenwerk **********Volkswagenwerk, the big West German auto maker, said yesterday that first-quarter net income increased 27.9 percent, to the equivalent of about $23.4 million at current exchange rates, from about $18.3 million a year earlier. **********The company said from its headquarters in Wolfsburg that sales had increased 8.9 percent, to the equivalent of $4.3 billion, from $3.95 billion in the first quarter of 1981. **********---- Nissan Motor **********TOKYO, May 28 (AP) - The Nissan Motor Company, Japan's second-largest automobile maker, said today that its net income for the fiscal year 1981 edged up two-tenths of 1 percent, to $354 million, from $353.3 million a year earlier. **********The latest profit increase for the maker of Datsun vehicles, though slight, represented an improvement from a 1.8 percent drop in the fiscal year 1980 from the previous year. **********Sales in the latest year rose 6.1 percent, to a record $13.2 billion, from $12.44 billion in the fiscal year 1980, the company said. ---- Earnings tables, page 44.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/21/busin.body_text: **********Charles J. McMullin, 32, has been appointed president of Scientific Inc., a solid- and liquid-waste collection and disposal company based in Scotch Plains, N.J. He succeeds Marvin H. Mahan, 61, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer. **********Mr. McMullin said that he would focus on ''compliance, compliance, compliance.'' **********He continued: ''We cannot take one step forward until we are satisfied that we are resolving the environmental problems.  There is no such thing as a dollar in profitability if you do not have compliance. This industry is basically a collection of people who are responding to a need.'' **********Before joining Scientific as a vice president in 1979, Mr. McMullin had been associated with the Department of Solid Waste Management in Middlesex County, N.J. From 1975 to 1977, he was a group manager for PQA Associates, an engineering concern. **********Mr. Mahan founded Scientific in 1965 and has been chairman and chief executive since then. He added the title of president in 1978.  According to Mr. McMullin: ''a byproduct of solid waste composition is methane gas. Now, this energy is being sold to utilities at a much greater price than they were willing to pay before. We also expect to have something going this year on conversion of solid waste to steam or electricity.'' Leonard Sloane

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/21/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Guatemala Would Meet Kidnappers' Demand
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/21/world.body_text: **********The Guatemalan Government said today it would allow relatives of the kidnapped daughter of the Honduran President, Roberto Suazo Cordova, to publish a rebel propaganda statement if the woman was released first. **********Dr. Judith Xiomara Suazo Estrada, 33 years old, was kidnapped last Tuesday while on her way to work at a hospital here. **********She is President Suazo Cordova's daughter by his first marriage and has been living in Guatemala City. **********A statement by President Efrain Rios Montt said the Government would allow the publication of a propaganda statement received from the ''terrorists'' holding Dr. Suazo Estrada if the kidnappers released her first. **********Publication of the rebel statement was the kidnappers' only demand. The Guatamemalan presidential communique said Dr. Suazo Estrada's family and the Government had received copies of the rebels' statement, but gave no details. **********Guatemala has forbidden the publication of any statements by leftist groups without previous Government approval.  Maria Luisa Perez Rivera, Dr. Suazo Estrada's aunt, said in an interview here that her niece suffered from an ulcer and asthma and required medicine and a strictly controlled diet.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/11/busin.print_headline: MARKET PLACE; RECOUPING ON AN OPTION
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/11/busin.body_text: **********WHEN a call option is about to die, sell it twice. Then buy a new option on the same stock. Anyone who does that believes the shares underlying the call are going to stop going down and rally strongly. **********The customer - or speculator - is using a so-called bull spread. It is designed to reduce risk while offering the hope of above average rates of return. When used in connection with a dying option, it can help an individual reduce or recapture the original cost and even provide a limited profit. **********A call option gives the holder the right to buy 100 shares of the underlying stock at a preset exercise price. The basic strategy is to exercise the call when the actual price is substantially higher. In this bear market most call options have been unsuccessful. That's because current stock prices are well below most exercise prices. **********Thus, one broker is urging customers to use a spread to recoup.  Look, for example, at the recent action in Bally Manufacturing. The stock has dropped 5 points in the last two months. Those who bought calls on Bally before that drop are threatened with option losses. **********Consider a speculator who bought the Bally November 35 call option. Say that speculator paid $200 - 2 points - in May for each of 10 of those calls, or $2,000. At the time, Bally sold at 32. The option holder clearly expected a rally in Bally. Instead the shares dropped to 27. **********For the speculator to profit, Bally would have to move higher than 37 by the expiration on Nov. 20. That's because the speculator must get back the 2-point cost, only possible at the expiration if the stock is at 37, 2 points above the striking price of 35. There are also transaction costs of about $100. **********Will Bally reach 37-plus by mid-November? It seems unlikely, since that price would represent a gain of more than 37 percent in a short time. **********Should the speculator give up? Some who believe the bear market has far to go would say yes. But not Arthur Kaufman, who urges Shearson/ American Express clients who still like their stocks to ''repair'' failing option positions. **********Mr. Kaufman, who is Shearson's vice president in charge of option marketing, obviously has an ax to grind. He acknowledged that these repairs sometimes cost money, saying: ''The speculator has an opportunity to lower his breakeven point -in this case from 37 to 32. But he limits his up-side potential and pays more commissions.'' **********What the speculator does is sell the 10 calls he or she owns along with 10 identical calls that he or she does not own. The price: about 3/4, or $75, a call. That is, the customer would receive $1,500 for the 20 calls. To avoid being short the second lot he or she uses all $1,500 to buy 10 November calls with an exercise price of 30. Bally is more likely to reach 30 than 35, so these calls cost more - 1 1/2. **********Commission costs would amount to about $200 for the 30 options involved. ''The resulting position is called a bull spread,'' Mr.  Kaufman said. **********The speculator now owns 10 calls with an exercise price of 30 and is short 10 calls at an exercise price of 35. The speculator has not eliminated the 2-point deficit experienced in establishing the original call position. Thus, Bally must reach 32 in order for the speculator to break even. **********That is, if Bally does reach 32 the calls at 30 would be trading at 2, and each of the 10 would be worth $200 - $2,000 for the lot. The calls at 35 the speculator is short would be worthless and there would be no obligation there. In the event of a bull market, the 10 short calls would be covered by the 10 calls the speculator owned. So a vigorous rally in Bally would limit profits on the long calls but the risk on the short calls would be eliminated. **********To wit, let's assume that Bally experiences a major rally, moving substantially higher than 37. The speculator would be asked to deliver 1,000 shares of stock at 35. But the speculator has the right to buy 1,000 shares at 30. There is a difference of 5 points less 2 points - $5,000 less the $2,000 paid for the initial call - $3,000 in profit. **********That would be true whether Bally reached 40 or 50 or really hit the jackpot. Obviously, had Bally reached 50, for example, the unhedged speculator who rode out the storm with the original November 35 calls would have made a killing, specifically 15 points minus the 2 points cost, or $13,000. **********But the unhedged speculator would be more likely to lose the $2,000 original cost and would lose it all if the stock was 35 or less at expiration. **********Mr. Kaufman noted that the risk of establishing the spread is increased by $200 - the additional transaction costs. If Bally closes at any price under $30 all options in this example - both the long and the short expire worthless - and the customer's total costs represent commissions plus the $2,000 paid for the initial 10 call options -''which he would have lost anyway,'' he said. **********''I would emphasize that the objective in using this strategy is to increase the chance of breaking even with the possibility of making a modest profit,'' Mr. Kaufman said. He added that the strategy would, of course, be applicable to losing positions in many other stocks with call options.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/29/busin.print_headline: MGM UA AND WARNER ENDS TALKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/29/busin.body_text: **********Warner Communications said today that it had terminated discussions aimed at acquiring the United Artists music company and Warner Bros. pre-1950 film library from MGM/UA, an unexpected decision that casts a long shadow over MGM/UA's efforts to resolve its financial problems. **********MGM/UA, which carries bank debt totaling $670 million, would have received approximately $95 million from the sale. According to Frank E. Rosenfelt, MGM/UA vice chairman, the negotiations fell apart because of dozens of unresolved points, rather than one main problem. **********Earlier this month, a lending consortium led by Bank of America extended a $525 million line of credit to MGM/UA under a debt restructuring plan. At that time, Ralph Kuhns, vice president for entertainment company loans at Bank of America, said the sale to Warner Communications would ''make a big dent'' in MGM/ UA's debt, reducing the company's annual interest payments of more than $100 million by approximately $17 million. **********Mr. Kuhns refused to comment on the collapse of negotiations today, as did Warner Bros.  Mr. Rosenfelt said, however, that the bank agreement was not contingent on closing the Warner's deal. ''We won't have the slightest difficulty selling either the music company or the classic Warner Bros. film library,'' he added. Problems Began a Year Ago **********MGM/UA's financial problems began in May 1981, when the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Film Company purchased United Artists from Transamerica for $380 million. The majority stockholder of M-G-M, Kirk Kerkorian, bought United Artists to give M-G-M the capacity to distribute its own movies and an extensive library of old films. **********The stock market decline and persistent high interest rates almost immediately put MGM/UA into a cash bind from which the company has not managed to escape. **********While the breakdown of talks with Warner's was a setback for MGM/ UA, the company did receive some good news on its suit against the Transamerica Corporation: Transamerica agreed to pay MGM/UA approximately $40 million to settle the dispute. **********Under the terms of the settlement, Transamerica will pass to MGM/UA the tax savings realized by Transa@merica in 1981 before the sale of United Artists and will accelerate the payment to MGM/UA of related interest owed to United Artists.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/18/world.main_headline: P.L.O. OFFICIAL IN ROME DIES IN A CAR-BOMB BLAST
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/18/world.print_headline: P.L.O. OFFICIAL IN ROME DIES IN A CAR-BOMB BLAST
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/18/world.body_text: **********A Rome-based official of the Palestine Liberation Organization was killed in a car-bomb explosion today, and an anonymous telephone caller claiming to represent the ''Jewish Armed Resistance'' later took responsibility. **********The same caller also said the group was responsible for the slaying Wednesday night of a Palestinian medical student here. **********Kamal Hussein, the 33-year-old deputy director of the P.L.O.'s Rome office, was killed by ''an extremely powerful, sophisticated'' bomb planted under the seat of his car and connected to its ignition system, the police said. **********On Wednesday night, gunmen in a moving car fired at least 20 bullets into the Palestinian student, Nazeh Matar, 32, on a street near his home. Witnesses told police that after Mr. Matar went down, the car stopped and one of the terrorists fired directly into his head. Mr. Matar also worked as a correspondent for a newspaper in Kuwait. **********A bystander, Anna Maria Carelli, 36, was wounded in the blast that killed Mr. Hussein. She was reported in stable condition in a Rome hospital. **********Shortly after the blast, a man who said he represented ''The Jewish Armed Resistance of the Jewish Defense League'' called the New York office of The Associated Press and said his group was responsible for both killings. **********The caller made a short statement saying that the killings were timed to coincide with the invasion of Lebanon by the Israeli Government of Prime Minister Menachem Begin. **********The J.D.L.'s national chairman in New York, Meir Jolovitz, denied that the Jewish Armed Resistance was a J.D.L. splinter group.  ''However, we have had and continue to have contact with groups in Europe who agree with our policy of measure for measure and terror for terror,'' Mr. Jolovitz said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/13/world.main_headline: EGYPTIAN MOSLEMS MARK RAMADAN DESPITE CRISIS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/13/world.print_headline: EGYPTIAN MOSLEMS MARK RAMADAN DESPITE CRISIS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/13/world.body_text: **********A cannon's boom has resounded here on recent evenings, touching off much joy, for the sound is part of the rhythm of Ramadan, the Moslem holy month, now in its 16th day. **********By day, as Islam dictates, Cairo's faithful have been fasting. By night, after the evening cannon fire, they have been eating and shopping. **********Ramadan is observed by the great majority of Cairo's more than 10 million people, and many of them have been shopping for holiday clothes and presents in addition to food. The shopping has been a bonanza for merchants, though not for those businessmen dependent on imports from Lebanon. **********That trade, said Zohair Hamdan, a Lebanese diplomat here, ''has been completely paralyzed'' by the Beirut crisis. Hasn't Dampened Festivities **********But the repercussions of the crisis have not dampened Cairenes' Ramadan festivities, said Dr. Munir Abdelmagid, a dentist, ''because this feast is part of their religion.'' **********And yet, other Cairenes say, past Ramadans have been affected by Middle East convulsions that were closer at hand. Because of the lunar calendar, the annual Ramadan holy month is celebrated at various times of the year. **********The Ramadan festivities in 1973 were made more joyous, they report, by elation over the Arab-Israeli war in October, which was seen here as a great victory. But in 1967 Ramadan festivities were dampened by anguish over Egypt's defeat in the war with Israel that year. **********The fasting resumes daily at first light and goes on all through the blazing African summer days. Drinking liquids and smoking are forbidden along with eating until evening begins and, as the Koran specifies, it becomes too dark to tell a white thread from a black one. **********Then the cannon booms from its emplacement on the city's southeastern outskirts, and Cairenes break their fast with a meal known in Arabic as ''iftar.'' **********Later many people go shopping, largely to get ready for Bairam, the three-day feast at the end of Ramadan. They buy new clothes for their children or material to make clothes with, and they stock up on sweets. Economic Life Is Normal **********While the religious and commercial pulse of life has been normal, so have the specific rhythms of Egypt's economy.  Traffic through the Suez Canal has been proceeding as usual during the Lebanese crisis, a canal executive says.  The exchange rates that street money-changers give for the Egyptian pound have fluctuated only slightly, if at all, since Israel invaded Lebanon on June 6. **********This spring, however, the rates dipped markedly for a time when Egypt regained the last slice of the Sinai Peninsula from Israel.  The dip, economists say, was caused partly by a widespread fear that further Egyptian-Israeli peace moves might be in doubt. **********There have been small-scale power outages in recent days, with the brilliant Ramadan street lighting said to be one cause. Another, it is said, was the heavy use of television sets to watch the World Cup soccer matches being held in Spain.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/23/world.main_headline: Turkish Climber Reports No Trace of an Ark
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/23/world.print_headline: Turkish Climber Reports No Trace of an Ark
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/23/world.body_text: **********Two American members of a Protestant fundamentalist expedition to Mt. Ararat managed to reach the summit but failed to find any trace of Noah's Ark, a Turkish military officer who accompanied them said today. **********The expedition of 12 Americans, led by a former astronaut, James Irwin, ended last week when Mr. Irwin hurt himself in a fall while approaching the summit of the 16,946-foot peak, Turkey's highest. **********Mr. Irwin was flown to the Fevzi Cakmak Hospital in Erzurum, 445 miles east of Ankara, where an official said today that he was ''recovering quite fast and was able to walk to the Turkish bath in the city Sunday.'' **********The expedition, which was sponsored by a group in Colorado Springs, Colo., had hoped to find evidence that Noah's Ark settled on the northern slope of Mt. Ararat. **********A member of the Turkish military excort, First. Lieut. Orhan Baser, said that Richard D. Bass Jr., of Dallas, and John M. Bradley Jr., of Birmingham, Ala., reached the top. **********In a telephone interview, Lieutenant Baser said the Americans found no evidence of the ark.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/17/world.print_headline: BRITISH ATTACK: 'TWERE WELL IT WERE DONE QUICKLY'; Military Analysis
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/17/world.body_text: **********The military arguments for prompt British landings in the Falkland Islands are multiplying.  Supporting the argument, military analysts said, are the evident dangers to the British task force in continuing the blockade in the face of numerically superior Argentine air power and three unlocated submarines. Also on the side backing a landing, the analysts said, was the relative ease of Friday's commando raid on Pebble Island. **********The alternative to landings by marine commandos and paratroops in battalion strength is a series of hit-and-run raids by commandos against isolated Argentine outposts. These would serve to keep the Argentine garrisons off balance and apprehensive, but they are unlikely to have the military or political impact of the establishment ashore of two or more battalions. **********Say British Would Have Edge **********Major landings would have their own risks. But the military view here is that as long as the landings were made at some distance from the main Argentine garrisons on East Falkland Island at Stanley and Darwin, the British could consolidate their landings and be in a favorable position, backed by Harrier jet fighters and helicopter support, to rebuff Argentine counterattacks. **********Harriers carried out another attack on the Stanley airfield late Saturday. This could have been part of the softening up process preparatory to landings, or it could have been simply another effort to tighten the blockade by hitting the island's only major airfield. **********The British tactical problem is complicated by the presence on the islands of four or five mobile radar systems. Most of these are operating on East Falkland. **********When the task force sailed six weeks ago, the Royal Navy advertised its capacity to jam both radar and communictions between the islands and the mainland. Evidently, it has not been able to halt the radar transmissions. The Argentine teams, constantly on the move, pick up ships of the task force as they approach the islands and transmit the information to air and sea headquarters on the mainland.  Military Urges Landings **********This ability to pinpoint the British ships as they approach the islands is one of the reasons why British military leaders are urging the Government to permit landing operations soon. The military leaders are concerned, an official said, by the prospect that further time will be wasted in what they regard as futile talks at the United Nations. **********Another reason is that the air and sea blockade is not as tight as had been hoped. One object of the Pebble Island operation was to eliminate the airstrip on which light aircraft, based on the mainland, had been landing supplies, which were then ferried to East Falkland or dropped to the garrisons on West Falkland and at Darwin. **********British sources are confident that supply missions of this sort do not lessen the overall impact of the blockade. But they concede that garrisons running short of food and spare parts can be kept going by frequent air drops. **********One of the main distributors of supplies reaching Pebble Island was the Argentine supply ship Isla de los Estados. The British frigate Alacrity apparently sunk her with four rounds from a 4.5-millimeter gun last week. British Gathering Information **********The raid by 50 commandos on Pebble Island and reports from the 100 or more troops on the Special Boat Squadron believed to be operating on East Falkland for the last 10 days have provided the task force with a great deal of information about the size and state of readiness of the Argentine garrisons. **********But the information, although valuable, does not outweigh the difficulties that the British have faced since the outset of the operation. **********Sir Michael Beetham, head of the Royal Air Force, has been apprehensive about Britain's numerical weakness in the air since the Falkland operation began, according to an air force source. **********The 20 or more Harriers available, the source said, are not sufficient to maintain air protection of the fleet and simultaneously support a landing. Landings can be made, military sources are confident, but the troops ashore would then be vulnerable to air attack from the Argentine mainland. **********British planners point out that the most successful Argentine attack - the disabling of the destroyer Sheffield -was carried out by Argentine aircraft flying from mainland bases. **********They balance this with British successes against the Argentine surveillance ship Narval and the bombing of airfields and installations in Stanley and Goose Green. They add that the Super Etendard fighter bombers aboard Argentina's only carrier have played no role in the fighting. Next 5 Days Called Critical **********As far as could be learned from qualified sources, the British Chiefs of Staff have told the Government for the last week that conditions for a landing will be better in the next five days than they are likely to be until winter storms abate. **********The ground has been prepared by the attacks on Stanley, by the accumulation of detailed intelligence about the location, morale and state of armament of the garrison and by the addition of the transport ship Canberra, with about 2,500 troops aboard, to the task force. To allow the Canberra and later the Queen Elizabeth 2, carrying the Fifth Brigade, to loiter off the Falklands in defiance of the threat of Argentine aircraft and submarines is to ''invite trouble,'' a senior naval officer said. **********The view in senior military quarters is that a blockade, no matter how tight, is unlikely to force an Argentine surrender.  Options other than major landings do not commend themselves to the army or the navy. One obvious option is ''littoral warfare,'' enshrined in British military doctrine since the Napoleonic wars. But warfare of this type involving repeated air- or seaborne landings is unlikely to be profitable or even possible as the weather deteriorates. 'Macbeth' Invoked **********Any or all such landings could involve the construction of a makeshift airstrip for use by Harriers and Sea King helicopters.  Despite the obvious dangers involved in a major landing, the Chiefs of Staff, it was learned, favor this as the most effective choice available to them with the present resources and the prevailing weather. **********One planner summed up the situation with a quotation from ''Macbeth'': ''If it were done when 'tis done, then 'twere well it were done quickly.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/26/busin.main_headline: NORCROSS STRUGGLES TO SURVIVE ITS DEBT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/26/busin.print_headline: NORCROSS STRUGGLES TO SURVIVE ITS DEBT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/26/busin.body_text: **********Norcross Greeting Cards has had four owners since its founder, Arthur Norcross, died in 1968. Now the company is close to extinction. **********First, it went to a wildlife foundation, as specified in Mr.  Norcross's will. Then it was sold to William Mannion, a Philadelphia businessman. Later he sold it to the Ziff Corporation, a New York publisher, which picked it up to augment Rust Craft Greeting Cards, a floundering Massachusetts company that Ziff had purchased primarily for its television holdings. **********Finally, the combination of Norcross and Rust Craft was acquired by Windsor Communications Inc., a privately held company. With $23 million in liabilities last August, Windsor entered into Chapter 11 proceedings under the Federal bankruptcy law and has quit producing greeting cards. **********Windsor's debts stem largely from its expensive consolidation of Norcross and Rust Craft in a field that is dominated by two giants.  ''This industry is not 1, 2, 3,'' said J. Kendrick Noble Jr., who follows the industry for Paine, Webber, Mitchell Hutchins. Composition of a Market **********Hallmark and the American Greetings Corporation together account for 75 percent of the $2 billion greeting card market. A third company, Gibson Greeting Cards, has a market share of about 10 percent. Even after Norcross and Rust Craft joined forces, they commanded only 6 or 7 percent of the market, analysts say. **********But Windsor's larger problems, industry experts suggest, probably have had more to do with a doubtful marketing strategy than with any debt financing problems. **********According to Margery Forer, president of the National Association of Greeting Card Publishers, the company's effort to produce and sell both upscale Norcross cards and mass-market Rust Craft cards did not work out. **********''You can't straddle and be successful,'' she said. ''Norcross was always associated with a particular look. After Mr. Norcross died, no one continued that look, and you didn't know what to expect. They never seemed to focus on any other styling or market.'' A Look at Windsor's Costs **********Moreover, according to an industry executive who asked not to be identified, the split marketing strategy created cost problems.  Greeting card producers can cut production costs by maximizing production runs, he said, but Windsor, by maintaining its two distinct lines, was in effect increasing its costs. **********C. Charles Smith, Windsor's chairman, takes issue with that view.  ''The cost of production really had nothing to do with our financial difficulty,'' he said. The company's troubles, he declared, derived mainly from obstacles encountered in financing its debts. **********The debts began piling up about a year ago after Windsor spent $10 million to close Rust Craft's Dedham, Mass., plant, to pay employees incentives to stay on until the closing date and to relocate the operation in West Chester, 25 miles west of Philadelphia. ''I think we did too much too soon,'' a Norcross manager said. **********One of the obstacles Mr. Smith referred to involved a dispute over an audit by Price Waterhouse that led to the accounting firm's refusal to issue financial statements. Fresh Line of Credit Lost **********The dispute apparently centered on a reversal by Price Waterhouse of accounting procedures used in the company audit. The accounting firm would not give details, but the lack of a financial statement resulted in Windsor's losing a fresh line of credit and a lowinterest loan with which it intended to purchase the building that houses its center of operations here. **********Windsor encountered another obstacle when its primary financing source, the A.J. Armstrong Company, was acquired in August 1981 by the Security Pacific Financial Corporation. Nancy V. Alquist, a Windsor lawyer, said, ''The new entity had a change in lending policy that resulted in the loss of a credit line of approximately $13 million.'' **********However, analysts suggest, Security Pacific Financial's cut in financing may also have been due to Windsor's unstable condition.  In August 1982, with its debts mounting, Windsor was asked by its creditors to file for involuntary bankruptcy under Chapter 7 of the Federal bankruptcy law. Under Chapter 7, a company is liquidated and its assets distributed among the creditors. Reorganization Procedure **********Windsor responded, however, by filing for voluntary reorganization under Chapter 11, which allows the company to continue operating either under a court-appointed trustee or with current management.  Windsor is now being managed by Mr. Smith, the chairman and one of the company's four shareholders. **********Windsor stopped producing greeting cards several weeks ago. With its current work force of 75 employees, the company is cutting back its operations and paying off its debts. **********As part of that process, the company recently sold its Canadian affiliate, Rust Craft Ltd., and roughly one-quarter of its American inventory. The sales price exceeded $2.5 million. **********Mr. Smith said Windsor had not yet presented its plan for reorganization to the bankruptcy court. Thus, he explained, he could not be specific as to hopes for the company's future. **********He did say, however, that he would like to see Windsor operate eventually at about one-third its prior revenue base of $80 million.  It could do so, he said, by using existing manufacturing and distributing plants in Joliet, Ill.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/15/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Savin Gamble On Process
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/15/busin.body_text: **********THE Savin Corporation, whose shares have been surprisingly strong this week, continued to gain ground yesterday following an announcement that Savin was negotiating to sell control to a multinational company. The shares closed the day at 10 1/4 for a twoday gain of 2 1/8. **********Savin, an innovative office copier enterprise, did not identify the other side but disclosed that, among other endeavors, the would-be buyer of its shares was in the office equipment business. Savin added that the negotiated price would probably be in the region of $9 a share. **********Completion of the deal would end Wall Street guessing as to how Savin would exploit its new liquid-process copier. Savin has been building a new plant to market the device in upstate New York and needs additional financial muscle. The company has already spent at least $40 million on the plant and may spend a similar amount in future to complete the manufacturing facility. **********Last May, Savin appeared to have found the answer when it announced a tentative agreement to combine office machine marketing efforts with the Olivetti Group of Italy, but the plan was scrapped. **********Harry Edels on of the First Boston Corporation regards Savin as a particularly attractive property for a multinational. Savin's independent d ealer network has built an impressive army of satisfied customers in the United States in recent years. But technological shortcomings have limited Savin's machines to the lower, somewhat less profitab le end of the market. **********Now Savin's so-called Landa technology may put the company in direct competition with the giants. The Landa approach was developed by an employee of that name at Israeli facilities of Savin. **********On a prototype basis, the Landa machine has produced sharper images than prior liquid-toner machines. The new system suspends the paper above the imaging drum. Unlike older liquid-toner machines, the Landa version does not soak the paper with isobars. **********Since isobars cause air pollution, Savin copier speeds have been limited to 12 to 15 copies a minute. The prototype machine produces 60 copies a minute without isobar problems. If the company can achieve similar results with production models costing $15,000 to $20,000, it could offer stiff competition to equivalent-speed Xerox and Kodak models costing $80,000 to $90,000, Savin says. **********There are a number of ifs in the situation, though. Many wonder whether Savin will prove to be a successful manufacturer, though Stanford J. Garrett, an analyst at Paine Webber Mitchell Hutchins, is impressed with the people the company has hired to run the plant as well as with the highly automated facility. **********The decision to become a manufacturer was forced on Savin under a settlement with its former manufacturer, Ricoh of Japan. Under the terms of that agreement, Ricoh was barred from the United States market for three years. The Landa technology is Savin's answer to Ricoh and other tough competitors from Japan. **********The company has said that the technology can be retrofitted to earlier models of its liquid process copiers. With a $500 million annual market, Savin is perhaps poised for major success. **********Savin's plant is nearly complete, but the company must have additional financing if it is to move into high gear. Savin's $200 million in debt represents a lofty 54 percent of capital, and $80 million is due in five years. Thus, an influx of capital seems essential. **********''This is a classic bet-the-company situation'' Mr. Garrett said in referring to Savin's decision to take on heavy debt and become a manufacturer. He believes that the company has ''oversold'' the Landa process in saying that it is as important to the busines as Xerox's first copier. **********Nevertheless, he is impressed with the retrofitting feature and believes a very large portion of the current customer base will opt for the Landa process. To Mr. Garrett, the key question involves how good the new process is. **********It impressed him in prototype. He said that the dealer organization was happy to stay with Savin but added that alternative technology was available from Japan. The dealers probably will not remain loyal if Savin fails with its new product, he said. **********Mr. Edelson believes that, if Savin is able to produce a machine that meets planned specifications soon, the company could gain significant market share. But if Savin faces delays, Ricoh and othe r Japanese companies could threaten the market Savin already holds. **********Savin continues to sell Ricoh-made machines and after several losing quarters may become profitable again soon. John Westergaard of Equity Research Associates believes Savin will have nominal losses at worst in the quarter ending this month. He is recommending the shares for the long term on a basis that the company could earn $8 to $12 a share in the fiscal year 1986.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/31/busin.body_text: **********A Federal class action suit filed here on behalf of a group of Continental Illinois Corporation shareholders charges the huge bank holding company and its senior executives with ''fraudulently inducing'' the public to buy its stock by systematically masking the company's true financial condition. **********The suit, which could have wide repercussions for the American banking system, also names the national accounting firm of Ernst & Whinney, the company's accountants. **********The action, filed on Thursday in United States District Court, contends that Continental, the nation's sixth-largest banking concern, and several of its senior officers concealed the bank's true financial condition from the public during the period from Feb.15, 1981, to July 29, 1982. **********Continental last week reported a loss of $61 million in the second quarter, largely because of its purchase of $1 billion in energy loans from the Penn Square Bank of Oklahoma City, which failed on July 5. **********After the scope of Continental's involvement with Penn Square became apparent in early July, the Chicago bank's stock plunged from the $30 range to a close of $16.125 today, for a total paper loss of about $560 million. **********The suit, which did not specify the amount of damages being sought, was brought by Bernard I. Mirochnick, a resident of Skokie who holds about 1,000 shares of Continental stock. **********The class action is on behalf of those investors who bought Continental stock between Feb.15, 1981, and July 29, 1982. The suit estimates that ''at least several million shares'' were traded during that period. **********Two law firms are handling the case for Mr. Mirochnick, and both are specialists in class action suits. They are Much, Shelist, Freed, Denenberg, Ament & Eiger of Chicago and Greenfield & Chimicles of Philadelphia. **********The basis of the suit is that Continental knowingly concealed the true extent of its its ''nonperforming'' loans in the period. The allegation carries potentially broad implications for the banking industry, banking experts and analysts said, because the methods of concealment cited in the suit are commonly used by the nation's large banks, especially those with foreign operations. **********According to the suit, ''Defendants failed to disclose that the extent of 'nonperforming' loans had been concealed by means of deceptive maturity extensions, rate concessions, rollovers and other means.'' **********A Continental spokesman said, ''We have not been served with the complaint, so we can't comment on it.'' It was also learned that James D. Harper Jr., an executive vice president who was named in the suit, sold 68,938 shares of his Continental stock between April 22 and April 30 this year at prices between $29.75 and $30 a share. After the sale, Mr. Harper was left with 1,850 shares. **********At the time Mr. Harper sold his shares, there had been no public disclosure that the bank might have large losses. In response to a reporter's question, a bank spokesman said that Mr. Harper sold his stock ''for the sole reason of realigning his personal investment plans.'' **********Other executives named in the suit were Roger E. Anderson, Continental's chairman; John H. Perkins, president; Donald C. Miller, vice chairman, and Gerald K. Bergman, executive vice president in charge of special industries services. **********Ray Groves, chairman of Ernst & Whinney, said he had not known about the suit until he was informed by a reporter. But he said, ''We certainly stand behind our report and audit and will respond in the appropriate fashion in the appropriate court.'' **********Beyond Continental's relationship with the failed Penn Square Bank, the suit also cites the bank's loans to other troubled companies.  They include American Invsco, $250 million; AM International, $12 million; International Harvester, $200 million; Flight Transportation, $6 million; Grupo Alfa of Mexico, $100 million; Turbo Resources, $50 million; Nucorp Energy, $130 million; Balmoral Mines, $30 million, and Wickes Companies, $31 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/07/busin.body_text: **********ON Capitol Hill, Claude Pepper continues to press for a change in the retirement age. Successful some years ago in getting the age changed to 70 from 65 for most working people, the Florida Democrat now wants to eliminate an age cap completely. **********Vigorous at 81, Representative Pepper (who was a Senator for many years) is widely regarded as a walking advertisement for elimination of any age barrier in employment. **********Dr. Arthur Flemming, president of the National Council on Aging, recently suggested that the Reagan Administration might support a bill eliminating any retirement age if it would not require companies to hire new people over 70. Dr. Flemming expressed optimism about legislative passage this year. **********''I have long advocated making illegal compulsory retirement on basis of age,'' he said. ''It has already been eliminated in the Federal Government. If the law is amended, it would effectively encourage the private sector to utilize this available resource -our older people. It would prevent a great deal of costly mental and physical deterioration. Companies that have regarded older people as an asset have had satisfactory experiences.'' **********As an example, Dr. Flemming mentioned the Travelers Insurance Company, which offers its retired workers part-time employment not only to supplement their pensions but also to alleviate the disorientation of retirement. **********Encouraging people to work longer and encouraging companies to consider keeping them on the job could help the Social Security system, which faces the specter of a swelling outflow of money for pensions without enough payroll deduction money coming in. Members of both parties in Congress have been talking of increasing the age for early retirement and of raising the regular Social Security retirement age above 65. **********Meanwhile, though, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reports a record number of unemployed older workers. According to figures for this year's second quarter, released Friday, people aged 55 or older who were described as ''unwillingly unemployed'' and were seeking jobs totaled 744,000, up from 500,000 a year earlier. And 334,000 additional people of 55 or older had become discouraged and quit looking for work, the bureau found. **********Partly as a result of the recession, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and various states have been deluged with age discrimination lawsuits. **********There has been a sharp increase since the fiscal year 1979, when 5,374 cases were filed with Federal and state agencies. The total rose to 11,076 the following year and to 15,311 last year. Much of this growth is a result of layoffs in manufacturing industries, hard hit by the economic slump. **********One significant aspect of the outlook for jobless older persons seeking work is the fact that their duration of unemployment is about 20 percent longer than the average for the entire population.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/14/busin.body_text: **********Despite the global slump in the world oil market, 23 companies today made high bids totaling a near-record $2.1 billion for rights to drill for oil and gas in the Beaufort Sea off Alaska's North Slope. **********The highest bid for an individual tract was $227 million, made by a group consisting of Mobil, Tenneco and British Petroleum and its Sohio affiliate. The actual awarding of the areas is subject to Federal approval of development plans and environmental assessments. **********The tracts offered by the Interior Department cover 1.8 million acres in an area thought to hold one of the richest oil and gas reserves in the country. **********Revenues Could Reach $75 Billion **********The department estimates that the tracts in the Diapir field in Prudhoe Bay contain 2.36 billion barrels of oil that could produce revenues of $75 billion to $80 billion. **********J. Robinson West, Assistant Secratary of the Interior for Policy, Budget and Administration, said this evening: ''We are absolutely delighted. This vindicates our outer continental shelf program. The program is alive and well.'' **********The program speeds the pace of auctions for offshore areas and expands the areas to be made available for oil and gas exploration.  Environmental groups oppose the program because they feel it has been hastily developed and will intrude on ecologically fragile areas. **********As part of the program, bidders are permitted greater flexibility in financing lease purchases in order to attract more companies.  There is also greater flexibility in assessing the environmen- tal impact of exploration and drilling activities.  Interior Secretary James G. Watt had said that if the Beaufort Sea lease sale brought in bids of $1 billion, it would be a success. But industry executives said that Mr. Watt was being very cautious, even given the current slump in the oil business. **********A total of 252 bids were made during the sale, which was held in Anchorage. Bids were made on 125 tracts of the 338 offered. An Interior Department spokesman said the names of the successful bidders would be announced in about two weeks. **********The highest total of bids accepted for a single lease sale was $2.6 billion, for a sale in the Gulf of Mexico in 1980. The previous high in Alaskan waters was $488 million in 1979, also for a sale in the Beaufort Sea. **********Mr. West of the Interior Department said the Beaufort sale would produce $12 billion to $13 billion in royalties for the Treasury and $5 billion in taxes. **********In the auctions, sealed bids are submitted and the Government permits the highest bidder to submit plans for development of the field. If they are satisfactory, the bidder is allowed to begin exploratory drilling. Production requires further approval. **********Mr. West said today's sale was ''fundamental'' to the success of the department's offshore program, which will make a billion acres of the outer continental shelf available over a five-year period. ''It is important to recognize that Alaska is the energy future of this nation,'' he said. **********He also said the Beaufort Sea was particularly attractive to industry because of the proximity of the Trans-Alaska Pipeline System terminal at Prudhoe Bay, where reserves of 10 billion barrels of oil have been found. **********The promise of potential oil strikes in this area is regarded as so high that it outweighs concerns over current depressed market conditions. ''A lot of companies have been saving their pennies for this one,'' said Charles D. Matthews, president of the association, whose members provide equipment and technical expertise for the offshore oil industry. Risks Are High, However **********But industry officials also noted the risks. ''These things are always the biggest crap game in town,'' said Frank Rogers, consultant for the American Petroleum Institute, an industry association. **********Mr. Rogers noted that earlier wells sunk closer to the shore in Prudhoe Bay had cost $75 million each. Wells in the new leasing area, he said, could cost $100 million. **********In addition, environmental restrictions will add to the costs. One restriction prohibits drilling during the migratory season of the bowhead whale, which is hunted by Alaskans for subsistence. **********Sarah Chasis, senior staff attorney for the Natural Resources Defense Council, said the Beaufort Sea sale was not a good test of the leasing program because it was conducted under old rules governing financing and environmental assessments. Moreover, she said, the area was particularly attractive to industry, and the bids today did not reflect the appeal of the program as a whole. **********The council is one of the groups opposing Mr. Watt's program on the ground that it does not offer adequate protection to marine environments and coastal economies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/27/world.body_text: **********Pope John Paul II today declared the year 1983 a Holy Year in commemoration of the 1,950th anniversary of the Year of Redemption - the year Jesus died. **********Closing a four-day meeting of the Sacred College of Cardinals with an address in Latin, the Pope said: ''And now, it is near to my heart to make an announcement to you that will certainly be a cause of grand joy for you and the whole church.'' **********The Pope, recalling that in 1933 Pope Pius XI proclaimed the 1,900th anniversary as a special jubilee year, said there were strong reasons for celebrating 1983 in the same fashion. The reasons he offered were the centrality of the Redemption to Christianity, the approacing Synod of Bishops and the ''worthy preparation'' for the Holy Year 2000. **********The Pope said the Holy Year would begin in the course of the next Lent. ''Let us ask the Lord that this celebration will bring a gust of spiritual renewal at all levels!'' the Pope called out. A Change in Frequency **********Vatican sources were surprised at the announcement, which appeared to them to set in motion a tradition of celebrating six Holy Years each century instead of four, the last being in 1975. **********The first jubliee year was proclaimed in 1300 by Pope Boniface VIII. By 1343 the frequency was increased to every half century, by 1389 to every 33 years and in 1470 the present rhythm of every quarter century was instituted. Now the Redemption, to be commemorated in the '33 and '83 years, appears to be making the number six each century. **********The Pope also announced that a new code of canon law, which has been in preparation for several years and was expected to be published this year, was still under study. **********''The importance of the work still requires a certain period of verification and reflection, which I have entrusted to a restricted and qualified study group,'' the Pope said. He did not explain the delay in publication of the laws to govern all church affairs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/06/busin.body_text: **********The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company expects a 25 percent drop in first-quarter earnings because of the recession, Charles J. Pilliod, chairman, said today. In the period a year earlier the company netted $43.1 million on sales of $2.2 billion. **********But Mr. Pilliod, speaking at the company's annual shareholders' meeting, said he thought the worst was over for the nation's economy.  ''I feel the economy has bottomed out, and if confidence can be restored, all the other elements are there to put us on the move both here and abroad to a lasting recovery,'' Mr. Pilliod said. **********Goodyear, the nation's largest tiremaker, has been negotiating since March 9 with the United Rubber Workers union for a new threeyear labor contract. The B.F. Goodrich Company and the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company are also bargaining with the U.R.W. The current contracts, covering 45,000 rubber workers, expire April 20. **********Goodyear also disclosed that it planned to exchange up to 1.6 million of its common shares for $7.95 million principal amount of its 8.60 percent sinking fund debentures due 1995 and $37.4 million principal amount of its 7.35 percent sinking fund debentures due 1997. **********The tire manufacturer said that Goldman, Sachs & Company, which owns the debentures, would sell the shares it received in the exchange. Goodyear at the end of last year had 58.1 million common shares outstanding.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/14/busin.main_headline: WARNER AND MCI POST GAINS WHILE CBS AND TIME INC. SLIP
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/14/busin.print_headline: WARNER AND MCI POST GAINS WHILE CBS AND TIME INC. SLIP
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/14/busin.body_text: **********Warner Communications and the MCI Communications Corporation, two of the nation's fastest-growing communications companies, yesterday reported hefty earnings increases in the second quarter, while Time Inc. and CBS, which are trying to expand into new electronic services, reported slight declines in net income. CBS **********CBS said its net income for the second quarter of 1982 dipped by 1.5 percent, to $46.1 million, or $1.64 a share, from $46.8 million, or $1.67 a share, in the comparable period last year. **********The 1981 figures included losses from mass-market paperback book publishing that has since been discontinued. Counting continuing operations only, second-quarter net income declined by 4.4 percent, the company said. Revenues increased 4.1 percent, to $1.03 billion, from $988 million. **********Thomas H. Wyman, president of CBS, said in a statement that he was satisfied with the results, given the economy and CBS expenditures on development of new activities, such as video games, home electronic information services and high-definition television. **********CBS said revenues for its Broadcast Group rose 12 percent in the quarter and that profits also rose. The Records Group suffered a 2 percent decline in revenues but showed a profit. Last year the group posted a loss for the period. Time Inc. **********Time Inc. said earnings fell to $47 million, or 75 cents a share, in the second quarter, from $49.2 million, or 80 cents a share, in the period in 1981, a decline of 4.5 percent. **********The figures for the 1981 period included losses from The Washington Star, which has since closed. Considering continued operations only, Time said its earnings fell 9.6 percent. Revenues rose 7.7 percent, to $906.5 million from $841.6 million. **********''Magazine income, although off slightly from last year's exceptional performance, was very strong considering the economic environment,'' J. Richard Munro, president and chief executive officer, said in a statement. He said book publishing income was ''way down,'' forest products were also down, but income for video activities increased strongly because of the growth in subscribers at Time's cable television company and its Home Box Office programming service. Warner **********Warner Communications, the parent company of Atari Inc., continued to capitalize on the video game boom in the second quarter, reporting a 60.1 percent increase in net income on a 34.2 percent rise in revenues. **********Net income rose to $68.2 million, or $1.05 a share, compared with $42.6 million, or 66 cents a share, earned in the second quarter of 1981. Revenues climbed to $907 million from $676 million. **********The Consumer division, which includes Atari, showed a revenue increase of 127 percent, to $461.6 million, with pretax income nearly tripling, to $111.8 million. Video games sales were up ''dramatically,'' the company said, and home computer sales, a relatively small part of Atari's business, increased more than fourfold. Operating income from Warner's film activities was also up, while income from the publishing and record groups declined. MCI **********MCI, the leading long-distance service competitor of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, more than doubled its revenues and tripled its net income in the second quarter of 1982, compared with the period in 1981. **********Net income reached $36.5 million, or 75 cents a share, compared with $10.7 million, or 19 cents a share, in the corresponding period of 1981. Sales rose to $185 million from $86 million. The figures do not include MCI's acquisition of WUI Inc. from the Xerox Corporation, a transaction that was not completed until the end of the quarter.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/09/busin.main_headline: CLORE STOCK TAKES OVER AT GULF
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/09/busin.print_headline: CLORE STOCK TAKES OVER AT GULF
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/09/busin.body_text: **********Alan E. Clore, the leader of a dissident stockholder group that won control of the Gulf Resources and Chemical Company, was appointed chairman yesterday at the first meeting of the company's new board of directors. He replaces Robert H. Allen, who was dismissed. **********Gary A. Childress, the former president of a Pennsylvania resources and waste-management concern and a member of the dissident slate, was named chief executive officer. The office of president and chief operating officer will continue to be held by Frank G. Woodruff ''pending the outcome of a further review of the company's operations,'' a spokesman for the dissident group said last night. **********Mr. Clore participated in the New York meeting by a telephone linkup from Paris and could not be reached for comment.  Asked why Mr. Clore had not taken the post of chief executive of the Houston-based energy concern, Kenneth J. Bialkin, partner in Wilkie, Farr & Gallagher, counsel for the Clore group, indicated that he was unable to devote full time to running the company. **********''The chief executive officer is a full-time employee,'' Mr.  Bialkin said. ''Mr. Childress is a professional manager.'' Earlier in the day, the company said it would drop lawsuits against Mr. Clore and the other dissidents, as well as suits challenging the validity of some of the filed proxies. Countersuits by the Clore group were dropped in return. **********The new board, which controls 15.64 percent of Gulf Resources' common stock, is expected to certify the preliminary proxy count as one of its first acts. That count, released late last month, showed the dissidents with 55 percent of the vote. **********Of the 14 directors, 12, including Mr. Clore and Mr. Childress, are members of the dissident group. The two other directors were reelected. **********Mr. Childress, who is 48 years old, had been president of the Dart Company during the early 1970's. He then joined the Warner Company, a minerals and waste management concern, when it was acquired by the venture-capital arm of E.M. Warburg Pincus. Warner was sold to Waste Management Inc., of Oak Brook, Ill., last year. **********Mr. Clore, a 38-year-old Swiss citizen, personally controls 15.4 percent of Gulf and has been involved in numerous American stock acquisitions. **********In 1980, Mr. Clore purchased a 5.88 percent stake in Pullman Inc.  for $21.3 million; when Wheelabrator Frye Inc. bought Pullman three months later for $600 million, his stake was worth $35 million. He also reportedly doubled his money on a 4.1 percent stake in Marshall Field & Company, when Batus Inc., the American unit of B.A.T.  Industries of London, made a bid for the company. **********The investor, who rarely makes public appearances, is currently enmeshed in a suit in England seeking a quarter of his father's $146 million estate. His father, Sir Charles Clore, who had been one of the richest men in Britain, owned Selfridges department store in London and other holdings. **********The 10 other new board members are William E. Ambrose, 45, president of the Universal Fuels Company, Denver; Sheldon M. Atlas, 58, a New York consultant; Robert G. Boulton, 53, of Winston-Salem, N.C., consultant to Morton-Norwich Products, and Averell Harriman Fisk, 33, president of Fisk Investment Services, Palm Beach, Fla. **********Also, John D. Murchison Jr., chairman of Murchison Oil and Gas Company, Dallas; Seymour Graubard, 38, a senior partner with Graubard Moskovitz McGoldrick Dannett & Horowitz, a New York Law firm; Carolyn Sue Kelly, 38, vice president of the Wynn Oil Company, Dallas; John F. McCracken, 38, a principal with Sterling-McCracken Capital, Dallas; Bruce Slovin, 46, president of MacAndrews & Forbes Group Inc., New York; and William Woodward 3d, a New York investor. **********Two members of Gulf Resources' previous board were re-elected: Raphael Bernstein, 50, a partner in Bear Stearns & Company, and Jack T. Trotter, 55, a Houston investor who controls three-tenths of 1 percent of the company's common stock.
