https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/05/world.main_headline: U.S. IS SAID TO LAG ON PLEDGE TO FOOD AGENCY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/05/world.print_headline: U.S. IS SAID TO LAG ON PLEDGE TO FOOD AGENCY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/05/world.body_text: **********The head of a United Nations agency that seeks to increase food production in impoverished countries says his organization may be in jeopardy because Washington is refusing to fulfill a financial pledge. **********The agency, the International Fund for Agricultural Development, was established after a 1976 agreement to help small farmers and the landless in the world's poorest countries. It is financed both by the industrialized nations and by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. In its first three years of operation, the industrial countries contributed $569 million, the OPEC nations $435 million. **********The United States, an initiator of the agency, contributed $200 million in the first three years. President Carter offered $230 million for the 1981-83 replenishment; President Reagan reduced that to $180 million but none of it has been contributed. **********The three-year total was authorized in both houses of Congress and $40.5 million was appropriated by the House for the last fiscal year. The Senate struck it out, and its view prevailed. Staff Seen as Too Large **********The Senate action, led by Senator Robert W. Kasten Jr., Republican of Wisconsin, was based on a sentiment that the OPEC nations, which hold the same number of votes as the industrial countries, were committed to match their contribution. There was also a feeling that the fund had exceeded its projected staff size. It employs 74 people in the professional category. **********On Wednesday, acting on the Administration's request for $65.4 million for the 1983 fiscal year, which began Oct. 1, an appropriations subcommittee headed by Mr. Kasten reduced the amount to $10 million. This would leave the United States to contribute $170 million next year to meet its pledge, which has not been withdrawn. **********This is believed to be virtually impossible, and Philip Birnbaum, the fund's vice president, who is on loan from the State Department's Agency for International Development, said that the situation was ''a minor tragedy.'' **********The fund's president, Abdelmuhsin M. al-Sudeary, an agronomist from Saudi Arabia, said that if the agency was unable to finance its activities, ''no other effort like this will succeed.'' **********Mr. Sudeary said that ''the spotlight will be on the United States'' Dec. 13-15 at the annual meeting of the fund's governing council.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/13/busin.main_headline: LTV AGREES TO SELL ITS STEAMSHIP UNIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/13/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; LTV AGREES TO SELL ITS STEAMSHIP UNIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/13/busin.body_text: **********The LTV Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell its Lykes Brothers Steamship Company subsidiary to the Interocean Steamship Corporation for $150 million. **********The purchasing company was formed by existing senior management of the subsidiary headed by its president, W.J. Amoss Jr., and Lykes Brothers Inc., a Florida based company that was the original parent company of Lykes Brothers Steamship. **********The closing is scheduled for mid-February 1983, subject to Federal regulatory requirements and conditions of the purchase agreement.  Of the $150 million sale price, $85 million will be in cash, LTV said. It added that it had sold the unit becuase LTV's strategic plan is focusing on growth in the high-technology areas of energy products and services, aerospace and steelmaking. Consequently, it said, ocean shipping does not fit in the plan. **********Lykes Brothers Steamship operates a fleet of 46 American-flag vessels serving five continents.  Earlier in the day, LTV, a big defense contractor, cut its quarterly common stock dividend to 6.25 cents a share from 12.5 cents. LTV also cut the quarterly dividend on its ''series 1'' participating preference stock to 7.08125 cents a share from 14.1625 cents. **********The company lost $58.3 million in the three months ended Sept. 30, more than offsetting a small profit in the first six months of the year. LTV said it expected losses to continue into the fourth quarter. PU COMPNEWS FOLOS

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/05/world.main_headline: STATE DEPT. MOVES TO KEEP NAMIBIA ON COURSE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/05/world.print_headline: STATE DEPT. MOVES TO KEEP NAMIBIA ON COURSE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/05/world.body_text: **********The State Department renewed efforts over the weekend to prevent a dispute concerning the presence of Cuban soldiers in Angola from endangering negotiations, scheduled to start in New York on Tuesday, that are intended to end the conflict in South-West Africa. **********Robert Cabelly, an assistant to Chester A. Crocker, the Assistant Secretary of State for Africa, arrived in Luanda Saturday for previously unannounced talks with representatives of the South-West Africa People's Organization, the Soviet-armed insurgent group battling South Africa's disputed control of South-West Africa, also known as Namibia. **********The discussions followed talks in Washington in June between Mr.  Crocker and South African officials. Western sources said the Luanda talks were designed to prevent a further souring of the atmosphere after public exchanges between South Africa and the insurgents over what is termed ''linkage'' by the United States and South Africa of the Namibian issue with a withdrawal of the 15,000 to 20,000 Cuban soldiers stationed in Angola. **********South Africa Demands Pullout **********In recent weeks, South Africa has asserted that a settlement of the guerrilla war must be accompanied by a Cuban withdrawal from Angola, which provides the insurgents with bases. **********The guerrillas, for their part, have said the New York negotiations are imperiled by South Africa's demands. But the guerrilla spokesman here, Hidipo Hamutenya, has said a delegation will attend. **********The Western sources indicated that the exchanges had made the negotiations more difficult and that part of Mr. Cabelly's mission was to give the guerrillas an assessment of the state of the talks beyond what was termed ''rhetoric'' by both sides. **********The inference was that the United States is trying to convince the protagonists that the recent public statements may be designed to satisfy political constituencies, not to block the negotiations. The United States is the principal member of the so-called Western contact group that has been trying for several years to mediate between the rebels and South Africa over the future of Namibia. Other members of the contact group are Britain, Canada, France and West Germany. 'Other Longstanding Problems' **********A serious complication has arisen from a proposal by the contact group concerning linkage that has reinforced the rebels' suspicion that South Africa plans to use the issue to stall. The proposal, presented to the rebels in June and made available to reporters in Luanda last week, implicitly links a Namibian settlement to ''other longstanding problems'' of the region, a clear reference to the Cubans who are supporting the Luanda Government and to the anti-Government rebels backed by South Africa in southern Angola. **********The carefully worded proposal, part of a longer document, is apparently designed to ease South African fears that the Cuban presence is a threat to Pretoria's own security. It is also apparently intended to fulfill Washington's wider desire to oppose Soviet influence. **********Mr. Cabelly's talks with rebel officials have not been publicly announced here, and Western diplomats have indicated that the United States would prefer a minimum of publicity about the present phase of the ''delicate'' discussions. **********A Western diplomatic source said the visit seemed designed to ''smooth ruffled feathers'' and to discredit a belief among the insurgents that they are being pressed to accept a settlement that will benefit only the South Africans. August Target Date for Accord **********The timetable for the new discussions envisages agreement on a settlement by Aug. 15. The Western strategy, the sources indicated, is to keep up momentum to prevent the guerrillas or South Africa from backing out. **********According to Western and African diplomatic sources, however, the United States insistence on linkage, however diplomatically phrased, has divided the contact group, with Canada, France and West Germany opposing the American position and Britain ambivalent about it. **********Washington also ties the establishment of diplomatic relations with Angola to a Cuban withdrawal, a linkage that Angola rejects, just as it rejects any formal tie between a Namibia settlement and the Cuban presence. **********At the same time, there is an awareness here of potential benefits from normalized relations with the United States. After years of hostility and suspicion about the Central Intelligence Agency's involvement in the civil war that surrounded Angola's independence from Portugal in 1975. There have also been fears that the United States, which is still regarded here as ''imperialist,'' wants to destabilize the Government in Luanda. **********According to recently published United States statistics, Angola earned $559 million in exports to the United States in 1980 and imported $111 million worth of United States goods, making America its largest trading partner that year. **********The oil industry, mainstay of Angola's broken economy, is dominated by United States oil companies, mainly Gulf and Texaco. U.S. College Stars to Tour **********The Angolan authorities recently gave a fresh signal of interest in normalizing diplomatic ties. In March, at what Angolan sources called ''the highest level,'' the Government gave approval for a United States all-star college basketball team to tour Angola. **********The organizers of the tour - Carmine Calzonetti of St. John's University and Richard Lapchick of the Phelps Stokes Fund in New York - visited Luanda last week to set up the tour by a squad from the Big East Conference. **********In an interview, the two organizers said the State Department had been supportive of the tour, which is due to start July 27, and they compared it to the Ping-Pong diplomacy that preceded the establishment of relations between the United States and China.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/16/busin.main_headline: Advertising; New Shop Seeks Its Own Niche
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/16/busin.print_headline: Advertising; New Shop Seeks Its Own Niche
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/16/busin.body_text: **********TWO former leaders of the Needham, Harper & Steers creative department in New York, Lois Korey and Allen Kay, have opened their own advertising agency with $6 million in billings. **********The proprietors of Korey, Kay & Partners, which has offices in the Empire State Building, last Friday explained what will set their agency apart from the field. **********It is being positioned as a shop for entrepreneurs and an agency that, although a corporation for legal reasons, will conduct itself like a partnership. No corporate titles will be made public. **********Employees who deliver new accounts - and K.K.P. will only accept major pieces of business - will become partners and will get some of the income from those accounts as will the top account, art and copy people on each client. **********Only $3 million-and-above accounts will be accepted (''We want to be billing $100 million soon,'' Mrs. Korey said) except in the founders' areas of expertise and here the minimum is increased to $10 million. Those areas are office equipment and systems (they previously supervised Xerox), travel (Amtrak), beauty and fashion (Charles of the Ritz), insurance (American Insurance Group) and major appliances (Frigidare). **********Of the two accounts already in the house only one can be identified. It is Sheridane Designs Ltd., for Pierre Cardin Ties.  The kind of clients Mrs. Korey and Mr. Kay are looking for ''demand advertising that's bolder. Brighter. More daring. Exciting.  And inventive. They know they're appealing to real live human beings. Not some statistics on a flow chart. They expect big wins. Dramatic growth. And they haven't let their business sense replace their sense of humor.'' **********That's how the two described their thinking in an ad.  And, they say, one of the first entrepreneurs they worked for was Nelson Rockefeller, when as creative partners at McCann-Erickson they were lent to Jack Tinker & Partners, a sister company, to work on one of his gubernatorial campaigns. **********McCann is where they first met. Mrs. Korey, 45 years old, was a Barnard dropout who wrote comedy for Steve Allen on the ''Tonight'' show when she was 19. She later made an effortless switch to writing copy. **********Like his sidekick, Mr. Kay, 36, started out in the Washington Heights section of Manhattan, but moved to Fair Lawn, N.J., before he started high school. An artist, Mr. Kay determined early in his career that he would never top Picasso, so he tried advertising. He pursued that craft during summers while he was going to the Art Center College of Design in Los Angeles. Mr. Kay was barely out when McCann got him. **********They were at Needham for 11 years, she as executive vice president and executive creative director and he as senior vice president and creative director. You can't get much higher without running the place. Now they're giving that a try.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/15/busin.main_headline: AGREEMENT WITH I.B.M. STILLS ACADEMIC ANXIETY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/15/busin.print_headline: AGREEMENT WITH I.B.M. STILLS ACADEMIC ANXIETY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/15/busin.body_text: **********An agreement among the International Business Machines Corporation, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Harvard Medical School has averted the questions of academic freedom that have plagued other recent contracts between corporations and universities. **********The five-year, $3.4 million contract is for the development and use of equipment used in a technique that doctors hope will enable them to detect diseased tissue without subjecting patients to X-rays. **********The research that I.B.M. is sponsoring on the Boston-area campuses is known as nuclear magnetic resonance. Doctors hope to make use of the process, in conjunction with computers, to form an image of tissue and diseased cells. **********Ownership of Patents **********Under the contract, Harvard and M.I.T. will retain ownership of all patents arising from the research, and I.B.M. Instruments, an I.B.M. subsidiary, will receive rights to license the patents on a nonexclusive basis, according to spokesmen for the project. The principal researchers will be free to publish their findings without prior permission from I.B.M. **********''I believe that industry and universities are coming to realize that in long-run projects their goals are similar,'' said Dr.  Douglas Adams of Harvard, who will be directing the research at Brigham and Women's Hospital, an affiliate of the medical school. **********The agreement, generally considered favorable to the academic institutions, comes at a time when university officials have grown increasingly concerned that academic freedom may be jeopardized by permitting too much industry control over sponsored research. Concerns at Harvard **********Those concerns are especially strong at Harvard Medical School, which received sharp criticism and faced a Congressional inquiry after Massachusetts General Hospital, closely affiliated with the school, entered a contract in 1981 with Hoechst A.G., a West German pharmaceutical concern. **********Hoechst is spending $70 million to create a new department of molecular biology at Massachusetts General Hospital. In return, the company will receive exclusive rights to market any inventions that result from the bioengineering studies at the hospital. **********Scholars have been worried that companies holding exclusive rights -and often control over when research results can be published - may use their financial leverage to steer researchers toward immediately profitable findings rather than basic research. Dr. Adams said that while I.B.M. never sought an exclusive license, the freedom to publish findings without prior approval ''was an issue dealt with in negotations.'' **********An I.B.M. spokesman said that the company often agrees to nonexclusive licenses, but would not comment further.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/08/world.body_text: **********Syria said tonight that fighting began today between Syrian and Israeli ground forces in southern Lebanon.  A communique issued by the army high command said that Syrian forces confronted Israeli tanks that were advancing on Syrian positions south of Jezzin and destroyed some of them by artillery and antitank rocket fire. No number was mentioned. **********The action was reported to have occurred on the second day of Israel's drive into Lebanon in an operation intended to destroy the main military bases of the Palestine Liberation Organization. The communique said the fighting erupted after Israeli planes and artillery had attacked ''areas in which our troops were stationed'' in the Jezzin area and in Beirut. **********It said the ground action took place near Haitura, Jamaq and other towns protecting the southwestern entrance to the Bekaa Valley.  Jezzin, which is 12 miles east of Sidon, is the largest town in this area. The Bekaa Valley is a route through which a tank force could invade Syria from Lebanon. **********Syria was reported tonight to have sent substantial reinforcements to Lebanon, including an armored division. 5 Syrians Reported Killed **********The communique, which quoted a military spokesman, was issued by Sana, the official Syrian press agency. A nightly newscast on Syrian Government television was delayed almost 20 minutes to allow the announcement to be read. **********The communique said five Syrian soliders, including an officer, were killed in ground action with the Israelis.  It said that two Israeli fighter-bombers were shot down by Syrian jets when ''they attacked residential areas and Palestinian camps in Beirut.'' Syria lost one plane, the communique said. **********It was the first time since Israel started bombing Lebanon four days ago that Syrian planes had gone into action.  The reported outbreak of ground fighting between Israel and Syrian forces today came after the Israelis had overrun the most important strongholds held by the Palestinians just south of the southernmost Syrian positions. **********When the Israelis took Beaufort Castle, a crusader fort on a sheer cliff and the towns of Nabatiye, Hasbeya and Rasheiye, there was no buffer left between them and the Syrians. Until today's ground clashes, foreign diplomats here said the Israelis and Syrians were sending each other signals indicating that they did not want a confrontation but would each be firm in safeguarding minimum military objectives. Some of the Signals **********The diplomats said such signals included repeated statements by Israeli radio announcers on Sunday that the thrust into Lebanon was not intended as an attack on Syrian forces. **********The Syrians, according to these diplomats, signaled back that they would take no action against the Israeli forces unless their own positions were attacked. **********Syria, it is felt, is under conflicting pressures. It does not want to be drawn into a confrontation with Israel in Lebanon that it cannot win. On the other hand, it is felt, Syrian prestige and credibility in the Arab world are likely to suffer gravely if the Syrian Army in Lebanon does nothing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/02/world.main_headline: AWACS ACCORD IS DENIED BY SAUDI

Weinberger had negotiated such an accord during a recent visit to Riyadh. **********''The reports are baseless,'' Prince Sultan said. ''These lies circulated by certain news agencies under pressure of Zionist elements are malicious toward Islam and the whole Arab nation.'' **********On several recent occasions, Saudi officials have issued denials in the Arabic press of detailed reports and interviews in Western news outlets. ---- Special to the New York Times **********WASHINGTON, March 1 - Secretary Weinberger confirmed today that he had obtained an agreement from Saudi Arabia to abide by United States conditions governing the operation of the Awacs planes being sold to the Saudis. ''We got it,'' he told reporters, speaking of a long negotiation during his visit last month to Saudi Arabia. He said the accord would soon be submitted to Congress.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/02/busin.main_headline: French Nationalization Blamed in Divorce Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/02/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; French Nationalization Blamed in Divorce Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/02/busin.body_text: **********In French business circles, it is the divorce of the year.  Halfkiddingly, she blames the Socialist Government's nationalization program. Not kidding at all, his spokesman says it's a private matter. **********She is Francine Gomez, president of Waterman S.A., one of the world's largest makers of fountain pens. He is Alain Gomez, president of the Thomson Electronics Group, which with 130,000 employees is the biggest company in its field in France. **********Mrs. Gomez, 50, is the third woman in her family to run the business. She describes herself as ''a classic emanation of the French right wing.'' Mr. Gomez, 44, is a doctor's son who became a company executive and an active Socialist and was placed at the head of Thomson when it was nationalized last year. **********Now, after 15 years of marriage, they live apart. There are no children. Mrs. Gomez, who is bringing the divorce action, told a news agency: ''When a husband's work totally takes the place of his personal life, he winds up not being around anymore. Until recently, we had a private life, but it disappeared some months ago. All in all, I'm a victim of the nationalizations.'' **********Until last year, Mr. Gomez had been president of Saint-Gobain Emballage, a manufacturing division of Saint-Gobain that specializes in glass and construction materials. When the Socialists took power, Mr. Gomez's close friend, Jean-Pierre Chevenement, became Minister of Industry. Mr. Gomez was named head of Thomson, which is supposed to lead France's drive into advanced electronic technology. **********Saying she preferred not to talk much about the divorce, Mrs. Gomez saved her vehemence for Socialism in France. ''We continue to work pretty normally,'' she said with a huge, rather mischievous smile that is a fixture in French business magazines. ''I'm not really involved in politics, but the truth is my family is what you could call a classic emanation of the right. I believe in family, and work and all that retrograde stuff. I don't believe in disorder or anything that can bring it.'' **********''There's great disorder now. You get three different ministries doing three different things and no sense of who's in charge. Let's say things are difficult but not catastrophic.'' **********Mr. Gomez's company lost about $24 million last year and has forecast substantially greater losses this year. Mrs. Gomez's company lost about $685,000 during the six months ended last March, and earned about $1 million in the quarter ended Sept. 30.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/24/world.body_text: **********State Department officials said today that the Reagan Administration was considering the sale of helicopter spare parts and communications equipment to Guatemala because the human rights situation there was improving. **********At the same time, a human rights group denounced the Government of Gen. Efrain Rios Montt for ''despotic and totalitarian'' practices.  The Americas Watch Committee, a New York-based human rights monitoring group that focuses on Latin America, said in a long report on Guatemala today: ''Those who are with the Government are fed; those who are not with the Government are shot. No one is permitted to remain neutral. Those who do not aid the Government - by forming civil defense patrols or by providing information on the whereabouts of guerrillas - may not be allowed to live.'' **********The report contrasts sharply with public and private statements by State Department officials. ''While much remains to be done,'' John Hughes, the State Department spokesman said Monday, ''we have also been encouraged by steps the Guatemalan Government has already taken to address human rights concerns.'' He said the steps had been taken in the context of Government efforts to contend with an insurgency movement ''supported from outside its borders.'' **********And today, Stephen W. Bosworth, deputy assistant in the Bureau of Inter-American Affairs, said the Administration has ''currently under consideration'' the sale of military equipment totaling $3 million. Another ranking official said that President Rios Montt had ''eliminated human rights abuses'' in Guatemala City, was working on a presidential election timetable and had begun a ''vigorous'' antiguerrilla campaign in the countryside. **********These are the key reasons, he said, that President Reagan had decided to meet President Rios Montt in Honduras on Dec. 4 during Mr. Reagan's trip to Latin America. Officials said that the decision on arms supplies for Guatemala was now up to President Reagan. **********Although the potential sale of military equipment to Guatemala is relatively small, the deal is likely to provoke strong Congressional opposition. Congress has no legal power to block the possible sale, although the House Foreign Affairs Committee says it has an ''understanding'' with the State Department under which no military aid will be given to Guatemala without the panel's approval. The State Department says it has only to consult the panel, not get its approval, for military aid to Guatemala, the most populous nation in Central America. The United States-Guatemalan military relationship was severed in 1977 when the Carter Administration cited human rights abuses there. **********The report by Americas Watch said that decrees promulgated by General Riios Montt, who took power after an army-backed coup in March, ''presuades us that the Guatemalan Government has overtly abandoned the rule of law and that it has overtly substituted a system of government that is both despotic and totalitarian.'' The Americas Watch mission to Guatemala was headed by Orville Schell, chairman of the group and former president of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York. **********Americas Watch said that a report last month by Amnesty International, the human rights organization, that 2,600 people had been massacred in Guatemala in the previous six months was ''responsible and conservative.'' **********But Assistant Secretary of State Thomas O. Enders, in a letter to Amnesty, took issue with the massacre report and said that guerrillas in Guatemala ''have waged a sustained and increasingly indiscriminate campaign of terror, arson, intimidation, kidnapping, mayhem, bombing and murder. **********''Failure to publicize these incidents gives the public a one-sided impression of what is happening in Guatemala,'' said Mr. Enders.  ''Furthermore, it implies that human rights criteria only apply to governments and not to guerrilla groups.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/27/world.main_headline: Egyptians Are Warned O f Economic Sacrifices
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/27/world.print_headline: Egyptians Are Warned O f Economic Sacrifices
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/27/world.body_text: **********President Hosni Mubarak said today that his economic goals would require sacrifices and he cautioned officials not to undermine the Government's credibility with exaggerated promises. **********In a half-hour address on television, he dwelled on the faltering economy and said new steps had to be taken within ''a social framework that is quite clear.'' **********''Egypt belongs to all the people,'' he said, ''and so the wealth of this country should not be restricted to a privileged few nor should the grass roots be shouldering beyond what they can endure.'' **********The focus of Mr. Mubarak's talk, the fifth since he came to power after the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat on Oct. 6, was that economic change would involve austerity and security. **********He said economists would meet in mid-February to formulate a fiveyear plan, and he said politicians should insure that such a plan is ''genuine, honest and without hiding anything from the people and without exaggerating hopes and promises.'' **********The semiofficial newspaper Al Ahram said today that Mr. Mubarak had already started an austerity policy. The newspaper said he had ordered an end to the lavish annual Oct. 6 military parade, the one at which Mr. Sadat was slain, and has earmarked the funds for military housing and other things. **********In addition, Al Ahram said, Mr. Mubarak decided to cancel festivities that Mr. Sadat had planned for April when Israel is scheduled to return the last part of Sinai to Egypt. Instead, the newspaper said, there would be restrained obs ervances in Sinai's provincial capital of El Arish and in Parliam ent in Cairo. Other austerity measures call for fewer Government cars and less expensive entertaining of official foreign guests.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/31/busin.main_headline: SAXON EXPECTS TO POST BIG '81 LOSS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/31/busin.print_headline: SAXON EXPECTS TO POST BIG '81 LOSS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/31/busin.body_text: **********Saxon Industries, a paper products and photocopier manufacturer, said yesterday that it expects to report a pretax operating loss of about $47 million in 1981 and to take an additional write-off of up to $50 million for losses on the sale of some of its units. **********The company attributed the operating loss to high interest expenses, totaling $46.9 million last year, and to a $15 million charge against earnings resulting from an unspecified change in the way it accounted for its photocopier sales. **********The additional write-off arose because the company is selling parts of its business at below book value in an effort to raise cash to reduce its debt. Those sales are expected to yield $50 million in the next three months and more cash later, Saxon said. **********The company also said that it was applying to the Securities and Exchange Commission for a 15-day extension for filing its 1981 10-K report so it can obtain waivers of certain provisions from its lenders. **********Saxon has been profitable in the last few years but earnings have been falling. In the first nine months of 1981, Saxon reported revenues of $575 million, up 8.6 percent from the year before. But its net income of $2.78 million, or 42 cents a share, was down almost 50 percent from the similar 1980 period, reflecting 41 percent higher interest expenses. **********The company has not released its fourth-quarter report, but the announcement yesterday seemed to indicate that the pretax operating loss would be about $51 million. Sells Low-Cost Copiers **********Saxon's main business is selling paper and paper products, such as envelopes and pads. It sells low-cost copiers made by two Japanese companies. It also has an advertising specialty group that makes articles such as playing cards and wall calendars. **********The company would not break down the fourth-quarter operating loss beyond the interest expense and one-time charge. In general, however, the paper industry has been depressed and the low-end copier business has been hurt by price competition. **********Jay J. Jacobson, a Saxon vice president, would not specify the accounting change that would lead to the $15 million charge. Mr.  Jacobson also would not say which units were being sold. **********Saxon's announcement came after the close of trading in New York.  Its stock, traded on the New York exchange, closed yesterday at 5 3/8, up 1/2.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/28/busin.main_headline: LEADING INDEX SEEN ON THE RISE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/28/busin.print_headline: LEADING INDEX SEEN ON THE RISE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/28/busin.body_text: **********The index of leading indicators for September, the last major economic report to be issued before next week's congressional elections, will be up between five-tenths to seven-tenths of 1 percent, Government officials said today. The index will be released Friday. **********The index is intended to forecast recoveries and recessions, and it is now being awaited by analysts looking for signs of a recovery.  The index declined in August, after rising the previous four months, shaking once again predictions from the Administration and private forecasters about the beginning of a recovery. **********Useful to Reagan **********A rise in the index is likely to be used by President Reagan to push his argument that his economic program is working and has reduced inflation, brought down interest rates and produced a rally in the stock market. But it is unclear whether the President will be able to offset the impact of the deep recession and the 10.1 percent unemployment rate in September. **********While the index of leading indicators rose for September, a companion index, known as the coincident index, will drop again, the officials said. That indicates that much of the economy continued to decline and leaves unclear whether the recovery has begun. The coincident index moves up or down simultaneously with the economy. **********Some economists in the Administration and many private economists now state that the recovery will not begin until the end of the year.  After a meeting with small-business leaders at the White House today, President Reagan said, ''there is some sunshine on the horizon,'' adding that his policies ''can make a drastic reduction in this recession.'' **********Separately, the Labor Department reported that wage settlements for the first nine months of this year were down significantly from the corresponding period of 1981, and were one percentage point below the inflation rate. **********For the year so far, the major collective bargaining agreements in the private sector provided average increases of 3.8 percent in the first year of the contract. Over the life of the contract, the average adjustment is 3.5 percent a year. **********The consumer price index for the first nine months rose 4.8 percent.  The small increases reflect the severe impact of the recession. But more significantly, economists said, the decline is necessary to make progress on inflation more permanent. Wages are a key factor in inflation and are often used to gauge a so-called underlying rate of inflation. **********The low rate reflects many settlements in the first half of the year, especially in the automobile industry, that gave no specified increase over the life of the contract. **********Wage settlements increased in the third quarter, but still averaged only 5.8 percent, down from 9.8 percent for all of last year.  The leading index declined nine-tenths of 1 percent in August, breaking a string of four consecutive increases which the Reagan Administration had been citing as a signal of an approaching recovery. In a news conference at the time the August figure was released, Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said the leading indicators would rise in September. The five-tenths figure fits in with some private forecasts. Two Areas of Growth **********A rise in the stock market, which has continued in October, and a jump in building permits are the two key positive factors in the index, which has 10 parts, officials said. But the improvements are expected to be offset somewhat by a decline in the average manufacturing workweek. **********While much of the information the index is based on is available, revisions are possible. That is why officials gave a range for the expected increase. **********The coincident index, measuring current economic activity, will fall because of higher unemployment and September's drop in industrial production, officials said. However, because this index is not as broad a measure as gross national product, a decline does not necessarily mean that the entire economy is slumping.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/16/world.main_headline: SADAT'S DEATH GIVES TOURISTS PAUSE ABOUT EGYPT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/16/world.print_headline: SADAT'S DEATH GIVES TOURISTS PAUSE ABOUT EGYPT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/16/world.body_text: **********The horse and buggy, its brass fittings gleaming in the sunlight, sits with a forlorn driver for hours near the Happi Hotel waiting for a passenger. **********The other night a belly dancer, Miss Ahly, undulated in a nightclub with only a handful of customers to view her twitching hips.  Out on the glittering waters of the Nile, near the first cataract of the great river, only a few graceful feluccas - small, narrow vessels with lateen sails - moved silently through the water with a scattering of tourists aboard. Many more were moored to piers waiting for customers. Normally at this time of year, Aswan is full of tourists taking advantage of the warm weather, the flawless blue skies and the joys of an easygoing oasis filled with water and greenery and with the desert visible in the distance. **********But the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat on Oct. 6 has cut deeply into Egypt's tourist industry, a key f actor in the nation's precarious economy. And Aswan's troubles have been complicated in recent weeks by a series of minor earth tremo rs caused by irruptions in the Red Sea. 'There Is Nothing to Annoy' **********''I hope it will change much very soon,'' said Dr. Mohammed Sabry Zaki, a surgeon who is also Governor of Aswan Province. ''Everything is secure here. There is nothing to annoy a visitor. **********''Our income here is derived mainly from tourism, fishing and the sugar-cane industries,'' Dr. Zaki continued, in an interview in a large office in the center of the sleepy town. **********Fishing on a large scale is new to Aswan and is a result of the huge High Dam, which has controlled the flooding of the Nile and created an enormous lake called Lake Nasser. It is teeming with fish, primarily because very little fishing took place for several years after the completion of the dam. **********In 1980, 31,000 tons of fish were taken from the lake, and that, says Dr. Zaki, is too little. ''We are fishing only 15 percent of the total lake,'' he said, ''near the shores because it's still done by the primitive method - the felucca.'' The feluccas date back to the pharoahs. **********The center of the lake, which is well over 100 yards deep, is unexploited so far, Dr. Zaki said, but a Japanese company that specializes in deep-water fishing is working with local fishermen to reach into those depths and bring back the big ones. **********Have the tremors had an effect on the High Dam? Dr. Zaki was asked. ''Absolutely not,'' he said. ''The engineers inspected and were 100 percent sure that there was not the least damage.'' Meetings Held to Assure People **********After the first tremors struck, town meetings were held to assure people that the dam was not imperiled and to stave off fears of a calamity of almost unimaginable proportions if the great wall holding back the Nile was pierced. **********In several respects the construction of the High Dam rejuvenated Aswan, which in ancient times was a major marketplace for the exchange of products from Africa and the Mediterranean countries. **********New land was irrigated, flooding was controlled, and electricity was generated and fed to villages and towns nearby.  Tourism increased. People were attracted by the dam as well as the ancient and splendid temples of Philae dating from about 400 B.C. to the time of the Romans. **********After the peace treaty was signed between Egypt and Israel, Dr.  Zaki said, ''a lot of Israelis came and started to build a bridge of friendship.'' **********Hotels sprang up, and these days some of the more modest ones are doing better than the plush ones because youthful tourists, especially backpackers, have apparently not been deterred by the assassination to the extent that older travelers have been. Aga Khan Came for the Sands **********One visitor each winter to Aswan was the Aga Khan, who said that neck-high immersions in the dry, soft desert sands eased his rheumatism. When he died in 1959, his wife, the Begum, had a huge mausoleum built for him that stands imposingly in a desert setting just above their residence on the left bank of the Nile. **********Dr. Zaki envisions the construction of a spa in Aswan to help those with rheumatism enjoy the winter sun, the dryness and the unpolluted air. **********Near the Aga Khan's mausoleum, a gang of camel drivers stands waiting for customers to take a ride. A felucca with a few tourists docks near them, and the travelers are besieged and beseeched to ride the lumpy, bad-tempered beasts. **********One of the camels refuses to heed his master and lopes off toward a village nestled in sand dunes. Others shudder and show off their big, bad teeth. ''Fine ride, fine ride,'' a young driver says. **********The camel is ordered to get up from its crouch, and the ungainly creature rises with a snort on lumpy legs. It is the end of another slow day, and the young driver drags his beast homeward. **********''Tomorrow it may be better,'' he says in Arabic, echoing the hopes of others in Aswan who want the hordes of tourists to descend again.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/20/world.main_headline: Botha Opens Talks On Future of Namibia
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/20/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Botha Opens Talks On Future of Namibia
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/20/world.body_text: **********West Africa, Nov. 19 (Reuters) - Prime Minister P.W. Botha of South Africa began two days of talks here today aimed at breaking the impasse over the future of South-West Africa, which is also known as Namibia. **********Apart from settling the fate of the present internal government of Namibia, the talks could have an important impact on wider discussions in Washington next week between the South African Foreign Minister, Roelof F. Botha, and Secretary of State George P. Shultz. **********At the heart of the impasse is South Africa's repeated demand, so far supported by Washington, that Cuban troops leave Angola before an internationally acceptable settlement can be reached in Namibia, which is ruled by South Africa in defiance of United Nations resolutions.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/05/world.main_headline: SAILOR'S LAMENT: WHAT DID THEY DO TO SHANGHAI?
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/05/world.print_headline: SAILOR'S LAMENT: WHAT DID THEY DO TO SHANGHAI?
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/05/world.body_text: **********Once Shanghai ranked among the world's rowdiest ports of call, with a licentiousness that outstripped even its own reputation. **********A sailor on shore leave found no lack of diversion, from gambling casinos like Delmonte's or Farren's to nightclubs and dance halls like Ciro's or Roxy's, which normally closed at 6 A.M. but would stay open later if the patrons requested it. **********Sleazier sport was found in the countless dives, opium dens and brothels near the waterfront. Beggars tugged at the jackets of carousers prowling the red-light district off Fuzhou Street and sailors settled quarrels with knives in ''blood alley,'' under the indifferent gaze of hard-eyed young prostitutes. **********Muggings were commonplace. And the practice of bashing a tipsy sailor unconscious and sending him out involuntarily on another ship occurred often enough to spawn the expression ''to be shanghaied.'' **********But Asia's most notorious dens of vice closed down after the Communists took over Shanghai in 1949. Some 30,000 prostitutes were packed off for re-education and several hundred thousand opium addicts were detoxified. The old racecourse was razed to make way for a people's square and park, with only some bleachers left to evoke the thrill of a bet on the right horse. Communist Morality **********Communist morality has turned Shanghai into what may well be the world's most prudish major port of call.  ''If it was paradise, it was only for adventurers,'' said Gu Yiping, director of the Shanghai International Seamen's Club. ''For other people, it was hell. Our Shanghai people suffered a lot.'' **********Mr. Gu is responsible for entertaining sailors when they reach China's biggest port after a long voyage. His club, which was founded in 1950 as the seamen's home, works hard to provide wholesome fun. **********There are cheap tickets to local operas and acrobatic shows. There are volleyball and basketball games. There are tours of local factories and communes. There are trips to the zoo. The club even hosts get-acquainted parties where arriving sailors can get to know other arriving sailors. **********''Recently we sent some chefs to American ships to let them have a taste of Chinese food,'' said Mr. Gu, who explained that it was not easy to ferry Chinese cuisine across the harbor. The chefs, who were used to cooking with gas, were also upset to find the galleys equipped with electric stoves. **********''But we solved this difficulty,'' Mr. Gu reported. ''That was a specific demonstration of our friendship with American friends.'' The seamen's club, which is housed in the elegant old Russian Consulate on the waterfront where the fetid Suzhou Creek pours into the muddy Huangpu River, hardly lacks for business. Visited by 30,550 Seamen in 1981 **********Shanghai now handles 85 million tons of cargo a year. Last year 30,550 seamen from 85 countries sailed in on 1,135 foreign vessels, Mr. Gu said. His club tallied up 90,000 separate visits. It is now expanding by building another 12-story building next door. **********Sometimes the seamen get a bit out of hand. In a brawl last August about 20 sailors demolished the ground-floor bar at the respectable Shanghai Mansions Hotel just down the street from the seamen's club.  One Shanghai resident described it as a ''Hollywood-style punchup'' with policemen being flung through plate-glass windows when they arrived to restore order. **********Municipal authorities reacted by closing down the coffee shops and bars of Shanghai's three major hotels. Now a sailor can get a drink only in the paneled bar of the seamen's club, which opens at 5 P.M.  and closes at 11 P.M. The bar serves ice cream sodas and pineapple ice cream along with alcoholic beverages. **********The bartenders keep a solicitous watch over their charges. ''We are not capitalists,'' Mr. Gu said. ''We don't try to make them drink too much. We want to preserve their health. We want to love and protect them. The majority of seamen understand our rules.'' **********Mr. Gu, who was never a sailor himself, has no nostalgia for the bad old days. Today a seaman rarely gets robbed in Shanghai, he said, while ''it was a common scene before liberation.'' He added, ''I saw such rascals myself.'' The ban on prostitution extends even to casual fraternization between foreign seamen and local women. **********''After liberation the prostitutes were given medical treatment and were taught special skills to make a living, so they could find jobs and get married,'' Mr. Gu recalled. ''Of course most of these people were innocent. There was nothing for them in the countryside so they came to the city, but there was no work for them here.'' Ideological Journals in Library **********If seamen stay ashore too late to get back to their ships they can sleep in one of the club's 40 tidy beds for about $4.50 a night.  Before retiring they can visit the club's reading room, which is stocked with copies of Beijing Review, China Reconstructs, Social Sciences in China, and other publications of an ideologically uplifting nature. **********Mr. Gu led a visitor on a tour of the club's facilities, which include a table-tennis table, three billiard tables, a chess room and two small restaurants. The hall displays photographs from the recent 12th Communist Party congress. There is also a shop selling guitars, stuffed animals and local souvenirs, all at prices that Mr. Gu said were cheaper than in the hotels. **********''We don't intend to make money deliberately,'' he explained. ''We make just enough to support ourselves.'' The employees outnumbered the seamen in the club, but Mr. Gu explained that it would get busier later that evening. Outside the bedrooms a sailor in dungarees slouched in a chair staring glumly into space. In one restaurant a half-dozen other men lingered over their cups of coffee. **********Mr. Gu acknowledged a risk that the seamen might import their own Western decadence into Shanghai. He said that the club ran regular education sessions for its employees to inoculate them against bourgeois contamination. **********''We have an open door policy but we can resist their way of life,'' explained Chao Bufa, an earnest young staff member.  A large display case in the foyer, lit up like a jeweler's window, offered lost items for sailors to claim when they next reached port.  As proof of Shanghai's vaunted new incorruptibility, the display included, along with some umbrellas, sunglasses and dolls, a disposable all point pen.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/23/world.main_headline: TRUDEAU USES TV BLITZ TO SPELL OUT NATION'S PLIGHT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/23/world.print_headline: TRUDEAU USES TV BLITZ TO SPELL OUT NATION'S PLIGHT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/23/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau went on national television three times this week to dramatize the depth of his nation's economic problems and to urge Canadians to work together to solve them. **********''In our country, as we face winter, men and women - almost a million and a half of them - are without jobs,'' he said in the third 15-minute prime-time broadcast Thursday night. ''Many more live with the worry that your jobs will be next.'' **********Despite Mr. Trudeau's warning that Canada is ''in trouble,'' he offered no new policy directons, instead urging adherence to the Government's existing voluntary restraint program. In addition, he blamed the worldwide economic downturn for many of Canada's difficulties. **********Reactions to Broadcasts Differ **********Although public opinion polls have not yet been completed, the effect of the broadcasts seemed to be to leave supporters pleased, opponents angered and many others somewhat confused. **********Joe Clark, leader of the Progressive Conservative Party, said he did not plan to ''dignify'' the speeches by exercising his legal right to reply on the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation channel that broadcast the Prime Minister's speeches. Ed Broadbent, leader of the New Democratic Party, called Mr. Trudeau's telvision blitz ''a farce in three parts.'' **********In the cozy, mainly working-class bar of the slightly seedy Spadina Hotel here, an argument raged among customers about whether they should even to listen to the first speech. ''Do you like him that much?'' the bartender asked. ''I'm not interested in what he's got to say.'' **********When the speech ended, however, a man at the bar said, ''A terrific speech - he sounded like Churchill.'' Trudeau's Popularity Sagging **********The speeches came at a time when Canadian unemployment exceeds 12 percent, inflation is nearly double levels in the United States and industrial production is flagging. They also came when Mr. Trudeau's popularity is sagging, with the most recent Gallup Poll showing only 28 percent of Canadians approving his performance and 61 percent disapproving. **********The Prime Minister's talks appeared designed to instill confidence among Canadians, in the manner of President Roosevelt's fireside chats during the Depression. Although aides confirmed this was the purpose, they sought to minimize this aspect of the talks for fear it would overstate the gravity of Canada's economic difficulties, spurring unnecessary anxiety. **********Somewhat surprisingly, Mr. Trudeau's remarks appeared directed more toward Canadian inflation, which has recently shown signs of abating, than toward unemployment, which is naggingly persistent.  This week the Government announced that Canada's consumer price index dropped to a 10.4 percent annual rate in September, the lowest level in 26 months. That marked the fourth month in a row that the inflation rate declined. Example Set by Government **********Essentially, the Prime Minister argued that cutting the inflation rate would lower costs, allowing companies to make productivity improvements, which would spur growth and eventually jobs. Mr.  Trudeau asked the public to cooperate by voluntarily emulating the Government's own mandatory plan to allow Government workers only 6 percent wage increases this year and 5 percent raises next year. **********As such, Mr. Trudeau ruled out wage and price controls as unduly coercive. ''Controls would declare, with the force of law, that Canadians cannot trust Canadians,'' he said in his second talk. He also rejected large cuts in the national deficit, arguing that spending cuts would be inhumane at a time of soaring unemployment. **********Large-scale budget reductions, he said, ''brutally wring inflation out of the system and in the process impoverish many more Canadians.'' He said this was the course of action that caused ''the Great Depression and 10 lost years.'' CBC Is Criticized **********In addition to the outcry of opposition politicians, the CBC was hit by sharp criticism for broadcasting the talks on three consecutive nights. The network's president, Pierre Juneau, who was appointed by the Prime Minister, called a news conference to defend the network. **********Moreover, a group of about 50 CBC employees signed a petition protesting the network's decision to broadcast the speeches without accompanying commentary by its own reporters, and CBC technicians protested the decision to employ a Toronto advertising agency to tape the shows, rather than CBC employees. **********For some CBC employees, however, the whole affair ended with a laugh. On the CBC's public affairs program ''The Journal'' on Thursday night, a program that is usually devoted to straight news and analysis, an actor poked fun at the Prime Minister's fireside style in a moderately bawdy routine.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/19/world.main_headline: BUENOS AIRES SAYS FALKLANDS' TRUCE IS STILL UNCERTAIN
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/19/world.print_headline: BUENOS AIRES SAYS FALKLANDS' TRUCE IS STILL UNCERTAIN
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/19/world.body_text: **********Argentina said today that a ''total cessation of hostilities'' with the British would be reached only when Britain withdrew its forces from the Falkland Islands, lifted its blockade of the Argentine coast and ended its economic sanctions. **********Responding to British demands for a formal pledge to end all hostilities, the Government said in a note to the United Nations that all Argentine forces were currently observing a cease-fire. But it said the truce would be ''precarious'' as long as Britain maintained its occupation of the islands, its blockade and its sanctions. **********However, in what Foreign Ministry officials here described as an indication that Argentina would foresake military operations for the immediate future, the note asked for the renewal of United Nations negotiations ''for a definitive solution to the dispute.'' **********No Response From Britain **********There was no immediate response to the Argentine stand by Britain, which had sought through its demands to insure that there would be no further military action by Argentina's planes or ships after the surrender of its ground forces in the Falklands on Monday. **********The British confirmed today that they and the Argentines had reached agreement on the return home of most of the more than 10,000 Argentine prisoners being held in the Falklands. The Argentine Foreign Ministry announced Thursday night that an agreement had been reached and that the operation would begin today, but Britain initially said only that it would consider an Argentine proposal to that effect. Foreign Minister Nicanor Costa Mendez said 4,500 Argentine soldiers captured on the Falklands were en route today to Argentine ports aboard the British ship Canberra, a luxury liner that had been converted by the British task force into a troop ship. The British ferry Norland was said to be carrying 1,000 others. Interim President Sworn In **********British officials still insist that about a thousand selected prisoners, principally officers and commanders, will be held rather than returned with the rest because Argentina has not promised to cease hostilities over the Falklands, which its troops seized April 2. **********Today, the Interior Minister, Maj. Gen. Alfredo St. Jean, was sworn in as interim President of Argentina, replacing Lieut. Gen. Leopoldo Galtieri, who resigned Thursday as a result of the defeat in the war for the Falklands. General Galtieri, as army chief, had also been a member of the ruling three-man junta, and he was replaced in that capacity by Maj. Gen. Cristino Nicolaides. **********The Government crisis, however, remained unsolved; the military was still divided on a permanent President.  The Argentine note was addressed to the President of the United Nations Security Council, and Gustavo Figueroa, the third-ranking official in the Argentine Foreign Ministry, said in an interview that, ''in general terms, this is our answer'' to Britain. He said no other replies were planned. **********Senior Government officials stressed that the note was meant to be conciliatory in calling for the United Nations role and acknowledging that hostilities are in fact over for the time being. The counter demands, one official said, were ''to keep a little door open so that we can maintain some small pressure on the British to give us the islands back.'' **********He said it was impossible for Argentina ''to give in and completely say that all is lost, but in reality there is nothing we can do militarily for the time being.'' He said that if the British ''read bewteen the lines, they will know what we mean.'' **********A Western diplomat close to the issue said there appeared to be little chance that Britain would find the position taken in the Argentine note acceptable. He called the note ''a dodge'' and said the British had no intention of withdrawing their forces from the Falklands. **********In its note today, Argentina called on the Security Council ''to pursue its efforts to obtain from the United Kingdom full compliance'' with Security Council Resolutions 502 and 505. **********The first calls for an end to hostilities and for negotiations, plus the withdrawal of Argentine troops from the islands. The second, calls for Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar to help negotiate a solution. Neither resolution, however, says anything about the small British force that was in the Falklands before the Argentines seized the islands, and Britain presumably could argue that neither resolution prohibits the stationing of British forces there. **********Foreign Ministry officials said that they favored a resumption of the Secretary General's mission because, they said, he seemed fair and well versed in the issues. They said Argentina would continue to seek soverignty over the Falklands. **********Senior Argentine military officers said that it was the resignation of President Galtieri that opened the way for the note to the United Nations. General Galtieri, they said, wanted to continue the war but had been opposed by the overwhelming majority of army generals who were involved in the meetings that have been held since Monday to formulate an Argentine response to Britain. **********The note was finally approved this morning by the ruling three-man junta, including General Nicolaides, the officials said. They said that General Galtieri also registered his approval. **********General Nicolaides was formally inducted into the junta in a somber ceremony tonight. This morning he was formally installed as Commander in Chief of the army. Troops En Route to Argentina **********The note to the United Nations said: ''There exists in fact, given the present circumstances, a cessation of hostilities, which Argentina observes, but this cessation will be precarious so long as the British attitude as evidenced by the military occupation, the blockade and the economic aggression subsists. **********''The total cessation of hostilities will be reached only at the moment the United Kingdom agrees to lift the naval and aerial blockade and the economic sanctions referred to before and when it withdraws its military occupation forces from the islands, the naval task force and the nuclear submarines that it has deployed in the waters of the region.'' **********The Almirante Irizar, a converted icebreaker, arrived this morning with about 400 wounded aboard at the southern Argentine port of Comodoro Rivadavia, 1,100 miles south of here. The wounded were taken in ambulances through blocked-off streets to local hospitals.  Military sources said that two of the wounded soldiers died en route from the islands.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/17/busin.body_text: **********World natural gas reserves are sufficient to meet demand for the next 170 years, the president of the 41-nation International Gas Union said today. E. Giorgis told a trade convention that demand for natural gas had grown rapidly over the past two decades, totaling 52.5 trillion cubic feet in 1980. Mr.  Giorgis said recent studies indicated total recoverable world gas reserves amounted to 9,835 trillion cubic feet, a third of which had already been proven. Over the next 40 years no more than a third of these reserves would be used, he said. Natural gas accounts for 20 percent of international primary energy demand.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/20/busin.body_text: **********The United Technologies Corporation reported yesterday that an extraordinary gain of $40 mildion caused earnings in the second quarter to rise 18.6 percent as sales slipped 1.4 percent. **********The tax-free gain resulted from an exchange of 1.92 million shares of United Technologies common stock and cash for about $165 million of its debentures. **********Excluding the extraordinary gain, net income in the latest three months would have been 14.3 percent lower, to $105.3 million from $122.8 million. **********The Hartford, Conn., company said that net income in the latest three months advanced to $145.6 million, or $2.45 a share, including 77 cents from the extraordinary gain and based on 52.3 million shares outstanding. In the second quarter of 1981, net income amounted to $122.8 million, or $2.08 a share, based on 49.4 million shares outstanding. Sales in the second quarter fell, to $3.51 billion from $3.56 billion. **********Harry J. Gray, chairman and president of the conglomerate, said that the slow economy continued to restrain the company's operating income during the latest quarter. He also said that the company's research and development outlays were up and that the company had programs in operation that were ''improving productivity and profitablity.'' **********''Earnings were in line with what I had expected,'' said Alan Benasuli, analyst at Drexel Burnham Lambert. ''They had a lower tax rate, which helped results. However, they are getting hurt on outright engine sales as well as on sales of spare parts and general aviation engines.'' **********On June 15, United Technologies exchanged 1.9 million of its commmon shares and cash for about $165 million of its debentures held by Goldman, Sachs & Company. A tax-free gain of $40 million resulted from the transaction, which reduced United Technologies's debt-tototal-capital ratio by two percentage points. **********Unted Technologies develops and builds high-technology products for worldwide commercial and Government markets. These products include Pratt & Whitney jet engines, Carrier air-conditioners, Otis elevators and escalators, Sikorsky helicopters and Mostek semiconductors. Monsanto **********The Monsanto Company reported that the withdrawal from certain businesses caused net income in the second quarter to slip 8.1 percent, to $86.2 million, or $2.17 a share, from $93.8 million, or $2.35 a share, in the second quarter of 1981. Sales dropped 12.9 percent, to $1.62 billion, from $1.86 billion. **********Monsanto, based in St. Louis, said that net earnings in the latest three months included a charge of 22 cents a share associated with the company's previously announced withdrawal from the European lowdensity polyethelene business. **********Foreign-currency translation and exchange gains of 61 cents a share were included in the second quarter of 1981, Monsanto said, compared with the inclusion of a loss of 1 cent a share in the results of the latest quarter. **********For the first six months of this year, net income dropped 13.4 percent, to $233.7 million, or $5.88 a share, from $269.8 million, or $7.16 a share, in the first six months a year earlier. Sales slipped 10.6 percent, to $3.36 billion, from $3.76 billion. Burlington **********Burlington Northern Inc., based in St. Paul, announced that net income in the second quarter, aided by income from discontinued operations of $103.4 million, rose sharply to $121.4 million, or $3.20 a share, from $39.4 million, or 99 cents a share, in the second quarter of 1981, which included $4 million of discontinued operations. Sales dropped 6.3 percent, to $1.04 billion, from $1.11 billion. **********The income from discontinued operations in the second quarter came primarily from the sale of Burlington Northern Air Freight for $102.2 million, or $2.74 a share. **********For the first six months of 1982, Burlington Northern's earnings increased 22.9 percent, to $159 million, or $4.15 a share, from $129.4 million, or $3.32 a share, in the first half of 1981. Sales fell 8.5 percent, to $2.05 billion from $2.24 billion. American Electric **********The American Electric Power Company announced that net income in the latest three months dropped 12.9 percent, to $63.7 million, or 40 cents a share, from $73.1 million, or 47 cents a share, in the second quarter a year earlier. Revenue fell 5.7 percent, to 990 million from $1.05 billion. **********The Columbus, Ohio, concern, the largest utility holding company in the nation, said that earnings were adversely affected by the continued depressed economy in the seven-state region served by the company as well as the mild weather during spring. Ethyl **********The Ethyl Corporation reported that its North Sea oil and gas operations helped lift earnings in the second quarter of 1982 by 13.4 percent, to $27.9 million, or $1.39 a share, from $24.6 million, or $1.24 a share, in the corresponding quarter last year. Sales, however, slipped 7.9 percent, to $417.6 million, from $453.4 million. **********For the first six months of this year, the Richmond-based petroleum and industrial chemicals company said that net income fell 1.5 percent, to $45.1 million, or $2.25 a share, from $45.8 million, or $2.25 a share, in the first half of 1981. Sherwin-Williams **********The Sherwin-Williams Company said that despite a decline in paint profits, net income in the second quarter rose 22.4 percent, to $18 million, or $1.75 a share, from $14.7 million, or $1.45 a share, in the comparable period last year. Sales advanced 31.1 percent, to $523.2 million, from $399.1 million. **********For the first six months, the diversified Cleveland-based coatings producer said that net income increased 15.9 percent, to $19 million, or $1.83 a share, from $16.4 million, or $1.60 a share, in the first half of 1981. Sales rose 30.9 percent, to $925.8 million, from $707.3 million. ---- Tables, pages D11-D12.
