https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/02/busin.main_headline: WHY A BRITISH PENSION FUND INVESTS IN U.S. PROPERTY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/02/busin.print_headline: ABOUT REAL ESTATE; WHY A BRITISH PENSION FUND INVESTS IN U.S. PROPERTY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/02/busin.body_text: **********Wendy Luscombe is in charge of a $400 million portfolio of American properties for the British Coal Board pension fund, one of the largest pension funds in Europe. She speaks so softly that it is often difficult to hear her, but her message rings clear. **********''We demand a little blood,'' she said when asked about real estate deals the pension fund is making in the United States. Along with other institutional investors, the Coal Board fund is one of the forces that have altered the development business in this country over the last few years. **********Developers of office buildings, shopping centers or industrial properties were once independent operators who took all the risks and rewards of building, and they used borrowed money to do it. Not any more. With the demise of the fixed-rate mortgage, lenders insisted on becoming partners with developers. Now lenders want a share of the equity, a larger piece of the profits and ''a little blood,'' as Miss Luscombe says. **********Believing that property investments in the United States offer a better return than real estate in Britain or other European countries, the Coal Board started its drive here in 1979 when it acquired the Continental Illinois Real Estate Investment Trust. The Coal Board formed a subsidiary called Pan American Properties, with headquarters in Manhattan, for its American real estate. Miss Luscombe, who studied at Oxford as a chartered surveyor, became president of Pan American Properties in January 1981. She worked with a major British developer and the Chase Bank in London before joining the Coal Board. **********Pan American's best-known property is Washington's Watergate complex, where the pension fund has a 50 percent interest. But Pan American has larger investments in various shopping centers. **********Although it has acquired nothing in New York City, Pan American now owns, partly or entirely, 39 properties, including office buildings, apartments and industrial buildings, from California to Florida and New Jersey. **********In New Jersey, Pan American has office buildings of about 150,000 square feet in Parsippany, Piscataway and Montvale as well as a 250,000-square-foot industrial building in Moonachie. **********The Coal Board's real estate holdings in England are valued at about $2 billion, Miss Luscombe said, but in England the board has not bought any properties for about three years. Instead the board is developing its own properties and has become one of the country's leading developers. **********The Coal Board has no plans to become a developer in the United States, though. ''It's important you don't run before you can walk,'' Miss Luscombe said. ''It took me about a year just to learn the language here. When someone said a property was a 'good deal for a European,' they meant it was a rip-off.'' **********In addition to making higher profits in the United States, she said, the Coal Board decided it wanted to expand in this country to diversify its portfolio. **********Pan American now limits the size of its investment in any property to $30 million or $40 million. Miss Luscombe does not favor ''glamour cities,'' such as Houston, for investments. **********''We've always said we will not invest in Houston,'' she said.  ''Literally, you can throw - for lack of a better word - a property up in 18 months in Houston. There's a tremendous demand, but supply always goes out to meet it.'' Prime space in Houston, she continued, ''rents for about $23 a square foot, which is not all that different from rents in Cleveland.'' **********Instead Pan American prefers properties in what Miss Luscombe calls ''second-tier cities.'' Some examples are Tampa, Fla.; Winston-Salem, N.C., or Des Moines. She likes state capitals, which ''always have a good underpinning of Federal employees,'' and any city with a university. ''There's often a synergy from unversities because of research,'' she said. **********Miss Luscombe's analysis of the Manhattan office market is a model of caution. She said there ''could be some softening, not so much from new construction but from nonexpansion.'' As leases expire, businesses face a doubling or tripling of rents, she said, ''which may cause a lot of companies to decentralize'' and move part of their operations out of the city. **********The high rents in New York, she predicted, will also force businesses to reduce their space requirements. ''I think you'll see a lot of pushing the desks together,'' she said. ''You see it in London. Here you walk into offices now, and there are acres of room between desks.'' **********In London, she said, top office space rents for about $100 a square foot, although the method of calculation is different from most leases in New York City. Space in London is usually rented on a net lease, meaning the tenant pays separately for all utilities, taxes and maintenance. **********Miss Luscombe noted the growing power of financiers in real estate transactions. ''Developers may in the end become glorified project managers,'' she said. ''There will be a lot more merchant developers - developers who build and sell out. The emphasis has changed. The financiers have the strong hand now.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/31/busin.body_text: **********The depressed steel industry slipped further last week as United States mill operations in the week ended last Saturday sank to 39.9 percent of capacity from the previous week's 40.5 percent, which had been the year's low, according to an industry trade group. **********Total output fell to 1.178 million tons last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute said. **********The capacity utilization figure was the lowest since 1938, when the yearly average was 39.6 percent and no weekly figures were kept. the group said. Employment, off to 280,000, is also at the lowest level since those statistics were first kept in 1933.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/19/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Finding Small Growth Stocks
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/19/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Finding Small Growth Stocks
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/19/busin.body_text: **********HINDSIGHT beats foresight, as the expression goes, but 20-20 vision may turn up small growth companies that will please investors seeking profits. **********Lord Abbott & Company, a $3.5 billion money manager based in New York City, looks for 20 percent earnings growth and a return on equity of 20 percent or better in choosing shares for the Lord Abbott Developing Growth Fund. Daniel Cooney, executive vice president and portfolio manager of the fund, said that shares meeting these tests have helped the $125 million fund post superior returns over the past five years. **********Net asset value is up 178.7 percent since September 1977. After an 8 1/2 percent initial sales charge, that gain adjusts to 163.5 percent. The latter represents a gain of 21 percent annually and compares with an annual percentage rise of 10 for Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. **********Mr. Cooney notes that growth is easier for companies starting at a lower base. That is, a $10 million concern can more readily reach $20 million in sales than a $150 million company can hit $300 million. **********He is quite interested in companies with sales of $10 million - less so in $150 million companies. He weighs selling companies that reach that level, as their greatest growth may be over. **********In explaining his bias against even larger old-line companies, he notes that with age comes bureaucracy - companies move more slowly.  But older companies create opportunities for smaller companies, which often enter niches that the older companies have overlooked. **********Mr. Cooney is especially excited about prospects for his kind of company today because there is much venture capital around and because new niches are being created at a rapid rate in a changing economy. **********Still, he warns that shares of small companies are quite volatile.  Thus, his fund is highly diversified and gaited to the long term. He often holds shares for many years, until a company starts to mature. **********The fund is in many different niches, from retail trade to miscellaneous manufacturing. As might be expected in the computer age, 40 percent of assets are in technology companies. **********Since he seeks high growth - and the higher the growth rate the higher the multiple a company bears - he pays higher price/earnings multiples than those investing in slow growth companies. P/E's of up 15 or more are not uncommon in his portfolio. **********He adds, though, that most holdings were bought at substantially lower P/E's - before the market took off in August. Here are the fund's largest holdings, which he would still buy at today's prices. **********Verbatim, the fund's largest position, is a maker of floppy disks - flexible recording disks. He likes Verbatim because it supplies a product that is going into small-business, personal, and word processing computers - all of which are growing at rates in excess of 25 percent a year. Verbatim earned $1.80 a share in the June 1982 fiscal year. With earnings up 70 percent in the most recent quarter, street sources say that Verbatim may earn $2.50 a share in the fiscal year ending June 1983. The current P/E relative to that estimate is about 14. **********Pic-N-Sav is a California and Arizona specialist in discontinued merchandise. The chain buys close-outs, and in some cases at a fraction of cost, for resale at about 50 percent of the normal retail price. The stores offer clothing, tools, sporting goods and canned goods. The company earned $1.21 a share last year. Street sources expect $1.50 a share in the current year for a P/E of 15 times. **********The Tandon Corporation makes small floppy disk drives and small hard disk drives. Mr. Cooney likes the company for the same reasons as Verbatim. Tandon earned 70 to 75 cents a share in the September year. The company may earn $1.25 a share this fiscal year for a P/E of 18. **********Lawson Products distributes industrial maintenance items such as nuts, bolts and drills. Mr. Cooney expects the company to carve out an ever larger share of this highly fragmented market. Net profit margins after taxes are up to 11 percent. (A 10 percent or better net after tax is regarded as exceptional.) Lawson earned $2.02 a share in 1981 and is expected to earn $2.25 a share in this recession year. In 1983, earnings should reach $2.75 a share, a P/E ratio of 11. **********Food Town Stores is a regional supermarket chain in a strong growth area of North Carolina and is not to be confused with the Food Town chain in the Northeast. It enjoyed an unusually high return on equity - 25 percent - in the calendar year 1981. The average food chain has a return on equity half as large. Food Town earned $2.24 a share in 1981, should do $2.45 a share in 1982 and $3.20 a share in 1983 for a 15 P/E. **********Electro-Biology Inc. offers medical equipment to aid the knitting of slow healing leg and arm bones. The company earned 31 cents a share in the calendar year 1981, should earn 95 cents a share in 1982 and about $2.15 a share in 1983 for a P/E of 17. **********Molex Inc. make terminals and connectors for the electrical and electronics industries. This company is ''highly efficient,'' Mr.  Cooney says, because its after-tax margins exceed 10 percent. The company earned $3.15 a share in the June 1982 fiscal year and should earn $3.60 a share in the current fiscal year for a P/E of 14.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/02/busin.body_text: **********More businesses failed last week than in any week since the Depression, the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, a business information concern, said yesterday. **********It said 696 commercial and industrial companies either were forced to close or filed for reorganization in the week ended last Thursday, up from 572 the previous week and more than double the 280 recorded in the comparable 1981 week. **********The latest figure is the highest since January 1932, when the weekly average was 799, according to Rowena Wyant, a vice president in Dun & Bradstreet's business economics division. She added, however, that failures as a percentage of total businesses in operation were far greater in the early 1930's. **********For the year to date, Dun & Bradstreet has recorded 15,829 business failures, up 47 percent from the similar period a year ago. At the current rate of 466 failures a week this year, the post-World War II peak of 17,075 failures, recorded in 1961, will be surpassed by the middle of September.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/08/busin.body_text: **********TESTS often try to measure how smart people are. But in the future, the tests themselves might be ''smart'' because they will be taken on computer terminals instead of on paper. **********Such computerized examinations will be able to do things the paper versions cannot. Instead of asking the same questions to each person, the computer will be able to decide on questions as the test is in progress, tailoring the test to each individual. Computerized tests can score themselves instantly. **********At the same time, however, the advent of computerized testing is likely to fuel new controversies about the proper use of such tests as qualification for school or employment. **********The armed forces are working toward converting to computers, starting in 1984, the test that is used to qualify and classify recruits. It will be one of the first uses of a technique known as adaptive testing. **********In such a test, the computer chooses each question from a large bank of items based on how well the person has done on the previous questions, thereby automatically adjusting the difficulty of the test to match the person's ability. The Educational Testing Service, although it is far from switching the Scholastic Aptitude Test to computers, is doing research on computerized tests in general and adaptive ones in particular. **********Adaptive testing promises to make tests shorter and more accurate than existing tests, say proponents like David J. Weiss, a psychology professor at the University of Minnesota. Existing tests always contain a lot of questions that are wasted because they are too hard or too easy. Words such as cat and dog are too simple to distinguish a good 10th-grade speller from a poor one. **********For that reason, test questions are usually geared for a particular level of ability. But that in turn leads to another shortcoming. A 10th-grade spelling test is good at distinguishing between the abilities of average 10th graders but not between two students who are well above average or well below average, Professor Weiss said. **********Adaptive testing can eliminate needless questions and yet measure all ability levels accurately, at least in theory. ''Our goal is to reduce the length of the exam by half,'' said James R. McBride, head of the computer adaptive testing project at the Navy Personnel Research and Development Center in San Diego. He said adaptive testing, by varying the questions to each recruit, would also cut down on the cheating. **********Adaptive testing, however, has its drawbacks. It takes large amounts of data to calibrate the difficulty level of each question and complex theory to decide which question should follow which.  Perhaps even more serious is the prospect that someone might challenge such a test in court, contending that it discriminates by not asking everyone the same questions. **********Political and legal concerns over such questions helped scuttle a plan by the Federal Office of Personnel Management to replace the Civil Service examination with an adaptive test and they might also impede the spread of such tests to corporations. **********''If you're not being challenged in court now, why stir up a hornet's nest?'' one Government expert said, summarizing the reaction he received from some companies. **********Even without adaptive testing, computerized tests can do other things that paper tests cannot. They can offer immediate results, which might be important in clinical psychological tests. The computers can test memory, by having something appear on the screen, then disappear, something that is difficult to test with paper. **********The Air Force is experimenting with using video game-like tests to measure hand-eye coordination and flying aptitude. Computers using artificial intelligence will increasingly do some of the diagnosis of psychological or medical tests, a task previously reserved for professionals. **********Several small companies are already coming to market with computerized testing systems. Psych Systems of Baltimore and Compu-Psych Inc. of Liberty, Mo., sell computerized tests systems mainly for use by clinical psychologists. **********The Assessment Systems Corporation of St. Paul is working with Psych Systems to develop an adaptive test for bank clerical employees. Continental Illinois National Bank is considering using the test. Delta Employment Systems of Dallas offers a computer interviewer. Applicants ''are more likely to tell the computer the truth than they are an interviewer,'' said B.J. Whitworth, senior vice president for administrative services for a division of the Hughes Tool Company, which uses the system. **********But test data can be abused. Unlike paper tests, for instance, computerized exams can also keep track of how long it takes to answer each question. Some vendors of new equipment assert that this could be a valuable piece of information - a delay in answering a question could indicate a job applicant might be trying to hide something. **********''The types of things an interviewer perceives from body language, we're able to quantify,'' said Walter J. Rychlewski 3d, president of Compu-Psych. Similarly the Delta computer interviewer alerts the employer to questions that took unusually long to answer. **********''That's a more absurd premise than the lie detector premise,'' said Norma Rollins, head of the privacy project of the New York Civil Liberties Union, which objects to lie detector tests because they can be inaccurate yet are accorded great weight. Computerization, she said, might mean that objectionable tests that should not be used as a basis for employment decisions would become more widespread and might also lend such tests ''an aura of objectivity.'' **********Proponents acknowledge such dangers, but predict that computerization is inevitable ''By the year 2000, paper and pencil tests should not exist anymore, anywhere,'' Professor Weiss predicted.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/24/world.print_headline: BRITISH GIVEN AN UNEXPECTED BONUS BY ARGENTINES' INACTIVITY ON GROUND; Military Analysis
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/24/world.body_text: **********For the past 48 hours British forces, according to reports from the South Atlantic, have methodically strengthened and expanded their beachhead in the Port San Carlos area while Argentine ground forces, according to British officials, have done little to oppose them. **********The result is that the British tactical position has improved dramatically. According to British estimates, they now have enough troops and weapons ashore to hold their beachhead against the maximum attack that Argentine forces could launch. **********Military analysts, here and at the headquarters of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in Brussels, are increasingly convinced that the next British landing will be closer to Stanley, possibly at Rookery Bay some miles to the east of the islands' capital. **********The Argentine command's problems are consequently complex, according to these analysts. A major Argentine attack now on the beachhead would leave beaches at Rookery Bay and elsewhere relatively unprotected. **********The opinion among qualified military and political sources in London is that the British Government, emboldened by the reported success of the landing and the retention of the initiative, now intends to move rapidly to engage the remaining Argentine forces on the islands. Radar on High Ground **********One of the reasons for British confidence is that during the two days of Argentine inactivity on the ground, the British commandos and paratroops in the beachhead have been able to establish their radar on the high ground on both banks of the San Carlos River. This will help the Rapier surface-to-air missile batteries within the British zone to react swiftly to any air attack on the troops. Shortage of Supplies **********British naval sources contend that one of the unrecognized dividends of the British blockade of the islands is that the Argentine forces cannot hope for adequate supply and reinforcement.  The sources conceded that one or two transports might get through to drop supplies to the forces at Stanley, but this would not make up for the ammunition, food and fuel already consumed. **********If, as some neutral observers argue, the next two days are critical, the British believe they are well prepared to meet any belated counterattack. According to reports from the area, the airfield at Port San Carlos has been improved and lengthened to take not only Harriers but helicopters carrying supplies and, if necessary, reinforcements. These shipments will relieve the navy of the risky job of moving close inshore to deliver supplies in landing craft and free those craft for use elsewhere. **********Any British advance from the beachhead, or Argentine counterattack from Stanley, would have to overcome the forbidding terrain. The ground between the two forces is covered with peat bogs cut by streams and lakes. There are no roads that far west on East Falkland Island and any counterattack would have to be delivered largely by marching infantry, under the fire of the 105-millimeter guns and 81-millimeter mortars now deployed in the beachhead. **********The ability of the Argentine personnel carriers to cross the terrain is questionable, according to British military sources.  Neutral intelligence sources say that the garrison at Stanley is equipped with personnel carriers, but there is no verifiable information on the number of these vehicles. Argentine Personnel Carriers **********One type is the Swiss-built Mowag Roland, which carries three or four infantrymen and is armed with 7.62-millimeter machine gun.  Another is the LARC, a version of the American DUKW, a World War II amphibious vehicle with large variable pressure tires. The third is the American LVTP-7, a tracked amphibious vehicle that can carry up to 25 infantrymen and a 20-millimeter cannon and machine gun. **********The British are confident that their Scorpion light tanks, armed with 76-millimeter guns, and the Scimitar armored cars, which have 30-millimeter guns, will be able to handle any armored personnel carriers the Argentines can get through the peat bogs for an attack. **********Both the British armored vehicles might have been designed for exactly this type of terrain. According to one authoritative source they exert less ground pressure than a marching infantryman and can cross bogs impassable to foot soldiers. **********Military analysts here believe that the Argentine force, if it attacks the beachhead, needs support by helicopters and Pucara light attack aircraft. **********At the start of the fighting Argentina had 42 Pucaras. Some have been lost to British Harriers and an undetermined number have been destroyed by bombing. Harriers, hitting the Goose Green airstrip today, reported a number of the light aircraft lying wrecked near the strip. **********Royal Air Force officers argue that no Argentine counterattack has what one called ''the faintest chance of success'' unless it is adequately supported by Mirage and Dagger jet fighters and A-4 attack planes flown from the mainland. Even if these aircraft are deployed, he said, they would have to contend with the winter storm now closing over the Falklands.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/19/busin.body_text: **********To the Business Editor: **********In ''Abandoning Its Original Mandate'' (Dec.5), William Winpisinger wrote that ''the advent of Labor Secretary Raymond Donovan and company has opened the department to severe charges of failing to serve the constituency its charter requires.'' Mr. Winpisinger starts off by declaring that labor leaders feel cut off and alienated from the Labor Department. While I admit that the relationship hasn't been as close as I would like, neither has it been as nonexistent as Mr. Winpisinger makes it out to be. Every day there are meetings between representatives of organized labor and officials at the department. **********I myself have met with leaders of the United Auto Workers, the American Federation of Government Employees, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.  Building Trades Department, the United Paperworkers, the International Ladies' Garment Workers Union, the Teamsters and the International Longshoremen's Association, to name only a few. **********Mr. Winpisinger also criticized the selection of Donald Dotson to fill a vacancy on the National Labor Relations Board. According to Mr. Winpisinger, Mr. Dotson, ''served in civilian life as a labor relations lawyer for a string of industrial companies.'' The N.L.R.B. is supposed to be an impartial body. What counts is the ability to render fair and impartial decisions. Is a former union employee any less likely to be impartial than a management employee?  Is fairness the exclusive property of organized labor? **********Mr. Winpisinger saved his harshest criticisms for the Occupational Safety and Health Administration. I know that OSHA will write a detailed response to the charges against it, so rather than beat a dead horse, I'll just say that our intent in OSHA is to provide workers with safe and healthy workplaces without crushing employers under a mountain of costs they can't bear. **********What disturbs me most about Mr. Winpisinger's commentary is what he chose not to say.  He didn't say that the Labor Department has increased its efforts to apprehend those who would steal from the Government, from businesses and from American workers. Our efforts have resulted in nearly 200 indictments and 150 convictions for fraud and other crimes. We've also won more than 130 indictments and nearly 100 convictions against racketeers. **********Mr. Winpisinger also didn't talk about legislation which saved the Black Lung Trust Fund. Thanks to this legislation, the fund's $1.5 billion debt will be repaid. **********Mr. Winpisinger conveniently overlooked many other accomplishments, including: the Jobs Training Partnership Act; a 45 percent reduction in the department's FY 1982 budget; elimination of audit backlogs; savings of over $2 billion in regulatory costs; increased emphasis on worker health and safety; hearing conservation programs; rule changes that will allow nearly half a million retirees to work up to 40 hours a month without losing pension benefits. RAYMOND J. DONOVAN, Secretary of Labor, Washington, D.C., Dec.13, 1982

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/23/world.main_headline: IRAN LAUNCHES THREE-PRONGED DRIVE NEAR IRAQI PORT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/23/world.print_headline: IRAN LAUNCHES THREE-PRONGED DRIVE NEAR IRAQI PORT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/23/world.body_text: **********Iran launched a new drive Wednesday night near this strategic Iraqi oil port, and Iraq said today that it had repulsed the two brigades that led the attack. **********It was Iran's third major drive since Iran moved into a new phase of the 22-month-old war a week and a half ago by thrusting across the border into Iraq. **********An official communique said that several thousand Iranians were killed and that many were captured in the three-pronged drive.  Sounds of the battle could be heard throughout the night in Basra, about 15 miles from the scene of the action.  Correspondents who visited the front line today saw about 15 wrecked tanks, most of them British Chieftains and Soviet T-55's. Other damaged tanks were seen being hauled on transporters past cheering crowds in Basra. **********Officers at the scene told correspondents that the Iranians had pushed about two and a half miles into Iraqi territory, but were beaten back by artillery fire. **********By midmorning the fighting had died down. A long line of Iraqi tanks could be seen at rest on the desert horizon just a few miles from Iranian territory. **********An Iraqi military communique said the Iranians launched three simultaneous thrusts. It said the Iranians were repelled in one sector while Iraqi troops counterattacked in the other two sectors.  The communique gave no Iraqi casualties, but a senior field commander said they were light. Hussein Meets With Aides **********President Saddam Hussein presided over a joint meeting today of Iraq's top three policy-making bodies - the Revolutionary Command Council, the leadership of the ruling Baath Party and the Cabinet. **********The Iraqi press agency said officials at the meeting discussed the military situation, including the latest Iranian attack, and a United Nations Security Council resolution this month calling for a ceasefire in the 22-month-old Persian Gulf war. **********The meeting was followed by a Defense Ministry announcement calling up additional Iraqi reservists. It said Iraqis born in 1953 should join the military starting Aug. 1. **********In a message to President Hussein, an unnamed commander quoted by the Iraqi press agency said: ''We have absorbed the enemy attack and strongly struck against its collapsing army and destroyed it. The bodies and wreckage that litter the battlefield testify to that.'' **********Iraq has that its forces have killed about 13,000 Iranian soldiers since Iran launched its latest offensive on July 13. One of the aims of the offensive, code-named Operation Ramadan, is the overthrow of the Iraqi Government **********The attack on Wednesday began at 10:30 P.M., only hours after the end of the Moslem holy month of Ramadan. ---- Iran Reports Gains in Iraq **********LONDON, July 22 (Reuters) - Iran said today that its army destroyed four Iraqi divisions Wednesday night in an attack east of the Iraqi port of Basra. **********Fighting continued along a 100-square-mile area of southern Iraq, the Teheran radio said.  An Iranian military communique said more than 2,000 Iraqi soldiers, including senior officers, were killed or wounded in the second phase of Operation Ramadan. **********In the new drive, the communique said, Iranian forces advanced an additional four miles into Iraq, reaching the Katiban River in flat, marshy country east of the disputed Shatt al Arab waterway separating the two countries. **********The Iranian press agency reported today that Iranian forces had advanced 13 miles inside Iraq.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/17/busin.body_text: **********Swissair plans to invest 2.5 billion Swiss francs, or $1.33 billion, between 1982 and 1985 on aircraft fleet renewal, according to its planning director, A.  Bernhardsgruetter said. **********However, a stagnant market for European airline seats means Swissair will not expand its fleet of 50 aircraft to 55 in the period as planned and will now delay delivery of some Airbus A-310 models on order, he added. **********Mr. Bernhardsgruetter, speaking at a meeting of the Swiss/German Economic Club, said that Swissair originally planned to take delivery of 10 Airbuses by 1986 but that delivery dates would now be delayed by one or two years. He added that Swissaircould see little possibility in the near future of taking up options on five new McDonnell Douglas DC-9-81 aircraft.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/03/busin.main_headline: MARINE MIDLAND IN PACT TO GAIN CENTRAN STAKE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/03/busin.print_headline: MARINE MIDLAND IN PACT TO GAIN CENTRAN STAKE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/03/busin.body_text: **********Marine Midland Banks Inc. has reached an agreement with the Centran Corporation of Cleveland under which Marine could eventually obtain a 37.5 percent interest in the Ohio bank holding company, the two banking concerns announced last night. **********The agreement is part of a growing acquisition trend in which the nation's banks are preparing for a possible change in Federal law that would permit interstate banking. This is the second such arrangement in which Marine is involved. The Chase Manhattan Bank and the Chemical Bank have made similar arrangements with out-of-state banks. **********Centran, the fifth-largest banking organization in Ohio, with assets of $3 billion, reported a net operating loss, before securities transactions, of $12.1 million in 1981. The net loss, after securities transactions, amounted to $22.2 million. Its principal bank is the Central National Bank of Cleveland, the third largest in the city. **********Under the agreement announced yesterday, Marine Midland will pump $70 million of capital into Centran through the purchase of newly issued, nonvoting preferred stock. The purchase would be made as soon as the agreement receives approval from the regulatory authorities. **********In addition, Marine Midland would receive warrants to buy 2.3 million shares of Centran common stock at a price of $30 a share. On Monday, Centran's stock was trading on over-the-counter markets at about $18 a share. Trading in the stock was halted yesterday. Confidence in Law Change **********But the warrants could not be used until there is a change in Federal laws that prohibit banks based in one state from owning banks in other states. It is uncertain if or when Congress might enact such a change, but Marine is confident it will occur in the not-toodistant future. **********The warrants will expire after 20 years, or earlier under some circumstances, which were not disclosed yesterday by the banks.  If the warrants are exercised, Marine Midland would wind up with 37.5 percent of Centran's common stock outstanding.  The preferred stock would have an average life of 15 1/2 years, and would carry a dividend rate that would rise to 12 percent, from 6 percent, over a five-year period. **********''We look forward to working with Centran and to a mutually beneficial partnership in the 1980's and beyond,'' said Edward W.  Duffy, Marine's chairman. With assets of $18.7 billion, Marine is the 14th-largest banking organization in the United States. **********This is the second such arrangement worked out by Marine, which is controlled by the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation of Hong Kong. Marine made a similar arrangement last year with the Industrial Valley Bank and Trust Company, which is based in Philadelphia. **********Banking industry sources said yesterday that Centran's problems appear to stem from a heavy investment in low-yielding, long-term securities -a situation similar to the one that is causing huge losses at savings institutions across the nation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/20/busin.main_headline: OIL PRODUCTION BY SAUDIS SLIPS TO 3-YEAR LOW
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/20/busin.print_headline: OIL PRODUCTION BY SAUDIS SLIPS TO 3-YEAR LOW
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/20/busin.body_text: **********Saudi Arabia, the world's largest oil exporter, has let its oil production slide about 500,000 barrels a day, to a level between 7 million and 7.5 million barrels a day, oil analysts and traders said yesterday. Since November, the Saudis have cut production by 3 million to 3.5 million barrels daily. **********Output is now at the lowest level in three years. The cuts are seen as a direct response to the current worldwide oversupply of crude oil, variously estimated at between two million and three million barrels a day. Also in reaction to the oversupply, the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) yesterday cut the selling price of oil produced on the Alaskan North Slope by up to $2.27 a 42-gallon barrel, and Exxon confirmed that it had reduced the wholesale price of heating oil, kerosene and diesel fuel by 5 cents to 6 cents a gallon. **********Flurry of Activity **********A sharp decline in the price of oil on the spot, or noncontract, market over the last several weeks has apparently touched off the flurry of activity. Platt's Oilgram Price Report, a trade publication, said that spot prices of oil are now running $3.50 to $5 a barrel below official selling prices. A shipment of Arab light oil, the grade of crude that OPEC uses as a reference for all its pricing decisions, for instance, changed hands yesterday for $29 a barrel, $5 below the list price. **********The response of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries was to intensify calls for an emergency meeting to halt the sharp drop in prices. Yesterday, Iraq's oil minister, Tayeh Abdul Karim, told the Iraqi Government press agency that a special OPEC meeting should be held this month to stop the spiraling price decline. **********OPEC's chairman, Sheik Mani Said al-Otaiba, the oil minister of the United Arab Emirates, who has the authority to call a special meeting, recently said that a time and place for a special session were being considered. The next regularly scheduled OPEC meeting is set for Quito, Ecuador, on May 20. **********Oil analysts said the two reasons for today's persistent oil glut are a sharp drop in demand and Saudi Arabia's continuing high level of output. **********Petroleum demand in the non-Communist world has dropped 10 percent over the last two years and is continuing to decline this year.  Meanwhile, Saudi Arabia has maintained a production level that other OPEC members believe is far too high. Analysts in the Arabian Gulf, for instance, calculate that Saudi production would have to fall to 5 million or 5.5 million barrels a day to end the glut. **********The country's production ceiling, however, is 8.5 million barrels, and policy makers have historically preferred to keep output fairly close to the targeted level. In addition, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, the Saudi oil minister, says Saudi Arabia needs to produce 6.2 million barrels a day to meet its immense revenue requirments.  However, Sheik Yamani has repeatedly said Saudi production would be allowed to fall to balance the market. 'Less Incentive' **********''The action is the direct result of current market circumstances,'' Gary Ross, research director of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, said. ''There is just less incentive to lift Saudi crude. **********Sohio said it had lowered the price on Alaskan North Slope oil sold on the Gulf Coast by $2.27 a barrel, to $29.75, and by $1.27 a barrel, to $29.50, for oil sold on the West Coast. The moves affect about 300,000 barrels of daily sales. Exxon and Atlantic Richfield, the other producers of oil on the North Slope, do not disclose prices. **********''This is, in fact, what we feel we have to price our Alaskan North Slope production at to be competitive,'' a Sohio spokesman said.  ''The move was made in response to pressures in the marketplace.'' **********Analysts say a domestic market free of price controls for more than a year has been leading the way in the current push to lower prices.  The Sohio action trails two rounds of reductions in the prices that United States oil companies were willing to pay for domestic crude.  The result, in part, has been drops in the price of heating oil and gasoline of as much as five cents gallon in 1982. **********The Exxon Company USA, the principal domestic subsidiary of the Exxon Corporation, for instance, this week cut its wholesale prices for heating oil, kerosene and diesel fuel by from 5 cents to 6 cents a gallon at various East Coast and Gulf Coast terminals. **********The Saudi moves, as usual, were not announced. The four principal companies that produce Saudi oil - the Aramco partners of Exxon, Mobil, Texaco and Socal - are under strict instructions from the Riyadh Government not to comment on Saudi production. However, they observe that it varies daily because of technical considerations in the oilfields and the schedule of tanker arrivals. Thus, average production for any particular month is not known until the month has ended. **********James Tanner, editor of Petroleum Information International, a trade publication, said that output was believed to have averaged 7.2 million to 7.3 million barrels a day over the last week, sinking as low as 6.8 million barrels on one day. **********How long the current glut, with its downward tug on prices, will last is the question that consumers, oil companies and independent analysts are asking. Oil companies have significantly drawn down their inventories, suggesting resurgence in demand might develop.  Currently, worldwide stocks are approximately 100 million barrels a day greater than normal, compared with 500 million barrels a year ago. **********However, evidence is mounting that, amid high interest rates and ample supplies, companies no longer feel compelled to maintain such high inventory levels. It costs about 75 cents a month to carry a barrel of oil. **********One oil company planner suggested that the amount of oil that companies feel they need to keep on hand may have dropped irreversibly.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/26/busin.main_headline: EMPLOYMENT AGENCIES SUFFER AS JOBS THEY CAN OFFER DROP
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/26/busin.print_headline: EMPLOYMENT AGENCIES SUFFER AS JOBS THEY CAN OFFER DROP
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/26/busin.body_text: **********Benson Employment Inc., a small New York agency, is having no problem attracting job seekers, unemployment being what it is.  Its problem, with fewer jobs than ever to offer its applicants, is that its commissions are tumbling, its profits are sliding and, in January, it had to let go one of its counselors - one-quarter of its entire staff. **********Similarly, Mahoney Placement Services Inc., one of the largest employment companies in the country, has 25 percent fewer openings to offer its applicants than a year ago, and it, too, is paring its own staff, through attrition. ''Companies aren't hungry to make that hire,'' said Thomas Murphy, Mahoney's vice president. **********Layoffs and Hiring Freezes **********Employment agencies stand to make money every time the corporate revolving door swings, but this year, they say, it is swinging less often because of layoffs and hiring freezes. **********The white-collar unemployment rate was at 4.8 percent of the work force in May and 5 percent in June, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics - the highest levels since the record 5.3 percent figure reached in May 1975, the peak of that recession. **********The result has been the retrenching, sometimes the wobbling, and occasionally the collapse of some of the 10,000 to 15,000 employment agencies across the country. Licensed by Cities **********These agencies are closely held; fewer than half join a professional association, and because they are licensed by cities, a look at the industry becomes more of a mosaic than a panorama. But in New York City, the hub of the business, the Department of Consumer Affairs says there are now only 644 licensed employment agencies - down 18.2 percent from the 787 that were licensed in 1980. ''It's definitely off,'' said Karen Black, a department spokesman. **********Another grim sign for the agencies is that help wanted sections in the nation's newspapers are shrinking. The index of these ads, issued by the Conference Board, a business research group, stood at 87 in May, down from 118 in May 1981; its norm, based on a 1965 average, is 100. **********Some agencies also report that more companies are going the do-ityourself route on hiring, particularly for clerical jobs. Some place their own classified ads; a few award bonuses to employees who make successful referrals. **********As a result, many of the agencies are in trouble. ''A lot of little agencies - one- to four-desk operations - have closed,'' said Ira Gottlieb, president of the National Association of Personnel Consultants' New York office. ''About a dozen of our 189 member agencies have closed since January.'' **********The reverse side of the employment business is the agency that deals in temporary jobs. Typically, these agencies thrive on the same conditions that are throttling their permanent-employment counterparts. Hiring a ''temp'' saves an employer a long-term salary commitment and fringe benefits. It is essentially a patch job and, as such, one more lost commission to the permanent-job agency. **********Most of the agencies handling permanent jobs are cautious about releasing information, partly because they are private and partly because the industry is still feeling the effects of investigations that have, in the past, turned up racial discrimination and false advertising. ''People think all employment agencies place phony advertisements,'' complained one agency head. Smaller Agencies Hurting More **********The smaller agencies seem to be hurting more than the larger, more diversified, ones. Benson, for example, advertises ''better'' administrative and secretarial jobs offering higher pay, travel or writing. In May 1981, its best month for revenues since 1964, it had 150 job openings. This May, said its owner, Irving Cohen, it had 50.  Its revenues, which are not disclosed, dropped accordingly, he added. **********''The most qualified people are the last to be laid off,'' he said, ''so those who are looking for jobs are rarely the best.'' The resulting decline in agency commissions, he added, must still stretch to cover rising overhead and advertising costs. **********The much larger Mahoney, which runs one professional and three clerical placement offices in Manhattan, expects to make money this year by the grace of its business school. Its placement offices are ''not knocking them dead,'' said Mr. Murphy. **********The key to survival seems to be running in place, fast. ''We're making the same, if not more money, but we are working harder than we've ever worked before to stay where we are,'' said Ruth Manning, who owns Staff by Manning Ltd., a three-desk Manhattan shop specializing in executive secretaries, office managers and administrative assistants. High End Being Squeezed **********Even the high end of the business, in which salaries range upward of $50,000 and layoffs are the last to occur, is being squeezed, according to the Association of Executive Search Consultants. **********''Traditionally, senior management is most immune to the negative effects of recession, but this recession is proving to be somewhat different,'' the association's latest survey of its members began.  The survey said that the number of assignments filled by its executive recruiting companies declined by 24 percent in the first half of 1982, compared with last year. **********''Even merger and acquisition specialists found their prospects dimming, with a 55 percent decline in the demand for jobs in the second quarter,'' the report said. **********There are at least 750 recruitment concerns in business across the country. Recruiters, unlike agencies, are paid to conduct a search whether or not they fill a job. Sixty of these companies belong to the association. Of those, ''at least 2 percent, maybe 4 percent, are in trouble,'' its president, John A. Richmond, said. **********As it happens, one sliver of the high-end market is definitely thriving, according to Richard Hill, president of the National Association of Personnel Consultants. ''Bankruptcy lawyers are in high demand,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/08/busin.body_text: **********Frances Denney Inc., an old-line cosmetics and fragrance company founded in 1897, is embroiled in thoroughly modern litigation with its former stockholders, including the former chairman, Armand Deutsch, and the former chief executive, William Fine. **********In 1977, Mr. Fine and a group of investors bought Frances Denney, then a small and unprofitable concern. **********Under Mr. Fine, a former president of Bonwit Teller and publishing director of several Hearst magazines, the company was repositioned to make its skin-care products more appealing to younger women. **********By July 1980, the fast-growing company needed greater financial and research support, Mr. Fine said at the time, and Frances Denney was sold for $5 million - realizing a profit of roughly $1.5 million for the investors - to Delalande S.A., a French pharmaceutical company. **********Now Frances Denney's 22 former shareholders are suing Delalande to collect the third and final payment of $1.3 million that was due on March 1. Delalande has countersued, arguing that certain warranties in the purchase agreement were breached, and claiming an indemnity of $1.8 million, according to Delalande's attorney, Saul Sherman. **********The former shareholders recently rejected a settlement offer by Delalande as being ''hopelessly out of line with what the stockholders are now due.'' Depositions are being taken from both sides this month. **********In 1981, Frances Denney generated about $27 million in sales and had a slight loss, said Mr. Fine, who resigned as chief executive last March to start the W.M.F. Fund, a corporate consulting firm. **********''It's a situation where two years later, because of the recession or whatever reason, the wagon broke down,'' Mr. Fine said, ''and now they don't want to pay for the wagon.'' Sandra Salmans

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/27/busin.body_text: **********The General Motors Corporation reported net income of only $128 million for the first quarter of 1982 and said the profit came from financing auto loans rather than from making cars and trucks. **********The earnings, which came to 41 cents a share, were down 32.6 percent from $190 million, or 63 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales fell to $14.7 billion in the latest quarter from $15.7 billion. **********G.M., the country's largest car maker, acknowledged that its first-quarter net income came largely from earnings of $131.2 million at its General Motors Acceptance Corporation and Motors Insurance Company, which finance auto purchases and insure cars. **********The company's operating loss was $7.4 million in the latest quarter on the basis of gains from foreign currency translations and vehicle sales, which declined 13 percent, to 1.47 million, from 1.69 million a year before. American Motors Report **********The quarter's after-tax operating loss narrowed to $2.9 billion after figuring in $78.6 million of other income, such as real estate transactions, an income tax credit of $256.8 million and interest expenses of $330.9 million. **********In a separate report today, the American Motors Corporation announced a loss of $51 million for the first quarter, narrowed slightly from a loss of $52.7 milllion a year before. These were the auto industry's first two reports for the quarter ended March 31. **********Executives of General Motors attributed the company's operating loss and the reduced profit for the quarter to ''the prolonged recession and resulting slump in vehicle sales.'' But Roger B. Smith, chairman, and F. James McDonald, president, said in a joint statement that their outlook for the rest of the year was optimistic. ''The impact of the recession will undoubtedly continue to be felt in second-quarter results,'' their statement said, ''but the recession appears to have about run its course.'' Continuation of a Trend **********The first-quarter earnings continued last year's trend. Although G.M. was the only domestic car company to report a 1981 profit, it acknowledged that its earnings of $333 million last year were a result of the performance of its finance and insurance subsidiaries rather than of auto production. **********Analysts said that the latest report, nonethless, showed improvements in General Motors' efforts to cut costs.  ''With a 22 percent decline in unit volume in North America, just staying in the black is testimony to their cost cutting,'' said David Healy, an industry analyst with Drexel Burnham Lambert.  Nevertheless, Mr. Healy observed that ''in a sense they earned their profit in the accounting department, not the car department.'' **********''The results were very poor but satisfactory under the circumstances,'' said Arvid Jouppi, a Detroit-based analyst with Collin, Hochstin & Company. Mr. Jouppi said General Motors would not regain solid profitability until car buyers return to auto showrooms in sufficient numbers for the company to run its plants at high volume. **********G.M.'s net income in the fourth quarter of 1981 was $97 million, or 31 cents a share, which was up from $62 million, or 21 cents a share, a year before. **********Analysts expect G.M. to be more profitable this year than in 1981, with the amount depending on the timing and vigor of the nation's economic recovery. Mr. Healy said he anticipated earnings of as much as $4 a share - about $1.2 billion - while Mr. Jouppi said his projection was between $600 million and $900 million. **********G.M. said it sold 906,000 cars, trucks and buses in North America during the first quarter, down from 1,162,000 in the comparable 1981 period. However, its overseas production rose to 418,000 vehicles from 341,000. Overall vehicle sales totaled 1,470,000, down from 1,690,000. American Motors **********DETROIT, April 26 (AP) - American Motors said declining sales of cars and Jeeps explained its first-quarter loss of $51 million. Its $52.7 million loss in 1981's first quarter was its largest deficit ever for any Jan. 1-March 31 period. **********''Industry retail sales were adversely affected by a stagnant economy, high interest rates and bad weather,'' W.Paul Tippett, American Motors' chairman and chief executive officer, said in a statement. **********Worldwide vehicle sales to dealers totaled 56,400 units, down 21 percent from 71,277 in the 1981 period. But revenues rose slightly, to $600 million, from $598 million. **********American Motors lost $136.6 million in all of 1981. It last reported a three-month profit for the first quarter of 1980, when it made $1.3 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/04/world.main_headline: HAIG AIDES SAY MIDEAST ENVOY MAY BE NAMED
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/04/world.print_headline: HAIG AIDES SAY MIDEAST ENVOY MAY BE NAMED
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/04/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. was reported by a ides today to be seriously considering whether to name a high-level negotiator to the drawn-out Egyptian-Israeli negotiations on Palestinian self-rule. The aides said that Mr. Haig spent consider able time during the last five days while he was in California stu dying Middle East problems, and in particular the pros and cons of appointing a specialMiddle East envoy in order to dramatize the R eagan Administration's commitment to gaining an agreement by the end of April. One key StateDepartment official said, however, that Mr. H aig seems unconvinced, despite recommendations from within the Admin istration and from outside experts, that the time is right to ta ke that action. Talks With Envoys This Week **********State Department officials said the decision on whether to name a special envoy will be one of the matters that Mr. Haig intends to raise with the American ambassadors to Egypt and Israel, who have been recalled to Washington for a wide-ranging discussion of Middle East diplomatic issues, including ways of giving some new impetus to the Palestinian autonomy negotiations. **********Alfred L. Atherton Jr., the Ambassador to Egypt, and Samuel W.  Lewis, the Ambassador to Israel, were due in Washington for talks early this week. Mr. Haig himself is planning to visit Cairo and Jerusalem later this month after attending a special foreign ministers meeting in Brussels of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization that is to discuss coordinating steps on the Polish crisis. That NATO meeting will be held either Jan. 11 or 15, the officials said. **********According to various State Department officials, as well as others with close contacts within the Administration, the chief candidate for the role of special negotiator is Brent L. Scowcroft, a retired Air Force general, who served as President Ford's national security adviser. **********After the signing of the Egyptian-Israeli peace treaty in Washington in March 1979, President Carter named special envoys to take over the responsibility for representing the United States in the negotiations on Palestinian self-rule, which, like the peace treaty, was agreed to in outline form at the Camp David talks in September 1978 by Mr. Carter, President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt and Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel. **********The first special envoy was Robert S. Strauss. After he resigned to head Mr. Carter's re-election campaign, Sol M. Linowitz took over and, according to Mr. Linowitz, concluded about 80 percent of the projected accord by the time he resigned after President Reagan was inaugurated. Mr. Haig has resisted the naming of a successor to Mr.  Linowitz until now, giving as the reason that the time was not right and that until the Egyptians and Israelis had made further progress, it was better to avoid creating undue expectations by naming a special envoy. Envoy Would Report to Haig **********Officials said that if Mr. Scowcroft or someone else is named as a high-level envoy, he would report to Mr. Haig and not directly to Mr. Reagan, thereby easing Mr. Haig's concerns that the State Department retain control of the negotiations. **********Both Mr. Begin and Hosni Mubarak, who succeeded Mr. Sadat as President of Egypt, have urged the United States to take a more active role in the autonomy talks. Mr. Begin and some of his top aides, including Defense Minister Ariel Sharon, have accused Washington of showing increasingly less support for the Camp David process and have cited the lack of a special negotiator to back up their claim. **********Mr. Reagan and Mr. Haig have publicly supported the continuing negotiations on Palestinian self-rule and have committed the Administration to carrying out the Camp David accords. **********The autonomy talks have made little apparent progress since they resumed last fall after a delay of many months because of elections in the United States and in Israel. Mr. Haig, to the surprise of some of his aides, has insisted that, to the contrary, the talks have brought significant results. ''We've made more progress in 11 months than the previous administration made in 3 years on the subject of autonomy,'' he said in a recent interview with Hearst newspapers. Withdrawal From Sinai **********Under the Egyptian-Israeli peace treaty, Israel is to return to Egypt by April 25 the remaining part of Sinai that it has occupied since the 1967 Middle East war. Israel has already returned more than two-thirds of Sinai. In return, Egypt agreed to full diplomatic relations with Israel and to a number of cooperative ventures. **********In the minds of all parties, the April 25 date has taken on signficance because if there is no accord on Palestinian self-rule in the West Bank and Gaza Strip by then, it will appear to other Arabs as if E gypt s igned the Camp David accords solely to get back its own territory. **********Egyptians say they want an autonomy accord by April 25 to demonstrate that they were sincere in their support for Palestinian rights in the West Bank and Gaza. Israelis say an agreement would be useful to keep Egypt fr om renouncing the peac e treaty once it retrieved its captured lands. **********The United States has said that if a Palestinian accord is reached by April 25, this would make it easier to involve Jordan and other nations, such as Saudi Arabia, in the next stage of peace efforts and would allow a reconciliation of Egypt with the rest of the Arab world. Relations With Israel Cited **********Until now, the Administration has been represented at the Palestinian talks by Mr. Atherton and Mr. Lewis, joined by specialists from Washington. **********Mr. Haig was reported by aides to want to discuss, particularly with Mr. Lewis, ways to restore to normal relations with Israel and to avoid the public clashes of recent months. The latest, over Israel's sudden decision in effect to annex the Golan Heights, so upset the Administration that it indefinitely suspended further discussion of carrying out a strategic cooperation agreement with Israel that had been signed only two weeks earlier. **********That, in turn, led to Mr. Begin's public attack on the Administration and his statement that he regarded the suspension as tantamount to a cancellation. Since then, both sides have said that the accord legally still exists, but there has been no move to carry out any of the joint activities called for in the document. **********The Administration, which voted for a United Nations Security Council measure condemning the annexation, now must decide what to do on Tuesday when the Council meets to discuss a Syrian call for sanctions against Israel. The Administration has said it is unlikely to support sanctions as such.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/09/busin.main_headline: CHEMICAL TO OFFER BANKING AT HOME
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/09/busin.print_headline: CHEMICAL TO OFFER BANKING AT HOME
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/09/busin.body_text: **********Chemical Bank, in one of the first announcements of its kind, said yesterday that it would introduce a service that would allow its customers in the New York area to bank at home using personal computers. **********Such home electronic banking has been the subject of numerous market tests, but Chemical, the nation's sixth-largest bank, would be the first of the nation's largest banks to offer such a service commercially. **********Customers using the system would be able to do such things as keep track of their checking accounts and home budget, transfer money from one account to another and pay bills electronically by typing commands on the computer keyboard. **********Mark Plakias, research director for Link Resources Corporation, a New York market research firm, said that as home banking, shopping and other electronic services achieved commercial status, other companies were likely to follow Chemical. Its move ''indicates the consumer is much more ready to use this kind of a product than most people imagine,'' he said. **********Nevertheless, Chemical's move is something of a gamble because it is not certain that the public is ready and because electronic home banking cannot be used for two things consumers normally do at banks - make deposits and obtain cash. **********''The market doesn't exist for this,'' said William B. Cornfield, director of home information services for Chemical. ''It has to be created.'' **********The service, known as Pronto, has been tested on about 200 households since November. Chemical will start offering the commercial service before the end of the year, initially to between 2,000 and 3,000 of its checking account customers, the bank said. **********Users would need an Atari home computer, a television set for a viewing screen, a cartridge similar to a video game cartridge containing the banking program and a device called a modem, which connects the home computer over the telephone line to the bank's computer. Chemical officials said the computer, modem and cartridge could be purchased for less than $500. Monthly Fee of $8-$10 **********In addition to the initial equipment costs, customers will be charged a monthly fee of $8 to $10 and will have to pay local telephone charges. **********John A. Farnsworth, senior vice president, said the system would eventually work with other home computers and terminals. The company is also offering to license its system to other banks. **********He also said that Chemical, possibly in partnership with other companies, planned to offer electronic services beyond banking. They include the ability to order merchandise electronically, to retrieve stock quotes and evaluate portfolios, to read news reports, to check concert schedules and order tickets, and possibly even to buy and sell stocks. **********Mr. Farnsworth said about 250 companies - including major retailers, oil companies, credit card companies, and utilities - had agreed to accept electronic bill payments through Chemical's new service. Instead of writing a check and mailing it, consumers would type the proper commands and money would be transferred from their accounts to the billing company's account, saving both the bank and the consumer the cost of mailing and processing checks. **********It is uncertain how Chemical will fare in its venture. For one thing, Chemical has not fully developed its plans for marketing the system. There could also be regulatory limits on what services a bank could offer and whether they could offer banking across state lines, though Mr. Farnsworth said those did not appear to be a problem. **********Mr. Plakias of Link Resources said a more important question for Chemical and for electronic banking in general was whether smaller banks will agree to license the system for their own use. Other Banks Interested **********Two other major New York banks, Citibank and Chase Manhattan, have also been experimenting with home banking using computers, but they have not yet decided whether to offer them to the general public. **********The first commercial system was introduced by United American Bank in Knoxville, Tenn., in October 1980; it has about 400 users. The system, licensed from Financial Interstate Service Corporation, is not fully automatic, in that when a customer types in commands for a bill to be paid, the bank then must issue a check to the company.  With Chemical's system, the transfer is automatic.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/30/busin.main_headline: TOWN HOUSE DEVELOPMENT GOING UP IN MAMARONECK
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/30/busin.print_headline: ABOUT REAL ESTATE; TOWN HOUSE DEVELOPMENT GOING UP IN MAMARONECK
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/30/busin.body_text: **********Diane Greenberg Millstein took a circuitous route to housing development. She was a planner who helped the town of Greenwich, Conn., establish its zoning a decade ago, and before that she had worked as a regional planner in southwestern Connecticut. **********The shift began in 1975, when she bought waterfront land abutting a boat yard in Mamaroneck, where she and her husband live. It was six years before the town finally approved a plan for 13 town houses.  Mrs. Millstein has started to develop them under the name Indian Cove. In the meantime she has also built and sold a town-house condominium project called Pine Ridge in Larchmont. **********The Long Island Sound shoreline of Westchester County is not hospitable terrain for new development. Exclusive older communities of large detached houses in the metropolitan area typically resist ''infill'' housing on relatively small sites, unless the new house is large and detached itself. But Mrs. Millstein's persistence eventually was rewarded. ''I just kept plowing ahead,'' she said. **********Speculatively built single-family houses on individual lots in communities with high land costs are an anachronism in the 1980's.  Not only is it prohibitively expensive for most buyers; it is also inconsistent with what most buyers want. **********What does make sense to builders and planners is the town house. By grouping several houses within a single structure, costs are significantly reduced. Yet the overall density of the development is not significantly changed. The additional land is used for open space, community facilities or landscaping. **********All these principles have been brought into play by Mrs. Millstein, whose development company is called DGM Partners. Arthur J. Wexler is the architect, and a partner in building Indian Cove. **********The 13 town houses will be in four buildings, each with a New England seaside look appropriate to the setting. It is a 3.6-acre site in the boatyard and club area off Rushmore Avenue. The total density is about six to the acre. **********These are to be houses with gray-stained cedar facades and asphalt shingle roofs and 2,200 to 2,300 square feet of space, with three or four bedrooms. There will be an outdoor swimming pool, a private dock area for the buyers' boats, and extensive landscaping. They are offered at prices ranging from $267,500 to $345,250. Site work is in progress and the first delivery of homes to buyers is expected in the spring. **********In Larchmont Mrs. Millstein developed 40 two-bedroom town houses, each with a garage, on a 6.5-acre site off the Post Road (Route 1) once occupied by a nursery. A previous owner had cleared the land to develop it as a tennis center. But townspeople wanted housing.  Knowing of Mrs. Millstein's efforts in Mamaroneck they encouraged her to buy the property. **********These 1,600- to 1,800-square-foot two-bedroom houses came on the market in 1978 at prices of $85,000 to $100,000. Landscaping and other site work shield the houses from the main road, and a narrow 20-foot road twists through the development. In a few years the trees will provide complete privacy. **********Within six months the houses were selling for $150,000 to $160,000, Mrs. Millstein said, as buyers added skylights, fireplaces in bedrooms, front or rear sun rooms, larger living rooms and more. At Indian Cove, the buildings will provide even more flexibility, she said. **********The buyers at Pine Ridge consisted mainly of older people selling houses and, to some extent, divorced families. Perhaps 10 to 15 percent of the market for new housing in the metropolitan area consists of recently divorced people, builders say. **********As Mrs. Millstein sees it, much of the current zoning in Westchester is outdated. It was created at a time when new housing was being built for ''mom and dad, two or three kids and a dog.'' But these days most people seeking new housing are in smaller households. **********Instead of basing zoning restrictions on dwelling units per acre, it might be more appropriate to set limits based on the number of people, Mrs. Millstein said. Builders could then produce more but smaller units without affecting population density since family sizes are smaller. **********Mrs. Millstein has plans for housing in northern New Rochelle. She owns four acres of land off Pine Brook Boulevard and intends to build 18 condominiums as detached houses. The open space will be owned and operated jointly by the condominium buyers. **********''No yards, no play areas,'' she said. ''It's geared to fewer kids. God knows, in the suburbs there are enough four-bedroom houses. But there aren't enough two-bedroom units with studies instead of playrooms. We need housing to accommodate smaller families.'' **********Mrs. Millstein is a native of Rye, N.Y. She majored in economics at New York University, graduating in 1949. She returned to Columbia University 11 years later to study architecture, but switched to planning. She and her husband, a lawyer, have two adult sons.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/07/world.body_text: **********Heartened by evidence that the Falkland conflict has already damaged Washington's relations with Latin America, Cuba is now trying to use the crisis to end its political isolation from much of the region. **********In the last two months, Havana has emerged as one of the strongest supporters of Argentina, with which it had tense relations before the dispute. And it took the lead in mobilizing sympathy for Argentina at a meeting of third world nations professing nonalignment that ended here early today. **********Cuban officials have also argued that, despite their political differences, Latin American countries - with Cuba among them - have been drawn together as never before by the issue. Fidel Castro, the Cuban leader, said last week that the Falklands had stirred ''the most nationalist Latin Americanist sentiments that I've ever known.'' **********Further, Cuban officials believe that Washington's decision to support Britain in the crisis has damaged the entire concept of an inter-American system linking the United States and Latin America and has weakened the Inter-American Treaty of Mutual Assistance, a pact traditionally invoked only to combat Communist threats in the region. Pact 'Awaiting Decent Funeral' **********''Whatever happens, things will never be the same again,'' a senior Cuban official said. ''The United States said the treaty wasn't applicable against Britain, but the next time Washington tries to use it, Latin America won't follow.'' **********Cuba's Foreign Minister, Isidoro Malmierca Peoli, told delegates at last week's nonaligned meeting here that both the treaty and the Monroe Doctrine were now awaiting ''a decent funeral.'' **********Foreign diplomats said Havana's decision to exploit the rift between Washington and Latin America also reflected its conclusion that recent secret contacts with Reagan Administration officials offered little hope for an improvement in United States-Cuban relations. **********''Cuba has nothing to lose and a lot to win,'' a well-placed Western diplomat said. ''The talks with the Americans were going nowhere. This was a chance that Fidel could not pass over.'' Few Friends in the Region **********Regional analysts recalled that, having re-established ties with much of Latin America in the mid-1970's, Cuba's relations with numerous countries, notably Argentina, Venezuela, Peru, Colombia and Costa Rica, had again deteriorated over the last two years. **********With the Reagan Administration campaigning strongly against supposed Cuban involvement with Central America's revolutionary movements, much of Latin America also seemed happy to push Havana back into the cold. Only Mexico, Nicaragua, Grenada and, occasionally, Panama were willing to be counted among Cuba's friends in the region. **********But, seeing Latin America's anger and frustration over the Falklands directed even more against the United States than Britain, Cuba has now jumped at the opportunity to pull closer to the rest of Latin America, starting with such countries as Peru and Venezuela that have adopted similarly strong positions in the crisis. **********''Nothing dramatic has happened yet,'' a Cuban official conceded.  ''In both cases, our relations are still at the level of charge d'affaires rather than ambassadors. But this whole business is going to have very profound consequences.'' Cubans Note Positive Results **********Given Argentina's recent record of repression against suspected leftist militants, some Cuban officials conceded a certain embarrassment in finding themselves now supporting the Buenos Aires junta, although they fell back on the argument that the Falklands is a cause supported by the entire Argentine people. **********But they also quickly pointed out that the crisis had also brought them positive results, specifically the withdrawal of Argentine military advisers from El Salvador and Guatemala, where they were providing counterinsurgency training to local armies, and from Honduras, where they were helping armed bands of anti-Sandinist Nicaraguan exiles. **********''This alone is a considerable achievement,'' an official argued.  ''The United States had clear plans for Argentina to form a force capable of invading Nicaragua and this won't happen now.'' **********In the name of trying to isolate Washington, Nicaragua has also followed Cuba's lead in supporting Argentina over the Falklands, pardoning Buenos Aires overnight for its earlier efforts to disrupt the Sandinist regime. Nicaragua's Foreign Minister, Miguel d'Escoto, told last week's conference that ''the anti-imperialist sentiments of Latin America have reached levels never previously achieved'' as a result of the South Atlantic conflict. One day earlier, Argentina offered 7,000 tons of wheat to help Nicaragua overcome food shortages caused by serious flooding last month. **********As a result of the Falkland crisis, some countries have revived the idea of replacing the Organization of American States with a new regional organization that would exclude the United States.  Argentina's Foreign Minister, Nicanor Costa Mendez, who last week described Cuba as ''the pride of the Caribbean'' to astonished delegates, has even suggested that Cuba be welcomed back into the Latin American community, although President Castro himself said it was ''a little premature'' for Havana to return to the O.A.S.
