https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/13/busin.main_headline: Business and the Law; Bankruptcies: Chaos Prevails
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/13/busin.print_headline: Business and the Law; Bankruptcies: Chaos Prevails
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/13/busin.body_text: **********THE Supreme Court's June 28 decision that the Bankruptcy Reform Act of 1978 gave bankruptcy judges more power than was constitutionally permissible has left debtors and creditors, and their lawyers, confused about how to handle pending cases - and even more uncertain about the future of the bankruptcy system. **********The Marathon Pipe Line ruling gives Congress until Oct. 4 to devise a constitutional system, either by giving bankruptcy judges the same legal status as Federal district judges, or by shifting some of the work they now do into other courts. **********The timing could hardly be worse. Both the bankruptcy system and Congress are already under tremendous pressure: the system, to keep up with the rising tide of business and consumer bankruptcies, and Congress, to get through a crowded legislative agenda in time for a late August recess. Meanwhile, the bankruptcy system is in chaos. **********''There's a lot of uncertainty right now,'' said Ronald Orr, a Los Angeles bankruptcy lawyer. ''No one knows what they can and can't do, and we're not going to know until Oct. 4. It's about as messy as it could be.'' **********Many lawyers are considering turning to the Federal district courts until the question of the bankruptcy courts' jurisdiction is resolved, especially for the ancillary third-party claims that arise in the course of a large business bankruptcy or reorganization. **********Some are even talking about filing bankruptcy petitions in a Federal district court, on the theory that there can always be a transfer to a bankruptcy court if necessary. Others say it is not clear that the district courts have the power to hear bankruptcy cases: if the bankruptcy system is not amended by the Oct. 4 deadline, they add, it may become impossible to declare bankruptcy. **********Although the Supreme Court has been known to extend its deadlines, an extension in this case would put the bankruptcy question before a lame-duck Congress at best, or a whole new Congress, at worst. **********The fallout from the Supreme Court decision is already affecting pending cases. Many lawyers are trying to protect their claims by asking the bankruptcy judge not to take any action until a new system is in place. **********''The prospect for large companies and creditors to get quick relief is bleak and very messy,'' said Kenneth Klee, another Los Angeles bankruptcy lawyer. **********That may be true well beyond Oct. 4. Bankruptcy reform is such a controversial issue that many experts think Congress will be unable to meet the deadline. **********In some ways, the decision is a vindication for the House of Representatives, which originally wanted to give bankruptcy judges the same status and lifetime tenure that Federal district judges received under Article III of the Constitution, thereby avoiding the constitutional problem. In April, Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., the New Jersey Democrat who heads the House Judiciary Committee, introduced legislation to convert bankruptcy judges into Article III judges. Even if that bill passes, though, the President must appoint the bankruptcy judges, and the Senate must confirm them, a process most experts expect will take several months. **********Most bankruptcy lawyers are rooting for the Article III approach, which would allow bankruptcy judges to retain the broad powers the 1978 law gave them. Going back to the old system, under which a bankruptcy court handled a bankruptcy and a district court or a state court handled third-party ancillary suits, would be a tremendous waste of time and money, they say. **********The Senate, however, has never liked the Article III approach.  Senator Strom Thurmond, the South Carolina Republican who is the chairman of the Judiciary Committee, and others insisted on the arrangment embodied in the 1978 law and, at least so far, have given no signs of changing their minds. **********Even if the two houses of Congress reach a quick agreement on the question of the status of bankruptcy judges, another more troublesome political problem remains. For some time, Congress has been faced with intense lobbying pressures from those who want to make the bankruptcy laws more favorable to creditors. Congress Watch, a Ralph Nader group, says that banks, finance companies and others who are pushing the changes have contributed nearly $1 million to Congressional campaign coffers - most of it to members who support reform legislation. **********In fact, bankruptcy reform is one of the most controversial issues on Capitol Hill. And now that the Supreme Court has forced Congress to take action on the judges' jurisdiction, it is unlikely that the legislators will be able to avoid the policy questions. **********''There's no doubt in my mind that there will be a debate on the substantive issues,'' said a member of Senator Bob Dole's staff. Mr.  Dole, the Kansas Republican who is the chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee's Subcommittee on Courts, wants to make it harder for consumers to liquidate personal debt, a reform that is strongly supported by lenders and just as strongly opposed by consumer advocates.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/03/world.main_headline: REGIME IN POLAND OUSTS 90 OFFICIALS IN THE PROVINCES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/03/world.print_headline: REGIME IN POLAND OUSTS 90 OFFICIALS IN THE PROVINCES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/03/world.body_text: **********Poland's military regime has removed 90 provincial and city officials, according to a senior staff member of the country's ruling military council. **********Col. Zdzislaw Malina, deputy head of the council's Secretariat, was quoted by the Warsaw radio today as saying that the ousted officials included those who ''under normal conditions worked efficiently'' but who ''unfortunately did not cope with the new tasks resulting from the specific nature of martial law.'' **********The radio also broadcast an attack against student activists and disclosed that the suspended students' union had been involved in ''various actions'' to protest martial law. '200,000 Social Parasites' **********The broadcast, quoting the Communist Party newspaper Trybuna Ludu, said many students were among ''200,000 social parasites'' refusing to work. Last week, in announcing compulsory labor for all men between the ages of 18 and 45, the military Government exempted students. **********The Government had announced plans to reopen universities next week, but the broadcast today indicated that the authorities might be afraid the students would not return to classes. **********This evening the Polish television announced that jail sentences averaging five to six years had been given to five workers charged with leading a strike that ended last week at the Katowice steel mill. The workers were accused of ''causing considerable losses to the national economy.'' Provincial Military Committees **********The radio quoted Colonel Malina as saying that 9 of the 90 officials removed in 34 of Poland's 49 provinces were provincial governors, deputy governors or mayors; the other 81 were chief administrative officers. **********Colonel Malina, who reportedly made his remarks in an interview with Trybuna Ludu, said provincial military committees had been running the provinces since the imposition of martial law on Dec. 13. **********The provincial committees, Colonel Malina said, have strengthened the principle of one-man leadership as well as the duties of local officials and industrial heads. **********In 1973, the Communist Party, known as the Polish United Workers' Party, tightened its control at the provincial level by making the provincial party secretaries the heads of state presidiums. **********Colonel Malina said in the interview that the provincial committees were concentrating their efforts on ''insuring security'' and ''maintaining work discipline.'' **********According to the Warsaw radio, industrial work has been interrupted by a shortage of energy and raw materials. The Government, the broadcast said, will guarantee pay for employees who lose work time because of what the radio described as ''standstills in various enterprises and works.'' **********''In accordance with the labor code,'' the broadcast said, ''employees are entitled to remuneration according to their grades for the duration of a standstill.'' **********Last week, the Government announced that it was establishing a new set of guidelines to guarantee energy and raw material for factories, although at increased costs. In that announcement, the Government said it had expanded its list of essential industries to include some food-processing plants. **********The Warsaw radio said that in Szczecin, where the curfew was reduced by two hours today, two executives with the state-run transport company had been expelled from the Communist Party and were in danger of dismissal because of their involvement in ''strikes and protests.'' **********The Polish military Government, judged by its radio and television statements, is waging a campaign to convince Poles that the Soviet Union is their closest friend. Daily reports are made on the arrival of Soviet food, raw materials and other supplies needed to aid Poland's severely damaged economy. **********The theme is also prominent in Soviet reports from Warsaw and in Soviet press and broadcasting comments on the P olish situation.  Today, the Soviet press agency Tass quoted Tr ybuna Ludu in a lengthy account of the New Year's Eve message by the Polish President, Henryk Jablonski. The report was at almost to tal variance with those based on the same message monitored in the We st. In the Tass version, the emphasis was on the necessity of martial law and on Po land's place in the ''socialist community.'' Gone were Mr. Jablonski 's references to Polish patriotism, ''national accord'' and ''sociali st renewal.'' **********''There cannot be any return to the situation from before Dec.  13,'' the Tass version of Mr. Jablonski's speech said.  As monitored in the West, Mr. Jablonski said that over the last year Poles had introduced ''actions aimed at creating political, legal and personal guarantees for preventing a repition of the evil and distortions which existed before August 1980.'' It was in August 1980 that the independent labor union Solidarity was formed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/21/busin.main_headline: MOSCOW ACCEPTING A YEAR'S EXTENSION OF U.S. GRAIN SALES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/21/busin.print_headline: MOSCOW ACCEPTING A YEAR'S EXTENSION OF U.S. GRAIN SALES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/21/busin.body_text: **********The Soviet Union has accepted President Reagan's offer of a one-year extension of a grain sales agreement due to expire Sept. 30, Agriculture Secretary John R. Block announced today. **********The acceptance was delivered in writing today to the American Embassy in Moscow, Mr. Block said. He added in a statement that ''the willingness of the Soviet Union to accept this extension is proof that the Soviets believe the President's pledge that the United States will again be a reliable supplier.'' **********That statement was in contrast to the acrimony that has surrounded President Reagan's ban on the use of American-made or Americanlicensed equipment for the construction of a 3,700-mile pipeline to bring natural gas from Siberia to the Soviet Union. **********Second Yearly Extension **********The new grain agreement was the second yearly extension of a fiveyear accord that has regulated Soviet purchases of American grain since 1976 and has assured American farmers of a Soviet market for some of their grain. **********The agreement says that the Soviet Union must purchase at least 6 million metric tons of American corn and wheat a year and can purchase a maximum of 8 million tons. For any larger purchases there must be prior government-to-government approval. In the current year, the United States has offered the Russians an additional 15 million tons above the 8 million. 14 Million Tons Bought **********The Russians have actually purchased a total of 14 million tons in the current agreement year. But a White House fact sheet distributed today projected that the Russians would actually buy a record 17.8 million tons,topping their previous record of 15.3 million tons set in 1979. **********Under heavy pressure from farm states that are facing record harvests, huge unsold grain surpluses and weakening farm prices, President Reagan offered July 30 to extend the accord passed the Sept. 30 expiration. But he did not attempt to increase the minimum purchases required of the Russians, as American farmers have wanted to do. **********There had been speculation in Moscow and the grain trade that the Soviet Union might reject the offer to extend the grain agreement because of the Reagan Administration's embargo on the sale of pipeline equipment. **********There had also been speculation that Moscow would decide to meet its foreign grain needs with purchases from other countries - chiefly Australia, Argentina and Canada - as it had done after President Carter curtailed grain shipments to the Soviet Union in retaliation for the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan in January 1980. **********While the United States has been reporting record grain crops this summer, the Soviet Union has faced its fourth dismal harvest in a row, necessitating large purchases abroad. **********Mr. Block said that the grain agreement extension ''will allow American farmers to continue rebuilding this important market which was thrown away to our competitors during the partial embargo.'' He stressed that he would be contacting Soviet officials immeditely to set a date for discussing additional sales beyond the minimums. **********American farm officials said that, if the Russians had felt the United States would not be a reliable supplier of grain in the future, they would have pressed for an agreement of longer than one year. **********But one Russian official said earlier this week, at a meeting of soybean industry officials in Pebble Beach, Calif., that the American reputation as a reliable supplier had already been hurt. **********Boris Antoniuk, the project manager of the United States-Soviet Trade and Economic Council, said that Moscow would buy from the United States only as a last resort when supplies were unavailable from other countries. **********American reliability as a supplier of manufactured goods and technology has also been hurt, according to Western European leaders and many business leaders in the United States, by the embargo on pipeline equipment, first imposed last December and expanded in June. **********The Administration's insistence on permitting grain sales to the Soviet Union while embargoing turbines and other goods for the pipeline has been strongly attacked by European officials who see the policy as inconsistent, hypocritical and harmful to European and trans-Atlantic interests. Soviet Role in Poland Cited **********President Reagan imposed the pipeline embargo in retaliation for what he has called the Soviet role in repression in Poland. Although the Europeans say they need the line to diversify energy supplies, the Administration argues that the line will strengthen the Soviet Union economically by giving it an additional $10 billion a year of hard-currency earnings. This could be used for a greater military buildup, the Administration says.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/05/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Oppenheimer Official Joins Dillon, Read
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/05/busin.body_text: **********Timothy G. Dalton Jr. has been named president of a new investment management subsidiary established by Dillon, Read & Company.  Mr. Dalton, 43, joins Dillon, Read from the Oppenheimer Capital Corporation, where he was a senior vice president.  ''It's been part of the Dillon, Read game plan to get into the money management business,'' Mr. Dalton said. **********''Our intent is to go after retirement funds and other institutional kinds of money.'' **********Starting from scratch is not easy, however. ''There are an awful lot of people out after that business,'' he said. ''I have a record, and obviously we will have to build up our own record. We have a prospect or two that I'm quite sure will provide us with funds in the very near future.'' **********Mr. Dalton has spent 20 years on Wall Street since graduating from Princeton. Before he joined Oppenheimer in 1976, he worked for Franklin Capital Investors, College Retirement Equities Fund and Scudder, Stevens & Clark. **********The new investment unit will be called Dillon, Read Capital Inc.  and its chairman will be John P. Birkelund, president of Dillon, Read.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/02/busin.body_text: **********It may be some time before Wall Street echoes the trumpet fanfares that heralded today's opening of Walt Disney's futuristic addition to the Disney World complex in Lake Buena Vista, Fla. **********The $900 million Epcot Center, a melange of advanced technology, science, history and Disney-brand entertainment, opens at a time when Walt Disney Productions is struggling to halt a slide in corporate earnings and a decline in attendance at its well-known parks. **********Simultaneously, the company is attempting to revive its slumping movie division and enter the crowded field of pay-television programming. **********With Epcot, the late Walt Disney's acronym for Experimental Prototype Community of Tomorrow, Disney appears to have staked its future more than ever on amusement parks, which accounted for 69 percent of revenue in 1981. Epcot is Disney's biggest addition since Walt Disney World opened 11 years ago. **********Dependence on New Ventures **********Renewed growth by Disney depends on the success of the new ventures, but it may take a year or more before the company's prospects become clear. Nevertheless, some analysts are pleased with what they regard as Disney's direction. **********''After stagnating for five years, the company is in the process of becoming a major factor in entertainment again,'' said Alan Kassan, a vice president of the First Manhattan Company. **********For the nine months through June 30, Disney's profits fell 14 percent, to $72 million, or $2.17 a share, from $83.8 million, or $2.57 a share, in the similar period a year earlier. Revenue rose 6 percent, to $735.2 million. **********Disney is expected to finish its 1982 fiscal year, which ended today, with about $3.15 in earnings per share, versus $3.72 last year. The range of Wall Street forecasts for 1983 is between $4.25 and $5. **********The jump is expected to come partly from a rebound in attendance generated by the Epcot opening, plus the opening of a new Disneyland in Tokyo. Disney has no equity in the $450 million Tokyo project, the first of its kind outside the United States, but will be paid a licensing fee of 7.5 percent of the park's revenues. **********Attendance this year at Disney World, the country's most popular vacation resort, was down by 5 percent through June, and was not expected to equal last year's total of about 12 million when the count for the 1982 fiscal year stopped on Thursday. Its West Coast counterpart, the 27-year-old Disneyland, in Anaheim, Calif., south of Los Angeles, has been running about 7 percent below the 1981 pace through the summer. **********E. Cardon Walker, Disney's chairman and chief executive, said he expects Epcot to bring an additional 8 million people a year through Disney World's turnstiles, raising the total there to more than 20 million. Lagging Movie Division **********Although the drop in attendance is a nagging problem, Disney's movie business has been a calamity. Pretax profits in films fell 29 percent through the first three quarters on a 7 percent increase in revenue. **********''Families don't go to the movies like they used to, and we just haven't done well,'' Mr. Walker conceded. ''But we're not going to quit trying.'' **********A recent attempt, ''Tron,'' the story of a man trapped inside a video game and condemned to play until death, did lure some teen-age moviegoers. Its computer-generated images stirred a spate of publicity last spring, but the film drew mixed critical reviews and was a box-office disappointment. Still, the film, which cost $21 million, or more than double the average production cost in Hollywood, is expected to make some money by the time its foreign run is completed. **********More important, many considered the new elements in ''Tron'' as evidence that Disney executives have begun to shed their rigid loyalty to Walt Disney's concepts of how to run the business. Mr.  Disney died in 1966. Disney's top management has long been branded by industry analysts as insular and overly conservative. Walker Retirement Indicated **********Mr. Walker, 67 years old, has been chief executive since 1971 and chairman since 1980. He has indicated that he will retire next spring after the opening of the Tokyo Disneyland, and the start of the Disney Channel on pay television. **********Analysts expect that Ronald W. Miller, 49, president and heirapparent, is not likely to quickly change the company's direction. Nevertheless, it was Mr. Miller who opened Disney studios to outside talent and some analysts said he is more willing to consider new approaches. **********He said in an interview that the futuristic setting of the vast Epcot Center ''will be a platform'' for hundreds of hours of Disney programming, mainly for the Disney Channel, but also for Disney's weekly program on the CBS television network. **********''I think the Disney Channel could be the most rewarding project we have going,'' Mr. Miller said. ''Most of our new programming will be coming out of here and Walt Disney World. If that catches on, a lot of families will be signing up.'' Westinghouse Quits Project **********Cable operators are reportedly eager to add the Disney Channel to their offerings when it begins next April. But the Westinghouse Corporation, which was to have been an equal partner, abandoned the effort earlier this month in a programming dispute. **********Analysts are divided about the channel's prospects. Skeptics doubt that enough families will pay the monthly $10 fee to receive it. ''I think it will be a fiasco,'' said Arthur E. Rockwell, an analyst with Crowell, Weedon & Company, in Los Angeles. **********Still, Disney expects to draw two million subscribers by next spring. ''It's a good concept,'' said Harold Vogel of Merrill Lynch, ''and it should be a nice contributor to earnings in six to eight years.'' **********Epcot, on the other hand, is expected to enhance Disney's profitability almost immediately. The company's $600 million initial investment in the project, in real terms, is less than half the $700 million it took to open Disney World in 1971. **********In addition to the $600 million of its own money, Disney received another $300 million from sponsors such as the Exxon Corporation, the General Motors Corporation, the Eastman Kodak Company and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. **********At today's closing price of $57.125 on the New York Stock Exchange, a gain of 50 cents, Disney's market value is about $2 billion. At that price, Mr. Kassan argues, Disney is undervalued. **********''Disney remains a totally unique franchise with very significant asset values,'' he said. ''They are trying to be creative again instead of milking the old theme parks.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/09/busin.body_text: **********In March 1980 John Roberts Opel was named chief executive officer of the International Business Machines Corporation in addition to his title of president. I.B.M.'s decision ended brief speculation that he might be passed over in favor of someone deemed more likely to help the giant, but troubled, company improve its less-than-customary performance. In the end, it seemed, loyalty, a plan of succession and his role as a sort of alter ego won out. **********Yesterday the Justice Department wearily dropped its 13-year-old antitrust suit against I.B.M., and Mr. Opel, as the company's top officer, again appeared to be a victor against great odds. Two and a half years ago his triumph was over unfounded rumor. This time it was over ''big government.'' **********The 57-year-old Mr. Opel has long trod a trail blazed by Frank T.  Cary, I.B.M.'s tight-lipped, tough-minded, former chief executive officer. It was Mr. Cary who held out against legions of Government lawyers, countless court hearings, mountains of written testimony and, some say, intrigue from competitors eager to help the Government's efforts against I.B.M. A Time for Accolades **********But if steadfast support and professional and personal loyalty mean anything, the Kansas-born Mr. Opel - an I.B.M. man since 1949, when he joined the company as a salesman - would appear to deserve the accolades he received yesterday at corporate headquarters in Armonk, N.Y. **********Mr. Opel was a member of the giant computer manufacturer's ruling council for a decade prior to his appointment as C.E.O. In all, he was at Mr. Cary's right hand for about 20 years. Mr. Opel is described by close associates as thoughtful, soft-spoken and, according to one of them, ''not too dramatically different in behavior from Frank Cary.'' Mr. Opel's steady advancement through the years is evidence of his sponsor's unflagging support through some difficult times, such as when I.B.M.'s conservatism allowed upstart competitors to carve out market niches for themselves. **********After joining I.B.M. as a salesman at Jefferson City, Mo., Mr.  Opel traveled a wide circle from the Ozarks to the Iowa border. He served 10 years in the field, creating a record that attracted the attention of Thomas J. Watson Jr., the head of the company, who made Mr. Opel his executive assistant and two years later a corporate vice president. Ascending the Ladder **********In 1968, somewhat less than 20 years after he joined the company, Mr. Opel was appointed senior vice president and chairman of the executive committee. He had entered the inner circle of I.B.M.'s elite. **********Still more recognition and responsibility lay ahead. In 1972 he was named head of the data processing division, representing the company's main marketing activity. By then, rival executives either had come under his wing or had been outpaced, and in 1974 it seemed only natural when he was named president at age 49. For some time Mr. Opel and Mr. Cary, beh ind their executive desks, had been physically separated by only a tiny anteroom. Mr. Opel's next move, to chief executive off icer, was just as natural six years later when Mr. Cary stepped down at age 60 in line with I.B.M.'s policy. **********Mr. Opel's wife is the former Julia Carole Stout, and they have two sons and three daughters. His outside interests include opera, fishing and ornithology. **********Last October I.B.M. moved to simplify its product-group marketing approach in favor of allowing single sales represenatives to sell a wide rantge of I.B.M. products. Outlining I.B.M.'s Aims **********Analysts considered this an effort to compete more effectively in the proliferating field of personal computers. But Mr. Opel declared in a statement that ''this new marketing structure will simplify the distribution of our products and better serve our customers' needs.'' These twin objectives could easily have been lifted out of a business management textbook. **********Like Mr. Cary, Mr. Opel holds a Master of Business Administration degree. Mr. Opel's is from the University of Chicago; Mr. Cary's is from Stanford University. Members of I.B.M.'s top brass, perhaps savoring yesterday's glowingvi ctory, seemed slow to leave for home late in the day. But efforts to reach Mr. Opel for comment proved unsuccessful. A corporate sp okesman explained that ''Mr. Opel is involved in meetings at Ar monk.'' **********What would prompt meetings so soon after yesterday's bombshell in Washington? Surely not another antitrust suit? The I.B.M. spokesman laughed. ''Not for another 13 years, at least,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/18/busin.body_text: **********Movie makers have stepped up their war against pirated home videotapes, according to the industry's chief investigator. **********Armed with writs of seizure, Federal marshals entered stores in four cities of Illinois and California on Tuesday. **********They confiscated copies of such movies as ''Superman,'' ''Sharkey's Machine'' and ''Rollover,'' said Ewing Layhew, executive director of the Film Security Office of the Motion Picture Producers Association. **********Just before the raids, four civil lawsuits charging piracy were filed in Chicago and suburban Tinley Park as well as in Temecula and Vista, Calif., Mr. Layhew said in a telephone interview from Los Angeles. The charges were brought by major film companies, including Columbia, Embassy, M-G-M, Paramount, 20th Century-Fox, United Artists, Universal and Disney. **********Sales of pirated tapes are costing the video industry up to $700 million a year in lost revenues, Mr. Layhew said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/20/busin.body_text: **********The Walter E. Heller International Corporation, the Chicago c ommercial finance and bank holding company, said today that it will take a one-time, pretax, $79 million write-off for 1981 as a result o f ''irregularities'' discovered in its Phoenix office.  The write-off will cut Heller's 1981 net income 46.5 percent, to $23 million, from $43 million in 1980, the company said. **********The ''irregularities'' occurred in offices of Walter E. Heller Western Inc., a domestic finance unit. The company said in Chicago that ''Heller's internal control procedures uncovered an intricate series of diversions of funds which amount to a loss of about $19 million.'' **********''We're more disappointed than embarrassed,'' said Robert L.  Meyers, Heller treasurer. ''But, when a senior executive decides he wants to do something tricky, it's very difficult to stop him. He let us down.'' **********Lawsuits have been filed seeking recovery of the funds, the company said, but it was decided to take the write-off because the irregularities may mean an ''entire loss exposure.'' The parent company said that the manager of the Phoenix office and several other employees had been dismissed. **********Heller officials would not give details of the irregularities, nor would they identify any of the dismissed employees. Audits Performed **********In 1981, concerned Heller officials asked that an internal audit be performed on the records of the Phoenix br anch, but the report failed to show anything. Still not satisfied, Heller then sent an independent auditor to check the Phoenix bran ch's books in October.  That investigation uncovered the irregulariti es. **********Heller also filed a claim with the Fidelity Insurance Company to recover $10 million of the loss.  ''Who knows when we'll get it,'' Mr. Meyers said. ''It may be a year, or four or five years before we get it back.'' Nonetheless, the company has also ''learned a very valuable lesson,'' Mr. Meyers added. ''Our regular internal procedures work, but it didn't uncover it fast enough. We'll tighten up our procedures to make them work faster.'' Absorbing the Loss **********Thomas G. Rosencrants, an analyst with William Blair & Company, the Chicago brokerage firm, said, ''Heller won't go out of business because of the theft, but it does say something negative about their financial controls.'' **********To soften the blow, Heller has added the $19 million to the $59 million in problem loans it was prepared to write off against its earnings for 1981. **********Heller is a 62-year-old finance and bank holding company, whose primary customers tend to be small businesses that are unable to meet the strict loan requirements of large banks. Because these assetbased loans have greater risk, Heller tends to charge a higher interest rate. **********With the write-off, Heller earned $23 million on revenues of $900 million in 1981, down from $43 million on revenues of $660 million in 1980. **********According to the company, its net earnings would have totaled $45 million without the write-off, but instead amounted to only $23 million. **********''We elected to take the write-off now,'' Mr. Meyers said. ''Now it won't have an impact on earnings. We expect next year to turn out much better.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/07/world.main_headline: IRANIAN OFFICERS, SEEKING REVENGE, TALK OF PURSUING ARMY INTO IRAQ
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/07/world.print_headline: IRANIAN OFFICERS, SEEKING REVENGE, TALK OF PURSUING ARMY INTO IRAQ
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/07/world.body_text: **********With most Iraqi forces having been driven back across the border this week, some Iranian officers said today they were eager to press on into Iraq, just a mile west of this devastated village. **********''Eventually, we must have our revenge,'' one field commander said.  But the officers apparently have not been given permission to do so by the Government, even though Iran says its offensive has eliminated all but a few Iraqi enclaves on Iranian soil. The Iranian troops are dug in on and behind the high ground here, awaiting counterattacks and conducting reconnaissance patrols. **********Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini and his disciples seem disinclined to attempt a repetition of last summer's unsuccessful thrust toward Basra. The next step may well be an attempt to liberate the Iraqiheld areas near Khurramshahr and Fekkeh, south of here, and near Naft-i-Shah, far to the north. Clouds of Dust **********The Iranian buildup in this area is impressive. Tanks, tank transporters, trucks, jeeps, bulldozers and helicopters shuttle back and forth, sending clouds of dust into the air above the hills, the plain and the picturesque buttes and valleys carved by the Meimeh and Douvrij Rivers. **********The Iranians say they have cleared 210 square miles of Iraqi troops, advancing for about 6 miles along a 35-mile front leading southeast from the town of Dehloran. They also say they have captured intact 45 tanks or armored cars, including several Brazilian-made Cascavel vehicles. These carry a big gun and can make 75 miles an hour. **********A new battalion of the Revolutionary Guards Corps, which gets all Iraqi booty, is to be formed to use the captured armor. The guards appear proficient in handling vehicles of all sorts, despite their sketchy training, but are not involved with planes or helicopters. Fatigues and Tennis Shoes **********The guards corps is now said to number up to 150,000 men, most of them in their 20's. They wear rumpled, often mismatched fatigues and tennis shoes, and many of them tie red scarves bearing Islamic slogans around their heads. Most have had only three months' training. But they are fiercely nationalistic and idealistic and seemingly fearless. They are integrated with regular army units during combat, but the partnership seems unequal. **********At a briefing Friday, for example, a guard in his early 20's did the talking; a regular captain simply muttered at the conclusion that he had nothing to add. A guard said that ''the army's superior technical skills and our powerful faith makes us strong,'' but some regular officers, crisp in their American-style uniforms, and with 15 or 20 years' service, found it hard to disguise their displeasure at being obliged to negotiate every decision with youngsters. **********The guards are an unsmiling lot, given to chanting at any opportunity. They wear no insignia of rank and never salute, and they talk frequently of their willingness to be ''martyrs.'' On their left breast pockets, they wear a blue and gold patch that shows a globe, an arm and an AK-47 assault rifle - a symbol, one 23-year-old explained, of their eagerness to fight overseas ''for the oppressed of the world.'' He mentioned El Salvador as the kind of place where he would like to fight. **********Riding motorcycles, the guards take on tanks with RPG-7 anti-tank rockets. They also attack boldly across mine fields, as do members of the Basij, a paramilitary organization made up mostly of teen-agers.  A fuzzy-cheeked 15-year-old told reporters at Ein-i-Khosh that his parents ''believe that I was a gift from God, so if I'm killed I'd be a gift to God.'' **********The most important Iranian accomplishment in this week's military campaign, it appeared, was freeing the region east of the offensive from the threat of artillery attack. Much of the area had been liberated in March, but, with their guns emplaced on the heights, the Iraqis had been able to shell towns and highways at will. **********Iranian commanders asserted, and Iraqi prisoners-of-war confirmed, that the fighting took place entirely on Iranian soil, despite the contentions of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq that his troops had pulled out of Iran. Burned hulks of Iraqi T-55 tanks, built in the Soviet Union, litter the harsh, arid flatlands near the Iraqi border not far from here. **********The equivalent of three Iranian brigades, more than 10,000 men, were involved in the offensive, which began Monday night. Iranian losses were described as ''lighter than expected'' and the Iranians said they downed 10 Iraqi planes, killed or wounded more than 3,500 Iraqi troops and taken almost 1,750 prisoners. **********The prisoners were assembled today on a gravel parade ground at the big Vahdati air base at Dizful, about 65 miles east of here, for interviews by correspondents. One prisoner, a lieutenant colonel who commanded a battalion, said his men had been surrounded in the rain and in the dark and overwhelmed. He said the Iranian attack had been ''massive, well-organized and precise.'' **********His unit had been sent into Iran to hold the Bayat oilfield, the Iranian part of which lies around Hill 400 near this village. It has a capacity of 25,000 barrels a day. They built reinforced bunkers, laid mines and unrolled yards of concertina barbed wire, the colonel added, but were unable to resist a combined attack by Revolutionary Guards infantry and armor. An Air Base With Familiar Signs **********Despite reports in the West that the Iranian Air Force was all but grounded because of a lack of spare parts, American-built F-5's fly regular sorties from Dizful. **********The air base bears all the hallmarks of its former United States advisers: a huge sign, in English, proclaiming it ''the home of the fighters''; officers who speak in American military slang, calling kilometers ''clicks''; and fancy guest quarters, jocularly known as ''the White House,'' with tiled bathrooms containing sunken tubs.  Visiting correspondents, heckled at every stop with chants of ''Death to America,'' slept there Friday night under United States Army Medical Corps blankets. **********With its neat rows of officers' quarters, its palm trees, its November sunshine and its gas stations labeled POL, for Petroleum, Oil and Lubricants, the base might be in Texas or California. Only the insignia on the C-130's, the F-5's and the Chinook and Huey helicopters are different. **********Many villages have been destroyed. Musian, which has a population of 5,000 before the start of the 25-month Iran-Iraq war, now has a population of zero. Only three or four houses have been left with as much as one wall standing. Utility poles lie on the ground with their lines stretched across the desolate streets. A few battered oil drums mark what was once the main intersection. Outside the village, scraggly cows wander aimlessly. **********The region's economy formerly depended on dairy herds and fruit trees grown with the help of irrigation. Both activities have been ruined, and the pipeline leading from the Bayat field has been severed in several places. There is no sign of nonmilitary activity for mile after forlorn mile.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/13/world.print_headline: ISRAEL REPORTS KNOCKING OUT ANOTHER SYRIAN MISSILE UNIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/13/world.body_text: **********Israeli warplanes destroyed another Syrian ground-to-air mobile missile launcher today in the Bekaa Valley of eastern Lebanon, the military command here reported. **********The command also disclosed that three Israeli soldiers were killed in what it described as a guerrilla ambush in the same region on Friday. **********A Government source said today after the weekly Cabinet meeting in Jerusalem that Israel would not tolerate a war of attrition with Syrian and Palestinian forces in Lebanon. He said Israel would use political or military means to stop such incidents from recurring. **********The attack on the missile launcher was the third such air strike since Wednesday. Six launchers have been destroyed in the three air raids, according to the military command. **********Each of them was said to have had four rockets in launching position and additional ones in storage. All the attacks were in the Dar al-Baideh area six miles east of Bhamdun on the Beirut-Damascus highway. A Warning to Syria **********The military command reiterated a warning that Israel was ''adamant in its resolve not to allow the Syrians to introduce surface-to-air missile batteries into Lebanese territory.'' **********The military command, in its report on the guerrilla attack Friday, said four Israeli soldiers were returning from a reconnaissance mission during the afternoon when their jeep passed a thickly wooded orchard north of Amik. **********The command said guerrillas fired a rocket at the jeep, killing three of the soldiers and wounding the fourth. The orchard was between the Israeli and Syrian positions. **********Dan Meridor, the Cabinet spokesman, said Israel had warned Syria through the United States that the authorities in Damascus would be held responsible for breaches of the cease-fire by guerrillas operating in Lebanese territory controlled by Syria. 98 Truce Violations Reported **********The Israeli press said today that 4,000 to 5,000 guerrillas, including some reportedly withdrawn from Beirut, had been deployed in territory under Syrian control. The Syrians were said to have 30,000 troops in Lebanon and 10,000 more just over the border. There were said to be 1,500 Syrian tanks in Lebanon. **********A background paper issued tonight by the military command asserted that Syrian and guerrilla forces had broken the cease-fire in the region 98 times since July 23. **********The cease-fire came after heavy Israeli attacks on Syrian forces in the area destroyed 72 tanks, 2 self-propelled cannons, 18 armored personnel carriers and 9 other vehicles. **********The paper said 12 Israeli soldiers had been killed because of truce violations. It said violations had also led to the deaths of 20 Lebanese soldiers and one Lebanese civilian. Five Lebanese civilians were said to have been wounded. Nine guerrillas were killed and three captured, according to the report. **********The document said Syria supplied intelligence information and logistic support to the guerrillas, enabling them to cross the lines to lay mines and attack Israeli positions with rifles and rocketpropelled grenades. **********At the Cabinet meeting, the ministers rejected the peace plan approved at the recent conference of Arab League leaders in Fez, Morocco. They said the proposals were ''hostile and anti-Israeli'' and ''aimed at the destruction of Israel.'' ---- Guerrilla Version of Attack **********SHTAURA, Lebanon, Sept. 12 (Reuters) - A leader of the Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine said today that his group had ambushed an Israeli vehicle in the Bekaa Valley and killed six soldiers. **********The guerrilla leader, Abul Abed, a member of the front's central committee, said the Palestinians fired rocket-propelled grenades at an Israeli command vehicle six to seven miles behind Israeli lines two days ago. **********Speaking at a command post near the Bekaa Valley town of Shtaura, he said a senior officer was among the Israelis killed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/03/world.main_headline: Rockefeller Said to See Hope for Angolan Ties
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/03/world.print_headline: Rockefeller Said to See Hope for Angolan Ties
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/03/world.body_text: **********David Rockefeller, on an African tour, says his visit to Angola could help toward normalizing relations between Angola and the United States, the official Angolan press agency reported today. **********Mr. Rockefeller, a director and former chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank and a strong advocate of United States recognition of Angola, told the agency after visiting oil installations in northern Angola that his trip was essentially commercial. **********But he added that it ''could accelerate the process toward normalization of relations between the United States and Angola,'' according to an agency dispatch received in Lisbon from Luanda, the Angolan capital. **********Washington has refused to establish diplomatic relations with Luanda because of the presence of Cuban troops in Angola since its independence from Portugal in 1975.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/03/busin.body_text: **********Under a program announced Thursday by Citibank, a customer could lose hundreds of dollars if checks deposited to his account were to bounce, the bank said yesterday. **********But Richard C. Kane, a senior vice president, said that the chances of that happening were slight, and that the bank would make every effort to avoid it. **********The new program is intended to enable customers to draw cash immediately from automated teller machines against checks deposited to their checking accounts, even before the deposited checks are cleared. Citibank protects itself by holding the customer's other accounts as collateral until the deposited checks clear. **********There would be no problem as long as all checks deposited eventually cleared satisfactorily. Effect of Forced Withdrawal **********But if the checks did not clear, the depositor could be subject to heavy losses if Citibank, to compensate for the bounced checks, took money out of certain other accounts held by the depositor: Heavy penalties required by the Federal Government could apply if such an action involved a premature withdrawal from certain deposit accounts. **********For example, the Government imposes a penalty of three months' interest for the premature cashing of six-month money market certificates. **********The Government requires that these certificates be issued in minimum denominations of $10,000. But Citibank has a program under which an individual need deposit only $3,000 of his own money, and the bank will lend him the additional $7,000 to buy one of these certificates. **********If the customer had only $3,000 in the certificate, and if the bank charged the account because of a bounced check, the customer would be subject to a three-month penalty based on the entire $10,000. If the yield on the certificate were 12 percent, the penalty would be $300. **********Mr. Kane said, however, that Citibank, before it would draw funds from the certificate, would notify the customer that the check he had deposited had bounced, and the customer would be given a few days to try to correct it. **********In addition, Mr. Kane said, if Citibank had to make a drawing to cover a bounced check, the bank would try to cause the customer the least difficulty. For example, it would first draw from a customer's line of credit, if he had one with the bank, or it would draw the funds from the portion of a $10,000 certificate above $3,000, automatically giving the depositor a loan for the amount taken.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/31/world.main_headline: KIRKPATRICK FEUD WITH HAIG IS NOTED
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/31/world.print_headline: KIRKPATRICK FEUD WITH HAIG IS NOTED
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/31/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the United States delegate to the United Nations, engaged in a heated argument last week over United States policy in the Falkland Islands, aides to Mrs. Kirkpatrick said today. **********The quarrel was said to have been touched off by private meetings Mrs. Kirkpatrick held with high-ranking Argentine and other Latin American officials. **********According to one account, Mr. Haig accused Mrs. Kirkpatrick of undermining his policy of support for Britain, a NATO ally led by a Conservative Government. Mrs. Kirkpatrick is said to have responded that Mr. Haig lacked sensitivity to Latin American concerns. Mr.  Haig's tone was described as angry while Mrs. Kirkpatrick's was described as cool. **********'A Lively Exchange' **********Today, Mrs. Kirkpatrick said, ''It was a lively exchange.'' Asked if she and Mr. Haig reproached each other, she replied, ''Basically there is less than perfect agreement.'' **********The precipitating incident was believed to be a meeting held by Mrs. Kirkpatrick in New York on Tuesday with Brig. Jose Miret, Argentina's Secretary of State for State Planning. Argentine officials said the brigadier is one of a half-dozen officials in the second tier of authority, just below the ruling three-man junta. **********Asked about the meeting last week, Mrs. Kirkpatrick said the two largely discussed what the United Nations might do to end the crisis. She said that the brigadier was one of 15 or 20 Latin American officials with whom she met. **********''I've spoken a great deal of Spanish in the past week,'' she said. ''I've done a lot of listening and reporting to the State Department.'' U.S.-Latin Ties at Issue **********Mrs. Kirkpatrick is known to favor a more neutral stance between Britain and Argentina to arrest the deterioriating relations between the United States and the southern hemisphere. She is the author of a book on the Argentina of Juan Domingo Peron and is a specialist in Latin American politics. **********Newsweek magazine, first to disclose the quarrel, said that Mr.  Haig and Mrs. Kirkpatrick traded angry words for 45 minutes. Mr. Haig was said to have accused Mrs. Kirkpatrick of interfering with his handling of foreign affairs and to have said her links to Latin Americans clouded her view of the Falklands. **********Mrs. Kirkpatrick reportedly retorted that Mr. Haig was surrounded by pro-British aides and could not understand Latin American feelings. **********The United Nations delegate said today: ''There has been a big debate in our Government. This is an agonizing issue. There are powerful arguments for remaining neutral and for tilting to Britain.  I have leaned to the neutral side.'' **********She added, ''There aren't very many people in our Government who take an interest in Latin America.'' The State Department would not comment on the exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/21/busin.body_text: **********Attorneys for those owed money by Lombard-Wall Inc. postponed forming a creditors' committee yesterday because of uncertainty over just how much unsecured debt was held by the failed government securities firm. **********Only the attorney for the New York State Dormitory Authority stood and said he wanted to serve on the committee because his client definitely had unsecured debt. **********''We don't form one-member committees,'' the acting United States trustee, Cornelius Blackshear, said after the morning meeting at the Federal Building in Manhattan. Mr. Blackshear and his deputies, who organize creditors' committees to oversee corporate reorganizations, gave the attorneys two more weeks to decide if they wanted to form such a group for Lombard-Wall. Filing Made Aug. 12 **********Lombard-Wall and its subsidiary, Lombard-Wall Money Markets, filed for protection from creditors Aug. 12 under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act after the Bankers Trust Company expressed concern about the companies' financial condition and stopped clearing their transactions. **********In its initial court filing, Lombard-Wall said its 10 largest unsecured creditors held unsecured debts of $177.2 million. The Dormitory Authority, which raises money in the tax-free bond market for public and private institutions in the state, was listed as the largest unsecured creditor, with $52 million in unsecured debt and an additional $250 million of secured debt. **********On Thursday, Moody's Investors Service suspended its ratings on issues sold in recent years by the authority for six New York hospitals. The authority had invested with Lombard-Wall the hospitals' funds that were not immediately needed for construction. **********Yesterday, the Standard & Poor's Corporation said it decided against changing any ratings after discussing the situation with Lombard-Wall and reviewing the progress it had made in liquidating securities. **********Much of Lombard-Wall's business was in repurchase agreements, in which the company borrowed money and put up securities as collateral. Lombard-Wall was also involved in reverse repurchase agreements, in which it lent money and held securities as collateral. **********The idea was to profit by lending out funds or securities at a higher interest rate than they were borrowed. Falling Rates Brighten Picture **********Several of the more than 50 lawyers at yesterday's meeting said they were uncertain just how much of the creditors' debt was unsecured. One reason was that falling interest rates had increased the value of securities being held as collateral. **********Many of the attorneys also indicated that they were trying to negotiate a settlement with Lombard-Wall. The firm obtained a temporary restraining order last week, forbidding creditors from selling collateral. However, it has reached agreements with several of the largest creditors, allowing them to sell securities, recoup their money and turn over a profit to Lombard-Wall. **********Yesterday, Federal Bankruptcy Judge Edward J. Ryan signed three more agreements, permitting the Bucks County Bank and Trust Company, of Quakertown, Pa., to recover $10.1 million invested for the Bucks County Industrial Development Authority; Ashland Oil Inc., of Ashland, Ky., to recover $7.2 million, and the Merchants National Bank, of Topeka, Kan., to recover $876,000. **********Judge Ryan is scheduled to hold a hearing Monday morning on whether other firms acted improperly by selling securities they were holding as collateral. At issue is whether Lombard or the firm from which it borrowed money owned the securities. **********In a separate development, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York announced that Edward J. Geng, senior vice president of the Baer American Banking Corporation, was named to the newly created post of senior vice president in charge of government securities surveillance. The Fed set up an informal surveillance unit after the failure in May of Drysdale Government Securities. With the failure of Lombard-Wall, the Fed has decided to strengthen the group.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/13/busin.body_text: **********SINCE it takes less energy to slice through the air than to plow it aside, automobile designers throughout the world are trying to improve vehicle aerodynamics as a way to get better fuel economy. **********When a car travels faster than 50 miles an hour, more than half the energy needed to keep it moving goes to overcome wind resistance, and this proportion grows as the speed increases. There is a rule of thumb in the auto industry that a 10 percent increase in aerodynamic efficiency yields a 3 to 4 percent increase in overall fuel economy. **********Such an improvement is all the more attractive since it is essentially free, compared with the hundreds of millions of dollars needed to produce more efficient engines or lighter structures. ''A car's got to have that sheet metal, so I can make a signifigant contribution if I can find a way to bend it more efficiently,'' says Jack Telnack, the chief design executive for the Ford Motor Company's North American operations. **********This emphasis on slippery shapes is changing the way new cars are designed. Engineers in Detroit who once demanded ever more powerful engines and stylists whose favorite color was chrome now spend hours huddled at wind tunnels, seeking the sleekest shape and surface. Drag coefficients have replaced horsepower ratings -and, to some extent, even mileage ratings - as symbols of technological achievement. **********Drag coefficients are determined in a wind tunnel. Each wheel of a car sits on a sensitive scale that measures the change in forces as wind speed increases. The coefficient is the force divided by the frontal area of the car and adjusted for the density and velocity of the air. **********The drag coefficient is expressed as a decimal, with 1 defined as a flat plate facing the air stream. In the cheap energy era of the 1960's and early 1970's, most American cars had drag coefficients in the range from high 0.5 to low 0.6. Today's cars average about 0.45, according to design engineers at the General Motors Corporation. Some new models, including G.M.'s new Pontiac Firebird, are in the low 0.3 area. A few experimental models have gotten down to 0.22. **********When G.M. engineers placed a sleek experimental fiberglass body on one of its ''X'' cars, the drag coefficient dropped from 0.45 for the production model to 0.285, and highway mileage increased by 15 miles a gallon. **********The basic idea of aerodynamic automobile design is to make the air flow as smoothly as possible along the surface of the car without touching off drag-inducing turbulence. As a result, the wedge shape - characterized by a low, sloping front hood and a high, bluff rear end - is becoming more common. Although old-time ''streamlining'' usually included a tapered back, designers say it is better to make a clean break with the air. Engineers say they expect more fastback designs, replacing the traditional ''three-box'' layout of distinct hood, roof and rear deck. **********Other modifications for new car models include flush side molding, window glass bonded to the body, and wheels and wheel covers in line with the side of the body to minimize turbulence. **********In fact, the quest for a smooth airflow may bring back fender skirts, a style feature of the 1950's. An innovation will be found on the redesigned 1983 Ford Thunderbird, which will have the traditional drip rails along the roof line concealed by extending the doors into the roof. **********Air management under the car is getting attention too. Some designs now include an air dam to divert most of the air stream away from engine and suspension components, while others are exploring partly or completely enclosed undersides. **********Aerodynamic automobile design remains something of a black art for various reasons. Since air is invisible, for instance, it is hard for engineers to determine exactly how it is flowing over their models.  And computer-aided design, which has revolutionized the planning of many other automobile components, has not yet been able to deal with the complex movement of air over a car. **********''In some ways it's easier to do an airplane,'' said Charles H.  Torner, an executive engineer at G.M.'s Technical Center in Warren, Mich. ''Aircraft shapes tend to be simpler, and you have a free flow of air on all sides. A car has fenders, bumpers, headlights and other protrusions as well as the interaction with the road surface.'' **********To make things harder, designers cannot be sure the results they get with the one-third-size models used in wind tunnel tests will be reproduced in full-size cars. For this reason, G.M. recently spent $25 million to build a wind tunnel at its Technical Center to conduct full-size testing. **********In the 1930's the Chrysler Corporation introduced its ''Airflow'' models. They were hailed as a technical success, but they looked too different from other cars to become popular and were dropped after a few years. Citroen has been making aerodynamically efficient cars for decades, but they have not been a big sales success outside France. **********Now, however, designers are counting on higher mileage to overcome consumers' resistance to radical-looking automobiles.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/31/busin.main_headline: ON THE FRONTIER OF A NEW ECONOMICS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/31/busin.print_headline: ON THE FRONTIER OF A NEW ECONOMICS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/31/busin.body_text: **********ELECTION day, November 1932.  America's economic problems were the dominant issue - the only issue - in the landslide Presidential victory of Franklin Delano Roosevelt. The economy was in collapse and F.D.R. had pledged to create jobs for the nation's 12 million unemployed - while somehow managing to balance the Federal budget. Little did he know then that eventually he would embrace the radical ideas of a Briton named John Maynard Keynes, who advocated huge deficit spending to bring the United States out of its depression. **********Now it is election day, 1982. The shattered economy is once again the dominant issue of a national political campaign. Unemployment is at 10.1 percent, not the 24 percent of Roosevelt's era - thanks in large part to the adoption since then of Keynesian policies to cushion an economic decline. Still, hopes for recovery keep moving further into the future, notwithstanding the President's insistence on the campaign trail this fall that his policies will soon restore the economy to buoyant, noninflationary growth. **********There are some who share this belief, who think the economy's vitality can be restored by shrinking the relative size of Government and lowering tax rates. And there are others who, doubting this, still think that Keynesian policies remain the basic solution to the nation's economic problems, with some minor modifications to avoid a revival of inflation. **********But there is a third, emergent group of analysts - at the frontiers of economic thinking - that believes neither Lord Keynes nor President Reagan has provided the answers to the stagnation that has plagued the American economy for a decade or so. This group has no grand theory and no grand theorist to lead it - at least not yet.  It's an odd assortment of bankers, businessmen and politicians, of Nobel-prize winning economists and those of less distinction. They share a conviction that President Reagan or a president after him will need to do what F.D.R. did a half century ago: develop a new set of policies to meet a new economic crisis, one of stagnation and potentially explosive inflation rather than spiraling depression. **********EVEN so distinquished a Keynesian as Paul A. Samuelson fears that traditional policies will no longer be enough. They may spur the United States economy out of recession, said the Nobel Laureate, but they will not propel it very far along the elusive path of healthy growth. **********''If the world did what it ought to do and engineered a real recovery, the structural problems would still remain,'' said Professor Samuelson, a professor of economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. ''They would not just go away. If we go on with business as usual, what we will have is more of the stop-and-go driving, more stagnation.'' **********To such thinkers the perils of Pittsburgh and Detroit, the ascendancy of Japan and Germany and the paltry growth of productivity in the United States during recent years, are a telling history.  Though their views may differ in detail, these analysts see recent history as proof that many of America's economic policies and institutions - its free-wheeling labor settlements, its catagorical income support programs, its jumble of policies affecting business and industry - are outmoded. These so-called ''structuralists'' think such problems threaten the very heart of the American economic system and the growing affluence that so many Americans have come to regard as their birthright. **********''The problem now is that we have structural impediments in the economy that make any macroeconomic policy insufficient,'' said Robert Reich, a professor at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government.  ''When you have only 69 percent of capacity being used, 10 percent unemployment, a crumbling infrastructure, a labor force becoming steadily demoralized, to me these are not signs of an economy that is adjusting.'' **********For Mr. Reich, what's needed is a more coherent Government approach to industry. For others, like Bennett Harrison of M.I.T and Barry Bluestone of Boston College, the fundamental need is for changes in the adversarial relations of business and labor. To Felix Rohatyn, a partner at the investment banking firm of Lazard Freres & Company, a new financing mechanism to help direct money to select industries is critical. And still others, like Mr. Samuelson, worry about excessive wages in some basic industries, but see no easy way to bring them in line. **********''I don't have a nice program that is so obviously correct that it is bound to command approval,'' Mr. Samuelson said.  The structuralists offer no simple, singular explanation for the slowing of productivity and growth - but, again, their focus is generally on programs and institutions. Mr. Samuelson thinks a key factor is the demise of the work ethic, a deterioration fostered by affluence and by a host of well-meaning, but excessive income support programs. He and others also brood about the tendency of wages in this country to go up, but not down, ultimately pricing American labor - and its products - out of many highly competitive international markets. **********IN interviews and in their new book, ''The Deindustrialization of America,'' Mr. Bluestone and Mr. Harrison describe the problem as a breakdown of communications between labor and management compounded by the mobility of capital that has led to what they call corporate disinvestment in the United States. American corporations, they note, have found it easier to flee the United States for lower-wage countries, rather than develop new products and processes to provide profitable work for American workers. Harvard economist John Kenneth Galbraith agrees, blaming the problem on the ''sclerosis'' of corporate management. **********And Robert Zevin, a senior vice president and economist with the United States Trust Company in Boston, points to a kind of technological turning point the United States reached in the mid-1960's. ''Up until then, every new plant was bigger, more fuel efficient, more labor efficient, and real prices and unit prices went down,'' he says. This, combined with the inflationary bias of Keynesian policies, Mr. Zevin says, has hurt.'' **********At this stage, the structuralists' solutions to the nation's problems are diverse - and murky. In part, this may be inevitable because the problems that concern them are basically institutional and as such are not matters that modern economists, skilled in data handling and computer analysis, handle most readily. Mr. Reich, a lawyer and political scientist himself, puts it this way: ''Macroeconomists are not interested in or knowledgable about institutions since they haven't studied them. Their reference is economic aggregates. What we're talking about is a new discipline that is not antithetical to economics, but that looks at different issues.'' **********Mr. Reich, who has emerged as a popular adviser this year to socalled neo-liberal Democratic politicians, thinks the United States must make existing institutions, including labor unions and businesses, more amenable to change. Organized labor,'' he thinks, ''could be a terrific vehicle for change if it embraced training, relocation and other programs that could foster change.'' **********Another critical component of the Reich strategy calls for an overhaul of Government policies to encourage business modernization, rather than inhibit it. He notes that Government policies such as antitrust rules, tariffs, quotas, loan guarantees and price supports already shape how business operates, but without any coherent theme. **********Mr. Harrison and his research partner Mr. Bluestone are even less specific about an agenda, although their main concern is that labor not be decimated in the process. Mr. Harrison notes that for decades, there has been a ''social contract'' between business and labor: ''Labor would come to the bargaining table every two to three years to get new wages that would reflect gains in productivity and inflation. Business agreed to share because it bought them industrial peace.'' **********But, as he notes, ''that system - the industrial relations of a growth era -is clearly breaking down in this new era of shrinkage.'' For this reason, these analysts endorse some form of industrial planning. ''It may be true that an incredible recession will force real wages down to the point where it will be profitable to hire workers again,'' Mr. Bluestone said. ''But in the meantime, the costs of that are immense. The whole idea behind industrial planning is that you can shorten the time periods so that the economy moves more quickly and more directly and with less cost.'' **********SOME skeptics question whether any form of Government planning can work as well as the free market. Planning advocates, however, generally point to Japan and Germany as examples where a loose form of Government intervention appears to have benefited industry and the country as a whole. As Mr. Bluestone notes: ''We and most people in Europe believe it is possible to have an industrial policy with an ingredient of forward planning that does work.'' **********Even on Wall Street, the alleged heart of the capitalism, Mr.  Rohatyn sees a role for more direction from the top - at least for a while. ''The Government has to lean against the wind to keep imbalances from getting out of hand,'' he says. ''These may be regional differentials, social inequities, racial inequities, or budgetary problems, but the market is not necessarily a balancing force. It may be destabilizing,'' he says, echoing Lord Keynes' rationale for deficit spending enunciated decades ago. ''This does@n't mean I am for a planned economy,'' he adds. ''But in certain areas, at certain times, it is necessary for the Government to intervene.'' **********Recalling his experience during the New York City financial crisis in the mid-1970's, and the problems in dealing with the various factions - labor, business, government, the public -Mr. Rohatyn also points out the need for some kind of mechanism that will permit various groups to make unpalatable decisions, such as postponing pay increases or cutting services. **********''We're like a ship that has accumulated barnacles for the last 25 years,'' Mr. Rohatyn comments. ''Management has not been alert.  Labor is asking too much. Now we have to pay for it by restructuring, or rolling back. And it is very difficult to roll back gains in a democracy without setting up some kind of bargaining structure.'' **********Thinking along these structuralist lines is, of course, still resisted by many. Francis M. Bator, a professor of political economy at Harvard University, argues that an overvalued dollar is the main problem behind America's problems in foreign markets. He also thinks that traditional Keynesian stimulus would go far to help boost the economy's prospects. ''A lot of the secular problems people are talking about are really just symptoms of very deep business cycle problems,'' he says. '' If we fixed macroeconomics properly all these structural problems would drop down to third order of magnitude problems.'' **********As for the White House, it is still betting that an imminent recovery will put enormous structural problems to rest. The Administration's bow to structuralism is embedded in the ''supplyside'' tax cut of 1981 and in its continuing effort to reduce regulation and enhance the power of the market wherever possible. **********To the true structuralists, however, this optimism is reminiscent of the early days of the Roosevelt era, when atavistic policies proved no match for the problems of the day. It took F.D.R. years to abandon his budget balancing rhetoric and to adopt wholeheartedly the ideas of Lord Keynes. Even then, it was the rise of Hitler, not purely economic insight. that finally led the country back to full employment and growth. THE EVOLUTION OF F.D.R.'S ECONOMICS **********The country needs and, unless I mistake its temper, the country demands, bold, persistent experimentation. It is common sense to take a method and try it. If it fails, admit it frankly and try another.  But above all, try something.  May 22, 1932 **********Government, like any family, can for a year spend a little more than it earns. But you and I know that a continuance of that habit means the poorhouse. July 30, 1932 **********We have called on enlightened business judgment, on understanding labor and on intelligent agriculture to provide a more equitable balance of the abundant life between all ele- ments of the community. Dec.6, 1933 **********The Federal Government is in a better position than it ever has been to prevent that disastrous expansion and contraction of credit which in the past has made our economic life a succession of unhealthy booms and disastrous depressions.  Oct.2, 1935 **********We do not yet know enough in a changing economic order to guarantee any nation permanently against times of depression. We believe, however, that steps like these which we have taken and are taking will at least greatly cushion depression - will prevent the up-curve from rushing to a violent, mad peak of false prosperity and prevent another violent, mad descent into another sink of suffering and disillusionment like the one from which for the last three-and-ahalf years we have been surely emerging. April 13, 1936 **********To balance our budget in 1933 or 1934 or 1935 would have been a crime against the American people. To do so we should either have had to make a capital levy that would have been confiscatory, or we should have had to set our face against human suffering with callous indifference. Oct.1, 1936 **********I will always believe in private enterprise as the backbone of economic well-being in the U.S...It was this Administration which saved the system of private profit and free enterprise after it had been dragged to the brink of ruin. Oct.14, 1936 **********I am glad that prosperity is back with us again and, believe me, it is going to stay. Oct.22, 1936 **********None of this (recovery) came by chance. It came because your Government refused to leave it to chance. Oct.29, 1936 **********...The Treasury is all right and we are balancing that budget - you needn't worry... Oct.3, 1937 **********It has taken courage for the Federal Government to go into the 'red,' ... But it has been worth it. July 8, 1938 **********The deliberate use of government funds and of government credit to energize private enterprise - to put purchasing power in the hands of those who urgently needed it and to create a demand for the products of factory and farm - had a profound effect both on Government and private incomes ... https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/07/world.body_text: **********Clouds of hot ash and debris kept American helicopter pilots from reaching thousands of villagers stranded today on the slopes of El Chinchonal. **********Experts said the volcano was still trembling. **********Twenty-one people have been killed and more than 500 injured in a series of eruptions that began March 29.
