https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/26/busin.body_text: **********To the Business Editor: Representative George Miller, in ''Don't Let Industry Shirk Its Duty'' (Sept. 5), and other writers, have talked about the ''asbestos industry'' as if the more than 200 companies involved in asbestos litigation were one and the same - equally involved, equally negligent and equally responsible. This simply is not true. **********Keene Corporation and some other companies never mined or manufactured asbestos - as the Manville Corporation did and still does - but purchased it from mining companies as well as from the United States Government. **********Keene Corporation was formed in 1967, and in 1968 purchased the stock of Baldwin-Erhet-Hill, a small fabricator of thermal insulation products, some of which contained small amounts of asbestos. Had Keene been aware of an asbestos hazard, it never would have purchased Baldwin. When reports of a hazard to insulation workers were confirmed, Baldwin labeled its asbestos-containing products as potentially harmful and at the same time started to remove the fiber from these products. By the end of 1972, less than four years after the acquisition, the use of asbestos was discontinued. Despite its limited involvement through Baldwin, Keene has faced more than 14,000 legal suits, the cost of which far exceeds the profits earned by or the price Keene paid for the company. **********Keene was drawn into these asbestos cases because asbestos supplied by others was used in Baldwin's thermal insulation products. Those suppliers were substantially larger than Baldwin and had research departments, medical staffs and superior knowledge concerning asbestos and its hazards. How could Baldwin be drawn into the asbestos cases? In an attempt to cut its own losses, Manville brought Keene and other customers into the initial cases, knowing that all of the companies in the chain of distribution jointly could be held legally liable regardless of fault. **********And what about the Government's responsibility? While some tend to underplay it, the role of the United States Government in this mess simply cannot be ignored. The United States Government established military specifications requiring the use of asbestos, established ''safe level'' workplace standards for Government-owned and contract shipyards and then failed to enforce these standards, stockpiled and sold raw asbestos to the ''asbestos industry'' and in 1945 issued a Public Health Service report which erroneously concluded that insulation workers were not at risk. Almost half of the cases against Keene have been brought by former employees of Government-owned or controlled shipyards. **********Moreover, it appears that the United States Government is reaping positive financial rewards from this litigation. Federal Government employees receive compensation through the Federal Employees Compensation Act (F.E.C.A). If a former Government employee sues Keene and recovers, a part of the recovery is then ''recouped'' by the Government to make up for the F.E.C.A. payments made to the employee. **********Keene is in the unique position of being the only company which fought for and obtained real insurance coverage. After a four-year legal battle that went all the way to the United States Supreme Court, Keene gained a Federal court decision requiring its primary insurance carriers to pay for essentially all of Keene's asbestos litigation expenses up to the limits of the policies. **********However, the magnitude of the asbestos situation indicates that the nation faces a major societal problem that cannot be solved in the courts - a problem that compensates lawyers handsomely and shortchanges those who are truly injured. Experience indicates that of every dollar spent on asbestos litigation, about 70 cents goes to lawyers, 15 cents to insurance companies and only 15 cents to those claiming an injury. **********Even though Keene is in the position of having significant insurance coverage, other companies - no matter what type of product they produce -may not find such protection in the future. Companies in almost any industry could face a crushing array of product liability claims that will have to be handled through a system of compensation in which everyone but lawyers is a loser. **********The pertinent question is how to compensate injured workers. Keene has and will continue to ask Congress, the ''asbestos industry,'' the insurance industry and others to work towards a solution to that question. **********Bankruptcies and lawsuits are not the answer.  GLENN W. BAILEY Chairman Keene Corporation Manhattan, Sept.21, 1982  ---------------------------------------------------------------------  More letters on Page 23.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/19/world.print_headline: SALVADORANS AT FT. BENNING 'A SMATTERING' OF JUNGLE WAR
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/19/world.body_text: **********A group of five soldiers struggled to find a way to move a heavy, cumbersome, two-wheel cart across the water with only bridge pilings and a few boards to work with, and time was running out. Two-thirds of the way across, the soldiers and the cart plummeted into the water. **********That was one of 17 outdoor leadership tests given today to 156 Salvadoran officer candidates training at this large military base on the outskirts of Columbus, Ga. The problem-solving exercises are the same as those given to United State Army officer candidates. **********According to the Army instructors, the Salvadorans perform virtually the same as others who have been through the course.  The soldiers, almost all of them between the ages of 19 and 21, are part of a contingent of 490 Salvadorans selected to qualify to become officers in the Salvadoran Army by training here for 14 weeks instead of four years at El Salvador's military academy. 1,000 Trained at Fort Bragg **********In addition, 1,000 noncommissioned officers and infantry soldiers are being trained by American instructors at Fort Bragg, N.C., as part of the Reagan Administration's plan to aid the Salvadoran Government in its war against some 4,000 to 6,000 leftist guerrillas. **********Publicly, Army spokesmen and other military officers said today that the Salvadorans ''are doing very well.'' They said the officer candidates had performed ''superbly on the rifle range; their marksmanship is near the very top.'' **********''They are enthusiastic and interested in learning,'' Lieut. Col.  Wayne Andrews, the public affairs officer in charge of the ''noninterference visual opportunity'' for the press, said today.  ''They look like they are good soldiers.'' **********Privately, however, other officers, including some instructors, acknowledged the ghosts of Vietnam floating on the morning fog of Fort Benning. **********Pressed about potential parallels between this training mission and the United States' advisory involvement in the early years in South Vietnam, the officers force a smile and say they are not qualified to address such a question. Jungle Warfare Training **********Asked whether they think that these trainees will be able to fight productively at home under higher-ranking officers who have limited, if any, knowledge of the tactics or methods taught here, or whether United States military officers will be needed to lead them in battlefield exercises, the instructors give the same smile and the same answer. **********Colonel Andrews said the candidates would receive ''a smattering'' of antiguerrilla and jungle warfare training, even though virtually all the fighting in El Salvador is against guerrillas and much of it is in jungles. He said the soldiers training at Fort Bragg were receiving more hours of guerrilla-related, Special Forces-type instruction. **********He added that leadership and small-unit tactics training were applicable in any locale and in much of the fighting that the Salvadoran candidates would face at home. **********The colonel said the candidates were generally of a higher educational, social and economic level in El Salvador and had been picked for the training here because of those qualifications. The Salvadoran Army has about 700 officers, considered far fewer than the more than 1,000 needed in its 22,000-member armed forces. Cost Put at $3 Million **********Colonel Andrews said the training of the 490 men would cost slightly more than $3 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/06/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou dismissed his Under Secretary of Foreign Affairs because he failed to block a Common Market communique criticizing Soviet involvement in Poland's crackdown, Government and diplomatic sources said today. **********In a one-sentence statement, the Prime Minister said Asimakis Fotilas, the Under Secretary, had been dismissed ''because he failed to follow the instructions of Foreign Minister Ioannis Haralambopoulos'' at Monday's meeting of the Common Market foreign ministers. **********The Foreign Ministry and Government spokesman refused to elaborate. **********Other Government and diplomatic sources, however, confirmed that Mr. Papandreou had expected Mr. Fotilas to veto a clause in the final communique blaming the Soviet Union and its allies for the crackdown in Poland. Opposition Assails Government **********The disputed phrase in the communique, approved unanimously in Brussels by the 10 member countries of the European Economic Community, said the Polish situation was affected by ''serious external pressure and the campaign directed by the Soviet Union and other Eastern European countries against the efforts for renewal in Poland.'' **********The Government later formally disassociated itself from the communique, underlining its insistence on not condemning Soviet and Eastern European involvement in Poland. A statement by Dimitrios Maroudas, spokesman for the Government, said Greece ''does not consider itself bound by the communique.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/25/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; SmithKline Head Gets Added Post
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/25/busin.body_text: **********Henry Wendt, the 48-year-old president of the SmithKline Corporation, a major pharmaceutical and health-related product company, has been elected to the additional post of chief executive officer. He succeeds Robert F. Dee, 57, who continues as chairman of the Philadelphia-based corporation. **********''We are less affected by economic cycles than most,'' Mr. Wendt said in a telephone interview. ''The pharmaceutical industry is unusually well insulated from the general vicissitudes of the economy. We make products for people who have a very real need.'' **********Mr. Wendt also noted that ''our business is fueled by new products.'' The company's biggest product today, and the largest selling prescription drug in the world, is Tagamet, an ulcer medication introduced in 1976. **********Mr. Wendt began at SmithKline in 1955 and has spent his entire career there. He became president of consumer products 18 years later, executive vice president of the parent company in 1974 and president in 1976. **********Mr. Dee, also a career man at the company, joined in 1948 and became a vice president in 1967. He was named a group vice president two years later, president and chief executive in 1972 and chairman six years ago. **********''We see some effects of the current economy, and it's going to be tough in the next six moths for the industry in general,'' Mr. Wendt stated. ''But we will see a swing in the last half of the year, and I think it will benefit all business.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/07/busin.body_text: **********Pay rises for top executives in American corporations slipped to 13 percent in l98l from the 1980 average of 14 percent because of lower inflation and declining profits, according to an annual study of about 16,500 executives released yesterday. **********The findings also indicated that future increases in top-executive base salaries will lag behind the inflationary rise.  The study was the 10th annual survey on executive compensation conducted for the Financial Executives Institute by Arthur Young & Company. It was based on an analysis of pay of executives in more than 1,600 companies in 27 industries and in all seven regions of the United States. **********The highest-paid executives last year were those in the chemical industry, earning an average total compensation of about $190,319.  Top executives in the petroleum industry were next highest, earning an average $172,550, followed by those in communications, where the average earnings were $166,874. **********Executives working in high-level posts in industrialized and newly industrialized countries are highest paid in Japan and lowest in Britain, according to another survey. The Business International Corporation, a consulting and research concern, conducted the survey covering 1981 for its multinational clients. **********In industrialized countries surveyed, salaries in Britain were the lowest at all levels as were those in Hong Kong among newly industrialized nations. Salaries in Brazil for middle management were the highest of all countries surveyed while lower-level executives in Belgium had the highest salaries in that job category. Financial Executives Study **********The Financial Executives study found that real estate executives ranked lowest of the industries surveyed, earning an average $96,437. Just above them were top executives in commercial banking, earning an average $101,012, and life insurance executives, who earned $103,843. **********The same study found that top executives working in the Northeast section of the United States had the highest average total compensation, with senior executives there earning $147,890, in contrast to top executives in the Rocky Mountain states, who had the lowest compensation, averaging $88,501. **********Edwin S. Mruk, a partner in Arthur Young who along with James A.  Giardina, also a partner, conducted the study, said: ''When compared with the compensation earned by some entertainers and sports figures, executive salaries appear modest. Executive pay in more than 75 percent of United States corporations is directly related to corporate performance. In many companies, because of poor economics, executive pay has been frozen or cut.'' **********Added Mr. Giardina: ''There is no doubt that companies are placing less emphasis on base salaries and markedly greater emphasis on variable forms of compensation. The evident trend toward variable compensation based on performance is borne out by our study, which shows that the rate of increase in base salaries in 1981 tended to trail significantly that of the increase in bonus payments.'' **********Norman Wellen, president and chief executive of Business International, said that compensation norms varied between the United States and Japan. ''In the U.S., there are stock options, insurance, profit-sharing, and so on, besides salary,'' he said. ''In Japan and in many other foreign countries, the perks may include free housing, cars, chauffeurs, free social service benefits to the entire family as extras paid for by the businesses. In addition, any tax on perks is also paid by the employer.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/30/world.main_headline: NEW STRIFE IN AFGHAN PARTY REPORTED
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/30/world.print_headline: NEW STRIFE IN AFGHAN PARTY REPORTED
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/30/world.body_text: **********President Babrak Karmal of Afghanistan, who returned home last week after a two-month visit to East Germany and the Soviet Union, is facing opposition from members of the ruling Communist party who are angered by the reported slaying of hundreds of young party activists in a valley north of Kabul, the capital, Western diplomats said today. **********Hundreds of young Communists were said to have been killed on June 14 in an ambush by Afghan guerrillas near the strategic Panjshir Valley about 70 miles north of Kabul. The party activists, many in their teens, had gone to the area in a convoy to support a joint military offensive by Afghan and Soviet forces that apparently have seized control of much of the narrow, winding corridor. **********''Party officials, especially members of the Khalq faction, have openly resisted efforts to take people from state enterprises to the Panjshir'' to spread the party's ideology, one of the diplomats said here. ''In some cases they threw the recruiters out of their offices,'' he said. Long Rivalry Between Factions **********Rivalry between the Khalq, or Masses, faction and Mr. Karmal's own Parcham, or Flag, group has existed for many years. Scores of members of the two groups were gunned down in street battles during the first months of President Karmal's regime. He took power after Soviet troops overthrew his predecessor, Hafizullah Amin, in December 1979. **********However, diplomats here say that the bitter divisions within the party appeared to have been papered over after Soviet leaders threw their support behind Mr. Karmal and the Parcham group. **********Mr. Karmal, one of the diplomats noted, was out of the country when Soviet and Afghan troops opened one of their biggest assaults on the rebel stronghold in the Panjshir region in May. The official Soviet and Afghan press organs also differed in their descriptions of his trip to Moscow. **********The Soviet press agency Tass reported that the Afghan President had traveled to the Soviet Union for rest and reuperation. But Bakhtar, the official Afghan agency, said that Mr. Karmal had had a series of medical tests during his visit. Parley Held in Geneva **********Diplomats here believe that President Karmal held extensive discussions with Soviet leaders on the situation in Afghanistan. They say that he also monitored the Geneva talks on the Afghan situation that were arranged by the United Nations and brought together representatives of Pakistan, Afghanistan and Iran. **********Commenting on Mr. Karmal's long absence from Kabul, a Western diplomat said, ''Either he is supremely confident of everything being under control - and everyone knows that this is not the case - or the Russians have refined their running of the administration to such a point that his absence or presence does not really matter.'' **********Another Western diplomat reported that there had been a two-hour clash last week between Soviet troops and Afghan soldiers near the American Embassy in Kabul after a Soviet truck accidentally drove through an Afghan checkpoint. No casualties were reported in the incident, which was apparently the first armed clash between Soviet and Afghan soldiers in the capital this year. **********A large number of prisoners in Kabul are reported to have started a hunger strike last week. The reason for the strike is unclear, diplomats said, but they said that visits by relatives to the prisoners at the Pul-i-Charki jail were not being allowed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/08/world.print_headline: Europe Defends Right To Use Trade Sanctions
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/08/world.body_text: **********The European Common Market today defended its right to impose trade sanctions against Argentina in support of Britain in the Falkland Islands dispute. **********The Common Market told the council of the 87-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade that it had exercised its ''inherent right'' to defend its security interests when it imposed an embargo on imports from Argentina. **********Tran Van Thinh, the representative of the Common Market, said this right was recognized by a GATT article saying any member was free to take any action it deemed ''necessary for the protection of its essential security interests'' in time of war or ''other emergency in international relations.'' **********The community was answering an Argentine complaint that the embargo violated GATT's fair trade rules.  Canada and Australia, which were also named in the complaint, defended their trade measures with the same argument. No action was taken by the council, which left the complaint in abeyance. **********Argentina's representative, Gabriel Martinez, said the sanctions violated Argentina's right under GATT rules to most-favored-nation treatment from all the other members.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/02/world.body_text: **********Attorney General William French Smith left here today feeling ''heartened'' by Thailand's attacks on the region's opium production and heroin traffic, but also with a keener sense of the obstacles to controlling narcotics at their source. **********The problems, Mr. Smith said in an interview Sunday, include rugged opium-growing terrain, rich traffickers backed by their own armies and the fact that hill tribes have depended on opium crops for generations. **********The Thai authorities ''have some very difficult problems, some of which are political,'' Mr. Smith said, but he added that the Thai Government was ''dedicated'' to overcoming them. **********After four days of high-level talks here about the problems of drugs and refugees, Mr. Smith and his party, which includes Francis M. Mullen Jr., acting administrator of the Drug Enforcement Administration, flew on to Pakistan. Good Opium Harvest Reported **********Mr. Smith said a primary mission of his round-the-world trip was to stress that America's multibillion-dollar narcotics business was its ''No. 1 crime problem''. **********The ''golden triangle'' of opium-growing country where Thailand, Burma and Laos converge had a good harvest this year, narcotics officials say, producing about 600 tons of boiled-and-dried opium, or enough to refine into 60 tons of heroin. Of this, 75 to 80 percent is likely to pass through Thailand, much of it bound for export, Mr.  Mullen noted today at a news conference.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/21/busin.main_headline: Technology; Broader Tests For Fuel Cells
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/21/busin.print_headline: Technology; Broader Tests For Fuel Cells
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/21/busin.body_text: **********AT a time when generous supplies of oil and gas are slowing the nation's investment in solar energy, biomass conversion and other alternative forms of power generation, the fuel cell is entering its second important phase of nationwide testing. **********Often described as a superbattery, the fuel cell first gained wide attention when it was used to generate power on space flights in the 1960's. By the mid-1970's, in the hope the cells would gain an important role in generating electricity for homes and businesses, the utility industry had invested $150 million to design and test 65 of the devices at apartment buildings, offices and factories. **********Despite that investment, fuel cells are far from widespread. But many utility executives remain convinced that the devices can lessen their dependence on huge, centrally situated power plants. That potential will be tested at 50 sites across the country during the next 18 months. **********One of these sites is Manhattan, where the Consolidated Edison Company will begin using a relatively large, fuel-cell power plant next to its East River generating station. The utility said it expected the plant, which is designed to generate 4.8 megawatts of power, or enough electricity for 2,000 customers, to be switched on in early 1982 after three years of construction, long delays and an investment of $80 million. **********In addition, 49 smaller devices will be used to provide electricity to residential buildings, restaurants, banks and small factories in more than two dozen states. One these sites is Vernon, Conn., where a 40-kilowatt cell housed in a nine-foot-long green cabinet will be switched on today at the Southern New England Telephone Company's Rockville Central office building. **********The cell in Vernon is designed to provide power for the telephone company's electric switching equipment. The device ''looks like an elegant Dumpster,'' said Emmanuel Ford, a spokesman for Northeast Utilities, which is in charge of the project. He added that it ''promises to be very, very efficient.'' **********A fuel cell resembles a large battery that can be constantly recharged. A component of the device converts a conventional fuel, most commonly natural gas, into hydrogen. The hydrogen is used to bathe one of the electrodes in the cell, which in turn shoots a current of electrons to another electrode, generating power. Thus, a cell does not use internal combustion, and does not emit pollutants.  Nor does it have moving parts, so it is quiet. **********More important, engineers believe that the cells being demonstrated will prove far more fuel-efficient than conventional power plants. In addition to electricity, the chemical reaction that takes place produces heat and water. With cells adjacent to buildings, the heat can supplement or replace conventional heating systems. In Vernon, for example, Mr. Ford said the fuel cell might satisfy most of the heating requirements of the office building. **********The smaller cells now entering tests, which are made by the United Technologies Corporation, all provide 40 kilowatts of power. The cells tested in the mid-1970's generated about one-third of this, and did not have the heat recovery capacity of the new devices. **********The earlier equipment ''was of symbolic value, but didn't have the features needed for commercial applications,'' said William Podolny, vice president and general manager for fuel cell operations at United Technologies. The newer devices ''move very close to what is required'' for commercial use, he said, adding that if the tests were successful, marketing the cells for commercial power generation could begin by 1987. **********Development and testing of the cells would not be possible without huge investments by the Government and the utilities. The current program, for example, is being paid for by the Gas Research Institute, which is a trade organization for the natural gas industry, and by the Department of Energy and a group of 23 utilities. **********Critics of the program assert that the plentiful supplies of oil, which are expected to last for at least five years, make alternative fuels far less important than they were thought to be in the 1970's.  Even if the cells prove more efficient than conventional power plants, they maintain, utilities are not likely to invest heavily in radically different systems of power generation unless they are forced to by energy shortages. **********Continuing research and development, moreover, may be handicapped by lower levels of Federal funding for alternative-fuel projects.  The Department of Energy has spent more than $30 million in each of the past two years on fuel-cell projects, but the Reagan Administration has recommended that funds for the current fiscal year be cut to below $10 million. **********The utiltities industry, however, ''sees promising potential that fuel cells will relieve some of the pressure'' to build conventional coal or nuclear plants, said Lelan F. Sillin, Jr., chairman of Northeast Utilities.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/28/world.print_headline: HAZARDS OF SALVADOR'S POWER STRUGGLE; News Analysis
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/28/world.body_text: **********What appears to be a struggle for political power in El Salvador between the center, represented by the Christian Democrats, and the right, represented by four conservative political parties, is something both far more complicated and possibly far more dangerous. **********There are at least five, and possibly six, major forces influencing the negotiations over who will lead the country's efforts to pull itself out of civil war and into some semblance of economic recovery. **********They are the Christian Democrats; their rightist opponents, who may make up two factions rather than a solid front; the Salvadoran armed forces; the leftist rebels, and the United States. Centrists' Situation Tenuous **********In a nation where fradulent elections, personal deal-making and military coups have been the traditional means of installing and removing governments, nearly every action involving democratic principles and political compromise is an experiment. **********The Christian Democrats are in a tenuous situation. Although they won a plurality of the popular vote cast in last month's elections for a Constituent Assembly and 24 of the 60 seats, they have been forced into a minority role by a coalition of the right. **********This has caused deep consternation not only among officials of the United States, but also in the Salvadoran military.  Reagan Administration officials, realizing the lack of support in Congress and among the American people for a military solution to El Salvador's leftist insurgency, had accepted the idea that a redistribution of wealth is critical in gaining the Salvadoran people's backing in the struggle against the left. Rightists Disturb the U.S. **********They were therefore distressed when the Christian Democrats, the party most likely to continue that type of change, failed to garner a majority in last month's voting for the Constituent Assembly, which will elect a President and schedule election. **********And they were even more disturbed by the coalition among the rightwing parties, some of whose candidates ran on a platform of dismantling the changes already enacted and others of whom have been closely tied to the random violence and killings that are euphemistically referred to as human rights violations. **********A Government controlled by these factions, Administration officials fear, would be unable to retain the Congressional support necessary to obtain further military and economic aid, giving the leftist rebels an additional advantage. **********That message has been impressed repeatedly on the politicians and the military since the elections, but the military - which was unencumbered by direct involvement in the immediate battle for political power - grasped it more quickly. **********When the military realized last week that the politicians' power struggle could undercut its own interests, it stepped in, virtually ordering the politicians - particularly those on the right - to come to terms on a moderate President to give the Government at least an appearance of balance. It was, said a leading rightist politician, ''an elegant coup.'' **********For while the military is conservative, the rightists of the Nationalist Republican Alliance headed by Roberto d'Aubusson's are decidedly more so, and there is considerable personal animosity between officials of the two sides. There is, as well, a constituency of junior military officers with relatively progressive views, and military leaders know they must satisfy them as well. **********No one is saying publicly what will happen if the military does not get what it wants, or if the power of a moderate President, if one is indeed elected, is undercut by the the rightists in the Constituent Assembly. In putting together the Assembly's charter last night, the rightists showed some restraint in assigning themselves power, but not nearly as much as the Christian Democrats had wanted. **********There have been many rumors of a possible military coup in recent days, leading the politicians to be extremely cautious in their public reactions. **********Among them, Mr. d'Aubuisson, who has been chosen head of the Assembly, has been the least guarded, at least toward the military.  For the moment, it appears he is betting that the United States has too much invested in its promotion of democracy here to allow it to be shattered by a military coup. His blistering attack Monday on Jaime Abdul Gutierrez, a top military leader and member of the ruling junta, for exerting pressure on the parties' presidential deliberations was an indication of that. **********At the same time, Mr. d'Aubuisson has been extremely careful of late in his statements about the United States. But several officials - Salvadoran and foreign - believe the rightist leader's response may have had a substantial element of ''shoot the messenger'' and was as much a condemnation of American intervention as of military pressure. **********One clue to El Salvador's future will come with the selection of a President. The United States, as well as the military, are hoping that the rightist coalition will split, at least on this issue, and that the conservative National Conciliation Party - which worked with the military in its two decades of power -will join the Christian Democrats in selecting a moderate for the post. **********A remaining mystery, however, is the power of the left. The guerrillas have recently been conducting only sporadic battles in the countryside and have been relatively inactive in San Salvador, but that could change quickly and dramatically. Rebel radio stations have been telling the public to prepare for a major offensive beginning this weekend. And Christian Democratic leaders are warning that if they are excluded from the legitimate centers of democratic power, support of the left by the political center could substantially increase.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/24/busin.main_headline: BURLINGTON'S BID CALLED INADEQUATE BY EL PASO'S BOARD
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/24/busin.print_headline: BURLINGTON'S BID CALLED INADEQUATE BY EL PASO'S BOARD
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/24/busin.body_text: **********The El Paso Company said yesterday that its board of directors had found the $24-a-share offer by Burlington Northern Inc. for just over half of the energy company to be inadequate and not in the best interest of its shareholders. **********At its meeting yesterday the nine-member board also voted unanimously to provide an incentive for its 98,000 shareholders to hold on to their shares, authorizing a dividend of one share of a new series of 8 percent cumulative convertible stock for every 20 shares of outstanding common stock. **********The company said that the preferred stock would have a stated value of $25 a share and that each share would be immediately convertible on a share-for-share basis into El Paso common stock. The cost to the company of issuing the stock could total $62 million **********Restraining Order **********El Paso also said that, pending a hearing scheduled for Dec. 30, the District Court of El Paso County, Tex., had entered a temporary restraining order that enjoins Burlington Northern from enforcing, publishing or communicating the Dec. 30 proration date of its tender offer. **********Larry Crowley, an energy analyst for the Houston-based securities firm of Rotan Mosle, said that the rejection by the El Paso board, which met at the company's headquarters in Houston, came as no surprise. **********El Paso's current book value is $11 a share. If the company's potential earnings from its proven oil and gas reserves are factored in at today's energy prices, he estimated, the book value stands between $26 and $30 a share. **********In trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange El Paso closed at $24.50, down 75 cents.  Burlington Northern issued a statement from its corporate headquarters in Seattle expressing disappointment at the rejection.  The company, which owns the nation's largest railroad in terms of trackage, added that ''no amount of corporate manipulation or the threat of litigation should affect the outcome of an offer that provides El Paso shareholders with a fair value for their stock.'' **********Burlington Northern, in announcing its offer, which became effective last Tuesday, said that the proration period would expire on Dec. 30. If the offer is oversubscribed, the company said, the shares tendered by that date would be purchased on a pro-rata basis. 51% of Shares Sought **********Burlington, which is seeking about 51 percent of El Paso's shares, said that the offer would expire at midnight Jan. 19 unless it was extended. **********Burlington, anticipating opposition, has filed lawsuits in Federal district courts in Delaware, Louisiana, Oklahoma and Utah, seeking a judgment that the takeover law of each of the states was unconstitutional and and has also sought injunctions against enforcement of the laws. **********Travis H. Petty, the chairman and president of El Paso, told shareholders in a letter that Merrill Lynch had advised the board that the price of $24 a share was inadequate. **********He also said that, according to Burlington Northern's offer, there were no definitive plans to acquire the remaining shares. ''Your board believes,'' he continued, ''that Burlington Northern may have difficulty financing an acquisition of the remaining El Paso common stock on a basis that would be equitable to the remaining El Paso stockholders.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/19/busin.body_text: **********Norcen Energy Resources Ltd. said that an appeals court in Cincinnati had agreed to expedite its hearing on the Canadian company's request to lift a preliminary injunction blocking its offer to control the Hanna Mining Company. Earlier this month, Judge John M. Manos of Federal District Court enjoined Norcen's $45-a-share offer for 42.7 percent of Hanna. The judge cited evidence at the time that Norcen had misrepresented its intentions by telling regulators it only wanted an investment position when it planned to take control of Hanna.

Gen. David Ivri. In response, other military correspondents told the military command here that they would prefer not to participate in the conference at this time. **********Mr. Scemama, after four days with Israeli troops in Lebanon, broadcast a report Friday night showing Israeli troops in Lebanon parodying an Israeli nursery rhyme in which they sang: Airplane come down to us Fly us off to Lebanon We will fight for Sharon And return in a coffin. **********The manangement board of the state television criticized the broadcast.  The army is conducting an inquiry into Mr Scemama's conduct. He is said to have broken away from his military escort in Lebanon and violated an understanding that he would not question soldiers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/20/world.body_text: **********The official Soviet press agency Tass said today that President Reagan's expanded embargo on United States supplies for the Siberian natural gas pipeline amounted to an attempt at ''political blackmail.'' **********''This decision is sure to aggravate differences on both sides of the Atlantic in relations between the U.S.A. and the West European countries,'' Tass added. **********The White House announced Friday that Mr. Reagan was expanding his embargo against American equipment sales for the pipeline to cover foreign subsidiaries and licensees of American companies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/24/world.main_headline: IRISH VOTERS, VOTE-WEARY, TRY IT AGAIN
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/24/world.print_headline: IRISH VOTERS, VOTE-WEARY, TRY IT AGAIN
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/24/world.body_text: **********Politicking Irish-style lost a lot of its appeal Sunday night for the handful of party faithful waiting on the sidewalk outside Our Lady of Refuge Church for the evening mass to end. **********The cold wind coming off the Irish Sea whipped down the avenue and stung the campaign workers gathered under the street light near the church entrance, shivering in weather that would give the city its first frost of the season. **********Working the church gates on the Sunday before an election is a hallowed tradition in Irish politics, as much a part of a campaign as a fish fry on the American political trail. No campaign would be considered complete without a candidate or his aides standing on a car top after mass and roaring the benefits of the party at a readymade audience. **********A few of the leaflet-carriers on this night had been up before dawn, and this was the sixth mass of the day they had worked. Besides being chilled to the bone, they were weary, maybe a little cross, and like everyone else in Ireland they were less than certain about how Wednesday's national election was going to turn out. Election 'Too Close to Call' **********''Too close to call,'' said the man from Fianna Fail, the party of Prime Minister Charles J.  Haughey.  ''Aye,'' said a worker hunched in a blue wool overcoat and clutching a sheaf of papers that trumpeted the greater glory of the Fine Gael party and its leader, Dr. Garret FitzGerald. ''This one's going right down to the tape.'' **********It was a fleeting moment of rare agreement between two old political camps that have held fierce allegiances that can be traced to the Easter Rising in 1916. Fianna Fail and Fine Gael are nearly indistinguishable in philosophy - in any other northern European nation they would be considered Christian Democrats - but loyalties have been passed inside families from generation to generation like fine Waterford crystal and far more durable. But on this night there seemed to be no pleasure in it. **********Most of Ireland seems thankful that the third national election campaign in 18 months is coming to a close. Mr. Haughey, whose Government collapsed three weeks ago when it failed to win a confidence vote, has squared off against Dr. FitzGerald for the third time since June of 198l. Mr. Haughey lost that first match but came back to win last February. The Irish public, which is reputed never to get its fill of politics, seems ready now to swear off the binge. Greater Instability Feared **********There are fears, however, that a crumbling economy, high unemployment and no prospects of relief can lead to even greater political and social instability. Contributing to this anxiety is recognition that the Irish political system, so encrusted with tradition and personalities, has failed in a year and a half of revolving-door governments to produce new faces or new solutions. **********''Up until recently the perception was that domestic governments could do a lot to control their economies,'' said Michael Gallagher, professor of political science at Trinity College in Dublin. ''In Ireland governments have learned that employment is outside the scope of Irish governments.'' For the first time in anyone's memory, he noted, no major party candidate is making promises about good times being around the corner. Instead, they are preaching austerity and cutbacks. **********However, many voters do not expect the new realism to daunt the ways in which Irish politicians have used party loyalty and tradition as substitutes for new directions and bold thoughts. This attitude seemed summed up in the quick moves of Aoibheann O'Keeffe when she was one of the first to leave Our Lady of Refuge at the conclusion of the service. **********''That's the message from your Fianna Fail candidates,'' said a campaign worker, pushing the literature at her like playing cards fanned out in his hand. **********Mrs. O'Keeffe dodged his offer with flashing eyes.  ''And what is the message?'' she inquired sharply, her head angled with suspicion.  ''Charlie Haughey will keep the country moving,'' the man said, his confidence slipping under her glare.  ''Oh, backwards is it?'' Mrs. O'Keeffe rejoined, pushing past the man, who turned to search for more receptive faces in the crowd.  What both parties fear is that neither will be able to gain a majority of seats in the election. This would set up another round of negotiations in the Parliment for either Mr. Haughey or Dr.  FitzGerald to form a coalition with one of the minority left-wing parties. But it was exactly this kind of unstable coalition that led to the collapse of the last two governments as the leftists refused to support austerity programs. **********Another impotent Parliament could force yet another election next year, a prospect so depressing to the Irish that it brings fury into the voice and eyes of voters like Mrs. O'Keeffe.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/23/busin.body_text: **********WASHINGTON A TELEVISION picture tube invented by scientists at RCA Laboratories in Princeton, N.J., is expected to display much brighter colors and requi re less electric power. **********Patent 4,311,944 was granted this week for the improved cathode ray tube to Stanley Bloom, a member of the technical staff, and Carmen A. Catanese, director of picture tube systems research. **********A conventional tube has a shadow mask near the screen to separate the red, green and blue, but its narrow apertures limit the electrons passing through. The focus mask used in the patented tube has wider apertures with electron lenses that pass greater current. **********The inventors have said that the tube has higher brightness, better picture resolution, higher reliability and lower power consumption than the conventional tube. RCA is continuing to investigate fabrication techniques for the new focus mask before deciding on production.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/13/world.body_text: **********China plans to send 15,000 students abroad, most of them to study natural science and technology, as part of its 1981-85 five-year plan, the official New China News Agency reported today. **********China now has more than 11,000 students and scholars abroad, including about 8,000 in the United States.  Under the five-year plan, the agency added, the Government will spend $350 million to improve laboratory facilities at major colleges and will graduate 2.3 million students from secondary vocational schools, 1.5 million from colleges and 45,000 from graduate schools.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/12/world.main_headline: POPE STARTS WEST AFRICA TRIP TODAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/12/world.print_headline: POPE STARTS WEST AFRICA TRIP TODAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/12/world.body_text: **********Nine months after an assassin's bullets nearly took his life, Pope John Paul II will resume his travels Friday with an seven-day, four-nation journey to West Africa. **********Originally planned to cover only Nigeria and Gabon, the Pope's itinerary has been extended to include two small countries that occasioned surprise when the schedule was announced last month. **********On his way from Lagos, Nigeria, to Libreville, Gabon, on Wednesday, the Pope will stop for six hours in Cotonou, the capital of Benin, formally known as Dahomey. And on the following Friday the Pope will visit the two main towns of Equatorial Guinea, Malabo on Bioko Island, which in Spanish colonial days was Santa Isabel on Fernando Po, and Bata in Rio Muni, the mainland part of the small country on the Atlantic Ocean. **********What gave rise to the surprise is that Benin professes Marxism-Leninism, and Equatorial Guinea suffered for 11 years under the regime of Ngumena Biyoto Masie, who presided over the killing of tens of thousands of people. Nigeria Is Main Stop **********Nigeria, black Africa's most populous and wealthiest country, is the principal object of the papal journey. Politically the country is under the strong influence of Moslems, who make up nearly half the population of 80 million. Its Roman Catholic minority accounts for about 8 percent. **********In addition to Lagos, the Pope will visit the university city of Ibadan, the northern city of Kaduna, and Enugu and Onitsha, in the heart of the eastern region of the ethnic Ibos, who seceded in 1967 to form brief ly the state of Biafra until the central Government put down the rebe llion with great loss of life. About half of the Ibos are Roman Cat holic, and they are the core of the Nigerian Catholic minority. **********In Kaduna, on the other hand, the Pope will be in the heart of Moslem country, where only about one percent of the population is Catholic. **********Gabon, a former French colony with a population of 600,000, is nearly half Catholic. The Pope is to arrive there Wednesday and will leave Libreville Friday on his return journey. **********The addition of Benin and Equatorial Guinea to the schedule are proof of the church's earnestness in its relations with Africa, Bernardin Cardinal Gantin, a Benin citizen, said in an interview at the office of the Pontifical Commission on Justice and Peace, which he heads. **********''Yes, it is astonishing that he is going there,'' the Cardinal said. ''But to go only to countries that offer no obstacles would be a form of abstention. The Gospel demands the contrary. The Pope must evangelize.'' **********Benin's surprising agreement to a papal visit is viewed by diplomats and church sources as a sign that the military regime of President Mathieu Kerekou is acknowledging the lack of success of eight years of a doctrinaire African version of Marxism-Leninism that did not find substantial support from the Soviet Union or China. **********After seven years of suppression of the church and widespread nationalization and regimentation in Benin, Cardinal Gantin said, ''things go so badly in the country that they need us.'' **********The African journey is the first of a series of papal trips already announced or considered likely this year. According to unofficial sources, the Pope will visit Portugal on May 13, the anniversary of the day in 1917 when a group of children said they saw the first of six apparitions of the Virgin Mary. Due in Britain in May **********A five-day trip to Britain is scheduled for the end of May. In June the 61-year-old Pope is expected to visi t Switzerland on an invitation from the International Labor Organ ization. Last week the Vatican announced an eight-day trip to Spain in October, the first papal visit to that predominantly Catholic co untry. **********A big question mark hangs over a projected return visit to Poland on Aug. 26, the 600th anniversary of the Madonna of Czestochowa, the country's most revered national and religious image. Wieslaw Gornicki, a political adviser to Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, was reported to have said in a recent interview soon to appear in the Italian magazine Dialogo Nord-Sud that the Pope was still welcome in his native country and needed only to advise of the date of his visit. **********The Primate of Poland, Archbishop Jozef Glemp, left for Warsaw today after a seven-day stay here, during which he conferred almost daily with the Pope on the Polish situation. Neither he nor the Vatican issued an announcement on the talks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/12/busin.body_text: **********The stock market's attempt to continue its recent rally ran out of momentum yesterday as prices ended mixed in slower trading. The main casualties were some of the technology issues, which have been hardhit recently because of lower earning estimates. **********The Dow Jones industrial average, which was in the plus column throughout the session, closed up 0.67 point, at 805.56. In the previous two days the Dow had risen 9.42 points after having dropped almost 45 points in the preceding six sessions. **********In the overall market, declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered stocks that advanced by 766 to 661. Turnover on the Big Board fell to 53 million shares from 59.4 million shares on Wednesday, as institutional interest decreased. **********Ralph Acampora, vice president and technical analyst for Kidder, Peabody & Company, said the market seems to be ''trying to make a near-term low so it can start a rally.'' On Monday, the Dow fell to the 795.57 level, the first time it closed below the 800 mark in almost two years. **********Mr. Acampora said that a major rally would not materialize until investors were convinced that interest rates would continue to decline and that Congress and President Reagan would reach a compromise on the huge Federal budget deficit. **********The biggest decliner in the technology group was Honeywell, which tumbled 5 5/8 points, to 65, after the company reported that its first quarter computer revenues would be below expectations with a ''significant effect on its earnings.'' **********Other losers among the technology stocks included Teledyne, which fell 5 1/8, to 112 1/2, and Digital Equipment, which was down 2 1/4, to 72 1/2. In the same category, Texas Instruments dropped 1 5/8, to 76 5/8, and Prime Computer lost 1 1/4, to 17 5/8. **********The big gainer on the exchange was Carolina, Clinchfield & Ohio Railway which soared 20 points, to 81, after the CSX Corporation, a railroad holding company, agreed to acquire all of Carolina, Clinchfield's outstanding shares in exchange for a new CSX convertible preferred stock. CSX added 1 point, to 45. **********The RCA Corporation, which again was heavily traded, lost 1 1/8 points, to 19 3/8, after the Bendix Corporation announced on Wednesday that it did not plan to acquire any more of RCA's common stock. Bendix said it now held 7.3 percent of RCA's common. Earlier this week Bendix reported it would buy up to 9.9 percent of RCA's common. **********Marshall Field fell 1 point, to 20 1/2, in active trading. The company's request to bar the Icahn group's purchase of more of the department store's shares was denied by a Federal judge. However, it was learned that another unidentified company has joined Icahn's group of investors in buying Marshall Field's stock and that the group has increased its holdings to well over the 23.1 percent last reported. **********On the American Stock Exchange, the market-value index slipped 1.01, to 248.18. Dillard Department Stores climbed 2 3/4 points, to 24 1/2, after reporting higher fourth-quarter profits. **********In the over-the-counter market, the Nasdaq composite index eased 0.33, to 170.09. The Tipperary Corporation advanced 1 1/4, to 9 5/8, after the oil and gas concern announced that its credit line had been increased from $30.8 million, to $45 million by the Midland National Bank.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/29/world.main_headline: TANAKA BACKS JAPANESE PREMIER'S RE-ELECTION BID
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/29/world.print_headline: TANAKA BACKS JAPANESE PREMIER'S RE-ELECTION BID
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/29/world.body_text: **********Leaders of the Liberal Democratic Party, the handful of conservatives who make the real decisions of state in Japan, have decided that Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki should serve another two years in office, according to highly placed figures in the governing party. **********While officials here feel it is too early for a formal announcement of his candidacy - party elections are not expected until October - Mr. Suzuki has no serious rivals at the moment for the post of party president, and he has a formidable, declared backer. **********The backer is former Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka. On Friday Mr.  Tanaka told a group of his supporters at the hot springs resort of Hakone in the mountains southwest of here that he endorsed Mr. Suzuki for another two-year term as the head of the party. **********Mr. Suzuki has served ''most faithfully and successfully'' as Prime Minister since 1980, Mr. Tanaka said.  The president of the governing party is almost automatically the head of the Government because the Liberal Democratic Party has majorities in both houses of Parliament and therefore can name its own candidate without consulting the weak opposition groups. A decision by the party to give Mr. Suzuki another term as its president would mean that he would continue to serve as head of government, with no further action in Parliament required. **********Nihon Keizai, a financial newspaper regarded as well informed on conservative politics, said that the party's plans called for a vote about Oct. 20 by the 421 Liberal Democratic members of the two houses of Parliament. **********The paper envisages a scenario under which Mr. Tanaka puts the decision before the party in an ebullient power play.  ''The Suzuki and Tanaka factions are thinking of recommending Prime Minister Suzuki not just by 50 people, as prescribed in the party rules, but by more than 200 people at one stroke, when Suzuki registers his candidacy on Oct. 16,'' the paper said. **********The forecast illustrates the power in Mr. Tanaka's hands, despite the fact that he is facing criminal charges of having taken $2 million in bribes when he was Prime Minister in the early 1970's to influence Japanese airlines to buy Lockheed aircraft. A judgment in his case is expected late next year. **********Mr. Tanaka resigned from the Liberal Democratic Party when the charges were brought and now sits in the lower house as an independent. His strength rests on the 109 members of Parliament who acknowledge that they are his supporters. With these and Mr.  Suzuki's group, Mr. Tanaka has a ''battle corps,'' as the press calls it, of some 195 Members of Parliament, and he claims to control in secret at least 20 more members of some other intraparty groups. **********Control of Parliament itself is not at issue. The Liberal Democrats, with a major victory in the elections for both houses of Parliament in 1980 - the first time that elections for both houses had been held on the same day - has unexpectedly recovered its absolute majorities. It now has 287 members in the 511-seat lower house and 134 in the 252-member upper house. **********Mr. Tanaka, the strategist of this victory, is considering another double election next year, he said at Hakone this week. The election success of 1980 was important, officials here feel, because it paved the way for a sharp turn toward the right in Japanese politics. This could be reinforced if elections were held next year, because the opposition groups, especially the largest one, the Socialist Party, suffer from low morale, members said. **********''The public has given up on us,'' a leading Socialist legislator said recently. ''We just have to self-criticize.'' The opposition parties have notably failed to make an issue of the dominant role played in the governing party by Mr. Tanaka, a man facing serious criminal charges. Mr. Suzuki, a compromise candidate when he came to power, promised at that time to clean up politics but has failed to do so - to many officials, he seems putty in Mr.  Tanaka's hands - and yet he has also escaped serious criticism by the opposition.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/02/world.main_headline: IN CHINA, THE HIGH COST OF MODERNIZATION
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/02/world.print_headline: IN CHINA, THE HIGH COST OF MODERNIZATION
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/02/world.body_text: **********Despite a promising economic future, China is still not generating enough revenue to keep up with the demands of its modernization program, Finance Minister Wang Bingqian said today. **********Mr. Wang made the disclosure in a report to the annual session of the National People's Congress, where he announced a state budget for next year that would continue to run an annual deficit of about $1.5 billion. **********The draft budget anticipates total revenues next year of 123.2 billion yuan, or $61.6 billion, and total expenditures of 126.2 billion yuan, or $63.1 billion, leaving a gap of 3 billion yuan, or $1.5 billion. This is about 11 percent more than in the 1982 budget. **********On Tuesday Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang disclosed a belated five-year plan that incorporates a total budget deficit of 14.5 billion yuan, or $7.3 billion, from 1981 to 1985. Mr. Zhao said an effort would be made to keep the deficit below 3 billion yuan, or $1.5 billion, for the remaining years of the plan. Steady Upturn Predicted **********The deficit arose partly because of the retrenchment of the Chinese economy starting in 1979, when the leadership cut back its ambitious modernization program. It also reoriented production away from traditional heavy industry and toward light industry and consumer goods production. **********Today Mr. Wang said the decline in revenue was coming to a halt and a steady upturn would start next year.  Although this was evidence of improvement, Mr. Wang told China's nominal Parliament, ''the growth of revenues still cannot keep pace with the needs of economic and social development.'' **********''It is imperative to work doubly hard to keep a constant balance between revenue and expenditure and further improve the state financial situation,'' he said. **********The biggest drain on the Chinese budget has been the large array of subsidies for food, rent and other consumer needs, which now account for 30 percent of the Government's expenditures. The Chinese press has reported that these subsidies cost the state nearly 32 billion yuan, or $16 billion, last year. **********The New China News Agency, in circulating excerpts of Mr. Wang's report today, did not say whether he brought up the subsidies problem. Last week, in an article in the People's Daily, Mr. Wang said that the subsidies should be reduced gradually to 20 percent of total state expenditure. **********In his speech Tuesday, Prime Minister Zhao said that prices would be kept ''largely stable,'' suggesting that there were no immediate plans to overhaul the expensive subsidy program. **********Instead, the Government plans to raise additional revenue by collecting more taxes and imposing tougher controls on capital investment. A Change in the Tax System **********Today the New China News Agency reported on a further portion of Mr. Zhao's report, in which he said that the state would replace the customary delivery of profits from state-owned enterprises with tax payments to raise more revenue. The tax system would be changed to make this possible. **********Last summer the People's Daily disclosed that tax evasion was serious in China, with investigators uncovering violations that totaled 1.3 billion yuan, or $650 million, and 40,000 enterprises that paid no taxes at all. **********The New China News Agency also quoted Mr. Zhao as saying on Tuesday that China would strictly supervise the total volume of its investment to make sure there was enough money for energy, transport and the technical transformation of existing industries, three critical areas in China's industrialization drive. **********Mr. Zhao said that under new regulations all investments in fixed assets must now be incorporated into the state plan and that construction projects must comply with guidelines determining their scope beforehand. **********The Prime Minister was quoted as saying that since 1949 ''China has suffered several major setbacks in economic construction, all of which, apart from political reasons, could be attributed economically to the blind extension of capital construction.'' **********Mr. Zhou said that ''China cannot afford to, and must not, make such a mistake again.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/15/world.main_headline: SYRIANS REPORTING KEY ROAD IS OPEN
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/15/world.print_headline: SYRIANS REPORTING KEY ROAD IS OPEN
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/15/world.body_text: **********The Syrian authorities said today that they had reopened the main highway running through the embattled city of Hama, but that troops were still rooting out die-hard insurgents from narrow alleys and underground catacombs in the ancient quarter. **********The Government characterized the battle as a ''mopping-up operation.'' The traditionally rebellious, fundamentalist Sunni Moslem city has been sealed off since Feb. 2, when a Government security force attempting to raid a suspected stronghold of the underground Moslem Brotherhood was wiped out, sparking a general insurrection. **********With a call from the minarets of the mosques to rise against the Alawite-dominated Baathist regime of President Hafez al-Assad, key Government and party installations were attacked and Baath Party members and security forces were killed. **********Reacting to the worst outburst of opposition in his 12 years in power, President Assad sent at least two full brigades and special security troops, an estimated 6,000 to 8,000 soldiers, into the city.  Some Areas Reduced to Rubble **********The city was completely sealed off, with traffic on the main highway running north from Damascus through Homs to Aleppo and the Turkish border diverted around Hama with roadblocks. **********Western diplomatic sources said the troops pounded the city with tanks and artillery fire, reducing some areas to rubble, while the insurgents barricaded primarily in the Hadhir quarter used mortars, rocket launchers and other heavy weapons against Government positions. There were reports of air strikes. There were also unconfirmed reports of some troops defecting to join the rebels. **********Casualties were believed to be heavy on both sides. At least 400 wounded soldiers were reported to have been evacuated to a military compound near the capital. The toll inside Hama was expected to be higher. Fragmentary reports indicated that the dead and wounded could not be pulled from the streets because of the heavy gunfire. **********Three mosques, apparently used as fortresses by the rebels, were destroyed during the fighting, the Syrian sources said. None Allowed Into Hama **********Although the authorities said they had opened the road, the highway skirts the edge of the city and no one was allowed into Hama itself.  Sources said the rebels were holding out in caves in the nearby hillside and the authorities were trying to work their way through cramped, twisting streets in house-to-house battles with well-armed insurgents, many of whom seemed determined to die rather than be captured. **********Hama, a strict orthodox Sunni city, has for centuries been resistant to central authority and in recent years has been the site of several violent uprisings. Government forces have been cracking down in the area over the last four months in a drive against the Moslem Brotherhood, which is leading a terrorist campaign against the regime. **********President Assad has been buffeted by the terrorist attacks, which included assassinations of ranking party and military officials and their Soviet advisers and a car bombing in Damascus at the end of November in which more than 90 people were killed. In addition, an attempted military coup within the air force was reportedly put down in early January. **********Nevertheless, the President and his brother, Rifaat Assad, appear to be in control of the strict and widespread security apparatus.  The trouble in Hama is believed to have started when the intelligence and security forces began a search for what they had been told was a large cache of arms hidden by the Moslem Brotherhood.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/14/busin.body_text: **********The Chicago Board of Trade's hopes to begin trading stock index futures contracts soon based on various Dow Jones & Company market averages have been dashed by the appellate court of Illinois, which ordered that a stay granted by a trial judge last week ''remain in full force and effect'' until it made a further ruling. **********The board had planned to start trading on the futures contract last Monday, after a circuit court judge ruled June 4 that the board would not violate Dow Jones trademark and property rights by creating a stock index tied to the Dow averages as long as the board did not use the Dow Jones name and issued a disclaimer. **********But the judge ordered the board not to begin trading until Dow Jones had a chance to file an appeal. **********The three-judge appellate panel, however, ordered on Friday a further stay until it had time to review the case.  Although a board spokesman, Raymond Carmichael, said that the board was ''unhappy'' with the order, it did not find the request to review the case ''unreasonable.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/06/world.main_headline: ROLE OF GOVERNMENT IN NEW TECHNOLOGY DEVELOPMENT MAY SPLIT CONFEREES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/06/world.print_headline: ROLE OF GOVERNMENT IN NEW TECHNOLOGY DEVELOPMENT MAY SPLIT CONFEREES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/06/world.body_text: **********The call by President Francois Mitterrand of France yesterday for more direct involvement in the development of new technologies seems bound to divide the participants at the economic meeting in Versailles. **********Mr. Mitterrand thrust so-called high technology into the spotlight with the hope of convincing his fellow heads of state that technology is not just a bargaining chip in dealing with the developing and Eastern bloc nations, but also a key to economic recovery. The negative side to all this, in Mr. Mitterrand's view, is that unmanaged technological development can also create destructive competition among the seven partners at Versailles. **********High technology defies precise definition, but its impact is undeniable. In mature industries, companies with access to high technology manufacturing devices, such as computerized machine tools and industrial robots, frequently prosper by producing higher quality products more efficiently while competitors with similar or even lower labor costs whither. **********More importantly, in terms of providing new jobs and long-term prosperity, new industries are spawned when technological advances are designed into marketable consumer and industrial products. 'Innovate or Evaporate' **********The situation has been summed up by American businessmen in the pithy motto, ''Innovate or evaporate.'' Mr. Mitterrand's proposal for increased government-sponsored research and a division of areas of concentration among the industrial nations elicited from President Reagan the contrary view that new technology development is best left to private enterprise.  However, many technology development experts, both within and outside of industry, think that the proponents of pure free enterprise will find themselves in an increasingly uncomfortable competitive position. **********''Technology nationalism is spreading,'' said William Summers, president of Booz, Allen & Hamilton Inc.'s Technology Management Group at the Bethesda, Md., office of the international consulting firm. It shows up in a variety of subsidies, incentives and trade barriers that governments erect to stimulate new high technology industries. These policies are also used defensively to protect older industrial sectors that are strategically important or have failed to innovate fast enough to stand up to foreign competition. **********France and Japan are the two Versailles participants most committed to nationally planned technology development, and both have successes to show for it that have encouraged nations like Britain, West Germany, Italy and Canada to take tentative steps toward national technology planning. French Government's Role Cited **********Partly through control of nationalized companies and partly through incentives and subsidies, the French Government has played midwife to notable French advances in telecommunications, aerospace (despite the commercial failure of the supersonic Concorde) and rail transit. It has also become a world leader in nuclear technology. **********Japan has become known as Japan Inc. for its Government's success in organizing cooperative efforts among Japanese companies to meet nationally defined objectives for its key export industries. Most of these efforts have been directed toward refinement and practical application of basic electronics and manufacturing innovations made in the United States and Europe. **********In recent years, however, the Japanese Ministry of International Trade and Industry has underwritten programs aimed at producing significant home-grown innovations in basic technologies likely to have a major commercial impact in the future, such as biotechnology and photovoltaics. In addition to directing attention to key technologies, the Trade Ministry has focused Japanese research and development on promising materials, such as high performance ceramics. **********By contrast, the United States and, to a lesser extent, Britain, are regarded as the nations at Versailles most committed to private entrepeneurial selection of which technologies to develop. In both nations, the private approach is nurtured by government policies and the financial markets, which can quickly generate vast sums of venture capital for new concepts that excite investors. 'Energy' of Free Enterprise **********''It may be wasteful and it diffuses ability because people jump from one company to another, but it creates more energy,'' said Martin L. Ernst, senior vice president at Arthur D. Little Inc., a consulting firm based in Cambridge, Mass. **********Many analysts caution that both the superficial similarities and differences in national technology policies can be misleading. For instance, while the central government plays a major role in setting technology priorities in both France and Japan, the Japanese system involves much more input from businessmen and brutal domestic competition. The result is that Japan is considered less likely to become bogged down in commercially impractical technology commitments than France. **********Nor is the United States so committed to the free enterprise approach as the Reagan Administration often professes. European analysts such as Juan Rada at the International Management Institute in Geneva note that the American Government exercises a major influence over technology development through its military spending. **********The high military-related component of American technology interests has helped create the nation's lead in crucial areas such as electronics, aerospace and materials science. But it is a mixed blessing, directing Government support and research talent away from areas with limited military applications, such as biotechnology. **********Moreover, according to Mr. Summers of Booz, Allen, America's competitive position is hurt by reliance on military-oriented companies and Government agencies to recognize the spinoff potential of their technologies. ''The big defense companies don't understand the needs of the industrial, commercial and consumer-oriented companies. It's an entirely different culture.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/27/busin.main_headline: Business and the Law; Class Actions: A New Phase
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/27/busin.print_headline: Business and the Law; Class Actions: A New Phase
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/27/busin.body_text: **********THE practice of law has its fashions. And since 1966, when new Federal rules of civil procedure were adopted, class action suits have been the rage. But fashions change, and if three recent cases are any indication, many judges are now reluctant to widen the scope of class actions any further. **********''I think we are entering a new phase,'' said Peter Gruenberger, a partner at Weil, Gotshal & Manges, a New York law firm. ''Courts are beginning to look much more closely at the total impact of a class action.'' In recent months, he added, in cases involving an intrauterine device, Firestone tires and the collapse of an overhead walkway at the Kansas City Hyatt, ''judges have refused to certify classes I believe they would have allowed a few years ago.'' **********Originally, class actions were seen as a way to save judicial time and energy. Instead of each victim of a widespread fraud or disaster bringing a separate lawsuit, Rule 23 permitted all the victims to gather into one class to try their claims in one large legal action.  This saved the defendant from being dragged into courts all over the country and forced to defend the same question over and over, and helped the victims by eliminating the danger that the first one to get into court and win a judgment would use up all the defendant's resources. Class actions also made it possible for new kinds of victims, especially those whose individual damages do not amount to much, to take legal action. **********''When Rule 23 was drafted, I don't think anyone had a clear idea of its potential,'' said Judge Jack Weinstein of the Federal District Court in Brooklyn. ''In price-fixing cases, mass disasters, prison cases, shareholder derivative suits and product liability suits, there may be no way to handle the problem effectively on an individual basis. Multinational corporations have effects on people who can't fight back unless they band together.'' **********Business has always disliked the class action system, perceiving, correctly, that it leads to more claims. But judges, particularly in the years of social change that followed the adoption of Rule 23, rapidly granted class treatment to everything from civil rights grievances to consumer claims. The rate of expansion dropped somewhat after a Supreme Court decision making class actions more costly to bring, but picked up again in recent years. Now, many judges have become reluctant to sanction further extension of class actions. **********''Judges are beginning to ask themselves whether the defendant's business can withstand a huge judgment, and whether the court can withstand the challenge of unraveling the laws of 50 states,'' Mr.  Gruenberger said. **********A good example of the tighter attitude toward such suits is provided by a decision earlier this year in which a judge refused to treat several claimants against the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company as representatives of a larger class. The case involved steel-belted radials that had been voluntarily recalled by Firestone following a 1978 National Highway Traffic Safety Administration report of safety problems. **********Many tire owners who were injured by the radials had sued and won.  But the lawyers in the recent case wanted to create a class of nearly 14 million tire owners, none of whom had suffered any injury, but who merely claimed ''economic'' damages for breach of an implied warranty of merchantability on the tires. Judge Charles S. Haight Jr. of the Federal District Court in Manhattan refused. **********In the Hyatt situation, many of the victims of the skywalk collapse had already filed claims in a state court before the Federal class action was certified. The United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit refused to uphold the Federal class created by the lower court on the ground that it would interfere with pending state claims. **********In last month's Dalkon Shield case, too, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit would not uphold a nationwide class of women who claimed they were injured by the intrauterine device.  Since the women came from many different states with different legal standards, the court ruled, it would be difficult to decide whether this class was entitled to punitive damages from the manufacturer, the A.H. Robins Company. **********The appeals court also took apart a second class the lower court had certified - a class of California women who would jointly try the issue of Robins's liability - on the ground that the circumstances of each individual woman's injury could vary dramatically. **********''If there's any lesson to the three cases, it's that the expansion of class actions has probably leveled off,'' said Arthur Miller, a Harvard law professor and class action expert who was active in the Hyatt case.
