https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/25/busin.body_text: **********Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau authorized today the formation of a new Government corporation to direct the sale of the Canadian Government's interests in five companies. **********In announcing the move, Senator Jack Austin, Minister of Social Development, said the Canada Development Investment Corporation would be charged with the management of a Government-owned portfolio of stock in several private corporations. He said the corporation would try to sell four Government-owned corporations and its equity in a fifth to private businesses. **********In most of the cases, the Government had invested at a time when the companies were in difficulty and the Government wanted to preserve the jobs they represented. **********''This reorganization of Government assets is designed to enhance the commercial management of publicly owned assets and to facilitate privatization,'' declared Senator Austin. Jean Charpentier, chief spokesman for the Ministry of External affairs, called the move the first step toward ''a more businesslike administration'' of Government-owned companies. Selected List **********Mr. Austin said that for the time being, the new Government corporation would not be concerned with such major Government-owned operations as Air Canada, Canadian National Railroads and Petro-Canada, the national oil company. **********Analysts said the Government had previously said it planned to sell some of its corporate holdings and that the announcement today did not represent any policy shift. Senator Austin said that while the economy was in recession, he was not sure that buyers could be found for the properties. **********Government officials said it was premature to speculate on what proceeds the sales might bring.  Among the holdings the Government plans to sell are two aircraft manufacturers that it purchased in 1971 in order to keep them going.  These are De Havilland Aircraft of Canada, which had a staff last year of 3,500, sales of $450 million and profits of $2 million, and Canadair Ltd., whose 5,400 employes build the Challenger business jet, unmanned surveillance systems and parts for Boeing and Lockheed. The company had sales of $235 million last year and a profit of $3 million. Teleglobe Canada **********Another company listed for divestiture was Teleglobe Canada, which maintains international telephone links through cables and satellites and which employed 1,300 people and showed $47 million in net income last year on revenues of 70 million. **********The fourth Government-owned company to be turned over to the new corporation is Eldorado Nuclear Ltd., which closed its uranium mine in Saskatchewan and reported losses of $129.9 million last year. **********Finally, the new corporation is to take over control of the Government's minority share in Massey-Ferguson Ltd., the troubled farm machinery producer, which had losses of $186.2 million. The Federal and the Ontario governments together have invested $200 million in Massey in exchange for equity in the form of preferred shares. **********Mr. Austin said foreign investors would not be discouraged from buying minority holdings in the companies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/12/world.main_headline: 15 SOUTH AFRICAN SOLDIERS KILLED IN ANGOLAN DRIVE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/12/world.print_headline: 15 SOUTH AFRICAN SOLDIERS KILLED IN ANGOLAN DRIVE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/12/world.body_text: **********South Africa said today that it had begun a new drive against guerrilla bases in southern Angola, killing at least 314 guerrillas so far this week and losing 15 soldiers. **********Military headquarters in Pretoria said the 15 South Africans had died when a helicopter flying paratroopers into battle in Angola was shot down. **********It was the largest loss suffered by South Africa in any single incident of the 16-year-old war against the guerrillas of the South West Africa People's Organization, which is seeking to end white rule in South-African-controlled South-West Africa, also known as Namibia . **********The death of the 15 South Africans -12 paratroopers and three helicopter crewmen - was announced with the statement that 201 guerrillas died in a clash on Monday. Today the armed forces said 113 others were killed in an attack on a guerrilla camp on Tuesday, and operations were continuing. 'Double Standard' Is Charged **********A spokesman said the operation had been touched off by the recent capture of documents revealing what he called the ''double standard'' of the insurgents during current negotiations for an internationally acceptable settlement leading to independence for Namibia. **********The South African radio, meanwhile, quoted the ambassador to the United States, Brand Fourie, as having said that reports that South Africa and the guerrillas were about to sign a cease-fire agreement were ''pure guesswork.'' **********There has been a flurry of speculation about an early cease-fire since Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha mentioned a target date of Aug. 15. **********But he made clear that several issues remained to be resolved, and South African officials have renewed their insistence that Cuban troops must leave Angola before South-West Africa could achieve independence. **********Ambassador Fourie, who headed South Africa's Foreign Affairs Department before going to the United States, said that, while there have been exchanges on a cease-fire, any reports about these were purely speculative.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/08/world.print_headline: BRITAIN IMPOSING WAR ZONE AROUND FALKLAND ISLANDS; HAIG PLANS MEDIATION TRIPS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/08/world.body_text: **********Britain threatened tonight to sink any Argentine ship that came within 200 miles of the Falkland Islands after Monday morning. **********John Nott, the Defense Secretary, made the announcement at the end of a seven-hour debate in the House of Commons on the seizure of the South Atlantic archipelago by Argentine troops Friday. The disclosure, which amounted to the imposition of a blockade, curtailed the time available for efforts to find a peaceful solution. **********(Argentina announced early Thursday that it had created a 200-mile defense zone off its shores and around the Falkland Islands in response to the British threat. Earlier, the Argentines extended their civil rule over the islands in a ceremony at Stanley, the capital, in which Gen. Mario Benjamin Menendez was inducted as governor of the Falkland, South Georgia and South Sandwich Islands.  Page A12.) **********Submarine Reported in Area **********The British submarine Superb, a nuclear vessel of the hunter-killer type, was reported by military sources to have arrived off the Falklands, and several of her sister ships are believed to be on the way. **********Britain's policy, Mr. Nott told the Commons, ''will be meant to deny to Argentine forces on the Falklands the means to reinforce and resupply from the mainland.'' The minister said Argentine vessels entering the area, which he called a maritime exclusion zone, ''will be treated as hostile and are liable to be attacked by British forces.'' **********According to United States officials, the British Government is putting pressure on Washington to provide London with military intelligence and other support for the British flotilla that is heading for the Falklands, and Washington is concerned about the possible effects of its decision. (Page A10.) No Specific Action Mentioned **********Mr. Nott, in his speech to the Commons, left open the question of what action would be taken against vessels already inside the prohibited area. A large number of Argentine ships are thought to be lying in the harbor at Stanley, the main settlement of the islands, or just off the coast. **********Britain's new Foreign Secretary, Francis Pym, opened the debate in the House by declaring that Britain intended to force the Argentines out of the Falklands as soon as possible. ''We would much prefer a peaceful settlement,'' Mr. Pym said. ''We will do all we can to get one. But, if our efforts fail, the Argentine regime will know what to expect. Britain does not appease dictators.'' **********Making his first speech as Foreign Secretary in an atmosphere of crisis, Mr. Pym used unusually harsh language to describe the takeover. Bending over his text and speaking with earnest deliberation, he said that the islanders ''have become the victims of the unprincipled opportunism of a morally bankrupt regime.'' **********The members' benches were jammed as Mr. Pym, who was appointed Foreign Secretary following the resignation of Lord Carrington Monday, began his address. **********He made no mention of President Reagan's decision to send Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. to Britain and Argentina this week on a peace-making trip. The Foreign Office said later that the Government ''warmly welcomes'' the decision and the opportunity to talk about ways in which the United States ''might most effectively support our efforts to secure Argentine withdrawal.'' **********That was an indirect way of making clear Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's determination not to negotiate with Argentina, either directly or through third parties, until it pulls its troops out - a position confirmed at a meeting of the Cabinet this morning. Despite a hint from the Argentine Interior Minister, Gen. Alfredo St. Jean, that a withdrawal might under some circumstances be discussed, the Cabinet remained deeply gloomy about prospects of a settlement. Warships Heading for Islands **********Meanwhile, the British battle fleet sailed on toward the Falklands, where it is expected to arrive about April 23 after a voyage of almost 8,000 miles. Some reports said today that it would contain fewer than the 36 ships originally planned - perhaps as few as 20 - because of the need to keep ships in reserve in case the Government decides upon a blockade as the best means of regaining the islands. **********A key feature of the debate was an unsuccessful attempt by James Callaghan, Mrs. Thatcher's Labor Party predecessor, to pin her down as to precisely what Britain hoped to achieve if it succeeded in forcing the Argentine occupying force off the islands. **********In his speech, Mr. Pym said the Government intended to return them to British ''administration'' - the same phrase used by Mrs. Thatcher in the Commons on Saturday. But on Monday night, the Prime Minister promised to restore British ''sovereignty'' in the Falklands. Which word, Mr. Callaghan asked, was the right one? **********As he spoke, Mrs. Thatcher silently mouthed the word ''sovereignty.'' But when she rose to reply to him, she answered less directly, arguing that she believed that British sovereignty remained in force. **********The question arose because many Members of Parliament believe the Government might be hoping to work out a deal, similar to one that fell through in 1981, under which Britain would yield sovereignty in return for a lease of perhaps 25 years that would permit the continuation of British administration. Callaghan Charges 'Blunder' **********Mr. Callaghan, a former petty officer in the Royal Navy, accused the Prime Minister of ''a gross blunder'' in failing to take preventive action before the Argentine attack in the Falklands. As long ago as March 3, he recalled, Richard Luce, a junior Foreign Office minister who resigned along with Lord Carrington on Monday, had expressed ''deep anxiety'' about the situation developing in the South Atlantic. **********Both he and Denis Healey, the Labor spokesman on foreign policy, pledged support for the decision to dispatch the flotilla to the Falklands. But Mr. Healey said the opposition was offering ''no blank check'' in a situation that he said was full of ''appalling difficulties.'' The situation, he said, had been created by Government negligence in ''one of the most disgraceful episodes in British history.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/20/busin.main_headline: GOULD SELLING PART OF ELECTRIC DIVISION
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/20/busin.print_headline: GOULD SELLING PART OF ELECTRIC DIVISION
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/20/busin.body_text: **********Gould Inc., a maker of high-technology electronics parts, said today that it had signed a letter of intent to sell a significant portion of its electric motor division. While Gould would disclose neither the prospective buyer nor the terms of the transaction, analysts estimated the price at about $100 million. **********Gould announced its intention to sell the division and its distribution and controls business in May as part of a strategy to divest itself of substantially all of its electrical operations and concentrate on its high-technology electronics businesses, such as semiconductor chips, minicomputers and electrolytic copper foil. **********''Gould longed to change from an electrical company into an electronics company, and with this sale it has reached the point of no return,'' said John J. McElroy, a portfolio manager with Drexel Burnham Lambert in Philadelphia. **********Mr. McElroy called Gould's electric motor division a good buy.  ''The businesses that Gould is selling are not poor performers or sick companies,'' he said. ''The company is selling them because they don't fit in with its overall strategy, and it needs the cash to focus on its future businesses.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/26/world.main_headline: Jesse Jackson Sees Pope About Haitian Refugees
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/26/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Jesse Jackson Sees Pope About Haitian Refugees
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/26/world.body_text: **********The Rev. Jesse Jackson, the American civil rights leader, met with Pope John Paul II for 20 minutes today to discuss the plight of Haitian refugees living in Florida, the Vatican said. It released no details on what it described as a private audience. **********Mr. Jackson, who is on a European tour, had earlier said that he intended to draw the Pope's attention to the plight of 2,500 refugees from the Caribbean island of Haiti living in camps in Florida. Mr. Jackson said they were ''being held in concentration camps'' and were the victims of ''a contradiction'' in United States policy on human rights. **********''Aid and trade have been cut off to Poland under oppression, but the United States is in partnership with the fascism of Haiti,'' he said. **********The refugees say they are escaping poverty and political repression by the Government of President Jean-Claude Duvalier. The Reagan Administration has not recognized the Haitians as political refugees, saying their plight is economic.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/29/busin.main_headline: CITIES SERVICE ASSERTS IT PLANS TO BID FOR MESA
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/29/busin.print_headline: CITIES SERVICE ASSERTS IT PLANS TO BID FOR MESA
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/29/busin.body_text: **********The Cities Service Company, which said earlier it had ''reason to believe'' the Mesa Petroleum Company was putting together a group that might attempt to take it over, decided yesterday, in a preemptive move, to act first and attempt a takeover of Mesa. **********Amid speculation that Texaco might eventually emerge on Mesa's side, Cities Service announced plans to seek 51 percent of Mesa's 66.8 million shares at $17 a share, or $580 million in cash. **********Allan V. Cecil, a spokesman for Mesa, declined comment on the move, but sources said they suspected that Mesa, together with partners, had been on the verge of making a bid for Cities Service involving an estimated $1.8 billion in cash. **********On the New York Stock Exchange, where its shares did not begin trading until 45 minutes before the close, Cities Service advanced $1.50, to $37, in heavy volume. Mesa, halted at 1:21 P.M., ended the session at $16.75, up 75 cents, and 25 cents less than the Cities Service offer. Bid Viewed as Warning **********Some professionals regarded the offer for Mesa as low and meant more as a warning not to move against Cities Service. Last year, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company headed a group that granted Cities Service a $3.5 billion line of credit, a war chest now at $500 million but restorable. **********Commenting on the bid, Guy P. Wyser-Pratte, executive vice president of Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc., said, ''If Texaco comes into this, Cities Service will have to put away its pop gun.  Texaco would be like the U.S. cavalry coming to Mesa's rescue.'' **********T. Boone Pickens, chairman of Mesa, and John K. McKinley, chairman of Texaco, are friends. Analysts argued, however, that Texaco might not want to run the risk that the Mobil Corporation did when it was rebuffed on antitrust grounds in its bids for Conoco and Marathon. **********Wall Street sources said they had heard Mesa was preparing an offer for 51 percent of Cities Service at around $45 a share. Cities Service's pre-emptive move could change that, however. Mesa owns 4.1 million shares of Cities Service, or 5.2 percent. It is suing Cities Service on charges that it interfered with Mesa's earlier efforts to increase its stake. At that time, Mesa's partners were understood to be Louisiana Land and Freeport-McMoran. They withdrew when Cities Service threatened to take them over. **********Moreover, mindful that Federal Judge John J. Manos of Ohio twice refused to give Mobil clearance to buy Marathon, even when Amerada Hess agreed to buy Marathon's refining and marketing operations, these sources said that Mesa was understood to have lined up partners, possibly to buy pieces of Cities Service and thus avoid an antitrust challenge. **********These sources said the Southland Corporation of Dallas, which has some 7,000 7-Eleven stores, might join the group to get Cities Service's gas stations. The Damson Oil Corporation of New York was said to be interested in Cities Service's oil refineries but is now understood to be out of the group. The Madison Fund of New York is thought to be another potential partner. **********As envisioned by some Wall Street analysts, Mesa was expected to turn to Continental Illinois of Chicago and the Bank of Montreal to arrange part of the financing. The rest was expected to come from the partners, who supposedly would buy preferred stock in Mesa that would later be exchanged for Cities Service assets. **********Cities Service said its Wall Street advisers would be the First Boston Corporation and Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb. Mesa's adviser is believed to be Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/07/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Transamerica Airlines Names New Chairman
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/07/busin.body_text: **********Henry P. Huff, president and chief executive of Transamerica Airlines, has been named chairman. Mr. Huff will retain his duties as chief executive. Howard K. Howard, executive vice president, succeeds Mr. Huff as president. **********The airline, based in Oakland, Calif., is a subsidiary of the Transamerica Corporation of San Franciso, the diversified financial services company. It has 38 planes and specializes in charter passenger and cargo operation. In 1979 it began offering scheduled service to Ireland and Amsterdam from New York, Chicago, Los Angeles and San Francisco. **********Mr. Huff, 62, joined the airline in 1964 when it was known as Trans International Airlines. Mr. Howard, 55, was president of Saturn Airlines, a cargo charter, when it merged with Trans International in 1976. The name was changed to Transamerica in 1979. **********Under the new management alignment, Mr. Huff will concentrate on strategy and Mr. Howard will lead the day-to-day company operations.  Transamerica Airlines has been consistently profitable in the past few years. Last year it earned $21.4 million on revenues of $360 million. This year, said Richard Slakoff, a spokesman, the company hopes to earn ''over $20 million.'' **********Mr. Huff began his career at the Curtiss-Wright Corporation in 1942 as an aerodynamics and flight test engineer. He joined Slick Ariways in 1947 and was executive vice president when he left to join Transamerica in 1964. **********Mr. Howard joined Saturn in 1968 as assistant to the president and was named president in 1972.  Daniel F. Cuff

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/21/world.body_text: **********President Chun Doo Hwan appointed a new Cabinet today after all his ministers tendered their resignations in the wake of a financial scandal that led to calls for Mr. Chun's resignation from opposition and church leaders. **********The President kept Yoo Chang Soon as Prime Minister but changed 11 ministers in the 27-member Cabinet.  He also replaced his aide, Kwon Jung Dahl, as secretary general of the ruling Democratic Justice Party with another former army officer, Kwon Ik Hyun, in another move to quell criticism of corruption in government. **********The resignations over a multimillion-dollar scandal in the money market, and the first calls on Mr. Chun to quit in his two years in power, have presented him with his gravest crisis. Chun's Resignation Demanded **********''He ought to go now,'' said Kim Young Sam, leader of the banned New Democratic Party. ''That would be best for Chun and for Korea.  His policies have failed.'' **********Mr. Chun is not expected to leave office, but the scandal appears to have damaged his reputation. For one thing, relatives of his wife, Lee Sun Ja, are involved. In addition, Mr. Kwon, who ran the ruling party for Mr. Chun, was friendly with some of those arrested in the scandal, according to prosecutors. **********Prosecutors, meanwhile, have presented a report on the financial scandal in the money market here that led to the arrests of two former bank presidents, a former deputy head of the Korean Central Intelligence Agency and his wife, an uncle of Mr. Chun and at least 14 other influential people. **********The report said Chang Yong Ja, a moneylender depicted as the key figure in the scandal, loaned $79 million in cash to six industrial companies in return for $361 million in bank-guaranteed promissory notes. She then sold more than half of the notes for cash in a 13-month period ending last April. **********The unorthodox transactions led to the bankruptcy of the Illshin Steel Company and several other medium-sized companies whose notes were sold by Mrs. Chang. In an effort to shore up the battered financial market here, the Government has injected large sums into the economy through banks. **********''The whole thing is acutely embarrassing,'' a Government official said.  There were three immediate reasons for the Government's embarrassment.  The scandal suggested that legal controls over the money market - the money market plays a central role in finance here because banks do not lend to anyone other than big customers - are defective and that the presidents of two banks helping Mrs. Chang with the guarantees were influenced by powerful people behind the scenes. **********Among those arrested were Mr. Chun's uncle by marriage, Lee Kyu Gwang, a retired general who headed a mining company. Mr. Lee, it emerged, is a brother in law of Mrs. Chang. **********Many Koreans say they feel that the revelations to date are only the tip of an iceberg of corruption in high places.  The scandal appears to strike at the policies dearest to Mr. Chun.  After he came to power as head of an army junta in May 1980, he announced what he called a ''purification campaign'' to ''root out'' corruption in government. **********Recently, aides said, Mr. Chun's goal has been to revive the flagging economy. In an effort to establish his rule, he tried to expand the once dynamic economy and cut inflation. But now, with the Government pumping funds into the economy to shore up the money market, efforts to control inflation are expected to go by the board.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/29/busin.main_headline: Washington Watch; A Six-Month Capital Gain?
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/29/busin.print_headline: Washington Watch; A Six-Month Capital Gain?
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/29/busin.body_text: **********IF a couple of other tax matters can be resolved, Congress just might, in the special session that opens today, shorten the holding period for long-term capital gains to six months. Profits on an asset are now taxed as long-term capital gains only if it has been held for a year. **********The man who killed a six-month provision in a House-Senate conference in August, Representative Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, is reported to be willing now to go along. One such report comes from Edward O'Brien, president of the Securities Industry Association, with a membership including the big brokerage houses. Mr. O'Brien went to see the Chicago Democrat twice. He said he received ''some assurances'' after the conference and got ''strong encouragement'' in October. **********A second such impression is reported by a Senate aide who understands Mr. Rostenkowski gave an assurance to Bob Dole, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, during the conference. The Kansas Republican has been sponsoring a six-month provision since June. **********Mr. Rostenkowski does not say yes or no. He said that, if the Senate were to pass such legislation, ''I would be concerned with the vehicle.'' Translation: What other tax provisions are part of the bill? He also said he would be unwilling to go to conference, and to avoid one under House rules the Senate-passed bill would have to be adopted on the floor without objection - meaning a single member could block passage. **********To soften the opposition of House liberals, Mr. Dole had the Finance Committee attach the six-month bill to a House-passed measure that would relieve three California utilities of roughly $2 billion of contested tax liabilities. Then, as a courtesy, he let a Finance Committee Democrat, Max Baucus of Montana, attach a bill to let artists take deductions for works of their own that they donate to tax-exempt institutions, such as libraries. **********Many tax experts see the Baucus bill as opening the way to abuses, including reductions of taxable income from nonartistic endeavor.  Senator Dole dislikes the Baucus bill and will not oppose a floor attempt to kill it. Should that fail, his staff is preparing a series of crippling amendments. Mr. Dole also wants to make changes in the utilities bill. If all of this comes off smoothly, investors may get a Christmas present of a six-month holding period. Bankruptcy Courts **********Unless Congress reconstitutes the Federal bankruptcy courts by Dec. 24, they will grind to a halt, say aides to Representative Peter W.  Rodino Jr., the New Jersey Democrat who is the chairman of the House Judiciary Committee. Not so, say aides to Bob Dole, the Republican chairman of the Senate Judiciary subcommittee on the courts. The Dole aides contend that, under interim rules laid down by the Judicial Conference, a part of the courts system, bankruptcy proceedings will continue under the supervision of Federal district courts. **********Behind this disagreement, which may be more apparent than real, there simmers a power struggle between Mr. Rodino and Mr. Dole. They agree that, under a 1982 Supreme Court decision, Congress must pass legislation to reconstitute the bankruptcy courts. The Supreme Court's stay of its own order invalidating the present courts expires Dec. 24. Mr. Rodino wants a bill already approved by his committee passed during the special session of Congress. **********Senator Dole wants Congress to include provisions that tighten up the consumer credit provisions of the 1978 bankruptcy act. He believes they are too liberal and have been abused by individuals who run up big installment debts. Mr. Rodino does not like the Dole amendments. **********The Rodino bill would authorize the President to appoint 224 bankruptcy judges. Like other Federal judges, they would serve ''during good behavior,'' in the words of Article III of the Constitution, not for a fixed term as provided by 1978 legislation.  They would be paid $65,000 - more than the $58,500 they get now and less than the $70,300 paid to Federal district judges. **********House passage of the Rodino bill is likely. Whether the Senate will act depends on the priorities of the Senate leadership. If the Senate acts, a House-Senate conference would be inevitable. Showdown on Trucking **********Transportation lobbyists say the big trucking companies may be on an ill-fated ''Poli gambit'' in their confrontation with Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis. **********For those who may have forgotten, Robert Poli was the air traffic controllers' union president who in 1981 threatened to strike and drive the airlines out of business if Secretary Lewis did not grant the union's demands on work conditions. Mr. Poli wound up with no union, and the airlines are still flying. **********Lately Secretary Lewis, as part of his attempt to forge a working coalition, told the American Trucking Associations Inc. that, if they accepted higher operating fees as part of the Administration's highway-repair program, he would urge Congress to enact larger truck lengths and weights uniformly across the country. Mr. Lewis's analysts argued that the increased payload on longer trucks would pay the higher taxes. The added tax bite would be substantial, an increase from $1,800 a year for a truck carrying a 70,000-pound cargo to $5,000. **********Edward V. Kiley, senior vice president of the A.T.A., said ''no deal'' last week. Mr. Lewis replied in so many words: Very well, we will limit user-fee increases on trucks, but you, the A.T.A., are on your own with Congress in your campaign for uniform truck lengths and weights. The upshot could be that Mr. Lewis gets an increase in truck taxes - albeit less than he had anticipated - with the truckers getting next to nothing in return.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/04/busin.body_text: **********A conference committee today began deliberations on a tax bill aimed at raising $21 billion in tax revenues in the coming fiscal year and $98 billion over the next three years amid indications that both parties see a need for a strong campaign by President Reagan if the bill is to become law. **********''The margin of victory will be determined by the amount of participation from the executive branch,'' said Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee. He predicted that there would be ''no chance of passage without a full court press'' from the White House. **********But, he added, ''failure by the conference committee to agree would be totally destructive.'' **********Unusual Position **********The seven Senators and eight Representatives are in the unusual position of working entirely with a bill written by the Senate, rather than with bills from both chambers, since the House decided it did not want to write its own tax-increase package in this election year. A key problem facing the committee is how to fashion a compromise bill that will pass the House, where many Representatives have indicated their unwillingness to go along with any tax increases. **********Both Mr. Rostenkowski and Robert Dole, Republican of Kansas, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, emphasized the need for agreement between the two parties if the bill was to pass. **********Senator Dole, who is chairing the conference on HR 4961, also known as the Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act of 1982, characterized the bill as a bipartisan effort, and called it a ''reform bill, not a tax increase bill,'' which he maintained would not increase the tax burden on the average American. He also said that it raised revenues ''in the most equitable and reasonable way possible.'' Business Share Biggest **********Indeed, the greatest portion of the new tax revenues that would be raised by the Senate bill would come from business. According to a report prepared for the conference committee by the staff of the Joint Committee on Taxation, business tax provisions would account for $40 billion of the $99 billion of proposed new revenues. Many of these provisions would sharply restrict some of the business tax cuts enacted only last year. **********Individual income tax provisions, on the other hand, would provide only about $6 billion in new tax revenues, under the Senate bill.  Other categories that would provide further tax increases include excise taxes, pension, life insurance and employment taxes. **********During the first day of discussion, held in a meeting room filled to overflowing, the conference committee moved slowly through a listing of the various tax increase provisions. **********The staff of the Joint Committee on Taxation has produced two documents outlining the provisions offered for consideration, a 161-page blue-covered book with tax measures, and a 109-page white-covered book on spending proposals. **********While no votes were taken, some of the discussion seemed to indicate that certain items were likely to be contested or changed.  These included proposed limits on medical deductions, on taxdeferrals under multiyear contracts and on accelerated depreciation and the investment tax credits. **********Today's session was the first chance the Representatives on the committee had to discuss the various measures and to voice objections and suggestions. Even Senate discussion of the measures had been quite brief, since much of the bill was hammered out in a lengthy one-day session of only Republican committee members. Medical Cost Proposal Assailed **********One provision that drew fire was a proposal to require that medical costs that could be deducted must exceed 7 percent of taxable income, rather than the 3 percent floor that exists now. Representative Sam Gibbons, Democrat of Florida, called the moved ''a very cruel tax on old people.'' **********But Congressional tax experts observed that the deduction tended to be used most by middle-income and upper-income people, who itemize deductions, and that the expenses being deducted were often for such items as psychiatric care or orthodontic work, which were least likely to be covered by a health insurance plan. **********Another criticism leveled at the Senate bill was that certain provisions would limit the ability of American companies to compete internationally. And some conference members questioned the provisions limiting safe harbor leasing and accelerated depreciation. **********The committee will continue its meeting tomorrow morning, with more discussions of the revenue-raising proposals.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/14/busin.body_text: **********Texaco Inc. said that 1982 oil production from the Tartan Field in the British North Sea would be lower than it had anticipated. https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/28/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Federated's Lazarus Retires as Chairman
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/28/busin.body_text: **********Ralph Lazarus stepped down yesterday as chairman of Federated Department Stores Inc. after a lifetime career there. The company's board named Howard Goldfeder, president and chief executive officer, to succeed him. **********Mr. Lazarus, 68 years old, said ''I felt the time had come for me to step down'' after 46 years with the company. Mr. Goldfeder added that Mr. Lazarus had ''earned'' the opportunity for ''a less direct line responsibility.'' **********That role will come as chairman of the board's executive committee, a position that Mr. Lazarus was given yesterday at the company's annual meeting in Cincinnati. He had been the chairman of the big department store chain, which includes Bloomingdale's and Abraham & Straus in the New York area, for nearly 15 years. **********Mr. Goldfeder, 56, has been Federated president since 1980 and chief executive officer since February 1981. He has spent his career with Federated except from 1967 to 1971, when he went to work for the May Company. **********Mr. Goldfeder said in a telephone interview that he would retain the title of chief executive officer but that no one would hold the title of president. The company, he said, would be managed by an Office of Corporate Principals, which would include him and three vice chairmen, Melvin Jacobs, Donald J. Stone and Will M. Storey, who was elected a vice chairman and director yesterday. **********Mr. Storey, who is joining Federated from his position as executive vice president and chief financial officer at the Boise Cascade Corporation, will also be chief financial officer. **********Federated was formed in 1929 by the F.& R. Lazarus Company of Columbus, Filene's in Boston and A.& S. of Brooklyn. It has grown into a diversified retailer that passed the $7 billion mark in sales last year. **********The company has reported a 28.5 percent decline in earnings in its fiscal first quarter, ended May 1, generally in line with the results of most big retailers. Earnings were $29.1 million, or 60 cents a share, compared with $40.7 million, or 84 cents a share, in the corresponding period last year. **********Mr. Goldfeder said there was no indication of a pickup in business. Disinflation, which would add to consumers' disposable income, and the July tax cut are positive signs, he said. But consumer confidence needed to be restored through an easing of interest rates and a resolution of the budget issue, Mr. Goldfeder added.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/05/busin.body_text: **********The stock market was pounded anew in very heavy trading yesterday with computer and other technology issues coming under particular pressure. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 7.61 points, to 807.55, the lowest close in almost 22 months. **********Volume swelled to 74.3 million shares, the fourth-busiest session ever on the New York Stock Exchange. Wednesday's turnover of 70.2 million shares had been the seventh-heaviest trading in Big Board history. **********Data General, a computer manufacturer, was a factor in the broad market selloff as its shares responded to management forecasts of a decline in earnings in the March quarter. It plunged 10 points, to 33 3/4. This compares with a record price of 87 3/4 in 1980. **********''That's one more example we're seeing of the 'black hole,' whereby a stock hits a vacuum on bad news,'' commented Alan R. Shaw, chief technical analyst for Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. **********Digital Equipment, which also makes minicomputers, fell 3 3/4 points, to 78 1/2. A major brokerage firm reduced its earnings estimates. Institutional Investors **********Institutional investors, such as pension funds, bank trust departments and insurance companies, which normally account for nearly two-thirds of all trading, were exceedingly active.  Yesterday's total of 1,239 blocks of 10,000 or more shares was the second highest on record, after 1,365 blocks on Jan. 7, 1981, when exchange volume hit its record of 92.9 million shares. **********''Institutions were heavy sellers of energy-related stocks, as well as technology issues, right from the start,'' reported John A.  Conlon, who heads the block trading desk at E.F. Hutton & Company.  ''However, I think we might be approaching a sold-out condition in the energy group.'' **********Energy issues, which bore the brunt of selling pressure on Wednesday, when the Dow dropped 10.66 points, steadied somewhat yesterday. **********The Mobil Corporation, the volume leader, slipped 3/8, to 21, its lowest price since 1979. It hit a high of 44 7/8 in 1980. Mobil, second only to Exxon, the nation's largest oil enterprise, now sells at under four times last year's earnings and yields 9.4 percent. New Market Favorites **********Until a year ago, the stock market's three favorite sectors were energy, technology and precious-metals - all sought after as inflation hedges. But in recent months, with investors increasingly worried about interest rates, the recession and eroding corporate profits, the situation has changed dramatically. Instead of inflation stocks, many analysts have sung the praises of electric utilities, food issues and other traditionally ''defensive'' groups. **********During this emergence of new market favorites, gold-mining stocks have plunged, along with energy and technology issues. The drop in precious-metal issues mirrors the price action of gold bullion, which fell yesterday below $350 an ounce, the lowest it has been since September 1979. **********But the market still managed to produce its oddities yesterday. In over-the-counter trading, Hollywood Park Inc. jumped 5 points, to 31 1/2 bid. The company, which operates a horse racing track near Los Angeles, said it has discovered the presence of oil and gas in commercially significant quantities on its property. **********Meanwhile, the Nasdaq composite index fell 1.72, to 176.29.  The American Stock Exchange's market value index tumbled 4.39, to 255.82, also reaching a new low since May 1980. The Amex, which is dominated by natural resource issues, hit its high of 380.36 last August. **********Mr. Shaw of Smith Barney regards ''the level of extreme risk'' on the Amex index at between 200 and 205.  He is far more optimistic about prospects for resilience in the Dow industrials, now hovering just above 800, which is regarded by market technicians, as are all round numbers in this barometer, as psychologically significant. **********''I don't see the Dow falling below the 760-770 area at worst,'' he declared.  Yesterday, industrials finished at their lowest level since 805.20 on May 12, 1980. At that time, spurred by a price rally in the fixed-income market, the Dow was recovering strongly from a closing low of 759.13 set on April 21, 1980. **********In recent weeks, however, stocks have parted company with bonds.  The steady drop in stock prices has occurred alongside rising prices and declining yields for bonds. **********Yesterday, there were 490 advances and 1,034 declines on the Big Board.  The sell-off in technology issues has been accompanied by heightened caution on the part of Wall Street analysts. Two days ago, Barry Tarasoff of Goldman, Sachs & Company advised clients to take partial profits in several computer stocks that outperformed the general market in the first two months of 1982.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/21/world.main_headline: ZAMBIA'S KAUNDA OFFERS PRETORIA 'GOSPEL' OF PEACE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/21/world.print_headline: ZAMBIA'S KAUNDA OFFERS PRETORIA 'GOSPEL' OF PEACE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/21/world.body_text: **********In public at least, there are more hints and fervent hopes than hard facts about the outcome of last month's meeting between President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia and South Africa's Prime Minister, P .W. Botha, representatives of southern Africa's opposed racial and political forces. **********Mr. Kaunda met Mr. Botha on the border between South Africa and Botswana on April 30, and the encounter, not previously discussed with the Zambian leader's so-called front-line colleagues, elicited harsh criticism from his peers. **********The front-line group, made up of Angola, Botswana, Mozambique, Tanzania, Zambia and Zimbabwe, is, by tradition, black-ruled Africa's main pressure group in any negotiations concerning the advent of majority rule in southern Africa. **********The outcry against Mr. Kaunda from some in the front-line group recalled earlier opposition to his diplomacy during the seven years of conflict that transformed white-ruled Rhodesia into independent Zimbabwe. During that period, Mr. Kaunda met with Ian D. Smith, then Prime Minister of Rhodesia, and John Vorster, then Prime Minister of South Africa, in a mediation effort that brought cries of ''sellout'' from his peers. **********A Different View in Lusaka **********Yet the view from Lusaka, then as now, is different, suffused with President Kaunda's vision of himself as an elder statesman, uniquely qualified for the grand gesture that, perhaps, will bring peace or, perhaps, will regenerate his image as a historic peacemaker on the interational scene at a time of domestic difficulties and decreased regional influence. **********According to Zambian and Western sources, Mr. Kaunda carried with him several signals for Mr. Botha. One, as subsequently publicized, was the message that South African whites must talk to the ''true'' leaders of the country's black majority, such as Nelson Mandela, whose release from imprisonment Mr. Kaunda reportedly sought. The alternative, in the Zambian view, is a revolution. **********Mr. Botha, according to a Zambian source, replied that he would discuss the matter with his colleagues, causing some small sense of encouragement among Zambian officials. Another strand of what has been termed in Lusaka ''the gospel according to Kaunda'' was, according to Zambian and Western sources, an assurance to Mr. Botha that South Africa need not fear for its security if South-West Africa becomes independent of Pretoria's rule under a Government run by the South-West Africa People's Organization. Guerrilla War in Namibia **********The insurgents are fighting a guerrilla campaign against South African dominance in South-West Africa, also known as Namibia, and are armed and otherwise supported by the Soviet Union and its allies. In the Zambian view, however, the guerrillas are not ''puppets of Moscow,'' as South Africa sees them, but nationalists who, in the event they assumed power, would not allow their territory to be used as an operational base by the Soviet-supported guerrillas of the African National Congress, which opposes white rule in South Africa. **********A prominent Zambian, in tune with official thinking, compared the Namibian nationalists to Zimbabwe's guerrilla fighters who, he said, had, at the insistence of the front-line countries, refrained from offering bases on Zimbabwean territory to the African National Congress after Zimbabwe's independence two years ago. **********''We did not allow it in Zimbabwe, we would not allow it in Namibia,'' the Zambian figure said, requesting anonymity. On the broad scale, Mr. Kaunda's message seems, in part, to have been to present a muted version of Soviet influence among the Namibian insurgents and in his own country. **********Such was Lusaka's concern to play down Moscow's role that, according to an authoritative Zambian source, the Government and the officially guided press here accorded low prominence to a visit by a ranking Soviet delegation shortly before the Botha-Kaunda meeting.  ''You do not commit adultery with one while you are wooing another,'' a Zambian official said, referring to Lusaka's desire to reduce the appearance of Soviet influence because of Pretoria's extreme aversion to Moscow and its policies. Outcome of Talks Unclear **********The outcome of the talks, however, has thus far been unclear. A consensus among Zambians and Westerners here is that Mr. Kaunda would not have taken the political risk of meeting Mr. Botha without guaranteees that his efforts would be rewarded. But, on the Namibian issue, Mr. Kaunda's assurances about the guerrillas seem to have been partly contradicted by the insurgents themselves. **********The guerrilla group rejected the latest Western proposals for a settlement a day after Mr. Kaunda met Mr. Botha, and Reagan Administration officials said they believed that the Soviet Union had already made clear to the guerrillas that Moscow's support would not waver if the insurgents chose to dismiss the Western plan. 'The Devil Himself' **********Yet there is an almost desperate sense of hope in Lusaka that Mr.  Kaunda will be vindicated in meeting a man who is sometimes called by Zambians ''the devil himself.'' **********Zambians almost seem to be scouring the horizon for an omen from Pretoria, as evidenced by an editorial Tuesday in The Times of Zambia, a newspaper that sees its role as an interpreter of official policy to its readers and as a conveyor of popular sentiment to the Government. The column reflected on remarks by Mr. Botha last weekend in which he urged South Africans to ''make peace with neighboring African states.'' **********The editorial was clearly intended, in part, as a signal to Pretoria. It congratulated Mr. Botha and encouraged him to continue in like vein. ''The so-called gospel according to Kaunda is seemingly paying dividends,'' the article rejoiced, while cautioning Mr. Botha to avoid playing for time and to call off his military strikes into Angola, Namibia's northern neighbor. **********The comment was evidence of a profound desire by Zambians to see some recompense for Mr. Kaunda's extension of the olive branch after years of making sacrifices on behalf of others in southern Africa's liberation wars. Hope Seems Forlorn **********''Botha must give something now,'' a Zambian who works outside his own country said. ''You've no idea how isolated we Zambians have become among other Africans after the meeting with Botha.'' In immediate terms, the hopes seem forlorn. Despite the April 30 meeting, South Africa raided southern Angola, where the Namibian insurgents are based, earlier this week, prompting skeptical Zambians to assume that, in talking to Mr. Kaunda, Mr. Botha had made only a cosmetic gesture designed to stall the black African campaign against apartheid. **********Additionally, the Kaunda-Botha meeting has divided the front-line group, with Mozambique, Tanzania and Zimbabwe criticizing Zambia despite the organization's intense desire for at least the appearance of solidarity. **********Some Zimbabweans, for instance, compare the April 30 encounter with Mr. Kaunda's discussions in 1975 with Mr. Vorster, negotiations that Zimbabwean radicals say were designed to thwart the guerrilla war and install a moderate Government. **********The Zambian riposte is that the negotiations led directly to the release from detention of Robert D. Mugabe and Joshua Nkomo, the men who led the guerrilla war to independence in 1980. Mr. Mugabe is now Zimbabwe's Prime Minister and Mr. Nkomo the minority leader there, an outcome that ran counter to Mr. Kaunda's support for Mr. Nkomo.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/26/busin.body_text: **********Caisse de Depot et Placement du Quebec, the pension fund for the province of Quebec's teachers and civil servants, has become the largest single shareholder in Alcan Aluminium Ltd., Alcan disclosed today. **********The company said in a proxy statement mailed out with its annual report that Caisse now holds 4,380,945 Alcan shares, or 5.3 percent of the company's outstanding common stock. **********At today's closing price of $24.25 (Canadian) on the Toronto Stock Exchange, the indicated value of Caisse's holding was $106 million. **********Alcan, with revenues of $4.9 billion (Canadian) in 1981, is Canada's largest aluminum producer and fifth-largest industrial company. **********An Alcan spokesman said the company had sought no assurances from Caisse about the possibility of future Alcan stock purchases and an official of Caisse said the agency would make no comment about its intentions. **********The role of Caisse as a shareholder in companies with Quebec operations has become controversial since it first announced two years ago that it would go beyond passive investment to take an active role in companies considered of ''strategic'' importance to Quebec. **********Caisse, in cooperation with other Quebec provincial agencies, now holds 42 percent of Montreal-based Domtar Inc., one of Canada's major forest-products companies, and 51 percent of Gaz Metropolitain, Quebec's biggest gas utility. A concern owned 30 percent by Caisse and 70 percent by Toronto-based Brascan Ltd. holds the major shareholding of 39.2 percent in Noranda Mines Ltd., Canada's secondbiggest mining company. **********In 1981 Caisse spent roughly $800 million (Canadian) acquiring common and convertible shares. Its portfolio of such securities was worth about $2.3 billion by the end of 1981, a spokesman for the agency said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/11/busin.body_text: **********The Digital Equipment Corporation reported yesterday that net income in the fourth fiscal quarter of 1982 rose 4.1 percent, while revenues increased 15.1 percent. **********The Maynard, Mass., company, one of the country's largest manufacturers of data-processing equipment, said that net income in the latest three months ended July 3 advanced to $121.7 million, or $2 a share, from $116.9 million, or $2.19 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Revenues rose to $1.08 billion, from $938 million. **********For the full fiscal year ended July 3, Digital said, net income increased 21.5 percent, to $417.2 million, or $7.53 a share, from $343.3 million, or $6.70 a share, in the preceding fiscal year.  Revenues moved 21.3 percent higher, to $3.88 billion from $3.2 billion. **********Alfred M. Bertocchi, vice president finance and administration, also said that the company had spent $511 million on new plant, property and equipment during the year, bringing the total outlay over the last three years to $1.1 billion. **********However, Digital announced yesterday that it expected to cut its capital spending for fiscal 1983 to between $350 million and $450 million. The lower spending level, the company said, will mainly reflect a decline in office and plant construction. **********''Over the longer term, increasing heat can be expected from I.B.M. and the Japanese,'' according to a recent analysis of Digital by the Value Line Investment Survey. ''But greater attention to productivity and a strong research and development commitment should keep Digital competitive.'' Norton Simon **********Norton Simon Inc., a diversified consumer products company, reported that net income in its fourth fiscal quarter ended June 30 fell 13.7 percent, to $29 million, or $1.01 a share, from $33.6 million, or 77 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Revenues edged up two-tenths of 1 percent, to $785.9 million, from $784.6 million. There were 27,992,647 shares outstanding in the latest quarter, compared with 39,642,177 in the fourth fiscal quarter of the preceding year. **********Earnings for the latest quarter are before a loss from discontinued operations of $6.6 million and an extraordinary gain of $23.2 million. **********For the full fiscal year, Norton Simon reported, net income increased 3.9 percent, to $107.7 million, or $3.31 a share, from $103.7 million, or $2.26 a share, in the preceding year. Revenues remained even at $2.99 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/28/busin.body_text: **********AT first glance, it looked as if Metromedia could not quite make up its mind. It was selling the 45,000 billboards owned by its Foster & Kleiser division for almost $500 million to a limited partnership.  But the transaction included a somewhat unusual clause that provided for the possibility that Metromedia might buy back the billboards in five years - if both the buyers and sellers agreed. **********In this era of corporate deal-making, when companies buy and sell businesses like so many properties on a Monopoly board, analysts were not bothered by Metromedia's trying to keep one foot in an old business at the same time it headed into newer ventures. They applauded the move because it helped the company financially, providing new cash to help finance its move into other, highertechnology businesses. **********But they also liked the idea that Metromedia might some day reacquire the billboards. For while outdoor advertising is a prosaic business, it also generates a lot of cash. Last year, Foster & Kleiser, the largest outdoor advertising unit in the United States, brought in $121 million of the company's $462 million in revenues and $40 million of its $123 million in income from continuing operations. **********''A lot of companies don't want to give up their good old businesses as they move into new businesses,'' said Fred Anschel, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds. ''And outdoor advertising has grown very steadily, at 10, 12, 15 percent a year. Why not try to get it back? It's a good business.'' **********The market also seemed to react favorably to the completion of the transaction. Last Thursday, as the Dow Jones industrial average moved up 10 points, Metromedia's stock, the highest-priced on the New York Stock Exchange, spurted to a high of $302 a share. Yesterday, however, it slipped back, to 294 1/2, down 7 1/2, while the Dow climbed 25.48 points. **********Metromedia has had an active year in restructuring itself. Besides the recent sale of the billboards, it acquired several radio paging busi-nesses and several new radio and television stations, and sold off some others. **********It has also applied to the Federal Communications Commission for permission to establish cellular mobile, or wireless, telephone systems in at least nine large cities, including New York, Chicago, Miami, Boston and Washington, and is expected to apply for a number of smaller markets as well. Most analysts look for cellular radio to be a particularly lucrative business - even better than billboards - and to start returning substantial profits quickly. **********''I've seen projections that there should be reportable earnings in about a year, and the margins being talked about are extraordinary,'' said Dennis H. Liebowitz, a vice president at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. He said estimates of profit margins were in the 60 percent range. **********But as Metromedia pursued these new ventures, it was accumulating a substantial debt load. The company has long been known for its deft use of leverage. But at some point this year it became clear that further expansion would probably require some kind of financial restructuring. **********The limited partnership ''deal has very distinct advantages for Metromedia,'' said David Londoner, an analyst at Wertheim & Company.  ''It cleans up their balance sheet and allows them to make more acquisitions,'' he added. ''It gives them a great deal more flexibility.'' **********The transaction itself took eight months to piece together. The main architect was Lee J. Seidler, a general partner at Bear, Stearns & Company and a professor of accounting at New York University. **********Investors put up $150,000 in cash for each of 534 units, for a total of $80 million in equity. A $350 million 10-year loan was obtained from a consortium of six banks, led by Citibank. Metromedia provided $70 million of financing in the form of a five-year, zerocoupon note. **********What impressed many observers was the recognition that the billboards could be treated as real estate, which allows investors to take tax deductions not only for the equity they put up, but also for the money they borrow. **********''For investors, it is an opportunity for a multiple write-off,'' said Herman M. Schneider, a tax partner at Coopers & Lybrand. ''I think it is a fantastic deal for both parties, a no-lose proposition.'' **********The transaction has come in for some criticism, too. In a recent article in Barron's about it, for example, Abraham J. Briloff, a professor of accounting at the Baruch College of the City of New York, contended that its ''inspired'' use of some old tax rules was resulting in the deal's being ''bankrolled by the public, via the United States Treasury.'' **********But Mr. Seidler and other tax experts defend it as a valid use of existing laws. Mr. Seidler, for example, notes that Metromedia will pay taxes on the proceeds from the sale. ''It is a real sale,'' he said, adding, ''We haven't guaranteed Metromedia will get the billboards back, but we wanted to give them a crack at it.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/29/world.main_headline: SEOUL OPPOSITION LEADER ASKS END OF BAN ON 580 POLITICIANS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/29/world.print_headline: SEOUL OPPOSITION LEADER ASKS END OF BAN ON 580 POLITICIANS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/29/world.body_text: **********A prominent opposition leader has urged that the South Korean Government lift a ban on some 580 politicians at once to restore ''elementary freedoms and democracy to the people of South Korea.'' **********The head of the banned New Democratic Party, Kim Young Sam, who was reached by telephone at his home where he has been under house arrest for the last seven months, also urged that President Chun Doo Hwan restore freedom of the press. **********''That is fundamental,'' he said. ''We have to have a free press in my country. That is where everything begins. It is an essential of any democracy.'' **********Mr. Kim's comments came a day after the release from prison of Kim Dae Jung, his sometime ally and sometime rival in politics.  After the murder of President Park Chung Hee in October 1979 the two Kims were seen as possible successors. Kim Young Sam was widely viewed as being in the strongest position to gain the presidency, with Kim Dae Jung as his closest rival. **********No election was held. When Mr. Chun, then an army general, seized power in May 1980, he had Kim Dae Jung arrested and prosecuted on sedition charges and had Kim Young Sam confined to his home.  President Chun later banned the existing political parties and disqualified some 580 politicians and National Assembly members from public life until 1988, when his seven-year term is to end. **********Kim Young Sam was released from house arrest after a year and then confined to his home again seven months ago.  South Korean officials said recently that they might allow the 580 banned politicians to return to public life but President Chun is believed to have ruled out concessions to the two Kims. **********''It's now more than a decade since we had free elections under a passable charter,'' an aide to Mr. Kim said. ''We should not let year-end euphoria over Kim Dae Jung's welcome release obscure elementary difficulties here.'' **********Mr. Kim said that without democracy South Korea would not be able to compete with and prevail over the Communist regime in North Korea in the long run. He asserted that without free elections and a press free from Government control there could be ''no democracy nor a resemblance of a free society.''House Arrest Never Reported **********''Take the fact that it has never been reported in the Korean press that I am under house arrest,'' he said. ''What kind of liberty do the media actually enjoy?'' **********''The newspapers in Seoul are packed with distortions day by day,'' he said, ''and the trouble is that when rumors take hold, no one knows what to believe.'' **********The banned politician lives in a two-story home on a hill in Seoul. The modern house is on a narrow road that has been sealed off by the Agency for National Security Planning and by the police. No one is allowed to enter or leave Mr. Kim's home apart from his wife and one or two members of the domestic staff. **********''Looking out of my window now there are 40 men out there,'' Mr.  Kim said. ''Forty men or more, sometimes with their big buses, blocking the road.'' **********Mr. Kim said in an earlier phone call to Tokyo this month that his wife was allowed to shop but was constantly watched and made to feel uncomfortable. None of his party members is allowed to visit, he said. **********''No one has ever explained to me what this house arrest is about, what its aim is nor the reason for it,'' he said.  In the telephone interview, Mr. Kim also said Kim Dae Jung should be allowed to return to South Korea after receiving medical treatment in the United States and to recommence political activities along with other banned politicians.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/11/busin.body_text: **********Six leading American banks have made emergency loans totaling $600 million to Brazil to help tide it over until it obtains a larger and longer-term credit from the International Monetary Fund, according to banking sources. **********The United States Government also is expected to lend between $500 million and $1 billion to Brazil in the near future, the sources said. **********Brazilian officials are now in Europe seeking similar credits from large European banks. Brazil is trying to raise a total of $1.5 billion by year-end, from both private banks and governments, the sources said. **********In a related development, the I.M.F. has agreed to a credit for Argentina of $2.1 billion.The funds would become available over a 15-month period. Conditions on Credits **********The I.M.F. agreement came after difficult negotiations between Argentina and the fund over measures to be taken by Argentina to restrain its economy and improve its international financial position. The situation was different in Brazil, where the Government had adopted a belt-tightening program without discussing it with the I.M.F. **********''Brazil has already adopted an austerity program that would meet I.M.F. standards,'' said Joel Korn, a vice president of the Bank of America who is stationed in Brazil. **********Brazil's main problem has been the reluctance of many foreign banks, primarily smaller ones, to provide it with new credits or to renew maturing credits. **********That was why the latest $600 million loan was made by only a handful of major United States banks - the Bank of America, Citibank, the Chase Manhattan Bank, the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company and the Chemical Bank. Political Constraints **********Brazil has been reluctant to seek credits from the International Monetary Fund mainly for domestic political reasons. Citizens of many debtor countries, including Brazil, often resent having austerity programs imposed on them by outsiders, such as the I.M.F., which was set up in 1944 to help nations stabilize their economies. **********Because national elections are scheduled for Nov. 15, the Brazilian Government is especially reluctant to approach the I.M.F. for a credit now. It is expected to do so immediately after the elections.  The $600 million in credits, all of which mature in no more than 90 days, therefore is considered a ''bridge loan,'' to be used only until the I.M.F. credit becomes available. **********One of the major problems is that banks in other developing countries have been refusing to renew loans to Brazil, just as Brazilian banks have been retrenching on loans to other lesserdeveloped countries.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/02/world.print_headline: U.N. VOTES FOR OBSERVERS IN BEIRUT; Text of resolution, page A6.
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/02/world.body_text: **********The Security Council, hastily summoned to debate Israel's latest attacks on west Beirut, unanimously demanded a cease-fire today and asked United Nations military observers to insure that it is maintained. **********By the time the vote was taken, Israel had already announced that a new cease-fire, the ninth since Israeli forces invaded Lebanon June 6, was in effect. **********The Council's action today, however, marked the first time that it has agreed to install even a symbolic United Nations presence in the Lebanese capital. Until now, Israel has strenuously opposed any such move, and it was unclear tonight whether it would accept the United Nations observers. But since the United States joined the other 14 Council members in voting for the resolution, it would be difficult for Israel to say no. Today's Security Council meeting was requested by Lebanon. **********2 Reasons for Israeli Opposition **********Israel has opposed any role for United Nations observers in Beirut for two reasons. Israel does not want to collide with even a symbolic United Nations presence, and it wants an American-led force, not a United Nations team, to supervise the withdrawal of the Palestine Liberation Organization from Beirut. The observers have no such task, but their existence might encourage demands for United Nations troops to oversee any departure of the guerrillas. **********If United Nations observers are not placed between the Palestinian fighters and Israel, but are confined to points from which they can watch any military action, the confrontation problem will not arise, American diplomats say. **********The Council delegates were awakened at 3:30 this morning after reports were received of Israel's intensive armored, air and sea attacks on west Beirut. Five hours later, the delegates gathered in the @anterooms off the Council chamber to negotiate a text on which they could agree. **********Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the chief United States delegate, successfully edited a first draft. She deleted language critical of Israel and won an assurance that the observers would be limited to the Beirut area and a statement that the cease-fire should embrace not only Lebanon but ''all military activities across the Lebanese-Israeli border.'' **********Her success reflected the other members' eagerness to put United Nations observers in Beirut, and this was the heart of today's resolution. It ''authorizes the Secretary General to deploy immediately on the request of the Government of Lebanon, United Nations observers to monitor the situation in and around Beirut.'' **********Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar is in Tunisia on an African tour, but he stayed in touch with the Council by telephone.  He is drawing his cease-fire observers from the United Nations Truce Supervision Organization. **********That little-known group consists of 298 officers ranging from captain to lieutenant colonel and drawn from 17 countries, including the United States and the Soviet Union. Its headquarters are in Jerusalem. The organization was set up in 1948 to oversee the end of hostilities after the first Arab-Israeli war. **********The truce supervision organization is commanded by Lieut. Gen.  Emanuel Erskine of Ghana, and he can immediately call on about 10 officers now stationed in Beirut. In addition, 80 officers attached to the organization are with the United Nations peacekeeping forces in southern Lebanon. **********Mrs. Kirkpatrick was silent in today's debate. Other delegates strongly criticized Israel. Dr. Ahmed Esmat Abdel Meguid, the Egyptian delegate, said he ''condemned in the strongest terms the new aggression by Israel against west Beirut and the P.L.O.'' **********The Lebanese delegate, Ghassan Tueni, deplored what he called Israel's ''vicious, atrocious killing'' and pleaded for help from the Council. **********The Israeli envoy, Yehuda Z. Blum, did not discuss the resolution but said Israel had simply responded to cease-fire breaches by the P.L.O. **********Tonight, Mr. Perez de Cuellar said that the P.L.O. and Lebanon had agreed to the United Nations observers but that Israel was reserving its decision until its Cabinet had met. **********In addition to the United States, the other Council members are Britain, China, France, the Soviet Union, Ireland, Spain, Panama, Japan, Uganda, Poland, Zaire, Togo, Guyana and Jordan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/17/world.main_headline: U.S.-CHINA ACCORD PROVIDES FOR CUT IN ARMS TO TAIWAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/17/world.print_headline: U.S.-CHINA ACCORD PROVIDES FOR CUT IN ARMS TO TAIWAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/17/world.body_text: **********The United States and China have signed a new communique governing both countries' relations with Taiwan.  Administration officials say the document should prevent a major rift with Peking. **********In the communique, expected to be made public on Tuesday, China pledges to seek reunification with Taiwan only by peaceful means, and the United States promises not to exceed current levels of sales of fighter aircraft to Taiwan and to reduce them gradually. **********John H. Holdridge, the Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, gave unpublicized briefings this morning to Senate and House leaders in advance of the public announcement of the new development in Chinese-American relations. **********Production of Jets to Continue **********Simultaneous with release of the communique, the Administration intends to inform Congress officially of the plans for continued coproduction of F-5E fighter planes between the Northrop Corporation and Taiwan, the Congressional sources said. The Administration announced in January its intention to continue to allow Taiwan to produce the F-5E, while denying it access to more advanced fighters. **********But official notification of the decision has been delayed because the United States sought to work out first a new understanding with Peking governing relations in which continued American arms sales to Taiwan would be at least tacitly accepted by China. **********China has publicly denounced American arms sales to Taiwan as an infringement of China's sovereignty over the island and not in keeping with the decision by the United States to establish diplomatic relations with China in January 1979 while severing official ties with Taiwan. Taiwan Relations Act **********Under the Taiwan Relations Act, approved by Congress after relations were established with Peking, the United States maintains unofficial relations with Taiwan and is committed to supplying Taiwan with ''such defense articles and defense services in such quantity as may be necessary to enable Taiwan to maintain a sufficient self-defense capability.'' **********The State Department refused to comment on Mr. Holdridge's discussions.  Participants in his briefings, however, said that in the communique, worked out in Peking by Ambassador Arthur W. Hummel Jr.  and Chinese officials, the United States reaffirmed its view that ''there is but one China'' and that it attached great importance to good relations with the Peking Government. **********The Chinese, in the preamble to the statement, said that they were committed to the peaceful reunification of Taiwan with the ''motherland'' and that that was ''a fundamental policy.'' Congressional sources reported that Mr. Holdridge said that the stress on peaceful reunification was significant. **********On Dec. 15, 1978, when the two sides announced diplomatic relations would be established on Jan. 1, 1979, the Chinese said that ''as for the way of bringing Taiwan back to the embrace of the motherland and reunifying the country, it is entirely China's internal affair.'' **********Actually, the Chinese have been stating their desire for peaceful reunification with Taiwan since September 1981.  The United States said in the new communique, the sources said, that given the statements in the preamble, it would not exceed annually either in quantity or quality the level of arms sales to Taiwan in any given year since normalization. In 1979, the United States shipped about $800 million worth of arms, the highest amount to date. Level of Sales to Be Reduced **********In the statement, the United States also said that the level of arms sales to Taiwan would be gradually reduced, but there was no cutoff date for such sales as sought by the Chinese during the negotiations that have been going on for the last 10 months. **********According to the sources, the major issue that had held up an agreement in recent months was the disagreement over the American desire to link gradual reduction of arms sales to Taiwan with progress toward peaceful solution of the Taiwan issue. The Chinese said this was tantamount to interference in their affairs. **********The formula as finally worked out has the Chinese stating that peaceful reunification is a fundamental policy of China, and Washington asserting that in light of that statement, it will gradually reduce arms sales. **********According to participants, when Mr. Holdridge briefed the Foreign Relations Committee on the document, concern was voiced over the commitment to reduce American arms sales to Taiwan There was questioning of whether this was undermining the Taiwan Relations Act. **********Mr. Holdridge defended the language, asserting that the Administration would live up to the commitments to Taiwan under the Taiwan Relations Act. Under Fire From Conservatives **********The Administration has been under fire in recent weeks from conservatives, such as Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, who have complained about the delay in going ahead with the F-5E co-production plans with Taiwan, and who feared that the Administration might sign a communique with Peking setting a time for ending arms sales to Taiwan. **********It has also been criticized by others for endangering relations with Peking, which former officials like Zbigniew Brzezinski view as crucial to American long-range strategic interests against the Russians. **********Negotiations intensified in the last two months as the Administration informed Peking that it had to send the F-5E notification to Congress before Congress recessed in late August and it preferred to have a statement worked out with Peking before doing so. **********Administration officials have said that they assumed the Chinese would not let the sale of American military equipment to Taiwan lead to a rupture in relations with Peking, but there has been concern that Peking might reduce the level of relations or take some other symbolic step if the F-5E sale went ahead without some framework statement such as the one just worked out.

Paisley and his militant Protestant movement suffered a setback today in returns from a parliamentary by-election Thursday in southern Belfast. **********The candidate of Mr. Paisley's Democratic Unionist Party, the Rev.
