https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/25/world.main_headline: U.S. AIDE SAYS SOVIET WANTS ARMS PACT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/25/world.print_headline: U.S. AIDE SAYS SOVIET WANTS ARMS PACT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/25/world.body_text: **********The chief United States negotiator to the coming talks on reducing strategic arms said today that he was convinced Soviet leaders wanted an arms agreement and an overall reduction in tensions with the West. **********At the same time, the negotiator, Edward L. Rowny, a retired Army lieutenant general, said the movement for a nuclear arms freeze ''hurts'' Reagan Administration efforts in talks with Moscow. The strategic arms talks with the Russians are set to begin in Geneva on Tuesday. **********The effort to freeze nuclear forces at the existing level ''hurts me as a negotiator,'' Mr. Rowny said. ''It hurts to have someone looking over my shoulder, believing this will have an impact, believing there's a sentiment.'' **********On a recent trip to Western European capitals to discuss the approaching arms negotiations, Mr. Rowny said, the movement for a freeze appeared to be on the decline. Western European leaders, he said, ''are very much afraid of a freeze.'' Movement Said to Peak Out **********''They feel the freeze movement has kind of peaked out and is on a downscale and that's good,'' he added.  Mr. Rowny said the Europeans were especially concerned that a freeze could mean that the United States would forgo the deployment overseas of two weapons that many West Europeans want: Pershing 2 ballistic missiles and ground-launched cruise missiles. **********''The freeze locks inequalities into position,'' said Mr. Rowny, who held a breakfast meeting with reporters as well as a news conference at the State Department. ''You have to begin negotiating what a freeze is all about. Then you have to negotiate the verification aspects of the freeze. The freeze is just a bummer from a negotiator's point of view.'' **********Mr. Rowny, who resigned from the strategic arms negotiating team in 1979 because of disagreement over American concessions to the Soviet Union, voiced optimism about a new pact. ''I think the Soviets want an agreement,'' he said, adding that his assessment was based on ''intuition, plus feedback.'' Sees Brezhnev Commitment **********He said Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, seemed ''committed'' to an arms agreeement. ''They think detente can come back,'' he said of the Russians. ''They desperately want technology transfers, they want credits.'' **********Mr. Rowny said that in the last 10 to 15 years the Soviet Union had build up its strategic arsenal to create a potentially ''destabilizing situation'' with the United States. The Administration proposal for the talks calls for each side to reduce its missile warheads by a third, down to 5,000 on no more than 850 missiles. This would require the Russians to cut their missile force by 1,500, compared with 850 for the United States. **********Asked about the ''linkage'' concept, in which United States attitudes toward the Soviet Union are based in part on Soviet actions in other matters, Mr. Rowny said, ''Linkage is always in the background, you can't negate it. **********''If relations are better, you have a better chance of getting an agreement,'' he continued. ''If there are strained relations, it's a tougher chance.'' Verification Issue Cited **********In response to a question about the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan and reports of the use of biological and chemical warfare there and elsewhere, Mr. Rowny said: ''I worry about what they're doing in other areas. This impinges on what I do.'' He indicated that Soviet actions elsewhere were especially closely linked to the delicate issue of verification, the procedures to insure that the Russians are not cheating on an agreement. **********''There is an impact in what happens in other areas,'' he said. He remarked that the Administration had ''not ruled out on-site inspection'' as a verification method, although the Soviet Union has consistently opposed it. **********''You have to move toward more cooperative means,'' he said. ''You have to push them to agree to more openness.'' ---- Talks on Medium-Range Arms **********GENEVA, June 24 (AP) - In one of the briefest sessions since negotiations began almost seven months ago, American and Soviet representatives met for an hour and 50 minutes today in their talks on reducing intermediate-range nuclear forces in Europe. **********The meeting was the 34th of the current series. No substantial progress has been reported.  The two sides are to confer again Tuesday, the same day set for the opening of parallel talks on strategic or long-range nuclear weapons.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/29/world.main_headline: Weinberger Reluctant On Bigger Beirut Force
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/29/world.print_headline: Weinberger Reluctant On Bigger Beirut Force
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/29/world.body_text: **********Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger expressed reluctance today about enlarging the force of American marines in Lebanon or extending their time there but nonetheless left open those possibilities. **********At the same time, Mr. Weinberger told reporters that the United States would assist the Lebanese Government in rebuilding its armed forces. **********''Their armed forces are going to need some assistance,'' he said, ''and the country is going to need some assistance, economically and militarily and every other way.'' **********A White House spokesman, Larry Speakes, responded to continuing speculation that the Marine Corps force in Lebanon would be enlarged by saying, ''There are no plans now to increase the size of the multinational force or the United States participation in it.'' France and Italy also have troops in Beirut. **********Mr. Weinberger said the force was intended to insure the withdrawal of all foreign forces from Lebanon. ''The desire is to do that in as quick a time as possible and with the minimum number of forces,'' he said. **********He also said that ''you're not going to maintain peace by manning the borders with ever larger forces.'' Mr. Weinberger said peace would come by ''strengthening the Lebanese Government so that it can prevent its territory from being used in any way that would foster war.'' **********Mr. Weinberger added, however, ''I can't really say today what we'll be doing three or four weeks from now.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/17/busin.main_headline: Economic Scene; Military Surge As Spur to Jobs
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/17/busin.print_headline: Economic Scene; Military Surge As Spur to Jobs
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/17/busin.body_text: **********THE drop in industrial production by half a percentage point in August implies that unemployment, which has held at 9.8 percent of the labor force for the last two months, is likely to rise above 10 percent before the November elections. **********The drop in production also lowers the rate of industrial capacity utilization, putting additional pressure on capital spending by business. For August, factory use declined to 69.4 percent, off half a percentage point from the low July level. **********Under the impact of excess capacity, industry has been cutting its capital appropriations steeply. Alan Greenspan of Townsend-Greenspan notes that, excluding highly volatile petroleum expenditures, manufacturers slashed their capital appropriations 17 percent in the second quarter and 34 percent in the last three quarters. Actual capital spending seems to have some way still to fall. **********Mr. Greenspan finds that cash flow of corporations is providing even less support to capital spending than in 1975, ''despite the passage of the 1981 Economic Recovery Act,'' which was to provide strong stimulus to saving and investment. **********In a new econometric analysis, Prof. Robert S. Chirinko of Cornell University finds a ''low response'' of investment and saving to tax changes but re-emphasizes the importance of capacity utilization and cash flow to capital spending. **********Professor Chirinko concludes that ''recently enacted personal and business tax cuts will have little direct effect on spurring new investment.'' And he warns that, ''if these cuts, combined with other aspects of the Reagan economic program, result in depressed levels of demand and capacity utilization, they may well have perverse effects on capital formation in the 1980's.'' **********However, the Reagan Administration's economic program, adverised as a supply-side policy, is not entirely lacking in measures to increase total demand as a means of creating jobs. **********The major demand stimulant in the Administration's program is military spending, which is scheduled to rise to $364.6 billion in 1987 from $190.5 billion in the current fiscal year. Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger has been waging a stubborn campaign to prevent the defense budget from being trimmed by critics in Congress or within the White House who argue that too rapid a military buildup is hurting the economy. **********In a recent interview, Mr. Weinberger said, ''You get 35,000 more jobs for every extra $1 billion you spend on national defense.'' This is a number that came to him from an economic unit within the Pentagon called the Defense Economic Impact Modeling System. **********This system, known as Deims, employs a macroeconomic model similar to those used by Data Resources and Wharton Econometric Forecasting Associates, private economic forecasting concerns, both of whose models derive from an essentially Keynesian view of the world. **********In addition, Deims uses an input-output model, derived from the work of Wassily W. Leontief, to trace the impact of defense expenditures on 400 industries and 161 skilled labor categories as an method for helping defense producers plan ahead. **********The Pentagon's economists regard 35,000 jobs per extra $1 billion as a conservative estimate. They now estimate that the direct effect of military outlays on prime contractors, subcontractors and material producers is 25,000 jobs per $1 billion and that its indirect or multiplier effect, as the dollars are respent in other industries, is to create 25,000 or 30,000 more jobs, for a total of 50,000 to 60,000 jobs per $1 billion in military spending. **********Deims finds that, at present levels of spending, the military budget accounts for 2.2 million industrial jobs, not counting 960,000 civilian jobs in the Department of Defense. By the fiscal year 1987, it estimates that military spending will account for 3.4 million industrial jobs plus about a million civilian jobs in the Defense Department. **********Mr. Weinberger says the case for rising military spending depends primarily not on its economic benefits but on ''our high estimate of the Soviet threat.'' However, he insists that ''doing this is not bad for the economy.'' He maintains that the impact of military spending on budget deficits is exaggerated by its critics because ''military outlays generate greater tax revenues, unlike transfer payments.'' **********These arguments have apparently helped Mr. Weinberger keep the support of the President, and he says he has other supporters in the White House, of whom he names two: ''Judge Clark and Ed Meese.'' He also maintains that Secretary of State George P. Shultz is on his side.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/04/busin.body_text: **********The International Harvester Company said it had agreed to terms on the sale of two of its secondary businesses.  Harvester, which termed the agreements ''another step in the company's reduction of its break-even point,'' said the separate transactions would net it between $65 million and $70 million. **********The company said it had signed a letter of intent with the Dana Corporation of Toledo, Ohio, to sell the assets of its axle and transmission plant in Fort Wayne, Ind., and that it had agreed to sell its airline tow-tractor business to Ingersoll-Rand for cash.  Both agreements are expected to be completed this week. **********Larry D. Hollis, machinery analyst at Robert Baird & Company, a Milwaukee brokerage firm, said the deals were ''not terribly important, and I'm willing to bet that Harvester did not sell the assets for a gain.'' **********He added, ''The company will have some pocket money for working capital, but they will exhaust it very quickly.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/22/busin.body_text: **********Marshall Field & Company, frightened by the biggest takeover threat it has yet faced, is scrambling to find a more acceptable merger partner than the Icahn group, which has already purchased a 19.4 percent interest, or to turn up a purchaser for the roughly 2.1 million shares owned by Icahn. **********The search, according to financial sources, even includes Carter Hawley Hale Stores, Los Angeles, which in 1977 found its own $42-ashare takeover offer spurned by Field's management. And another retailer, the May Department Stores Company, has expressed interest in a possible merger with Field in the last few days. **********Despite a lingering ill feeling against Carter, Field reportedly has been making inquiries through a third party. The third party appears to be Goldman, Sachs & Company, the investment bankers, hired by Marshall Field last week to help it find ''alternatives'' to the Icahn group. **********Field recently obtained a temporary restraining order blocking Icahn from making further purchases of Field shares. Looking for Other Buyers **********People close to the situation said Goldman, Sachs had been actively ''shopping the market'' for a more appealing investor or merger partner. John Boyle, chairman of the May stores in St. Louis, met with Angelo Arena, Field's chairman, in Chicago. But discussions were inconclusive, according to financial sources. **********There are indications that the Icahn group hopes to increase its holding of Marshall Field common (if it can emerge from the restraining order) to 20 percent. Once that threshold is achieved, the owner of the block could report a like share of Marshall Field's earnings as its own. That prospect would enhance the Icahn group's ability to find a purchaser for its Field shares if it decides to sell them. **********Reports yesterday indicated that the restraining order against Icahn would be partly lifted today, with the rest to be removed tomorrow. **********The Icahn Capital Corporation, principal entity of the Icahn group, said Friday that investors affiliated with Icahn had filed an amended 13-D statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission.  The amended statement included a plan covering the sale or financing of Field's valuable real-estate assets. Comments From Officers **********A top executive of Carter Hawley Hale said there had been no contacts ''to my knowledge'' with Goldman, Sachs. Waldo H. Burnside, vice chairman and chief operating officer of Carter, said in a telephone interview, ''The economics of the situation and our stock price would, I think, make any arrangement with Field's a remote possibility.'' Philip M. Hawley, chairman of Carter Hawley Hale was said to be away on a holiday. **********Carter's common has recently been selling at about l3 after reaching a year's high of 20 7/8. Marshall Field's common has recently been selling at close to 20 after peaking at 22 within the last year. **********Carl C. Icahn, head of Icahn Capital, declined to see a reporter late last week. Two members of his law firm -Gordon, Hurwitz, Butowsky, Baker, Weitzen & Shalov - consented to answer questions but mostly skirted making direct replies. **********Asked if Marshall Field's opposition to the Icahn purchases reflected its perception that Mr. Icahn had usually made investments in companies and sold them for a profit, David Butowsky, a partner in the law firm, replied, ''He has had some situations in which he has sold stock he bought and one, in the instance of Bayswater Realty and Capital Corporation, where he remained, became chairman and is running the company.'' Opportunist or Investor? **********Mr. Butowsky added, ''It's to the advantage of an entrenched management to paint Mr. Icahn as an opportunist, but any investor is free to follow any of his options.'' **********In a suit filed by Field on Feb. 8, which led to the restraining order, the Chicago retailer charged Mr. Icahn and several companies associated with him of having violated Federal securities law in their purchases of Field stock. **********Marshall Field has been considered ripe for takeover for some time because of its erratic earnings record, management's relatively small stock ownership, its holdings of valuable real estate and the impression that it barely defeated the stockholder suits filed against it after it rejected Carter Hawley Hale's offer. **********But John Landschultz, who has watched Field since 1959, does not consider the big retailer so vulnerable. Mr. Landschultz is an analyst at Mesirow & Company, a Chicago brokerage house. **********''Marshall Field dominates this area,'' he said, ''and it's a much improved company over what it was four and five years ago, even though we are in a recession. Icahn, it seems to me, is in pretty deep and can't get out on his own without finding a buyer. Icahn's money is tied up, and he needs to find someone or have someone found to buy him out.'' Stockholder Suits a Factor **********Other analysts believe, however, that Marshall Field may have to locate a buyer for the company in view of the class action suits filed in the wake of Carter's offer. **********Fran R. Blechman, vice president and analyst at Merrill Lynch, said, ''It's difficult to see any major department store chain that could buy Field's without running afoul of antitrust regulations, so it may be another kind of retailer or even a foreign company.'' **********Monroe H. Greenstein, a partner at Bear, Stearns & Company, noted that Field's attractive real-estate assets, its Water Tower Place Center, the State Street store in Chicago's Loop and several shopping centers it owns all offer an ''interesting target.'' **********Although Mr. Arena of Marshall Field was not available for comment in Chicago, an associate who asked not to be identified said that Field's options were not confined to finding a merger partner or a buyer of the Field shares held by Icahn. ''We could buy another company, too, or issue stock for that or another purpose,'' he said.  ''There are at least 15 options that Goldman, Sachs could pursue for us. But they all boil down to buy or sell.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/08/world.main_headline: ISRAELI CABINET APPROVES PAYMENT TO THE DISPLACED SETTLERS IN SINAI
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/08/world.print_headline: ISRAELI CABINET APPROVES PAYMENT TO THE DISPLACED SETTLERS IN SINAI
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/08/world.body_text: **********The Israeli Cabinet voted narrowly today for a large package of financial compensation to Jewish settlers who will have to vacate their homes, farms and businesses when the final strip of Sinai is returned to Egypt next April. **********The decision appeared to defuse angry protests by settlers who had burned buildings and begun to build fortified positions in Yamit, on the Mediterranean coast, to protest what they said were inadequate grants. A more ideological group of settlers, however, remained opposed to the withdrawal in principle, calling it a ''retreat'' and urging the Israeli public to resist the pullout. **********The Cabinet decision, proposed by Simcha Ehrlich, the Deputy Prime Minister and Agriculture Minister, allocates about $263 million to approximately 1,400 families in the Yamit area and in Sharm el-Sheik on the Red Sea. **********The grants, which amount to an average of nearly $188,000 per family, are meant to cover the costs of abandoned structures and equipment and to compensate for years of building stores, factories and lucrative hot-house farms. Each family's award will be different, depending on the value of the business left behind. Finance Minister Opposed Move **********The Cabinet vote was 5 to 4. Among those opposed was Finance Minister Yoram Aridor, who argued that the large sums would undo his efforts to cut Government spending as a way of curbing inflation. **********But the decision to make such large grants, and the authorities' refusal to prosecute any settlers for arson, testifies to Israel's deep ambivalence over relinquishing the final swath of Sinai, which runs from El Arish on the Mediterranean to Sharm el-Sheik on the Red Sea. **********Under the Egyptian-Israeli peace treaty, it must be returned to Egypt by April 25, when it is to come under patrol by an international military force. **********The idea of pulling out Jewish settlements touches a nerve of discomfort in Israel, where settlement has always been regarded as integral to the nation's solidity and well-being. Some Israelis think it shameful for Jewish settlements to be uprooted, and their distress is felt with sympathy at the Cabinet level. Concern Over Egypt and U.S. **********Consequently, there is pervasive unhappiness here as the withdrawal date approaches. Many Israelis, noting the assassination in October of Egypt's President, Anwar el-Sadat, see a peaceful Egyptian regime as a fragile thing, and wonder what will happen to Cairo's policy after April. Many distrust the United States, which is supposed to be the guarantor of the Camp David accords but has taken to punishing what is viewed in Washington as Israeli misdeeds by delaying weapons shipments or curtailing aid to Israeli military industries. **********Nevertheless, various officials in the Government, and Prime Minister Menachem Begin himself, have repeatedly said that Israel intends to observe its commitment to withdraw on time. Officials explain that only some egregious violation of the treaty by Egypt would precipitate an Israeli refusal to return the territory.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/11/busin.main_headline: China Sets Rules for Oil Drilling
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/11/busin.print_headline: China Sets Rules for Oil Drilling
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/11/busin.body_text: **********China today announced the rules under which foreign oil companies would be allowed to help develop its offshore oilfields, and said that bids for drilling would be invited soon. **********Foreign oil company sources in Peking said that the regulations, which had been pending since December, held no great surprises and that they were in line with other countries' rules governing joint oil ventures. **********The New China News Agency said that the regulations on the exploitation of offshore oil resources had been approved by the State Council. **********Tenders from foreign companies would be invited as soon as a controlling body, to be known as the China National Offshore Oil Corporation, had been set up, it said. **********China produces about two million barrels of oil a day. But Chinese output has declined slightly since 1980 and the country urgently needs to tap new fields to meet rising demand. **********Offshore seismic surveys have already been conducted by four groups representing most of the major oil companies including Amoco, Exxon, Mobil, British Petroleum and Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine. **********Since the announcement last December of a new foreign enterprise income tax law, foreign oil companies have been awaiting the exploration regulations and a promised model contract that will show them the share of production and profits they can expect in joint ventures with China. **********These documents would provide the basis on which the oil companies would conduct joint ventures with China, the sources said. The model contract has not yet appeared, though China has said it has been prepared. **********The China National Offshore Oil Corporation would invite bids, sign petroleum contracts with foreign enterprises and have full control over exploration, development, production and marketing. **********The agency said that foreign partners would have to provide all exploration risks. Once a commercial field was discovered, the foreign company and the Chinese corporation would make a joint investment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/25/busin.body_text: **********Read it and weep for times long gone: A balloon-tire Elgin bicycle for $30.95. A .22-caliber Springfield rifle for $4.25. An all-cotton man's shirt for $1.79. Women's leather shoes for $1.98 a pair. An 18-karat wedding ring with three small diamonds for $5.98. A five-pound box of candy for 98 cents. **********The prices are all listed in the 1933 Christmas catalogue of Sears, Roebuck & Company, which the giant Chicago retailer has reprinted in a limited edition for the nostalgic. It was the first Sears Christmas gift catalogue. **********Although it was published nearly a half-century ago, the 88-page booklet shows that times, at least in one way, have not changed.  Promotional lures were in effect even then. **********For example, Sears advised its customers in 1933 that if they ordered $5 or more in merchandise from the holiday or fall general catalogue they could buy a Hammond electric clock or an Ingraham spring-wound clock for $2.99 (both sold regularly for about $7.50 each). Customers ordering $7.50 or more in goods were entitled to buy a 26-piece Rogers silverware set for $4.99 (the regular price was about $15). A Hard Year **********Promotions were needed in 1933, a year in which the Great Depression hit bottom. The average American who had a job - almost 25 percent were out of work -earned only $16.65 a week, compared with today's average salary of $332.13 a week, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. **********Thus, although the Sears prices of the 1930's may look attractive in the 1980's they may not have been any more affordable to the consumer at that time. **********''The right way to think about prices is not how many dollars they involve as much as how many hours a typical consumer has to work to earn the cost of a particular item,'' said F. Thomas Juster, director of the Institute of Social Research of the University of Michigan. **********''Today's prices are much higher than 1933's,'' he continued, ''but the typical American has to work fewer hours to pay for those higherpriced goods. That means that real productivity has gone up and that is reflected in wages rising faster than prices.'' **********Professor Juster said in an interview from Ann Arbor, Mich., that graduate students at the university had asked undergraduates to choose between the prices of the Sears catalogues of the 1940's and those of the 1960's. ''The instructors found that the students selected the higher-priced 1960's catalogues because along with the price changes comes a subtle series of product quality and innovation changes,'' he said. **********In Chicago, Ernest L. Arms, national news director of Sears, said that slightly less than 10,000 copies of the 1933 catalogue had been printed. ''We wouldn't, of course, want to live through the times that that catalogue represented,'' he said. **********The catalogue was reprinted ''strictly for internal use and for people in the media,'' Mr. Arms said, adding, ''It is not for sale and a sentence on the inside cover says, 'Merchandise shown in this reprint is not offered for sale.' '' **********Commenting on the Sears reprint, John D. Rich, a principal in Case & Company, a management consulting firm in New York, said yesterday: ''It's an interesting thing that Sears has done. It is becoming a trend for old-established companies to reproduce mostly as a goodwill gesture catalogues, packages and wrappers that they used decades ago. In the Sears case, though, the 1933 catalogue came out during an unhappy Christmas and it's a poignant reminder of what we don't want to get back to this season.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/17/busin.main_headline: GULF RESOURCES FOE IS ELUSIVE INVESTOR
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/17/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; GULF RESOURCES FOE IS ELUSIVE INVESTOR
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/17/busin.body_text: **********Alan E. Clore, the Swiss investor waging a proxy fight against the management of Gulf Resources and Chemical Company, did not show up at the company's recent annual meeting -nor could he be located for an interview - which surprised few who knew him. **********''Clore is an elusive fellow, very private,'' said an executive at one of the firms Mr. Clore has hired for that fight.  Not much is publicly known about the 38-year-old man behind the 15.4 percent stake in Gulf Resources. He heads the dissident committee that is trying to unseat current management; the results of that struggle will not be known until May 21, when the proxies are counted. **********Mr. Clore, now a Swiss citizen and private investor, is the son of the late Sir Charles Clore, one of Britain's richest men, who left his son a legacy of investment warfare tactics, but excluded him from his will. The estate, estimated as high as $146 million, is the subject of a tug-of-war between Mr. Clore, who is suing for one-quarter of it, and a British court, which has frozen some assets while trying to collect taxes on others. **********For one so out of favor with his father, however, Mr. Clore's career has closely followed Sir Charles'. Both men began investing at the age of 21, dabbled in financing movies and breeding race horses, and became aggressive investors. **********Sir Charles was known as a ''corporate raider'' who repeatedly forced the hand of management in unfriendly takeovers through his company, Sears Holdings Ltd. **********The younger Mr. Clore, a graduate of Oxford University, may have inherited his acumen for investing in takeover targets. In August 1980 Mr. Clore reported that he had purchased a 5.88 percent stake in Pullman Inc. for $21.3 million. When Wheelabrator-Frye Inc. bought Pullman three months later for nearly $600 million, his stake was worth $35 million. And he reportedly more than doubled his money earlier this year on his 4.1 percent stake in Marshall Field & Company, when Batus Inc., the American unit of B.A.T. Industries of London, bid for the company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/01/world.body_text: **********Two former Secretaries of Defense told a Senate Committee today that they did not accept President Reagan's assertion that the Soviet Union had nuclear superiority.  They strongly urged Mr. Reagan to make greater haste in seeking a resumption of nuclear arms control negotiations. **********The former officials, James R. Schlesinger and Harold Brown, also suggested that American nuclear deterrence might be weakened by statements that the Soviet Union had superiority. **********Mr. Schlesinger, who headed the Pentagon under Presidents Nixon and Ford from 1973 to 1975, and Mr. Brown, who was Secretary under President Carter from 1977 to 1981, made their remarks in testimony before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. **********On Thursday, the committee began what its chairman, Senator Charles H. Percy, Republican of Illinois, described as ''landmark'' hearings on the rising debate over nuclear weapons. At Odds With Weinberger **********On some points, the testimony of the former officials contrasted sharply with that of Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger. On Thursday, he insisted that President Reagan was correct in saying at a news conference on March 31 that the Soviet Union had a ''definite margin of superiority.'' **********But Mr. Schlesinger and Mr. Brown broadly supported some important aspects of the Reagan Administration's defense policy. Both endorsed an increase in conventional strength and the production of the MX missile. And both declined to endorse the proposal for a freeze in the deployment of nuclear weapons that had prompted Mr. Reagan's remark about Soviet superiority. **********Mr. Schlesinger acknowledged that the Soviet Union had ''gradually acquired a hard-target kill capability against American forces which now in all probability substantially exceeds'' that of the United States. **********But he added that the United States ''should not brood about or overstate'' this deficiency and ''above all we should not suggest that the deficiency in this single dimension implies inferiority because the word 'inferiority' may suggest to others that our deterrent is, indeed, inadequate.'' Mr. Brown expressed similar views. Accuracy of Soviet Missiles **********In the argot of nuclear strategists, a hard target is one, such as a missile silo or military command post, that has been strengthened to withstand some levels of nuclear blast, heat and radiation. No target can withstand a nearby explosion by a powerful warhead. **********The Soviet Union has developed land-based intercontinental missiles with very powerful multiple re-entry vehicles. In recent years the missiles have reportedly become accurate enough in theory to destroy most of the 1,052 operational United States ICBM silos. **********But Mr. Brown said the Russians ''do not have anything like strategic superiority in a useable sense.'' The two officials said they believed the United States had substantial superiority in submarines carrying nuclear missiles, strategic bombers and cruise missiles under development. **********''The United States has and will continue to have, in my judgment, sufficient surviving and deliverable weapons to destroy the urbanindustrial base of the Soviet Union - even after absorbing a Soviet strike,'' Mr. Schlesinger said. **********Mr. Schlesinger, who headed the Atomic Energy Commission and the Central Intelligence Agency under President Nixon and was Mr.  Carter's first Secretary of Energy, said ''such a capability is frequently considered the ultimate deterrent.'' **********''If the present discussions of superiority and inferiority are taken to suggest that the Soviet Union can deny the United States that capability, then the suggestion that the Soviet Union has superiority is invalid,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/06/busin.body_text: **********Many companies do not get as much time as they would like to plan for changes at the top. But Automatic Data Processing Inc., whose chairman and chief executive officer, Frank R. Lautenberg, was just elected United States Senator from New Jersey, had more than a year. **********Long before the Senate campaign began last winter, Mr. Lautenberg had picked Josh S. Weston, the president of A.D.P., as his successor at the Clifton, N.J., computer services company. Mr. Weston will assume the additional title of chief executive officer when Mr.  Lautenberg leaves for Washington in early January. **********In the last month, the long-sluggish price of A.D.P. stock rose 30 percent. Financial analysts say that if Mr. Weston, who is well liked in the investment community, can help see A.D.P. through its current troubles, most of them traceable to the recession, the company's future is bright. **********''Lautenberg did an excellent job at A.D.P.,'' said Sandra P.  Kraus, who follows the company for Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc.  ''But I have a lot of confidence in Weston, too. I have very positive feelings about the company these days.'' **********Mr. Weston does indeed have some problems to overcome. A.D.P. has had a comparatively tough year. The company, which offers computerized record-keeping services to companies that do not have their own computers, predicted that its earnings would rise 10 percent in the 1983 fiscal year, which ends June 30. That growth would be impressive for most companies. But during the last decade, profits at A.D.P. rose at an annual pace of at least 15 percent, far more in some years. **********A.D.P. earned $58 million on revenues of $669 million in the 1982 fiscal year. Its stock closed Friday at 35, down 1 3/8, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. **********The recession has hurt A.D.P., particularly its payroll-processing business, which represents a third of the company's revenues. The company processed 290 million paychecks last year. **********In an interview, Mr. Weston said many of the 80,000 companies using A.D.P. payroll services have reduced their staffs because of the economic downturn. ''Our average customer had 4 percent fewer employees'' in October than it did in the same month of 1981, he said. ''Since we get paid by the transaction, we get affected,'' he said. **********The recession also made difficult the start last year of a payroll system intended for companies with fewer than 20 workers. A.D.P.  estimated that the service, called Autopay 1, would have 15,000 clients by now. It fell 20 percent short of the goal, despite extensive advertising. 12 Years With Company **********Mr. Weston, 53 years old, joined A.D.P. in 1970 and became its president and chief operating officer seven years later. When Mr.  Lautenberg became more involved in New Jersey politics in the late 1970's, Mr. Weston assumed day-to-day command of the company. **********Starting next month, Mr. Weston will have control at A.D.P., even though some of his corporate duties will be shared with the company's newly named chairman, Henry Taub. Mr. Taub was chairman once before, from 1969 to 1977. (His brother, Joseph Taub, is president of the New Jersey Nets professional basketball team.) **********''Weston has run A.D.P. for a while now, and he's shown himself to be a tough manager,'' said David Wu, a technology analyst for Montgomery Securities, a San Francisco brokerage firm. Under Mr.  Weston, Mr. Wu said, ''A.D.P. has made very few mistakes.'' **********Ulric Weil, an analyst at Morgan Stanley & Company, said he expected changes at A.D.P. under its new chief executive. Mr. Weston, he said, might pursue a more conservative acquisitions policy than did Mr. Lautenberg. Between 1979 and 1982, A.D.P. bought 18 companies at an average cost of more than $3 million each. **********''Weston is very cost-conscious,'' Mr. Weil said, ''And in the future, I think, there will be a tougher assessment of profitability before an acquisition is made.'' **********Another challenge for A.D.P. will be sharpened competition in the data processing industry, especially after the creation of American Bell Inc., the new communications equipment subsidiary of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. **********But analysts say that if the recession does not worsen, A.D.P. will be in good shape to meet the new competition. And its traditional computer operations, which provide data processing for small- and medium-sized companies, should show steady growth, they say. Push Into High Technology **********Of more interest to many of the analysts, however, is A.D.P.'s recent push into high-technology, high-growth markets, including electronic banking. **********Last year A.D.P. began selling automatic teller systems - networks of computerized banking machines that offer customers 24-hour-a-day service - to small banks and savings and loan associations. **********More than $4 million will be spent in 1982 to expand the automatic teller division, ''which makes it our biggest single ongoing investment,'' Mr. Weston said. A.D.P.'s teller machines are installed in 20 states. **********So far A.D.P. has lost money on electronic banking ''and it won't break even on it for a year,'' said Mrs. Kraus of Lehman Brothers.  ''But I think it's going to be a very attractive market for the company.'' She said A.D.P. had indicated to analysts that its electronic banking business would bring in annual revenues of $50 million by 1987.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/03/busin.main_headline: AILING CANADIAN DOLLAR TOUCHES A RECORD LOW
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/03/busin.print_headline: AILING CANADIAN DOLLAR TOUCHES A RECORD LOW
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/03/busin.body_text: **********For the second consecutive day, the Canadian dollar fell to an all-time low against its United States counterpart before support measures by the Bank of Canada brought a modest recovery. **********The Canadian currency closed today at 80.37 cents American, up from Tuesday's close of 80.06. But in a morning of heavy speculative pressure, it dipped to as low as 79.92 cents, beneath the previous low of 80.08 set in the Depression year of 1931. **********Today's rise, which began around noon, was attributed to heavy market intervention by the Bank of Canada and to the expectation that the bank would increase its trend-setting interest rate on Thursday, possibly by as much as a half point, to 17.5 percent. **********High interest rates act to strengthen a currency by increasing the yields on investments made in that currency. But they also have contributed to the current recession in Canada and abroad by increasing the cost of consumer credit and of corporate borrowing for capital investment. **********Analysts said the Canadian dollar's latest slump was less the result of new factors than a reflection of the strengthening American dollar and renewed attention to the continuing weaknesses of the Canadian economy. **********The currency has been weakened by the recession, by large government budget deficits, by a balance of payments deficit and by the appeal of even higher interest rates available abroad. It also has been hurt by a growing fear of nationalist Canadian economic policies that restrict foreign investment, especially in oil and gas. **********Recent buy-outs of some foreign holdings in Canadian energy concerns have also dumped large sums of Canadian dollars on exchange markets, further weakening the currency. **********Many experts expect the dollar to fall to 78 cents in the months ahead, with a few even forecasting a 75-cent level in the absence of decisive government steps to reverse the trend. Domestic Political Issue **********With unemployment currently exceeding 9 percent and the annual rate of inflation still over 11 percent, the stagnant Canadian economy has become a hot domestic political issue. Finance Minister Allan MacEachen in the past has mentioned that the Government might be willing to reassess its economic policies in July if conditions did not improve by then. **********''These situations are quite often transitory,'' he told reporters today, noting that last August the dollar fell from 83 cents to nearly 80 cents, and rose again to 83. **********Mr. MacEachen, who today rejected opposition party demands that he order the Bank of Canada to lower the official bank rate, also announced that the Government was trying to raise $750 million on the European bond market to bolster the country's official currency reserves. Currency Reserves in Decline **********The reserves fell by $651 million last month. Most of the total, along with some of a $300 million line of credit with Canadian chartered banks, was spent buying unwanted Canadian dollars to support the currency. **********A key problem is the country's current account deficit. Although Canada has enjoyed a substantial trade surplus of about $11 billion a year in recent years, demand has been softening among most of its major trading partners. **********At the same time, the flow of interest and dividend payments out of the country to foreign investors and banks has been climbing. It may reach $18 billion this year, leaving Canada with at least a $7 billion deficit in its current account. **********The Liberal Government of Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau has shown little inclination to moderate its spending policies, which are expected to create a $13 billion budget deficit this year. **********The Trudeau Government has denied frequent rumors that it is considering devaluing the dollar or imposing foreign exchange controls. Such steps were taken by Canada in World War II and during the Korean War. They were later lifted and a free-floating Canadian dollar was worth $1.0552 in American funds in October 1959. As late as 1974 it stood at $1.0394.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/12/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Former I.B.M. Official Is Genigraphics Chief
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/12/busin.body_text: **********Flavil Q. Van Dyke, who has spent his career until now at the International Business Machines Corporation, has thrown in his lot with a smaller company that has just gone on its own. **********Mr. Van Dyke, 42, has been named president and chief executive of Genigraphics Inc. He has spent 17 years at I.B.M. in a range of sales, products and marketing jobs, most recently as corporate director of management development at I.B.M. headquarters. **********Genigraphics, which is based in Syracuse, had been a unit of the General Electric Company until this summer, when its management and two venture capital firms, J.H. Whitney & Company and Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stowe, purchased it for an undisclosed sum. **********Genigraphics sells slides for annual meetings and other business meetings and provides artistic help with the graphics. It also sells complete computerized slide systems to larger companies at a cost of some $350,000. The company, which has sales of about $40 million, employs 400 and operates 20 service centers. **********At I.B.M., Mr. Van Dyke served in such positions as vice president of product marketing and vice president of sales support in the office products division. He is a graduate of Brown University. **********''I am every bit a fan of I.B.M. as I was three months ago, or 17 years ago,'' Mr. Van Dyke said. ''In my opinion, it's just an exemplary company.'' What tempted him at Genigraphics, he said, was the ''competence'' of the venture capitalists, the fact that the company was not a fledgling operation and ''the considerable opportunities in terms of the future.'' Daniel F. Cuff

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/17/world.print_headline: MAN IN THE NEWS; FRIEND OF THE FALKLANDERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/17/world.body_text: **********When Rex Masterman Hunt, the British Governor of the Falkland Islands, surrendered them to the invading Argentines last April, he made this defiant declaration, as he and his wife boarded the plane at the Stanley Airport: ''We'll be back.'' **********Now, triumphantly, Mr. Hunt is making good on his promise, going back - probably within days - to an island territory that is once again in British hands, and he is ''absolutely delighted.'' **********A 55-year-old career diplomat who has spent most of his time in British embassies and consulates in Asia, Mr. Hunt has received a good deal of praise for his conduct during the Falkland crisis.  People here were very pleased to read, for example, that after his surrender, to an overwhelming force, Mr. Hunt refused to shake hands with the Argentine commanding general. **********''I do not shake hands with an invader of British territory,'' he told the general. The Argentine said that it seemed ungentlemanly behavior, to which Mr. Hunt replied, ''I think it very uncivilized to invade our country.'' 'Don't Lose Heart' **********During the two and a half months that followed, Mr. Hunt has remained in Britain, his role somewhat ambiguous and his future uncertain. In general, he avoided public attention, though he did make an occasional attempt to raise morale back in the Falklands. For example, in an Easter message broadcast by the World Service of the BBC, he said: ''Don't lose heart. I'm looking forward to coming back soon.'' **********At one point in Britain's negotiations with Argentina, it seemed that his job, with its colonial connotations, might be eliminated as a concession to the Argentines. But no one in the British Government is talking about conceding anything to the Argentines any more, and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, announcing on Tuesday that Mr. Hunt would be going back to the Falklands, said that he would be ''in effect'' a kind of civil commissioner, working in concert with Maj.  Gen. Jeremy Moore, who commands the British military force there. **********While the Prime Minister was speaking in the House of Commons, paying tribute to the British servicemen who had died ''that others may live in freedom and justice,'' Mr. Hunt was listening from the gallery. And the tears that he occasionally wiped from his eyes were a reminder of the close ties that have built up between the Governor and his island territory in the two years that he has served there. **********''He is the most popular governor we have had in years and years,'' said a longtime resident of the Falklands, who is in London.  ''Well before this crisis started, Rex Hunt was known as a man who really had the islanders' interest at heart.'' A Former R.A.F. Pilot **********An affable, gregarious man with the blunt, direct manner often associated with his native Yorkshire, Mr. Hunt likes to drive himself in a Land-Rover across the marshy Falkland countryside. For longer trips, he flew his own Cessna Skyhawk, using skills learned as a Royal Air Force pilot in the closing days of World War II, when he was still a teen-ager. (He thinks the plane was destroyed during the war.) **********He and his wife, the former Mavis Buckland, often entertain in Government House, their roomy, green-roofed residence on the west side of Stanley, on the waterfront, and their 20-year old daughter and 18-year-old son, on visits from England, are also well known to the 1,800 islanders. **********''Rex is the kind of unpretentious chap who, instead of telling someone else to do something, will pull on his Wellington boots and march across the bogs to do it himself,'' a friend from the Falklands said. **********In an interview with a British newspaper early in the confrontation, Mr. Hunt said that he would like to be aboard one of the ships in the naval task force, so as ''to be with them when they land'' in the Falklands. **********But he also attaches importance to the ceremonial side of his job.  For formal occasions, he rides around Stanley in the official governor's car, a maroon London taxicab with the Union Jack flying on the front fender. And for his expulsion by the Argentines, he insisted on wearing the full regalia of his office, which includes a sword and a hat with ostrich plumes. In Saigon at the Fall **********In response to a question, he said Tuesday that he is taking these symbols of the Falklands' colonial status back to Stanley with him.  But it was a reflection of the ambiguous nature of his new status that he added, in reference to the plumed hat, ''I will wear it if I am authorized to wear it.'' **********Mr. Hunt, who has a degree from Cambridge University, joined the overseas civil service in 1951, and served a long tour in Uganda, retiring from there as a district commissioner in 1963. He then joined the diplomatic corps, in which his posts have included Indonesia, Malaysia and Vietnam. **********He was in Saigon at the time of its fall in 1975 and was evacuated to Singapore, an experience that he said was ''very similar'' to his departure from the Falklands last April. **********Today, he said that he was all packed to return to Stanley, and would be going as soon as the Defense Ministry could arrange it. And he said there would soon be other arrivals on the islands. Six hundred people have applied to settle in the Falklands - not only from Britain, but also from Australia, New Zealand and Canada. **********''They say they want a new life helping to rebuild the islands,'' Mr. Hunt declared, saying that skilled immigrants would be very welcome. ''The Falklands have a very bright future indeed.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/30/world.main_headline: TALKS ON FATE OF THE P.L.O. ARE SAID TO BE DEADLOCKED
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/30/world.print_headline: TALKS ON FATE OF THE P.L.O. ARE SAID TO BE DEADLOCKED
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/30/world.body_text: **********Official Lebanese sources said today that the American special envoy, Philip C. Habib, told a European Ambassador that, although the Palestine Liberation Organization had accepted the principle of neutralizing its military presence in Lebanon and transferring its leadership elsewhere, ''there is a total block on how and when this should be done.'' **********Palestinian officials said the P.L.O. was negotiating in good faith and recognized the predicament that it was in. But the officials said the guerrilla group was also ''playing for time.'' **********The organization's leader, Yasir Arafat, still appears to be hoping that pressure on the United States from Saudi Arabia, as well as pressure on Israel from the European Economic Community, the United States and domestic critics may avert an Israei assault on west Beirut, where 6,000 to 7,000 guerrillas are trapped. **********The Threat of an Assault **********Once the threat of an Israeli assault is removed, Palestinian officials said, the P.L.O. leadership will be better able to negotiate the details of their disarmament and future presence in Lebanon. **********But today's events seem to indicate that time is not on the side of the P.L.O.  Senior Lebanese security sources said the Israelis had moved troops trained in street fighting into the hills around Beirut. The troops were said to be backed by a large number of small, Israeli-made Merkava tanks, which are more suitable for urban warfare than the large American-made M-60's also used by Israel. **********The P.L.O.'s Moslem leftist allies are openly calling for the surrender of the guerrillas.  Nabih Berri, leader of the Shiite Moslems in Lebanon, whose militiamen fought alongside the P.L.O. in southern Lebanon, said today that the battle was lost. ''The P.L.O. has to accept the terms of the victor,'' he said. ''The sooner the Palestinians do that the better.'' 'A Very Sensitive Stage' **********This evening, former Prime Minister Saeb Salam, the principal intermediary between Mr. Habib and Mr. Arafat, declined for the first time to discuss the details of the negotiations. **********Although he did not rule out the possibility of a breakthrough, he said, ''The talks have entered a very sensitive stage and I do not want to say anything that might upset them.'' **********On Monday, Mr. Habib was given the P.L.O.'s proposals for the future presence of the guerrilla group in Lebanon. He relayed them to the Israelis, who reportedly rejected them as ''absurd.'' **********Mr. Habib, in a meeting today with Prime Minister Shafik al-Wazzan and Foreign Minister Fuad Butros, offered a new set of American questions for the P.L.O. The guerrilla group's answer to them may determine whether the talks continue. Dispute on Disarmament **********Lebanese Government sources familiar with the negotiations said the P.L.O. had accepted the fact that it must neutralize its military and political presence in Lebanon. But they said the guerrillas' idea of how that should be done was totally inconsistent with both the Lebanese and American positions. **********The United States and Lebanon have called for full disarmament of the P.L.O., total Palestinian subservience to the Lebanese authorities and the removal of the guerrilla leadership from Lebanon as soon as possible. **********The P.L.O. Executive Committee met this evening and reaffired its unanimous intention to hold out for a ''symbolic'' military presence under Lebanese Army control as well as an honorable departure for P.L.O. fighters ''if and when they leave Lebanon.'' **********Palestinian and Lebanese Government sources outlined the major points in dispute in the negotiations. 'Absolutely No Way' **********The P.L.O. wants two brigades of the Palestine Liberation Army to be put under the command of the Lebanese Army, similar to the guerrilla group's status in Jordan, Egypt and Syria. A senior Lebanese defense official said there was ''absolutely no way the Lebanese Government would accept this.'' **********The Palestinians want between 50 and 75 of their own policemen to be permitted to carry arms and control security within the refugee camps. This demand has also been rejected by the Lebanese. **********The Palestinians want United Nations guarantees that if the P.L.O.  leadership leaves the country the 600,000 Palestinian civilians remaining will not be subjected to Lebanese or Israeli harassment. **********The Lebanese Government is willing to negotiate these assurances, but it is insisting that all the guerrilla fighters who entered Lebanon illegally, particularly after 1970, must leave. In addition, all the Palestinians who remain will once again be under the Department of Refugee Affairs and will not be permitted any extraterritorial previleges. A Diplomatic Mission **********The guerrillas also want the Lebanese Government to reaffirm that the P.L.O. is the sole representative of the Palestinian people and that the guerrillas will be allowed to maintain a mission here with full diplomatic status. In addition, P.L.O. leaders would be permitted to travel in and out of Lebanon after they leave. The Lebanese Government stand on these demands is not yet clear. **********The Palestinians are insisting that any disarmament should be gradual, beginning with the deposit of heavy weapons at a specific location guarded by the Lebanese Army. The Lebanese Army would eventually deploy troops in all refugee camps in west Beirut. If any P.L.O. fighters chose to leave, they would be able to take their weapons with them. **********The Lebanese Government is divided on the issue of arms. The Moslem Cabinet ministers are willing to be flexible about disarmament, but President Elias Sarkis and the Christian Ministers want an immediate and total disarmament. **********The P.L.O. is also demanding American and Soviet guarantees for the safety of any guerrillas who leave Lebanon. And it is insisting that any withdrawal must be with dignity. **********The Moslem ministers are flexible on this point, but the Christians want to get the P.L.O. out of the country any way that they can.Finally, the P.L.O. is unwilling to approve the details of the agreement until the cease-fire is consolidated.  ''We will not negotiate with a gun to our heads,'' said a Palestinian official with knowledge of the meeting. ''If our backs are pushed up against the wall, we will fight before accepting Israeli or Lebanese surrender terms.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/12/busin.main_headline: Commodities; Big Growth In Assets Of Funds
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/12/busin.print_headline: Commodities; Big Growth In Assets Of Funds
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/12/busin.body_text: **********COMMODITY futures speculators need not be reminded that the first half of 1982 was an expensive time for most of them because they continued to favor the long - or buy -side of the markets during a period that witnessed large price declines in almost all commodities. **********One measure of the price decline was the Commodity Research Bureau's index of futures prices, which fell to 244.9 from 254.9 (1967 equals 100) in the first half. Last Friday, the futures index closed at 240.5, up from 239.1 on the week, but down from 272.7 a year ago. **********All this was academic, if not amusing, to the small but growing number of investors in commodity funds, almost all of which registered extraordinary gains in assets. Indeed, the gains surpassed those of practically every other investment medium in the first half. **********''Of the 40 commodity funds we monitor, 38 posted gains in assets, quite large gains in fact, while the only losses were of 1.5 and 4.6 percent,'' said Jay Klopfenstein, president of Norwood Securities Inc., a Chicago securities brokerage house that is not involved in commodity futures or funds. **********''We began to look at these funds as part of our research work a few years ago and since then have only followed those that provide us with full disclosure of their operations,'' he said in a telephone interview last week. **********As shown by Mr. Klopfenstein's latest monthly report, which covers the first half and last month's results, the gains for both periods have been ''spectacular, but by no means unusual.'' The reason, he went on, was that the funds, also known as commodity pools, rely on two basic systems that are generally unavailable to the average individual trader. **********One is the extensive use of computers to forecast commodity futures price trends. The other is the willingness to sell short, when the computer signals this course of action. ''Obviously, the pool managers were heavily short during the price decline of the first half,'' Mr. Klopfenstein noted. Most individual speculators are fearful of being short: that is, promising to deliver something they don't own. **********Whether this fear of selling short is a carryover from the futures speculators' earlier trading pattern in securities, as many brokers hold, or some other reason, it has long been a factor that commercial hedgers, who are generally short the market, depend upon to assume the price risks the hedgers seek to avoid. **********But there is no doubt about the reasons for the growing popularity of the commodity funds with small investors in the few years since most of them were organized. These operations were discussed by Alan J. Sarnoff, vice president of the Eastern Capital Corporation, which has underwritten several of these funds, in an interview last week. **********''The typical fund consists of between 5,000 and 15,000 shares that are offered to the public by brokerage houses or other underwriters at $1,000 each, plus a one-time commission, usually of $50 to $70 per share. Once the shares are sold, a professional management team then takes over and runs it. The managers receive their income from flat fees charged each month as well as incentive fees based on the fund's performance, which is usually reported to shareholders each month.'' **********Mr. Sarnoff pointed out that hardly any fund invests all its capital in the futures market at any given time; many keep about half in Treasury bills as a reserve. What about losses? **********''The way most funds have been set up recently, all the investor can lose is half the investment because the funds self-liquidate when the assets reach 50 percent of the original offering price,'' he continued, ''at which time the remaining money is disbursed to the shareholders, who can then recover a portion of their loss as a tax deduction. Some funds disburse part of their gains periodically as dividends; others reinvest all profits.'' **********Shareholders can withdraw their money, usually on 30 days' notice, at certain specified times or at any time. ''By law these conditions are spelled out in the prospectus and investors should read them carefully before investing,'' he cautioned. **********While commodity trading in any form is still considered far from prudent by people accustomed to more traditional investments such as stocks and bonds, the performance of most of the funds, in which nearly $500 million has been invested thus far, has led many to chose them for their Individual Retirement Accounts since the law covering such instruments was liberalized last year. **********The first and thus far the only futures fund specifically for I.R.A. investments was organized by Mr. Sarnoff's company this year as Boston Futures Fund III. It was sold out and began operating last June 3. Funds I and II have been operating as regular funds for several years. **********Because a limit of $2,000 a year has been set on individual investments in I.R.A. accounts, that is the minimum accepted by Boston Futures Fund III. The same minimum is now being accepted by Mr. Sarnoff's fourth fund, also aimed at I.R.A. investments, and others are being preparing for 1983 and subsequent years. **********''Of course, there is no guarantee that any fund will produce gains year after year, but in the 'worst case' scenario all the investor can lose in an I.R.A. commodity fund is half the initial investment, $1,000 plus commission, and write the other half off as a tax deduction,'' Mr. Sarnoff added.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/27/busin.body_text: **********Bankeno Mines Ltd., a dormant shell corporation controlled by Turbo Resources Ltd., a Canadian oil and gas producer, said today that it had offered to acquire all outstanding shares of Merland Explorations Ltd. of Calgary in a deal valued at about $260.6 million (United States). **********Turbo, an energy exploration and production concern that already owns a 50 percent stake in Merland, said Bankeno's share-and-warrant offer would equal or exceed the $13.30 (Canadian) a share that Turbo paid for its Merland stake last summer. **********Robert Dixon, president of Merland, said in an interview here today that the offer was ''a bunch of scrap paper'' and predicted that it ''will end up in court'' because of anticipated opposition from minority shareholders. **********If successful, the net result of the transaction would be to transfer the bulk of both Turbo's and Merland's assets to Bankeno.  Turbo's oil and gas assets, valued at $93.4 million (Canadian), would be e xchanged for 9.3 million common sha res of Bankeno. Turbo would then hold about a 60 percent of the res tructured Bankeno. **********Bankeno would have instant assets worth about $526 million (Canadian), comprising about 800 million barrels of proved and probable crude oil reserves and 46.8 billion cubic feet of natural gas. **********Bankeno's land inventory would encompass about 700,000 gross acres in western Canada, plus 772,000 net acres along the western Overthrust Belt in the United States. **********The company said the offer is not being made to Merland's United States shareholders.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/23/busin.body_text: **********The Marquette National Bank of Minneapolis, in the nation's first merger between a commercial bank and a thrift institution, announced yesterday that it had acquired the ailing Farmers and Mechanics Savings Bank of Minneapolis. The move will create the fourth-largest commercial bank in the city, with deposits of more than $1.1 billion. **********The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which helped arrange the merger, said Marquette had won Farmers, the state's only savings bank, in a bidding contest with three other Minnesota banks and nine from other states. **********If a bank fails, the F.D.I.C. must pay off the insurance on all the bank's deposits. To avoid that costly process, the F.D.I.C. looks for other banks to bid for the failing bank. If a sale or merger occurs, the F.D.I.C. generally accepts the bid that permits the Government agency to accomplish the venture at the lowest cost. New Legislation Helped **********In Minneapolis, Michael J. Pint, Minnesota's Banking Commissioner, noted that about three weeks ago, in a measure tailor-made for Farmers, legislation was enacted to allow an out-of-state bank holding company to acquire a savings banks in Minnesota. The measure permitted the bidding to be extended to out-of-state banks. Mr. Pint said that the presence of out-of-state banks ''made the bidding more competitive and less expensive for the F.D.I.C.'' **********Carl R. Pohlad, president of Marquette and of the newly named F.  and M. Marquette National Bank, said in an interview that the savings bank's assets were ''sound,'' and that there were ''no big losses'' but that there was ''a question of liquidity,'' with low-interest home mortgages that could not be sold without losses. **********Farmers had been in financial difficulty for a year or more. It ended 1981 with deposits of $825 million and a net worth of $41 million. F.D.I.C. Puts Up $30 Million **********He explained that in the past, when bidding for such an institution, banks would make their offers, after which the F.D.I.C.'s involvement was ended. In this instance, as part of the arrangement for Marquette's rescue of Farmers, he said, the F.D.I.C.  would put up $30 million in capital, pay the difference between the bank's cost of funds and the value of the assets it acquired, but also share later in any profits on the assets acquired. **********The nation's more than 5,000 savings and loan associations and savings banks have been losing money because high interest rates have forced them to pay more for funds than they earn from their mortgage portfolios and long-term bonds.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/04/world.main_headline: ISRAELI AMBASSADOR WOUNDED IN LONDON SHOOTING
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/04/world.print_headline: ISRAELI AMBASSADOR WOUNDED IN LONDON SHOOTING
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/04/world.body_text: **********The Israeli Ambassador to Britain was shot and critically wounded Thursday night as he left a party at a luxury hotel. **********The envoy, Shlomo Argov, 52 years old, was hit at least three times shortly after 11 P.M. after walking out of the Dorchester Hotel, where he had been attending a dinner in honor of diplomats. **********Mr. Argov underwent a two-and-a-half-hour operation at the National Hospital for Nervous Diseases early today. A hospital spokesman said the Ambassador was in critical condition with a bullet wound in the head. **********According to reports from the hotel, as Mr. Argov left the party and walked a few yards along Park Lane, a man who had been loitering at a nearby automobile showroom jumped forward. Shots were heard and the Ambassador fell to the ground. **********''He was slumped on the floor just by his car,'' said Moses Hayes, a Tonga Embassy driver waiting near the hotel entrance. ''He was shot outside just by his car.'' **********The attacker ran off, pursued by a member of the Metropolitan Police Diplomatic Protection Group who was guarding Mr. Argov. Shots were heard from around the corner, in South Street, and the man thought to be the attacker fell to the pavement. He, too, was taken to the hospital, where he was said to have a bullet wound in his head. **********''The assailant is now under guard in the intensive care unit in hospital but is expected to live,'' a Scotland Yard spokesman said.  Robert Maxwell, a British publisher, who was only yards away from Mr. Argov when he was shot, said later, ''There was a loud burst of shots just as the Ambassador was coming out of the hotel.'' **********He said shots had been fired from a submachine gun held by an assailant of Arab appearance. According to Mr. Hayes's description, the man was about 5 feet 6 inches tall and was carrying a pack on his shoulder. **********''The attack was all so fleeting,'' Mr. Maxwell said. ''It has left me shocked and disgusted.'' A Scotland Yard spokesman said a car fitting the description of a vehicle seen waiting near the Dorchester had been stopped in Brixton, across the Thames River in South London, and two men had been detained. The spokesman said a weapon had been seized. **********Israeli and British officials declined to speculate on the identity or background of the assailant or assailants, but they evidently believed that the attack had been politically motivated. Earlier Attacks on Israelis **********It was the fourth recent such incident against Israeli diplomats, but the first in Britain. On April 3, Yacov Barsimantov, an official of Israeli Embassy in Paris, was fatally shot by a young woman in his apartment. Three days earlier, attackers sprayed the offices of the Israeli military attache in Paris with machine-gun fire. **********Although a shadowy Beirut-based group called the Lebanese Revolutionary Armed Faction claimed responsibility, Israel accused the Palestine Liberation Organization in the two attacks. Just before that, there had been an attack on Israeli officials in Vienna. **********The Barsimantov shooting was discussed by the Israeli Cabinet, which later said it would regard attacks on officials anywhere as a breach of the cease-fire between Israel and the P.L.O. in southern Lebanon. Area Is Sealed Off **********After the attack here, the police sealed off the area along Park Lane, which borders on Hyde Park. By the gutter, a few yards from the hotel entrance, a policeman stood guard under the glare of floodlights that illuminated a section of blood-spattered pavement and a pile of white, blood-soaked rags. **********Members of the Board of Deputies of British Jews gathered at the home of Martin Savitt, vice president of the board, to await news of the Ambassador's condition. Mr. Argov, who has represented Israel here since September 1979, is a respected and well-liked diplomat on his second tour here. **********He had studied political science at Georgetown University in Washington, where he was awarded a bachelor's degree, and international relations at the London School of Economics, where he received a master's degree. **********Mr. Argov served in the army from 1947 to 1950 and began his Government career in 1955 in the Prime Minister's Office. Since then, he has served in Lagos, Nigeria; Accra, Ghana; New York, Washington, Mexico City and, just before his arrival here, as Ambassador to the Netherlands. **********He is married, with a son and two grown daughters who live in Israel.
