https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/08/busin.print_headline: BUDGET OFFICE ACCEPTS TIGHTENED BANK RULES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/08/busin.body_text: **********The Office of Management and Budget agreed today to accept a proposal by Federal bank regulators that would require commercial banks to disclose more detailed information about bad loans and the banks' financial condition. **********William M. Issac, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said his agency and the budget office had reached a compromise on the disclosure dispute: The budget office, backing away from an earlier plan to veto the rules, will now withhold the veto in return for an agreement by the bank regulators to delay putting the new rules into effect for three months. **********The new reporting requirements were issued last month by the interagency Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council, a panel of bank regulators that has been seeking since June to expand bankreporting requirements. The agencies redoubled their efforts to toughen disclosure rules following the collapse of the Penn Square Bank in Oklahoma. **********Many banks have opposed the tighter reporting requirements, especially a provision that the regulators make most of the new data available to the public. **********''We're concerned that some of that stuff could be subject to misinterpretation,'' said Fritz Elmendorf, a spokesman for the American Bankers Association, the trade group representing most of the nation's commercial banks. ''In an extreme case, it could precipitate runs or a large amount of withdrawals if a bank appeared to have some bad loans on its books.'' **********Mr. Issac, in an interview following today's F.D.I.C. board meeting, said: ''It may be that some people who aren't running their banks properly will be embarrassed by this information, but it seems to me that's the way it should be. If people are running their banks properly, disclosure shouldn't bother them at all.'' **********The interagency examination council includes representatives from the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, the National Credit Union Administration, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the Federal Reserve System and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, although only the last three are directly affected by the new bank reporting requirements. Meeting Planned **********In response to industry requests, the council agreed today to meet with a group set up by the American Bankers Association to consider some of the concerns expressed about the new disclosure requirements. **********Christopher De Muth, administrator for information and regulatory affairs at the budget office, said: ''There's no furious interagency conflict going on. It's just that on this one matter, we thought the council was unnecessarily precipitate, and a little more time was advisable.'' **********Mr. De Muth added, however, that other agencies would be expected to justify on a regular basis their need for the data.  The budget office, under the 1980 Paperwork Reduction Act, reviews regulatory decisions for cost and reporting burdens. In a letter last week explaining his disapproval, Mr. De Muth cited several reasons, including the council's delay in issuing the regulations until a few days before the comment period had closed; concern that the new requirements might aggravate the reporting requirements on the banks, and the fear of possible ''misinterpretation and misuse'' of public information. **********The new disclosure forms, as planned by the regulators, involve two phases. The first was to have become effective for the quarter ending Sept. 30, but has been delayed for three months. In that phase, all commercial banks will be required to file quarterly reports about past-due loans, interest rate sensitivity, contingent liaibilites and other off-balance-sheet items. Beginning with the quarter ending June 30, 1983, these reports will be made available immediately to the public. **********The second phase, which the council has decided to delay until March 1984, also calls for a more extensive listing of balance-sheet assets and liablilties, statements of income and expenses and supporting schedules. Today's action will not affect this phase.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/12/busin.body_text: **********Short- and long-term interest rates rose yesterday as securities dealers tried to reduce their inventories in advance of the Federal Reserve's money supply announcement today. **********By late in the day, some short-term rates had increased more than a quarter percentage point, while in the long-term market, the 14 percent Treasury bonds due 2011 fell more than a point, to 102 3/8, raising its yield to 13.66 percent from 13.49 percent. **********Anthony Hanlon, president of the Discount Corporation of New York, a government securities dealer, said that prices declined yesterday because ''dealers have been paring their inventories.'' He noted that projections for today's money supply number ''have been gradually raised to an increase of two to five billion.'' **********Traders worry that an increase in money supply would be accompanied by stable or perhaps higher interest rates because it would keep the money supply well above the Fed's target level. With money supply above target, the Fed would tend to make bank reserves less available, rather than more plentiful, thereby pushing up interest rates. **********Not all analysts expect the money supply to increase. At Money Market Services Inc., economists said that the $5.8 billion drop in the basic money supply in the last six weeks ''shows a weak trend'' that they do not expect to be significantly interrupted by today's data. **********Although high interest rates are a burden to government and corporate borrowers, they are a boon to those who have cash available for investment. **********The State of Alabama, for example, is using its $449 million windfall from offshore oil leases sold two years ago to fund the newly authorized Alabama Heritage Trust Fund. By the end of this month or early in April, the fund is expected to transfer money out of local banks to buy about $500 million of long-term Treasury notes and bonds, or perhaps agency securities. **********The fund was approved by voters March 2, and, according to state officials, its principal will be untouchable, although interest payments will flow to the state's general fund. **********A simple yield of 13 percent on a $500 million investment - a yield that could easily be arranged under current market conditions - would earn $65 million a year for the state budget. According to officials at Kidder, Peabody & Company who are working with Alabama officials, the purchases may be arranged directly with institutions that would like to sell securities, as well as through the secondary market. **********''The state had an asset in these offshore properties that was noninterest-earning, but which is now interest-earning,'' said Lane Genatowski, vice president at Kidder, Peabody. He said the investments would be in fixed-income securities to provide a predictable flow of money to the state budget. **********With the additional income from the trust fund, plus royalties and other revenues that will accompany the start of oil and gas production, state officials also obtained voter approval for a huge new issue of general obligation bonds totaling as much as $520 million. **********In the corporate market, securities dealers continued to bring new issues to market, although prices have slumped for some issues sold earlier in the week. Investment bankers said that the increased supply in the corporate market, where more than $1.5 billion of new issues were sold this week, compared with $2 billion during all of January and February, has been great enough to help reduce prices and raise interest rates.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/25/world.main_headline: AT PRISON, POLES AWAIT RELEASE OF KIN
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/25/world.print_headline: AT PRISON, POLES AWAIT RELEASE OF KIN
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/25/world.body_text: **********A small knot of people sat on a bench by the guardhouse outside Bialoleka prison today, waiting to see whether their husbands and sons would be released. **********From time to time the gray metal door in the prison wall opened, and they would freeze with attention. Sixteen martial law internees had walked out this morning, some into the arms of waiting relatives, some to walk alone to the bus stop 200 yards away. A few stayed behind to see whether their friends would be released. **********One middle-aged woman, dressed in white, had been coming every day since Wednesday. Her husband had been in Bialoleka, southeast of Warsaw, for 221 days. Most of those destined for release had already walked out and she was becoming apprehensive that her husband was among the 637 destined to remain interned. No Advance Notice of Release **********Prison guards offered no help, nor did the Interior Ministry. The internees were not being told in advance of their release, and simply emerged in knots, dazed and surprised, without any idea as to how many others would follow. **********''When they come out and learn how things are,'' one of the women on the bench said, ''some find they were freer inside than out. Some have gone back to their factory to learn they have no job, and their friends are sometimes wary of being too close to them.'' **********The scene in the driveway outside Bialoleka was probably being repeated at detention centers across Poland following Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski's announcement Thursday that 1,227 people interned at the time of the imposition of martial law Dec. 13 would be freed. **********Two days after his announcement, it became clear that he had not meant the immediate release of those 1,227, but a process that had begun several weeks earlier and would continue for an unknown time more. Dissident's Son Is Freed **********Among those released from Bialoleka was Maciej Kuron, the 22-yearold son of Jacek Kuron, the prominent dissident. He was playing table tennis when a prison officer told him he was leaving.  Within 30 minutes he was out. **********A bear of a man with short hair, long beard and a ready smile, Maciej Kuron seemed unmarked by his seven months in detention, and he said he looked forward to returning to Warsaw University in the fall. His father remains in Bialoleka, where the son saw him only three times in seven months. His mother is hospitalized with tuberculosis she contracted while in detention. **********''There were about 300 detainees in Bialoleka at one time, although by the time I was released only 80 had been there, like me, from Dec. 13,'' Mr. Kuron recounted. **********''Morale was good. We agreed from the outset not to allow any interrogations, and nobody did. It was worst at the beginning when they interned whole families, placing children in foster homes. I was in a cell with a person whose wife died and he had been taking care of his child. **********''The police took the child to a foster home. I was told the child had a terrible shock and is now partly paralyzed, and the father talked about nothing else.'' **********Mr. Kuron said people desperately eager to get out to rejoin children were offered statements of loyalty to sign. Few Signed Loyalty Statement **********Those who did found that they were soon asked to sign another statement, pledging cooperation with the authorities, before they would be released. He said only about 5 percent of the internees at Bialoleka had signed the loyalty statements, and reports from other detention centers gave similar figures. **********Like other detainees, Mr. Kuron reported little direct mistreatment. He recalled only one incident in his seven months in detention. On May 13, the security police ''undressed people with their boots,'' ordering prisoners to undress while they kicked them after the detainees began singing defiant hymns. **********The meager prison food was regularly augmented by generous parcels from relatives and the Red Cross. But facilities were cramped and primitive, and after an inspection on July 5, the International Committee for the Red Cross declared conditions at Bialoleka worse than at any other camp. **********The detainess at Bialoleka were forbidden to hold seminars or meetings. But Mr. Kuron described an elaborate information system that included radio receivers, regular information on the Solidarity underground outside, and even internal news bulletins passed from hand to hand. Solidarity Leaders Isolated **********But if the rank-and-file detainees enjoyed a limited amount of contact, Mr. Kuron's father and the members of Solidarity's National Commission, who were held under rigid isolation, did not. **********These men were held in a prison cell block where they could gather only two at a time and where meetings with outsiders were rarely allowed. **********Mr. Kuron said the authorities made only a half-hearted effort to indocrinate detainees. In the beginning, a lecturer was brought in to discuss the economic situation, but the response was so negative that there were no further lectures. **********Mr. Kuron also reported only limited receptivity to the Government's offer of emigration visas for any Solidarity leaders who wanted them. Of those at Bialoleka, he said, only 10 or 15 of the 500 or so internees who passed through while he was there agreed to emigrate, and none were well known. **********Western embassies expect the interest in emigration visas to grow if released detainees begin having difficulties finding jobs. General Jaruzelski's announcement that Poles outside Poland would be allowed to return freely was expected to further enhance the appeal of emigration.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/05/busin.body_text: **********To the Business Editor: ''Our national discussion of poverty is superficial,'' wrote Professor Bergmann. As her discussion of poverty proceeded, she proved her point. **********She dismissed the case for income guarantees that would let unemployed and underemployed people lead ''modestly comfortable'' lives with this sweeping statement: ''Such a system would make sense only for the aged and the highly disabled. However, if applied universally, it would increase the number of free-loaders beyond bounds.'' That conclusion is not only superficial, but empirical studies have indicated that it is false. **********It's discouraging that such myths are still repeated by economists who have honest intentions, now that the Federal Government has sponsored four income maintenance experiments, designed and operated by economists, specifically to test labor supply response to unconditional income guarantees more generous than those provided by existing welfare programs. **********The experiments began in 1968 with the New Jersey Graduated Work Incentive Experiment. Since several three- and five-year samples have been concluded, most recently those in Seattle and Denver, analysis of the labor supply results has appeared so frequently in economic journals that economists, at least, should be aware that the work reductions of able-bodied adults supporting families are most certainly not ''beyond bounds,'' even in response to an income guarantee at 135 percent of the poverty line. **********The percentage reductions in hours of work of prime age males, as measured against control samples not eligible for those income guarantees, have fallen in the range 1 percent to 8 percent. Those empirically quantified work reduction averages are typically characterized as ''moderate.'' **********From 1968 through 1980, the four experiments cost taxpayers about $30 million in benefit payments and $80 million in administration, data collection, and research costs. Analysis of the data has advanced standards of econometric sophistication. Methodologies developed in the experiments have been adopted by economists investigating quite a few other topics. **********Because so much expertise and money has been spent on the income guarantee experiments, attention and respect should be paid to the evidence they offer about the labor supply, as attention and respect has been paid to the statistical techniques that produced that evidence.  KATE LUXEMBURG School of Public and Urban Policy University of Pennsylvania Philadelphia, Aug.28, 1982

The patented formula contains acrylic acids and disulfides, as well as related salts.Electromagnetic Device Purifies Water Supplies **********A Miami manufacturer of electromagnetic water purifiers was granted a patent this week for one that he plans to sell directly to farmers to purify surface water in their wells. Miguel F. Brigante, president of Electronic Water Conditioners Inc., got patent 4,347,133. **********The invention, which employs a magnetic field, includes a filter, a recirculating pump and a tank in which heavy metal flakes are precipitated. These and other particles are blown out under control of a timer. **********The new equipment, trademarked Trus-Tray, is reported to have been used successfuly in four states and four foreign countries. Mr.  Brigante got patents in 1979 for water conditioners trademarked Electro-Mag, which are used with steam boilers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/15/busin.body_text: **********WHAT commodity trader, especially those in the gold market, doesn't wish he had a second chance to buy or sell a futures contract. If the traders could, then longs would surely opt to buy gold at a lower price and shorts would have sold bullion when prices were much higher. **********Oddly, gold traders can benefit from hindsight through the use of ''lookback'' options sold through brokerage houses by the Mocatta Metals Corporation. With these lookback options, the investor has the right to buy gold at its lowest price during the life of the ''call'' option, while those who bought ''puts'' may sell the metal at its highest price. **********By definition, a call option gives the buyer the right - but not the obligation - to purchase the underlying commodity at a predetermined price during a specified period of time. A put option is the right to sell it under the same conditions. How much the options cost the buyer depends on the current value of the commodity, the time remaining in the option and related factors that determine the odds for making a profit. The cost of all options is the premium, plus the brokerage commissions. **********Last Thursday, when the price of gold bullion was quoted at $330 an ounce, based on the then London afternoon fixing, Terry S. Mayer, director of marketing at Mocatta Metals, explained the new lookback options as follows: **********''Suppose one buys a three, six, nine-month or longer call option on gold at $330 a ounce and, during the life of the option, the price drops to, say, $270, before coming back to, let us say, $330.  Ordinarily, the buyer of the call would be out the premium and use this loss as a tax deduction because it would not be worthwhile to exercise the option. But with a lookback call option, the buyer has the right to buy the bullion at $270 an ounce, its lowest price, and thus either make a profit or at least offset the premium cost.'' **********Again, with gold selling at $330, the strike price of a typical put option would be much lower, say, $270, for comparision purposes. If the price came back to $330 toward the option's expiration, the buyer of the lookback put option could exercise it at its highest price, $330, and acheive the same results as the lookback call buyer. **********''Obviously, the odds on a lookback option are more in favor of the buyer and the premium on the standard 100-ounce option is also slightly higher than on ordinary calls and puts,'' Mr. Mayer said.  ''As for commissions, that depends on the brokers who retail our options. Mocatta doesn't deal with the public.'' **********What about the premiums? Mr. Mayer pointed to a small computer in his office and said: ''As with any commodity, prices are changing every moment, depending on changing market prices, the flow of call and put orders and other factors that are constantly being computed.  Every broker that handles our options has one of these machines and can execute an order in seconds, even faster than it takes to execute a futures trade. **********The reference to futures was intended because commodity options, including gold bullion, on regulated exchanges is due to start within a few months. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission has set up a pilot program that will let each exchange offer options on one of their futures markets. Most of the nation's 11 major commodity exchanges chose options on their most popular futures market. New York's Commodity Exchange, the biggest metals futures market, has chosen to trade gold bullion options. **********But Mocatta Metals, which is the American affiliate of the 310-year-old London brokerage house of Mocatta Goldsmid Ltd., is pleased at this development because it will create a much greater and, most important, legitimate market in options. Since June 1978, Mocatta and a few small bullion dealers have had a virtual monopoly as dealers in options. **********The reason: the C.F.T.C., unable to halt the widespread frauds in dealer options at the time, outlawed all options, except those offered by such reputable bullion dealers as Mocatta, which has long had a policy of buying back any of its options (at current values) at any time, although it is legally not bound to do so. **********In any case, Mocatta has been offering options on many commodities, all through brokerage houses. Besides gold, silver and platinum bullion, these include various gold bullion coins, copper and United States coins with silver content. And they will soon offer options in foreign currencies that the Philadelphia Stock Exchange has requested Federal permission to trade later this year. **********Another reason why Mr. Mayer welcomes exchange-traded options is that much of Mocatta's business is ''customized'' to suit trade and individual clients. ''We don't think the standardized exchange options will compete with our lookback options or our new 'trading range' options that we plan to introduce in a few weeks,'' he noted. **********Trading range options will offer investors less expensive premiums because they will limit the profit obtainable on these instruments.  For example, Mr. Mayer said that the ordinary or lookback option sets no limit on the profit a buyer may make. ''But,'' he went on, ''suppose one bought a $400 gold call and was willing to forgo all profits above, say, $425. In such cases, the premium would be sharply reduced. The same would apply to put options. In other words, why pay premiums for unrealistic profits when more reasonable investment gains can be had for more modest outlays.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/08/world.body_text: **********American explosives experts used jackhammers today to dig out a live United States Air Force Sidewinder air-t o-air missile embedded in the concrete floor ofa barn. **********The police said the experts were not expected to finish until Monday.  The 10-foot rocket, accidentally fired last Monday by an American F-15, made a direct hit on the roof of a barn in Schramberg, 62 miles southwest of Stuttgart. The rocket pierced the barn's concrete floor before coming to rest 6 feet underground. **********The rocket was discovered when the owner of the barn saw the hole in its roof.  A United States military spokesman at the Ramstein Air Base said the accidental firing of the rocket was caused by a mechanical malfunction.

Haig Jr. and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko. **********The chief American negotiator, Paul H. Nitze, and his Soviet counterpart, Yuli A. https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/12/busin.body_text: **********A crowd of unhappy shareholders squared off against the Tosco Corporation's testy management today in a tightly orchestrated, 90-minute annual meeting that drew cries of protest from the outnumbered dissidents. **********The outcome of a proxy fight led by Kenneth M. Good, a Colorado land developer, will not be known until May 24, when the counting of ballots cast at today's meeting is completed. Mr. Good's group wants to oust Morton M. Winston, Tosco's president and chief executive, and possibly liquidate the $3 billion energy company, **********The strength of applause from both sides during the meeting suggested that Mr. Good, who controls 8.8 percent of the company's common shares, had gained considerable support in his six-week battle. ''I think it is very close,'' he said later. Vigorous Applause for President **********But the majority of the more than 1,200 shareholders who crowded into the ornate ballroom of the Beverly Wilshire hotel for the meeting had clearly sided with Mr. Winston. ''I congratulate you,'' an elderly man told the Tosco management, to vigorous applause. **********The basis of Mr. Good's primary attack against Mr. Winston was his assertion that Tosco management knew as early as last Sept. 24, but did not inform its shareholders, that the Exxon Corporation's private estimates for constructing a Colorado shale-oil production plant had risen to between $5 billion and $6.3 billion. Last month, Tosco said the cost would be about $3.8 billion. **********Tosco was a 40 percent partner in the project with Exxon until May 2, when Exxon announced that it was ending its participation. As part of its agreement, Exxon agreed to pay Tosco $380 million. Before that, Mr. Good had campaigned for Tosco to sell its interest to Exxon for up to $450 million before its option to do so would expire at the end of this year. Project Estimates at Issue **********''I would not have bought my Tosco stock,'' Mr. Good said, if he had realized that the difference in estimates for the cost of the shale-oil plant, known as the Colony Shale Oil Project. ''I suspect that many of you feel the same way.'' **********Mr. Good acquired his Tosco holdings for $50 million, or an average price of about $25 a share, including interest payments. Tosco shares, which sold for a high of $45 late in 1980, closed today at $14.125 a share, up 75 cents, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. **********Mr. Good also criticized Tosco for spending $40 million last year in ''unallocated'' corporate expenses. He charged that much of the money was wasted on staff at its headquarters for the ''preservation of Mr. Winston's personal fiefdom.'' Microphone Disconnected **********At one point, Mr. Good's microphone was disconnected at the direction of Erwin Millimet, a lawyer seated at Mr. Winston's right who ran much of the meeting. He warned Mr. Good against ''personal attacks'' on any Tosco officials. **********Earlier, Mr. Millimet, a partner in Stroock, Stroock & Lavan, a Manhattan law firm, noted that a ''sergeant-at-arms'' was present and added, ''It is hoped that it will not be necessary to ask an unruly shareholder to leave.'' **********Stern-faced security guards in business suits were evident in several areas of the ballroom throughout the meeting.  On the day of Exxon's announcement, Mr. Winston said Tosco would retain about $100 million in profit from the Exxon payment after various expenses. Mr. Good said the amount does not include another $120 million in cash Tosco accounted for as repayment of invested capital. **********In response to a shareholder's question, Mr. Winston said today that the amount of a special dividend had not been determined by Tosco's directors. He indicated earlier that the dividend would be less than $4 a share. **********In his comments, Mr. Winston, a Harvard-trained lawyer who joined Tosco in 1962, said that the company, the nation's second-largest independent refiner, had come through the oil glut in better shape than most of its competitors. Optimistic Forecast for '83 **********He said he anticipated that gasoline prices would rise again before the end of the third quarter. ''Our prospects for 1983 look quite bright,'' he said. **********Speaking to reporters after the meeting, Mr. Winston denied that Tosco had been aware of Exxon's higher estimates for the Colony project last fall. ''At no time did I have any indication that Exxon was considering a shutdown of the project,'' he added. **********He reiterated that Tosco still believes that shale-oil production is workable. He said Tosco will step up its lobbying with the Reagan Administration and Congress to gain more Government funding. **********He added that Tosco's negotiations to sell a portion of Tosco's large holdings of shale-oil property in Colorado and Utah to Japanese interests, which he declined to identify, were continuing. **********''It is gratifying to see that there remains strong interest elsewhere in the world in shale-oil development,'' he said.  Mr. Good said that if his slate of five nominees to the Tosco board is defeated, he might continue to buy Tosco shares. He said he would sell many of his real estate holdings, valued at more than $100 million, to finance the purchases. **********Asked if he would lead another proxy fight in 1983 should he lose, he replied, ''I might own the company by then.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/04/world.main_headline: LONDON ORDERING 35-SHIP TASK FORCE TO THE FALKLANDS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/04/world.print_headline: LONDON ORDERING 35-SHIP TASK FORCE TO THE FALKLANDS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/04/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, speaking during the first weekend session of Parliament since the Suez crisis of 1956, said today that the Falkland Islands ''remain British territory'' and ordered a large naval task force to the South Atlantic. **********In addition, Mrs. Thatcher announced that Argentina's financial assets in Britain would be frozen and other economic sanctions would be imposed. **********In Buenos Aires, the military Government said it would ''not retreat'' from its seizure of the islands. It broke diplomatic relations with Britain, in response to a similar move by London on Friday, and froze British assets in Argentina. (Page 18.) **********Mrs. Thatcher, in a 24-minute opening address to the packed chamber of the House of Commons, declared: ''The Falkland Islands and their dependencies remain British territory; no aggression and no invasion can alter that simple fact.  It is the Government's object to see the islands are free from occupation.'' Calls for Ministers to Quit **********Nonetheless, politicians of both the Conservative and Labor Parties repeatedly called during the tumultuous three-hour session today for the resignations of key ministers. **********The Prime Minister, who canceled all weekend engagements to remain at 10 Downing Street, steadfastly refused to say what action would be taken when the large convoy, which will consist of 35 to 40 ships representing about two-thirds of Britain's naval strength, reaches the Falklands in about two weeks. **********''I stress I cannot foretell what orders the task force will receive as they proceed,'' said Mrs. Thatcher, somber and choosing her words deliberately. ''That will depend on the situation at the time.'' **********The British action of freezing Argentine assets closely resembled the American freezing of Iranian assets during the period of the hostages' captivity. **********Traditionally, the freezing of assets represents an extreme and unusual step, just short of war. The British action is estimated to apply to $1.5 billion in gold, securities and currency deposits, onequarter of what Britain is believed to have at risk in Argentina. **********In addition, new export credits to Argentina were suspended. And late this afternoon the Government announced that it would halt sales of military equipment, aircraft and spare parts to Argentina. Most arms sales to the military Government are already banned because of its record on human rights, but last year Britain sold $22 million worth of military equipment to Argentina. **********Britain's strategy clearly rests on the hope that the impending arrival of such a large military force will spur Argentina to accept a diplomatic solution. **********But near the end of the session of Parliament, John Nott, the Defense Secretary, who has become the target of the harshest criticism, said that if diplomacy ''fails - and it will probably do so - we have no choice but to press forward with our plans.'' Mr.  Nott, whitefaced and shaking, was repeatedly drowned out by jeers from the opposition. **********The Defense Secretary said the task force would be led by the 19,500-ton aircraft carrier Invincible, which will sail from Portsmouth Monday. The force will include a second carrier, destroyers, frigates, landing ships, 1,000 marine commandos and a ''substantial'' number of other troops, military officials said. **********The force will include Queen Elizabeth's second son, the 22-yearold Prince Andrew, who has been serving as a helicopter pilot aboard the Invincible. **********The Government has refused to provide military details, but a substantial portion of the convoy is believed to be already under way. The ships are expected to rendezvous at the mid-Atlantic island of Ascension, which is being restocked with ammunition, fuel and supplies by Royal Air Force transport planes from Lyneham Air Base in Wiltshire. **********The Defense Ministry refused to discuss reports by an Argentine news agency that the nuclear submarine Superb could reach the Falkland Islands by Sunday. **********Whatever the outcome of the crisis, it appeared certain to have substantial ramifications for Britain's military spending plans.  Although this nation has been increasing military outlays faster than any other in Europe, it has simultaneously begun reducing the size of the surface navy, a cutback which now seems in substantial jeopardy. 'Certain Heads Must Roll' **********The criticism of the Thatcher Government was notable for the intensity of the attacks from Conservatives over the lack of anticipatory measures. Mr. Nott and Lord Carrington, the Foreign Secretary, were singled out for leaving Britain in the difficult position of trying to regain control over the islands, which have been a British possession since 1833. **********''In order to save the Prime Minister and the Government, I am afraid that certain heads must roll, including that of the Foreign Secretary and, I very much regret to say, that of the Defense Secretary as well,'' said John Stokes, a Conservative Member of Parliament. **********In the debate, several Conservative backbenchers joined opposition demands for the resignation of Mr. Nott and Lord Carrington over the handling of the affair. **********''What has happened to the Falklands is a disgrace to the British flag,'' said a Convervative M.P., Nicholas Winterton, calling on both officials to take the ''honorable'' course and quit. 'Skin Off a Rice Pudding' **********''In the next week or two, this House, the nation and Mrs. Thatcher herself will find out of what mettle she is made,'' said Enoch Powell, the former Conservative Cabinet official, urging a military attack. **********Lord Wigg, a Laborite, said, ''We have spent 111 billion pounds on defense since the end of the last war and we can't knock the skin off a rice pudding.'' **********Another full-scale debate in Parliament on the Falkland situation will be held Tuesday and Wednesday and an investigation will be begun by the Commons Select Committee on Defense. **********Substantial unhappiness with the Thatcher Government also resulted when Humphrey Atkins, the Deputy Foreign Secretary, apologized for ''misleading'' members Friday about when he was last in touch with the Falkland Islands. **********Mrs. Thatcher told Parliament that there were no civilian casualties in the Falklands in the takeover, but implied that the marines put up resistance. **********The Prime Minister said that she had spoken by telephone to the ousted British Governor, Rex Hunt, after he was flown to Uruguay by occupation forces, and that he reported that the marines ''were superb - they acted in the best tradition.'' **********Mrs. Thatcher said Mr. Hunt told her the Falkland Islanders were ''in tears and don't want to be Argentinian.'' Despite the Government's initial inaction, the Prime Minister said it would have been absurd to dispatch the British fleet ''every time there is bellicose talk in Buenos Aires.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/26/world.body_text: **********Vietnamese ''boat people'' have been arriving on the southern coast of Thailand in markedly smaller numbers this year than in the first three months of last year or the year before, according to a field officer here for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. **********Seventy-six boats bearing 1,977 Vietnamese arrived on the southern coast of Thailand, between Chumphon and the Malaysian border, in the first three months of this year. The total compares with 5,935 arrivals in the same period of 1981 and 5,672 in the first three months of 1980. **********The proportion of boats that have been attacked by Thai pirates has remained the same, according to preliminary statistics based on reports from United Nations receiving points for refugees up and down the coast. **********Last year, four out of five such boats arriving here were said to have been attacked while at sea. Among those that were attacked, the ''average'' boat was attacked 3.5 times. Robbings and beatings of those aboard continued unabated, and on 44 percent of the boats that were attacked in 1981, the women were raped. Statistics Holding Steady **********''These statistics are holding for 1982,'' said the United Nations officer here in Songkhla, the largest port in southern Thailand. The official asked not to be named on the ground that such statistics should come from United Nations officials in Bangkok. **********The Gulf of Thailand has been virtually unpatrolled by armed Thai Government vessels since last September when a patrol program financed by the United States expired. **********A naval patrol program similar to the one abandoned in September, but organized this time by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, is expected to be presented soon for the Thai Government's approval. Eight donor nations have agreed to contribute $3.6 million for the purchase and operation for six months of four patrol boats, four Vietnamese fishing boats for use as decoys, four Thai trawlers, and a computer with which the Thai Government plans to keep track of the registration numbers of fishing boats in its coastal provinces. **********The High Commissioner's office first proposed late last year that it take over the formerly American-backed program. The Thai Government, however, objected to a provision that certain foreign diplomats in Bangkok act as monitors. It was unclear here this week whether diplomatic monitors were still part of the United Nations plan. Camp's Population Down **********The Songkhla camp for boat people, which held more than 6,000 people for long periods of 1980 and 1981, had a population of 536 today. The camp is now officially considered a transit facility, and the Thai Ministry of Interior regularly buses its population, gathered from smaller camps along the coast, to a larger camp north of Bangkok. **********In a recent case that is said to be typical, 11 Vietnamese men in a fishing boat landed March 28 on a Union Oil Company rig in the Gulf of Thailand about 150 miles north of here. Eleven others -four women and their babies - who had left South Vietnam in the same boat had been abducted in an attack by pirates, they reported. **********On April 9, the Herta S, a ship privately financed in Western Europe that assists boat people, visited the 11 men, who were being kept on a barge attached to the oil company's rig. The ship provided them with a doctor and two days ago, after United Nations officials had been granted permission by local Thai authorities, the men were brought ashore. **********Last year, 211 Vietnamese boat people were reportedly abducted, nearly all of them by Thai pirates. Of those, 133 are still missing.  Some have been taken to isolated islands. Others, according to local accounts, have ended up in the brothels of Hat Yai, a busy tourist center a few miles west of Songkhla. Boats Arriving Now Are Smaller **********The Vietnamese boats that have been arriving since last October, when the flood of boat people began to ebb, have been smaller than earlier boats and have carried fewer people per boat than in 1980 and early 1981, when 300 or 400 refugees would often pack themselves into one overloaded vessel. **********A Vietnamese boat that arrived here March 9, for example, was carrying 32 people - 15 men, 10 women and 7 children. The boat is still stranded in front of the Samila Hotel - a reminder that this long, spectacular coast of sandy beaches and coconut palms, a haven for tourists as well as fishermen and pirates, received 737 Vietnamese refugees during March. **********Nearly all the recent boat people have been ethnic Vietnamese. In 1979 and for a time afterward many of those leaving Vietnam by boat were ethnic Chinese. **********The United States is expected to be the largest contributor to the international program designed to reinstitute Thailand's antipiracy patrols. Among the other donor nations are Australia, Norway, Switzerland, France and West Germany. **********In early June Songkhla, Thailand's main receiving point for seaborne refugees, will be one of the sites for a major naval exercise involving the United States Seventh Fleet. The operation, named Cobra Gold, will include a landing by United States marines as well as joint maneuvers with the Royal Thai Navy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/22/world.main_headline: SCHMIDT FOES WIN IN LOWER SAXONY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/22/world.print_headline: SCHMIDT FOES WIN IN LOWER SAXONY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/22/world.body_text: **********The Christian Democrats won a substantial victory tonight in voting for the parliament of the state of Lower Saxony, the first major election in West Germany since the Government of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt was returned to power in 1980. **********The Chancellor's Social Democratic Party suffered heavy losses in the race for the State Legislature, which was regarded as a national test. **********The Christian Democrats gained voters in traditional urban working-class areas usually dominated by the Chancellor's party. The Greens, an ecological party opposed to NATO and its plans to station new nuclear missiles here, attracted the ballots of many young people, who in the past were considered Social Democratic supporters. **********Since the 13-year-old national coalition of Social Democrats and Free Democrats won re-election in October 1980, the Bonn Government has been weakened by strains between the coalition partners, growing economic problems and dissension in the Social Democratic party between those backing Mr. Schmidt and leftists who have challenged his security policy and the strong alliance with the United States. Free Democrats Also Gain **********Today's election results gave the Christian Democrats, who have governed alone in Lower Saxony since 1978, their best showing in the state since 1947. The Greens, who are believed to have profited from scandals in labor unions allied to the Social Democrats and from bribery investigations involving aides of the Chancellor, entered the State Legislature for the first time. The Free Democrats, who failed to win representation in the legislature four years ago, returned to the parliament by winning more than 5 percent of the vote. **********On the basis of official preliminary results from all polling stations in Lower Saxony, the Christian Democrats won 50.7 percent of the vote, compared with 48.7 percent in the 1978 election. The Social Democrats fell to 36.5 percent, down from 42.2 percent four years ago. The Free Democrats won 5.9 percent, compared with 4.2 percent in 1978, and the Greens got 6.5 percent, compared with 3.9 percent in 1978. **********The state election was the first of four this year in West Germany. Mr. Schmidt's coalition will probably face a crisis if the state government supporting the national coalition is defeated by the Christian Democrats either in Hamburg in June or in Hesse in September. **********Beyond the psychological effects of such a defeat, an opposition victory in either state would mean that Christian Democrats would attain a two-thirds majority in the Bundesrat, or upper house of Parliament, whose members are appointed by the states. This would enable the opposition to block any legislation initiated by the Government. 'Loser Is Named Helmut Schmidt' **********''The loser of the election is named Helmut Schmidt,'' said Helmut Kohl, the Christian Democrat's parliamentary chief and former candidate for Chancellor. **********Willy Brandt, the Social Democratic chairman, said the results showed that the national coalition had not been ''convincing enough.'' **********Ernst Albrecht, the Christian Democratic Minister-President in Lower Saxony, said: ''The obvious difficulties of the Social Democrats are only beginning. The coalition at the national level is clearly at an end. It's truly half dead. I just don't see how they can work out of this situation.'' **********Spokesmen for both the Social Democrats and the Free Democrats, however, insisted that the results would not affect their national alliance. **********Peter Glotz, national manager of the Social Democratic Party, acknowledged the sharpness of his party's defeat, which, he said, showed ''that the attitude toward us is poor at the present time.'' But the election involved the state alone, he said, and nothing more.  Leftists Start New Party **********Gunter Verheugen, the general secretary of the Free Democratic Party, said the Greens had won entry into parliament in Lower Saxony at the expense of the Social Democrats. But he acknowledged that the victory by the opposition ''won't simplify things, although it doesn't start any irreversible process.'' **********Additional problems for the Social Democrats developed over the weekend with the founding of a new left-wing party. Called the Democratic Socialists, the party is led by Manfred Coppik and Karl Heinz Hansen, two members of Parliament who had renounced their membership in Mr. Schmidt's party with accusations that it had become a vassal of the United States on security issues and an ally of big capitalism in economic matters. They said the party would enter the elections in Hesse. **********The new party called for a ''decisive demonstration'' against the policies of President Reagan when he visits West Germany June 9 and 10 for a summit meeting of NATO member nations. **********A spokesman for the Greens expressed interest in a ''fruitful dialogue'' with the new Democratic Socialists.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/25/busin.main_headline: Personal Finance; DIVIDING FUTURE BENEFITS IN DIVORCE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/25/busin.print_headline: Personal Finance; DIVIDING FUTURE BENEFITS IN DIVORCE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/25/busin.body_text: **********WHEN couples begin to wrangle over the specific details of a divorces ettlement, the first things they tend to think about are who gets t he house, furniture, car, stock and children. But equally important m atters, such as whether the wife will be covered under her husband'sg roup health insurance plan or have a claim against his pension, tendt o get overlooked. **********''With divorce rates where they are, it's surprising that these items haven't become a more important issue,'' said Lloyd M. Kaye of William M. Mercer Inc., a New York employee benefits and compensation consulting firm. **********The precedent for letting a divorced wife share in her former husband's pension is well established. A pension represents income the husband earns during the marriage that is being foregone until his retirement. Marriage is an economic as well as emotional partnership, the argument goes, and so the man's retirement pay should be subject to division in the same way as his current salary and other assets. At the same time, a woman's right to her former husband's group health insurance policy is a murkier issue. A woman can potentially save thousands of dollars over the years if she successfully bargains for a claim against such benefits, or their equivalent in cash or other assets. **********Although a good health insurance policy can be vital to a woman divorced in middle age, especially if she already has health problems, obtaining coverage through her former husband's work policy is virtually impossible if he complies with the rules. And the cost of buying an individual policy can be prohibitive, exceeding $2,000 or $3,000 a year, depending on a woman's health and age. **********''Most group policies are geared to a definition of a worker's dependents, which generally does not include the person's exspouse,'' said Theresa B. Stuchiner, a partner with Kwasha Lipton, an employee benefits consulting firm in Fort Lee, N.J. **********In order to continue coverage for a former spouse, the worker usually neglects to tell his employer about the divorce or falsifies information on the claims form, benefits experts say. ''What typically happens is that the company never finds out about the divorce until the employee remarries,'' Mr. Kaye said. **********A similar situation exists with the health insurance plans that cover Government employees. Military wives, for example, lose their right to free medical care at service bases upon divorce. And while the divorced spouses of Civil Service employees are supposed to have the right to convert their former partners' group medical policies into an individual policy within 30 days, without having to undergo a medical exam, some say the provision is not adequately policed or publicized. **********''I know of one case where an insurance company wrote to a divorced woman who converted and said it would not cover her for the ailment it had been paying for when she was married,'' said Edith Fierst, a private attorney in Washington. **********But help for divorced spouses of military men may be on the way.  The Senate Armed Services Committee approved a bill last week that would allow 180 days' medical care coverage to all former spouses, and continued coverage for former spouses with serious ailments who were married for at least 20 years during a serviceman's career and who do not remarry. And earlier this year, the state of Massachusetts passed a law giving divorced spouses the right to remain in a company group health insurance plan until the nonworking spouse or the insured worker remarries. But the law is applicable only to new contracts and not to existing ones. And in the event of the worker's remarriage, the law gives the former spouse the option of remaining in the group plan or buying an individual plan. THE situation of getting a cut of the husband's benefits is much m ore defined with pensions. ''The basic question is to what extent s he can get at that money,'' said Mrs. Stuchiner. ''It's quite clear t hat the Federal courts will go along with permitting attachment of p ension benefits to support alimony or child support obligations. In m ost of the cases, the courts have leaned over backward to a ccommodate the nonemployee spouse.'' Typically, the cases arise whena former husband has been delinquent in alimony payments or child s upport. **********But there is a complicating piece of law - the Employee Retirement Income Security Act. Under Erisa, pension plan administrators are specifically prohibited from assigning a worker's pension to anyone other than the worker. Many divorced husbands and plan sponsors maintain that Erisa overrides state laws that entitled a former wife to claim some portion of the husband's assets. However, lawyers for divorced wives argue that the nonassignment clause in the law was included mainly to prevent creditors from attaching a worker's pension and not for it to be placed beyond the reach and economic needs of his dependents. **********The courts have tended to agree. ''It would be ironic indeed if a provision designed in part to ensure that an employee spouse would be able to meet his obligations to family after retirement were interpreted to permit him to evade them with impunity after divorce,'' said the Federal District Court in northern California in April 1978. **********One notable exception to the trend of court cases favorable to divorced wives was a Supreme Court decision last June that held that a military pension was the ''exclusive property'' of the retiree. The man did not have to divide his retirement pay with his former wife, said the high court, because the Federal military retirement system overrides state community property laws. **********But Congress may soon reverse that situation. When the Senate Armed Services Committee approved last week the bill providing limited health coverage for divorced military wives, it also approved a provision that would restore the right of state courts to include military retirement pay as marital property that may be divided in divorce settlements. **********The situation regarding other Government workers is spotty. The Foreign Service Act of 1980 says that the former wives of foreign service officers who were divorced after Feb. 15, 1981, are entitled to a share of their former husbands' pensions proportionate to the duration of their marriage during the time the men worked for the Foreign Service. **********But the former wives of Civil Service employees, who are not covered by the Social Security system, are not so fortunate. Although the women can claim a part of their former husbands' pensions while the men are alive, they lose the right to a survivor's annuity - which guarantees continued benefits -when the men die. There is a very limited provision that allows the man to give the annuity to his first, rather than his current wife, but the provision is little publicized and consequently little used.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/19/busin.body_text: **********Negotiations have broken off between Grupo Industrial Alfa and the Mexican Government on the country's purchase of some of Alfa's subsidiaries. **********In addition, the Government is refusing to allow Alfa to draw on an unused line of credit, money that Alfa was depending on to cover a cash shortage. These disclosures were made earlier this week in a telex sent by the Chase Manhattan Bank to Alfa's bankers. Chase heads a committee that is trying to restructure Alfa's debt. In April, Alfa halted payments on $2 billion of debt to 134 foreign banks, but the Mexican conglomerate is still paying interest. Alfa is invlolved in steel, tourism, food processing, capital goods and other products.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/13/busin.body_text: **********Canada's Bureau of Competition Policy is examining the reorganization proposal of the Bell Telephone Company of Canada and may recommend a public hearing, Ian Nielson-Jones, chief of the agency's regulated section division, said today. **********''We're concerned that the information available publicly is sketchy and confusing,'' he said.  David Orr, Bell's director of corporate public relations, said the company believes its plan has been fully publicized.  Bell's plan calls for creating a parent company, to be called Bell Canada Enterprises Inc., that would be free to invest in nonregulated businesses through separate subsidiaries. Bell shareholders will vote on the plan Aug. 18.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/11/world.main_headline: 6 SALVADORAN SOILDERS FACE COURT IN SLAYING OF AMERICAN NUNS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/11/world.print_headline: 6 SALVADORAN SOILDERS FACE COURT IN SLAYING OF AMERICAN NUNS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/11/world.body_text: **********El Salvador's military authorities today surrendered six National Guard soldiers to a civilian court that will decide whether they should be tried in the murder of three American nuns and a lay worker 14 months ago. **********Brought here from the National Guard base in San Salvador by helicopter, the six faced proceedings that could lead to formal charges being filed against them by the weeke nd. **********Under Salvadoran law, as explained by lawyers and clerks at the courthouse, the judge has 72 hours in which to weigh the evidence and decide either to charge the men formally, hold them for further investigation or release them. Men Are Not Indicted **********The families of the slain women had been told by the State Department that the men would be indicted today, but the court action was apparently a preliminary procedure. **********Today's development came at a time when the Reagan Administration is seeking to demonstrate that the Salvadoran Government has improved its human rights performance. One of the conditions set by Congress for continuing aid to El Salvador was that there should be progress in the investigation of the slaying of the four Roman Catholic missionaries. **********On Dec. 2, 1980, Ita Ford and Maura Clarke, members of the Maryknoll Order, returned from a trip to Nicaragua and were met at the airport in San Salvador by Dorothy Kazel, an Ursuline nun, and Jean Donovan, a lay worker. All Subject to Threats **********All four had been working in poor communities and had been subjected to threats. Weeks before their killings, a sign was tacked to the door of the parish house where two lived saying that its occupants were ''Communists'' and ''anyone who enters this house will die.'' **********The four were last seen by Canadian missionaries in the baggage area of the airport. Their bodies were found the next morning by villagers in Santiago Nonualco, 15 miles northeast of the air terminal. They had been shot in the head, partly disrobed and beaten. National Guard soldiers quickly buried the bodies, but a judge subsequently ordered them exhumed. **********The case drew great attention i n the United States and led the Carter Admini stration to suspend aid to El Salvador on Dec. 5, 1980. The controver sy grew with suggestions that the Salvadoran military was stalling the investigation because of signs pointing to the involvement o f ranking military officials. **********The brother of one of the slain women said Tuesday that he thought the time it had taken to bring the soldiers to court was an indication that higher-ranking members of the Salvadoran military were involved. **********Robert E. White, the American Ambassador at the time of the murders, charged that ''the message we were getting was that this would crack the military wide open.'' **********Under United States pressure, a special investigating commission headed by a Salvadoran Army colonel was appointed, but last November American officials here said that it was not actively pursuing the investigation. **********The judge in charge of the case, Mario Alberto Rivera, said it was at a ''dead end.'' He had assumed the case after the sudden resignation of a predecessor, and shortly afterward he too quit. **********Ballistics and fingerprint tests by the United States Federal Bureau of Investigation resulted in the arrest of two National Guard soldiers in April 1981. Four other National Guardsmen who were on patrol with them on the night of the killings were also arrested at the time. Two were later released and two more guardsmen were arrested last month. Two Kept Apart From Others **********The six men presented to Judge Bernado Rauda Murcia today were Luis Antonio Colindres Aleman, Francisco Orlando Contreras Recinos, Jose Roberto Canjura Moreno, Carlos Joaquin Contreras Palacios, Daniel Canales Ramirez and Salvador Rivera Franco. **********They stood in pairs, handcuffed together and dressed in rumpled civilian clothes. Their hair was unkempt and only one was cleanshaven. They alternately kept their heads lowered, some shielding their faces with their hands, and chatted with the blackhelmeted former colleagues guarding them. **********Two were kept apart from the other four. There have been reports that new evidence leading to today's proceedings was obtained through confessions. **********According to a letter submitted to the judge by the Commander in Chief of the National Guard, Gen. Carlos Eugenio Vides Casanova, five of the men were discharged from the National Guard Tuesday and arrested by civil authorities at 6 P.M. The other was arrested the day before. **********Accompanying the letter was a 56-page investigative report compiled by the military that was not made public. The letter said that the report included a statement of a former National Guard soldier whom the letter identified as a ''witness.'' General Casanova wrote that the witness, Julio Cesar Valle, could not be found. The only physical evidence presented by the military authorities to day was a tire, a yellow automobile jack and a burgundy dress from th e scene of the murders, though the F.B.I. has examined rifles, bu llets and a tooth fragment. **********Court authorities declined to answer any questions about the proceedings.  A National Guard lieutenant at the courthouse said he had fought at the suspects' side during combat with guerrillas and that they were ''good soldiers.'' **********''Whatever errors some elements commit,'' he added, ''doesn't tarnish the institution.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/29/busin.main_headline: Mariah Acquires Rights To Resume Magazine
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/29/busin.print_headline: ADVERTISING; Mariah Acquires Rights To Resume Magazine
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/29/busin.body_text: **********Bits and pieces from magazine land: Mariah Publications, publishers of Outside magazine, has announced that it has acquired the publishing rights to Rocky Mountain magazine, which ceased publication in April because of ''recessionary pressures.'' **********David Gordon, a Californian who used to publish a weekly newspaper called Beverly Hills People, plans in September to bring out Beverly Hills World, a monthly, controlled-circulation magazine that will be sent to 30,000 area homes. **********He is in town showing a dummy to ad agencies in hopes of landing some national advertisers in the premium price range. A four-color page will go for about $3,000. **********And, finally, down in North Miami, Fla., Halsey Publishing is breathing easier now that it has landed the job of publishing a magazine for the members of the 110 private country, city and athletic clubs operated all over by the Club Corporation of America.  It will fill the income vacancy created when Braniff stopped operations and there was no longer an audience for its Flying Colors in-flight magazine. Halsey also produces Sky for Delta, Time Zones for Transamerica, Skylite for Butler Aviation and Jockey Club Magazine for Miami's Jockey Club.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/28/busin.body_text: **********Volkswagen Canada Inc. says it is delaying indefinitely the opening of its $102 million parts plant being built in Barrie, Ontario, because of the sagging economy. **********Bruno Rubess, who heads Volkswagen's Toronto-based Canadian subsidiary, said the car market in the United States was suffering badly and the plan to build the plant was based on the assumption of higher sales. **********''It would be very foolish indeed to open it, hire people and create a sick plant,'' he said. However, he stressed that the company was not abandoning the project, which was to have opened in September 1983, and would have created 500 jobs.
