https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/22/world.main_headline: UNEASY PEACE COMES TO RURAL GUATEMALA BUT DISQUIET LINGERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/22/world.print_headline: UNEASY PEACE COMES TO RURAL GUATEMALA BUT DISQUIET LINGERS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/22/world.body_text: **********The Guatemalan Government has succeeded in bringing an uneasy peace to much of the countryside, where just a few months ago reports of battles with guerrillas and massacres by Government troops were commonplace. **********But for the largely Indian population, the convulsions of a guerrilla war have been replaced by new concerns and new disruptions of their traditional way of life. **********Interviews with dozens of Indian villagers, church workers, Government officials and soldiers and officers -conducted during a four-day 600-mile tour of the Guatemalan highlands -found a dramatic change. **********While scattered incidents of violence continue, indications are that the Government has reasserted substantial control over all but certain stretches of the border with Mexico and a handful of areas in the interior. Means Are in Dispute **********The means by which this control was achieved remain in dispute.  The military and the Government of Gen. Efrain Rios Montt, which took power in a coup last March, insist that the renewed support for the regime resulted from a failure by the leftist insurgents to fulfill their promises of a better way of life, combined with a new level of social concern by the Government. **********''They promised them the sky and the earth but they didn't fulfill them,'' said a ranking officer at the Santa Cruz del Quiche military base. ''Instead of leaving a bad situation for a better one, they left a bad situation for something worse.'' **********Others, including church workers and international human rights organizations, say that the military conducted a five-month wave of terror in enough selected locations in the countryside to cause widespread intimidation of the people, thus convincing them that continued support of the leftists was hazardous to their lives. Coercion by the Guerrillas **********One thing on which substantial numbers of both sympathizers and opponents of the leftists have come to agree, as some trappings of peace have returned to the countryside, is that the guerrillas at least partly caused their following to drop to its present low level by forcing unwilling Indians to support their cause. **********''They started out really easy with the people, paying for things, but in the end they did exactly the opposite,'' said a religious leader in Huehuetenango province. ''They forced people, they killed people for joining the civilian patrols. But to my knowledge, they never wiped out a village - at least not in Huehuetenango.'' **********A ranking military officer in Quiche, talking about the villagers of his province, put it this way: ''Why are there no guerrillas?  Because they were the guerrillas.'' **********''The guerrilla in the civil population is like a fish in water,'' he continued, paraphrasing Mao Zedong. ''You take the water from the fish, the fish dies; you take the people from the guerrillas and they die.'' Villages Are Diverse **********While most people here think it premature to say that the guerrilla movement is dead, a journey from Huehuetenango, the provincial capital, to this tiny northern village illustrates many of the changes that have come to the region. **********To get to San Mateo Ixtatan, a policeman in Huehuetenango said, pointing into the mountains, ''you take the north road and climb, climb into the clouds.'' That is just the beginning. Above the clouds, the road continues to wind on and on, a steep, rutted route that gives the impression of driving up a flight of stairs covered with fist-sized rocks. **********Where the road nears a village, every tillable piece of land that is not a sheer drop seems to be planted - with corn, wheat, cabbages, watermelon or other crops - making an orderly patchwork of the mountainside. **********The difficulty of transport has contributed to the survival of strong distinctions among the Indian population; from one village to another just a few miles away there may be a difference in dress and even in language. This physical and cultural separation makes any kind of broad organizing effort problematic. Many Checkpoints on Roads **********Between the provincial capital and this village, 18 civilian patrols man road checkpoints, monitoring the flow of traffic with varying degrees of vigilance. The men speak of their recent lives with varying degrees of relief and concern. **********From one point to another, the movement of the guerrillas' apparent retreat can be traced - from ''todo tranquilo,'' or ''all calm,'' at checkpoints near the outset, to a colorfully unprintable term meaning ''still messed up'' closer to the point where, earlier this month, leftists sledgehammered a concrete electrical tower, dropping the lines into a 4,000-foot canyon and leaving the northern half of Huehuetenango without power. **********The civilian patrols began under President Romeo Lucas Garcia, who was subsequently overthrown, but have been stepped up dramatically under General Rios Montt's ''rifles and beans'' program of pacification and rural aid. The Government insists the patrols are voluntary, but most of the participants believe otherwise. **********''They threaten you with punishment if you don't serve - put you in prison,'' said Clemente Francisco, who was manning a checkpoint near the village of Soloma. Another problem, he said, was that manning the post - which he had done 24 times since July 1 - took time from tilling his land, ''and we have big families to take care of.'' No Gerrillas Are Sighted **********None of the men at the checkpoints reported having seized or even seen a guerrilla since they started patrolling with their sticks, slingshots, flintlock rifles or M-1's earlier this year, and some were beginning to have doubts, particularly since in Huehuetenango few have received any of the ''beans'' promised by the Government. **********''We are fulfilling the orders of Rios Montt,'' said Fernando Joaquin. ''They say they will give us something later.'' He added that the patrols had been keeping track of the hours they served and hoped to see some reward for their efforts later in the month. **********Elsewhere along the route, Indian villagers, some of them women with babies in slings on their backs, can be seen among thousands of fallen pine trees. At the military's behest, they are cutting a swath 20 to 30 yards deep away from the road to remove cover that might be used for guerrilla attacks. **********While there are still scattered reports of military men stealing from vilagers, a change in tactics has led to a marked improvement in the relations between the Indians and the soldiers in this region.  The change is noticed and discussed by soldiers although their superiors will not acknowledge it. 'We Have Dialogues' **********''Now we talk to the people, we have dialogues,'' said one of several soldiers guarding workers who were trying to erect a wooden pole to replace a shattered electrical tower. ''It's better; it's less dangerous for us. Before we harassed each other.'' **********Some people here see the patrols less as self-defense and more as a means of forcing the Indians to commit themselves by working against the leftists. **********An occasional adobe house displays a slogan scrawled in spraypainted black letters: ''Not a piece of bread or a tortilla for the guerrilla.'' **********And the military has taken to putting signs on some of the electrical towers it replaces, in both Spanish and Indian dialect, saying: ''We the poor of these places and villages suffer more if we don't have light from light bulbs. With candles or gas we waste a lot of money. We plead with you not to knock down this post.'' New Problems for Indians **********The speed with which villagers moved from insurgency to counterinsurgency has created some new problems. In some places, villagers have turned on one another. There have been several reports of Indians who originally encouraged their neighbors to support the leftists now returning, under military pressure, to point out those who ''collaborated.'' **********A church worker in Huehuetenango province, who had earlier seemed sympathetic to the leftists' aims, said he sees a three-stage program by the military: first, intimidate the villagers; second, control them; third, be nice to them. **********''The people wanted to get free of the guerrillas; they just couldn't stand it anymore,'' he said. ''It's an awful tough thing to have two enemies out there.'' **********While the church worker acknowledged that the program seemed to be bringing a level of peace to the countryside, he worried about the effect on the Indian culture. **********''What's happening to the Indian today when he's forced to go on civil patrol, when he's forced to do all these things?'' he asked.  ''What's going on inside of the Indian person? What's being done to the culture? You can just feel that it's hurting.'' Administration Cites Gains **********The present state of relative peace in the countryside has been cited by the Reagan Administration as evidence that the human rights situation here is improving under General Rios Montt -a preliminary step toward allowing Guatemala once again to receive United States military aid, which has officially been cut off since 1977 because of human rights concerns. **********The questions the Government here has had difficulty answering is how, after years of battling the guerrillas, calm was so quickly restored and why, if the guerrilla threat has been vanquished as President Rios Montt says, military aid is still necessary. **********Amnesty International, the human rights group, maintained in a report earlier this year that peace came at the price of some 2,600 Indian lives, many of them women and children, as the military systematically attempted to eliminate guerrilla leaders and instill fear in their supporters. Church sources place the figure still higher. Refugees interviewed along the border with Mexico have told harrowing stories of the destruction of their villages by Government security forces. **********President Rios Montt, providing answers to written questions, dismissed the charges as ''lies, falsely promoted by entities that aid subversion.'' **********''I can say with total honesty,'' he asserted, ''that I have never ordered the killing of one single person, much less 2,600.'' He said the Government was winning over the people because ''there is now in Guatemala a Government that is concerned with the wellbeing of 70 percent of the people, the ethnic Indians that inhabit the major part of our territory.'' Army Rules More Blunt **********The army, in its written rules of engagement, is somewhat more blunt in describing its means: ''Destroy, neutralize or capture the permanent or clandestine guerrilla forces; win back the civil population that supports or tolerates whatever form of subversion; protect the population and help it in its development.'' **********''Subversion,'' it adds, ''should be combated using its methods and techniques. A disinformation plan should always be in execution.'' Military officers assert that, while combating the guerrillas more aggressively in recent months, they did not intentionally kill civilians. **********''Whenever there is a clash between the army and the guerrillas, some civilians are lost,'' said a military officer at Santa Cruz del Quiche. **********Asked how many civilians had died in this manner, he said, ''Not as many as you would imagine from reading The New York Times or The Washington Post.'' **********Another officer added: ''There was a period of more force, with more combats, but we were careful. I wasn't an assasssin a year ago and I'm not an assassin now. I've been doing this for 20 years.'' Diminished Need Is Noted **********While President Rios Montt continues to seek some military aid - aircraft parts and other items but, he says, ''nothing sophisticated or expensive'' -his field officers say the need for this type of help has diminished. **********''We don't need any military help,'' a ranking officer said, ''not because we are self-sufficient but because the problem of subversion is not a military problem but a problem of economic development. We need economic help.'' **********While some here have taken encouragement from the military's recently increased attention toward providing aid to civilians, some concerns linger, particularly over what the Government's response would be if the guerrillas regrouped and renewed their efforts. **********''The real problem is that there has not been a change in any institution before or after,'' said a church worker. ''There are people who are untouched who were the masterminds of the last regime.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/02/world.main_headline: 38 Dead and 37 Are Missing As Typhoon Strikes in Japan
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/02/world.print_headline: 38 Dead and 37 Are Missing As Typhoon Strikes in Japan
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/02/world.body_text: **********Thirty-eight people were dead and another 37 were missing after a typhoon battered central Japan during the night from the Pacific into the Sea of Japan, the police said today. **********Officials said 78 people were injured as the storm caused floods and hundreds of landslides that destroyed homes and washed out bridges, roads and railway lines. **********Nearly 300 houses were destroyed, and 17,000 flooded and road and rail communications were disrupted over a widespread area, including parts of Tokyo, the police said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/28/busin.body_text: **********Otto G. Stolz, 40 years old, has resigned as chairman, president and chief executive officer of the Cannon Mills Company, effective May 30. **********He will serve the company as a consultant. **********Cannon, one of the nation's largest textile manufacturers, went private last month. David H. Murdock, a developer and investor from Los Angeles, bought out the public shareholders in a $413 million takeover. He will become chairman, president and chief executive officer, the company said. **********Mr. Stolz, a former law professor at Duke University, was an Assistant Secretary of Housing and Urban Development before joining the Kannapolis, N.C., company in September 1977 as senior vice president.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/24/busin.body_text: **********The Corning Glass Works filed suit yesterday against the Valtec Corporation charging infringement of four Corning patents related to fiber-optic waveguide products and manufacturing processes. **********Valtec denied that it had infringed on Corning patents. **********''We have explored the patent issue a number of different times,'' said Valtec's president, James R. Kanely. ''We have said and we still say that we don't believe we infringe on any valid Corning patents.'' **********Valtec, a joint venture of M/ A-Com, a Burlington, Mass., electronics company, and Philips Industries, N.V., the Dutch electronics giant, is the third-largest American producer of optical fibers after the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and Corning, according to Kessler Marketing Intelligence, a consulting firm in Newport, R.I. Optical fibers are hair-thin strands of glass in which telephone conversations and data are sent using pulses of light. **********Yesterday's suit was filed in the United States District Court in Springfield, Mass.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/02/world.main_headline: BRITAIN REPORTS SEIZING KEY HILLS OUTSIDE STANLEY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/02/world.print_headline: BRITAIN REPORTS SEIZING KEY HILLS OUTSIDE STANLEY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/02/world.body_text: **********British forces have seized vital high ground about 10 miles west of Stanley, the capital of the Falkland Islands, after only moderate fighting, military sources said tonight. **********The sources disclosed that paratroopers and Royal Marines had ousted Argentine soldiers manning small outposts on the summits of 1,504-foot Mount Kent and adjacent hills, from which Stanley is clearly visible in good weather. The hills form a sharp ridge overlooking a featureless plain leading to the capital and would give the British valuable positions for observation and possibly for artillery. **********British control of the whole ridge would expose enemy forces, bottled up on a thin finger of land jutting into the South Atlantic, to 105-millimeter howitzer fire from one direction and 4.5-inch naval gunfire from the other. **********No Britons Reported Killed **********According to the Press Association, Britain's national news agency, no Britons were killed in the fighting, which was said to have occurred among pockets of snow on the hillsides. The agency reported that some Argentines had been killed and fewer than 10 Britons wounded. **********In Buenos Aires, a brief military communique said that Argentine warplanes had bombed British positions on Mount Kent, which appeared to confirm the statements here that Britain now controlled the peak. **********Britain announced, meanwhile, that first estimates indicated that about 250 enemy soldiers had been killed in the severe fighting around Goose Green last Friday. Over the weekend, the Defense Ministry said that 1,400 Argentines had surrendered and that 16 Britons had been killed in the battle, by far the biggest of the war so far. Argentine Troops Accused **********Maj. Christopher Keeble, the acting commander of the battalion that took Goose Green, charged in a delayed radio broadcast from the front that Argentine soldiers had kept firing after raising white flags. **********''They fought until they realized they were beaten,'' Major Keeble told Jeremy Hands of Britain's commercial television service. ''Then they showed the white flag. Then they fought a bit further. That's what sickened me, especially when you look into the loss of one particular officer's life.'' **********The battalion commander, Lieut. Col. Herbert Jones, and two other officers were killed when they led a party of 20 men in wiping out a nest of Argentine heavy machine guns blocking the British advance. **********Brian Hanrahan of the BBC reported late tonight from the South Atlantic that drop tanks of napalm, together with instructions for fitting them to Pucara ground-support aircraft, had been found at Goose Green. British officers fear, he said, that the Argentines may have built up further stocks of napalm at Stanley for use in the climactic battle of the campaign. **********Although it imposed a news blackout on most operational details, the Defense Ministry reported that a C-130 Hercules supply plane had been shot down by a British Sea Harrier about 50 miles north of Pebble Island off West Falkland. **********Hercules transports are usually unarmed, although one was said to have dropped bombs near a British warship over the weekend.  Ian McDonald, the ministry spokesman, said the Harrier involved in downing the supply plane was based on the aircraft carrier Invincible, which Argentina claimed to have put out of action last week. Carrier Reported Undamaged **********Dispatches from the fleet, published in British newspapers this morning, said again that the Invincible was undamaged. They said that an Exocet sea-skimming missile, of the type that sank the destroyer Sheffield, had been fired but had flown wide of its target. **********The ministry also reported that the civilian container ship, Atlantic Conveyor, hit by an Exocet on May 25, had finally sunk. Mr.  McDonald declined to say whether any of the ship's cargo, which included Chinook helicopters and spare parts, had been saved. **********Few details were available, even from unofficial sources, of the operations around Mount Kent. The British main force is said to have reached the peak from the northwest and the Second Battalion of the Parachute Regiment, the victors at Goose Green, to have pushed into the same general area from the southwest. Some sources said that only advance elements had moved that far forward. **********Helicopter gunships and artillery were believed to be supporting the advancing British columns, as well as Sea Harriers. 2 Bridges on the Routes **********An important detail that remained unknown was whether British troops had crossed two strategic bridges that the Argentines may have mined - one spanning the Fitzroy River on the southern track across the island, the other spanning the Murrel River on the northern track. **********Unconfirmed reports here and in Buenos Aires said that a third British column was moving toward Stanley from the north. It was said to be composed of the 3,000 to 3,500 Gurkhas and Scots and Welsh Guards of the Fifth Brigade, who were said to have opened a second beachhead after landing from the assault ships Fearless and Intrepid. **********If Maj. Gen. Jeremy Moore, the marine officer commanding British ground forces, chooses to bring all his combat forces into the battle for Stanley, he will have 7,000 to 8,000 men -about the same number that the Argentines reportedly have in the capital. **********General Moore has two options, military analysts said: to launch an all-out attack on Stanley and its critically important airfield or to besiege it. He also has the authority to offer the Argentine commander, Brig. Gen. Mario Menendez, the chance to surrender, political sources said after a meeting of the war cabinet today. Labor M.P.'s Press Point **********Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher is coming under increased pressure from the opposition Labor Party to make such an offer to save bloodshed and avoid humiliation of the junta in Buenos Aires, in the hope that in such circumstances a long-term settlement might be easier. The Argentine Foreign Minister, Nicanor Costa Mendez, has said in the past that the word ''surrender'' is not in his Government's vocabulary. **********British journalists were told in background briefings at the Defense Ministry today that no all-out assault on Stanley would be possible until supplies had been brought up from the original beachhead on San Carlos Bay, now more than 40 miles behind the British spearheads. But such briefings have sometimes proved incorrect in recent days. **********At the beachhead, arrangements were completed for the transfer of men wounded in earlier fighting. A group of 18 injured British soldiers and sailors, plus 24 Argentine crew members from the fishing boat Narwal, which the British say was spying on the task force, are to be landed in Montevideo, Uruguay, on Wednesday morning by the hospital ship Hecla, the Defense Ministry said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/12/world.body_text: **********Last weekend in Tirana, the Albanian capital, the Communist Government sponsored a conference on the ethnic roots of that small Balkan nation that carried implications for its territorial claims on neighboring Yugoslavia and Greece. **********The goal of the conference, according to Prof. Aleks Buda, president of the Albania Academy of Sciences, was to underline ''the Illyrian-Albanian continuity and autochthony of the Albanians in their historical territories,'' which he defined as stretching deep into the Serbian and Montenegrin portions of Yugoslavia as well as into northern Greece. **********Professor Buda, the organizer of the conference held July 2-4, said in a recent interview on Albanian television that the conference would bring to light new evidence showing the connection between modern Albanians and the pre-Christian Illyrians. Problems Sighted for Neighbors **********The premise that Albanians since ancient times have had a homeland that stretches well beyond present frontiers could become worrisome to both Yugoslavia and Greece, each of which has Albanian minorities. **********In the case of Yugoslavia, the Albanian minority, with a very high birthrate, now numbers 1.7 million, most of them living in Kosovo Province abutting northeastern Albania. Since the winter of 1981 Kosovo has been the scene of repeated irredentist riots, the worst of which caused nine deaths. **********For several years the Tirana leadership under the Communist Party secretary, Enver Hoxha, the longest-ruling leader in the Balkans, has been circulating maps of a Greater Albania that encompasses an area more than twice the size of contemporary Albania. **********But the National Conference Devoted to the Formation of the Albanian People, Their Language and Culture, convening under Mr.  Hoxha's aegis, would appear to carry the national goals a step beyond the maps. Albania acquired its modern frontiers by fiat of the great powers at the end of the first Balkan War in 1912. Historical-Political Significance **********While most scholars over the last century appear to agree that the Albanians probably derive from the ancient Illyrians, a group of tribes that spread up the Adriatic Coast to the edge of present-day Italy and eastward to the Danube, the conference represents the first time that this academic assumption has acquired a historic-political connotation in terms of Albanian territorial claims. **********In effect, Professor Buda asserted that today's Albanians - the 2.7 million in Albania proper and the nearly 2 milllion beyond the frontiers - can trace their origins directly back to Balkan Peninsula people who came on the scene even before the Greeks. **********The Balkans are full of these kinds of backdated ethnic claims.  The contemporary Rumanians hark back to the ancient Dacians, who were conquered by the Romans in the second century; the Bulgarians look back to ancient Thrace; the Serbs recall a short-lived medieval empire that stretched across parts of Albania and Greece, and the Greeks, having ranged as far as Gilbraltar in the west and India in the east, also claim a chunk of Macedonia. Albanian Claim Is Oldest **********The Albanian-Illyrian claim is the oldest, however, since the Illyrians were colonized by Greeks in the seventh century B.C. They were cited by Herodotus and other Greek historians. They defied the expanding Roman Empire under their Queen, Teuta, and it took two Roman invasions to subdue them. The history of the Albanians, like that of the Illyrian tribes, has principally been a matter of internal feuds and struggles against invaders. **********Another Albanian scholar who played a central role in the Tirana conference was Prof. Androkli Kostallari, director of Tirana's Institute of Linguistics and Literature. He has specialized in tracing Albanian place names back to the Illyrians. His associate, Prof. Mahri Domi, spoke on ''the forming of the Albanian language.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/11/busin.body_text: **********The French franc slumped to a record low today of 7.085 to the dollar, or 14.1 American cents, as fears persisted that President Francois Mitterrand might be forced to devalue the currency for the third time since taking office 15 months ago. **********There was also conjecture among currency dealers that the troubles of the franc would force a realignment of the European Monetary System, perhaps next week. **********The decline of the once-strong franc has been steady under the Socialist Government. A year ago, before Mr. Mitterrand's first devaluation, the franc was worth 18 American cents; by last June, when the second devaluation occurred, it was at 14.6. **********Finance Minister Jacques Delors acknowledged today at a meeting with reporters that currency markets were in an ''agitated'' condition. But he asserted that the franc would not be devalued or removed from Europe's fixed exchange rate monetary system. ''These are perturbations we must face up to,'' he said. **********French officials argued privately that the Government was determined to resist the latest bout of speculation against the franc because it believed currency traders had failed to appreciate the nation's new austerity budget for 1983, which is intended to fight inflation and restore confidence in the currency. **********Dealers reported rumors that France might seek new international credits, perhaps from the other member countries of the European Monetary System, to help tide it over the current speculative wave while the new austerity measures, announced last week, take effect. **********Speculation against the franc was given impetus today by an analysis by the Lloyds Bank in London, which argued that the new pressure on the French Government showed that the markets were unconvinced by the budget-cutting measures planned by the Mitterrand Government. **********In particular, Lloyds mentioned France's big trade deficit and its inflation rate, still running at twice West Germany's despite a freeze on wages and prices, as reasons for concern about the franc's future. **********French bankers also expressed doubts about the Government's ability to get its new budget measures through a Parliament dominated by Socialists who are generally more leftist than the Cabinet. They also wondered whether the unions would agree to the wage restraint the Government is asking. **********Figures issued by the French central bank show that France is continuing to lose reserves as the authorities fight to hold the franc's parity. Last week, the central bank reported losses of the equivalent of about $142.5 million, after acknowledging a huge loss of the equivalent of about $570 million in the week ended Aug. 26. Rumors on Dual Rate **********In recent days, currency dealers have reported persistent rumors that the French authorities may be forced to introduce a dual exchange rate if the speculative pressure keeps up. This means that France would continue to maintain a fixed exchange rate for the franc against other European Monetary System currencies for designated ''commercial'' transactions involving imports and exports of goods. But a separate market would be set up for capital movements and for other transfers of money or purchases of currency. This would be the ''financial'' franc and would be allowed to float freely. **********Some French bankers believe that such a ''financial'' franc would depreciate to about eight francs to the dollar while the ''commercial'' franc would be at a better rate. **********From the Government's point of view, a split exchange rate would insulate the French reserves against speculative capital outflows, though not against losses resulting from the trade deficit.  Politically, it would enable President Mitterrand to maintain that he had not devalued the franc or withdrawn it from the European Monetary System, which Francehelped create three years ago. ---- Gold and Silver Off By The Associated Press **********Gold fell $6 an ounce yesterday, to $442, on the New York Cmmodity Exchange, after having risen earlier in the day. In later United States trading, gold was quoted at $444 an ounce bid by the Republic National Bank, down $1. **********In Europe, gold fell $24 an ounce in early trading in London after losing more than $40 in Hong Kong. It recovered later, however, to close at $456.50 in London, down from $472.50 on Thursday. **********The dollar continued its weeklong climb, reaching record highs in relation to the lira and the Danish krone, as well as the French franc. **********Late dollar rates in New York, compared with Thursday, were: 2.5080 West German marks, up from 2.4913; 7.1025 French francs, up from 7.0400; 2.1400 Swiss francs, up from 2.1243; 263 yen, up from 259.35, and 1.2373 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2331. The British pound fell to $1.7108 from $1.7225.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/06/busin.body_text: **********This area has its own unmistakable signs of spring. John Deere turns its swans loose to strut around the manicured grounds of the company's headquarters. And the Deere factories usually switch into high gear to get ready for the year's peak selling season. **********But spring has come late to the Middle West this year, and a slackening in the demand for agricultural equipment has been one result of that delay. Consequently, Deere & Company, the farm implement industry's largest and most profitable company, is cutting back at a time when it normally would be expanding. **********Last week, Deere told its salaried workers, a proud and pampered group that has escaped the agony of its counterparts at the troubled International Harvester Company and Massey-Ferguson Inc., that it was freezing all salaries. Merit raises and a stock purchase plan were also canceled. **********A few days before that shock, Deere predicted a ''serious decline'' in earnings this year and announced it would slash production schedules by an additional 5 percent, dropping the level of output to 15 percent below last year's rate. The move was especially surprising because many economic forecasters have said that inventory cutting has run its course, and are predicting that a recovery is imminent. Does Not See a Recovery **********But Deere's president, Robert A. Hanson, does not see any recovery in the farm equipment and construction machinery areas - at least not yet. **********''Retail demand by farmers and contractors just isn't very strong right now,'' he commented. ''We looked for strengthening in December, January and Februray, but we didn't see that. So we're trimming to make sure we don't end up with too much invento@ry.'' **********At Deere, a well-disciplined and conservative organization where management decisions are made by consensus, the predominant feeling is that interest rates will stay high enough to keep demand for farm equipment, its main product line, below the anemic levels of last year. **********In the business and financial community, Deere has earned a sparkling reputation for planning and execution. In four decades, it outstripped competitors by building a strong balance sheet and an enviable dealer network. Heavy investment in new plants and modern equipment has made it the low-cost producer of farm equipment. **********But the recession in the farm economy, the worst since the 1930's, is blemishing Deere's remarkable performance. Fourteen percent of its 50,000 workers are already unemployed, with more layoffs on the horizon. Profits rose to $251 million in 1981 from $228 million the year before, but return on equity plummeted to 11.6 percent in 1980 and 11.8 percent in 1981, from 17.8 percent in 1979. **********And the situation promises to get worse. Exports, a significant part of Deere's business, have been eroded by the strength of the dollar. Commodity prices are low. Farm income, which fell 13 percent last year, to $19 billion, according to Continental Bank, is not expected to improve this year. In Deere's first quarter, which ended in January, profits fell 11 percent, to $33.7 million, on sales of $1.06 billion. **********''The farm equipment market is far different than anything we've ever seen,'' said Boyd C. Bartlett, senior vice president for farm equipment, ''Three companies are in trouble and they're liquidating inventory at distressed prices, trying to turn their product into cash.'' **********Massey-Ferguson announced recently that it would offer rebates of up to $5,500, or financing at 11 percent for one year, to buyers of some farm and construction equipment. Robert J. Gerstenberger, Deere's senior vice president for the construction business, said that on some $130,000 tractors discounts of up to $45,000 are common among makers - discounts that Deere refuses to match. A Strategic Decision **********Analysts said that Deere has made a strategic decision to trim inventories rather than prices.  ''They would rather sacrifice market share in the near term than destroy the integrity of their pricing structure,'' said John McGinty, at the First Boston Corporation. **********Deere insists that its inventories in the field are in better shape than its competitors, even though dealers owe the company almost $400 million more than they did at this time last year. Deere, and its competitors, generally extend credits to dealers for several months before they demand payment. **********These policies may have aggravated the inventory problem in the field, because dealers were looking for an upturn in the spring.  ''We have some big tractors that I wish we didn't have; I don't think we're going to sell them,'' says James M. Curless, owner of the Ruim Equipment Company in Lowell, Ind. He said that if business did not improve soon, he might have to lay off some of his 11 employees. **********Parts and raw materials have also piled up in Deere's warehouses, despite a computerized inventory control program started four years ago. Under the program, the company has learned to live with a oneand-a-half day supply of tires instead of a five- or six-day supply. **********And Robert W. Boecke, a senior vice president at Deere, said that the company was working toward the Japanese ''just in time'' model, which gets parts and materials to the plant only 30 minutes before they are needed. **********The recent decision to retrench will take time to implement, Mr.  Boecke said: ''It'll probably be the end of the summer before we get to the level we're comfortable with.'' **********As part of its austerity program, Deere has also asked its suppliers for a 2 percent across-the-board price cut, and has reduced capital spending to $175 million, half the planned level. **********Because of the capital spending revisions, the combines plant here in Moline will have to slow its modernization and expansion. The new modern paint shop that will use robot technology will have to wait a few years, as will other projects. **********But analysts said that Deere stood alone in facilities and technology. It has the country's most modern tractor plant at Waterloo, Iowa - one result of a recent $1.3 billion capital investment program. And the $175 million in capital programs is all going into product improvement. **********That augurs well for the company when the markets regain their strength. ''In five to ten years, I expect their market share to go from 35 percent to 50 percent,'' says First Boston's Mr. McGinty.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/26/busin.body_text: **********I. Martin Pompadur, 47 years old, will step down as president of the Ziff Corporation on July 31, Ziff has announced. Mr. Pompadur has made a preliminary deal for the purchase of four of Ziff's six television stations. **********The privately held company, which is based in New York, decided last year to sell its television stations and expand its operations in magazine publishing, which is its primary business. **********Industry sources said Mr. Pompadur's successor as Ziff's president was expected to be either its chairman, William Ziff, 52, who would retain the chairmanship, or Philip Korsant, 38, who is executive vice president. **********''I want to be involved in more facets of the entertainment and communications business than just print,'' Mr. Pompadur said Friday.  ''My background has been really in all facets of the business - radio, television, news, sports, the theater business,'' and others. **********Ziff is the parent company of the Ziff-Davis Publishing Company, which publishes 52 magazines; Ziff-Davis Broadcasting, which owns the television stations; Wharton Econometric Forecasting Associates, and other enterprises. It does not disclose its revenues and earnings. **********Mr. Pompadur said that about $60 million was the expected price for the four stations, which are in Augusta, Ga.; Saginaw, Mich.; Rochester, and Steubenville, Ohio. The purchase, which requires approval by the Federal Communications Commission, is to be made by a proposed partnership, with Mr. Pompadur as general partner. **********After a boyhood in Stamford, Conn., Mr. Pompadur graduated from Williams College and Michigan Law School and spent 17 years with the American Broadcasting Companies, becoming a director and assistant to the president before joining the Ziff Corporation as senior vice president in 1977. He moved up to president in 1978. **********Mr. Pompadur joined ABC after a friend sat near ABC's general counsel on a train and heard him say he wanted to hire a young lawyer. She said quickly: ''I've got a terrific lawyer for you.'' **********Mr. Pompadur married Joan Lynn Krassner in 1960 and they have two children.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/18/busin.main_headline: PLANT USE SET A LOW LAST MONTH
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/18/busin.print_headline: PLANT USE SET A LOW LAST MONTH
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/18/busin.body_text: **********With nearly a third of production lines idle, the nation's factories operated last month at their lowest levels of capacity since the Government began keeping records in 1948, the Federal Reserve reported today. **********Capacity utilization now stands at only 68.4 percent, below the 69 percent rate posted during March 1975, the final month of the 1973-75 recession. **********This latest piece of grim industrial news means not only that a major part of the economy continued to decline in October but also, according to some economists, that when recovery comes, many American factories may not be equipped to meet it. **********Another troubled sector, the construction industry, took some comfort from a report today showing that while October home starts were up only 1 percent from September, permits for future construction, spurred by lower interest rates, were up 17.7 percent.  (Page D11.) **********Oil, Steel Capacity Lost **********''We clearly are losing capacity'' as unneeded plants are closed or mothballed, asserted William C. Dunkelberg, chief economist for the National Federation of Independent Business. This, he added, ''raises the specter of bottlenecks'' when demand picks up again. **********A Federal Reserve economist, who asked that he not be identified, said today that he was working on new revisions of the nation's industrial capacity that would be made available within the next several weeks. **********''We're looking at the whole issue right now,'' he added, noting that ''I have a lot of evidence'' of significant declines in such sectors as oil refining and steel production. **********Indeed, low as the utilization figures are, they would be even lower if capacity were not being eliminated by plant closings.  The Gulf Oil Corporation, for example, has closed refineries in Toledo, Ohio, and Venice, La., during the current recession. This has had the effect of reducing its capacity to process oil even as it raised its utilitization rate to more than 80 percent. The industry average for the week ending Nov. 5 was 70 percent, up from a low of 64.6 percent in February. **********At the Inland Steel Company's Indiana Harbor works, the nation's biggest steel plant, only three of nine blast furnaces are now operating and the 76-inch hot-strip mill and the 14-inch bar mill are about to be idled for a week. Such shutdowns make inroads in employment levels as well as capacity. More than 5,300 Inland workers are on indefinite layoff. Idle Capacity Actually Doubled **********Economists caution that the capacity utilization figures are not as reliable as many other statistical series and the Fed itself notes that even in normal times plant utilization never approaches 100 percent. From 1955 to 1979, the rate for manufacturing averaged about 83 percent with a high of 88 percent in 1973. **********This means that the amount of idle plant capacity is now about twice as great as in normal times - one-third of the total instead of about one-sixth. **********Despite the deficiencies of the utilization index, which registered a decline of eight-tenths of a percentage point last month, its current readings are a source of concern, economists said. **********''I worry about it,'' the Fed economist said, ''because it shows the industrial part of the economy is very weak.'' He also noted that last month's declines were spread broadly among the various categories. **********The automobile industry skidded to an operating rate of 49.7 percent last month, six points above its February low but far below the 61.3 percent recorded as recently as July, today's report showed. **********The rate for producers of industrial materials fell one-half point, to 67.2 percent, putting it below its previous record low of last June. **********Within manufacturing, the operating rate for advanced processing industries fell 1.1 point, to 69.8 percent, while the rate for the primary processing industries fell three-tenths of a point, to 65.8 percent. Permanent Losses **********The utilitization rate for producers of durable goods materials fell one point, to 61 percent, as producers of raw steel, aluminum, parts for consumer durables and parts for equipall curtailed operations. **********The rate for the production of energy materials, however, rose six-tenths of a point, to 78.5 percent.  Mr. Dunkelberg observed that some of the plant capacity that was being more or less permanently lost because of closure, age or lack of maintenance would probably never be needed again. This is because of shifts in the economy itself, such as the progressively higher proportion of it based on services. **********''Some of it,'' however, he added, ''you worry about because it doesn't come back very easily.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/28/busin.main_headline: Dow Declines 2.67, to 822.77; Weakness In Utilities
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/28/busin.print_headline: Dow Declines 2.67, to 822.77; Weakness In Utilities
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/28/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices gave ground yesterday as additional companies reported lower profits for the June quarter. Xerox and Avon Products, former glamour stocks, each sold at their lowest prices in many years after announcing a decline in earnings. **********The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 2.67 points, to 822.77, its fifth straight setback. Over all, declining issues outpaced advances by 886 to 503. Volume expanded to 45.7 million shares from Monday's 37.7 million. **********Utility stocks continued weak after scoring gains earlier this year in response to declining interest rates and other factors.  ''Tax considerations are sending electric utilities lower,'' stated Charles S. Comer of Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc.  The Senate has passed a measure that would repeal the tax-free reinvestment of utility dividends and a Senate-House conference will decide its fate. The reinvestment provision was part of the Tax Act of 1981. Yesterday, the Dow Jones utility average fell 1.20 points, to 104.79, down from a high of 116.95 on May 7. **********Xerox, the volume leader, dropped 1 1/2, to 30, after selling at its lowest level since 1964. The stock hit a high of 171 7/8 just 10 years ago, after the Xerox copier swept to fame and fortune. After releasing lower earnings yesterday, the company said it expects the next 18 months to be a difficult period. **********Avon Products fell 3/4, to 20 7/8, selling at its lowest price in eight years. In its heyday as a glamour stock, Avon traded at 140 in 1973. The company has declared a quarterly dividend of 75 cents a share since June 1980. It currently yields about 14 percent annually.  Dividend Cut Predicted **********''I think there's almost no question that directors will cut the quarterly dividend - probably to 50 cents -when they meet on Aug.5,'' said Daniel J. Meade of the First Boston Corporation. **********Polaroid, another former glamour issue that once traded at 149 1/2, rose 1 3/8, to 21 3/4, after reporting better-than-expected operating earnings. Analysts said the resignation of Edwin H. Land, the company's founder, as chairman, was another factor helping the stock, on the rationale that his successors would emphasize new areas such as industrial photography. **********AMF Inc. fell 1 1/8, to 15 1/4, after reporting lower profits.  In over-the-counter trading, Intergraph Corporation fell 4 1/8, to 18 3/4, evidently in response to disappointing June-quarter profits.  The Nasdaq market value index declined 0.74, to 170.71. **********The American Stock Exchange's market value index dropped 1.04, to 254.22.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/04/world.main_headline: RIFT ON SALVADOR GROWS IN CONGRESS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/04/world.print_headline: RIFT ON SALVADOR GROWS IN CONGRESS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/04/world.body_text: **********Congress appears to be increasingly divided over the decision to send more aid to El Salvador, but for the moment the Administration seems to have majority support for its policy of trying to prevent the overthrow of the Salvadoran Government. **********At a news conference today, Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. said, ''I hear some rising objections to what Haig is doing from within the Democratic Party and from my area at home.'' **********But his fellow Democrat, Representative Jim Wright of Texas, the majority leader, said in an interview, ''I agree with the Administration position, and I very actively oppose any effort to withhold assistance to the moderate Government of Duarte.'' Two Unappealing Choices **********Perhaps the most frequent reaction on Capitol Hill, however, was expressed by Senator J. James Exon, Democrat of Nebraska, who said the United States had two unappealing choices. ''If we turn down the additional aid,'' he said, ''we could be helping the Communist guerrilla takeover of the country. But on the other hand, we'd be aiding a Government we're not happy with. The bottom line is, which is the lesser of two evils?'' **********Some members of Congress have long criticized the human rights record of President Jose Napoleon Duarte, the leader of El Salvador's military-civilian junta. There have been frequent criticisms, for example, of his Government's investigation of the murder in December 1980 of four American churchwomen there. Those murders prompted Congress to require the Administration to certify that El Salvador was making progress on restoring human rights before it could continue receiving aid. **********The latest protest on Capitol Hill was triggered by the White House decision to certify that El Salvador was making such progress and could therefore receive $135 million in aid this fiscal year.  Officials have said this amount was to be increased and the Administration has said it would send $55 million more from unrestricted Pentagon funds. In Congressional testimony yesterday, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. vowed that Washington would do ''whatever is necessary'' to prevent the overthrow of the Salvadoran Government by leftist guerrillas. **********In reply, more than 30 members of Congress introduced a resolution opposing the President's certification. The resolution appears to have little chance of passing, and some lawmakers said it would have no legal force even if it did. But it indicated a significant segment of Congressional opinion. **********In another move, more than 50 lawmakers wrote to President Reagan, asking him to withdraw the certification. An organizer of the effort, Representative Richard L. Ottinger, Democrat of Westchester, declared: ''We want the President to know that we can not accept a certification based on facts that were pulled out of a hat. His assessment simply flies in the face of realit y. There is compelling evidence that the human rights violations in El Salvador have never been more brutal and widespread.'' Memory of Vietnam **********Representative O'Neill said today that many Roman Catholics, including priests and nuns who have served as missionaries in El Salvador, were expressing their concern to members of Congress.  Representative Thomas S. Foley of Washington, the majority whip, said he had heard from many religious officials, not just Catholics.  ''There's a lot of concern out there,'' he said, ''and I don't think the Administration is sufficiently aware of it.'' **********Alluding to Vietnam and a not uncommon concern, Senator Donald W.  Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan, said: ''In the past the United States has gotten itself deeply involved in situations by doing it a step at a time. At some point we cross a line and we find ourselves making a commitment of resour ces and prestige without doing it carefully.'' **********Mr. Riegle also worries that in a time of tight budgets the United States cannot afford a major commitment to El Salvador. ''I'll be very blunt,'' said Mr. Riegle, whose home state leads the nation in unemployment, ''we need an aid package for Detroit.'' **********Others say Secretary Haig has increased concern on Capitol Hill.  ''My reaction is that he doesn't care about listening to Congress,'' said Mr. Foley, who added, ''I think we are playing a macho game in El Salvador.'' Few Alternatives Seen **********Despite the criticism, many in Congress seem inclined to support the Administration on a difficult issue. For example, Representative Clement J. Zablocki, the Wisconsin Democrat who heads the Foreign Affairs Committee, said, ''I'm not completely satisfied with the Duarte Government, but what is the alternative?'' **********Those who oppose aid to the country, Mr. Zablocki said, ''want to write El Salvador off to the fate of Cuba or Nicaragua.'' He added: ''I'm not of that opinion. This Administration would be condemned if it didn't try to keep El Salvador from becoming Communist.'' **********''The Administration was criticized last week because it wasn't strong enough in Poland,'' Representative Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican whip, complained. ''How can you win?'' **********While some legislators remembered Vietnam, others remembered Cuba and said the United States made a mistake in not resisting Fidel Castro's takeover more actively. ''I can't believe,'' said Representative Wright, ''that the Batista Government, with all its corruption, was as bad as the bloodbaths that followed in the wake of Castro.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/23/world.main_headline: STAFF IS REDUCED AT TIMES OF LONDON
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/23/world.print_headline: STAFF IS REDUCED AT TIMES OF LONDON
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/23/world.body_text: **********Rupert Murdoch, the owner of The Times of London and The Sunday Times, risked their future tonight by ordering the dismissal of 210 employees despite the opposition of trade unions. **********Mr. Murdoch, the Australian who bought the two papers a year ago, issued the dismissal order following the failure of 10 hours of lastditch negotiations. He had threatened to close The Times and The Sunday Times if the unions refused to accept his plan to stem losses running at the rate of more than $25 million a year, but he expressed hope after the breakdown in the talks that he could keep publishing. **********However, a union official hinted strongly that the papers would be hit by an immediate strike.  ''We have already decided not to accept the dismissals,'' said Barry Fitzpatrick, who heads the clerical branch at The Times of the National Society of Operative Printers, Graphical and Media Personnel. ''If he dismisses people on the scale he says he plans, it will not be possible to bring out the two papers.'' **********Original Deadline Extended **********After more than a decade of mounting losses, labor troubles and periodic closedowns, Mr. Murdoch had decided upon severe staff cutbacks as the only means of survival. He had set a deadline for Sunday night for agreement by the trade unions, but he extended it for 24 hours, with the possibility of another 24-hour extension if an agreement on the principles of an settlement had been reached by late tonight. **********Union and management negotiators plunged into talks this morning, but they failed to work out an agreement, despite the statement of a spokesman for News International Ltd., Mr. Murdoch's holding company, that closing would begin by noon Tuesday in the absence of an agreement. **********Just before 10 P.M., Mr. Murdoch and the union men appeared in the lobby of the newspaper's offices. The publisher, who owns other papers here, in Australia and in the United States, including The New York Post, read a formal statement. Clerical Branch Assailed **********After announcing the failure to reach agreement on staff levels, he said that some of the unions involved had shown ''good will,'' but that the clerical branch of the printers' union, which had been asked to give up a large number of jobs, had given no ''sensible response.'' **********He went on: ''This means that tomorrow morning mandatory notices go out to 210 clerical staff. These are the minimum immediate requirements - and they are made in the clerical department because that is the most grossly overmanned in the industry. The company invites everyone who works for The Times and The Sunday Times to come in as usual. If production continues, we hope that the present negotiations can resume and can be concluded with urgency.'' **********The publisher clearly hoped to split the printers' union from the other unions by restricting the dismissals to the most militant group, hoping the others would accept his action to save their jobs.  Implicitly, he backed away from his threat to close the papers if he got no agreement on the staff cuts. Formula Reported Modified **********But officials of other newspapers doubted that the unions would permit Mr. Murdoch to succeed.  Originally, he had demanded the elimination of 600 full-time employees and equally large reductions in shifts worked by part-time staff members. He reportedly modified that formula during Sunday's meetings, agreeing to consider a different pattern of reductions that would save about the same amount. **********In recent months, The Times has been losing almost $600,000 a week, and The Sunday Times, once a big money-maker, has also slipped into the red. Together, they have a full-time workforce of 2,600 people. **********Mr. Murdoch is believed to be planning to put Times Newspapers Ltd. into receivership if he cannot get the staff cuts he wants, then to try to revive them - perhaps as a single, seven-day-a-week newspaper - some weeks or months later. But he will be able to do that only if the two newspaper titles can be protected from subsequent sale.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/04/world.main_headline: POPE ASSAILS SCIENTISTS' STRESS ON ARMS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/04/world.print_headline: POPE ASSAILS SCIENTISTS' STRESS ON ARMS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/04/world.body_text: **********Pope John Paul II said today that the concentration of scientific effort on the development of arms of war was ''a scandal of our times.'' **********Speaking to a gathering of scientists on the fourth day of his pastoral tour of Spain, the Pope said: ''Men and women who represent science and culture, your moral power is enormous. **********''It is you who can see to it that the scientific sector serves above all the culture of man and that it should never be perverted and used for his destruction. It is a scandal of our times that many researchers are dedicated to perfecting new arms for war, which one day could prove fatal.'' **********The formal character of the Pope's meeting with the scientists this morning contrasted sharply with the last event of his crowded schedule. This evening, in the country's largest soccer stadium, where only a few months ago Italy beat West Germany for the World Cup, the Pope seemed moved close to tears by the boundless enthusiasm of about 140,000 students and other young people. Traffic in Capital Stalled **********They packed every inch of the stands and field except for an area cleared around the stage, singing, shouting and jumping joyously and waving Spanish, papal and Polish flags. **********Not only the Pope's every gesture, but also the remarks addressed to him by representatives of Spanish youth, were greeted with thunderous cheers, which were taken up by the large crowds massed outside the stadium in the heart of the capital. For the second evening in a row, traffic in Madrid was almost at a standstill as the center of the city was given over to a papal fiesta. **********The Pope, who said the meeting was one of those to which he had looked forward the most, struck familiar themes in his address.  ''In the face of the manipulation of which he may feel himself the object by means of drugs, exaggerated sex, violence, the young Christian will not search for methods of action that will lead him to the spiral of terrorism,'' he said. ''That would lead him to the same or worse evil than that which he criticizes and deprecates. **********''He does not lapse into insecurity and demoralizaiton, nor does he take refuge in empty paradises of escapism or indifference. Nor drugs, nor alcohol, nor sex, nor a resigned and uncritical passivity are a response to evil.'' 'Consciences Must Be Awakened' **********The Pope was repeatedly interrupted not only by applause but also by frequent ''yesses,'' roars of approval and the shouting of slogans declaring his listeners' love for him. **********While the Pope often underlined his remarks to the young people with a warning index finger, he adopted a more somber tone in his speech to the scientists. **********''Consciences must be awakened,'' he said. ''Your responsibility and possibilities of influence on public opinion are immense. Make them serve the cause of peace and real progress of man. What marvels can be realized in our world if the best talents and the best researchers took each other by the hand to explore the roads of development of all men and all regions of the earth.'' **********Pope John Paul also met today with representatives of the Polish and Jewish minorities.  He urged the Poles to keep up their national traditions and faith, especially in these difficult days of their nation, and wished the Jews ''Shalom.'' He celebrated mass at a new church in a barren modern working-class section. **********Tomorrow the Pope will resume a schedule of travel through the provinces that will last until his return to Rome next Tuesday night.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/15/busin.body_text: **********The chairman of the Senate Banking Committee today introduced a bill that would use Government-backed promissory notes to bolster the net worth of ailing savings and loan associations and mutual savings banks. **********The bill, introduced by Senator Jake Garn, Republican of Utah, gives Federal regulatory authorities the power to issue the promissory notes in exchange for ''capital certificates'' from the thrift institutions, the effect of which would be to increase their net worth or capital accounts. **********An institution's net worth is equal to its assets minus its liabilities. **********The aid would be given to a thrift institution where the net worth has dropped to 3 percent of total assets or less. The measure, however, differs from a bill approved by the House Banking Committee last Tuesday. **********The House proposal, sponsored by Representative Fernand J. St Germain, the Rhode Island Democrat who heads the banking panel, limits aid to institutions with a net worth of 2 percent of assets or less, and would set up an $8.5 billion Treasury-backed fund to guarantee the net worth of failing thrift units. **********According to Senator Garn, the plan introduced today would not need any appropriations from Congress, but extends the promise of Federal aid by expanding the emergency powers of the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. **********Senator Garn said that Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan took part in the discussions that led to the proposal, but he declined to say whether President Reagan would endorse his bill. Hearings are planned during the last week of May.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/01/busin.main_headline: Professor Is Appointed Stanford Business Dean
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/01/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Professor Is Appointed Stanford Business Dean
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/01/busin.body_text: **********Robert K. Jaedicke, a professor of accounting, was named yesterday as dean of the Stanford Graduate School of Business effective Jan. 1.  Mr. Jaedicke, 53, succeeds Rene C. McPherson, 58, who announced his intention to resign in June, citing health and personal reasons.  Mr. Jaedicke, who will be the sixth dean of the school and the first elected from its faculty in 25 years, had served as acting dean from 1979 to 1980 and as associate dean for academic affairs from 1969 to 1981. He holds the endowed William R. Kimball professorship of acounting. **********Stanford said that the last dean promoted from within the business faculty was J. Hugh Jackson, who served from 1931 to 1958. The last three deans - Mr. McPherson, Arjay Miller and Ernest C. Arbuckle - were all corporate executives. **********Professor Jaedicke said he would not make any radical changes at Stanford but would continue to emphasize what he called the school's current strengths - finance, accounting and marketing. He added that he hoped to develop the school's international programs for executives overseas and its programs aimed at strengthening ties between government and business. **********''I just don't believe what is necessary is to come in and shake things up, that is, to change things abruptly,'' said Professor Jaedicke, who received his bachelor's and master's degrees from the University of Washington and his Ph.D. from the University of Minnesota. **********Professor Jaedicke said he considered research to be Stanford's greatest strength. In contrast to the Harvard Business School, where research is directed toward development of case studies for business, Stanford has prided itself on blending practical research with theory. **********Professor Jaedicke came to Stanford in 1961 after teaching at the University of Minnesota and at Harvard.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/17/world.main_headline: MUBAREK LETTER REASSURES BEGIN ON SINAI PULLOUT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/17/world.print_headline: MUBAREK LETTER REASSURES BEGIN ON SINAI PULLOUT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/17/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Menachem Begin received a letter today from President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and was officially described as satisfied and pleased by the message. **********The Prime Minister's press secretary, Uri Porat, said Mr. Begin believed Egypt and Israel would be able to resolve their differences and ''there is no reason to reconsider the Israeli Government's resolution to complete the withdrawal or evacuation on time.'' **********The optmistic statement, which came in a flurry of diplomatic efforts to ease Egyptian-Israeli tensions, represented an abrupt shift in the mood from earlier in the week, when some Israeli officials were talking of postponing the withdrawal from Sinai because of what they called Egyptian violations of the treaty. The pullout is scheduled for April 25. **********New Document Is Proposed **********An aide to the Prime Minister said Israel had proposed a new document that would clarify several points in the treaty in an effort to avoid further problems. The document, to be signed by Israel, Egypt and the United States, would reaffirm a ban on hostile propaganda and a ban on arms smuggling across the new border, the official said. It would also elaborate several points in the military annex to the treaty to clear up what the official called misunderstandings. **********The document was proposed in a series of high-level consultations between Egyptian, Israeli and American officials that appeared to have soothed some of Israel's anxieties.  The proposal was taken by Deputy Secretary of State Walter J. Stoessel Jr. to Cairo, one of Mr. Begin's aides said. **********Mr. Stoessel flew to Cairo after a second round of talks this morning with Prime Minister Begin and other Israeli officials.  Egypt's Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, Boutros Ghali, also met with Mr. Begin, delivering the letter from President Mubarak. 'Promised to Do Everything' **********In addition, an Israeli official said that Egypt's chief of military intelligence, whose name was not given, arrived in Israel for talks on Israeli charges of the infiltration of weapons and explosives by the Palestine Liberation Organization through Sinai into the Israeli-controlled Gaza Strip. ''They promised to do everything they could to close this border to such activities,'' the official said. Egypt has denied that it has in any way countenanced such smuggling. **********Although the Israelis contend that they have repeatedly complained to Egypt about the smuggling, they were impressed that President Mubarak dispatched a high intelligence official to deal with the problem. **********Israel's Defense Minister, Ariel Sharon, met with Mr. Mubarak in Cairo Thursday and said when he returned that Egypt had agreed to remove troops and equipment that Israel said exceeded the deployment limits in the parts of Sinai already returned. ''General Sharon didn't have to work too hard to convince the Egyptians,'' one official said. The United States field mission in Sinai is to check Egyptian compliance beginning Saturday, according to Israeli radio.  The Egyptians have denied the charge of excessive troops, although they did say that Mr. Sharon had discussed it with Egyptian officials Thursday. Border Still in Dispute **********One area where disagreement remains, however, is the new border to be established between the two countries after the April 25 withdrawal. The line is in dispute at 15 points, most seriously on a stretch of beach called Taba, south of Eilat, where an Israeli conern is building a luxury hotel. Egypt and Israel both claim the territory. Egypt's Foreign Minister, Kamal Hassan Ali, is scheduled to visit Israel Sunday for talks on the subject. **********The letter to Mr. Begin from President Mubarak was described by an Israeli official as ''a very good letter,'' written in a warm tone and containing ''very many expressions of goodwill.'' **********The Egyptian leader reportedly assured Mr. Begin that the final withdrawal from the last third of Sinai would remove the last obstacle to fruitful relations and that Egyptian-Israeli ties would enter a new era. In that period, Mr. Mubarak was reported to have written, more Egyptians will be pleased to visit Israel and to establish contacts ''with their cousins and neighbors.'' **********The wording was described by an aide to Mr. Begin as highly encouraging and an indication that any Egyptian actions would not be undertaken at Israel's expense. ----

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/08/busin.body_text: **********Unemployment crept up last winter not only in the United States but also in its main industrial rivals, except for Japan, according to figures made available today by the Bureau of Labor Statistics. **********Japan, which has held its jobless down to a 2 percent range since a small increase of the late 1970's, was still at 2.2 percent at the beginning of this year. **********The latest United States figure, for the month of May, was 9.5 percent.  Both France and West Germany registered 5.5 percent in the first quarter of 1982, compared wth 5 percent in the last three months of 1981. **********Britain continued its steady rise, to 13 percent from 12.5 percent, though monthly figures showed a drop to 12.9 percent in April.  Italy's rate increased to 4.6 percent for the quarter, as against 4 percent for the last three months of 1981.  The statistics bureau adjusts figures on unemployment from each country to make them comparable to those of the United States.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/24/busin.body_text: **********The Dow Jones industrial average fell 9.01 points yesterday to finish below the 1,000 mark for the first time since the end of October as stock prices continued to retreat on relatively modest trading volume. **********The industrial average closed at 990.99, bringing its cumulative loss for the last three sessions to 41 points.  Drug issues, responding in part to disappointing profit gains for Syntex, were weak.  Ralph J. Acampora of Kidder, Peabody & Company said the Dow industrials now hover at a critical juncture. ''If we get a meaningful break below 990, which represents a near-term cushion, stock prices could decline further,'' he added. ''I think the next band of real support exists between 930 and 940.'' **********Some other technical analysts maintain that a support area exists slightly higher - at around 950.  Mr. Acampora said he believes the Dow has already made its high for this year at the record closing of 1,065.49 on Nov. 3. ''But all this nervous selling we're seeing will be healthy for the market in the long run,'' he hastened to add. **********Declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered the gainers by nearly 2 to 1.  Volume totaled 72.9 million shares. This compared with Monday's turnover of 75 million shares and 70.3 million shares last Friday, which marked the lowest daily turnover in nearly seven weeks. **********Syntex dropped 4 3/8 points, to 54 1/2, after reporting that profits for the quarter ended Oct. 31 rose to $1 a share from 92 cents a year earlier. However, since some drug analysts had expected earnings of $1.08 a share for the latest quarter, the stock became a target for selling. Earlier this month, Syntex shares traded at a record price of 61. **********Syntex said that, outside the United States, a strong dollar continued as a depressant on its sales and net income. Foreign markets are an important source of business - and profits - for major American drug companies. **********Elsewhere, Upjohn dropped 3 1/8, to 43 1/4, after selling as high as 47. There were declines of more than a point each in Merck, Squibb, Abbott Laboratories and SmithKline Beckman. **********Litton Industries, which announced lower quarterly earnings, dropped 1 3/4, to 49 1/2. However, American Stores rose 1 3/4, to 61 1/2. It reported sharply improved profits. **********Boeing, the best gainer on the active list, rose 1 1/4, to 29 1/2.  China agreed to purchase 10 Boeing jetliners.  The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, trading ex-dividend, declined 1/4, to 58 3/8. The nation's most widely owned stock fell 2 5/8 points last week, when the company announced plans to sell 15 million common shares. **********In over-the-counter trading, Pabst Brewing rose 2 1/8, to 27 5/8.  JMSL Acquiring said it had increased its offer to buy three million common shares of Pabst to $35 a share from $30. **********The Nasdaq composite index eased 0.62, to 225.17.  The American Stock Exchange's market value index dropped 2.91, to 326.25.
