https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/26/world.main_headline: HIJACKER OF PLANE IS SEIZED IN SICILY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/26/world.print_headline: HIJACKER OF PLANE IS SEIZED IN SICILY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/26/world.body_text: **********A hijacker seized an Alitalia Airlines jet carrying 109 people on a flight from Algiers to Rome today and forced it to land in Sicily where he was captured by the police, an airline official reported. **********Airport sources said that while the hijacker was negotiating over the radio, one of the crew members overpowered him and the police then swarmed into the cockpit and seized him. **********The authorities said no passengers were injured during the ordeal aboard the Boeing 727, which lasted about three hours. But they said a police officer had suffered a broken right arm while helping to subdue the hijacker. The plane, with 101 passengers and a crew of 8, was on a direct flight from Algiers to the Italian capital. **********The police identified the hijacker as Igor Shkuro and said he was a 37-year-old native of Leningrad who had been living in Rome. They said he was carrying several passports, including one from Australia, and that they had not determined when or why he had left the Soviet Union. No Motive Given **********Passengers said the hijacker told them that he was a former member of the Soviet merchant marine and had once served a prison term in Sydney, Australia. **********Officials gave no motive for Mr. Shkuro's action, but police sources said he had flown to Algiers on Friday hoping to establish residence there. They said the Algerian authorities refused to issue him a visa, however, and put him on the first available plane back to Rome - Alitalia flight AZ871. **********He drew a knife and commandeered the craft about 20 minutes after it left Algiers, officials said.  Lido Lanconella, a passenger who was sitting a few seats ahead of Mr. Shkuro, said: ''All of a sudden, he screamed and jumped up. I saw a long knife - about eight inches - in his hand as he headed toward the cockpit.'' **********The pilot said the hijacker had grabbed the flight engineer and held the knife against his side, demanding that the plane land in Tripoli, Libya. When the Libyan authorities refused permission to land, Mr. Shkuro ordered the pilot to fly to Valetta, Malta, the pilot said. He said he was able to convince the hijacker that the jet was running low on fuel and would have to land at Catania. Passengers and Crew Freed **********The hijacker had allowed all of the passengers and five of the eight crew members to leave the plane within a half hour after it touched down at Catania's Fontanarossa Airport. **********The pilot, Leonardo Senisi, said he and the co-pilot, Ezio Bertonini, grappled with the hijacker while the flight engineer, Donato Longo, let in police waiting outside the cockpit door. **********Airport officials said the plane landed at Catania, on the east coast of Sicily, at 8:30 P.M. (2:30 P.M. New York time), about three hours after it was commandeered. According to the airport officials, the plane was hijacked about 20 minutes after it left Algiers at 5:25 P.M. **********The most recent hijacking of an Alitalia airliner occurred June 30, when a Sri Lankan commandeered one of the airline's Boeing 747's and forced it to Bangkok, Thailand, where he threatened to blow it up on the ground with 263 people aboard. The hijacker freed his hostages in return for $300,000, a reunion with his estranged son and wife and safe passage to Colombo, Sri Lanka, where he was later arrested. **********In January 1980 a Tunisian hijacked an Alitalia DC-9 on a flight from Rome to Tunis and forced it to land in Palermo, Sicily. The hijacker, who had also tried to reach Libya, gave up after a 12-hour siege without gaining the release of 25 Tunisian prisoners whose freedom he had demanded.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/20/world.main_headline: FORMER PREMIER GAINS A NARROW VICTORY IN IRELAND
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/20/world.print_headline: FORMER PREMIER GAINS A NARROW VICTORY IN IRELAND
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/20/world.body_text: **********Former Prime Minister Charles J.  Haughey's Fianna Fail Party won a narrow and probably inconclusive victory this morning in Ireland's second general election in seven months. **********After 18 tortuous hours of tabulation of the ballots cast Thursday, it appeared unlikely that Mr. Haughey would command a clear majority of the 166-member Parliament. But Fianna Fail was certain to hold more seats than the coalition of the Fine Gael and Labor Parties, which formed the outgoing Government of Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald. **********With complete returns reported from 38 of the 41 multimember constituencies, Fianna Fail had captured 78 seats, with 59 for Fine Gael, 13 for Labor and 6 for minor parties and independents. **********The Irish television predicted that Fianna Fail would have 81 seats after the completion of the complex calculations under the country's system of proportional representation, with 78 for the coalition and 7 for the others. Fianna Fail's own election experts said Mr. Haughey could hope for no more than 83 seats. In either event, Mr. Haughey would be forced to negotiate with the independents to form a government. **********In effect, the election produced another stalemate between the major political groupings, tilted this time slightly toward Fianna Fail. Some politicians suggested that yet another election might be needed in coming months. **********Early this morning, Dr. FitzGerald declined to concede defeat and said it was still conceivable that he could carry on as Prime Minister. He said it was ''remarkable that our vote held up as well as it did, given the fact that we went to the country on so tough a program.'' **********Dr. FitzGerald's Cabinet fell last month when several of the independents on whom it had depended for its majority refused to support the extremely severe budget he proposed to deal with Ireland's fiscal crisis. To combat 23 percent inflation and 12 percent unemployment, the Prime Minister proposed major tax increases and a debt-reduction program. **********The campaign centered on economic issues, with relatively little attention to the problems in Northern Ireland. Candidates of Sinn Fein, the political arm of the Irish Republican Army, fared badly, as did the independent Republican, Bernadette Devlin McAliskey. **********Mr. Haughey has said that he will continue talks on Northern Ireland with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain - talks that he initiated several years ago and that Dr. FitzGerald continued. But Mr. Haughey is not prepared to follow up Dr. FitzGerald's promise of a crusade to make the Irish Republic less sectarian to reassure Protestants in the North about the consequences of Irish unification. **********During his term as Prime Minister, Mr. Haughey, who is 56 years old, borrowed heavily, and Dr. FitzGerald accused him in the campaign of fiscal irresponsibility. At first, Mr. Haughey argued that there was no reason for an austerity budget, but he quickly backtracked and said he would be forced to increase taxes if he was elected. **********Public-opinion polls showed him to be one of the least popular party leaders in Irish history, and he appeared to have hurt his party's performance. **********Among the independents who were elected was Jim Kemmy, the Socialist whose vote was the key in bringing down Dr. FitzGerald.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/07/busin.body_text: **********If there's any doubt about the trickle-down effect of Reaganomics, one need only enter a bookstore. The Government's new tax law has provoked a veritable flood of new tax guides. **********''Whenever there's a tax change you can expect these books to sell,'' said Ann McKowen, a spokesman for Avon Books, the publisher of ''The 1982 Income Tax Book'' by Sylvia Porter. ''A lot of people think the Reagan tax cuts are for them.'' **********Blanche Blante, a spokesman for Simon & Schuster, agrees. ''Tax preparation books always do well, but this year is incredible.'' Simon & Schuster is the publisher of two tax guides this year: ''J.K. Lasser's Your Income Tax'' and ''How You Can Profit From the New Tax Law,'' also written by the Lasser Institute. **********So far this year, Simon & Schuster says, ''Your Income Tax'' has sold well over 1.6 million copies at $5.95 a copy, compared with last year's sales of 890,000. **********And it's still early. ''Most people just wait until April to start buying.'' said Miss Blante.  When Americans buy these tax guides, they can deduct the price of the books from the statements they file with the Internal Revenue Service. But deciding which book to buy can be as mind-boggling as the tax law. **********Many of the how-to books are packaged in eye-catching gloss of yellow, red and orange. Sometimes they carry suggestive titles - ''Take it Off!,'' for example, is a $2.50 guide by Robert S. Holzman that was published by Harper & Row. **********Others suggest they contain opportunities to cut pretty close to the law -like Rosalie Minkow's ''Creative Tax Benefits,'' published by Ace Books and selling for $4.50. **********Some of the books tout the opportunities their authors have discovered to take more than 2,000 legitimate deductions.  At least two new books this year have been written by former I.R.S insiders. There's ''The 1982 Tax Fighters Guide'' by Philip Storrer and Brian K. Williams, and Paul N. Strassel's ''Money in Your Pocket, Using the New Reagan Tax Laws. **********Among the best sellers, according to the B. Dalton's Bookstore on Wall Street, are vastly revised and expanded editions of old standbys, including the Lasser guide and ''The H & R Block Family Financial Planning Workbook,'' published by Collier Books. Dalton also cites Karen W. Arenson's ''Guide to Making the Tax Law Work for You,'' published by Times Books. **********Sylvia Porter, the syndicated financial writer and author of ''Sylvia Porter's Money Book,'' has revised her 1981 tax book this year, too. More than 365,000 copies have been printed, which according to Avon is double the number printed last year. **********Although no single taxpaper is likely to be able to make 2,000 deductions on his 1981 tax form, here are some examples of what ''Take It Off!'' conside rs to be tax deductible, provided the taxpayer meet s certain criteria: hairpieces, deer hunting, organic foods, paint removal, acupunture, air conditioning, hair spray, flowers and s tereo systems. **********But not everyone is as enthusiastic about the new tax books. ''The problem with these how-to books is that some people stretch the deductions too far, and that's when they get in trouble,'' said Peter Elinsky, a partner with Peat Marwick, Mitchell & Co., a New Yorkbased accounting firm. ''People just fill in their forms and hope that they never get caught,'' he said. **********Jacqueline Wilson

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/23/busin.body_text: **********The country's leading personal computer manufacturers are betting that the fastest route to placing a small computer in every American living room is to first get one through the schoolhouse door. **********''The evidence shows that when you are trained on one computer system, it is easy to get hooked on it,'' said Benjamin Rosen, a New York analyst who specializes in personal computers. For that reason, companies like Apple, Tandy, I.B.M. and Warner Communications' Atari unit want students to learn from earliest youth how to use their equipment and the software, or computer instructions, that run it.  Eventually, the theory goes, the students or their families are likely to buy the same computers. **********Foremost among the companies riding the crest of what Mr. Rosen calls ''a tidal wave of personal computers sweeping the educational establishment'' is Apple. The Apple II is now in thousands of classrooms. **********Thousands more are likely if the company is successful in obtaining passage of the so-called Apple bill, Federal legislation that would allow companies to write off two times the manufacturing cost of all computer equipment they donate to primary and secondary schools in one of the next three years. **********Two months ago the bill passed the House of Representatives by a 323-to-62 vote. Another version, with more restrictive write-off provisions that Apple says may jeopardize its giveaway program, passed the Senate Finance Committee before the November recess. The full Senate is expected to take it up before the end of the year. **********While Apple Computer keeps one eye on the legislation, its other is trained on the International Business Machines Corporation, which has made huge inroads into the market since it announced its first personal computer in 1981. **********At first, the computer giant seemed to eschew the school market, but it has recently placed ads in education journals urging the use of I.B.M. equipment in classrooms from kindergarten to college.  I.B.M. said last Wednesday that accredited schools and colleges could receive ''price allowances'' of about 22 percent on the basic personal computer system. **********Rapid growth in the field is forecast. According to a study last year by Creative Strategies International, an industry analysis group, hardware and software for ''computer-aided instruction'' produced revenues of $2 billion in 1981. The study indicates the figure will exceed $13 billion by 1987. **********Last month, I.B.M. also joined with Carnegie-Mellon University in a project that should result in the placement of 7,500 I.B.M. computers in every dormitory room and faculty office on campus. ''Nobody is hiding the fact that we and Carnegie-Mellon are trying to develop a system that other universities will want to install'' by the late 1980's, Lewis Branscomb, a vice president of I.B.M. and its chief scientist, said in a recent interview. **********If successful, the I.B.M.-Carnegie Mellon project could combine the best features of relatively inexpensive personal computers and much more expensive time-sharing systems that connect users to a large central computer through a terminal that has no processing capability of its own. **********The so-called work stations under joint design by I.B.M. and the Carnegie-Mellon staff are expected to be several times more powerful than a personal computer, and would operate independently. That would enable users at an infinite number of work stations to perform complex operations quickly without overloading the central computer with demands from users on each terminal. **********I.B.M. and the university are also installing a large mainframe computer to store large files, a more efficient system than the record-like ''diskettes'' used to store permanent files in most home computers. Expansion via Cable TV **********The mainframe will enable each student and faculty member to communicate with others through their machines. Carnegie-Mellon is also negotiating with Warner Communications, which holds the cable television franchise for the Pittsburgh area, to make the system available to every household in the area. **********Under the Carnegie-Mellon plan, students would likely be required to buy their computer, and they would take it with them after graduation. **********There are hopes, too, that students familiar with computers will buy them before entering college.  ''That idea has not eluded us,'' conceded Frederick M. Hoar, vice president of communications for Apple. But the ''primary emphasis'' of the Apple bill, he added, ''is to improve computer literacy in the schools.'' He said Apple would not be the only beneficiary of the bill. **********While Apple's competitors did not oppose the House measure, they have given Apple no help in Washington. One I.B.M. employee, who asked not to be identified, said that if passage of the bill led to indiscriminate donations of computers ''some are going to be used as expensive doorstops.'' **********Ron G. Stegall, vice president of computer sales for Tandy, which markets Radio Shack computers, said, ''We are not certain that the American taxpayer should be subsidizing our portion of the tax burden.'' **********Others in the industry, however, say that some computer companies and even parents are putting pressure on the schools, particularly at the elementary level, to buy equipment they do not need or do not know how to use. **********While I.B.M., Apple and Tandy have led the race to put computers into the classroom, others have also made inroads, including Commodore, whose PET computer is attractive to some schools for its relatively low price, and Texas Instruments. **********While few question the usefulness of computers at the college level, some students at Carnegie-Mellon have protested that purchasing a computer, at a cost of about $3,000, will add significantly to the price of an education. **********University officials say that in a decade, so much of the university's resources will be centered on the computer system that a work station will be as necessary as a library card. **********Whether computers will ever become that prevalent on campuses is still in doubt. So far, I.B.M. has committed itself only to an investment of about $20 million over three years at Carnegie-Mellon.  ''But this is phase one,'' Dr. Branscomb one. ''We're not counting on it going down the tubes.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/25/busin.main_headline: Dow Off 6.25, to 919.52; Volume at 7-Week Low
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/25/busin.print_headline: Dow Off 6.25, to 919.52; Volume at 7-Week Low
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/25/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices retreated yesterday as investors worried over the uncertain course of interest rates and the timing of the economic upturn. **********Volume sank to a seven-week low.  The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 6.25 points, to 919.52.  For the week, the indicator advanced 2.58 points, thanks to an 18 1/2-point surge on Tuesday that was sparked by a bond market rally and carried equity prices to a 13-month high at 934.79. **********Yesterday's turnover contracted to 54.6 million shares from Thursday's 68.3 million as professional money managers reduced their activity. It marked the slowest trading since 44.7 million shares changed hands on Friday, Aug. 13, the day that the market began its extraordinary rally. On Aug. 12, the Dow had finished at 776.92. Earnings Estimates Cut **********''Wall Street analysts are continuing to cut their 1983 earnings estimates for companies,'' said Raymond F. DeVoe Jr. of Legg Mason Wood Walker Inc. ''The start of the economic recovery is being pushed further into the future.'' He predicted that the Dow might decline to the 850-860 range during the autumn before finishing this year at ''close to the 1,000 mark.'' **********Reflecting a sharp decline in gold bullion prices, precious metal issues moved lower. There were declines of more than a point each in Homestake Mining and ASA Ltd. **********Semiconductor issues also came under pressure. Showing declines of approximately a point apiece were Motorola and Texas Instruments.  CCI jumped 3 3/8, to 13 3/4. A management group proposed to buy the entire equity interest in the company for $15 a share.  Colonial Penn Group, showing the largest percentage decline, fell 2 3/4, to 12. The American Association of Retired Persons is considering the sponsorship of an automobile and homeowners insurance program that Colonial Penn said could adversely affect its sales of similar policies. **********Kennametal dropped 2 3/8, to 23 5/8. It fell 1 7/8 points on Thursday after the company predicted a loss for the September quarter. **********Albany International retreated a point, to 26 7/8. It said thirdquarter profits would run substantially below results a year earlier.  A trading halt remained in effect for Bendix, Martin Marietta and Allied. The three companies are involved in a complicated takeover battle. **********Superior Oil, rumored frequently as a possible target in the energy group, rose 2 3/8, to 31 1/2.  Woolworth finished at 23, unchanged, before trading was halted for the day. The company announced that it will close its 336 Woolco stores in the United States and take a write-off estimated at $325 million in the third quarter. First Boston Up by 3 3/4 **********In over-the-counter trading, First Boston rose 3 3/4 points, to 58 1/2 bid, after climbing 5 points in the two previous sessions. The company is benefiting from lower interest rates, increased block trading in stocks and fees received in corporate mergers. It sold at 35 1/2 in early August. **********Crowley Food, which is engaged in possible merger talks, advanced 2 1/4, to 12 1/4 bid. The Nasdaq composite index gained 0.46, to 188.61. **********On the American Stock Exchange, several companies that build single-family homes moved higher. Pulte Home rose 2 3/4, to 30 5/8, while Ryland Group gained 1 5/8, to 22 3/8. The Amex market value index declined 0.28, to 290.64.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/01/world.print_headline: Argentine Junta Issues Curbs for Journalists
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/01/world.body_text: **********The Argentine military command released a series of restrictions today that foreign and local journalists are supposed to obey or face the possibility of imprisonment. **********''News agencies and/or correspondents accredited in the country,'' said clared the regulations laid down by the Joint Chiefs of Staff, ''will be responsible for the control of all information that originates in the country or coming from abroad which is transmitted or retransmitted either abroad or to national correspondents.'' **********Under the category of ''national security,'' the guidelines prohibit information that produces panic, is against national unity, detracts from the credibility of, or contradicts, official information, upsets internal order, generates agressive attitudes toward the country's British community, affects the relationship with other countries, or, coming from abroad, tends to facilitate the achievement of the opponent's psychological goals.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/13/world.body_text: **********Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir left today on a 12-day trip to Argentina and Uruguay. He is the second Israeli Cabinet minister to visit Latin America this month. **********Mr. Shamir said he hoped to sign agreements on technical and cultural cooperation with both countries. But he said he would not discuss military assistance. ''That is not my province,'' he said. **********Meanwhile, Defense Minister Ariel Sharon returned from Honduras, where he reportedly agreed to sell Israeli Kfir jet fighters to the military Government. He denied that Israel was committed to selling any arms, but added that an Israeli delegation would go to Honduras next month to work out details of a defense cooperation agreement. **********Mr. Shamir rejected criticism of Israel's ties with Argentina's right-wing military government. ''There is criticism of everything we do,'' he said. ''Our policy is to maintain proper relations with all countries in the world irrespective of the type of regime they have.'' **********However, he said he would raise the subject of Jews among the thousands who were kidnapped and apparently murdered during the military regime's war against leftist guerrillas in the late 1970's.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/28/world.body_text: **********El Salvador's rightist-controlled Constituent Assembly voted itself broad powers Monday night to organize the Government and control the nation's laws. **********It also voted to continue those parts of the social and economic programs now in place, but gave itself the option of modifying them. And it repealed a law that authorized future appropriations of property for the nation's land redistribution program. **********The Assembly abruptly canceled its meeting for today, at which it was to have tried once again to elect a president. The United States and the Salvadoran military are pressing for a moderate to be named to the post. But there is strong opposition from the extreme right. **********Some politicians from the conservative National Conciliation Party have told friends they were threatened with physical violence in recent days to keep them from siding with the centrist Christian Democrats to elect a more moderate president. **********Army leaders were said to be meeting this afternoon, and a Salvadoran close to military and political leaders said they were discussing how to deal with this problem. **********The seven-article decree approved late Monday would allow the Assembly not only to name the president, vice president, supreme court and other major officials, which had been expected, but also to review, and possibly reject, the president's cabinet and subcabinet appointments. It was approved after several hours of sometimes angry debate. Accept Junta's Decrees **********The Assembly stopped short, however, of assuming the ability to enact temporary laws that would have the force of the Constitution. A motion to give it this sweeping power was rejected unanimously. **********The Assembly also voted to accept as legal all the decrees promulgated by the civilian-military junta that has governed El Salvador since the 1979 coup. **********Included were the provisions for social and economic programs, such as land redistribution and federal control of banking and exports.  These the Assembly voted to recognize and maintain but also to ''perfect.'' **********The debate, and the subsequent votes, repeatedly pitted the 24 Christian Democrats - mostly unsuccessfully -against the 36 deputies from four rightist parties. **********The Christian Democrats were arguing for more limited legislative powers, in the hope that this would give the executive branch more flexibility if a moderate is selected for that office. **********The only issue on which the rightists split was over a proposal to appoint new municipal councils to replace the present ones, many of whom were chosen by the Christian Democrats. On this, the conservative National Conciliation Party sided with the Christian Democrats to allow the councils to remain in office.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/12/world.body_text: **********Liu Jingsheng, a Peking bus conductor, was winning at cards when his luck ran out. The police picked him up for gambling and eventually sent him off for three years of ''re-education through labor.'' **********Mr. Liu never stood trial for his offense and was never formally convicted. But he has served more than 16 months so far in a prison farm south of Peking. **********''I deserved it,'' he said as he stood with other inmates in front of a communal wash trough. ''Playing cards for money isn't allowed.'' Still, he acknowledged with a laugh, ''I don't like it here.'' **********Mr. Liu, who is 30 years old, is just one among thousands of Chinese who get disciplined outside the courts after running afoul of the law. Petty Thievery and Seduction **********The Tuanhe Farm, where he is confined, has 2,410 inmates serving administrative sentences for offenses ranging from brawling and petty thievery to gambling and seduction. **********Since late 1978, China has revived the rule of law, which was submerged by the arbitrary persecutions of the Cultural Revolution.  Criminal and civil codes have been promulgated and the legal profession has regained respectability. **********Yet ''laojiao,'' or re-education through labor, remains an accepted device for clearing the streets of troublemakers, most of them young, whose transgressions seem too petty to warrant a full criminal trial. **********The regulations on nonjudicial punishment, originally published in 1957, were reissued in early 1980. They give nonjudicial committees, which include the local police, the power to confine offenders for one to three years. No Stigma of Prison **********The system's proponents contend that it prevents the court system from being overloaded with trivial cases. Because sentences are flexible, the offender is encouraged to repent. He is not locked up with hardened criminals, and, at least in theory, he does not carry the stigma of prison when he returns to society because he has no record of a criminal conviction. **********''Our work here is to educate and reform those offenders whose offenses are not serious enough to require a jail sentence,'' explained Liu Shili, the deputy director of the Tuanhe Farm. **********Mr. Liu, a beefy man wearing the white jacket and red collar tabs of the Public Security Bureau, the Chinese police, said, ''We ask all our personnel to treat offenders just like doctors treat patients who have an infectious disease, like mothers teaching their children, like teachers instructing their pupils.'' **********Re-education through labor is a convenient way for the authorities to deal with a rise in juvenile delinquency. Although China's problem is still modest by American standards, recent articles in the press suggest that it is widespread. Trains Stoned by Youths **********Earlier this month, a Shanghai newspaper disclosed that 46 passengers had been injured so far this year by stones that youths had thrown at city trains. In the Peking suburbs, three teachers were hounded by students to the point of nervous breakdowns. In the southern province of Hunan, a recent report revealed that vandals had wrecked 10 of the 25 high schools in Xintian County. **********A sociologist, Liu Liexing, reported in a social science journal in northeastern Liaoning Province that juvenile delinquency was steadily rising and that crimes were being committed at a younger age. A conference in Kunming last year disclosed that more than 80 percent of the prisoners in Yunnan Province were juveniles. **********Although the inmates at the Tuanhe Farm range from 17 to 60 years old, the overwhelming majority - 87 percent -are under 25 years old, Mr. Liu said. **********More than half the inmates were there for some form of stealing.  Another third were sent for ''hooliganism,'' which Mr. Liu defined as ''fighting which disturbs the peace or taking liberties with women.'' The others were mostly accused of smuggling, blackmail or gambling. **********There were no female inmates at Tuanhe, but a visit to a similar prison farm in Shanghai last November revealed that most women were there for having premarital sex with boyfriends. **********The Tuanhe Farm, one of three in the Peking area, is considered a showpiece by Chinese standards, which is why the municipality let foreign journalists in for a recent visit. **********The 250 uniformed guards and other staff members do not carry weapons, and Mr. Liu said they were forbidden from cursing or hitting their charges. **********Each inmate can earn $14 a month laboring in the surrounding orchards, vineyards and fields. Last year, the farm produced 2,000 tons of fruit, 800 tons of vegetables and 400 tons of grain for the city. **********But life is still spartan. The inmates sleep wedged together on communal platforms in unheated barracks and eat rations that feature steamed millet bread and vegetables. Daily work in the fields is followed by two hours of evening study. Exercise includes military parade drill. ''We ask them to act collectively,'' Mr Liu said. ''We ask them to learn from the army.' A Monthly Evaluation **********Eager cooperation is the fastest way to get out. Mr. Liu said the behavior of the inmates was appraised monthly, with a full evaluation every six months. Those with a positive attitude might get out early. Those fighting the system could be kept an extra year. **********Li Fengming, a 21-year-old coal miner serving three years for beating up a colleague, wrote his self-criticism when he arrived and is now on his best behavior. ''If we continue to commit mistakes, our sentences will be extended,'' Mr. Li said as he nervously answered a journalist's question. **********Zhang Zhenshan, 21 years old, was caught picking someone's wallet and, after a month in police custody, was sent to the farm for two years. ''I'm looking forward to getting out,'' Mr. Zhang said as he vigorously pruned grape leaves in the vinyard. **********According to The farm's records, nearly two-thirds of the inmates were workers or unemployed youths. Less than 8 percent were the sons of Government employees. Mr. Liu avoided answering whether any were the children of party officials, China's most privileged class. **********Ma Yuliang, 38, told reporters that he had been put away for meeting with foreigners, which is discouraged in China. The farm director, Sung Yibin, became angry and insisted that his prison farm had no political detainees. **********''His offense is not contact with foreigners but hooliganism,'' the director said. He said Mr. Ma was in nonjudicial detention because he procured prostitutes for foreigners, seduced four women and committed robbery.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/04/busin.body_text: **********The Barclays Bank of New York, a subsidiary of the London-based Barclays Bank P.L.C., said it had completed a $26.5 million acquisition of a subsidiary of the Bankers Trust New York Corporation. Bankers Trust sold its 25-branch Hudson Valley division as part of its move out of retail banking, a corporate strategy change that was announced last year. https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/04/world.main_headline: ISRAELI AND SYRIAN ARMIES DIG IN AS DIPLOMATS SEEK WITHDRAWLS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/04/world.print_headline: ISRAELI AND SYRIAN ARMIES DIG IN AS DIPLOMATS SEEK WITHDRAWLS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/04/world.body_text: **********The following article was altered by Israeli military censorship.  WITH THE ISRAELI ARMY in the Bekaa Valley, Lebanon, Sept. 2 - The Israeli Army is deployed in significant strength across the width of Lebanon, ready for war or peace. **********Israeli tanks, long-range artillery and infantry face the Syrian Army along a cease-fire line that begins 15 miles east of Beirut and sweeps for about 45 miles southeast to within a few miles of the Syrian border. Israeli 175-millimeter guns are within shelling distance of Damascus. **********Most of the confrontation line is in the Bekaa Valley of eastern Lebanon, a fertile area of vineyards and apple orchards. But on a tour of the Israeli side of the front line, the area was being used more by soldiers than farmers. Donkeys Replaced by Armor **********The armored personnel carrier has for the time being replaced the donkey as the principal means of human transport in this green valley and on the surrounding dusty hillsides. **********Within a few days of invading Lebanon on June 6, the Israeli forces pushed the Syrians north to the present cease-fire lines.  The military situation in the Bekaa is now referred to by officials in Jerusalem and Tel Aviv as Phase II of Operation Peace for Galilee. **********Phase I was clearing Palestine Liberation Organization guerrillas from Israel's border areas and driving them out of Beirut. That was officially completed on Wednesday. Mutual Withdrawals Sought **********Phase II, senior Israeli officials say, is the mutual, simultaneous withdrawals from Lebanon of the Israeli Army and the Syrian Army. Politicians and diplomats in Jerusalem, Damascus, Washington and Beirut are supposed to arrange such withdrawals. In addition, Phase II presumably provides for the pullout of P.L.O.  guerrillas from Tripoli in the north and the Bekaa. **********The stated policy of all the nations involved calls for Israeli-Syrian withdrawals in an effort to avoid more war in Lebanon.  The President-elect of Lebanon, Bashir Gemayel, has said he wants all foreign forces to leave his country.  Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said on a visit to Beirut Tuesday that preliminary plans for mutual withdrawal were already being discussed. **********Ariel Sharon, the Israeli Defense Minister, has said that Israel does not want another war with Syria. But both Mr. Sharon and President Hafez al-Assad of Syria have said their forces will not be the first to leave. **********Prime Minister Menachem Begin has stated, and Mr. Sharon has publicly reminded Syria several times, that Damascus is now within range of Israeli artillery. The Israeli guns along the front line southeast of the Bekaa are 5 miles from the Syrian border and 15 miles from Damascus. Israelis Are Digging In **********The Israeli troops in Lebanon, many of whom are reservists, would prefer to go home to their professions, trades and university classes. But a tour of the front indicated clearly that they were preparing to spend the fall and winter in Lebanon if the withdrawal negotiations lagged. **********The Israelis were laying asphalt on old and damaged roads in case they had to fight in the muddying rain expected to start late in the year. Trailer trucks were bringing in prefabricated houses for soldiers to live in when the weather cooled. Israeli officers said the Syrians were making the same preparations. **********The size of the two armies is a military secret. Israeli military officials said the Syrians had as many as 50,000 troops in Lebanon, backed by several thousand P.L.O. guerrillas who had not been trapped in west Beirut by the Israeli Army. Although Israeli officials declined to disclose the size of their force in Lebanon, officers in the field gave the impression that it was at least (seven words deleted by censor). Israelis Are Confident **********The Israeli troops in the field said, predictably, that if they had to fight they would win. The Israelis expressed that opinion repeatedly during a reporter's tour of the front. **********An escort officer accompanied the reporter, but let him travel freely in the area, taking photographs while observing military units in the Bekaa and the hills that flank it. The Israelis interviewed spoke openly, but the officers asked that their surnames not be published. **********Generally, the officers said, there has not been much military conflict along the cease-fire line in recent weeks. Artillery, Armor and Infantry **********None of the Israeli officers would disclose details on the Syrian units facing them. But a map given journalists by the Israeli military, dated July 26, indicates that the Syrian forces include seven armored brigades, two artillery groups, three mechanized brigades and one infantry brigade. **********The Israeli map does not provide additional detail, but the armored brigades, according to field reports, include Soviet-made T-55 and T-62 tanks, but not the more powerful T-72's. Syrian artillery is reported to be ample, but not close enough to hit Haifa, the nearest large Israeli city. In a total war, of course, both sides could use planes and missiles against large cities. **********About a mile north of (one word deleted by censor) on the southeastern front, Captain Yosi, his fair skin reddened by the sun, wore a bathing suit, a T-shirt and a crew cap with the brim down as he stepped out of his command post, an armored personnel carrier crammed with radio equipment and maps. **********He commanded a battery of four 155-millimeter guns mounted on tanktread vehicles. The 40 men who operated the guns slept in tents a few feet from them. The guns, with an effective range of 12 or 13 miles, could rain shells on the Syrian forces two or three miles to the east. With binoculars, the Israelis looked up at the Syrian soldiers on the top of a ridge on Mount Hermon, and assumed the Syrians are looking right back. 'It's Been Quiet' **********''There were some artillery exchanges,'' the captain said, ''but it's been quiet for two weeks now. We are just waiting for orders.'' He said his men assumed that the Syrians had (six words deleted by censor) but he added of the Syrians: ''They'll go back without fighting. None of us want to fight. We only want to go home. **********A few miles northeast of the 155-millimeter battery was a battery of four 175-millimeter guns on vehicles. The guns were set in a patch of olive trees that provided no cover for the artillery but some shade for the soldiers. The olives on the trees tasted bitter. The guns were aimed at the Syrian lines, three or four miles to the north, but, according to Lieutenant Moti, they could be turned quickly on (one word deleted by censor). **********(Twenty-eight words deleted by censor) Lieutenant Moti, 32 years old, was an importer of furniture, mostly from Rumania, in peacetime. He had not had to order his men to fire on the enemy for more than two weeks. 'We Gave Them a Lesson' **********''Two weeks ago Sunday, the Syrians or the Fatah were shooting machine guns and some R.P.G.'s,'' he said, referring to rocket propelled grenades. ''So we gave them a lesson. Just for a few minutes. We don't have to shoot for hours. It is enough for a few minutes.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/28/world.main_headline: MOSCOW'S CHANGING OF THE GUARD AT THE K.G.B.: YURI V. ANDROPOV
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/28/world.print_headline: MAN IN THE NEWS; MOSCOW'S CHANGING OF THE GUARD AT THE K.G.B.: YURI V. ANDROPOV
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/28/world.body_text: **********If there were any doubt that powerful men in the Kremlin are positioning themselves for the end of the Brezhnev era, it seemed to be dispelled with the announcement on Wednesday that Yuri Vladimirovich Andropov, a career Communist Party official, had been relieved of his duties as head of the K.G.B., the Soviet intelligence and internal security agency. **********The transfer of Mr. Andropov had been expected after the disclosure the day before that he would return to his former post of a secretary in the 10-member party secretariat, which under Leonid I.  Brezhnev, the general secretary, runs the Soviet Union's affairs. Mr. Andropov was moved from the secretariat to the chairmanship of the K.G.B. in 1967 as part of an effort to affirm party control over the security agency. **********The announcement of his return to appeared to confirm rumors that Mr. Andropov wanted to place some distance between himself and the K.G.B. to strengthen his hand in what Sovietologists have dubbed the ''presuccession struggle'' in the Kremlin. It has long been assumed that the K.G.B. job is a deadweight on anyone aspiring to be the top man in the Kremlin. **********Viewed as a Moderate in K.G.B. **********Although the glowering look of his official photographs hardly conveyed it, Mr. Andropov was a moderate during his 15-year tenure at K.G.B. headquarters on Dzerzhinsky Square. Dissidents found him an implacable foe, but the party and the population as a whole rested easier. **********Placing the K.G.B., including its huge network of agents, under at least a semblance of ''socialist legality'' was the task set by Mr.  Brezhnev when he pulled the aide out of the secretariat and sent him to the K.G.B., a couple of blocks from the party's secretariat offices on Moscow's Old Square. **********Over the years, Mr. Andropov succeeded to the point that the ruling Politburo has judged it safe to reassign the post to a career security officer, Vitaly V. Fedorchuk. Move May Be Viewed as Gamble **********For Mr. Andropov, the move could be a gamble. While remaining at the security agency might have disqualified him from the party leadership, it would still have given him a voice in designating Mr.  Brezhnev's successor. By moving back to the secretariat, he has relinquished that power base for a more amorphous position where his skills at political infighting could decide whether he recedes in influence or inherits Mr. Brezhnev's job as general secretary. **********So far, the two main contenders seem to be Mr. Andropov and Konstantin U. Chernenko, a longtime Brezhnev confidant. Mr. Andropov staked his claim by giving the annual speech on Lenin's birthday last month, but Mr. Chernenko countered with an ideological speech to a gathering of political commissars of the armed forces two weeks later. **********The Brezhnev Politburo has presented an image of lifeless anonymity to the public, but Mr. Andropov's career provides some shadings. At the K.G.B., he established his ideological mettle, and any suspicions of queasiness in the face of popular challenge had been dispelled earlier by his role as Soviet Ambassador to Hungary during the uprising there in 1956. **********Last year, rumors reached Western diplomats that he was pressing for tough action in Poland before Mr. Brezhnev was ready for a crackdown. But readers of Soviet intellectual journals have found evidence suggesting that he may be more pragmatic than some of his rivals if his authority were extended to economic issues. From a Humble Background **********Like most men in the Kremlin hierarchy, he comes from a humble background. He was born June 15, 1914, the son of a railway worker, and took jobs as a telegraph operator and film projectionist before attending college. His first party job, as head of the Young Communist League in what was then the Karelo-Finnish republic, was interrupted for a stint organizing guerrillas in this area behind German lines in World War II. **********As a promising young official he was sent to the party's secretariat staff in 1951, and, except for a four-year stint in Hungary, remained there until he moved to the K.G.B. in 1967. While at the security agency, he was elected to the Politburo, first as an alternate member in 1967, and then as a full, voting member in 1973. **********Although his travels have been limited to Communist countries, he has impressed diplomats with his command of English, a rare accomplishment among Soviet leaders.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/18/world.main_headline: U.S. AND SOVIET TRY TO CUT U.N. COSTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/18/world.print_headline: U.S. AND SOVIET TRY TO CUT U.N. COSTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/18/world.body_text: **********Delegates from the United States, the Soviet Union and Britain will meet Thursday with Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar to express their concern over the rising cost of the United Nations, officials here said today. **********The rare collaboration between Washington and Moscow brings together the two biggest contributors to the United Nations budget.  Between them, they pay three of every eight dollars that the organization spends. This year's budget is estimated at $722 million, compared with $784 million for 1983. **********Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the American delegate; Oleg A. Troyanovsky, the Soviet representative, and Sir John Thomson, the British delegate, will meet with the Secretary General, according to the officials. **********The three diplomats expect to find a sympathetic audience. Mr.  Perez de Cuellar has frequently voiced alarm over waste and inefficiency at the United Nations and has promised to use what power he has to remake the organization's structure. He and Mrs.  Kirkpatrick discussed the issue in advance of Thursday's meeting, aides said. U.S. Seeks Airtight Ceiling **********The United States goal, according to American diplomats, is an airtight ceiling on spending increases. The British have said they want to stop any real increases in outlays, a slightly more liberal target that would permit gains big enough to pay for inflation. As far as is known, the Soviet Union has not specified a target, but has said that costs must be held down. **********Spending at the United Nations is determined by the General Assembly, where each of the 157 members has an equal vote.  Assessments, however, are fixed by a formula that takes into account each country's total output and per capita income. So dozens of smaller and poorer nations can vote for conferences, experts and new programs, aware that the costs will be borne almost entirely by richer and larger countries. **********The United States share of this year's budget is $180.3 million, or 25 percent. The Soviet share is $93.4 million, or 13 percent.  Britain, whose share is $32.2 million, or 4.6 percent, is the sixth largest contributor after Japan, West Germany and France. **********The three diplomats meeting with Mr. Perez de Cuellar are expected to stress that United Nations spending has risen over 80 percent in five years. For the United States, this has meant a rise in its contribution from $99.4 million in 1977 to the present level of $180.3 million. A New American Tactic **********This week the United States unveiled a new tactic to advertise its resistance to higher costs. It introduced amendments to at least three resolutions, approving their substance ''only to the extent that they can be financed without exceeding the level of resources approved in the budget.'' All three amendments were soundly defeated. **********But as one American official said: ''We want people to know we are serious. If they do, we hope the escalation in costs will stop.'' The United States now holds back its share of spending for the Palestine Liberation Organization and the South-West Africa People's Organization, the insurgents in the territory known as Namibia. **********Other nations have also refused to pay for activities of which they disapprove. France and the Soviet Union did not pay their share of the costs for United Nations peacekeeping forces in the Congo in 1960. So, far, however, no nation has withheld a payment for budgetary reasons.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/10/world.print_headline: Bullfight Arena Collapses In Mexico, Killing 14
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/10/world.body_text: **********The bleachers of a bullfight arena collapsed tonight, killing 14 people and injuring 400, Mexican state television said. **********The television said the accident occurred when spectators rushed to one side of the stadium at Milpa Alta, on the southern edge of Mexico City, to watch a bullfighter, Antonio Lomelin, arrive in a helicopter outside the ring. **********Red Cross spokesmen said casualty reports were not immediately available, apparently because the victims were rushed to numerous hospitals around Mexico City. About 3,000 spectators had packed the stadium.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/23/world.main_headline: SHIITES IN LEBANON SAID TO ATTACK ARMY BARRACKS IN CITY THEY TOOK
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/23/world.print_headline: SHIITES IN LEBANON SAID TO ATTACK ARMY BARRACKS IN CITY THEY TOOK
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/23/world.body_text: **********Several hundred armed men reportedly attacked a Lebanese Army barracks today in the eastern city of Baalbek and besieged it for two hours before retreating. **********The Beirut radio quoted the Lebanese Defense Ministry as saying that three of the armed men were killed and several were wounded in the attack by Lebanese Shiite Moslems, who are in the majority in Baalbek. The broadcast said two Lebanese soldiers were wounded. **********The attack followed a Shiite takeover of Baalbek's town hall and streets on Sunday to prevent the celebration there today of the 39th anniversary of Lebanon's independence from France. **********The Shiite takeover and attack on the army barracks constituted the first instance of armed protest by Lebanese citizens against the Government of President Amin Gemayel. **********The Defense Ministry report identified the attackers today as being from the same group that took over the town hall Sunday. That group identified itself as Lebanese Shiite Moslems who oppose the Government of President Gemayel and generally support Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini of Iran. **********The Defense Ministry statement was the Government's first acknowledgement of insurrection in Baalbek. An Earlier Report **********Earlier in the evening, however, the radio station of the Christian Phalangist Party of Mr. Gemayel said that there were 300 attackers besieging the army barracks, which is a fortresslike, highwalled structure on a hill on the edge of Baalbek. **********On Sunday at dawn, the insurgents took control of the town hall, overcame a small unit of Lebanese security troops without resistance, and occupied the streets of the city of 25,000 people. The Syrian Army, which occupies the general area, the P.L.O. and the Lebanese Army did not intervene. **********The insurgents ripped down or defaced Lebanese flags and pictures of President Gemayel and painted anti-Government, anti-Gemayel mottoes in the town hall. **********Leaders of the insurrection said on Sunday that they favored an Islamic state, similar to that in Iran.  Today an arrangement was made under which a Lebanese flag was allowed in the square. The compromise reportedly was the result of negotiations by the Syrian Army, the Lebanese security forces and the leaders of the Lebanese Shiite organization known as Islamic Amal. **********After today's battle, the Defense Ministry statement said, the Lebanese Army fortified its positions around its barracks and the city of Baalbek was described as calm. ---- 1,200 Reported Killed **********TEL AVIV, Nov. 22 (AP) - The Israeli newspaper Maariv said today that 1,200 Palestinians were believed to have been killed in recent Lebanese Army sweeps through West Beirut and that 60,000 had been sent to Syrian-controlled Lebanese territory. **********An Israeli Government source in Jerusalem said that the 1,200 Palestinians were known to have disappeared since the Israelis pulled out of the city at the end of September but that it had not been confirmed that they had been killed. Maariv quoted military sources as saying they believed the 1,200 had been slain. The Israeli Army declined comment. **********The newspaper said 60,000 Palestinians had been sent to Tripoli in northern Lebanon and to the Bekaa Valley in the east. Their houses were reportedly destroyed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/15/busin.body_text: **********The International Harvester Company, the debtridden manufacturer of trucks and farm implements, disclosed today that it had reached a tentative agreement with its lenders on major changes in its $4.2 billion debt restructuring plan. The proposal, the third modification of the debt plan, is expected to give the lenders a large share of Harvester's stock, but will also provide new financial liquidity. **********Harvester said it would not disclose the details of the package until the terms were definitive, but the company's lenders said the proposal involved the conversion of debt into equity, the easing of interest payments and the raising of additional collateral. The changes were needed, it was said, to permit Harvester to maintain liquidity for the next 12 months and avoid filing for bankruptcy. **********''It's the best solution for Harvester and the banks,'' said Rudy Mueller, an analyst with Sterling, Grace & Company. ''The banks would rather get 8 percent from a living company than zero from a corpse.''  30 Percent Stake for Lenders **********Under the proposal, Harvester would convert as much as $350 million in principal and interest owed to the banks into equity, giving the lenders about a 30 percent stake in the company. The equity would be in the form of nonvoting stock, most likely with warrants attached to buy common stock. **********In addition, Harvester would be able to defer some interest payments, and be allowed to make lower payments on the balance of the interest due, depending on the company's cash requirements.  Harvester's current interest rate is set at 108 percent of the prime rate, with the company paying interest in notes when the prime is above 16 percent and in cash when it is at 16 percent or below. **********The lenders also want Harvester to raise more collateral. The company has already mortgaged about 80 percent of its manufacturing assets. **********The new proposal requires the unanimous approval of Harvester's 200 lenders, and it has already run into a snag because one unnamed foreign bank has been reluctant to go along. This bank is said to support a plan to separate Harvester's finance subsidiary from the parent company. **********''The finance unit is doing just fine,'' a lender said. ''Some banks are not exposed to the parent company, and they are tired of the parent milking the child to help pay its bills. However, we don't see one little-bitty stubborn bank as pouring cold water on the plan.'' **********The new proposal, however, does not give Harvester everything it had wanted. In July, the company said it would ask its lenders for the conversion of more than $400 million worth of debt into equity, and the elimination of all cash interest payments on loans retroactive to July 1, offering lenders an equity security instead of cash. **********A compromise was drafted last Friday during Harvester's regular monthly meeting with its lenders.  ''Sure, it was a perfect negotiating tactic on Harvester's part to ask for more than they need, hoping to get more than we were willing to give, but we hold the purse strings,'' a lender said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/25/world.main_headline: BRAZIL ELECTIONS BRING VICTORIES FOR OPPOSITION
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/25/world.print_headline: BRAZIL ELECTIONS BRING VICTORIES FOR OPPOSITION
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/25/world.body_text: **********In the first three nationwide elections in Brazil in 17 years, opposition parties won an overwhelming majority of the vote and control of several major states. **********The voting was the centerpiece of a gradual politicial liberalization program known as apertura, or opening in Portuguese.  Although the continuing tabulation of the Nov. 15 election gave the Government party only about 30 percent of the vote, it was enough to assure them of a majority of the states and control of the electoral college that will choose the country's next President in 1985. Prospect for Civilian Rule **********The orderliness of the process, the reasonable showing of the Government's Social Democratic Party and the preference of opposition voters for moderate candidates over leftist ones appeared to enhance chances that the next President will be a civilian. The current President, Gen. Joao Baptista Figueirido, is the fifth consecutive military head of state since the armed forces took power here in 1964. **********Because the vote for gubernatorial, legislative and municipal posts is still being tallied, there could be a switch of several states before official results are announced next month. Reliable projections showed the governing Social Democratic Party with 12 states, the Brazilian Democratic Movement Party with 9 and the Democratic Labor Party of Leonel Brizola, the most controversial gubernatorial candidate, with the state of Rio de Janeiro. **********Mr. Brizola's brother-in-law, Joao Goulart, was President when the military took over Brazil in 1964. Mr. Brizola tried to turn enlisted men against their superiors and to mount armed resistence to the military takeover. Charges Are Traded **********Even before the votes were fully in, he and military officials traded charges. Mr. Brizola suggested that an excessively slow count in Rio indicated the Government was trying to steal the election, and Gen. Delio Jardim de Mattos, the air force secretary, called him a political ''arsonist'' in response. **********President Figueiredo's brother, Gen. Euclydes Figueiredo, said Mr.  Brizola was a ''bone we will have to swallow and digest and,'' he added menacingly, ''get rid of at the right time.'' **********Mr. Brizola moved to calm the dispute by promising an administration ''open to dialogue with all citizens and all authorities, be they civil, religious or military.'' He also praised President Figueiredo for the tenacity of his commitment to hold elections and liberalize Brazil's political life. **********Mr. Figueiredo's apertura program , has already brought about the lifting of most censorship, the restoration of political parties, the release of political prisoners and an amnesty under which men such as Mr. Brizola, who was exiled for 15 years, were able to return to Brazil and re-enter public life. **********Although falling two states short of its election eve hopes and having to accept Mr. Brizola's victory, the military-run Government appeared satisfied with the overall outcome. It had viewed winning a majority in the electoral college as crucial, and it appeared to be capturing some 230 of the 479 seats in Congress, 10 more than its most optimistic forecast. The possibility arose that the Government could negotiate a voting majority with a smaller party. . Figueirido's Prestige Rises **********The prestige of Mr. Figueiredo also rose. He had persistently assured doubters that the elections would take place, and his aggressive personal campaigning was seen as the principal reason the party survived voter resentment over the country's deep recession and its annual inflation of nearly 100 percent. **********The Brazilian Democratic Movement Party came away with the governorships of states containing over 60 percent of the population and producing 70 percent of the gross national product. At the same time it suffered key losses in two states that it had seemed sure of at the start of the campaign, Rio Grande do Sul and Pernambuco. **********Its most important conquests were Sao Paulo and Minas Gerais, the industrial centers of the country. The two new Governors, Franco Montoro and former Prime Minister Tancredo Neves, are both from the moderate faction of the party that ended up accounting for all the party's major victories. **********Mr. Montoro announced that he would not join any proposed ''front'' of opposition governors against the Government, and Mr.  Neves, calling himself ''a man of conciliation, dialogue and understanding,'' said he wanted to meet with President Figueiredo. Presidential Possibilities **********Of the potential civilian aspirants to the presidency, former Gov.  Paulo Maluf of Sao Paulo attained his objective of receiving more votes than any other Congressional candidate in Brazil's history, about 600,000, but he still emerged diminished because of the poor performance of his party in the state. **********The hopes of Interior Minister Mario Andreazza were sustained but not augmented by the showing of the Government party, whose campaign he supervised. **********Antonio Carlos Magalhaes, the departing Governor of Bahia, stayed high on the list by masterminding an overwhelming party victory in his state even after his first gubernatorial candidate was killed in a plane crash in the middle of the campaign. **********Marco Antonio Maciel of Pernambuco, the 42-year-old departing Governor and newly elected Senator, entered the list by producing a party victory in a state the party once considered unwinnable. **********As of today, the Government had won the states of Alagoas, Bahia, Ceara, Maranhao, Mato Grosso, Paraiba, Pernambuco, Piaui, Rio Grande do Norte, Rio Grande do Sul, Santa Catarina and Sergipe. The opposition had won Amazonas, Acre, Espirito Santo, Goias, Mato Grosso do Sul, Minas Gerais, Para, Parana, Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/15/busin.main_headline: G.T.E. AND WESTERN UNION POST QUARTERLY GAINS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/15/busin.print_headline: G.T.E. AND WESTERN UNION POST QUARTERLY GAINS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/15/busin.body_text: **********The G.T.E. Corporation, the nation's second-largest telephone company, said yesterday that net income for the second quarter ended June 30 rose 12.7 percent, partly on the strength of telephone rate increases. **********At the same time, the Western Union Corporation said its secondquarter earnings rose 55.3 percent, mostly as the result of special factors. Without the extraordinary items, earnings for the quarter would have risen 12 percent. **********G.T.E., until recently known as the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation, said net income for its second quarter rose to $201 million, or $1.14 a share, from $178.4 million, or $1.08 a share, in the 1981 quarter, when there were fewer shares outstanding. Revenues rose 13.5 percent, to $3.03 billion, from $2.67 billion in the 1981 quarter. **********Theodore F. Brophy, chairman and chief executive officer of the Stamford, Conn., company, said in a statement that ''the company performed well in the face of an adverse economic environment.'' Impact of Rate Increases **********G.T.E.'s telephone operations benefitted from $125 million in additional revenues derived from rate increases granted in the last 12 months. The company received twice as much in new rate increases in the first half of 1982 as it did in the first half of 1981, Mr.  Brophy said. **********The company said that the recession resulted in sluggish growth in long distance calling and in new telephone customers. Long-distance calling in the quarter rose 5.8 percent over the same period a year ago, compared with a gain of 8.7 percent in the year before that. The company said that the number of customer lines in service on June 30 was 2.1 percent higher than a year ago, compared with a 3.5 percent gain achieved the year before. **********The company said its sale of communications products rose 20 percent and net income rose 17 percent. But sales of electrical products, such as lighting systems, fell 7.7 percent and net income plunged 35.3 percent. Narrower Loss at Telenet **********G.T.E. Telenet Communications, the company's computer-to-computer communications network, showed a 29.3 percent gain in revenues, to $30.8 million, in the quarter. The unit narrowed its loss to $4.1 million from $4.6 million in the second quarter of last year, G.T.E.  said. **********Western Union said its net income for the quarter ended June 30 increased to $20.5 million, or $1.06 a share, from $13.2 million, or 68 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenues rose less than 1 percent, to $230.1 million, from $228 million. **********The company said its earnings results included a one-time gain of $5.7 million, or 33 cents a share, resulting from a $12.7 million refund received from the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.  The Federal Communications Commission ordered the refund after it found that Bell had overcharged communications companies for leased communications facilities. **********Partly offsetting the refund, Western Union said it had set up a $7 million reserve to cover possible costs resulting from the Government's recent cancellation of a military communications system that the company had been providing. **********For the six months, G.T.E. said its net income rose to $398.9 million, or $2.28 a share, from $356.7 million, or $2.18 a share, a year earlier. Western Union said its net income rose to $37.9 million, or $1.95 a share, from $23 million, or $1.15 a share, in the 1981 period.

Sinai was handed over last month under the Egyptian-Israeli peace treaty. **********Along with most other members of the Organization of African Unity, he had broken relations with Israel under pressure from Arab countries. Zaire is known to have maintained economic links with Israel despite the diplomatic break. President Mobutu received some of his army training in Israel. **********Zaire is the first African nation to restore relations, although others are said to have been approached by Israel and other countries on its behalf. ---- **********JERUSALEM, May 15 (Reuters) -An Israeli Foreign Ministry spokesman told reporters today that a special representative of President Mobutu was expected to in Israel by Sunday with official notification of Zaire's decision.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/30/busin.body_text: **********The Chase Manhattan Bank is planning to establish a new subsidiary for its investment banking activities that would be comparable in size to Bache Halsey Stuart Shields & Company, one of the nation's 10 largest securities concerns, the bank said yesterday. **********Under the plan, which is to be formally announced today, Chase will merge all its securities trading and capital market activities, domestic and international, into a single subsidiary of the bank. **********The company will not enable Chase to enter new fields at present because it, like the bank, will be subject to the Glass-Steagall Act that limits the types of investment banking activities in which commercial banks may engage; most importantly, underwriting corporate securities is prohibited. **********But there is widespread expectation within the banking industry, as well as in Washington, that the act may be modified - indeed, the Reagan Administration has advocated giving banks expanded powers - and Chase is putting itself in position to move ahead quickly should that change be made, as well as streamlining present operations. **********The subsidiary, to be known as Chase Manhattan Capital Markets (Holdings) Inc., will be capitalized at $175 million. Chase officials said that it would strengthen the bank's identity in investment banking and that it would sharpen its management's focus on the business. **********''We are saying to the industry, 'here we come','' said William S.  Ogden, vice chairman of Chase, who will also be chairman of the new company. **********According to Perrin H. Long of Lipper Analytical Distributors, the $182 million in equity of the new Chase subsidiary would make it ninth largest in the nation, trailing Bache and ahead of Paine Webber. **********Despite the Glass-Steagall Act, commercial banks may engage in a number of investment banking activities, such as underwriting United State Government securities and municipal bonds, and privately placing corporate debt. **********In addition, the act does not apply to the overseas activities of American banks, and many large banks, including Chase, have been very active in a wide range of investment banking activities outside this country. **********Mr. Ogden said that in 1981 Chase Manhattan's merchant banking group led international loan syndications totaling $42.2 million, more than any other financial institution. **********These syndications were arranged by Chase Manhattan Ltd. of London and Chase Manhattan Asia Ltd. of Hong Kong, which are capitalized at about $65 million. They will be acquired by the Chase Manhattan Capital Markets (Holdings). 'A Major Commitment' **********Chase will inject an additional $110 million of capital into the new company to support its domestic businesses, which will include dealing in and underwriting United States Government and municipal securities, the arrangement of mergers and acquisitions and corporate financial advisory services. **********''This says Chase is making a major commitment to this line of business,'' Mr. Ogden said. But he criticized current laws and regulations for severely limiting banks in competing fully in investment banking. **********''For openers, we would like to be able to underwrite revenue bonds,'' Mr. Ogden said. The Glass-Steagall Act allows banks to underwrite general obligations of states and municipalities, but not bonds that depend for repayment on revenues generated by a governmental agency. **********For example, although commercial banks may underwrite general obligation bonds of New York City and New York State, they may not underwrite bonds for such agencies as the Port of New York Authority, the New York State Power Authority or the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority. **********''Our aspirations go beyond wanting to underwrite revenue bonds,'' Mr. Ogden continued. ''Eventually, we would like to underwrite corporate debt.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/20/busin.body_text: **********Chaotic Credit Markets **********After remaining at high but quite stable levels since last fall, interest rates seem about to take off again. Since the Drysdale collapse, the credit markets, which had been cautiously eyeing a projected $45 billion in Treasury financings during the third quarter, have turned skittish at the sight of new Government paper.  With the economy struggling to get out of its rut, the change in attitude could not have come at a worse time. **********The bond investor is likely to purchase the new Treasury notes, says Edward Yardeni, chief economist at E.F. Hutton, but only at interest rates that insure a still-born recovery. And while most analysts acknowldege that recent upward movements in key short-term rates make a rise in the prime to 17 percent highly likely in the near term, that may not be the end of the increase, Mr. Yardeni says. **********A big surge in July's money supply, in conjunction with Treasury borrowings, could push the prime to 18 percent by August, he predicts. Such a rise would make real interest rates, already at high levels, more punitive and could push the economy back into recession. Prices Pick Up **********Those who expected high interest rates and a lingering recession to rule out anything other than minute increases in consumer prices are in for a surprise this week, when May's report is released by the Labor Department. Thanks to rising mortgage interest and energy costs, prices are apt to show their biggest monthly increase since last September, says Donald Ratajczak, an economic forecaster at Georgia State University. When measured against inflation's performance over the last few years, the increase Mr. Ratajczak expects - 7 percent at an annual rate - is hardly alarming. The upward blip is not likely to be temporary, however. Interest rates remain persistently high, and the full impact of rising gasoline prices will not be felt until the June and July reports are released, Mr. Ratajczak says. As measured by the Consumer Price Index, those factors are likely to cause the inflation rate to more than double between the second and third quarters, he predicts, to 7.5 percent at an annual rate. Some cooling is likely in the fourth quarter, he says, as mortgage costs start to ease. Still, the fact they have stayed so high for so long has caused Mr. Ratajczak to revise his inflation projection for 1982 upward by half a point, to 5.8 percent.  Commodities Crumble **********Just when it seemed that things could not get much worse for commodities, they have.  In the past month, the Commodity Research Board index, which has been sliding ever since peaking at 337 in November of 1980, has dipped another 6 percent, to around 230, the largest sell-off in post-war history. And, while the worst of the decline is over, some analysts say that further deterioration is likely in coming months. **********Despite the price decline, demand remains very weak, preventing excess supply from being drained out of the market. To speed the process, production, which in a number of areas has already been slashed, is likely to fall further, says Gregory Kipnis, chief economist at ACLI International, a commodity service firm. And, as output declines, the price index is likely to drop, too, perhaps by as much as 10 percent by summer's end. The E.M.S. Buys Some Time **********By realigning the French franc against the German mark and the Dutch guilder, the European Monetary System, created to promote greater economic and exchange rate harmony among its member countries, has managed to survive another crisis. However, unless President Francois Mitterrand of France follows up recent austerity moves - a temporary freeze on wages and prices and a further 10 percent devaluation of the franc - with additional steps, few analysts expect the tranquility to last long. **********If France is serious about defending the franc beyond this fall, decisions about further cuts in the workweek and increases in business taxes - both of which undermine productivity and investment - will probably have to be reconsidered, says Jonathan Francis, director of foreign exchange forecasting at Wharton Econometrics. **********If that does not occur, the franc is likely to come under renewed downward pressure late this year and early in 1983, he says. Rather than agree to a third realignment in two years, the French, whose commitment to the E.M.S. is wavering, may decide to withdraw, Mr.  Francis said, throwing the system's survival into question. **********Kenneth N. Gilpin
