https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/06/busin.main_headline:
ECONOMIC AFFAIRS;
LET THE F.T.C. BE A CHECK ON THE DOCTORS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/06/busin.print_headline:
ECONOMIC AFFAIRS;
LET THE F.T.C. BE A CHECK ON THE DOCTORS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/06/busin.body_text: **********WE are all aware of the beneficial effects of professional licensingb oards and medical associations that protect consumers from quackery a nd charlatans. But we are not so aware that these same associations a re actually being used to establish cartels for their members. And s uch cartels are convenient vehicles for setting higher fees on many k inds of health and other professional services. **********Congress will have to address this contradiction in a pending authorization bill that would drastically curtail the Federal Trade Commission's authority as policeman of these professional associations. Currently, the F.T.C. is able to bring actions against licensing boards and medical associations that violate the Sherman Antitrust Act, prohibiting conspiracies in restraint of trade. **********Not surprisingly, medical and other lobbies that favor clipping the F.T.C.'s wings argue that the agency has been harassing morticians, optometrists and even doctors and dentists by over-regulating their licensing procedures and activities. **********On the other hand, more public-minded economists favor continuation of the F.T.C.'s strong regulatory authority, and they include those usually noted for objecting to excess regulation. Their position is that while the morticians and surgeons control entry into their professions to protect consumers against quackery, there have also been many instances of misuse of their licensing power to restrict entry and thus make profits greater for current members. In this case, the economist is correct in opposing a reduction in the F.T.C.'s power. **********Consider the case in principle for totally free entry into these professions, which in practice almost no one supports. Any practitioner could use the title of mortician, lawyer or dentist just as anyone can now use the title of economist. Those who are poorly trained or prone to mistakes would lose patronage as their performance became known. Others would improve their skills by practice and their market shares would increase. Eventually, the incomes of quacks or incompetents would fall to the point where they would be forced to close and perhaps go into teaching or consulting. **********This is not, however, a very compelling argument for total deregulation in present day circumstances. Before market forces expelled the untalented, they might well have done considerable harm, both financially and by raising the mortality rate. **********By requiring practitioners to be licensed, so as to eliminate those that are incompetent, even the first mistakes that lose patients could theoretically be prevented. Public regulation through licensing can correct the serious problems created by lack of knowledge in the market. But do not be too quick to embrace total regulation. In practice, the licensing board can apply the wrong test or biased review procedures that produce even worse overall results. **********While the system works to keep the quacks out, it also can be used to keep legitimate competitors from offering cheaper and more abundant health care, and it is obviously in the self-interest of just such a professional association, though never spoken, to use the limitation on entry in order to keep fees at monopoly pricing levels. **********The problem is that licensing to remove quackery can also be used as a convenient excuse to raise the required level of service quality too high. More years of training, more equipment and longer apprenticeships could be required by the licensing professional association. These would be costly steps, and would thus be the basis for raising fees, greatly benefiting those already in practice.SUCH a conflict of interest often occurs when a licensing board c onfronts someone trying to introduce no-frills service, versus the r egular full-line service. Full-line has less potential for harmful e ffects on quality but also carries higher prices and profits. Such at endency to charge too much for full-line can only be checked by a s hift to no-frills service by large numbers of consumers. And the l icensing board, by banning no-frills service in the name of e nhancing health care, is not being entirely honest. Its actual aim i s to maintain and increase the profits to its members. **********There have been several examples of this in recent years. One was brought to light in a 1979 F.T.C. investigation of morticians, who were requiring consumers to buy coffins as a condition for cremation, thus raising prices to unjustifiable levels by their self-licensing activities. The victim is the consumer, required to pay for more than he needs. **********But the most questionable self-regulation centers on direct control of professional fees. The setting of a schedule of fees for service so as to discriminate between higher charges for high-income consumers and lower charges for others is the key to the use of monopoly power by any professional association. **********To maintain such a schedule it is necessary to prevent fee advertising so that the wealthy do not perceive that they are being overcharged. Also, it is important to prevent the development of services not on a fee basis, such as prepaid medical or dental care, since it is impossible to determine from such arrangements whether fees are being cut in violation of the schedule. **********Fee setting is a long way from state board licensing to solve quackery problems. Can we have one without the other? The Federal Trade Commission has operated in recent years to allow selfregulation, but to prevent conspiracy to set monopoly professional fee levels. Agency cases have dealt with fee fixing by the Michigan State Medical Society, and boycotts against health insurance cost containment programs by the Indiana Federation of Dentists. **********Another example was the F.T.C.'s rule requiring eye doctors to give copies of eyeglass prescriptions to all patients. Before this rule, many optometrists required that patients had to buy the glasses from them after the examination. Now, the patient, with prescription in hand, can shop around for the cheapest source of glasses. The banned practices may have had some uplifting effect on service quality, but they seem mostly to have been for the purpose of putting more money in optometrists' pockets. **********On the whole, the F.T.C.'s operations have dealt with the monopolizing activities of the professional associations. These activities have been more widespread than might be expected, and have contributed to higher costs of medical, dental, mortician and other services for more than 100 occupations. The objections to F.T.C.  practices have come from the professional associations themselves, not from economists concerned with the quality and price of professional services. **********If the morticians and dentists pressure Congress to limit these antitrust activities, we will all pay more for the same fillings, eyeglasses and appendectomies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/01/busin.body_text: **********In an apparent acknowledgement of the inroads being made on its business by Japanese competitors, the Xerox Corporation slashed prices on some copiers yesterday by as much as 47 percent and said that for the next three months it would offer several discount financing programs to ''meet competition head-on.'' **********Analysts said that the sharp cuts, which averaged 27 percent and affected primarily reconditioned machines at the lower end of Xerox's product line, were an effort to stimulate sales in a weak economy as well as to rebuff stiffening competition from Japan. **********The price reductions, effective today, range from 10 percent for the Xerox 2350 and 2830 copiers, originally priced at $3,995, to 47 percent for the Xerox 3109, originally $7,495. **********Under the financing plans, available through Oct.1, customers will be allowed to spread payments over 12 months with no finance charge.  Companies taking several years to pay will be offered 15.9 percent financing, down from a range of 19 percent to 28.5 percent. Bulk Discounts **********In addition, Xerox said, it would offer discounts of 10 percent to 15 percent for purchases of two or more copiers. **********''The price cuts are certainly among the steepest I've seen,'' said Eugene G. Glazer, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ''There's general weakness in copier pricing, but I'm not aware of any other companies being on such a big program.'' **********Eight of the 14 discounted models, however, are no longer in production, and most are rental machines. Used machines, Xerox said, would be reconditioned and sold with a new-product warranty. **********''The finance plans are like a second cut,'' noted Sanford J.  Garrett, who follows Xerox for Paine, Webber, Mitchell Hutchins Inc.  ''Xerox is almost offering a two-for-one sale of machines no longer in production. It will still have a pretty good margin on the machines, because virtually all have been used.'' Hard Cuts to Beat **********Xerox faces some of its stiffest competition from Savin, a domestic company that markets Japanese-made copiers, followed by Cannon, Minolta, Sharp and Toshiba, all Japanese. Analysts doubted that these companies could undercut Xerox's discounts: ''There's simply no way the Japanese can compete with that,'' Mr. Garrett said. **********When reached at home last night, E. Paul Charlap, chairman of Savin, said that the company had no plans to cut its copier prices.  According to Mr. Garrett, Xerox holds a commanding 45 percent share of the domestic copier market. In the low end, however, where the Japanese manufacturers are most active, it has a 30 percent to 35 percent share. **********Terry W. Dillman, a Xerox spokesman, confirmed only that Xerox ''wants to be more aggressive in meeting our competition, and obviously some of that is coming from the Japanese.'' **********Xerox, with estimated copier sales of about $1 billion last year, reported a 12 percent drop in its first quarter copier sales, the first such drop in its history. Analysts, noting that sales had also fallen in April and May, speculated that the price cuts had been timed to stimulate a rush of sales before the end of the second quarter.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/07/world.main_headline: U.S. GENERAL SAYS AMERICAN JETS HAVE PROVED RELIABLE IN LEBANON
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/07/world.print_headline: U.S. GENERAL SAYS AMERICAN JETS HAVE PROVED RELIABLE IN LEBANON
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/07/world.body_text: **********The head of the United States Tactical Air Command says that the performance of American-made fighters flown by Israelis over Lebanon should be noted by critics who assert that technically advanced weapons do not work reliably in combat situations. **********Gen. W.L. Creech, speaking Wednesday to reporters, said he felt reassured by the effective performance of McDonnell Douglas F-15's and General Dynamics F-16's over Lebanon. **********He said the Israelis had shot down 85 Soviet-built planes since the invasion of Lebanon on June 6.  General Creech acknowledged that the Syrian pilots were not up to the standards of Israeli fliers and that the Soviet aircraft were not the latest models. Even so, he asserted, American pilots in F-15's and F-16's ''would do very, very well'' against Russian pilots. **********General Wants More Planes **********General Creech contended that the Air Force was seriously deficient in the number of fighters necessary to carry out the Reagan Administration's ambitious new global military strategy. He suggested that his command, with its 34 fighter wings, was far short of the 54 needed. **********The plea by General Creech echoes that of other senior commanders who have asserted that the forces planned by the Reagan Administration are inadequate to fulfill the military commitments of the Administration. **********The Administration's strategy calls on the armed forces to prepare for a protracted conventional war with the Soviet Union, possibly in Europe, the Persian Gulf and Asia simultaneously. Prospects 'Don't Look Good' **********General Creech said, however, that the prospects for getting those planes ''don't look good.'' He indicated that priority in the Reagan Administration had gone to the President's $180 billion program to revitalize the nuclear deterrent of intercontinental missiles, longrange bombers and submarines and to build a 600-ship navy. **********General Greech said that of the 92 Soviet-built, Syrian-flown planes shot down by Israel since early June, 85 were downed by fighter planes. The others were hit from the ground by antiaircraft fire. **********Many of the the 85 Syrian planes, he said, were export versions of Soviet MIG-23's. Of these, 40 were shot down by F-15's, the general went on. He added that well-trained Israeli pilots flying F-15's had brought down 58 enemy planes in recent years, with no Israeli losses. **********The general added that Israeli pilots flying less high-powered but nonetheless highly advanced F-16's had shot down about the same number of Syrian planes. But he noted that Israel had about three times as many F-16's as F-15's. **********The rest of the Syrian planes were hit by older F-4 Phantoms.  Israel reported the loss of three aircraft to Syrian ground fire: an F-4, an A-10 attack plane and a helicopter.  General Creech said that all but a handful of the Syrian planes had been hit by Sparrow and AIM 9-L American-made missiles from distances of up to 24 miles. Only a few Israelis got close enough to an enemy plane to use conventional guns. This underscored the increasing importance of radar-guided and heat-seeking missiles in air combat. **********The general contended that the F-16 had shown itself to be reliable when maintained properly under wartime conditions. The Israelis, he said, reported that all 72 of their F-16's were ready to fly every morning.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/07/world.main_headline: YUGOSLAVIA, ITS ECONOMY FRAIL, TURNS TO AUSTERITY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/07/world.print_headline: YUGOSLAVIA, ITS ECONOMY FRAIL, TURNS TO AUSTERITY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/07/world.body_text: **********Yugoslav leaders, faced with huge foreign debts, an energy shortage and other problems, have urged tough austerity measures to save the country's stumbling economy while seeking new credits from Western banks. **********A recent meeting of the ruling Communist Party's Central Committee called for immediate steps to increase exports, reduce inflation, cut public spending and investment, raise industrial and agricultural production and save energy. **********Officials agree that the country's biggest immediate problem is its $20 billion foreign debt, which will cost $5.3 billion to service this year in payments on the interest and principal. **********Western banking sources say Yugoslavia has asked for a $500 million credit to be repaid over three years from the Bank for International Settlements, the bank based in Switzerland that groups Western central banks. This is almost certainly intended for the first half of next year, the sources said. **********''Despite difficulties,'' one source said, ''Yugoslavia will get through this year, but next year is going to be an even bigger problem.'' **********The Communist Party chief, Mitja Ribicic, and other leaders have denied rumors that Belgrade will have to ask for a rescheduling of its debts this year. **********''With great efforts,'' he told the Central Committee, ''we have been repaying all our foreign debts and must continue to do so.'' The planned economic measures are expected to go before Parliament for approval next month. 50% Cuts in Some Areas **********A senior official said they included cuts of up to 50 percent in some areas, including industrial production, gross national product and living standards. They also call for priority to be given to export-oriented industries, agriculture and energy. **********Yugoslavia plans to borrow $3.35 billion this year - $1.65 billion in credits to help service debts and $1.7 billion in supply credits.  Banking sources said Yugoslavia had so far managed to arrange loans totaling about $1.15 billion, including $650 million from the International Monetary Fund, $150 million from the World Bank, $250 million from Kuwait and $100 million from West German banks. **********For 1983, the only firm credit commitments to Yugoslavia are I.M.F. and World Bank loans of about $900 million, as against its total borrowing requirement of nearly $2 billion, the banking sources estimated. **********As a result of increased exports and an 11 percent decline in imports, Yugoslavia's foreign trade deficit in the year to early September improved to $2.7 billion, 34 percent less than at the same point in 1981. **********The country would have to export goods worth $35 million every day for the rest of the year, instead of the current $26 million a day, in order to meet the goal of a 12 percent increase set by the Government for 1982. Industrial Production Up Slightly **********The reduced imports have affected industrial production, which showed a negligible rise of seven-tenths of 1 percent so far this year compared with a 3.5 percent goal. **********Inflation is running at an annual rate of 30 percent, down from 40 percent level of the last two years but still well above the 15 percent goal set by the Government. **********Tourism will clearly not yield the expected $2 billion this year, but together with remittances from Yugoslavs working abroad and invisible earnings, it should contribute toward cutting the country's current account balance-of-payments deficit to the planned level of $500 billion. **********Officials said there were 850,000 unemployed out of a working population of more than 5.5 million, a rate of about 15.5 percent.  Depleted energy reserves are another grave issue, and the ninemember presidency has appealed for cutbacks by industry and individuals. **********The presidency said stagnating coal production, insufficient oil imports caused by foreign-exchange shortages and a prolonged drought affecting hydroelectric power had brought Yugoslavia to the verge of an energy crisis.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/05/busin.main_headline: 4 HELD IN MEXICO IN TAX CASE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/05/busin.print_headline: 4 HELD IN MEXICO IN TAX CASE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/05/busin.body_text: **********The Mexican Government has charged four directors of a Mexican company with tax evasion involving commissions received from an American oil equipment concern. **********The directors of Grupo Industrial Delta were arrested in connection with commissions received from Crawford Enterprises Inc., a Houstonbased company that sold equipment to Petroleos Mexicanos, Mexico's Government-owned oil company. Grupo Industrial Delta acted as Crawford's Mexican agent. **********The directors, who were arrested last Saturday and arraigned on Monday, were said by the authorities to have received $45 million from Crawford and to have sent the money to banks in Switzerland and the United States without reporting it as income. Allegations Denied **********The arrests came shortly before it became known that Crawford was one target in the wide-ranging United States investigation of charges that several American companies have paid millions of dollars in illegal bribes to officials of Petroleos Mexicanos. The Houston company has denied the allegations and has complained that the long Justice Department investigation, which has not resulted in any charges, has cost it business. **********Asked whether the money sent abroad by Delta was destined for officials at Petroleos Mexicanos, known as Pemex, an authoritative source in the Mexican Attorney General's office said that it was impossible to prove. ''What we know is that there was tax evasion and we've got them on that,'' the source said. **********Officials at Pemex said the contracts with Crawford were placed in the late 1970's when Jorge Diaz Serrano was director general of the corporation. **********Mr. Diaz Serrano resigned last June in a dispute over Mexico's oil export prices and is running for the Senate in Mexico's general elections July 4. **********A Pemex official who asked not to be identified said that the new director general, Julio Rodolfo Moctezuma Cid, found considerable confusion surrounding equipment contracts when he took over, and that it was now almost impossible to learn the details of the negotiations with Crawford. **********A statement from the Attorney General's office said it had acted in response to a formal complaint from the Finance Ministry against Delta and its five directors. The chairman of the board, Ricardo Garcia Beltran, was not among those arrested and is believed to be in hiding. Contract Signed in 1978 **********The statement said that federal auditors had discovered that in 1978 Delta signed a contract to serve as Crawford's Mexican agent in the sale of oil equipment and would receive commissions worth 7 percent of the value of total sales. Sales of $647 million were made, but income estimated at $45 million was not recorded by Delta and was instead sent abroad, the Attorney General's office said. **********It added that the money was sent in dollars through Mexico's Multibanco Comermex to banks in Switzerland and the United States, among them the Swiss Volksbank and the Texas Commerce Bank, based in Houston. The statement said that Delta's tax evasion may be higher than the estimate because ''other United States companies with which it did business must still be investigated.'' **********Asked whether Mexico had acted in response to information provided by the United States Department of Justice, the source at the Attorney General's office said, ''We were both following the case and we both knew about it.'' **********The arrests were made two days before an article about the grand jury investigation of Crawford appeared in Excelsior, a Mexican newspaper.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/16/busin.body_text: **********Intellectual Property Owners Inc. announced this week the selection of the Inventor of the Year for 1981. Don Ausmus, the winner, will be honored at a meeting on Feb. 7 in the Patent and Trademark Office, Arlington, Va. **********Mr. Ausmus, a paraplegic, invented and patented what is called the Moto-Stand, a battery-operated vehicle on which a handicapped person can motor around a room in a standing position, with hands free for cooking and other operations. The inventor was partially paralyzed in a 1975 motoring accident, and while he was recovering conceived the Moto-Stand. **********An Inventor of the Year must have the invention patented or made commercially available during the calendar year. The Advanced Technology Corporation, Kansas City, Mo., put the Moto-Stand on the market in 1981. Mr. Ausmus lives in Independence, Mo., with his wife and their two daughters.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/21/world.body_text: **********The small boxing arena shook with the fervent cheers and chants of more than 10,000 sweltering Argentines crammed into the bleachers, stuffed down the halls and spilling out onto the street. **********The jubilant partisans had not come to cheer a fight. They were attending Argentina's first legal political rally in more than six years of dictatorship. **********Friday night's rally, sponsored by the Radical Youth, a faction in the center-left Radical Party, was called two weeks ago in defiance of the military. But it suddenly became legal when the military regime lifted its ban on political gatherings last week. **********Ricardo Alvarez, a party organizer, stood in the back and scanned the sea of faces as the crowd roared again and again, ''The military dictatorship is going to end.'' He grinned with welling emotion.  ''They feel and want liberty,'' he said. Frenzied 'Historic Moment' **********He called the frenzy a ''historic moment,'' marking the revival of party politics in this intensely political nation.  The military, discredited for surrendering to Britain in the Falkland Islands and failing to put Argentina's chaotic economy in order, has been fullfilling part of its promise to return the nation to democracy within 20 months. **********Government workers are pulling dusty voting boxes from warehouses to repair them. Other workers are studying outdated voting lists.  But many Argentines, although gratified by their new freedom, are skeptical about some of its implications. In the past, the political parties, as well as the military, have failed them. **********''We are worse off than we were,'' an Argentine said in a letter published last week in La Nacion. ''And as if that weren't enough, power is being delivered to the same people who say today exactly the same thing they said before - the same people who, through influence or compliance, are responsible for the national unhinging of the 1970's.'' **********By ''the national unhinging,'' he meant the leftist terrorism that traumatized the country and brought on a military coup in 1976.  A larger complaint has built up over the last 50 years against many civilian political leaders. They have had a poor record of espousing wild-eyed populism, engaging in corruption and goading the military into coups against competitors. **********Only one elected President, Juan Domingo Peron, completed a full term in that period, as succeeding civilian and military goverments turned over the country to each other when their failures became too much for the public to bear. President Peron eventually fell victim to a coup. A Common Frustration **********One woman in her 30's who periodically escapes abroad reflected a common frustration. ''After you're here for a while, your standards lower,'' she said. ''But then you get so sick you can't take it anymore.'' **********Many politicians recognize the mood.  Admitting that ''the military is not the only one to blame'' for the country's ills, Deolindo F. Bittel, the acting head of the Peronist Party, said last week that ''the most grave problem is precisely that the people don't believe in anything anymore.'' **********Mr. Bittel called for ''faith'' in the re-emerging parties, but there has been little in their politics to inspire it.  The Government recognizes at least 15 national parties, not counting the Communists, underground leftist groups and independent provincial parties. Few Ideological Differences **********There are few ideological differences among the 15. All but one are left of center by American standards. Most are dominated by old men divided by personal ambitions. **********The single ideological exception is the centrist Federal Party, whose members hold political beliefs similar to those of liberal Republicans in the United States. There is no party for Reagan-style conservatives, depriving Argentina of what many political analysts say is needed balance. **********The military has filled the conservative role until now, usually allying itself with the upper class, but the reported idea of forming a conservative party has been dropped. **********The existing parties are faction-r@idden.  The Radicals, founded in the 1890's, represented the growing number of urban immigrants and broke the landed oligarchy's political control. But the party grew rigid as its longtime leader, Hipolito Irigoyen, refused to step aside or meet the changing demands of new industrial workers. He was overthrown as President in 1930 in the first military coup of the century. **********Many of today's parties are offshoots of the Radicals. The party itself, after almost 40 years under the control of Ricardo Balbin until his death last year at the age of 77, is headed by a portly, 66-year old biochemist, Carlos R. Contin. **********The Radical Party, generally regarded as the nation's second largest, is seriously split between two factions, Mr. Contin's National Line and the Movement for Renovation and Change, headed by Raul Alfonsin, a 55-year-old leftist firebrand with a long face and a drooping mustache. **********Mr. Alfonsin spoke Friday at the rally. He warned of the nation's ''tendancy to dissolution,'' and then accused the more moderate Mr.  Contin of being a ''collaborator'' with the military regime, a heady charge. **********Mr. Contin retained control of the party in a heated vote by party leaders Monday, but not until after a brief outbreak of shoving. Deeply Divided Peronists **********Argentina's largest party, the Peronists, are even more deeply divided, with about a dozen factions. Members have ranged from the extreme leftists who assassinated policemen in the mid-1970's to the extreme rightists who assassinated the leftists. **********The party's titular head, former President Isabel Martinez de Peron, is in exile in Spain.  The military had set out with wide popular support after overthrowing Mrs. Peron to restructure the party system. But the generals could not agree among themselves. **********Now, though a new law governing internal party procedures is expected any day, many parties have already chosen to ignore it.  Party leaders argue that the recurring military coups have prevented a firm grounding in democracy. The promise of democracy, however, has lured many Argentines, particularly young ones such as those at Friday's rally, to try again. **********''This meeting is education for me,'' said a 25-year old office worker, ''and I hope we are on the road.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/30/world.main_headline: WHITE HOUSE GOES ALL OUT FOR INDIA FETE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/30/world.print_headline: WHITE HOUSE GOES ALL OUT FOR INDIA FETE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/30/world.body_text: **********Optimism radiated from the White House tonight at a state dinner for Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India after her visit with President Reagan this afternoon. **********Preceded by a color guard bearing the flags of both nations, the President and the Prime Minister beamed at each other and chatted animatedly as they joined 116 guests in the East Room, which was bedecked with white lilies. **********The evening's highlight was a concert after dinner by the New York Philharmonic, conducted by Zubin Mehta, a native of Bombay who is still an Indian citizen. In what is thought to be the most elaborate entertainment to date at the Reagan White House, some 60 musicians performed at the concert, marking the first time that the orchestra has played at the White House. **********Before the concert, the guests dined in the State Dining Room, its tables bathed in candlelight. The menu was one of restrained opulence - seafood neptune, lamb in golden pastry, salad and French cheese and a frozen black cherry bombe. The wines, a Chardonnay, Cabernet Sauvignon and a sparkling wine, were all from California. Mrs.  Gandhi wore a raspberry silk sari, and Nancy Reagan wore a sariinspired, one-shoulder peach chiffon dress bordered in silver by Adolfo.  Nancy Mehta, the conductor's wife, wore an authentic sari in champagne silk. Performance in the Rose Garden **********After dinner guests drifted out to the Rose Garden, where the orchestra played in the balmy open air, surrounded by banks of white and crimson geraniums. **********Mr. Mehta, the orchestra's music director, conducted works by Handel, Mozart, Bruch, Gershwin and Beethoven. The conductor's appearance was initiated at Mrs. Reagan's request by Frank Sinatra, a mutual friend, Mr. Mehta said, and he juggled several engagements to play here. **********''I really feel this is very important,'' said Mr. Mehta.  ''There's no country in the world that has been as open to Indian immigration as the United States.'' Mr. Mehta immigrated to the United States in 1961 and now makes his home in New York and Los Angeles. **********After the performance the Reagans and the Mehtas sipped champagne and danced in the white marble Grand Foyer, along with the other guests.  Among them were three former Ambassadors to India, Robert F. Goheen, Ellsworth Bunker and John Sherman Cooper; Clare Booth Luce, former Ambassador to Italy; the actor Chad Everett; Charlotte Ford; Constance Hoguet, the president of the Philharmonic; S. Dillon Ripley, head of the Smithsonian Institution; the author John Updike, and Dr. John R. Hubbard, president emeritus of the University of Southern California and chairman of the Indo-United States Subcommission on Education and Culture.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/02/busin.body_text: **********The Hershey Oil Corporation of Los Angeles, a producer of crude oil and natural gas, said that two Transamerica Corporation units, the Transamerica Occidental Life Insurance Company and the Transamerica Insurance Company, had agreed in principle to make a $10 million equity investment in Hershey. **********It is planned that Transamerica will purchase 1.17 million new unissued Hershey Oil shares at $8.57 a share, which will provide Transamerica, a San Francisco-based diversified services company, with 20.6 percent of the Hershey Oil shares then to be outstanding. **********Hershey Oil also said it had agreed to purchase for $12 million the Western producing and exploration assets of Houston-based Carbonit Exploration Inc. The principal assets to be acquired are lands and leases of about 86,103 net acres, daily production of about 214 equivalent barrels of oil and more than 80 exploration projects.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/20/world.main_headline: FOR FOREIGNERS, RED IS THE COLOR OF SOVIET CARPET
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/20/world.print_headline: FOR FOREIGNERS, RED IS THE COLOR OF SOVIET CARPET
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/20/world.body_text: **********An American with fluency in Russian arrived in the historic town of Suzdal with his family only to find the entrance to the dining room at his hotel barred. **********''No places,'' barked a doorman, even after the visitor explained in Russian that he was staying at the hotel and had three hungry children and no place else to eat. **********Finally the American appealed to the hotel administrator, who blurted out in horror, ''I'm so terribly sorry. He apparently mistook you for Russians.'' **********There aren't many countries where being mistaken for a native would be cause for an apology. But then there aren't many countries, in Europe at least, where a foreigner evinces such awe, deference and profound suspicion. **********Peter the Great imported foreigners as a cure for Russia's backwardness and then isolated them in a section of Moscow dubbed the ''German quarter.'' Generations of foreigners since then have been isolated and coddled by a society that brands them as guests and spies in almost the same breath. Segregated as Much as Possible **********Foreigners in Moscow still live in separate and guarded compounds, with facilities superior to anything Russians have. A network of hard-currency shops, hotels and restaurants, and a host of separate services supplied by a compliant ''diplomatic corps service bureau,'' further insure that a foreigner can live in the style he or she is presumed to require, segregated as much as possible from Soviet citizenry. **********Whole regions and cities of the Soviet Union are declared offlimits to foreigners, and advance notice or special permission is required for travel even in ''open areas.'' **********Much of the special treatment can be explained by the expedient of extracting as much hard currency as possible from the bourgeois visitor. To this end, a Soviet hotel that charges a Soviet citizen 10 rubles, or about $15, will unabashedly charge the foreigner 60 rubles and may demand payment in hard currency to boot. **********There is also the inherent Soviet suspicion that every foreigner, especially if from the West, is a potential spy and threat to the Socialist morals of society, and therefore to be watched and isolated. But beyond this is a genuine compulsion to please and impress a personage who by the very virtue of being an outsider is deemed very important. Room Service in Yakutsk **********Two reporters visiting Yakutsk, a Siberian administrative center that is off the normal tourist track, were informed on arrival at the Lena Hotel that all their meals would be served in their room. The dining room, it seems, was being renovated. **********Accordingly, a liveried waiter appeared to set the table and serve a rather elaborate meal. It took considerable effort to refuse the service without seeming ungrateful for the attention. **********One motive for such unusual and compulsory room-service was obviously to keep the foreigners away from the natives. But it was equally clear that the authorities regarded the rowdy local eateries as below the dignity of foreigners, even if the reporters were professionally drawn to them. **********It is common, in the same vein, for tourists at hotels to be seated at tables decorated with their national flags - a gracious gesture of international friendship and a signal to unwary citizens that this table is off-limits. A Game of Impersonation **********But even when foreigners venture into the streets, doors closed to the masses open wide. Tickets to theaters or circuses, access to restaurants, service at a crowded store all materialize for the ''guest.'' And, notwithstanding the incident at the start of this article, Russians seem to have an uncanny knack for recognizing a foreigner. **********A popular game among teen-agers in Moscow is to ''dress up like foreigners'' and try to fool a doorman at a restaurant or a clerk at a store. It is somewhat akin to an American teen-ager's parading as an adult to buy a six-pack of beer - it's titillating, potentially rewarding and mildly risky. **********The advantages of being identified as a foreigner are substantial.  Traffic cops rarely stop a car with the distinctive foreign license plates; if they do, they even more rarely issue a summons. **********Foreigners are permitted to cut to the head of the six-hour queue to pass through Lenin's mausoleum; they are routinely ushered into V.I.P. lounges at airports and allowed to pass through the jam of Russians who, in the absence of assigned seats, regularly fight it out at the foot of the Aeroflot boarding ramp. 'And You, What Are You?' **********Vladimir Vysotsky, the bard, now dead, whose songs of the trials of everyday Soviet life have become a fixture of popular culture here, has one about people grumbling about others cutting in their line. In the refrain they are told in confidential tones: ''We ask you, friends, please leave. Those who are eating, after all, are - foreigners. And you, I beg your pardon, what are you?'' **********The line captures a sense of inferiority that so many Russians have before foreigners, an attitude also reflected in the high premium set by owning imported goods or having foreigners as friends and in the defensiveness Russians often show about their own goods, ways of life and achievements. **********Television programs and the press regularly depict a casual contact with a foreigner as the start of a downhill slide to sedition, and dissidents who are interrogated by the K.G.B. say contacts with foreigners are routinely held up as evidence of subversive intent.  Even for a loyal member of Soviet society, playing host to a foreigner or attending a reception at an embassy can lead to a chat with the ''authorities.'' The Snow in Chita **********For foreigners traveling about, the attention can be overbearing.  Two American reporters seeing Siberia were told their flight from the mining town of Chulman southwest to Irkutsk, via Chita, had been canceled because of snow at Chita. **********They were flown north to Yakutsk and transferred to a scheduled flight that had been waiting, fully loaded, for three hours. It was a detour of 1,500 miles, three times the original route, and when passing through Chita a few days later by train the visitors were told there had been no snow for weeks. **********But the Chita airport did double as a military airfield.  The law on the subject of controlling foreigners is rather typical of Soviet legislation on such matters. Enacted last year, it grants foreign citizens every conceivable right in the Soviet Union. But then it declares that any or all of these, including the right to live or travel anywhere, can be abrogated by unspecified ''competent authorities'' on grounds of state security, protection of the social order or ''protection of the health and morals of the population.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/03/world.main_headline: SOME RIGHTS GAINS SEEN IN GUATEMALA
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/03/world.print_headline: SOME RIGHTS GAINS SEEN IN GUATEMALA
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/03/world.body_text: **********Since a coup gave power in March to a three-man military junta headed by Gen. Efrain Rios Montt, there appears to have been a marked improvement in the human-rights situation for Guatemala's urban middle class, according to diplomats and Guatemalans. **********There has been noticeably less repression of the Roman Catholic Church, the press and the university. There are fewer kidnappings and killings of politicians and workers, hundreds of whom were assassinated in the civil war that began during the previous regime. **********However, ''the slaughter goes in the countryside as if nothing had ever happened,'' said one businessman who, like most people in Guatemala City, is still not confident enough to allow his name to be used. **********In recent interviews, a range of foreign diplomats, Protestant and Catholic religious leaders and politicians of opposing ideologies agreed that the killing of peasant Indians was greater than before the coup. 'No Break With the Past' **********The Indians ''are systematically being destroyed as a group,'' a Western European diplomat said. ''There is no break with the past.'' Indians make up 60 percent of Guatemala's population. **********The Committee of United Peasants, a leftist organization that seized the Brazilian Embassy here recently, said more than 3,000 peasants had been killed by the Government in the first six weeks after the coup. **********One politician, asked why he believed repression had diminished in the cities but continued in the countryside, said, ''The army no longer sees the politicians as enemies, but the peasants still are.'' **********According to an account carried in the country's second-largest newspaper, El Grafico, 110 people were assassinated in a 48-hour period late last month in Quiche, a rugged, mountainous province in the western part of the country that is a rebel stronghold. **********Among 21 peasants identified in a mass grave, four were said to be infants from 7 months old to 5 years; five others were 13 and younger; one man was 75, another 58. **********In Saquilla, a village about seven miles from a major military base, the dead were said to be 26 children, three men and 14 women, four of whom were pregnant. **********El Grafico recently carried an unusual editorial harshly condemning the violence.  ''The assassination of defenseless children and pregnant women is stupid, bestial,'' declared the editorial, which was signed by the paper's editor and publisher, Jorge Carpio Nicolle. 'Not Worthy of Any Aid' **********Calling the killings ''genocide,'' Mr. Carpio added: ''It seems incredible, but this new outbreak of mass assassinations demonstrates that Guatemala is far from peace or, at least, from the diminution of violence. The world will again close its doors because we really are not worthy of any aid while this continues.'' **********General Rios Montt has acknowledged that the editorial was laying the responsibility for the killings on the Government.  What happened in the jungle hamlet of Josefinos in the middle of May when at least 40 civilians and soldiers were killed shows how complex the situation is. **********As related by a survivor and other villagers in the remote region in the northern reaches of the country, a large guerrilla force entered Josefinos. They gathered the villagers for a political meeting and brought in cases of provisions. **********The guerrillas also killed two men they said were members of right-wing death squads, according to the villagers. Guerrillas Get Away **********The guerrillas fled before the army responded, but in a battle a few miles away, between 20 and 25 soldiers were killed.  About midnight, more soldiers arrived. The villagers say the soldiers began setting fire to the hewn-wood, thatched-roof houses and killing villagers. At least 20 people were killed, most of whom were women and children, the villagers said. **********A former soldier who now works for a small company in Flores, the largest nearby town, acknowledged that the army had burned the village and killed the people, because ''they were subversives,'' he said. **********Asked if the Indians in Josefinos supported the guerrillas, the survivor answered ''probably.'' Asked why, she glanced in the direction of the soldiers in camouflage uniforms who were manning a machine-gun post and answered: ''Because they have unjustifiably killed so many. They have taken them away, they killed them.'' **********The Government contends that the guerrillas are to blame for the killings. A senior army commander who escorted reporters to the scene of the killings of 12 men in Patzul, a hamlet in Quiche, said the ''subversives'' had disguised themselves in army uniforms ''to deceive the people, to deceive the United States.'' **********Guatemala's previous military government, which was replaced after an election and the coup in March, was widely considered to be one of the most repressive in Latin America. As a result, the United States has supplied only minimal economic assistance since 1977. Now, the Reagan Administration wants to provide helicopters, about $2.5 million in spare parts for helicopters, $300,000 for military training and at least $50 million to aid the country's crippled economy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/13/busin.body_text: **********The International Harvester Company, the debtridden manufacturer of farm equipment and construction machinery, announced today that it had reached an agreement in principle with Indiana officials on a $9.2 million loan guarantee plan to keep open the company's truck building plant in Fort Wayne. **********The agreement, which would allow 4,700 Harvester workers to keep their jobs at the plant, is thought to be one of several financial aid packages being considered by Indiana for the troubled company, Harvester officials said. **********Details of the pact were unavailable. But, in part, the plan calls for Harvester to sell its Fort Wayne distribution parts center to private investors, who would then lease the facility to Allen County, Ind., which would in turn lease it back to Harvester. Although no potential buyers were named, Gov. Robert D. Orr of Indiana said in a statement that ''more than one private investor has expressed strong interests'' in purchasing the plant. **********Under the agreement, the State of Indiana will commit $4 million.  Those funds will be secured by the parts center and Harvester's pledged unobligated machinery and equipment within the state. Allen County will commit another $2 million and the city of Fort Wayne $3 million more. Both commitments will also be secured by the parts center. **********Governor Orr called the agreement ''a very large first step'' toward keeping Harvester in Fort Wayne. Harvester has been negotiating with the states of Indiana and Ohio for financial aid to help keep truck manufacturing plants open in those states. **********William B. Colwell, a Harvester spokesman, said that talks were continuing with Ohio and ''we're making good progress in that area.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/31/busin.main_headline: Commodities; THE BREAK IN SUGAR FUTURES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/31/busin.print_headline: Commodities; THE BREAK IN SUGAR FUTURES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/31/busin.body_text: **********THE blow that the world sugar futures market had been bracing for since May 5 finally landed last Friday, when the price of the spot July contract plunged 0.42 cent a pound, to 7.80 cents. For the week, the loss was 0.45 cent. The other deliveries showed somewhat smaller losses for Friday and the week. Each hundredth of a cent is equivalent to $11.20 on each contract of 112,000 pounds. **********While the market in foreign sugar had been expecting, and absorbing, heavy selling since President Reagan ordered the reimposition of import quotas on May 5, the severity of last Friday's price break stunned many traders. After all, world sugar futures had already tumbled more than a cent since the President's proclamation. **********Another indicator of the intensity of the selling was that volume on New York's Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange last Friday rose to an estimated 11,000 contracts from 6,100 the day before. More important, the open interest is expected to show a large drop when it is reported tomorrow morning. As it was, the number of outstanding contracts fell by 2,400, to 62,000, in the first four days of the week. **********According to several brokers, many buyers were caught off guard because they had expected Friday's activity to be largely devoted to squaring accounts before the Memorial Day weekend. Indeed, many in the trade had left by the time the full force of the selling occurred. **********''What many longs didn't realize, or ignored, was that Tuesday is first notice day to deliver sugar against the July contract, and the shorts are more than eager to do so,'' one broker said. ''The country is awash in sugar, and the full impact of the new quotas will not be felt for a long time.'' **********Another view was offered by Erik N. Dunlaevy, sugar analyst at Balfour, Maclaine Inc., commodity brokers, who observed: ''Many traders had expected the No.11 world sugar market was finished after May 5, but when it continued quite active, albeit at declining values, they decided to ride it out.'' **********What the steady open interest and volume in the world sugar futures market did not disclose to many remaining speculators was that the composition of the hedging was changing rapidly. Many domestic producers, refiners, merchants and other hedgers had turned to the No.12 domestic sugar futures market on the same exchange. **********The No.12 market had been relatively inactive since the import quota system was abandoned on Dec. 31, 1974. Most domestic and foreign hedgers preferred the far more active and thus more liquid No.11 world futures. **********''Since May 5, domestic hedgers have been moving into the No.12 market because its prices are now more in line with values, while the shocked and confused foreign producers and users have rushed into the world futures to protect themselves from further price declines,'' Mr. Dunlaevy noted. **********Overall, he added, ''there would have been even more foreign hedge and outright selling, except that many of them did not want to sell into a declining market, preferring to wait for some technical or other rally to afford them an opportunity to do so without further sinking the market.'' **********How distraught the foreign producers have been was discussed by Nauman Barakat, sugar analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. ''Many foreign traders didn't expect world sugar to break 8 cents and sell at levels not seen since the second half of 1979,'' Mr. Barakat said. **********''Also, many thought the current import quota of 220,000 tons for the period ending June 30 would be revised sharply higher for the third quarter, thus taking some pressure off the surpluses held by foreign producers,'' he said. **********But this view is fading, as foreign producers have begun to compete against one another for the sharply restricted United States market despite the higher import fees that accompanied the President's proclamation. **********''Take the case of Argentina,'' Mr. Barakat said. ''In the first quarter of 1982, they sold 99,507 tons of sugar in this country.  Under the current quota, Argentina can only sell 9,460 tons. They will have to find other markets for the rest. So will all the larger exporters, such as the Dominican Republic, Brazil, the Philippines and the Central Americans.'' **********Their plight is equaled by many independent domestic cane sugar refiners who normally buy foreign raw sugar and sell the refined products to their customers under long-term contracts. These refiners also have rushed into the No. 12 domestic sugar futures market to try to lock in much of their forward sales commitments. **********Last Thursday, these refiners had sought an immediate preliminary injunction in Federal court against the new quota system. But Judge Bernard Newman of the United States Court of International Trade said he would reserve judgment on the matter. Because many in the trade expect no decision for several weeks, it also provoked some selling late last week.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/23/busin.body_text: **********Without committing President Reagan, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan hinted broadly today that the Administration would accept a temporary surtax on upper-income taxpayers as part of a budget compromise with Congress. **********The Secretary also articulated more fully than he has before the view that concerted action by Congress and the Administration to shrink future projected budget deficits is essential to reducing interest rates and to the success of the Reagan economic policy. **********For the first time, Mr. Regan also said that the Administration has to **********Paul A. Volcker, the Fed chairman, repeated his call for big reductions in projected Federal budget deficits. Page D2. deal with the public perception - mistaken in his view - that the President's tax and budget-cutting policies have hurt lower-income groups more than others. **********Speaking to some 400 corporate lobbyists and lawyers at a United States Chamber of Commerce breakfast, Secretary Regan said that the income surtax might be 4 percent of Federal tax liabilities in excess of $5,000. Illustratively, he said that someone who owed $10,000 in Federal taxes would pay an extra 4 percent on the second $5,000, or $200 more. **********''Will $200 destroy your incentive?'' the Secretary asked his audience -men and women who, he implied, make at least as much as the $69,000 annually that Cabinet officers are paid. His tone conveyed disbelief. His point was that the surtax would not materially dilute the incentives for work and risky investment that are supposed to flow from the three-stage tax cut the President signed into law last August. A tax cut of 5 percent took effect last October and 10 percent cuts are scheduled for July 1 of this year and next. **********The Treasury chief, a regular participant in the budget talks, was careful to say that the matter was not settled. ''This is a bone of contention, the surtax,'' he said. ''This has not been accepted by either side as being in place.'' **********After the breakfast, Mr. Regan expressed to several reporters a sense of urgency about the budget talks, a sense that officials said the Secretary had also expressed to the President. 'The Country Is in a Mess' **********''The country is in a mess,'' Mr. Regan said. ''People are hurting from this recession. Interest rates are staying remarkably high because of the perception we are not dealing with budget deficits.'' **********Mr. Regan, Murray L. Weidenbaum, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, and other senior officials have become concerned in recent weeks that unless interest rates decline more than they have, the expected recovery from the business recession may be delayed, feeble and short-lived. Accordingly, there is in the budget negotiations what Mr. Regan called ''a sense of urgency.'' **********The senior officials are understood to have expressed these fears to President Reagan, who was said to share their sense of urgency about the importance of fashioning an early agreement with Congressional leaders on raising revenue and cutting spending.  Meanwhile, Mr. Reagan has been receiving contradictory advice from supply-side economists and others, such as the United States Chamber of Commerce, who oppose any tax increases as likely to hobble the economy. Support for Tax Increases **********Secretary Regan was authoritatively reported to have assured members of Congress participating in the budget talks that the Federal Reserve System would not choke off any recovery with a tigher monetary policy. He has also sought to allay fears that the central bank might abruptly shift to easy money, causing a sudden surge in the money supply that might drive interest rates up by triggering expectations of a compensatory tightening. **********Support for tax increases and cuts in military and other spending were urged upon the Administration by several business representatives at a White House meeting this afternoon. **********''We urged them to move forward with the process which requires the acquiesence of the Administration and the business community in tax increases,'' said John M. Albertine, president of the American Business Conference, after the 90-minute meeting with senior White House officials. **********Alexander B. Trowbridge, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, said he counseled that the Administration seek a budget package that includes ''cuts in the defense budget, a capping of the rate of indexing in all entitlement programs and a search for new sources of revenue.'' Chamber Forecast Disputed **********Also represented at the meeting were the National Federation of Independent Businesses and the Business Roundtable. The Chamber of Commerce, which has issued a relatively bullish economic forecast in support of its opposition to tax increases, is experiencing strained relations with the other business groups and had a separate session at the White House last Friday. **********The chamber forecast last week that the economy would grow at an annual rate of 1 percent this spring and at a snappy 5 percent rate in the September quarter. **********In his breakfast talk to the corporate lobbyists, Secretary Regan addressed the politics of the budget exercise, starting with the observation that in politics, ''perception is reality.'' **********He also said: ''It is perceived that the Republican Party and Ronald Reagan's tax plan have benefited the rich more than the poor.  If there are to be some type of compromises reached in which social programs are cut back and taxes increased, one of the things that should be done is to try to make a better balance here between different groups in the United States.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/03/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Long-Term Bonds Advance; Short-Term Prices Mixed
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/03/busin.body_text: **********A lack of supply helped raise long-term bond prices a point or more yesterday, but was not much help to the shorter-term markets, where prices rose slightly or declined in some cases. **********Securities dealers attributed the strength of the bond market to the likelihood that the Treasury may not sell a 20-year bond in late March, as had been expected. Most of the buying yesterday was by speculators and arbitragers, market participants said. **********A slight increase in overnight financing costs, and an increase in the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market kept short-term rates essentially stable. The rate on high-grade commercial paper due in 30 days was little changed at 13 3/4 percent while three-month certificates of deposit were yielding 14.1 percent in the secondary market. **********New Drop in Yields Awaited **********With companies able to borrow at rates less than 14 percent in the commercial paper market, investment bankers say that many potential issuers of notes and bonds are waiting for long-term yields to fall further, even though the lack of new Treasury securities makes the market more attractive. **********Among those companies that are selling longer-term issues, a $75 million issue of Baa/BBB-rated 16 5/8 percent bonds of the Consumers Power Company go on sale today at a price of 99 to yield 16.832 percent to maturity in 1992. A $125 million issue of A/A+-rated Houston Lighting & Power bonds, also due in 1992, was offered yesterday to yield 15.274 percent and was about 85 percent sold, underwriters said. **********Late in the day, the First National Boston Corporation, a bank holding company, announced plans to sell $100 million of notes due in 1989. **********Among active Treasury issues, which new corporate issues would have to compete with for investor funds, the 14 percent notes due 1987 were offered yesterday with a yield of 13.9 percent, the 14 5/8 percent notes due 1992 were yielding 13.7 percent and the 14 percent bonds due 2011 were yielding 13.45 percent. **********''If the 10-year Treasury note yield got down to 13 percent I think there would be a significant increase in corporate issuing,'' a leading investment banker said. Federal Deficit Cited **********Although the Treasury's presence in the marketplace is not too burdensome now, analysts warn that the Federal deficit is not going away and that the Treasury will re-emerge in the second quarter as a heavy borrower. The short-lived nature of the hiatus in Treasury financing may be one reason why institutional buyers have not been rushing to the market, they added. **********Analysts at Merrill Lynch recently forecast that the Treasury would raise $26 billion of net new cash in the second quarter - a record amount for that quarter, which is traditionally a time of debt reduction as income tax receipts bolster the Treasury's coffers. **********In the bill market, the Merrill Lynch forecast is for weekly auctions of three- and six-month issues to rise to $10.4 billion by June, compared with $9.6 billion recently, while one-year bill auctions remain at $5.25 billion. **********In the note market, Merrill Lynch expects $5.25 billion of two-year notes to be sold monthly, plus one issue each of four, five, and seven-year notes of $3.5 billion each. Finally, the May refunding package of notes and bonds is expected to total $9 billion. **********In the tax-exempt market, the savings to borrowers who sell shortterm issues is even more pronounced than in the corporate market. Many issuers pay less than 7 or 8 percent on short-term obligations due in a month or so, compared with 12 percent and higher for top grade long-term bonds. **********A new issue of A-rated Chicago general obligation bonds shows how yields increase with longer maturities. Underwriters led by the First National Bank of Chicago reoffered the bonds at yields ranging from 9.25 percent in 1984 to 12 1/2 percent in 1992, with a 13.65 percent yield on term bonds due in 2003 and 13.75 percent for bonds due 2013. At those yields, which were determined after a negotiated purchase of the bonds from the city, they said the issue was oversubscribed, **********Among recent note issues, a MIG-1/ AA-rated issue of Salt River Project Agricultural Improvement and Power District notes due March 15, 1983, was offered at par with an 8 1/4 percent coupon through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers. That rate is far lower than the 14 1/4 percent yield recently available to institutional investors on long-term A-rated refunding revenue bonds of Austin, Tex. **********Another new issue was $125 million of slightly lower-quality MIG-2 rated notes of the Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority. The notes mature March 11, 1983, and are offered to yield 8.75 through underwriters led by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company. A companion issue of bonds proposed for sale this week was postponed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/08/busin.print_headline: Deere Drops 78 Percent; Bombardier Posts Profit
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/08/busin.body_text: **********Deere & Company said yesterday that net income in its fourth fiscal quarter plunged 78 percent because of the badly depressed farm equipment business. The company, the world's largest maker of farm equipment as well as an important producer of construction machinery, held out little hope for an improvement in the current fiscal year. **********The company, based in Moline, Ill., said net income in the three months ended Oct. 31 fell to $12.1 million, or 18 cents a share, from $55.3 million, or 82 cents a share, in the 1981 quarter. Sales dropped to $1.15 billion from $1.43 billion. **********Deere said the outlook for the fiscal year 1983 ''is not encouraging.'' It cited, as one factor, the poor prospects for recovery in the North American farm equipment market in light of the bountiful 1982 harvest, which has applied further downward pressure on already low crop prices. **********In an effort to cut back dealers' receivables, the company said that it is currently scheduling 1983 production at some 18 percent below 1982 levels. Deere said that these reductions would ''exert extremely severe pressure on operating results.'' **********For all of the fiscal year 1982, Deere reported net income of $52.9 million, or 78 cents a share, down 79 percent from $251 million, or $3.79 a share, earned in the fiscal year 1981. Sales fell to $4.61 billion from $5.45 billion. **********The company added that its 1982 worldwide production was down 20 percent from 1981 as a result of lower retail demand.  Worldwide farm and consumer product sales in 1982 dropped 14 percent, to $4 billion, Deere said. Industrial equipment sales tumbled 26 percent, to $575 million, it added. **********The company said that pretax foreign exchange gains amounted to $46.9 million in 1982, contrasted with gains of $61.8 million in 1981. In the fourth quarter, foreign exchange gains were $10.7 million as opposed to a loss of $10.8 million in the 1981 quarter. Bombardier **********Bombardier Inc., a Montreal-based maker of mass transit and recreational equipment, said yesterday that it earned $2.63 million, or 48 cents a share, in its fiscal third quarter ended Oct. 31, compared with a loss of $3.2 million a year earlier. Sales climbed to $178.3 million from $131.5 million. **********The concern has overcome a heavy exposure in the depressed snowmobile business to emerge as a strong presence in the market for mass transit equipment. **********Bombardier also said that it had received a deposit from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority of New York on a contract to supply 825 subway cars. The order raises the company's backlog to $1.35 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/27/world.main_headline: HAIG CANCELS A PITTSBURGH SPEECH TO ATTEND O.A.S. MEETING TODAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/27/world.print_headline: HAIG CANCELS A PITTSBURGH SPEECH TO ATTEND O.A.S. MEETING TODAY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/27/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. today canceled plans to give a speech in Pittsburgh on Thursday in order to represent the United States at an emergency meeting of foreign ministers of the Organization of American States. **********The meeting is being convened by Argentina, which is seeking help in its conflict with Britain over the Falkland Islands. It will be a continuation of a special session held last month by the 21 O.A.S countries that are signers of the Rio Treaty of mutual assistance.  That meeting ended inconclusively with calls on both Argentina and Britain to avoid a conflict over the Falklands. **********Now that the fighting has intensified, Argentina wants to take advantage of the widespread support it has received from other Latin American countries to get specific pledges of military and other assistance, Argentine diplomats said. Washington Fears Polemics **********United States officials said they were concerned that the session might also become a forum for polemics against Washington because of the decision by President Reagan on April 30 to side with Britain in the conflict. Mr. Haig is expected to defend that decision on grounds that Argentina violated the United Nations Charter in using force to settle disputes and that Britain was permitted to react militarily in selfde@fense. **********Secretary Haig is also expected to stress Washington's hope that a negotiated solution can still be achieved and to assure the other Latin countries of its interest in closer hemisphere harmony. **********The speech on Central America that Mr. Haig was to have delivered to the Pittsburgh World Affairs Council will now be given by Deputy Secretary Walter J. Stoessel. U.S. Urging Flexibility **********In recent days, the United States has urged Britain to remain flexible and not to insist on the humiliation of Argentina if a negotiated outcome could be achieved that would preserve the integrity of the United Nations Security Council's Resolution 502 of April 3. That resolution called for a cessation of hostilities, the withdrawal of Argentine forces from the islands and a political settlement. **********It was not clear today how much tangible support Argentina would be able to get from other Latin nations. Venezuela has been the most vocal in supporting the Argentines, but no major country has provided Argentina with any significant military help. Brazil has sold Argentina some patrol planes.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/13/busin.body_text: **********The owner of Saturday Review said yesterday that he might have to close the magazine on Monday.  The 58-year-old monthly journal of cultural affairs and literary criticism has often been in financial peril - it was declared bankrupt in 1973 - and it has been losing $1 million a year for at least the past three years. **********The owner, Robert I. Weingarten, said no final decision had been made, but the staff at the magazine's offices at 150 East 58th Street had been warned to prepare for the worst. **********''We're still grappling with the options,'' Mr. Weingarten said.  ''We're in the last hours of doing so.'' He said he had set a deadline of noon Monday for responses from people he had approached about ways to keep the publication in business. 480,000 Subscribers **********The June issue was mailed to 480,000 subscribers, but the combined issue prepared for July and August has not yet been printed. A dozen staff members have already been dismissed, a move that Mr. Weingarten said would have been taken in any event to pare costs. **********The magazine is owned by Macro Communications, a closely held public company that is traded over the counter. Mr. Weingarten controls Macro, which also owns the relatively healthy Financial World, a biweekly covering business news. A third Macro publication, View, devoted to coverage of television, is being sold. **********Since buying Saturday Review, Mr. Weingarten has raised both the advertising rates and subscription rates, but the majority of copies are sold through magazine discount houses at prices that provide little or no revenue to the magazine itself. **********The magazine has passed through a number of hands and a number of formats since it was founded in 1924 by Henry Seidel Canby and Amy Loveman. Its greatest success came after World War II, when, under the editorship of Norman Cousins, it provided a lively weekly look at cultural affairs, in general, and literature, in particular. Mr.  Cousins left Saturday Review in 1971, and although he later returned to run it for a few years, the magazine never recovered from the decision, by one set of owners, to split it into four separate monthlies. It later went to a biweekly format. Magazine Repositioned **********When Mr. Weingarten took over, he changed it to a monthly, to cut costs. He also took it out of the general-interest field, where it was competing with Atlantic and Harper's magazines, and restored the original editorial direction, concentrating on literary critcism and news of the visual and performing arts. The June issue, for example, included an article by Anthony Burgess about James Joyce, a review by Mordecai Richler of John Barth's new novel and articles on Louis Malle, the filmmaker, and on the London theater season. **********The editor, Stephen B. Shepard, said he thought the magazine had been sucessfully repositioned but ''we haven't had the money to do the necessary promotion.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/11/busin.main_headline: Advertising; American Heritage to Accept Ads
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/11/busin.print_headline: Advertising; American Heritage to Accept Ads
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/11/busin.body_text: **********SOON after American Heritage magazine went to soft cover in 1978 after 25 years as a hard-cover publication, there appeared within its covers an ad for subscriptions along with a bound-in card. It was the first ad the magazine had ever carried. Some time later, the six-a-year publication began to carry ads for American Heritage catalogue products. **********Subscribers may not have realized it at the time, but that was the nose and the ears of the camel of advertising coming into their tents. The publishers were testing the waters for public reaction, and got five negative letters at most. **********As a result, after all these years of abstinence, American Heritage will become an full-fledged advertising medium beginning with the August/ September issue. But with a difference. One of the first people the magazine turned to for advice, Joseph H. Newman, vice president-media director of Marsteller, convinced the publishers to take a very special route: a single advertiser per issue. **********Behind these major changes is Samuel P. Reed, 47-year-old chairman of the American Heritage Publishing Company, grandson of the late Samuel F. Pryor, chairman of the executive committee of Remington Arms, and son-in-law of the late Charles W. Englehard, multimillionaire precious metals industrialist and race horse owner. **********Mr. Reed quit the presidency of the Engelhard & Hanover investment firm to buy American Heritage from it. It had previously been owned by McGraw-Hill, which had bought it from the original crowd, which, led by James Parton, brought out the first 80,000 print order with a stake of $64,000. Now, for $67,500, a single advertiser can have six to eight advertising pages in a single issue but no back cover. **********With Byron Dobell, 55, editor, and Paul E. Hale, 39, the president and publisher he brought in from Time Inc., in his office, Mr. Reed noted that, when he became owner of the magazine, he was determined to go to soft cover, which he did three years ago; take advertising, which is soon to happen, and increase the publishing frequency, something to look forward to. **********The first advertiser to go after the 110,000 circulation will be Grumman, a Marsteller client, and the second, Oscar de la Renta, the fashion and fragrance company, whose agency is Calet, Hirsch, Kurnit & Spector. **********Should the readership be taken aback by the sudden appearance of commercial messages, although the management has research that says they will not be, Mr. Dobell will seek to soothe them in his editorial with the assuring words that the move ''fortifies our future and takes the burden of increasing costs off the necks of our readers.'' **********This is despite the fact that the recent increase in annual subscription price to $24 from $21 for the soft cover and to $45 from $35 for the deluxe (artificial leather) hard cover caused no drop in consumer interest or the comforting 74 percent subscription renewal rate. It had revenues last year of about $2.2 million. **********Mr. Dobell arrived in January after a distinguished career that included being managing editor of both Esquire and New York. He said yesterday that he planned very few changes to the history-oriented magazine except a few little touches that might make it even easier to read. **********Mr. Hale noted that for the single advertiser there were distinct possibilities for merchandising the involvement, and, to help, the company will make available at a reduced price additional copies of the magazine in both cover versions. **********Another change that Mr. Reed hath wrought is in the area of newsstand sales, where the publication had never ventured even when its circulation was way up over the 300,000 mark. But since last October, through Eastern News, distributor of a number of quality publications, American Heritage at $3 a copy has begun a ''slow and careful'' move into the retail marketplace.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/07/world.main_headline: Around the World; Filipino Athlete's Family Gets New Ransom Note
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/07/world.print_headline: Around the World; Filipino Athlete's Family Gets New Ransom Note
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/07/world.body_text: **********The family of a missing athlete, Tommy Manotoc, who secretly married the daughter of President Ferdinand E. Marcos, recei ved a note today urging them to comply with ransom demands. **********It was the second note they had received. **********The first, which arrived Saturday, was dismissed by the family as ''an obvious fake.'' The demands are for $2.5 million and freedom for imprisoned Communist leaders. But the athlete's father, Ricardo Manotoc, told reporters that he was not convinced the note came from his son, who was last seen dining with Imee Marcos in a Manila restaurant nine days ago. **********Supported by records from a court in Arlington, Va., the family has said that Tommy Manotoc, a 32-year-old basketball coach and amateur golfer, married Imee Marcos in the United States last month. They said he obtained a divorce in the Dominican Republic from his first wife, Aurora Pijuan, a former beauty queen. President Marcos expressed concern about the disappearance. But he also said he could have no interest in the matter because divorce was not recognized in the Philippines.
