https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/29/busin.print_headline: COMPANY EARNINGS; TEXACO AND SOHIO UP SLIGHTLY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/29/busin.body_text: **********More oil companies reported yesterday that earnings had been sluggish in the last quarter in 1981. Texaco Inc., the nation's third-largest oil company, reported a 1.4 percent gain and the Standard Oil Company (Ohio), No.13, reported an even smaller rise. **********The lackluster performance has been attributed to a poor economy that has damped demand for oil products. Although some crude oil prices have softened, prices for refined products have dropped even more, squeezing oil refinery margins, analysts said. **********Texaco's earnings were termed ''not bad'' by Bruce E. Lazier, an analyst with Paine Webber Mitchell Hutchins Inc., in light of a retroactive rise in the cost of crude from Saudi Arabia and the declining dem and - and prices -for refined products. ''Texaco's overseas refi ning market was down, and it increased its exploration expenses,'' M r. Lazier said. ''So it wasn't a bad performance. And it was a strong performance in relation to market conditio ns, which are pretty bad.'' **********John K. McKinley, Texaco's chairman and chief executive officer, citing the sluggish business conditions, said that ''operating in this business environment,'' Texaco ''could not fully recover'' increases in the cost of its Saudi Arabian crude. **********Sohio, however, was somewhat protected from the squeeze on refinery margins because a large percentage of its earnings come from the sale of crude from the North Slope of Alaska. Texaco **********In the fourth quarter, Texaco earned $507 million, or $1.96 a share, on revenues of $14.7 billion. This compared with the net income a year earlier of $500 million, or $1.86 a share, on revenues of $14.1 billion. **********Fourth-quarter earnings benefited from a $113 million after-tax gain in inventory profits from the sale of older inventories built up when crude prices were lower. But this was partly offset by a $43 million write-off after the closing of a Lockport, Ill., refinery and by a $21 million loss from translating operations in foreign currencies back into dollars. **********Net income for the full year dropped 3 percent, to $2.3 billion, or $8.75 a share, on revenues of $59.4 billion, from $2.2 billion, or $8.31, on revenues of $52.5 billion in 1980. **********For 1981, foreign currency translations yielded a net gain of $57 million. The 1980 results included a $402 million gain from the sale of Texaco's interest in the Belridge Oil Company. Standard of Ohio **********Fourth-quarter income at Standard of Ohio totaled $477.8 million, or $1.94 a share, on revenues of $3.70 billion. This compared with net income of $475.8 million, or $1.93, on revenues of $3.06 billion in the 1980 period. **********For the year, Sohio reported a 7 percent rise in net income, to $1.95 billion, or $7.92 a share, on revenues of $13.81 billion, from $1.8 billion, or $7.37, on revenues of $11.34 billion in 1980. **********Sohio's revenues reflected the inclusion of the sales of the Kennecott Corporation, which Sohio acquired on June 4. Kennecott's metals-mining operations lost $59 million since the June 4 acquistion, because of depressed copper and precious metals prices, but its industrial products and services operations earned $32 million. **********Sohio said earnings were hurt by higher ''windfall profit'' and severance taxes and by a doubling in exploration costs. A $30 million write-off of a desulfurization project in Cleveland partly offset increases in operating income from refining and marketing operations.  Sun Company **********The Sun Company, ranked No.11, reported that fourth-quarter earnings were up about fifteenfold, to $448 million, or $3.59 a share, compared with $30 million, or 22 cents, in the 1980 fourth quarter. Fourth-quarter revenues rose to $4.4 billion from $4.1 billion. **********But Sun's 1981 fourth quarter included one-time gains from sales of assets totaling $2.39 a share, while the 1980 period included a $1.33-a-share write-off of discontinued shipbuilding operations. **********Fourth-quarter operating earnings rose to $149 million in 1981 from $92 million in 1980. The company attributed the increase to higher domestic crude oil and natural gas prices. **********For the full year, Sun reported a 48 percent gain in net income, to $1.1 billion, or $8.59 a share, on revenues of $16 billion, from $723 million, or $5.71, on revenues of $13.2 billion in 1980. The full-year results included a gain of $135 million, or $1.07 a share, from the sale of the Sun's Sperry-Sun oilfield services subsidiary. Pennzoil **********Fourth-quarter earnings at the Pennzoil Company dropped 29 percent, to $54.8 million, or $1.05 a share, on revenues of $653 million, from $77.5 million, or $1.47, on revenues of $659.4 million a year earlier. Full-year earnings dropped to $221.6 million, or $4.23 a share, on revenues of $2.7 billion, from $308.5 million, or $5.90, on sales of $2.5 billion in 1980.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/10/busin.main_headline: FED BACKS CITICORP ON DATA UNIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/10/busin.print_headline: FED BACKS CITICORP ON DATA UNIT
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/10/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Reserve Board cleared the way yesterday for Citicorp to enter the data processing and transmission business through a subsidiary to be known as Citishare. **********The board's 6-to-0 vote approving Citicorp's application was a victory for the bank holding company in a three-year battle with computer services companies that contended Citicorp would be able to offer unfair competition because of its existing contacts with potential customers. **********Patrick J. Mulhern, Citicorp senior vice president and general counsel, said the ruling would clear the way for the holding company, parent of the nation's second-largest bank, to offer such new services as banking at home on computer terminals and electronic publishing of financial and economic data, which Citishare's customers would be able to read on computer terminals. **********''It sounds as though what we asked for, we got, pretty much,'' Mr. Mulhern said. ''It will have real significance in our being able to compete in the new world of technology, and we couldn't be more pleased.'' **********The pace-setting Federal Reserve Board ruling is expected to clear the way for other bank holding companies to also enter the rapidly growing field of data processing. **********The Fed found no evidence, as the computer service firms had feared, that Citicorp would tie its sales of computer services to making of loans through its Citibank unit or that it would subsidize its computer services with revenues from other activities. **********Citicorp was not given a carte blanche entry into computer services, however. Its activities must be restricted to ''banking, financial and economic data.'' **********Jerome Dreyer, president of the Association of Data Processing Service Organizations, which represents computer service companies, said it was likely the group would appeal. However, he said the decision was not as permissive in allowing Citicorp's expansion as he feared it would be. **********The Federal Reserve Board agreed that the activities proposed by Citishare are closely related to banking and therefore permissible under its Regulation Y, which governs the nonbanking activities of holding companies. Earlier this year, an administrative law judge appointed by the board had issued a similar ruling. **********Banks already engage in data processing and transmission for their internal needs and for their banking customers. Computers, for instance, are used to keep track of bank balances and for financial analysis. Automatic teller machines represent a form of data processing and transmission. **********The Fed ruling allows Citishare to offer computer programs, services and hardware to other banks, businesses and consumers, thus putting it into competition with computer companies. **********According to its application, Citicorp is considering a wide range of services. It expects to sell programs on a time-sharing basis to other banks and businesses, allowing them to perform such tasks as credit analysis and financial modeling. It plans to provide accounting, bookkeeping and economic forecasting for business generally. It also wants to provide customers with access to data bases containing information such as economic statistics and foreign currency quotes that are stored in Citicorp's computers. **********The application said it also expects to sell software, hardware, and data transmission services for fund transfers between banks.  Citicorp already owns two channels on a Western Union satellite, which it can use for its internal data transmissions but could also use for outside customers. It also might sell computer terminals and service to consumers, allowing them to pay bills, request balances or perform other banking functions at home. The bank is testing such services.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/07/busin.print_headline: FINKELSTEIN SEEKS ROLE AT CHOCK FULL O' NUTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/07/busin.body_text: **********Jerry Finkelstein, a New York publisher who has been increasing his holding in the Chock Full o' Nuts Corporation, said yesterday that he and associates planned to take a first step today toward seeking control of the company, which has said it would oppose the Finkelstein group. **********Mr. Finkelstein said without elaborating that his group would make a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission leading to a solicitation of proxies to elect a slate of directors at Chock Full o' Nuts. At last report, Mr. Finkelstein's group held 16 percent, or about 778,000 shares, of the fast-food and coffee company, and might control additional shares. **********William Black, chairman of Chock Full o' Nuts, and his family own about a quarter of the company's stock.  An informant close to Mr. Finkelstein said the group was moving to gain control of the company ''obviously to make the most out of its real estate, and to make it a larger and better company - it's a great company that has been slow.'' **********He added: ''The aim of this group is franchising throughout the United States.'' Currently, he said, the company owns about 30 retail outlets in the New York area, in addition to other operations. **********Howard M. Leitner, a Chock Full o' Nuts vice president and the chief financial officer, declined to comment on Mr. Finkelstein's announcement. **********In a legal victory for the Finkelstein group, a Federal District judge in New York ruled yesterday that Chock Full o' Nuts could not bar the group from acquiring stock or waging a proxy contest. **********On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Chock Full o' Nuts stock rose 25 cents, to $17.75.  The Finkelstein group said last month that it would contest the election of directors, and Mr. Finkelstein said that his group had been joined by William Woodward, an investor, and the Benenson Capital Company, led by Charles B. Benenson. Mr. Finkelstein is chairman of ABC Industries, which owns The New York Law Journal. He is also chairman of the Struthers Wells Corporation, which makes heat-transfer equipment. **********Mr. Leitner indicated yesterday that William Black, chairman of the company, and his wife owned 17 percent of the stock. According to previous dislosures, Mr. Black and his fellow directors control at least 20.6 percent. In addition, Barbara Jane Kennedy, a daughter of Mr. Black, owns almost 6 percent. **********Mr. Black, who has been said to be in poor health, told stockholders at the annual report last year that the replacement cost of its bakery on a 2.4-acre site in Secaucus, N.J., exceeded the book value of its other properties, plants and equipment. The plant's value has been estimated at $35 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/06/world.body_text: **********China said today that its spending on ''preparations against war'' would increase to more than $10 billion this year, ending two year's of reductions in military spending. **********The state budget and economic plan for 1982, made public in detail by the official New China News Agency, predict a deficit about the size of last year's $1.76 billion. **********They show that Government planners are hoping for a 4 percent increase in the value of agricultural and industrial output this year. **********Presenting his budget, Finance Minister Wang Bingqian said ''expenditures on national defense and preparations against war'' would be $10.5 billion, an increase of $629 million over 1981. **********China's military expenditure was trimmed to $9.92 billion in 1980.  No figure was announced for last year, but based on the disclosure in the 1982 budget the military spending in 1981 decreased to $9.88 billion. **********Military commanders were angered that they were expected to try to modernize China's oversized and antiquated armed forces as their budgets were being cut. **********Diplomats here say the budget increase is a concession to the military for its support.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/09/busin.body_text: **********The European Economic Community would receive a steel import quota of between 4 and 5 percent of total domestic consumption under proposals being laid before the domestic industry by Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige, industry and Government sources reported today. **********According to Government and industry sources, the Common Market made an offer to voluntarily hold exports to 4.95 percent of annual steel sales in this country. Mr. Baldrige, the sources said, came back with 3.95 percent. **********One domestic industry source said that he thought the industry would accept 5 percent across the board as the market share for the Europeans. **********The negotiations to settle a major conflict between American and European steel producers, which could touch off an Atlantic trade war, moved into a final phase because of an approaching statutory deadline at midnight Thursday. **********Mr. Baldrige and his deputy, Under Secretary of Commerce Lionel H.  Olmer, declined to comment on the negotiations, as did officials of the Common Market here. But Bill Brock, the United States trade representative, said he thought the chances were slim that an accord would emerge by Thursday. **********The Thursday deadline arises from the unfair-trade cases brought by American steelmakers last January. The Commerce Department must decide by midnight Thursday on the amounts of foreign government subsidies, if any, that were incorporated into the United States selling price of steel from seven members of the Common Market - West Germany, France, Italy, Britain, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg. **********In New York, Mr. Baldrige continued the negotiations tonight at a meeting at the Regency Hotel with executives of major domestic steel companies. Afterward, a Commerce Department spokesman in Washington declined to comment on the result. In a telephone interview, the United States Steel Corporation's director of press relations, Andrew Staursky, said from Pittsburgh that the meeting involved ''discussion of the pending steel trade cases.'' He declined to elaborate ''inasmuch as there is a judicial process under way on these complaints.'' **********On the basis of total demand for steel last year of 104 million tons, which includes domestic shipments plus imports but less exports, 4.95 percent would amount to a little more than 5 million tons, compared with 6.4 million tons the Europeans shipped here last year. **********However, the European offer excludes tubular products, which some industry sources said made it unacceptable. These products are used mainly in pipe for the oil and gas industry. They were in short supply last year, but because of cutbacks in domestic drilling activity inventories today are high. **********One industry source said that ''American steel companies are not going to give that market away.'' European steel industry sources said, on the other hand, that even after expansion, now under way, of tubular production capacity, future needs for this type of steel for oil and gas exploration will lead to a demand so great that the American industry will be unable to meet it. Last year American steel companies, such as United States Steel, were the biggest importers of tubular products. West Germany was the biggest supplier. **********Altogether, the Common Market's shipments of tubular goods last year into the United States totaled 1.8 million tons.  According to industry sources, the market share would be based on forecasts that would be self-correcting as the year progressed. The steel would come in ''competitively priced'' under a formula that would peg it close to domestic market prices, according to the proposal of Mr. Baldrige, the sources said. They added that the Common Market commission would monitor the steel on a product-byproduct and country-of-origin basis. **********In the unfair trade practices case, should the department agree with United States Steel and six other domestic producers that foreign governments provided substantial subsidies to help their companies sell at low prices in the United States, allegations that are denied by the Europeans, a process would follow that could bar much European steel from this market. **********The industry has charged that the subsidies, in the form of interest rebates, tax waivers, conversion of debt to government equity and other aids, amounted to as much as $300 on a ton of steel that currently sells for $450 to $500. The Commerce Department's concurrence would lead to the imposition of substantial countervailing duties that would price much of the foreign steel out of the market. **********European officials have made no secret of their intention to retaliate against American products if their steel market is sharply curtailed in the United States. **********The European steel industry is about as depressed as that of the United States and that creates pressure on the Europeans to keep up exports. In Belgium and France, there have been major steelworker riots protesting plant closings.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/11/busin.body_text: **********The Reagan Administration endorsed in principle today a Democratic proposal to reduce the limits on taxdeductible employer contributions to profit-sharing and pension plans. **********The endorsement by John E. Chapoton, the Treasury's Assistant Secretary for Tax Policy, appeared to strengthen the likelihood that this year's expected tax bill would raise some revenue by tightening up on tax benefits for pensions and profit-sharing. **********A lowering of the maximum employer contributions that are deductible has also been proposed by the chief tax writer in the Senate, Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, chairman of the Finance Committee. **********Mr. Chapoton, testifying before the House Ways and Means Committee, withheld endorsement of some provisions of Representative Charles B.  Rangel's proposed Pension Equity Tax Act, but a Rangel aide characterized his testimony as ''generally favorable.'' **********The bill by Representative Rangel, a Manhattan Democrat, was opposed by witnesses for a variety of employers and business groups.  Undergirding employer-funded pension plans are the immediate deduction of contributions from the employer's taxable income and the deferral of tax liability for an employee until he begins drawing pension payments.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/07/busin.body_text: **********Stan Janda of nearby Manassas, Va., walked into the Sears, Roebuck & Company store at the Fair Oaks Mall the other day to return an item. Soon, however, he found himself browsing through racks of literature at the store's financial service center, where employees were selling insurance, stocks and bonds, and homes. **********But on that day, all Mr. Janda did was browse. Such is the challenge faced by Sears: Can the world's largest retailer interest its traditional shopper in the financial services on which it has staked so much? **********Of course, Sears fully expects to succeed.  ''We definitely see this as viable in terms of public acceptance,'' said Douglas Fairwether, a Sears spokesman at its Chicago headquarters. ''If anyone was wondering if people will buy stocks where they buy socks, they will. We've seen that.'' **********About three months ago, Sears opened financial service centers - where consumers can buy auto insurance, sell 100 shares of A.T.& T.  or determine the best way to finance a home - in eight of its 851 stores, including the one here. Depending on how this test works out, other such centers could be introduced in the months ahead. **********But some financial service competitors have some doubts about the experiment. For example, Jim Settle, senior vice president and director of marketing at Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc., said that ''Sears is really emphasizing savings and spending under the same roof.'' He went on: ''But an investor's relation with his stockbroker is a very personal and intimate thing. I'm skeptical, but with a company with their resources, you've got to watch very carefully what they're going to do.'' **********And Peter Muratore, executive vice president and national retail marketing director at E.F. Hutton & Company, observed, ''Generally our industry is not a walk-in business and it isn't a casual business. I think investments are sold more than bought and I'm not sure that the atmosphere in a department store is conducive to this type of selling. But we hope they do very, very well and we would be happy to do similar things with other people if it is successful.'' Company in Position for Move **********The increased interest by Sears in financial services had its genesis at the start of 1982, when the company completed two big acquisitions - taking over Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., a securities broker-dealer, and Coldwell, Banker & Company, a real estate broker, for a total of more than $800 million. **********Sears already owned the Allstate Insurance Company - the country's second-largest writer of automobile and homeowner insurance after State Farm Mutual - and thus was positioned to offer one-stop shopping in finance just as it had been doing in general merchandise. While 76 percent of Sears's revenue of $18.2 billion in the first half of 1982 was still derived from its merchandising group, the company now has an important position in three major financial services - insurance, securities and real estate. **********''We plan to bring a variety of financial services to American consumers,'' said Charles F. Moran, vice president for corporate planning at Sears. ''What better place to do it than in the place where they are most familiar with you - in the Sears store.'' **********But Sears is less than loquacious about the results so far of this experiment in selling services. It refuses to disclose any statistics about the number of customers who have visited the centers, the amount of new financial accounts that have been opened or the revenue derived from this expensive square-footage. **********''Sometime after the first of the year, we'll be able to put together an evaluation of the data and determine what comes next,'' is all that Mr. Moran will say on this subject. ''But in any event, it is most probable that we would not have a financial service center in every store, because some are small and would not be able to support this kind of unit.'' Vast Potential Market **********The marriage of financial services and retailing is not unique to Sears. A number of supermarkets around the country installed automatic teller machines hooked up to local banks some time ago. And just last month, a joint venture was inaugurated between the Kroger Company and the Capital Holding Company to sell such products as insurance, money market funds and individual retirement accounts at some Kroger stores, starting with one in Grove City, Ohio. **********At Sears, however, the theory is that everyone in the store is part of one big, happy family, since the parent corporation is selling its own services as well as its own merchandise. And with 24 million active retail accounts and another 12 million catalogue customers, the company feels that the potential market for its financial services is huge. ''The Sears customer is America,'' asserted Mr.  Fairwether, the Sears spokesman. **********''People can come into a nonmedicinal, nonintimidating atmosphere for their financial services,'' said S. David Whipkey, manager of this 230,000-square-foot, two-level Sears store at the intersection of Route 50 and Interstate 66 in the Washington suburbs. ''And it's not like buying from a street-side vendor, either.'' **********The financial service center in Mr. Whipkey's store is an area of 1,400 square feet next to the busiest entrance and directly across from the catalogue, credit and customer service departments.  Decorated in subdued earth tones, the center is open and informal, shaped in a semicircle and with separate selling alcoves for its three components - Allstate, Dean Witter and Coldwell, Banker. **********Like the store itself, the financial service center is open from 10 A.M. to 9:30 P.M. daily and noon to 5 P.M. Sunday - longer by far than most brokerage, insurance and real estate offices operate.  Traffic in this service area varies from extremely light, as it was around noon on a recent Tuesday, to heavy, as employees say it is on Friday nights and Saturdays. Initially customers were drawn to the center through targeted promotional mailings offering a free financial planning guide to those who came in, but now business is largely generated from those customers who pass by. **********The employees that operate the Dean Witter and Coldwell, Banker booths in the service center rotate on a regular basis from nearby offices of their firms. Allstate workers are assigned to the store on a full-time basis and, like insurance salespeople everywhere, they spend much of their time calling on potential customers at their homes. **********''This place is very good for generating leads,'' said Shaun English, a Dean Witter registered representative who works one day a week at the store. ''We've been opening over two new accounts a day.'' **********Sears people like to tell stories about the unusual business that has developed since the financial service centers opened last July 19. For example, they talk about the couple who came in to open a $2.9 million brokerage account. And they recall the woman who saw a picture of a house in the Coldwell, Banker section of a center and told the representative there that she wanted to buy it - regardless of price or location.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/16/world.body_text: **********President Reagan welcomed the end of fighting in the Falkland Islands today and pledged the United States to assist ''in any way it can'' to produce a lasting political settlement. **********Despite the President's offer, senior Administration officials said Argentina and Britain should first try to settle their differences by themselves. One official said it would be ''presumptuous'' for the United States to seek to mediate or offer proposals without being asked by the Argentines and the British. **********This seeming reluctance by the United States to play a more active postwar role in the Falklands is largely a result, officials said, of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's determination to restore British political control over the islands and not to appear to reward the Argentines for their seizure of the Falklands by encouraging third-party involvement in negotiations. U.S. Said to Be Understanding **********One official said the United States would have preferred a more ''magnanimous'' approach to the Argentines by Mrs. Thatcher. But, he said, given the loss of British lives and the prolonged crisis, the Administration was understanding of her seeming refusal to do more than in effect demand unconditional surrender by the Argentines. **********Mr. Reagan's reaction to the cease-fire was made public in written form by the White House and was devoid of any praise for the British, whose side the United States has supported since April 30, after Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s mediation efforts had broken down. **********The statement also avoided terming the events an Argentine ''surrender,'' trying not to embarrass the Argentines, with whom Washington would like to improve relations now that the Falkland fighting is over. **********''The United States welcomes the cease-fire which is now in place in the Falkland Islands,'' Mr. Reagan's statement said. ''We hope the tragic loss of life which has thus far occurred in this crisis can now be brought to an end. For its part, the United States continues to stand ready to assist in any way it can to help resolve this conflict.'' Worsening of Ties Anticipated **********As a result of the decision to side with Britain, American officials have said that they expect a dramatic worsening of United States relations with other Latin American countries, particularly with Argentina and countries like Venezuela that strongly supported the Argentines. **********Various Latin American experts in the State Department have urged that the Administration give priority after the fighting to trying to repair relationships in the hemisphere, but to avoid dramatic steps such as a high-level visit to the region for fear that this would provide a target for anti-American groups and perhaps worsen the situation. **********Rather, they have advised seeking consultations after tempers have cooled, and making an effort to persuade Latin countries that the United States remains committed to the hemisphere alliance.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/29/world.main_headline: WAR SPARED FALKLAND WILDLIFE, BUT WILL THE PEACE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/29/world.print_headline: WAR SPARED FALKLAND WILDLIFE, BUT WILL THE PEACE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/29/world.body_text: **********The penguins, seals and other wildlife of the Falkland Islands were spared serious damage in the fighting here ''through a bit of good luck,'' said Ian J. Strange, the islands' conservationist. **********The penguins and seals, he said, ''were out to sea.'' The large colonies of seabirds, meanwhile, migrate in the winter, the season it was during the fighting and still is in these remote islands in the South Atlantic. ''If the fighting had commenced three months earlier,'' Mr. Strange said, ''it could have had a disastrous effect.'' **********The islands' wildlife, however, may yet feel the war's aftermath.  With the nearly certain prospect of Britain's establishing a large military garrison, probably doubling the Falklands' population of 1,800, the wildlife could be threatened, according to Mr. Strange. Tourist Trade Imperiled **********''There will be a lot of ship involvement,'' he said, glancing out at a harbor crowded with warships and transport vessels, ''and with that there will be accidents, oil spills.'' **********Another postwar difficulty, he said, is the likely curtailment of a small but steady tourist trade, most of it geared to Falkland wildlife. Ships that brought conservationists and photographers usually stopped in Argentina before sailing to the Falklands. ''They would then go on to Antarctica,'' Mr. Strange said. **********Argentina's strained relations with Britain, however, may prompt the tourist ships to bypass the Falklands. ''In any case,'' he said, ''I see political problems.'' **********For those who once came on their own, on a weekly flight from Argentina, prospects are similarly dismal because that link has been severed. Air Fleet Destroyed **********Within the islands, access between Stanley and the remote settlements on the main islands, and to the even more remote islands rich in wildlife, was almost entirely by air. But the entire local air fleet - two float planes and a land plane - was destroyed in the fighting. **********''There are only helicopters now,'' Mr. Strange said, ''and I've been trying to get on one to visit New Island,'' a reserve at the extreme western edge of the islands. **********''But our priorities are not high enough,'' he said.  Mr. Strange lives with his wife, Maria, and their 15-month-old daughter, Georgina, in a Scandinavian-style house made from a special sort of driftwood. ''About 80 years ago,'' he said, ''a ship called the Bertha was shipwrecked here, and it was carrying a cargo of cedar logs. I gathered them up and built the house.'' Stayed During the Occupation **********Mr. Strange arrived here 22 years ago from Lincolnshire, England, to run an experimental sheep farm, but he turned to conservation, following an interest that his grandfather and others in his family had pursued. He earns his living as a wildlife artist, stamp designer, writer and lecturer. **********During the Argentine occupation of the islands, he said, ''we refused to leave our house.'' That was a decision made by about half the people of Stanley, who assumed, correctly, that empty houses would be occupied by Argentine soldiers. ''I bricked up a corner,'' he said, ''which we used as a shelter, and in fact a couple of bullets went through a window.'' **********The house also suffered some shrapnel damage when a salvo from the British naval bombardment ''landed 30 meters away, by their radar installation.'' **********The Argentine authorities ''knew everybody here,'' Mr. Strange said, ''because many had worked for years as Argentinian representatives.'' **********''They were generally good normal people.'' Life Still Far From Normal **********Mrs. Strange is an Argentine, and she was asked to serve as a translator. ''She said she'd do so only in the hospital,'' Mr.  Strange said, ''and they accepted that.'' **********The fighting has ended, but life in the Falklands is still far from normal. ''People are short-tempered and very nervous toward each other,'' he said. **********''Just the sheer volume of noise,'' he added, glancing out at the busy waterfront. ''I haven't touched a paintbrush. I find it very difficult to concentrate.'' **********Among the qualities of the Falkland wildlife are the sheer numbers. ''There are millions of penguins, millions,'' Mr. Strange said.  ''There are also albatrosses, large seal herds and a variety of marine animals, such as dolphins and porpoises, and a few whales.'' **********Many seabirds use the islands as a breeding ground in the summer months, from October to March. Nobody had done any wildlife census work, he said, although he once estimated that the albatross colony numbered two million and that the penguins were more numerous. Some Birds Limited to Islands **********''We also have certain species of seabirds only found here,'' he said, ''such as a form of petrel prion and a rare form of hawk, the striated caracara, that exists only in the Falklands.'' **********He said the wildlife was concentrated on West Falkland, one of the two major islands, where there was relatively little destruction from the fighting. **********Stanley, where much more damage was inflicted, ''is not reknowned for wildlife,'' he said. ''But in Stanley the Agentinians used scare depth charges against possible frogmen, and porpoises and dolphins would have been killed, here and outside of Port William.'' Port William is just north of Stanley. **********Mr. Strange said Argentine soldiers inflicted some damage on the wildlife. ''They were short of food and were prepared to shoot anything in the bird line,'' he said. Strict Measures Needed **********The British presence, 2,000 to 3,000 soldiers now, is likely to be 2,000 in a permanent garrison.  Conservation measures will have to be strict, Mr. Strange said.  ''The islanders themselves,'' he said, ''tended to be conservationoriented, but we've had a lot of visitors and the younger people view wildlife with a different eye.'' **********Education, he said, was perhaps the answer. ''I have great difficulty teaching,'' he said. ''I can lecture easily, in the States and elsewhere, but one is a bit shy among one's own people. I'll leave that to the teachers.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/02/busin.body_text: **********Oppenheimer & Co., a Wall Street partnership famous for its bold, deal-making moves, has embarked on perhaps the biggest and most lucrative deal in its 32-year history - its own takeover for approximately $162.5 million, payable mostly in cash. **********In an announcement yesterday, it said it had agreed to sell Oppenheimer Holdings Inc., which includes the member firm of the New York Stock Exchange and three other operating businesses, to Mercantile House Holdings P.L.C. of London, a leading international financial services group. **********The partnership will receive an estimated $117 million in cash and the balance in stock in Mercantile House. The partnership consists of 26 general partners, plus 59 Oppenheimer employees and 36 investors. **********The biggest individual stakes belong to Oppenheimer's two principal architects and driving forces, Jack Nash, 52 years old, chairman and chief executive officer, and Leon Levy, 56, chairman of Oppenheimer Management, who will remain active in certain aspects of the combined company. Firm Started in 1950 **********The Oppenheimer brokerage firm, the original basis for the partnership's current vast interests, was started in 1950 by the late Max Oppenheimer -no relation to the South African Oppenheimer family, whose leading member, Harry F. Oppenheimer yesterday announced his retirement as head of the giant Anglo-American Corporation. **********Its first business was making markets in blocked German currencies after World War II. Mr. Levy joined the firm in 1951, originally building up the customer research effort, while Mr. Nash came aboard the next year. **********The firm's reputation for innovation reflects its role in such deals as raising $40 million in capital for John Z. DeLorean's gullwinged sports car several years ago. Last year, it floated a publicly owned bond, now traded on the American Stock Exchange, as a means of raising capital - the first privately owned Big Board firm to have done so. **********Along with various acquisitions, the firm also acquired - for its fashionable 32-floor private dining room -French-born Anne Marie Durand, the former personal chef of Katharine Graham, principal owner of the Washington Post Company. **********The merger with Mercantile marks not only the latest in several large investment-firm mergers but also the first whereby a foreign entity would acquire complete control of a major United States securities firm. 'Global Synergism' **********In an interview, Oppenheimer's 41-year-old president, Stephen Robert, said of the deal: ''You could call it global synergism.'' **********Its chief significance, he said, was that ''it will allow both Mercantile House and ourselves to expand our products and services - brokerage, money management and commodities - on an international scale.'' Previously, Oppenheimer, operating out of five branches in the United States and one in London, had enjoyed only limited exposure overseas. **********In recent years, foreign investments have been made in a number of Big Board firms, including Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the First Boston Corporation and the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation. **********Meanwhile, the increasingly global scope of the investment business was underscored only last month when Merrill Lynch, this nation's biggest broker by far, signaled that it intended to offer its services in worldwide markets far more aggressively. Merrill Lynch agreed to establish a Hong Kong connection by acquiring a 25 percent stake in Sun Hung Kai Securities Ltd. and a 15 percent interest in the affiliated Sun Hung Kai Bank. **********Last October, the Phibro Corporation, the world's largest trader of commodities, acquired Salomon Brothers, the nation's biggest privately owned investment banking firm. This was interpreted as a move to position Phibro-Salomon as a marketer of any commodity, including money, to any customer anywhere in the world at any time. Wall Street Admiration **********Reaction to Oppenheimer's major deal generally was one of admiration yesterday on Wall Street. **********''This gives Mercantile House direct access to U.S. markets in one fell swoop,'' observed George L. Ball, president of the E.F. Hutton Group, one of the securities industry's largest still-independent firms and itself a recurring object of takeover rumors. **********Perrin H. Long Jr., who follows the brokerage industry for Lipper Analytical Services Inc., was more exuberant. ''It's a very good deal for Oppenheimer's management,'' he declared. ''If I offered you 3.4 times your 'book value,' or net worth, which is what Oppenheimer Holdings is getting, you'd be crazy not to take it.'' **********Moreover, he noted, the $162.5 million price tag comes to more than nine times last year's reported profit of $17 million by Oppenheimer Holdings. **********Friends of Oppenheimer's two largest owners, Mr. Nash and Mr. Levy, said yesterday that these men, along with other senior partners, had indicated their desire privately for some time ''to cash in on their investment.'' **********As moving forces at Oppenheimer, the two men have complemented each other in remarkably successful fashion. As the partnership grew, it was Mr. Nash's role initially to watch over the finances while Mr.  Levy became the guiding light for money-making ideas. Later, in 1975, when Oppenheimer was reorganized into several units, Institutional Investor magazine characterized Mr. Levy as ''the partner in charge of interplanetary affairs.'' 'Call Me Jack' **********In personality, the two men are strikingly different. Mr. Nash, who often works in shirt sleeves at the firm's luxurious headquarters at One New York Plaza, is given to quick, direct answers. Once, when a visitor addressed him as ''Mr. Nash,'' he responded: ''Call me Jack.  Mr. Nash is my father.'' **********Mr. Levy, in contrast, has been described by friends as often conveying the air of an absent-minded professor. According to one documented story, he once ushered a woman into a taxi, walked around to the other door, opened it and then said: ''I'm sorry. I didn't know this cab was taken.'' **********Oppenheimer executives who will join Mercantile House's board of directors are Mr. Nash and Mr. Robert, along with Nathan Gantcher and Donald W. Spiro. **********Another beneficiary of the deal is Electra Investment Trust, which has been an investor in the Oppenheimer Group for seven years.  Electra's investment in the Oppenheimer partnership entitles it to 20 percent of the sale proceeds, to be paid in Mercantile House stock. The Oppenheimer partnership, meanwhile, is to receive 90 percent of its interest in cash and its remaining 10 percent in stock. **********Mercantile House will receive Oppenheimer & Co. Inc., the Big Board's 25th-largest firm, with capital of $41.15 million. It also will get three money-management and realty operating companies - the Oppenheimer Management Company, the Oppenheimer Capital Corporation, and Oppenheimer Properties Inc.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/04/busin.body_text: **********THE Dayco Corporation, the dominant producer of fan belts for the automotive industry, has been regarded as an investors' asset play.  Dayco's shares have languished since mid-1979 when automobile sales began to sag more deeply than anyone had expected. Earlier this year the shares traded at 11 3/8. **********Asset-conscious investors recognized this price as less than half the company's book value per share, and they reasoned that business would improve someday. Besides, despite hard times, the company was reporting fine profits and was generally optimistic. **********In its fiscal year ended last Oct. 31, Dayco seemed to have been unusually successful in view of the car makers' slump. The company initially reported earnings of $1.13 a share. This figure was higher than the general Wall Street estimate of $1.05 a share and was up from the $1.10 a share earned a year earlier. All figures shown are on a fully diluted basis. **********Then came the shocker. Dayco indicated in January that it had monitored foreign orders placed by an independent sales agent and discovered that they apparently were not valid. Dayco said that the $9 million profit it initially had foreseen would turn into an aftertax loss that could be as much as $5 million on a ''worst case'' basis. **********Last week Dayco announced an $11.7 million nonrecurring write-off because orders delivered to a port warehouse had not been picked up.  Thomas Ryan, vice president of corporate communications, explained that this write-off had eliminated the anticipated $9 million profit and resulted in a net loss to the company of $2.7 million. **********In its report last week, Dayco said there were ''substantial discrepancies between representations made to us by an independent sales agent and information received from foreign customers.'' So the company was forced to write off about $20 million in accounts receivable, inventory and prepaid expenses. **********Meanwhile, the automotive, off-the-road equipment and construction industry businesses have been doing poorly. Many of Dayco's original-equipment customers closed their plants to hold inventories at lower-than-normal levels, partly to trim interest costs at a time of high rates. **********What bothered at least one investor in Dayco stock was this barely noticed news item: The short interest in the shares of Dayco rose substantially in the month ended Feb. 11. **********Short interest, representing the sale of borrowed shares, indicates the degree to which investors are willing to bet that a stock will trade lower in the foreseeable future. For example, traders who think a company may fail to meet its earnings goal can go short, hoping that the stock will go down. If it does, they can buy shares in the open market at the lower price. The difference between what they get in selling the borrowed shares and what they pay later is profit. **********On Jan. 15 the short interest in Dayco was 136,599 shares. A month later it totaled 160,451 shares, an increase of 17 percent. (In February there was no trading on either Friday the 12th or Monday the 15th because of the Lincoln and Washington Birthday holidays.) Since the average daily volume was just 12,889 shares, the short interest represented a substantial part of the month's volume. **********Some of the short interest could represent hedging operations against the company's outstanding convertible bonds. Dayco's chairman, Richard J. Jacob, was reached at company headquarters and was asked to comment. He said he thought the rise in short interest did represent hedging against convertibles. **********But it is possible that someone who knew about the foreign-order problem sold a lot of shares short.  Since the company had already disclosed a potential loss, the prospects of a short-selling profit were modest. The price of the shares, at 12, appeared to discount fully the expected loss. When the actual extent of the loss was announced, the company's dividend seemed to be in jeopardy. The stock has been declining since then.  Dayco set a 12-month low of 10 late last week, and it closed yesterday at 10 1/4. **********Those who have been buying the shares on the basis of their intrinsic value have been disappointed. The book value has declined to $21 a share from $23.

The group is to arrive here Monday. **********Ann Griffiths, executive director of the National League of Families, said her group asked the Laotians to increase search efforts. https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/07/busin.body_text: **********French business activity weakened in the first three months of 1982, according to recently released figures, dealing a blow to President Francois Mitterrand's plans to revitalize the economy. **********The National Statistics Institute said the gross domestic product fell one-tenth of 1 percent in this year's first quarter after a rise of seven-tenths of 1 percent in the last quarter of 1981. The latest figure was revised from an originally reported rise of 1.4 percent. **********The Government's strategy has been based on rapid economic growth, financed by heavy state spending. But the administration recently reduced to 2.5 percent, from 3.3 percent, its forecast of 1982 economic growth. And now the figure is expected to be closer to 2 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/16/world.print_headline: GALTIERI MUSES ON WHAT-IF'S OF FALKLAND WAR
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/16/world.body_text: **********Argentina should have continued its war with Britain even after Argentine forces were defeated in the Falkland Islands, former President Leopoldo Galtieri said in an interview published today. **********General Galtieri, who as President ordered the Argentine occupation of the Falklands on April 2, said assistance from Latin America, Libya and others in the third world would have allowed Argentina to continue the fight. **********In an interview with the weekly magazine Siete Dias, General Galtieri said Libya had sent five planes loaded with ''very valuable elements'' in the war. **********Referring to Stanley, the Falkland capital, he said, ''Even with the loss of Puerto Argentino and without internationalizing the conflict, we should have continued the action in such a way that the enemy would have been faced by serious, permanent and systematic difficulties and risks and be obliged to realize that we Argentines were not going to surrender.'' Galtieri Was Ousted on June 17 **********He did not say what the commanders of the navy and the air force, the two other services making up Argentina's ruling junta, thought of his desire to continue the war. General Galtieri was ousted June 17, three days after the Argentine surrender in the Falklands, and was replaced as President by Maj. Gen. Reynaldo B. Bignone. **********In a new shake-up of top officers who took part in the war, the navy today announced the retirement of 18 admirals. Among them are Juan Lombardo, chief of the South Atlantic theater of operations in the war, and Leopoldo Suarez del Cerro, wartime chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. **********It was the second of the three armed forces branches to shake up its command after the Falkland defeat. The air force was restructured last month with the retirement of its wartime commander, Gen. Basilio Lami Dozo, and a dozen other generals. Military sources say a shakeup in the army could come later this month, when an army commission studying the service's performance in the war ends its investigation. **********General Galtieri said Argentina's main allies in the conflict were ''our Latin American brothers'' and members of the group of nations professing nonalignment. He said Libya ''sent five Boeing airliners loaded with different materials, with very valuable elements, without our having asked for or offered to buy anything, and without any economic or political obligation involved.'' Exocets Used Effectively **********He did not specify what the Libyan shipments contained, but unconfirmed reports circulating here during the war said Argentina had received French-made Exocet missiles from Libya. The Argentine Air Force and Navy made effective use of Exocets against British warships, sinking four of them. **********General Galtieri denied reports that his Government tried to capture the islands in a move to divert public attention from a social and economic crisis. Argentina is suffering from its worst recession in 50 years. **********He said he would not have ordered the invasion if he had thought Britain would use nuclear arms in a confrontation. ''Had we considered it probable that Britain would use its nuclear arsenal, with support from the United States, it would have been harebrained to attempt the April 2 operation,'' he said. **********General Galtieri, who said he now lives on his army pension, described himself as being ''at peace with my conscience, God, my family, my friends and my country.'' He added, ''I am happy.'' **********The 74-day Falkland war left 712 Argentines and 256 British dead.  Argentina invaded asserting that the Falklands, inhabited by about 1,800 settlers, mostly of British descent, were illegally taken from this country in 1833 when the Royal Navy expelled an Argentine governor and settlers from the islands.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/25/world.body_text: **********Fighting erupted in the mountains east of Beirut Tuesday, reportedly between Israeli-backed Lebanese Christian militiamen and Syrian troops. Plans to begin withdrawing Palestinian guerrillas through that area to Syria today were then postponed. **********The postponement was announced without explanation by the Israeli military command in Tel Aviv, the Israeli radio reported. The command said the pullout by sea would continue as scheduled. **********(An army spokesman said in Israel later Tuesday that the Israeli Government had been advised from Lebanon that the overland pullout had been put off for ''organizational and technical difficulties.'' The spokesman said he saw no major problems in the withdrawal as a whole.) U.S. Marines Land in Beirut **********Meanwhile, 800 United States marines landed at the Beirut harbor around dawn today to take control of the port and to help monitor the withdrawal of the Palestine Liberation Organization guerrillas.  The multinational force that will supervise the pullout will be made up of American, French and Italian troops. **********The Americans landed at exactly 5 A.M. (11 P.M. Tuesday, New York time) as the nose of the gray landing craft carrying the first company of 210 troops touched the edge of the wharf. The marines were met by Philip C. Habib, the special American envoy. **********''We had a lovely trip,'' said Col. James Mead, who led his men ashore. Israelis Deny Involvement **********The marines arrived hours after the fighting east of Beirut resulted in the delay in the overland pullout. An Israeli military spokesman in Beirut said Israeli forces were not involved in Tuesday's fighting, which broke out in the Bhamdun area 12 miles east of Beirut near the withdrawal route. **********But this was disputed in Lebanese Christian broadcasts and by the state-run Beirut radio. Both said Israeli gunners were exchanging heavy artillery fire in the Bhamdun area with the Syrians. **********Meanwhile, the pullout of Palestinian guerrillas continued Tuesday, with about 600 fighters from various factions leaving on a Cypriot car ferry for Yemen. The departing Palestinians were saluted by volleys of gunfire triggered by comrades still here. Signs of Some Snags **********Even before the postponement of the departure of guerrillas by land to Syria was announced, there were some signs that snags might be developing in the pullout plan painstakingly worked out by Mr. Habib. **********The numbers of guerrillas in the trucks departing for the port have appeared smaller than the numbers announced as scheduled to go, and the Israelis have raised objections to the vagueness of the lists made by Lebanese security officials. **********New violence and political tension were provoked in Beirut Tuesday by the election Monday of Bashir Gemayel, the Christian militia commander, as Lebanon's sixth President. Mr. Gemayel is to succeed Elias Sarkis next month. **********On Tuesday the homes of six more Moslem Members of Parliament who took part in the parliamentary session at which Mr. Gemayel was elected were attacked in west Beirut, as was a bank in which another owned half interest. On Monday, antitank shells and rocket-propelled grenades were fired at the homes of three Moslem Members of Parliament. The decision by some Moslems to attend the session raised the number of participants to 62, a bare quorum, making the holding of the election possible. 'A National Confrontation' **********Other Moslem politicians, religious leaders and militia chiefs met in a constant stream Monday and Tuesday at the mansion of Saeb Salam, a former Prime Minister, to discuss their response to the election of Mr. Gemayel. A statement was issued declaring their intention of ''offering a national confrontation.'' **********The statement accused the Lebanese Christian Phalangists of seeking through the election of Mr. Gemayel ''to impose a regime whose factional, dictatorial and fascist features are already obvious.'' **********''The election would not have taken place,'' the statement said, ''had it not been for the fact that the national public will was crippled by the Israeli military occupation.'' Premier Must Be a Moslem **********But some politicians suggested that the statement was carefully enough worded so that it did not preclude the possibility that some kind of a deal could be made. **********The President, who must always be a Maronite Catholic under the unwritten covenant that governs politics here, must name a Sunni Moslem as his Prime Minister. **********Former Prime Minister Rashid Karami, who lives in the northern port city of Tripoli, issued a statement rejecting the election entirely, saying, ''No power in the world will be able to force us to accept these results.'' **********Walid Jumblatt, the Druse leader who heads the coalition of leftist militia forces, gloomily told reporters here that he expected Mr.  Gemayel to use Israeli forces to suppress west Beirut. **********''Lebanon has now entered a big prison,'' he said.  Soon after the election of Mr. Gemayel on Monday, gunmen from various militia factions roamed the streets of west Beirut and began attacking the homes of Members of Parliament. **********At about 3 A.M. Tuesday, a powerful explosion blew apart the offices of the Beirut Riyadh Bank over a little pizza place on Hamra Street, and the bank was looted. Hussein Mansour, a Shiite Moslem, who attended the session, is a co-owner of the bank. **********By nightfall Tuesday, a total of nine homes had been attacked, including that of Kamal al-Assad, the Shiite Moslem Speaker of Parliament who had called the election. At one home, neighborhood people drove off firefighters who tried to put out the blaze. **********Most of the explosions came in west Beirut, but one was in the northern Lebanese town of Aqura, in an area controlled by the Maronite Catholic militias of former President Suleiman Franjieh. He has borne a grudge against the Gemayel family since a Phalangist raiding party killed his eldest son, the son's wife and baby daughter and about 30 followers several years ago.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/30/world.print_headline: POLAND'S CHIEF SAYS REGIME WILL LIMIT 'ACTIVENESS' OF U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/30/world.body_text: **********The head of Poland's military Government, Gen.  Wojciech Jaruzelski, plans to ''limit American activeness on Polish territory'' in retaliation for President Reagan's latest trade sanctions, the official Polish press agency P.A.P. reported tonight. **********In the first official account of General Jaruzelski's closing speech to a meeting of the Polish Communist Party's Central Committee, which ended Thursday, the press agency quoted the Polish leader as saying that he had expected the latest United States sanctions, which were imposed after the formal abolition of the Solidarity union Oct. 8. **********But the agency said General Jaruzelski went on to tell the Central Committee: ''Nonetheless, in the situation which has arisen, we will limit American activeness on Poland's territory. These will be our restrictions, applied by the sovereign Polish state.'' **********The Polish leader made no other reference to retaliation against the latest United States trade sanctions, and there was no indication from other official sources as to exactly what he had in mind. Earlier today, the Polish authorities informed the United States charge d'affaires in Warsaw that they were banning the distribution of the Polish-language magazine ''Ameryka,'' which is put out by the American Embassy here. **********After the Polish decision to abolish Solidarity, President Reagan withdrew most-favored-nation treatment for Polish exports to the United States. According to Polish officials, this is likely to cost Poland about $40 million a year in lost sales to the United States because of the higher tariff on Polish goods. **********General Jaruzelski said Poland was now coming under ''particularly fierce attack'' from the United States and ''other imperialist circles'' because they now realized their attempt ''to secure the collapse of a Socalist state'' had failed and they would not ''make a Trojan horse out of Poland.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/28/world.main_headline: CANADA PLANNING TO LIMIT NEWSPAPER CHAINS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/28/world.print_headline: CANADA PLANNING TO LIMIT NEWSPAPER CHAINS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/28/world.body_text: **********The Canadian Government is preparing legislation that is intended to limit the growth of newspaper chains as a way of protecting freedom of the press from private monopoly interests. **********James Fleming, the Cabinet minister dealing with press questions, announced the measures this week as the Government's response to a report by an official commission that warned of the dangers of ''conglomerate ownership.'' **********In a speech at the University of Western Ontario Tuesday and at a news conference on Wednesday, Mr. Fleming said no chain would be allowed to control more than 20 percent of the daily newspaper circulation in the country. **********Canada's two largest chains, Southam News and Thomson Newspapers, each have more than that but will not have to divest themselves of any properties because ''retroactivity is repugnant,'' Mr. Fleming said. But they will not be allowed to expand, he said. Smaller chains will be allowed to expand up to the 20 percent limit. Big Chains Under Indictment **********Southam has 28 percent of the newspaper market and Thomson 21 percent. Both are under indictment on charges of conspiring to reduce competition in four cities by closing or merging papers. **********Another restriction on press concentration contained in the new legislation will forbid ''cross media holdings,'' or the ownership by one company of a newspaper and a radio or television station in any single market area. Those who already have such holdings will have to demonstrate ''real hardship,'' Mr. Fleming said, to avoid having to give up one property. The Canadian Radio and Television Commission has had a policy of discouraging newspapers from owning broadcasting outlets, and that policy will now be applied more firmly. **********A private company not previously involved in the press will have to demonstrate that any newspaper it acquires will be managed independently of its other interests. **********The legislation will provide for a Canadian Advisory Council on Newspapers to receive complaints from the public and to promote public debate on press questions. The council will deal with newspapers that are not already members of provincial press councils. The Advisory Council, with 50 part-time members representing publishers, journalists and the public, will act independently of government and will have sanction power beyond the impact of public criticism of a paper. **********Mr. Fleming also announced a five-year cost-sharing program with an annual maximum of about $810,000 in government grants to help individual newspapers establish news bureaus outside their provinces and abroad. Foreign Dominance Cited **********He told students at the London, Ontario, university that ''Canadians continue, especially in the print media, to receive too little news from other parts of their nation.'' He added that with the dominance of foreign press agencies, ''we are receiving a view of the world most often filtered through non-Canadian eyes.'' He described the grants as ''purely economic'' and ''completely nonjudgmental editorially.'' **********Mr. Fleming said the Government had to avoid ''intruding or appearing to intrude in a matter intimidating to editorial freedom.'' But he added, ''The Cabinet has concluded that certain governmental actions must be taken to control potential interference with or infringement of freedom of the press.'' **********Reactions from the industry were mainly negative. The Thomson Organization condemned the idea of an advisory press council as opening the way to ''encroachment on freedom of the press'' and said a legislative freeze on expansion of chains was unnecessary. Gordon Fisher, president of Southam, said the Government would do better to spend money on journalism schools rather than on subsidies to newspapers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/03/busin.body_text: **********The stock market surged in heavy trading. Analysts said it was buoyed by hopes that the election will not change the economy's direction toward lower inflation and interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 16.38 points, to 1,022.08. Volume expanded to 104.8 million shares from Monday's 73.5 million. (Page D1.) **********Prices of tax-exempt and corporate bonds were firm in light trading. (D14.) The dollar declined in foreign-exchange trading, while gold prices were up $5.50 an ounce, to $433.50, in London. The Comex was closed. (D16.) Pork belly futures prices fell. (D16.) **********The Economy **********Sales of new single-family homes rose 23.7 percent in September, the Commerce Department reported, while the average sales price fell $7,000, to $82,300. Some economists saw the sales increase, following one of 5.9 percent in August, as a key factor in any recovery, pointing to increases in housing starts. They cited recent declines in mortgage interest rates. (D1.) **********Banks may compete directly with securities firms in selling commercial paper to investors, a Federal appeals court ruled. The decision upheld an interpretation of the Glass-Steagall Act by the Federal Reserve. Analysts saw it as a further move by banks into areas long reserved to investment houses. (D6.) **********New orders for factory goods rose 0.7 percent in September, the Commerce Department reported. The gain was seen as a healthy sign but too modest to indicate any major shift in the economy. It was concentrated in nondurable goods such as food-related items, with orders for durable goods such as cars declining. (D15.) International **********Three negotiating sessions have failed to resolve the dispute between the U.S. and its allies over sanctions against companies involved in the Soviet natural gas pipeline, according to high State Department officials. They said France is the main obstacle to an accord on a new East-West trade policy under which the penalties would be dropped. Still, they hope for an eventual accord. (D8.) **********Poland's creditor banks in the West have agreed to lend it $600 million as part of a plan meant to ease repayment of debts due this year, according to diplomatic sources. Under the rescheduling accord, Poland would have until next March to pay the foreign banks about $1.1 billion of the $3.3 billion due to be paid in 1982. (D1.) **********Warsaw asked the GATT council to urge the repeal of sanctions imposed by the U.S. on imports of Polish products. (D16.) **********British business leaders, ending an annual conference, called for relief from local taxes, a tougher trade talk stance and the removal of a surcharge on an insurance tax paid for all employees. It was clear that they wished to minimize disagreements with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Conservative administration. (D13.) Companies **********Duke Power plans to cancel construction of two large nuclear reactors. Since 1974, the North Carolina utility has spent $68 million on the reactors, but has completed only preliminary excavation for them. It said growth in demand for electricity, originally projected at 7 percent a year, is running at 2 percent a year. (D1.) **********Brentano's has told its employees that it may close its flagship bookstore on Fifth Avenue. As part of a belt-tightening drive, the company, which filed for Chapter 11 protection last May, closed its two Washington stores over the weekend. It has maintained a presence on Fifth Avenue for more than a century. (D9.) **********Internorth reported a 48.8 percent drop in net income in the third quarter. Emerson Electric's net edged up 1.7 percent. (D6.) **********Honeywell is reducing its labor force in information systems operations by almost 7 percent. (D4.) Today's Columns **********Does economics deal with objective reality or is it largely subjective? While labels like ''depression'' and ''recession'' may be arbitrary, an underlying layer of facts is there to be deciphered as a basis for intelligent action. Leonard Silk. Economic Scene. (D2.) **********Black & Decker may sell its ailing McCullough chain saw unit, but that would not necessarily restore past profit levels. Analysts are still cool toward the company, partly because of increasingly intense competition from tool makers abroad. Market Place. (D10.)

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/18/world.main_headline: HOUSE PANEL APPROVES $20 MILLION TO LEBANON
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/18/world.print_headline: HOUSE PANEL APPROVES $20 MILLION TO LEBANON
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/18/world.body_text: **********A House panel voted today in favor of $20 million in emergency help for Lebanon as several members of Congress assailed Israel's attack against Palestine Liberation Organization strongholds there. **********Representative Nick J. Rahall, Democrat of West Virginia, told the House Foreign Affairs Committee's panel on Europe and the Middle East that the United States ''has given birth to a monster'' in supporting Israel. **********''We have let that monster grow, we have armed it, and now we can't control it,'' said Mr. Rahall, whose grandparents were born in Lebanon. ''I am outraged that my country has permitted the Israeli Government to sacrifice the people of Lebanon so as to rid itself of the P.L.O.'' 'Fueled the Fire' of Hostility **********Moments earlier, Representative Mary Rose Oakar, Democrat of Ohio, said; ''Resorting to such an appallingly violent approach in Lebanon, Israel has fueled the fire of Arab hostility. Since we serve as Israel's weapons supplier, that hostility is extended to us as well.'' **********In approving the Reagan Administration's request for $20 million in emergency food, clothing and medical supplies for Lebanon, members of the House said that more money for the nation would probably be needed. **********Representative Lee H. Hamilton, Democrat of Indiana, said: ''We are hearing about carnage of enormous proportions.'' He said ''fairly reliable reports from Lebanon'' suggested that as many as 10,000 civilians had been killed since the Israeli attack, more than 16,000 wounded and in urgent need of medical supplies and as many as 600,000 uprooted. Israeli casualties, dead and wounded, are in the hundreds, he added. 1,000 Amputations in a Day **********Mr. Hamilton said that a doctor at the American University Hospital in Beirut reported that on Sunday about 1,100 limbs were amputated.  ''For purely humanitarian reasons, the fighting should be stopped,'' said Mr. Hamilton. He added that once the fighting ended the dimensions of relief needs would be assessed and ''further assistance will be discussed.'' **********Besides requesting $20 million in aid to Lebanon, the Administration has also announced a $5 million emergency assistance program, once the Beirut international airport and the harbor are reopened, to allow food and medical supplies. **********Representative Oakar urged the allocation of at least $200 million to rebuild Lebanon. Aid to Israel Noted **********''That is a large sum,'' she said, ''but we would like to remind the committee that it would be less than a tenth of the amount we annually provide Israel, which is slated to get $2.5 billion in U.S.  assistance in fiscal year '83.'' **********During the hearing, Representative Thomas P. Lantos, Democrat of California, took strong exception to some of the comments by Miss Oakar and Mr. Rahall, who testified before the panel, as well as statements by Representative Paul Findley, Republican of Illinois.  Mr. Findley, a member of the panel, is a supporter of Palestinian statehood. **********Mr. Lantos said that Lebanon was a peaceful nation until Palestinian and Syrian troops moved in. ''Thousands of P.L.O.  terrorists and Syrian soldiers overwhelmed the whole country, and the world watched,'' he said. ''Terrorists fired rockets into peaceful villages in Israel, and the world watched. Pregnant Israeli women, and Israeli children were murdered, and the world watched.'' Arms to Libya Cited **********He added that it was ''unfair'' only to cite American arms supplies to Israel, when weapons from the Soviet Union and Libya played a significant role in the violence that had racked Lebanon in recent years. **********Also appearing before the panel were Wat T. Cluverius, Deputy Assistant Secretary in the State Department's Bureau of Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs, and Bradshaw Langmaid Jr., an administrator for the Near East at the Agency for International Development. **********Mr. Langmaid said that providing medical help, assisting the homeless and rebuilding water supplies appeared to be the major priority at the moment. Food stocks, he added, appeared to be ''adequate.'' **********Mr. Cluverius said the Administration was committed to the withdrawal of all foreign troops from Lebanon. ''We want to see the Government of Lebanon reconstituted,'' he said. **********He said also that, while the United States wants an Israeli withdrawal, ''Lebanon can no longer be a launching pad for attacks against Israel.''
