https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/27/world.body_text: **********The Soviet Union said tonight that more fighting in the Falkland Islands dispute between Britain and Argentina would pose ''great danger'' - especially to ''those who provoke'' it. **********The warning, in a commentary carried by the state-controlled television, was the first substantive reaction here to the British retaking Sunday of South Georgia, a Falklands dependency. **********It did not specify the dangers the Soviet Union foresaw. **********The commentary criticized the mediation efforts of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and said that Britain and the United States were conspiring to increase NATO influence in the region. **********''In our times,'' it said, ''political problems are not solved with naval units - and the neo-colonialists will have to convince themselves of this.'' It insisted that the matter be turned over to the United Nations. **********The commentary gave no indication that the Kremlin would take steps to help Argentina militarily if the British mounted an attack on the Falklands, about 800 miles west of South Georgia. **********The Foreign Ministry has contended that the Soviet Union was neutral in the dispute, favoring a peaceful settlement.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/16/world.main_headline: U.S. TO SHIFT TO REMOVAL OF ALL FORCES IN LEBANON
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/16/world.print_headline: U.S. TO SHIFT TO REMOVAL OF ALL FORCES IN LEBANON
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/16/world.body_text: **********Administration officials said today that the focus of American diplomatic efforts after a Palestinian and Syrian withdrawal from west Beirut would be to work with the Lebanese Government to achieve the removal of all foreign forces, including those of Israel, Syria and the Palestine Liberation Organization, from the rest of Lebanon before fighting erupted elsewhere in the country. **********The officials, who are in close contact with the negotiations being conducted by President Reagan's special envoy, Philip C. Habib, shared the optimistic assessment of Israeli officials that an announcement on the details of a P.L.O. and Syrian withdrawal from west Beirut might occur in the days ahead. **********James A. Baker 3d, the White House chief of staff, said, as President Reagan had done on Friday, that the Administration was ''reasonably optimistic'' that resolution of the west Beirut crisis would be achieved. Removal Regarded as Essential **********The officials, however, cautioned that although world attention had been riveted on west Beirut in recent weeks, it was imperative that for restoration of stability in Lebanon all non-Lebanese forces leave that country. **********There are about 7,000 Palestinian guerrillas in northern and eastern Lebanon unaffected by the deal being worked out for west Beirut. In addition, there are estimated to be 30,000 Syrian forces in Lebanon and more than 50,000 Israeli forces. **********On Saturday, President Reagan met at Camp David with Secretary of State George P. Shultz and senior officials of the National Security Council and the State Department to discuss steps to take if the Habib mission arranges the evacuation of the P.L.O. from west Beirut. **********The officials said that there was agreement to give priority to the Lebanon situation, because until there is stability there, free of outside pressures, attention cannot be focused on reviving the dormant Israeli-Egyptian negotiations on self-rule for the Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied West Bank of the Jordan and Gaza Strip. Leadership Needed in Rebuilding **********In addition, plans for reconstructing the war-torn areas of Lebanon require calm and the political direction of the Lebanese authorities.  Officials said that papers had been drawn up dealing with specific problems, but that first and foremost, the Administration's attention was on making sure that the complicated plan for the withdrawal of the P.L.O. and Syrian forces from west Beirut goes forward. American, French and Italian forces are expected to monitor the pullback of the estimated 10,000 troops, of whom about 7,000 are said to be P.L.O.  forces. **********The withdrawal should take place over two weeks, the officials said, once an announcement is made by the Lebanese Government. At the same time, they said, talks with the Lebanese authorities will be intensified on achieving a withdrawal of Israeli forces and the remaining Syrian and P.L.O. forces. **********A complication in the situation, the officials said, is the coming expiration on Sept. 23 of the term of office of President Elias Sarkis. The Lebanese Parliament is expected to choose a Maronite Christian as his successor. Reports reaching officials here said that the process of picking a new president could begin this Thursday. Phalangist the Sole Candidate **********The only declared candidate is Bashir Gemayel, the leader of the Phalangist movement, who has been regarded as collaborating with the Israelis. But since the Israeli invasion began June 6, Mr. Gemayel has sought to leave the impression that he is independent of the Israelis. **********Under the Lebanese system, the one-chamber Parliament must achieve a two-thirds majority on the first ballot to elect a new president.  After that ballot, a majority is all that is needed. Some officials believe Mr. Gemayel could win on a second or third ballot. **********The Lebanese Government and most Lebanese public figures have said that all foreign forces must leave their country. This is also the policy of Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel, who has promised to pull his forces out of Lebanon once Israel's security is guaranteed and the Syrian and P.L.O. forces are gone. **********Mr. Reagan has repeatedly called for the withdrawal of all foreign forces, including Israel's, from Lebanon. Plans to Foster Withdrawal **********In a recent interview with an Arabic newspaper published in London, Al Hawadith, Mr. Gemayal said that, if elected president, he would set down, within 48 hours of the formation of his government, guidelines for the withdrawal of all foreign troops. **********Admnistration officials here said they were concerned that the Israelis, having used heavy military force to achieve the withdrawal of P.L.O. and Syrian forces from west Beirut, may try to duplicate that by launching attacks on Syrian and P.L.O. strongpoints in the north and east of Lebanon. **********The United States plans to assure that the cease-fire in Lebanon is maintained, the officials said.  What has not been decided, they added, is the form of the discussions of the post-Beirut phase of the withdrawals. Mr. Habib would be a logical choice as an intermediary, they said, but it was not certain whether he would take on the task, likely to require considerable time and effort. Forum Remains to Be Arranged **********The forum for the discussions will have to be worked out with the Lebanese Government, they said.  Until Israeli forces leave Lebanon, Egypt has said it will not resume the stalled autonomy talks for Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Moreover, the plans to disperse Palestinians from Lebanon to several Arab countries, a new urgency arises for finding a solution to the Palestinian problem, the officials said. **********This in turn may lead such Arab leaders as those in Saudi Arabia and elsewhere to take a more active part in seeking a formula acceptable to Israel within the framework worked out in Camp David in 1978. The Camp David accords offered the Palestinians considerable self-rule but left the status of the West Bank and Gaza to negotiations also involving Jordan. **********Richard Fairbanks, the State Department official in charge of the autonomy talks, took part in Saturday's meeting with Mr. Reagan and is expected to become more active in discussions with other nations of the Palestinian issue.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/05/world.main_headline: ASIAN GAMES GIVE MRS. GANDHI A POLITICAL VICTORY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/05/world.print_headline: ASIAN GAMES GIVE MRS. GANDHI A POLITICAL VICTORY
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/05/world.body_text: **********The end of the ninth Asian Games tonight marked what is widely perceived here as a political victory for Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, who brushed aside a threat from militant Sikhs to disrupt the 15-day-long event. **********Some 15,000 Indian Army troops and paramilitary and police personnel guarded roads and maintained tight security at the major stadiums to prevent any attempts to sabotage the games. **********There were virtually no protests; about a dozen Sikhs who shouted slogans against the Government at various stadiums were quickly arrested. **********2,000 Arrested **********Since the Asian Games began Nov. 19, about 2,000 members of the Shiromani Akali Dal Party, which campaigns against Government influence in Sikh affairs and for autonomy for Punjab state, peacefully submitted to arrest by violating a ban on rallies. The Sikhs are members of a religious group living mostly in northern India. **********The Sikhs were not the only ones opposed to the games, which cost the Government about $1 billion to stage. Opposition parties called the games a waste of money and said it could have been better spent on development projects. **********Both the local press and the public paid little attention to the Sikh demonstrations.  Many Indians, moreover, were proud of the speed and skill with which thousands of laborers, architects and engineers built the stadiums and sports centers for the games, which are held every four years. ''It shows that we are capable of pulling off a major technological and managerial event,'' said Gopal Shastri, a computer engineer with a Government company. Victory for Mrs. Gandhi **********For Mrs. Gandhi, the successful staging of the games became more than an issue of prestige. The Sikh threat turned the games into a political challenge, which, even her critics concede, she won. **********After the Sikhs announced plans to bus supporters from Punjab into New Delhi on the day the games were to open, hundreds were arrested as the police and paramilitary troops stopped their buses. Some Sikhs evaded the police and made their way to New Delhi, where they took refuge in a large temple. The police placed guards around the building but did not enter it. **********Scores of Sikhs then emerged from the temple every day to shout anti-Government slogans and walk to waiting police buses, which took them to jail. But beyond causing minor traffic snarls, they were unable to enforce their threat to disrupt the games. ''It was a washout,'' a senior police officer said. ''They couldn't achieve anything.'' Want Government Limited **********The Sikhs' demands are seen as a threat to the political integrity of India and to law and order. The Sikhs want the central Government's authority and functions in Punjab to be limited to military matters, foreign relations, communications, railways and currency. The Government has rejected this. **********Mrs. Gandhi, however, is said to be considering granting some of the Sikhs' demands, including one involving the transfer of Chandigarh, a union territory on the Punjab-Haryana border, to Punjab. **********The Akali Party, which is led by religious militants, has conducted a campaign in support of its demands since September. In October four Sikhs were shot dead when a mob tried to storm the Parliament building in New Delhi. Thousands were jailed but were released before the Asian Games started. **********New Delhi itself was freshened up in preparation for the games.  The capital's roads were cleaned and resurfaced, its lawns and fields were trimmed, new trees were planted, buildings were painted and hotels and bridges were opened. **********The organizers included top military, intelligence and police officials and influential political leaders like Rajiv Gandhi, the Prime Minister's son.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/17/world.main_headline: DOMINICAN LEADER, IN INAUGURAL SPEECH, SETS AUSTERE COURSE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/17/world.print_headline: DOMINICAN LEADER, IN INAUGURAL SPEECH, SETS AUSTERE COURSE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/17/world.body_text: **********The new President of the Dominican Republic, Salvador Jorge Blanco, declared his country ''financially bankrupt'' today and proposed a restructuring of its economy. **********President Jorge Blanco's inaugural address was a chronicle of economic devastation similar to those being heard throughout the Caribbean region as prices for agricultural exports, particularly sugar, fall and the price of imported oil rises. **********''We are victims of factors outside of our control,'' he said, ''induced by European and United States protectionism and by the estimated deficit of this latter country, which keeps international interest rates exaggeratedly high.'' Exports to U.S. Limited **********Like other countries in the Caribbean region that depend heavily on sugar for foreign exchange, the Dominican Republic is seeking relief from the restrictions that limit exports to the United States, its primary market. **********These exports are now hindered by a system of duties, fees and quotas, at least part of which would be eliminated by the Reagan Administration's economic aid program for the Caribbean basin. The limits on exports, combined with a sharply reduced world price for sugar, have placed sugar-producing countries in a major economic squeeze. **********''For every three dollars that came to the Central Bank last year, only two dollars will come this year,'' Mr. Jorge Blanco said. He added that while 1,000 pounds of sugar would buy 12 barrels of oil in 1974, the same amount would buy only four this year. **********Asserting that ''for severe illnesses severe remedies'' were required, Mr. Jorge Blanco called for a ban on imports of most foods and a year's freeze on wages and the prices of basic goods. **********He proposed new levies on property transfers and on urban property holdings, as well as increased import taxes on luxury items. ''The hour has come,'' he declared, ''that the Dominicans who have more pay more taxes to the nation.'' **********He also said that license fees for automobiles would be increased, both to raise money for the Government and to discourage the use of imported oil. **********Hours later, Mr. Jorge Blanco decreed by executive order a cut in the salaries of public employees earning more than $375 a month, including his own, which will drop to $3,000 a month from $5,000. Reserves 'in Red Ink' **********''The nation's economic chaos can disappear only if there is applied at all levels measures based on austerity and on the moralization of Dominican life,'' the new President declared. **********He said that for the first time the Dominican Republic's monetary reserves ''are in red ink.'' Payments of more than $450 million are due on the countrys's foreign debt this year and the balance of payments deficit is more than $400 million. The internal deficit of the Government and its agencies, Mr. Jorge Blanco said, is also projected at $400 million. **********The drastic nature of his proposals repeatedly caused an audible stir among the Dominican legislators, foreign dignitaries and other guests packed into the stuffy chamber of the National Congressional Palace for his nearly two-hour address. **********Moments after donning the red, white and blue presidential sash, presented to him by the outgoing head of state, Jacobo Majluta Azar, the 56-year-old Mr. Jorge Blanco announced that he would not seek re-election and proposed a constitutional amendment that would bar presidents from serving more than one term in office. 'Moral Force' Acclaimed **********''The possible diminution of political power that we will suffer,'' he said, ''will be more than compensated for by an unlimited increase in a force that is superior to political power: the moral force.'' **********He said the Dominican Republic, having shown through the orderly transition of power from president to president that it could achieve a political democracy, must now work to create an ''economic democracy.'' **********Within this plan, he announced a number of other proposals, including the creation of ''free trade'' zones to encourage foreign investment in manufacturing here and a program that would allow investments by Dominicans outside the country, in dollars, at higherthan-usual interest rates, with the capital to be used to help resolve the country's critical housing shortage. **********His message, despite its grim tone, was applauded loudly by the audience, which included representatives of several Latin American countries, including President Luis Alberto Monge of Costa Rica, President Luis Herrera Campins of Venezuela, and Sergio Ramirez Mercado, a member of Nicaragua's ruling junta. Bunker Heads U.S. Delegation **********The United States delegation was headed by Ellsworth Bunker, the veteran diplomat, who with Mr. Jorge Blanco helped negotiate the withdrawal of occupying United States troops from the Dominican Republic in 1965. **********The delegation also included Thomas O. Enders, the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, who has been using his visit here to hold informal meetings with representatives of a number of countries, including Costa Rica and Argentina.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/17/world.main_headline: GREECE TO INSIST ON DEADLINE IN TALKS ON BASES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/17/world.print_headline: GREECE TO INSIST ON DEADLINE IN TALKS ON BASES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/17/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou has issued a warning to the United States that if no agreement is reached on the American military bases in Greece within a specified time, the bases will have to go. **********Mr. Papandreou said the time limit for the talks would be fixed by the negotiators. Discussions between the United States and Greece on the issue are to begin Oct. 27. **********Mr. Papandreou, in an interview Friday, insisted that he was not seeking a confrontation with the Reagan Administration. But he said: ''Either there is an agreement, a new agreement, or then we are through with the status of the bases. In other words, suppose we fail to agree in six months' time or nine months' time, whatever it is, if we fail to agree, it does not mean the bases stay as they are. It means they will have to leave.'' **********Mr. Papandreou has said before that the negotiations could not drag on indefinitely. He is known to be under strong pressure from the Communists and his own Socialists to live up to election pledges of a year ago calling for the removal of the four American bases and some smaller installations. Mr. Papandrou now says, ''It was not one of our highest priorities, but the time has come.'' **********''I'm not sending any ultimatums to Washington,'' he said, ''but I do think they have to understand that this present state of affairs cannot last.'' **********He said the Americans, too, wanted a rapid conclusion. One of the Prime Minister's close aides said earlier that Greece was thinking in terms of six months to a year to complete all aspects of the talks. **********Mr. Papandreou said that on the issue of how long a period a new agreement would cover, the Greek position ''will develop at the negotiating table.'' The Communist Party has been pressing for the bases to go by the end of the Socialist Government's mandate, in three years. Mr. Papandreou said recently he would need two terms, or eight years, to carry out his party's program. Other sources close to the Government, however, talk about keeping the bases until some unspecified time when there is an agreement on the dismantling of the Warsaw Pact and NATO. **********The bases are not related to Greek national defense or to NATO, Mr. Papandreou said, but ''are strictly American facilities.'' He said they were set up in ''a neocolonialist climate'' that emerged after the civil war, which ended in 1949. **********The Prime Minister refused to say what price his Government would ask for the bases in the way of military and economic aid or security guarantees. **********''We do think that since the presence of bases in Greece is of some strategic interest to the United States that the question of Greek national defense might be associated with the problem of the bases,'' he said. **********Mr. Papandreou made no threats to quit NATO and, in fact, mentioned that Greece had taken part in a recent NATO exercise with the understanding that this would not jeopardize its claims to the airspace over Greek islands in the Aegean near Turkey. **********An agreement with Turkey on a moratorium on mutual recriminations has improved the atmosphere, he said, although no easy resolution of the Aegean dispute is in sight. As for Cyprus, Greece's major objective is to have Turkish troops withdraw from the island, but that depends on Turkey, he said. Turning to another subject, the Prime Minister xpressed some optimism that Socialist candidates would do well in Sunday's local elections, which are widely seen as the first significant public opinion test for the Papandreou Government.  He said, however, that the Communist Party was waging ''a very aggressive'' campaign, confronting the Socialists everywhere for the first time since Greece's return to democracy in 1974, and was even prepared to vote for rightists to keep the Socialists from winning. **********If the Communists make significant gains, Mr. Papandreou said, it will be partly attributable to the Government's foreign policy but more to its failure to achieve its economic objectives.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/12/busin.main_headline: INDUSTRIAL COUNTRIES FAIL TO AGREE ON HOW TO MEET ECONOMIC CRISES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/12/busin.print_headline: INDUSTRIAL COUNTRIES FAIL TO AGREE ON HOW TO MEET ECONOMIC CRISES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/12/busin.body_text: **********Government ministers from the 24 major industrial democracies completed a two-day review of the world economy this evening on a pessimistic note. They agreed that no early end to the recession is in sight and that six million more people are likely to become jobless this year, raising the total number of unemployed in their counries to more than 30 million. **********The ministers, attending the annual meeting of the Organizaton for Economic Cooperation and Development, which monitors the economic performance of its member nations, promised to keep trying to reduce inflation, preserve free trade and modernize industry. **********But their final communique shows they remain seriously divided over how to tackle the crises gripping their countries' economies. ''The message is not a very pleasant one,'' said Emile van Lennep, secretary general of the organization, in summing up the ministers' work at a final news conference. **********Views of Smaller Nations **********The O.E.C.D. meeting was scheduled this week to let smaller industrial nations express their views on the world economy before next month's meeting of government heads from the United States, Britain, Canada, France, West Germany, Italy and Japan at Versailles, France. **********In the view of many officials at the O.E.C.D. meeting, its somber conclusion and the divisions between many of its participants will cast a shadow over prospects for the Versailles meeting. **********As expected, the O.E.C.D. ministers again endorsed the joint recovery strategy to which they have been committed since the second surge of oil price rises in 1978. This holds that a lasting reduction in Western unemployment ''cannot be achieved on a sustainable basis'' unless inflation is beaten and the industrial nations develop internationally competitive industries capable of earning their way in the world. Action by Big 3 Suggested **********The major new recommendation to emerge here was a plea, expressed in imprecise language, for the United States to encourage faster growth by reducing its budget deficit and lowering interest rates. **********In the same recommendation, the ministers implied that Germany and Japan, which already have low inflation rates and booming exports, should maintain their big budget deficits to bolster world trade, which fell 1 percent last year. None of the countries were named in the communique, but officials confirmed that the wording pertained to the United States, Germany and Japan, the three strongest economies in the O.E.C.D. At the closing news conference, Mr. van Lennep said everybody wanted a reduction in the United States budget deficit. **********The American Secretary of the Treasury, Donald T. Regan, said Monday that his Administration also wanted to cut its deficit and to lower interest rates, now unusually high in comparison with the rate of inflation. **********But he warned that lower interest rates in the United States might not bring down rates in other countries unless they also trimmed their government spending. Both the German and Japanese ministers agreed that a lasting economic recovery requires a government to cut its deficit, making room for an upturn in borrowing by private industry to finance new investments. **********France's Foreign Minister, Claude Cheysson, defended his Socialist Government's decision to triple the French budget deficit in two years despite 14 percent inflation, saying it had given France ''somewhat faster growth and a better employment performance than other European countries.'' **********Similar differences in national outlook also undercut the ministers' reaffirmation in the communique of their ''commitment to combat all forms of protectionism'' and maintain ''an open trading system.'' **********Indeed, the meeting suffered a last-minute reverse today when France rejected a laboriously prepared compromise limiting the extent to which members might subsidize their exports with cheap credit.  Officials agreed that the French move threatened to unleash exactly the kind of trade war the ministers are pledged to avoid, unless a new compromise is reached before the present restraint agreement expires later this month. **********Bill Brock, special trade representative for the United States, called for a far-reaching commitment to extend free trade into wholly new areas of economic activity. He warned that the Western world was in danger of drifting into ''a new era of protectionism,'' **********In particular, he said, governments should quit subsidizing hightechnology industries, should accept free competition in the services sector and should treat foreign investors just like domestic ones. **********Arguing that future job creation will be concentrated in these fields, Mr. Brock said, ''We must make sure that these areas do not become subject to new types of protectionism, which would deny all nations the benefit of expanded trade.'' **********But his ambitious proposals, which worry many European governments, found no echo in the final communique. And Mr. Cheysson of France, which gives huge subsidies to high-technology companies, argued that the economically ''weaker'' countries had a right to help build up modern industries while it was the duty of economically ''stronger'' countries to practice free trade. **********The Foreign Minister of Japan, Yoshiz Sakurauchi, under heavy pressure to open up his country's markets to foreign imports, again promised concessions. But he did not say what his Government would offer or when it would do it. **********Finally, the O.E.C.D. ministers demonstrated the fragility of their consensus on policy, as well as their reluctance to make new pledges at a time of rising unemployment, by refusing to publish new policy recommendations made by the organization's secretariat. **********The secretariat paper, according to sources familiar with it, set out a wide range of specific economic reforms that individual countries should make as their contribution to a lasting recovery, in addition to the general O.E.C.D. commitment to curb inflation and maintain free trade. The most important of these recommendations is the one for the United States to cut its budget deficit and for Germany and Japan to maintain theirs. This found its way in convoluted form into the final communique but without any country being mentioned by name. **********In addition, the secretariat argued that countries such as Belgium, France and Britain must restore corporate profitability - the first two by cutting taxes and social charges and Britain by compensating for the squeeze on profits resulting from an overvalued pound. **********Washington, Bonn and Tokyo all dislike the O.E.C.D.'s recommendations on budget deficits, officials say, because they recall the secretariat's earlier ''locomotive'' recovery strategy, now considered discredited. This attempted to apply the Keynesian economic theory of demand management to the world scene by calling on low-inflation countries to reflate, thus giving a lift to the world economy. **********But according to the monetarist theories embraced by the present American, German and Japanese administrations, higher government spending gives only a temporary lift to output, which will eventually disappear in higher inflation. Lasting recovery, according to these theories, can be secured only by cutting government spending, lowering inflationary expectations and encouraging private industry to invest. **********Other European governments, officials say, are simply reluctant to make new economic commitments while their political freedom of maneuver is tightly restricted by the continuing recession and rising unemployment. **********---- High Jobless Levels **********WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) -Unemployment, which reached a post-World War II high of 9.4 percent of the American work force last month, has also risen to record and near-record levels in Canada, France, West Germany, Britain and Japan, according to the Labor Department. **********British unemployment, the highest among the Western industrial countries, rose from 11.3 percent in 1981 to 13 percent in the first three months of this year. For West Germany, the Labor Department calculated unemployment at 5.5 percent in the first quarter, up from 4.3 percent for 1981. Unemployment in Japan was 2.2 percent for the year ending March 31, a postwar record.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/24/world.main_headline: SALVADOR BLOCKS THE ENFORCEMENT OF LAND PROGRAM
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/24/world.print_headline: SALVADOR BLOCKS THE ENFORCEMENT OF LAND PROGRAM
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/24/world.body_text: **********In less than one month as a legislative body, El Salvador's Constituent Assembly has blocked most of the country's land redistribution effort from being carried out. **********In its first session, the Assembly enacted legislation that effectively annulled the plan of the previous Government to make peasant cooperatives out of 1,700 of the country's large farms. **********And last Thursday, the rightist-dominated Assembly suspended the ''land to the tiller law,'' which permitted peasants to buy the small plots they were working as tenant farmers or sharecroppers. The suspension was for one crop year, which for sugar cane, one of El Salvador's main crops, is four calendar years. **********Suspension 'a Political Maneuver' **********In his homily today, the Acting Archbishop of San Salvador, Arturo Rivera Damas, indicated that the legislators had wanted to repeal the land to the tiller law. He called the suspension a ''political maneuver'' designed ''to leave open the possibility of North American aid, which is conditioned on the reforms not being halted.'' **********In Washington on Thursday, the Foreign Relations Committee was told by Senator Charles H. Percy, its chairman, that ''not one cent of funds shall go to the Government of El Salvador'' if it suspended the land redistribution program. The Reagan Administration has proposed $128 million in economic aid for El Salvador through its plan to assist countries in the Caribbean region as well as $60 million in military aid. **********Five right-wing parties won 36 of the 60 Assembly seats in elections March 28, while the centrist Christian Democratic Party won the rest. The Assembly later elected Alvaro Alfredo Magana, a centrist with no formal party affiliation, to be provisional President of the country. He succeeded Jose Napoleon Duarte of the Christian Democrats, who had headed a military-civilian junta for the last two years. **********El Salvador's land redistribution program was begun two years ago in an effort to persuade peasants not to support the leftist-led revolution. Before the enactment of the program, fewer than 2 percent of the population controlled more than half of this tiny nation's fertile farm land. Program Acclaimed by Reagan **********The program was hailed as ''unprecedented'' by President Reagan recently and as ''the most revolutionary land reform in Latin American history'' by the American Ambassador, Deane R. Hinton. **********Under the first phase of the program all farms larger than 1,235 acres were expropriated, with compensation, and converted to peasant cooperatives. The second phase, which was announced but never carried out, provided for similar expropriatiion and conversion of farms larger than 247 acres. And the third phase, which is known as the land to the tiller law, decreed that peasants could buy up to 17 acres of the land they had been working as tenant farmers or sharecroppers. **********The second and third phases have been affected by the Assembly's actions.  Eighty-five percent of the peasant families who were to benefit from the agrarian program as originally announced live or work on the phase 2 and phase 3 properties. These farms contain 70 percent of the land included in the original redistribution plan. **********As explained by an agrarian analyst and a lawyer, the Assembly acted against the second phase when it repealed a law enacted by the previous Government that permitted expropriations. Since phase 2 had not been carried out, it is no longer constitutionally possible to expropriate those lands for conversion to peasant cooperatives. **********In terms of a more equitable distribution of the country's wealth and income, the second phase was the most important element of the agrarian program. In El Salvador's agricultural-based economy, wealth has long been measured primarily by the amount of land one owns. Coffee, cotton and sugar bring in about 75 percent of the country's export earnings and phase 2 farms accounted for about threefourths of these crops. Phase Lacked U.S. Support **********The demise of the second phase was expected, in large part because it did not have the support of the Reagan Administration. Most of the properties that would have been expropriated under the program are owned by people that ''constitute a considerable element of the country's political power structure,'' according to a study prepared for the United States Agency for International Development by Checchi & Company, a Washington consulting concern. **********But the suspension of the land to the tiller program was more of a shock. This program would have benefited more peasants than phases 1 and 2 combined. **********Most of these peasants are subsistence farmers, struggling to grow corn, beans and vegetables, often on tiny, sometimes seemingly vertical hillside plots. More than half of the country's corn, beans and sorghum, a key crop in this country, which grows no wheat, is cultivated by these peasants on parcels whose average size is about three acres. **********The prototype for the land to the tiller law was carried out by the United States in Vietnam. The principle architect there and in El Salvador was Roy L. Prosterman, a law professor at the University of Washington. 'Left Fears Land Reform' **********''The left fears land reform,'' Mr. Prosterman told a hostile audience of Salvadoran businessmen after the law was enacted. ''It deprives them of their most valuable weapon in implementing revolution because they can no longer appeal to the landless.'' **********Although the land to the tiller law has technically been suspended for only one crop year, there is considerable doubt that it will ever be reactivated. **********The Checchi report noted that while the army supported the first phase of the agrarian program, ''there appears to be no similar military commitment'' to the land to the tiller law. **********''It is not very clear until when the suspension is going to last since it could be like the state of siege that keeps being prolonged by the will of the legislators,'' Bishop Rivera Damas said today. The state of siege, first enacted in March 1980 for 30 days, has been continually re-enacted for 30-day periods and is still in effect. 'Victory for Landowners' **********Responding to protests by peasant organizations, the Assembly added a proviso to the suspension legislation that protects the rights of tenant farmers who had already received provisional titles, had applied for them or were entitled to apply for them under the original law. **********Roberto Viera, a Christian Democratic Party legislator, called the protections ''fine on paper.'' But he said that ''in practice'' the legislation was a ''victory for landowners.'' Landowners, bolstered by the legislation, will now begin to evict tenant farmers, he said. **********According to the Popular Democratic Union, a federation of labor and peasant organizations that is aligned with the Christian Democrats, 9,600 peasant families have been evicted from land they were renting since the Assembly began to chip away at the land redistribution program. Some 60,000 families have been threatened with eviction, the group said. **********The threat of eviction could discourage more renters from filing claims or perfecting their titles.  Since the land to the tiller law was enacted early in 1980, no peasant has received a clear title. https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/27/busin.main_headline: HIGH COURT TO REVIEW TENNESSEE BANK TAX
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/27/busin.print_headline: HIGH COURT TO REVIEW TENNESSEE BANK TAX
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/27/busin.body_text: **********The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a state can tax the income earned by banks on interest from United States bonds, Treasury notes and other Federal obligations. **********Federal law prohibits states and localities from taxing the interest earned by individuals on such investments. But the law contains an excep-tion, allowing states to impose ''nondiscriminatory franchise or other nonproperty taxes'' on the interest income earned by corporate holders of Federal securities. **********The case the Justices accepted today, Memphis Bank and Trust Company v. Garner, No. 81-1613, requires the Court to define that exception. The case is a challenge to a Tennessee state tax on bank earnings. The Tennessee law includes interest from Federal obligations in the banks' net taxable income, but does not count interest earned on bonds issued by the state or its localities. Paid Under Protest **********The Memphis bank paid $56,000 under protest for the 1977 and 1978 tax years, and sued the state for a refund, arguing that, if its earnings from interest on Federal obligations were not counted, it would have no liability under the state bank tax. **********The bank won in a local court, but the Tennessee Supreme Court ruled that the state tax fell within the ''nondiscriminatory franchise or other nonproperty taxes exemption.'' The tax is 3 percent of net income, minus deductions for taxes paid on the bank's real property. **********In its Supreme Court appeal, the bank is arguing that the Tennessee court was wrong both in regarding the state tax as a franchise tax and in characterizing the tax as nondiscriminatory. On neither count, the bank says, does the state tax come within the exemption. Discrimination Charged **********The tax is an income tax, not a franchise tax, the bank argues, and it is discriminatory in that it applies to interest on Federal obligations but not those of the state itself. **********Several other states have imposed similar taxes. The Rhode Island courts struck down the tax in that state, while state courts in Georgia, Texas and Minnesota have upheld bank taxes on Federal interest income. The Memphis bank asserted that other states were likely to follow unless the Supreme Court intervenes. **********The Federal Government has not expressed its views on the issue, but is likely to do so before the Court hears arguments next fall.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/26/world.main_headline: ISRAEL SAYS SYRIAN BUILDUP NEAR BEIRUT HAS COLLAPSED
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/26/world.print_headline: ISRAEL SAYS SYRIAN BUILDUP NEAR BEIRUT HAS COLLAPSED
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/26/world.body_text: **********The Israeli military spokesman declared tonight that ''the entire Syrian military buildup'' in the Lebanese mountains east of Beirut had collapsed at the end of the fourth day of heavy fighting along the Beirut-Damascus highway. **********Israeli combat planes flew missions through the day, attacking what the spokesman described as Palestinian and Syrian ammunition dumps and command posts. **********Shortly after this announcement was made, the Israeli state radio said that as of 8 P.M. Israeli forces had begun observing a new cease-fire in Lebanon and that Israel's agreement to do so had been communicated to Philip C. Habib, President Reagan's special envoy, currently in Beirut. **********The military spokesman said that the Beirut-Damascus highway was in Israeli hands from the Beirut suburb of Baabda to the town of Bhamdun, an east-west stretch of about 10 miles. **********This afternoon the Israeli forces gave the Syrian soldiers encircled in Beirut and in the town of Aleih along the highway an opportunity to leave peacefully in the direction of Syria, the spokesman reported. He said that many had done so. Says Israel Is Close to Goals **********The spokesman said that Syria's 62d Brigade, which had been stationed north of the highway, had also begun a retreat toward the Syrian border. **********Interviewed on television tonight, Defense Minister Ariel Sharon declared that Israel had as a result of the combat of the last four days drawn very close to realization of the two main goals of the invasion of Lebanon - ''the total elimination of the Palestine Liberation Organization'' as a factor in Lebanon and the removal of Syrian forces, which he characterized as the main support of the Palestinian guerrillas. **********The minister said that the Israeli ring around Beirut was impenetrable to hostile forces. Asked whether Israel intended to enter west Beirut, the largely Moslem and Palestinian-held sector of the city, Mr. Sharon said that many possibilities were under consideration and he declined to go into details. **********The official position of the Government of Prime Minister Menachem Begin is that its army will not enter Beirut. However, a Cabinet session on Thursday was reported to have decided to review this position, possibly after an expected visit here by Mr. Habib. **********Mr. Sharon said that Israel had proposed letting all members of the Palestine Liberation Organization leave for another Arab country in convoys to be inspected by representatives of the International Committee of the Red Cross. Israel maintains that the departure from Lebanon of at least the ''core'' of the Palestinian leadership is one of its minimum conditions for withdrawal from that country. **********The military spokesman announced that the brunt of the fighting today centered on the Aleih-Bhamdun segment of the highway.  For the first time, Israel reported that Lebanese Christian troops had joined the battle, moving eastward out of their stronghold in east Beirut. They were said to have captured the town of Jamur. **********Israeli officials have been showing signs of impatience with the inactivity of the Christians, bitter enemies of the Palestinians in the Lebanese civil war, since the Israeli invasion. Pullout Is Not Imminent **********Mr. Sharon sounded triumphant tonight, in the latest of a series of broadcast interviews on the course of the war. He said that whoever controlled the Aleih-Bhamdun stretch of highway controlled, in effect, Lebanon, and the Israeli Army now controlled it. He said he expected a letup in the fighting soon but predicted that Israeli troops would remain in Lebanon ''much longer than 10 weeks.'' **********The Defense Minister asserted that the latest flare-up in fighting had been brought on by Syrian violations of the cease-fire. He said that Israel replied to such violations not necessarily in the same sector where they occurred, suggesting that Israeli forces may have started the battle that led to their capture of the strategic highway after an outbreak of firing elsewhere in Lebanon. **********The military spokesman announced today that 22 more Israeli soldiers had been killed in battle Thursday. The total of dead of the invasion now exceeds 260. **********In a lecture to a private club today, the Israeli Tourism Minister, Avraham Sharir, declared that Israel's successes against surface-toair missiles supplied by the Soviet Union to Syria had been accomplished through technology invented here. He said the destruction of the missiles proved that the Soviet missile system was ''ready for the scrap heap.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/10/busin.body_text: **********A Tolerant Fed? **********The Federal Reserve is cashing in the chips that it has earned since October 1979 - a three-year period during which a mostly restrictive monetary policy succeeded in subduing inflation. The Fed is faced now with money supply data that will probably remain above its targets. But the bank does not want to wrench the money supply downward, because, many say, an economy with a 10.1 percent unemployment rate would suffer too much pain from higher interest rates. **********By reducing the discount rate again last week, the Fed signaled that it has decided to be tolerant of both the past and prospective increases in money supply growth. Not only would that policy encourage the lower interest rates that economists say are needed for a sustainable recovery, but it might also defuse political criticism of the Fed in advance of the November elections. **********The Fed will no doubt defend its actions by saying that money supply data are being distorted by changes in the banking system.  Specifically, it can point to the maturing of $27 billion of one-year tax-exempt certificates in the first week of October, which would result in a record large increase in the basic money supply to be reported this Friday. The 'Sixth Effect' **********Financiers in 17th-century London had their own tricks. They used a weather vane to indicate pending increases in the creation of money. When the vane showed an east wind, they knew that ships would be coming up the Thames to the city, where the exchange of goods would lead to an increase in the creation of money. **********A modern rule of thumb for predicting money supply growth relies on a pattern of large increases in the first week of each month - particularly the first month of a calendar quarter, when Social Security checks go out to millions of recipients. The ''sixth effect'' is a variation on this theme, which explains what to expect in months like the current one, when the sixth day falls on a Wednesday. In such months, the Treasury distributes Social Security checks on Friday, the first day of the month rather than on the third day, which falls on Sunday. As a result, the checks' proceeds may be on deposit in checking accounts - and thus counted in the money supply - for an extra two days. To cope with this, the Fed formed a committee of statisticians to prepare new seasonal adjustments. The refined adjustments would produce a different level of money supply than the Fed's traditional monthly seasonal adjustment process. But so far, the ''sixth effect'' remains a monthly footnote. The technicians have not figured out how to put the refinement into the seasonally adjusted figures that the Fed reports weekly. No Signs of Recovery **********Even with the fourth quarter underway, forecasts for it are thoroughly confusing. Some economists foresee another small rise in real gross national product; others say that a drop in output is possible. This adds to the confusion generated by the piddling growth reported for real G.N.P. in the second and third quarters. At first glance, those figures from the Commerce Department seemed to indicate an end to the recession. But many economists insist that economy is stagnant, with no convincing signs that a sustainable recovery is underway. **********The increase in the unemployment rate is likely to be another depressant, because unemployment fears seems to discourage consumer spending on big-ticket items even among households that could afford them. **********Sales of cars and housing are languishing at or near their lows and manufacturing companies are not increasing their output. In fact, industrial production is already 10 percent lower that at the start of the recession. Tax-Exempt Watershed **********The tax-exempt bond market, enjoying a record year, is nearing a watershed. In the past, more than 90 percent of the about $400 billion of outstanding securities issued by state and local governments have been sold in bearer form, where possession means ownership and there is a minimum of record keeping. But the new tax bill requires that all new bond issues after Jan.1 be sold in registered form. The Internal Revenue Service hopes that the registration records will help it spot wealthy individuals who are not reporting their income. **********The change is expected to be a shock to the tax-exempt market, where wealthy, privacy-conscious individuals have accounted for an estimated three-fourths of all purchases. Dealers expect that a twotier market will develop, with outstanding bearer bonds selling at a higher price and lower yield than similar registered bonds.  Michael Quint

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/30/world.print_headline: VIETNAM RELEASES INFORMATION ON MISSING AMERICANS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/30/world.body_text: **********Vietnam released information today about four American soldiers who were believed killed in the Vietnam War and said more bodies of dead soldiers would be returned to the United States. **********The information was given to a group of six Vietnam veterans and three other Americans who arrived in the capital Friday.  The Hanoi Government also announced that in the future it would deal with the veterans' group, and not with the United States Government, on questions involving 2,500 American servicemen whose fates in the Vietnam War are still unresolved. Names Listed for 4 **********A Vietnamese spokesman gave the names of four Americans who had been listed as missing in action in Vietnam and said that the bodies of four or five other Americans had been found. **********Only one of the eight or nine reported sets of physical evidence included both a body and an identity card. The body was said to be that of Lieut. (j.g.) Donald Patrick Frye. **********The Vietnamese Government said Lieutenant Frye was believed killed on July 19, 1967, in the province now known as Ha Nam Ninh, south of Hanoi. The province is the product of a merger of the former provinces of Ha Nam and Ninh Binh. **********Three other American servicemen, whose identification cards but not bodies were turned over to the veterans, were listed as Joe R.  Mossman, Hestle Roosevelt and Knapp Fredrick Woodrow. No Information Provided **********The Vietnamese provided no other information except to say that the three name tags were found in the three provinces of Ngha Tinh, Bac Thai and Binh Tri Thien. **********Bac Thai Province is north of Hanoi. Ngha Tinh and Binh Tri Thien Provinces are along a central strip of Vietnam, from north of the city of Vinh to a few miles below the former South Vietnamese city of Hue. **********A Vietnamese spokesman said that ''three or four'' other unidentified bodies had been discovered in Ha Nam Ninh Province and that another body believed to be that of an American had been found in Quang Ninh Province, which stretches northeast from Haiphong to the Chinese border. **********It was not clear when the bodies would be turned over to the veterans. Vietnamese Cites Ingratitude **********The last bodies of American soldiers to have been turned over by the Vietnamese were three that were returned to the United States last July. Vietnam's chief negotiator with the veterans, Viet Ngo Minh, said today that the ingratitude shown then by Washington had helped persuade Hanoi to deal with the veterans rather than with Washington. **********The veterans were invited by the Vietnamese Government on a weeklong visit after a similar trip last December. The announcement about the return of the bodies was made to a small number of Western newspaper and television reporters after a closed three-hour meeting between the veterans and the Vietnamese. **********The reporters were granted visas to cover the veterans' trip.  Mr. Minh said the bodies were discovered in the last few months, after a United States Defense Department team left Hanoi last February. The team, led by Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense Richard L. Armitage, came to Hanoi to inquire about Americans missing in action. It left with an agreement that the Vietnamese would send experts to Hawaii to study the technical aspects of identification. **********Mr. Minh said today that the experts might still go to Hawaii in August.  The American veterans and their lawyer and the theatrical producer Joseph Papp, who joined the trip to promote cultural exchanges between Vietnam and the United States, were later received by Vietnam's Foreign Minister, Nguyen Co Thach. **********Mr. Armitage's mission was not received by Mr. Thach. ---- U.S. Accepts Hanoi's Move Special to the New York Times **********WASHINGTON, May 29 - The Defense Department issued a statement today in reaction to the report that the Hanoi Government planned to deal with the veterans' group on matters concerning the fate of missing American servicemen. **********''We believe the resolution of the M.I.A. accounting issue depends on Government-to-Government cooperation, but the U.S. Government is willing to accept remains from whatever source,'' the statement said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/03/world.body_text: **********The Reagan Administration, moving to revive the chances for approval of its $350 million aid program for the Caribbean region, sent the Secretaries of State and the Treasury and other officials to Capitol Hill today to press for the proposal. **********Secretary of State George P. Shultz, in his first appearance before Congress since his confirmation hearing, told the Senate Finance Committee approval was needed to reaffirm the United States commitment to Latin America after the war in the Falklands. **********''Our security and credibility are at stake,'' Mr. Shultz said.  ''The tragic war in the South Atlantic has led some hemispheric friends - mistakenly I believe - to challenge our commitment to them as a partner. We must show them that this is not so.'' Mr. Shultz simply read his statement, then left for a White House meeting. **********Mr. Shultz assured the committee that the proposal included enough safeguards to protect American industry from the expected increase in Caribbean exports to the United States because of planned lowered tariffs. Political Goals of Program **********He and other supporters of the proposal said the plan was intended to prevent further economic deterioration that could lead to the overthrow of governments in the area. Mr. Shultz said, ''This is the kind of environment upon which the extreme and violent minorities on both sides of the political spectrum can feed and produce major political and social upheavals.'' **********Aides to the Senate Finance Committee are say the proposal may need some changes to protect some American industries, including footwear, wallet and purse manufacturers, to get through the committee and the Senate. **********Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan also supported the program. The Caribbean initiative, which was announced in February, includes $350 million in direct aid, reductions in tariffs and some investment incentives. The proposal, despite some movement in the House and the Senate, had slipped from view since then and some of its supporters thought it was doomed. The tax incentives would reduce revenue by about $65 million in the fiscal year starting Oct. 1 and by $81 million in fiscal 1986.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/01/world.body_text: **********At the edge of a narrow road in the mountains of northern Luzon, three old women in Ifugao tribal dress and a young mother and a baby wrapped in a bright-colored blanket huddle together to block out the cold, gusting wind. **********When a car slows to negotiate the muddy, twisting road, they struggle to their feet, hoping that a tourist might pay for a picture of some Ifugao on a ledge above a canyon, overlooking the famed Banaue rice terraces known as the Stairsteps to Heaven. **********In the mist and rain of the July and August monsoon season, it is difficult to see that the terraces, on which generations of Ifugao have toiled, are beginning to sag from neglect. Most of the latest generation of Ifugao custodians have chosen not to be rice farmers but rather construction workers, miners and truck drivers in areas of the Philippines that have electricity, paved roads and movie theaters. **********Now only about 1,000 families in Banaue, or about 7,000 of the 23,000 people, are rice farmers.  No new rice terraces have been built here in 50 years. Many of the terraces, some estimated to be 3,000 years old, have been abandoned.  By some estimates, only half of the terraces, which cover nearly 100 square miles of steep mountainside terrain, are being farmed. Not enough rice is produced here to feed the people of Banaue. **********Some residents would like to blame the Philippine Government for failing to check the erosion or help the farmers control the effects of the dry- and-wet cycle that has always plagued rice farming in this region of Luzon. But the terraces survived such extremes for centuries before modern farming techniques were developed. What the region needs, local officials said, is to have more young people stay and farm. **********The Philippine Ministry of Tourism and the local government have begun a joint campaign to encourage the local population to return to rice farming. **********But the Minister of Tourism, Jose D. Aspiras, supports a policy of nondevelopment for Banaue. He has been criticized for not encouraging construction of a good highway to make the trip to the terraces easier for tourists,

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/28/world.body_text: **********A hijacked Air Tanzania jet carrying about 90 people arrived from Athens today and was immediately surrounded by the police at Stansted Airport north of London. **********The four hijackers threatened to blow up the plane if security forces moved in.  Robert Bunyard, the Essex Chief Constable, said a demand from the hijackers to refuel the plane had been refused. ''It is not my intention to allow this airplane to leave this airport,'' he said. **********The Boeing 737 was hijacked Friday over Tanzania, landed in neighboring Nairobi, Kenya, then flew to Jidda, Saudi Arabia, where it refueled and flew to Athens. The hijackers are demanding the ouster of Tanzania's Socialist President, Julius K. Nyerere. **********When the plane landed here, the four gunmen aboard radioed that they wanted to see the Foreign Secretary, Lord Carrington, and the Tanzanian Ambassador to Britain, Amon Nsekela, officials said. Lord Carrington was in Kenya on an official visit. **********A Defense Ministry spokesman said ''there are contingency plans involving military units'' at Stansted, which is 30 miles north of London. Special Forces 'Standing By' **********The Press Association, Britain's domestic news agency, said about six members of the Special Air Service regiment were ''standing by.'' This was the unit that stormed the occupied Iranian Embassy in London to end a six-day siege by gunmen in 1980. **********The hijackers released six passengers Friday in Nairobi and two, a Belgian and a Somali, in Athens. Airport officials said it was believed that all the remaining passengers were Tanzanians. **********Home Secretary William Whitelaw, who is in charge of the British police, took control of the crisis. Essex County's Assistant Chief Constable, Peter Simpson, said the police were negotiating with the hijackers. Stansted is in Essex. **********The police sealed off Stansted, an international airport that mainly handles freight.  A crackled radio message to controllers, apparently relayed by the Tanzanian pilot and later broadcast on the BBC, said: ''We have a request. Would like the following persons to meet the aircraft on arrival. The Tanzanian High Commissioner in London and the British Foreign Minister and Mr. Oscar Kambona.'' Tanzanian in Exile **********Mr. Kambona, a former Tanzanian Foreign Minister and opponent of Mr. Nyerere, fled to exile in Britain in 1969. A brother said in a radio interview that he thought it unlikely that Mr. Kambona would meet the hijackers. **********Airport officials reported that a person identifying himself as the Tanzanian captain said there might be ''complications'' if the hijackers' demands were not met. **********Michel Picquet, a Belgian missionary released in Athens, said there were four hijackers armed with pistols, hand grenades and machine guns who said they belonged to the Tanzanian Youth Democratic Movement. **********Mr. Picquet said the co-pilot was injured, but he heard no shooting on the plane. Earlier, the hijackers said they had killed two people, but this was not confirmed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/07/world.main_headline: HAIG CALLS TAIWAN A 'DIFFICULT ISSUE' IN TIES WITH CHINA
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/07/world.print_headline: HAIG CALLS TAIWAN A 'DIFFICULT ISSUE' IN TIES WITH CHINA
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/07/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. has said that ''extremely sensitive discussions'' are under way with Peking over the Taiwan issue and that he is ''not in a position to predict the outcome.'' **********American officials previously said that talks were going on over the United Excerpts from interview, page 12. States' decision to continue arms sales to Ta iwan, something Peking regards as infringing on its sovereignty. But Mr. Haig's remarks, in an interview in his office Friday, seemed to indicate concern for future relations not voiced previously. **********''It would be counterproductive to go into details, because things are at a delicate stage, but speaking candidly, some diffi cult issuesare involved, '' he said. ''We are making a major effort to bridge these differe nces. I will be just as frank when I tell you I am not in a position to predict the outcome.'' **********Peking Arms Sales Shelved **********He also said plans to discuss the sale of American arms to Peking had been shelved and were ''hostage'' to resolution of the Taiwan talks. **********Asked whether the problem seemed serious, Mr. Haig nodded affirmatively and said, ''It has been serious.'' Mr. Haig is scheduled to leave on Sunday for Madrid, where he will represent the United States at a meeting of the conference on East-West security and cooperation in Europe. **********At the conference, he and other Western foreign ministers intend to accuse Poland and the Soviet Union of violating the human rights provisions of the Helsinki Final Act by imposing the military crackdown in Poland. Reagan Threatened Further Steps **********President Reagan has said that if there was no improvement in the situation, he might take further steps against Poland and the Soviet Union beyond the economic and political curbs announced earlier. **********But in recent weeks, American farmers have expressed opposition to any curbs on the sale of agricultural products. They have been supported in their campaign by the Secretary of Agriculture, John R.  Block. **********Mr. Haig, when asked about further economic sanctions, refused to rule anything out, but he hinted that he personally opposed an embargo on grain sales because the Soviet Union would be able to buy enough elsewhere. **********''I think the basic question in the area of economic sanctions has always got to be: Will it be effective?'' he said. ''Nothing could be more foolhardy than to unilaterally punish all or segments of American industry or agriculture with meaningless sanctions.'' **********The main question, he said, is whether such actions would be ''meaningful, lacking coordinated and comparable measures by other grain-producing nations.'' **********''The answer to that is unfortunately rather clear; that is, it would be circumvented,'' Mr. Haig said.  On another contentious issue - the Administration decision to pay domestic banks $71.3 million that Poland had not repaid on schedule rather than announce that Poland had defaulted - Mr. Haig affirmed his support for the move, despite criticism of it by Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger. **********Mr. Weinberger is reported to feel that he was not adequately consulted. He has also made the point that the decision was an interim move and would be reviewed again when other debts come due.  Mr. Haig concurred on that point. **********Mr. Haig said that it was an Administration-wide decision and that the Defense Department agreed with it. Cash Problem for Soviet Seen **********''The basic issue is, do you relieve the Poles and the Soviet Union from the obligation of meeting their international obligations or do you continue to press for the repayments, given the growing cash dilemma in the Soviet Union,'' he said. **********He said he did not want to become involved in a dispute whether Pentagon officials had known about the decision, but he acknowledged that it would be reviewed again. **********''I don't mean to suggest by that that there is any inclination to depart at this time from a decision that was made, because we feel unanimously that it was the right decision,'' he said. **********Mr. Haig's attention was called to a number of articles in the press suggesting that, as a result of the decision to move William P. Clark from the post of Deputy Secretary of State to that of national security adviser to the President, Mr. Haig would find himself increasingly isolated. The articles suggested that Mr. Clark, an old friend of President Reagan, would have increasing influence and would advocate positions different from those held by Mr. Haig. Haig Avows Close Ties to Clark **********When asked about such reports, Mr. Haig laughed and said, ''It is inconceivable that I will be isolated.'' ''I may have some surprises in store, but I sense precisely the opposite there,'' he said.  ''I have been very , very close to Bill Clark, and I remain very close to him. We are in constant contact allday long.'' **********He said it was ''very normal and natural'' for an Administration at the end of its first year to make changes in the way it handled foreign policy management and ''we are not finished yet.'' The China q uestion has been one of the most difficult ones for the Reagan Admini stration and Mr. Haig made no effort to disguise it.  Mr. Reagan, as a candidate for the Presidency, had made a number ofstatements ad vocating closer ties with Taiwan. This provoked expressions o f concern from Peking even before Mr. Reagan took office. **********The Communists in Peking contend that the United States, in recognizing them as the Government of China in 1979 and in ending official ties with the Nationalists on Taiwan, had given up the right to sell arms to Taiwan. No Loud Protest by Peking **********The Carter Administration, however, promised to maintain Taiwan's ability to defend itself, and the Taiwan Relations Act passed by Congress in 1979 also stated that the United States would ''make available to Taiwan such defense articles and defense services in such quantities as may be necessary to enable Taiwan to maintain a sufficient self-defense capability.'' **********Peking did not publicly protest very strongly about the Taiwan Relations Act at the time and, in fact, was rather quiet about continued American arms sales to Taiwan during the last two years of the Carter Administration. **********Mr. Haig, who was in China last June, said the Administration valued its relations with China and was ''determined to do all we can'' to advance them. **********''It goes without saying that since the beginning of this Administration, we have also had to face continuing disagreement with Peking over our arms sales to Taiwan,'' he said. **********For most of the year there was debate over whether Taiwan would receive an advanced fighter. The decision announced last month was that Taiwan would not get a new fighter, but would be permitted to continue to co-produce the F-5E fighter. Peking Stresses Principle of Sales **********This was regarded by some officials as a concession to Peking, but the Chinese contend that it does not matter what kind of plane is being sold to Taiwan, that it is the principle that counts. **********Peking says it will never be able to persuade Taiwan to unify peacefully with the mainland so long as the United States provides arms to Taiwan. It wants the United States to announce an elimination of arms sales over a set period - say, five years. **********Mr. Haig said the United States had made its position clear in both the Carter and the Reagan administrations on selling arms to Taiwan, but ''recognizes this is an area to be approached with prudence and discretion.'' **********He said that ever since Foreign Minister Huang Hua was here in October, there had been ''extremely sensitive discussions'' that were continued when John H. Holdridge, Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, went to Peking last month to disclose the decision on Taiwan arms.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/12/world.body_text: **********The Deputy Prime Minister, David Levi, said today that ''a massive program of building'' was being undertaken at established Jewish settlements in the occupied West Bank of the Jordan. **********Interviewed on the Israeli radio, Mr. Levi said, ''More settlements will be created soon, but only under the authority of the ministerial committee on settlements.'' **********Israel has built 103 settlements, housing about 25,000 people, in the West Bank since capturing the area from Jordan in the 1967 war. https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/24/world.body_text: **********No neon signs blink outside Rowena's, which might be termed the 21 Club of Soweto, South Africa's largest black settlement. **********It is a matter of not asking for trouble, rather than a matter of secrecy, for everyone - including the liquor squad of the South African police - knows why dozens of fancy, late-model cars can be found on weekend nights parked up and down the unpaved, dimly lit street where Rowena Mgcebetsha lives. If there's such a thing as a high-class shebeen, this is it. **********A shebeen - the word is a Gaelic import - is an illegal drinking establishment. In South Africa, it's also a subculture all its own and a beachhead within the free enterprise system that blacks have taken for themselves. **********There are untold thousands of shebeens in the country. In Soweto alone, they occupy about 4,000 of the 104,000 matchbox houses that are supposed, somehow, to accommodate the township's 1.2 million inhabitants, give or take a quarter-million. Only One Legal Bar **********There is also one legal bar in Soweto, just one, although the white Government decided two years ago to open the liquor trade to eligible blacks for liquor licenses on the same terms as whites. **********The single legal bar still belongs to the West Rand Administration Board - an arm of the central Government, which is the landlord for all the township's houses and, therefore, all the shebeens. The board also retains a near-monopoly on the retail sale of liquor in the township as the owner and operator of all but one of its retail outlets. **********The Government offers discounts to shebeen owners who buy in bulk - in hopes of taking their business away from retail stores in white areas. However, the liquor squad pounces on them and confiscates their stock - beer mainly, augmented by white wine and brandy. **********To hold down losses, the shebeen owners seldom keep more than one night's supply on the premises, dispersing the bulk of their stock in safe houses around the township. Since none of the beer or liquor companies make deliveries to unlicensed premises, all this booze has to be shuttled around the township in a clandestine fashion. The runners who move it operate a complex system that bears comparison to the original proposal for shuttling the MX missile on underground tracks. Skepticism About Legalization **********In the Government and among the shebeen owners not everyone is enthusiastic about the effort to bring all this enterprise into the open by upgrading some of the shebeens and turning them into legal neighborhood pubs. For white bureaucrats in the Government outlets, which are supposed to be turned over to private enterprise, it means disruption and a possible loss of status and position. **********The plan for giving liquor licenses to blacks outside their socalled ''homelands'' also runs counter to the original apartheid ideology. An urban black with a liquor license is, by definition, what the system was supposed to prevent: a permanent resident deemed by the Government to be responsible. Someone might even ask, ''Why can't he vote?'' Self-interest and ideology often run together in South Africa, and the liquor board is now processing black applications for licenses at a rate that seems glacial. **********The shebeen owners are also split on legalization. ''Did Al Capone want prohibition lifted?'' a white in the liquor business asked.  ''I'm not interested,'' said Mrs. Mgcebetsha, a heavyset woman with a skeptical gaze who stations herself in her kitchen next to a freezer loaded with lager beer, sizing up newcomers and turning away those who fall short of her social and sartorial standards. No Taxes, No Health Rules **********Someone suggested that her business might expand if it went legal.  ''I've got more business than I can handle now,'' she replied.  She also doesn't have to keep books, pay taxes, meet various Health Department requirements, such as separate toilets for men and women, or close down before she feels like it, which is often dawn. **********Lucky Michaels, the operator of the Pelican Club, leads a group of shebeen owners who see a liquor license as a passport into the world of capital accumulation, where blacks have traditionally been turned away. **********As chairman of a budding interest group called the Soweto Tavern Association, Mr. Michaels is planning for a day when its members will control wholesale liquor distribution in all the major black townships and use their profits to buy into South African Breweries, the major corporate purveyor. **********''Rowena is going to need a license,'' he confidently predicted.  Her skepticism would be overcome, he contended, if the Government would grant temporary licenses to shebeen owners, giving them protection from police raids during a transition period in which they undertook to upgrade their premises. ''The shebeeners don't understand they are paying more taxes than real taxes by putting up with raids,'' he said. Corruption Called 'Multiracial' **********Mr. Michaels, who still gets raided even though his association is now in formal negotiations with the Government, was referring to fines and bribes. Asked who the takers are, he laughed and replied: ''The corruption scene hasn't got a color line. It's multiracial.'' **********Others are not so sure that legal bars will be able to take customers away from shebeens. A good shebeen is known for its clientele and its music; the stereo has to be the best, as well as the loudest, and the records have to be the latest. Usually they are imports featuring black American singers and groups. **********Recently, at a popular shebeen called Irene's, business didn't perk up until about midnight. This gave the young woman who was s erving drinks time t o finish a fat romantic novel by Helen Van Slyke about corporate pol itics in New York. It was called ''The Rich and the Righteous,'' and the first sentence was, at least, timely. ''In January,'' it went, ''New York takes on the sullen aspect of a brooding empr ess.'' **********The young woman kissed the book before putting it down, and then, back in Soweto, served up Martell's V.O. brandy in a pint bottle bearing the label of a local gin. Irene Tshabalala, the owner, put on a record of Frankie Beverly and a group called the Maze. ''Live in New Orleans,'' it was called. And, at 12:30, the dancing began, with a young man in jeans that said Jordache and a jersey that said Pierre Cardin leading off.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/01/world.body_text: **********Thousands of Mozambique Government troops have begun a major offensive against rebels, said to be South African-supported, in an effort to clear the main transport links to Zimbabwe, a rebel spokesman here said today. **********Fighting is raging on either side of the route between the Mozambique port of Beira and Mutare, formerly Umtali, 150 miles to the west in Zimbabwe, a spokesman for the Mozambique National Resistance said. **********The guerrillas regularly attack communication links in Mozambique, which are vital to the efforts of black southern African countries, especially Zimbabwe, to lessen their economic dependence on South Africa. **********According to the Mozambique Government, the guerrillas are made up mainly of elite black units of the old Portuguese army.
