https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/15/busin.body_text: **********The United Technologies Corporation will purchase three telecommunications divisions of the General Dynamics Corporation for about $100 million in cash, the two companies annnounced yesterday. **********The units to be sold are the General Dynamics Communications Company, which sells telephone systems for businesses, and two divisions of Stromberg-Carlson Corporation, which makes switching systems for use in telephone company central offices and businesses. **********The units being sold had combined sales of $180 million in 1981 but had a loss of more than $27 million, according to Ray E. Forbes, a General Dynamics spokesman. The units had 4,000 employees. **********The sold units ''will fit in well with United Technologies' plans; they didn't necessarily fit in with ours for the future,'' Mr. Forbes said. **********A United Technologies official, who spoke on the condition that he not be identified, said the acquisitions would bolster the company's building automation business, which provides electronic controls for energy management, fire and security alarms and communications. **********United Technologies entered the telecommunications business last September after purchasing the Lexar Corporation, which makes a business switchboard, from Citicorp. The United Technologies official said the Stromberg-Carlson switchboards and the Lexar devices serve different segments of the market and would not conflict with each other.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/05/world.main_headline: ISRAELI IN U.S. STRESSES SHARED GOALS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/05/world.print_headline: ISRAELI IN U.S. STRESSES SHARED GOALS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/05/world.body_text: **********Israel's Foreign Minister sought yesterday to minimize Israel's differences with the United States over the latest Israeli actions in Beirut. **********The official, Yitzhak Shamir, told representatives of Jewish organizations in New York that ''thanks to this operation in Lebanon the position of the United States in the Middle East is the strongest that it ever was.'' **********''The rival Soviet Russia doesn't play now any role in our area, to a great extent thanks to our operation,'' he said.  Mr. Shamir met with President Reagan Monday at the White House and was told by Mr. Reagan that it was crucial that the ''constantly escalating violence'' end. Today Mr. Shamir repeatedly cited what he called the common goals of the United States, Israel and Lebanon in ousting the Palestine Liberation Organization from its strongholds as a prerequisite to peace in the Middle East. 'We Are Impatient' **********But he acknowledged ''there could be some differences about the urgency to reach these goals and about the tactics, how to reach them.'' **********''We are impatient,'' he said. ''We cannot wait for a long time.'' Mr. Shamir said he would not go into details about the differences but offered ''an example of the past'' that appeared to indicate some dissatisfaction with Philip C. Habib, the special American mediator in the Middle East. **********''A year ago - it was more than a year ago,'' he said, ''Philip Habib was sent by the President to Syria, to Lebanon, to Israel to find a solution for the removal of the Syrian missiles from Lebanon. **********''The goal of this mission was the removal of the missiles and the restoration of the status quo ante. There was full agreement about the formulation of this mision. But the results? The missiles all the time remained there until this last operation when they were removed of course no thanks to the efforts of Philip Habib.'' **********He added, ''There could be such a situation also now.'' Goal Is Removal of P.L.O. **********He did not elaborate and also remained silent on the immediate goals of the latest Israeli drive into west Beirut.  In his half-hour talk to the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations, 36 officials and their aides representing most of the nation's Jewish religious and secular groups, Mr. Shamir argued repeatedly that the P.L.O. had to be ''destroyed'' in order, he said, ''to have peace, security and stability in our area.'' **********The Foreign Minister called the removal of the P.L.O. ''a precondition for any improvement of the situation in our area and for any progress in the direction of peace between us and our neighbors.'' **********Mr. Shamir went on: ''The removal of the the P.L.O. from Beirut and Lebanon will announce a new era in the Middle East. They will leave Beirut and Lebanon and after the terrorist infrastructure will not be any more, not exist any more, after this center of world terrorism will cease to exist, after they will be able any more to send instructions through parts of the Middle East and many countries in the world about terrorist activities - at this moment everything will change in our area and we are sure new political horizons will be opened to all of us after many years to reach peace and stability.'' **********He added, ''We cannot exaggerate about the importance of this aim.'' 'A Solution Will Be Found' **********Mr. Shamir, a former Stern Gang fighter in the 1940's and Israeli hawk who declined to support the Camp David peace agreement with Egypt, returned repeatedly to the promise of peace once the P.L.O.  was ousted from Lebanon. **********''The moment we will finish,'' he said, ''a solution will be found for this problem. The peace process will be reopened and we will resume negotiations about autonomy'' - a reference to expanded selfgovernment for Palestinians living in the Israeli-occupied West Bank. **********A prime Israeli goal, he said, remains the creation of a 40- to 45-kilometer ''zone of security'' in Lebanon north of the Israeli border. Only a stable Lebanese Government free of P.L.O. pressure could agree to such an arrangement, Mr. Shamir said. **********However, he asserted, the P.L.O. is refusing to leave.  ''According to our information,'' he said, ''we know that they have not yet decided to leave Beirut and Lebanon. They try to gain time by procrastinating, by proposals without any prospect to be accepted.'' **********Mr. Shamir continued: ''If we want them to leave, and it is in our biggest interest to make them leave, we have to convince them that they have to leave as quickly as possible. The only choice they have before them is the choice of the way of leaving Lebanon, either to leave by negotiations or by other ways, other means.'' **********The Israelis must demonstrate to the P.L.O., the Foreign Minister said, that if diplomacy does not dislodge them ''there are other means to convincethem.'' **********Nevertheless he maintained that ''we are ready to accept a new cease-fire from this moment if the other side will keep it.'' He also said the army had taken extraordinary measures to limit civilian casualties by avoiding questionable targets. **********The removal of the P.L.O. from Lebanon would constitute a ''revolution,'' Mr. Shamir said. ''Lebanon which was until now dominated by the P.L.O. and by Syria and behind them Soviet Russia will become an independent country,'' he said, ''a part of the free world. It will have an impact on all other Arab countries.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/28/busin.body_text: **********United States steel mills operated last week at their lowest rate in 50 years, and less steel was produced than when the weekly recordkeeping began in 1962, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. **********Steel production dropped to 880,000 tons in the week ended last Saturday, a decline of 16.7 percent from the previous week's 1.757 million tons. **********Production dropped to 29.8 percent of capacity, from 35.8 percent the previous week. That was the lowest rate of mill use since 1932, when it averaged less than 20 percent for the full year. **********Net tonnage by district for the week ended Saturday totaled: Northeast coast, 125,000; Buffalo, 29,000; Pittsburgh, 67,000; Youngstown, Ohio 43,000; Cleveland, 49,000; Detroit, 82,000; Chicago, 310,000; Cincinnati, 49,000; St. Louis, 25,000; Southern, 44,000, and Western 57,000.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/13/world.main_headline: 39 KILLED AS SWISS TRAIN HITS GERMAN TOURIST BUS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/13/world.print_headline: 39 KILLED AS SWISS TRAIN HITS GERMAN TOURIST BUS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/13/world.body_text: **********A locomotive struck a bus carrying West German soccer fans home today from a weekend tour, killing 39 of the 41 men and women aboard, officials reported. **********They said 10 people were injured, including the signalwoman, who had failed to lower the railroad crossing barriers as the train approached. She was badly burned when flames from the wreckage engulfed the signal house beside the tracks. **********Also injured were two women aboard the bus, the locomotive engineer and six train passengers. Officials said that the six train passengers were released after treatment but that the four others were hospitalized and were in serious condition. They said they did not know how many passengers had been aboard the local commuter train. **********Maj. Eugen Thomann of the Zurich police said the crossing barriers were not down, as they should have been, before the bus passed through a level crossing about 12 miles south of Zurich in the early afternoon. He said the bus and the first car of the electric train burst into flames on impact. Engineer's Cabin Destroyed **********''Burned bodies, interspersed with pieces of luggage, sandwiches and running shoes were scattered on both sides of the track embankment,'' said Christoph Zuppinger, a local resident. **********He said the train ''sliced through the bus'' and the first car of the train ''was listing down the embankment with the engineer's cabin completely destroyed.'' **********''The passenger compartment was scorched everywhere,'' he said.  ''Nothing was left of the bus but burned-out wreckage, while the crossing house was gutted and demolished.'' **********All the bus passengers were believed to be members of a West German sports club and their wives from the Stuttgart area in southwestern Germany. **********A bus line official, Helmut Hassler, had said there were 39 passengers and the driver aboard the bus, but a passenger list obtained later by the police showed that there were 40 passengers. 'Flames Everywhere' **********The first two cars of the three-car train derailed, plowing into a field some distance past the rail crossing.  Major Thomann said it was not known if the signal lights at the crossing were operating. He said the engineer apparently saw the bus and applied the emergency brake about 160 feet before impact. **********''The train whistled, which was strange because it usually doesn't,'' said a witness interviewed on Swiss radio. ''Then, there was a big bang, and suddenly there were flames everywhere.'' **********A resident near the scene of the accident said the train usually passed the crossing at a speed of at least 37 miles an hour. He said that was the legal limit for the train in that area of the town. **********The injured were taken to regional hospitals, and the bodies were moved to the town's police headquarters for identification.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/22/busin.body_text: **********The failure of interest rates to fall in tandem with the encouraging declines in inflation indexes has led to a variety of complaints about the Federal Reserve's monetary policy. **********On one level, the Fed is criticized for following too slavishly its 2 1/2 percent to 5 1/2 percent growth target for the basic money supply. Those low growth rates, it is asserted, lead to high interest rates that have pushed the economy into a recession. The economic hardship could be alleviated, the critics say, by faster money supply growth that would not necessarily be inflationary. **********On another level, the Fed is criticized by the Shadow Open Market Committee, a group of monetarist economists, who said that the Fed has failed to make technical changes that ''would improve its monetary control and remove current high risk premiums in interest rates.'' **********The risk premium for bonds, referred to by the Shadow Open Market Committee's policy statement, is ''about 2 percentage points and is due to the uncertainty surrounding monetary control,'' said Allan H.  Meltzer, a professor at Carnegie-Mellon University. The risk premium is based on the idea that investors are so battered by sharp fluctuations in the prices of their notes and bonds that they now require compensation in the form of higher yields. Money Supply Controversy **********The technical aspects of controlling money supply are controversial in the credit markets, where analysts are uncertain how aggressively the Federal Reserve will try to keep weekly and monthly growth within its annual target. At a time when M-1 is above target, the analysts' uncertainty is heightened by predictions that the closely watched money supply measure will increase by several billion dollars in the week ending April 7. **********The nuances of the Fed's efforts to control money and credit are important because the more tolerant the central bank is of rapid money supply growth, the less upward pressure there will be on interest rates. Currently, the 13.38 percent yield on 30-year Treasury bonds is down from the peak of 15.2 percent last autumn but still higher than the 12.04 percent on President Reagan's inauguration day. **********Paul A. Volcker told Congress last month that money supply growth somewhat above target would be acceptable for a while, but he did not say exactly how much money supply growth is acceptable, and for how long. Predictions About Fed Moves **********Frank Mastrapasqua, economist at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, said little change in Fed policy is likely if there is an early April bulge in money supply. He noted that in past years, except for 1981, the early April bulge in money supply has been subsequently revised downward, which might encourage the Fed to ignore the increase and wait to see if it is reversed in subsequent weeks. ''The possibility does exist that the April bulge will be less than expected,'' Mr. Mastrapasqua said. **********Donald Maude, a money market economist at Merrill Lynch, came to the opposite conclusion in the March 19 Credit Market Bulletin where he wrote that the likelihood of faster money supply growth as tax refunds are distributed will encourage the Fed to keep money supply growth from getting too far out of hand. **********''Should the Fed perceive that the recession is fading, it would be almost impossible for the Fed to ignore a renewed surge without fear that its long fight for credibility would be lost quite readily.'' Against Tighter Control **********Economists at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company said in their March 22 newsletter that stricter control over money supply by the Fed is not necessary because ''no one has yet been able to demonstrate that the reported volatility in money has any impact on either the pace of economic activity or inflation.'' **********''If economic and other developments make it necessary for the Fed to ease monetary policy in the near term, the Fed may be in for considerable criticism,'' they said, and accusations by monetarists that it had ''caved in.'' **********The Lanston economists concluded, ''It is not the Fed that has a credibility problem; rather it is the monetarists who lack credibility.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/21/world.body_text: **********Iran's former Foreign Minister, Sadegh Ghotbzadeh, confessed on Iranian television to receiving money in connection with a reported assassination attempt against Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the Teheran radio said today. **********''I am shamed before the nation. Free me or execute me,'' Mr.  Ghotbzadeh was quoted as saying by an exile source.  Mr. Ghotbzadeh, whose face became familiar to millions of Americans as a spokesman for the Teheran Government during the hostage crisis, reportedly admitted in the interview that he had received money from an aide to a religious leader, who was stripped of his titles in connection with the plot. However, the religious leader, Ayatollah Kazem Shariatmadari, 82 years old, has not been officially charged in the plot, according to a revolutionary guard spokesman. **********Last week, two mullahs, Fakhreddin Hejazi and Hojjatoleslam Meshkini, said that Ayatollah Shariatmadari paid Mr. Ghotbzadeh up to $250,000 to buy a house in Teheran to launch a rocket at Ayatollah Khomeini's home 150 yards away. **********The accusations led Friday to the ransacking of Ayatollah Shariatmadari's religious school in Qum. The prelate was put under house arrest while two of his sons-in-law and four assistants were arrested, according to his son. **********The religious circle said Ayatollah Shariatmadari's role in the attempted coup was proved by Mr. Ghotbzadeh's confession. It said the ruling clergy had until now tolerated Ayatollah Shariatmadari's opposition to the Khomeini Government ''to protect the unity.'' **********A revolutionary guard spokesman in Qum said in a telephone interview that no formal charges had been made against Ayatollah Shariatmadari and ''he is at home.'' **********Ayatollah Shariatmadari telephoned his son Monday night to report the interrogation. ''He has been bleeding due to prostate disease and needs hospital treatment,'' Hassan Shariatmadari said in a telephone interview from Hamburg, West Germany, Tuesday. **********The son described the money given to Mr. Ghotbzadeh as an ''Eidi,'' or New Year's gift, and said it was $1,250.  He said protestors shut shops in the ayatollah's stronghold of Azerbaijan after the reported defrocking.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/10/world.body_text: **********Policemen investigating the kidnapping of Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier today arrested a fugitive suspected leader of the Red Brigades and 10 others believed to be members of the terrorist organization, the authorities said. **********The arrests came during dawn raids on three hide-outs on the outskirts of Rome, the police said. **********The police identified the chief suspect as Giovanni Senzani, 42 years old, who has been a professor of criminology at Florence University. Mr. Senzani, who was charged in connection with the kidnapping of an Italian judge in December 1980, had been a fugitive for more than a year. **********During their search of the hide-outs, the police seized bazookas and documents. Police Chief Giovanni Pollio said the terrorists were preparing to attack an important target, but he declined to elaborate. **********The arrests came at the end of a week of fruitless searches conducted by hundreds of agents trying to find the American general, who was kidnapped from his Verona apartment on Dec. 17.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/03/busin.main_headline: CAREY SIGNS BILL ON SECURITIES FRAUD
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/03/busin.print_headline: CAREY SIGNS BILL ON SECURITIES FRAUD
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/03/busin.body_text: **********Governor Carey signed legislation today that would stiffen the penalty for persons who intentionally engage in fraudulent activities in the sale, exchange or purchase of securities or commodities. **********The bill, which amends the General Business Law, makes any scheme intended to defraud 10 or more people while inducing or promoting securities transactions a felony. The measure also makes it a felony to intentionally suppress, conceal or omit facts in the offering and sale of securities a felony. **********Those convicted of such offenses could face up to four years' imprisonment and fines of up to $5,000, or double the amount of the gain. The new law will become effective on Sept. 1. **********Under current law, individuals who engage in such fraudulent practices in securities transactions are guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by up to one year in jail and fines up to $1,000. Differentiation Stressed **********''The present law makes no difference between those who intentionally act to defraud and those who might make a bad investment or give bad advice,'' said Nathan Riley, a spokesman for Attorney General Robert Abrams. Mr. Abrams first put forth the proposal calling for a change in the law. **********In a memorandum in support of the legislation, the bill's sponsors, Assemblyman Roger J. Robach, Democrat of Rochester, and Senator Ronald Stafford, Republican of Peru, pointed to ''an increasing number of unscrupulous promoters'' who are willfully engaging in fraudulent securities practices. **********''Most of such fraudulent practices involve a taking of property from members of the public under a common scheme or plan,'' the legislators added. **********Mr. Carey also approved a bill to eliminate the requirement that retailers prepay the local share of sales taxes collected on March sales. March Prepayments **********Under the current law, all retailers with quarterly taxable sales of $300,000 or more are required to file monthly reports of state and local sales tax collected and must remit those taxes to the state on a quarterly basis, except for sales taxes collected in March. Those taxes must be paid by retailers by March 20, 11 days before the end of the state's fiscal year. **********The law, which was enacted during the 1975 fiscal crisis to provide the state with additional revenue before the end of its fiscal year, was bitterly opposed by retailers statewide. **********The measure approved by Mr. Carey today would require retailers to prepay by March 20 only the state share of sales taxes collected on March sales. **********''The bill will give New York merchants some financial relief from a most burdensome tax,'' said the bill's prime sponsor, Assemblyman Arthur J. Kremer, Democrat of Long Beach, who is chairman of the Ways and Means Committee. ''By dropping the local share of sales tax, merchants can be assured of a reduction in their 1983 estimate payment by about 40 percent.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/29/world.body_text: **********The opposition Conservatives have retained Prince Edward Island, Canada's smallest province, and gained an extra seat in the provincial legislature, according to election results today. **********But the Liberals managed 45 percent of the popular vote against 53 percent for the Conservatives, virtually the same figures as in the 1979 poll. **********Prime Minister James Lee retained the province for the Conservatives, who won 22 of the 32 seats in the local legislature.  Pierre Elliott Trudeau's Liberal Government in Ottawa, its popularity at a 40-year low, is to fight three federal by-elections next month that political observers see as a major test of its program of price and wage restraints. **********The Liberals, battling 10.6 inflation and record high unemployment, have imposed a 6 percent ceiling on public wage increases this year and many of the provinces, all run by opposition parties, have followed suit.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/10/world.main_headline: MARCOS TO VISIT SAUDI ARABIA TO EASE MOSLEM-REBEL ISSUE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/10/world.print_headline: MARCOS TO VISIT SAUDI ARABIA TO EASE MOSLEM-REBEL ISSUE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/10/world.body_text: **********President Ferdinand E. Marcos is scheduled to visit Saudi Arabia this month for the first time. It is a country with which the Philippines has been developing close ties. **********The three-day visit will give him an opportunity to reply to charges that the predominantly Christian Philippines is not doing all it could to resolve peacefully the decades-old conflict between Christians and the five million Moslems in the southern part of the country. **********The 42-nation Islamic Conference Organization, whose headquarters are in Saudi Arabia, has repeatedly adopted resolutions urging its members to ''exert political, social and economic pressure'' on the Philippines to carry out an agreement worked out in Tripoli, Libya, in 1976 by the President's wife, Imelda Marcos, and the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. That accord called for autonomy for certain Moslem areas, the establishment of a provisional government and elections. **********Mr. Marcos said in a speech two weeks ago that the Philippines had done all that was required under the agreement. He said his Government had even offered the chairmanship of the provisional government to Nur Misuari, one of the recognized leaders in the region. But Mr. Misuari, who now lives in Saudi Arabia, denounced the plan. Status of Peace Talks **********The Philippines Government has claimed victory over the secessionist guerrilla forces of the Moro National Liberation Front and has agreed to peace talks to be held in Indonesia. But the Government maintains that the front refuses to attend. **********Islamic Affairs Minister Romulo Espaldon said at least 40,000 insurgents had ''returned to the folds of the law'' since 1972.  ''Those left in the hills are bandits, terrorists and kidnappers,'' he said. **********It was partly because of the conflict in the south that Mr. Marcos declared martial law in 1972. Martial law was lifted in the rest of the country in January 1981, but much of the southern area remains under emergency rule because the Government believes it is unsafe. **********The dates for the visit by Mr. Marcos and some Cabinet ministers, including the Minister of Energy, have not been announced.  Close ties with Saudi Arabia have been developing primarily as a result of the Philippine export labor program, which this year is expected to send thousands of Filipino laborers to Saudi oilfields.  Of the 240,000 Filipino overseas workers in the Middle East, 90 percent are in Saudi Arabia. Saudi Oil Is Imported **********In addition, the Philippines has been trying to insure its supply of oil. More than 75 percent of its energy comes from petroleum imports, and 40 percent of those imports come from Saudi Arabia. **********There has been speculation that Mr. Marcos will try to see Mr.  Misuari in Saudi Arabia. The speculation followed a remark by Mr.  Espaldon last week that such a meeting was possible. **********The President subsequently chided Mr. Espaldon and said he would not meet with any rebel leader.  Mr. Espaldon also commented that the nation's ''friends in the Islamic world'' would like to see the Moslem conflict resolved, suggesting that the Middle Eastern countries had the oil and revenues to back up their arguments.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/06/world.body_text: **********The United States and West Germany are divided over what course to follow next week when some 20 foreign ministers attend the Madrid Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. **********Western representatives, including Secretary of State Alexander M.  Haig Jr., plan to criticize the military crackdown in Poland.  Toughening its position since the Madrid meeting recessed on Dec.  18, five days after martial law was declared in Poland, the United States now believes that the conference should adjourn after the full-dress sessions next week. The Americans argue that the Polish situation makes it inappropriate to continue the talks here aimed at strengthening the Helsinki accords of 1975, which were the high-water mark of detente. **********But, according to American and European diplomats involved in shaping a Western position, West Germany's Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, has maintained that instead of being adjourned the Madrid forum should be used to criticize the Soviet Union and Poland for the crackdown. Mr. Genscher is also known to have insisted that the allies should avoid giving the impression that they are walking out on the conference. Poland to Chair Session **********In Washington, a senior American diplomat acknowledged the sensitivities of West German opinion about Madrid, but insisted that the differences with Bonn were only tactical. ''From everything that we can tell, there is a unanimous opinion among the allies that we're not going to be doing business as usual,'' said the American. **********Under an established rotation system, the chairman of the session when the full conference reconvenes on Tuesday will be Poland, wh ich might be represented by a Deputy Foreign Mini ster, Jozef Wiejaz. A bit of filibustering by Mr. Wiejaz could upse t the plans of a lengthening list of Western officials, includ ing Mr. Haig, to speak on Poland on Tuesday. The next full session i s scheduled for Friday, when a number of foreign ministers will speak .

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/01/busin.main_headline: CAPITAL INVESTMENT IN SEMICONDUCTORS EXPANDED BY JAPAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/01/busin.print_headline: CAPITAL INVESTMENT IN SEMICONDUCTORS EXPANDED BY JAPAN
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/01/busin.body_text: **********Japan's semiconductor industry, pushing to increase production, is in the midst of a big investment campaign that is likely to put further competitive pressure on American semiconductor makers, according to a major private survey. **********''The Japanese companies have been putting on an awful lot of capacity, and they are adding still more,'' said Robert H. Silin, director of consulting services of B.A. Asia Ltd., the Bank of America's Hong Kong merchant-banking arm, which conducted the study.  ''That means they have to keep those plants humming.'' **********In the last 48 months the pace of plant and equipment investment by Japan's 10 largest semiconductor producers more than tripled, to $828 million a year at present exchange rates, according to the report. **********This investment surge comes at a time when American semiconductor companies, suffering from weak markets in the United States and aggressive competition from the Japanese, have had to reduce operations and delay many investment programs. What Washington May Do **********To shield the domestic semiconductor industry from Japanese assault, the Reagan Administration is considering the possibility of limiting imports of one type of high-technology chip, the so-called 64K random access memory, on the basis of national security. **********But the Japanese industry is guiding its investment plans to sidestep the specter of other countries' protectionist actions, according to the B.A. Asia report. The 315-page volume, costing $590, is sold mostly to corporate and governmental clients (including the Central Intelligence Agency and the Soviet Government). The annual study - this is its third year - went to purchasers within the last two weeks. **********Increasingly, the Japanese are investing in semiconductor production and assembly facilities in the United States.  ''The nature of the Japanese competition will change over the next several years,'' Mr. Silin predicted in a telephone interview from Hong Kong. ''With offshore production, the Japanese challenge will not be something you can legislate against.'' More Unfinished Products **********Exports from Japan will more and more consist of unfinished products, such as silicon slivers, which are then packaged and bonded at Japanese-owned factories in the United States, the report says. Although the overall value of semiconductor exports may decline, shipments of unfinished items and the Japanese share of the American market could increase substantially. **********This strategy of offshore assembly to sidestep trade frictions has been successfully used in the past by Japanese producers of color television sets. Japan's TV companies, forced to curb exports for three years starting in 1977, now hold nearly all of the American market, but their share of it is no longer an issue. **********With leading Japanese semiconductor makers - such as Nippon Electric, Hitachi, Toshiba and Fujitsu -having set up assembly sites in the United States during the last few years, the trend is already apparent. In the four fiscal years through the one that ends today, the annual value of shipments of uncased integrated circuits (a type of unfinished product) from Japan increased nearly fourfold, to $145.9 million, the study says. Minimizing Trade Friction **********''The real issue, then, is not trade,'' the report says. ''Rather, it will be market penetration by Japanese-controlled corporations in the United States.'' **********In separate interviews, Japanese Government and industry officials said that recent moves to ease trade friction - especially Japan's ''voluntary'' restraints on auto exports -were taken into account in planning semiconductor investment in the United States. **********''We never again want to repeat the experience of the auto issue,'' said Hideji Sugiyama, deputy director of the industrial electronics division of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry. **********Another reason for Japanese investment in America is to be close to the market, according to Keiske Yawata, president of N.E.C.  Electronics U.S.A. Inc. in San Mateo, Calif. Although some American semiconductor companies are beginning to step up their investment in Japan, Mr. Yawata said most of them had been content to ship their products from the United States. **********''That was a mistake,'' he said. Future of Market in Japan **********Indeed, it is in the rapidly growing $4.3 billion semiconductor market in Japan that American manufacturers may suffer the most because of the Japanese increase in production capacity. **********Last year, for instance, Japan's imports of integrated circuits slipped from 22 percent of total consumption to 19 percent, with American producers accounting for the largest share of this. The figure will drop to 10 percent ''over the next several years,'' the B.A. Asia study predicts. **********''And the American companies that want to do well here will have to manufacture in Japan,'' Mr. Silin declared.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/11/world.main_headline: HAIG, ON EVE OF NATO TALKS, SAYS HE WANTS UNITY ON SOVIET SANCTIONS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/11/world.print_headline: HAIG, ON EVE OF NATO TALKS, SAYS HE WANTS UNITY ON SOVIET SANCTIONS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/11/world.body_text: **********Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that the United States would press its allies at a special NATO meeting here Monday for agreement on a framework for imposing sanctions against Moscow if the situation in Poland is not ''remedied in the immediate future.'' **********Mr. Haig, speaking at a news conference aboard his Air Force plane flying to the first emergency foreign ministers' meeting in the history of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, said that the United States also intended to ask the allies for a statement condemning Soviet involvement in the Polish situation. **********Mr. Haig's comments about what he expected from the alliance went beyond what he had said in Washington last week after President Reagan had met with Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany. Then, Mr. Haig indicated that the United States would not press for economic sanctions against the Russians - something opposed by Bonn at this time - and seemed satisfied with the NATO meeting limiting itself to a statement holding Moscow responsible for the Polish crisis. **********Mr. Haig said he was concerned that the Western allies not soften their response to the events in Poland by what he called ''the phony moderation'' of the Polish leadership in recent days. **********He said the formal lifting of censorship of foreign journalists and the parti al restoration of domestic telephone service in Poland fell into tha t ''phony'' category and were designed by the Polish leadership an d the Soviet Union to deceive Western public opinion. **********Reporters on the plane were told that in contrast to the amicable portrayal of Mr. Schmidt's meetings with Mr. Reagan and Mr. Haig as supplied by the principals themselves as well as by their spokesmen, the final session between Mr. Haig and Mr. Schmidt last Wednesday morning before the West German leader flew home was marked by some ''tough'' talk. A 'Floating Entity' **********Mr. Haig was reported to have told Mr. Schmidt that Washington was uncertain whether Bonn saw itself these days as part of the NATO alliance or as a ''floating entity between East and West.'' **********When some press reports appeared reporting these ''tough'' words, other officials on both the West German and the American side denied that the discussion had that character. **********Mr. Haig said aboard his Air Force 707 that the West had to tailor its policies for what he predicted would be ''a protracted, worsening, developing situation,'' with the possibility of growing repression within Poland and even direct Soviet military intervention possible. **********In addition, he said the Soviet Union was likely to try to take advantage of existing differences in perception within the Western alliance to further its ''strategic objective of splitting Western Europe from the United States.'' **********''What is clearly needed on the part of the West is the adoption of a common long-term strategic approach to events in Poland, an approach which will provide a long-term framework which would prevent a failure in the East from becoming a Western failure,'' he said. Mr. Haig said that already the Soviet Union , in messages to Western European leaders, was considerably mo re forthcoming and flexible than in its response to President Re agan. He said that the message from Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet l eader, to the President,was ''both cold and more rigid'' than in simi lar letters to European heads of state. **********In addition, he noted that the Soviet Union was threatening counter economic actions against European nations if they follow the American example and impose any sanctions. **********Mr. Haig said the West needed from the session on Monday of the NATO ministers ''a clear condemnation of the Polish 'junta' and Soviet responsibility for the events,'' as a ''clear recognition that the Soviet Union is behind the events in Poland.'' **********The ministers, he said, will repeat demands made previously by the Common Market and the United States for the end of martial law in Poland, release of the more than 5,000 prisoners, and renewal of negotiations on Poland's future among the Solidarity leaders, the church and the Polish authorities. **********Mr. Haig said, as he had in Washington, that he did not expect the Western Europeans to announce they would follow the American example and impose economic sanctions at Monday's meeting. 'Common Overall Approach' **********But he said today that the United States would regard the meeting as ''a success if we can achieve a common overall approach for the long haul, if we can establish a basis for action if the situation is not remedied in the immediate future.'' **********Without being specific, he said that he hoped that NATO would ''set in motion a framework for active consideration of economic and political sanctions.'' **********He noted that the West had already reached considerable agreement on sanctions against the Polish leadership, having already suspended any further government assistance to that country. But he said as to the Soviet Union, a consensus is ''badly lacking'' within the alliance. **********So far only the United States has announced any specific retaliatory steps against the Soviet Union. There is speculation in Brussels that at the meeting on Monday, there may be some language adopted talking of some reprisals in the political sphere, such as a limiting of political and cultural missions and exchanges. But there is no expectation of any specific economic steps at this time. **********Mr. Haig said that the United States intended ''to discuss concrete steps'' with the allies, but he recognized that ''the difference between member governments require in pragmatic terms individual approaches.'' One problem in drafting a joint statement is that the new Socialist Government of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou of Greece is opposed to any steps against the Polish Government or the Soviet Union. Mr. Haig said, ''We must not let the lowest common denominator of Western action be the most recalcitrant member state.'' In the past there have been NATO statements adopted without full unanimity, pa rticularly on military questions in which France has nottaken part. **********''The United States must be prepared to do what is necessary and correct,'' Mr. Haig said, stressing that the Americans felt they must take the lead and that the Europeans would be coaxed to follow suit. **********Mr. Haig's firmer comments and his insistence that the United States was interested in future sanctions regardless of the European attitude at this time was in part a response to some press commentary in the United States suggesting that the Reagan Administration was dropping its insistence on sanctions because of the allied opposition. Effect of Sanctions **********Mr. Haig seemed nettled by some columnists, in fact, who suggested such acquiescence in today's newspapers. In that context, reporters were told that although Mr. Schmidt made clear his view to the Reagan Administration that economic sanctions would have no meaningful economic impact on the Soviet Union, there could be no misunderstanding by him ''of the direction'' that the Reagan Administration was taking. **********Reporters asked Mr. Haig to explain what he meant by ''framework'' for future actions and in particular whether he was envisaging some new standing committee of NATO. **********He said there was no need for any new group, since NATO already has various standing committees.  ''I think we should not get too hung up on the mechanism of this framework,'' he said. ''What I'm really talking about is that there is a unified common perception of the nature of this problem, its strategic and historic implications, the culpability of the Soviet Union for the events that have occurred and recognition that if this situation is not remedied it's going to have historic impact on the full range of East-West relations.'' **********When he was asked how, given the hostility expressed by the Reagan Administration toward the Soviet Union, it could be considering a conference between President Reagan and Mr. Brezhnev, Mr. Haig replied sharply that ''When you have a crisis, you had better damn well communicate with the fellow who is perpetrating that crisis so he knows clearly where you stand.'' **********But he said he did not know when and if a meeting between the two leaders would actually take place.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/22/world.main_headline: Party of I.R.A. Wins 3 Ulster Assembly Seats
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/22/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Party of I.R.A. Wins 3 Ulster Assembly Seats
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/22/world.body_text: **********Three members of Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Provisional Irish Republican Army, won seats in in a new 78-member Assembly for Northern Ireland. Complete returns from Wednesday's balloting were not expected to be completed until late Friday. **********The Sinn Fein victories represented an initial setback to the hopes of the Social Democratic and Labor Party, the established leader of minority Catholics in Ulster who have rejected violent means and seek to break away peacefully from Britain to seek unity with the Irish Republic. **********The election was called by London in an effort to restore a form of self-rule to Ulster. Violence led London ten years ago to impose direct rule on the British province. **********The Sinn Fein winners were Gerry Adams, a Sinn Fein vice president; Martin McGuinness, at one time one of the I.R.A. members most wanted by the British authorities; and Owen Carron, who last year won a British Parlimentary by-election after the death of Robert Sands, one of the jailed I.R.A. hunger strikers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/26/world.body_text: **********Following are excerpts from remarks to the Security Council by Daniel Ortega Saavedra, leader of the Nicaraguan junta, as translated by the Nicaraguan Mission to the United Nations: The U.S. Government has entered into a period of meetings with representatives of the Mexican Government. After a round of meetings with the Mexican Foreign Minister, Don Jorge Castaneda, Mr. Alexander Haig made public a five-point proposal aimed at initiating conversations with Nicaragua following the elections scheduled for March 28th in El Salvador. **********The mere fact that the United States makes public a willingness to negotiate with Nicaragua on the basis of these points could be considered an encouraging element; but it turns out to be contradictory because, as I have been demonstrating throughout this exposition, the aggressive and destablilizing actions against Nicaragua by the U.S. Administration have been dramatically on the rise. **********The five points announced by Mr. Haig do not constitute a global approach to search for and find realistic solutions. The proposal fails to take into account the fact that the fundamental problem of the Central American crisis does not consist of the never-proven allegation that arms are reaching the Salvadoran revolutionaries via Nicaragua while, on the other hand, the United States is supplying arms, airplanes, helicopters, advisers, technical support and hurried military training to the Salvadoran army. **********Negotiations Called Urgent **********It is imperative, on the contrary, to accept with responsibility that the causes of the phenomenon lie in the injustice that reigns in El Salvador and that, therefore, it is urgent to find by way of negotiations a response to the possibilities of integral transformation demanded by Salvadoran society. **********We have not come to accuse, but to demand an end, once and for all, to the policy of aggressions, threats, interventions, covert operations, invasions against our homeland and the region. And to make it clear that the unfairly distributed resources of humanity on this planet do not give the powerful a right to act against weak and small people. **********I would like to sum up this presentation with concrete points that have been voiced before. These points are: 1. Neither Nicaragua nor any of the countries of the Central American and Caribbean region can be considered as a geopolitical reserve of the United States, or as a part of its so-called ''strategic frontier,'' a concept that restricts the exercise of our sovereignty and independence. **********2. Therefore, Nicaragua can in no way represent a threat to the security of the United States. We are a small country, a dignified and poor country, that follows a policy of international nonalignment. The national interests of the people and nation of the United States should not be confused with the particular policy of the present Administration, which is trying to make its own points of view prevail, even at the cost of peace and security, not only of its own citizens but of an entire conglomerate of countries which, like ours, have a right to determine their own destiny. **********3. We are willing to improve the climate of relations with the United States on the basis of mutual respect and unconditional recognition of our right to self-determinatiuon. **********4. We are willing to begin immediately direct and frank conversations with the Government of the United States, even in a mutually agreeable third country, with the objective of reaching concrete results through such negotiations. **********5. The Salavadoran patriots of the F.L.M.N.-F.D.R. have authorized us to transmit their willingness to begin immediate negotiations, without preconditions, reiterating once more the call they made through me before the 36th ordinary period of sessions of the United Nations. **********6. The revolutionary Government of Cuba has authorized me to communicate to this Security Council its willingness as well to begin negotiations without delay. **********7. The Government of National Reconstruction of Nicaragua, the Government of Cuba and the Salvadoran patriots of the F.M.L.N.-F.D.R. back ther initiative for neogotiatiosn taken by the President of Mexico, Jose Lopez Portillo, on Feb. 21 in Managua. **********8. Nicaragua is willing to immediately sign nonaggression pacts with all bordering countries of the Central American area in order to insure peace and internal stability in the zone. **********9. Nicaragua is obliged to reject the attempt by the United States to impose humiliating restrictions on its inescapable and sovereign prerrogatives regarding national defense. Demands to U.S. Listed **********We demand, on the other hand, that the Government of the United States immediately put a halt to whatever measure or covert plan of the many that have been announced and denounced and which have never been denied officially: secret destabilization plans, organization and financing of paramilitary forces advised and trained by U.S.  military personnel in Honduras and active and retired militarymen from Argentina and other countries of South America. **********- Put a stop to the use of Honduran territory as a base for armed aggressions and terrorist operations against our homeland. **********- Put a stop to the existence of counterrevolutionary military training camps in U.S. territory, mainly in Florida. **********- Put a stop to the traffic in arms and counterrevolutionaries between the territory of the United States and Honduras. **********- Put a stop to the participation of the United States intelligence community in the financing, training and organizing of forces and clandestine plans against out homeland. **********- Put a stop to the presence of U.S. warships in waters of Central America and off Nicaragua's coast. **********- Put a stop to the flights of spy planes that violate Nicaragua's airspace.  The United States must, in an official and explicit manner, voice its commitment not to attack Nicaragua, not to initiate or promote any direct, indirect or covert intervention in Central America. **********Nicaragua calls on the Security Council of the United Nations to issue an explicit pronouncement in line with the charter of the organization, regarding the obligation to search for a peaceful means of resolving the problems of the Central American and Caribbean region; the council's rejection of the acts of force and threats, and its repudation of any direct, indirect or covert intervention in Central America.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/30/busin.body_text: **********Except for cautious optimism from the automobile industry, business executives yesterday painted a generally gloomy picture for the economy in view of the budget impasse between President Reagan and Democratic Congressional leaders. **********The outlook - a rising budget deficit that would keep interest rates high -was viewed as particularly depressing for such areas of the economy as steel, housing, real estate, forest products, furniture and the suppliers that serve these and other industries. In credit markets, bond dealers and traders voiced dismay at the possibility of larger-than-expected deficits. (Page D1.) **********Richard M. Smith, vice chairman of the board of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, which lost nearly $67 million in the first quarter, said the breakdown in talks would ''further delay economic recovery and that will further delay recovery of the steel industry.'' If, he said, there were a further decline in the rate of steel production - now 60 percent of capacity - employment would continue to fall for his company. **********Maintaining that the deadlock over the budget was becoming more devastating to the economy day by day, J. Hugh Liedtke, chairman of the Pennzoil Company, told stockholders at the company's annual meeting in Houston that ''the economic well-being of every man and woman in this country is being imperiled'' by the impasse. He warned that the economy had ''absolutely no chance of making a sustained recovery'' and that interest rates would not come down until a Federal budget was in place that ''demonstrates that Federal spending is heading downward.'' 'Disaster for Us' **********''What this will mean to us is total disaster,'' Michael Sumichrast, chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders, said of the impasse. He estimated that settlement on the budget might have brought interest rates down to 12 percent from about 16 1/2 percent now. This, he said, might have raised housing production from 1.1 million units last year to 1.17 million this year and to 1.5 million in 1983. Now, he said, the prime rate would not come down and housing production this year ''at best'' might approach 1 million units, with no improvement next year. ''That's a disaster for us,'' he said. **********Arguing that the breakdown in budget talks meant ''paralysis of leadership until after the November elections,'' Jack Carlson, head of the National Association of Realtors and its chief economist, forecast ''only modest improvement in the economy this summer'' and predicted the economy would ''fall back into recession'' by the end of the winter. ''Only rich people will be able to afford the average home,'' he said, ''and middle-income and lower-income people will be left in the cold'' because of the failure to find a way to reduce the Federal deficit. **********At the Chrysler Corporation, Lee A. Iacocca, the chairman, stressed that the economy was the ''overriding issue'' facing the auto industry. He said that while the 10 percent Federal income tax cut, effective July 1, would be beneficial, ''we are concerned with the inability of the Government to deal with an ever-larger budget deficit, high interest rates, rising unemployment and sagging consumer confidence.'' **********Roger B. Smith, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, said the recession appeared to have ''about run its course,'' and if concern over the budget deficit could be contained, ''this would reduce the risk of recovery again being undermined by rising interest rates.'' **********In St. Louis, James A. Van Sant, chief executive of General Steel Industries, a supplier to a number of industries, said he was ''not sure'' there was a budget impasse, but added: ''Things are already extremely tough, and if they have to get a bit worse as part of the cure, General Steel is willing to stick it out. We've got to swallow the bitter medicine for a while longer to have a healthier economy this year or next.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/27/busin.body_text: **********WASHINGTON A VETERAN inventor, with more than 200 patents, proposes that automatic bank teller machines be used to transfer funds to program the operation of postage meters in offices. Luther G. Simjian of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was granted a patent this week for apparatus to issue cards that the meters will accept. **********Under patent 4,317,028, encoded charts can be validated for a specified amount by an automatic teller and a depositor's bank account charged accordingly. The authenticity of the card and the subscriber's identity are to be checked by computer in a central office. When the authorized sum is exhausted, the subscriber can order the automatic teller to issue a new card. **********In the plan, the bank would transfer funds to the Postal Service.  At present, postage meters are usually taken to a post office and reset when a service fee is paid. **********Mr. Simjian has an earlier patent proposing that coupons could be bought like stamps and used for resetting postage meters. A former resident of Greenwich, Conn., he is still president of Command Automation Inc. there. Many of his early patents were on cameras and X-ray systems. A recently patented golf ball he designed for putting practice has gone into production.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/08/world.main_headline: SWEDEN SAYS THE SUB MAY HAVE ESCAPED
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/08/world.print_headline: SWEDEN SAYS THE SUB MAY HAVE ESCAPED
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/08/world.body_text: **********Swedish military officers suggested today that the submarine that had been hunted since last Friday near a naval base in the Stockholm archipelago might have escaped out into the Baltic. They suggested also that a second submarine might have been detected. **********These statements came as helicopters dropped six more depth charges -four at about 2:30 P.M. and two at 5 P.M. - and then joined Swedish naval vessels beyond the bay area off the Musko naval base, about 20 miles south of here, where a hunt had been conducted since Friday for what the Swedish Navy called a foreign submarine. Swedish newspapers have suggested that the craft was either Soviet or Polish. **********Vice Adm. Bror Steffenson, Sweden's Chief of Staff, said at a news conference that the navy might have lost track of the submarine first sighted on Friday or that it could have ''left the immediate search area.'' **********Capt. Sven Carlsson, the chief naval spokesman, said that shortly before 2:30 P.M., when four depth charges were dropped, ''our forces established sonar contact with an object moving close to the northern exit of the area blocked by Swedish naval vessels.'' He said that that ''object'' was the target of the four depth charges. Possibility of Second Sub **********Another naval spokesman said the trapped vessel might have made a run for it, and that two more depth charges were fired around 5 P.M.  within 15 yards of the target close to the northern exit of the bay, which is known as Horsfjarden. **********''It could also mean that a second sub had approached the area,'' Capt. Cay Holmberg, an antisubmarine warfare specialist, said in an interview. **********He would not disclose whether the moving object was discovered, by sonar contact, just inside or outside the area sealed off by Swedish naval units. **********Admiral Steffenson said, on being asked whether a second submarine had been detected, that it was impossible to tell ''whether there might be one or two.'' **********''The new thing,'' he said, ''is the movement in the area of the exit where we tried to stop anything from going out. Our barrier there is not like a fence or chain.'' Difficult Hunting Grounds **********Admiral Steffenson said there were ''difficulties on the technical, tactical and geographical levels'' in the attempt to force any intruder to the surface. He said the Baltic's shifting waters and craggy bottom makes it one of the world's most difficult submarine hunting grounds. **********About 30 depth charges have been dropped during the seven-day hunt. Two helicopters were seen hovering over the northern exit of the bay minutes after the latest series of charges were dropped. **********Later, the helicopters suddenly shifted northward to positions closer to the harbor of Berga, a naval training base a few miles north of Musko. They hovered about 500 yards from the dock while four survey vessels scoured the bottom. **********Surface vessels were also seen moving through the exit toward the sea, and the submarine salvage ship Belos was sighted near the northern exit just outside the area where the helicopters hovered. **********A small flotilla of ships used for surveillance and measuring sea depth methodically swept back and forth across the area, and submarine-hunting helicopters continued a sonar search into the night.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/31/world.main_headline: British Pilot Rescued Behind Enemy Lines
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/31/world.print_headline: British Pilot Rescued Behind Enemy Lines
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/31/world.body_text: **********The pilot of a Harrier jet who bailed out of his crippled plane behind the Argentine lines on Thursday was rescued today by helicopter, a dispatch from the war zone said. **********Max Hastings of The Evening Standard of London reported in a dispatch from San Carlos Bay in the Falkland Islands that Squadron Leader Robert Iveson, 34 years old, had been hit during his seventh mission of the day from the aircraft carrier Hermes. **********After parachuting from his plane, Squadron Leader Iveson hid overnight in a house, then started to walk north toward the British beachhead. He heard the sound of the fighting for Goose Green, and when it stopped he turned on his radio beacon. **********Early this morning a helicopter appeared overhead, the pilot recounted. He fired an identification flare when he was sure it was British, and within an hour he was back at British headquarters, with only a few facial cuts and bruises to remind him of his ordeal.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/04/busin.main_headline: ( BUDGET STOP AND GO If recent performance is an indication, the economy will never see the record budget deficit predicted for the current fiscal year.
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/04/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS CONDITIONS; ( BUDGET STOP AND GO If recent performance is an indication, the economy will never see the record budget deficit predicted for the current fiscal year.
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/04/busin.body_text: **********The Federal budget posted a $14.8 billion deficit in February, about $1 billion less than the same period a year earlier, according to the Treasury Department's figures. Through the first five months of the fiscal year, the deficit totaled $53.7 billion, or $2 billion less than the total recorded during the October-February period of fiscal 1981. **********Economists at Manufacturers Hanover Trust write in the latest issue of Financial Markets that if these trends continue, the Federal deficit would total $76 billion this year, or $3 billion below 1981's record $78.9 billion. **********Current conditions make the performance even more remarkable, the bank's analysts say. Rapid contractions in the economy, rising unemployment and a much slower rate of inflation generally are factors that make the deficit rise, not contract. **********''So far this year, tax prepayments and overpayments seem to be a major reason why the deficit has been running at a slower rate,'' said Jonathan Neuberger of the Washington Analysis Corporation, a research subsidiary of Bache Halsey Stuart Shields. **********While recent developments have been a surprise, Mr. Neuberger and other economists still expect the deficit to be more than $100 billion this year. ''Treasury borrowings in the second half of the year should increase substantially,'' Mr. Neuberger said. **********''Since tax receipts have been so high, I suspect that refunds will be higher than normal this spring,'' he said. '' If that happens, Treasury borrowings could be higher than currently anticipated.'' **********Borrowings should get even heavier during the final quarter of the fiscal year, Mr. Neuberger said. By his reckoning, the 1982 deficit is likely to end up in the $130 billion to $140 billion range.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/18/world.body_text: **********The prospect that as many as 1,500 Palestinian guerrillas from west Beirut may soon arrive here has raised mixed emotions in Jordan, where more than half the population is already Palestinian and where the battles between Jordanians and Palestinian guerrillas of more than a decade ago have not been forgotten. **********On the one hand, sympathy for the Palestine Liberation Organization is widespread, even among many non-Palestinians, and it has grown since the Israeli bombardment of Beirut. King Hussein has put his offer of asylum, which was formally transmitted to the P.L.O. 10 days ago, in the context of Arab solidarity. He and his country plainly feel strong enough today, politically and militarily, to control some disarmed guerrillas. **********On the other hand, native Jordanians admit some doubts and worries. The Palestinian population in Jordan has grown rapidly, and the Palestinians, although law-abiding in recent years, have caused grave troubles in the past. They have sometimes spoken against the monarchy, and, before being expelled, the P.L.O. provoked Israel. 'Instigators of Hollow Emotions' **********King Hussein, in a speech broadcast last Wednesday on the 30th anniversary of his accession to the throne, warned against ''instigators of hollow emotions and sedition'' in the wake of the Israeli invasion of Lebanon and said he would show ''no mercy'' toward those who threatened his nation's unity, security and stability. The image that many of his listeners formed on hearing these remarks was of Palestinian guerrillas and their sympathizers. **********His words were taken less as a comment on the P.L.O.'s Jordanian homecoming than on the more general possibility that yet another Israeli advance might be followed by bitter political dissension among Arabs. Still, many Jordanians expressed surprise that the King had agreed to accept any of the guerrillas. Now that the guerrillas' arrival seems imminent, a typical attitude among Jordanians, according to one Palestinian official based here, is of ''latent apprehension.'' **********The official added, in a commonly held opinion, that Jordanian-Palestinian and Jordanian-P.L.O. relations had mellowed over the last few years. He also insisted, as almost everyone does, that no one could say what would follow the evacuation of Beirut. Memories of Black September **********One reason for the apprehension is the memory of Black September, a series of battles between Palestinian and Jordanian soldiers that began in September 1970 and ended only when bow-armed Palestinians had either been killed or expelled in 1971. Several thousand people died on each side, and deep bitterness toward the P.L.O. persists among some Jordanian soldiers, security officers and policemen. **********The Palestinians' sheer force of numbers has caused other grievances. And the likelihood that several thousand Palestinian refugees will soon head for Jordan can only add, however slightly, to those numbers. **********Excluding the West Bank, more than half of Jordan's 2.3 million East Bank residents consider themselves Palestinians, though most have been granted Jordanian citizenship. Half a million of the Palestinians still receive rations as official refugees.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/22/world.main_headline: U.S. OFFERS TO AID JOURNALISM IN THIRD WORLD
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/22/world.print_headline: U.S. OFFERS TO AID JOURNALISM IN THIRD WORLD
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/22/world.body_text: **********The United States offered today to support selected communications projects in developing countries as part of a ''cooperative association'' with a Unesco-sponsored program to promote third world journalism. **********But, addressing a meeting of the International Program for Development of Communications, the chief American delegate, William G. Harley, indicated that public and private resources from the United States would be channeled directly to countries receiving aid, rather than through the program. **********He said the United States Agency for International Development would make $100,000 available to finance preparation of appropriate projects. The American private sector was expected to make an important contribution, Mr. Harley said, but he offered few details. **********Government Control of News **********The Reagan Administration's refusal to contribute directly to the program stems from its fears that financing could be provided to projects (above all, the creation of national news agencies in some third world countries) that strengthen government control over information. **********But the United States is also anxious not to be seen boycotting a program that it originally proposed as a way of guiding discussions of a ''new world information order'' at the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization away from efforts to restrict journalistic freedom and toward practical ways of aiding communications in poor countries. **********Mr. Harley stressed today that the United States could help by providing experts in such areas as rural telecommunications, educational broadcasting, nutrition, health and family planning communications and satellite development. ''It is through stimulating new bilateral projects in individual countries that the greatest practical impact of the program will be felt,'' he added. **********The continuing philosophical differences between the United States and most third world countries over the idea of an information order have nevertheless come to the surface in discussions of both specific projects and the criteria that should guide the program's operation. U.S. Raises Objections **********This morning, another American delegate, Clifford Block, objected to approval of a project to develop the Asia-Pacific News Network because the agency had recommended that Western news agencies, such as The Associated Press and United Press International, be allowed to distribute news only through national agencies. **********''We have a very serious question related to a potential exclusivity that could affect private media in the region,'' Mr.  Block said. ''The national agencies could be centers to screen out information before it reaches private media.'' **********But support for the project was overwhelming. And because the program's 35-nation Inter-Governmental Council has so far acted only on consensus, the United States withdrew its formal opposition with the understanding that its reservations would be recorded. **********Wednes day, the Projects Committee of the co uncil also approved a request for financing to develop a Pan-Africa n News Agency that would cover 50 countries. Many other regional projects have also beenaccepted, although in many cases financing st ill has to be made available. To date, the program has received project requests worth $85 million, but pledged contributions of onl y $6 million. Phrases Are Changed **********In the Priorities and Criteria Committee this morning, the United States was more successful in eliminating phrases that were perceived as carrying ominous implications. **********A reference to the need for ''a more balanced exchange of news,'' for example, was replaced by a call for ''a free flow and a wider and better balanced exchange of news.'' Soviet, Cuban and East German delegates objected to the endorsement of ''a free flow,'' but finally accepted the compromise wording. **********Similarly, observers from the World Press Freedom Committee and the Inter-American Press Association warned against a call for ''active social participation'' in news organizations.After long negotiations, this phrase was also eliminated.
