https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/09/world.print_headline: Around the World; Greece to Investigate Finances of Newspapers
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/09/world.body_text: **********The Government has ordered an investigation into the financial resources of all Greek newspapers after a growing dispute over allegations that the Soviet Union is financing a major daily. **********The Government said previous governments had made generous loans to newspapers to insure their survival and that the dailies owed the state the equivalent of $27.5 million. **********Dimitrios Maroudas, under secretary to Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou, said the papers' debts would have to be repaid over the next 15 years. **********The measures, which were decided on in the last few months, were evidently undertaken by the Government in order to satisfy calls for action over the reported clandestine financing of Ethnos, a leftist daily. The conservative daily Mesimvrini said last week that Ethnos began publication six months ago with a $1.8 million Soviet grant and that Moscow was still covering its losses.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/19/world.main_headline: ANTINUCLEAR GROUP, 25, GATHERS IN NOVA SCOTIA
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/19/world.print_headline: ANTINUCLEAR GROUP, 25, GATHERS IN NOVA SCOTIA
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/19/world.body_text: **********The morning of Aug. 6, 1945, was clear and sunny, Prof. Iwao Ogawa remembers. At the time, he was helping his students at the Imperial Japanese Naval Academy, 10 miles south of Hiroshima, build a bomb shelter. **********Suddenly there was a brilliant flash of light, then a terrible rush of wind that shattered the windows in his house. A huge cloud rose over the city, singed red by the firestorm burning below. **********Professor Ogawa was in a unique position. He is the only nuclear physicist known to have observed the explosion of that first atomic bomb over Hiroshima. Within hours he began making calculations that led him to suspect what had happened, for Professor Ogawa knew that two teams of Japanese scientists were themselves secretly trying to build a nuclear weapon. The Pugwash Meetings **********Professor Ogawa also has a more pleasant recollection. Twenty-five years ago, he was one of a group of 22 distinguished scientists from 10 countries, including the Soviet Union and China, who met at this tiny fishing village of Pugwash to discuss ways of averting a nuclear holocaust. **********That conference, sponsored by the Cleveland industrialist Cyrus Eaton in response to an appeal by Bertrand Russell and Albert Einstein at the height of the cold war, was the first such meeting between American and Soviet scientists. It and a series of so-called Pugwash meetings that followed helped lay the groundwork for the Nuclear Test Ban Treaty of 1963, the United Nations-sponsored treaty to ban the spread of nuclear weapons and the 1969 convention outlawing biological weapons. **********In 1960 the scientists split with their patron, Mr. Eaton, fearing that his close personal ties to the Soviet leadership imperiled their neutrality in the East-West conflict. **********But this weekend a group of 35 arms control specialists, disarmament activists and scientists, including Professor Ogawa, returned to Pugwash to celebrate the 25th anniversary of the meetings and pay tribute to Mr. Eaton, who died in 1979. **********Pugwash, across the Northumberland Strait from Prince Edward Island, was Mr. Eaton's birthplace. The conferences were held on the waterfront in the converted storehouse of a lobster fisherman, and the guests were housed in a 170-year-old white frame inn. Group Backs Weapons Freeze **********Although this weekend's meeting was an informal one - a full gathering of the 2,000 scientists from 75 countries who now make up the Pugwash movement is to be held in Warsaw in August - the group adopted a resolution supporting a nuclear weapons freeze, a reduction in nuclear arsensals and pledges of no first use of nuclear weapons like the one made by the Soviet Union last month. **********The major question before the group, which included Linus Pauling, twice a Nobel laureate, was that of how scientists could take advantage of the sudden popularity of the antinuclear arms movement, particularly the freeze campaign. For years scientists like Professor Pauling warned about the dangers of nuclear war without much popular response. **********Herbert Scoville Jr., president of the Arms Control Association and a former Deputy Director of the Central Intelligence Agency, recalled that President Johnson proposed a freeze on nuclear weapons in 1967 and that in 1970 the Senate approved a freeze resolution by a vote of 72 to 6. **********Most of the participants agreed with Sergei P. Kapitsa, a member of the Soviet Academy of Sciences and the host of a popular science program on Moscow television, that neither superpower can gain nuclear superiority. ''There is an essential parity of strategic weapons, overkill parity,'' Professor Kapitsa said, differing with the Reagan Administration's view that the Soviet Union enjoys an advantage because of its lead in large land-based intercontinental ballistic missiles. There Is Some Disagreement **********But the participants did not all agree on how to put a freeze into effect. Paul M. Doty, director of the Center for Science and International Affairs at Harvard University, said that in most freeze resolutions, which call for a moratorium on the testing, deployment and production of nuclear weapons, it would be difficult to verify whether a nation had stopped arms production. **********Professor Doty, a leading arms-control expert, said it would be simpler to monitor deployment and testing of nuclear weapons. ''I myself wish production wasn't part of the freeze,'' he said. ''We have too little experience with it.'' **********Professor Doty said he hoped to begin work soon on drawing up a more carefully defined freeze proposal.  He also said the next 18 months to two years would be a crucial period for arms control. If the talks in Geneva between the United States and the Soviet Union on strategic and medium-range nuclear missiles do not make progress within that time, he said, the United States may have deployed its cruise missiles in Europe. **********Cruise missiles could upset the strategic balance, he said, and would be almost impossible to verify as part of an arms-control agreement. The Soviet Union trails the United States in developing a sophisticated cruise missile, Professor Doty said, but it will eventually have them and the arms race will have escalated to a new level. **********But Professor Doty was skeptical of Moscow's recent pledge not to use nuclear arms first and of similar proposals by disarmament groups in the United States. Such pledges would be too easy to circumvent, he argued. All a nation would have to do, he said, is explode a nuclear device inside its own territory and assert that it had been attacked, absolving itself of responsibility for sticking to the promise. Hesburgh Trying to Form Meeting **********Another participant in the conference, the Rev. Theodore M.  Hesburgh, president of the University of Notre Dame, said he had been working for the last 18 months to try to bring the world's top scientists together with the leaders of the Roman Catholic Church ''for the first time since Gallileo.'' **********Father Hesburgh said that he had worked out a draft program on the dangers and possible solutions to nuclear war and that the presidents of 15 national academies of science, including that of the Soviet Union, would present the program to Pope John Paul II in Rome in September. The draft does not single out any particular plan, Father Hesburgh said, but by joining scientific and religious authority it could increase pressure on the world's leaders to act. **********Professor Ogawa said he remembered how, after the atomic bomb had been dropped of Hiroshima, he helped organize teams of scientists to determine what had caused the disaster. **********''Our first clue was that X-ray film in the hospitals had all been blackened, exposed,'' he said. ''That could only have happened by radiation. We also had seismologists who measured the distance from Hiroshima at which gravestones had been toppled. Their estimate of the bomb's size proved very accurate. **********''The bomb was a terrible thing,'' Professor Ogawa went on. ''But until it was dropped, the navy officers were very confident they could fight on. After it, they came to me and asked for books about physics. It may have shortened the war.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/12/busin.main_headline: U.S. IS SAID TO LOSE $650 MILLION OWED IN '81 ROYALTIES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/12/busin.print_headline: U.S. IS SAID TO LOSE $650 MILLION OWED IN '81 ROYALTIES
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/12/busin.body_text: **********The Government failed to receive $650 million in oil and gas royalties it was due last year, according to a special panel of investigators. It said that the loss was due to underreporting by companies operating on Federal lands and the inability of the Interior Department to police its ''honor system'' of collections. **********The investigators also report that thefts of undetermined amounts of oil from Government and Indian leases have become ''a serious national problem.'' The panel cites estimates that 2 to 6 percent of all crude oil produced in the United States is being stolen from oilfields and tank farms. **********The investigation was conducted by the Commission on Fiscal Accountability of the Nation's Energy Resources, a five-member body set up by the Reagan Administration last July to study long-standing allegations of underpayments and enforcement laxity. The report of the investigating panel was given final approval by the commissioners on Friday. Recommendations Are Made **********To deal with the problems involving a royalty system that is expected to generate $20 billion a year by the end of this decade, the commission has made far-reaching recommendations, including fines of as much as $10,000 a day for violations. Fines were never imposed before. Only recently, in fact, have those underreporting their production been made to pay interest on late payments. **********''There has been very significant mismanagement of the royalty resources of this country,'' declared David F. Linowes, a management specialist and professor at the University of Illinois, who is the commission's chairman. ''Internal controls are almost wholly lacking within the Geological Survey.'' **********Preliminary drafts of the panel's work have already spurred action at the Interior Department, where senior staff members have endorsed nearly all its recommendations and have prepared decision memorandums for Secretary James G. Watt. **********The Administration is expected to announce proposals to tighten the royalty-collecting system within the next few days. The process is moving swiftly so that additional revenues can be included in the Federal budget for the fiscal year 1983. Separate Office Is Urged **********In addition to the proposed fines, the commission is recommending creation of a separate royalty management office outside the Geological Survey, and it urges that all leaseholders draw up plans outlining who is responsible for making payments to the Government. **********The panel also recommends raising the royalty percentage for new onshore leases to 162/3 percent, the level for offshore leases, from the present 12 1/2 percent. The Interior Department staff opposes this change, however, and it is unclear what Secretary Watt will recommend to the President. **********''Royalty management is no longer a small collection effort which can be managed easily while buried in a large engineering or scientific organization,'' the commission declares in the report. It calls the performance of the present collection system a ''severe embarrassment to the department.'' An efficient system has not been installed, the commission says, despite numerous investigations by the General Accounting Office and other agencies over the last 20 years. **********In essence, the panel says the Geological Survey has spent too much effort acting as a bookkeeper for the oil and gas industry while virtually neglecting field inspections and other enforcement methods. The panel proposes that the oil and gas producers themselves be required to do this work under rigorous new rules that would force them to meet standards for oilfield security and to designate responsibility for channeling royalties to the Government. A Lack of Records Is Cited **********Despite a few attempts to improve the system, the commission has found, the Survey ''has no complete, up-to-date records of all the individuals and companies who pay royalties.'' **********There are several hundred thousand individuals and companies holding some 18,000 producing leases, the commiss ion says, and the Survey's records are only partly computerized . **********The industry is expected to strongly resist measures calling for more reporting responsibility.  Peter B. Wellish of the Independent Petroleum Association of America said today that many of his group's 7,500 members, including some very small operators, would have to add 6 to 10 employees ''just to keep track of all these numbers.'' He termed this a mammoth job that ''would just cost enormous amounts of money.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/10/busin.main_headline: Market Place; M.T.A. Bonds: Firm Backing
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/10/busin.print_headline: Market Place; M.T.A. Bonds: Firm Backing
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/10/busin.body_text: **********THE Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the operator of New York City's bus and subway systems along with some regional commuter train lines, continues to enjoy access to the bond markets, even though state legislators have not come up with a subsidy and tax package needed by the authority to close a budget gap estimated at as much as $300 million in the current fiscal year. **********New York State, meanwhile, faces its own budget deficit and will be hard-pressed to match the $290 million subsidy it gave the authority in 1982. A cutback in state assistance would hurt, but, according to 1981 legislation that gave the M.T.A. enough financial credibility to borrow money in the bond markets, a shortfall in revenues from fares or government appropriations would leave it with no alternative except to raise fares. **********With all the uncertainty about future financing, the bonds issued by the authority might be expected to be depressed. In fact, the authority still enjoys enough acceptance in the marketplace to plan a $125 million bond sale next week. **********The backing for next week's new bonds is significantly different than for the $250 million of revenue bonds sold in October. But both are an outgrowth of the 1981 legislation that is the foundation for the authority's creditworthiness in the eyes of investment bankers and bond buyers. **********That legislation, known as the 1981 Transit Act, included promises to bondholders by the state and the M.T.A. that are unusual in the annals of government finance but were necessary if the transit authority was to sell $1.6 billion of bonds as part of a $5.7 billion, five-year capital spending program. In essence, the legislation helped the M.T.A. separate the fate of its bondholders from the turmoil of the state and city budget-making process. **********Of course, the financial markets are still aware of the difficulty of obtaining government funds. As Moody's Investors Service noted in its analysis of the M.T.A.'s revenue bonds sold last October, investors should expect ''the periodic controversy that surrounds it to continue.'' **********But thus far, analysts can only discern a slight drop in the price of M.T.A. bonds relative to other tax-exempt issues. The 10 3/8 percent M.T.A. bonds due in 2012 have fallen from an offered price in October of 99 1/2 to 88 1/2 yesterday, to yield 11.77 percent. But prices of other long-term bonds sold at about the same time declined by similar amounts. The 10 1/8 percent bonds of the Massachusetts Municipal Wholesale Power Authority, for example, have dropped to 89 recently from a price of 100 on Oct. 15. **********The bonds to be sold next week are secured by a contract between the state and the M.T.A. in which the state promises to pay $80 million a year for the next 35 years for capital improvements.  Because the state has contracted to pay that money, the authority can borrow against it, even though the money must be appropriated annually by the State Legislature. **********The state's promise to pay is good enough to warrant ratings of A and A by Moody's and the Standard & Poor's Corporation, respectively. Those ratings are a notch higher than the Baa and BBB+ ratings assigned to the revenue bonds that the authority sold for the first time last October. **********According to Robert Gerard, a managing director at Dillon, Read & Company, there is a significant difference between the Legislature's promise to pay $80 million annually and the assumption that the Legislature will make annual appropriations to subsidize the authority. **********''The direct result of a failure to appropriate money for the service contract would be a default on the bonds,'' Mr. Gerard said, ''whereas a bond default would not be the result of a failure to appropriate funds for the operating expenses.'' **********In Mr. Gerard's opinion, and that of many other market participants, the authority's revenue bonds, such as the $250 million sold last October, are well secured because of the requirement that the authority raise fares if needed to balance its budget.  Furthermore, that legislation allowed the authority to give the revenue bonds first lien on all its revenues and prohibited the state from allowing the authority to file for bankruptcy. **********Such legal protections are useful, but as analysts at both major rating agencies said, the ultimate protection for the bondholders depends on the ability of the transit authority to spend the borrowed money effectively enough to improve service and keep ridership from continuing to decline.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/28/busin.body_text: **********WASTING no time, Sears, Roebuck & Company, which said Tuesday that it would consolidate its three apparel accounts at one agency, began talking to Chicago agencies yesterday in its Chicago headquarters.  The account - for women's, men's and children's clothing - comes to $30 million. **********One of the agencies was Foote, Cone & Belding, which had the women's apparel business, as well as tires and batteries, and is the only incumbent being invited to pitch for the collective business. **********Also invited were Ogilvy & Mather and the J. Walter Thompson Company, both of which handle major nonapparel assignments for Sears.  It is also understood that the callers included the Leo Burnett Company, Chicago's biggest agency, which does advertising for Sears's Allstate Insurance Companies; Needham, Harper & Steers, and Tatham-Laird & Kudner. **********The two losers are McCann-Erickson, which handled men's apparel and Stern Walters/Earle Ludgin, which did children's apparel and is a subsidiary of Ted Bates/Worldwide. **********All agencies have agency-of-record jobs in certain media categories. McCann has been doing spot broadcast buying for all Searsproducts, whi le Stern Walters did all radio network buying and F.C.& B. all the sp orts programming. A spokesman for the world's largest retailer said that the media-buying assignments were not necessarily going to be a ssigned with the apparel business. **********Sears, according to reports, is beginning to find itself after five years of somnolence. One of its recent changes was to consolidate the three apparel categories in the Merchandise Group and this month put them under Wayne T. Holsinger, who was moved from vice president, women's apparel, to vice president, wearing apparel. **********According to a Chicago adman on an inside track, Sears people ''are nice people to work with, and although they refer to agency people as suppliers, they treat them like marketing partners, just as they like to be treated.'' **********The fact that the only incumbent to get to compete is Foote, Cone & Belding is based on the lucky coincidence that Sears recently made a news-making agreement to sell Levi Strauss & Company jeans, breaking a long tradition of not merchandisin g any brand names but their own - and they do have a number of jean s. Otherwise Foote, Conemight have been dropped because of conflictin g products. It has been doing Levi's advertising since it acquired Ho nig, Cooper & Harrington, San Francisco, Levi's longtime ag ency, in 1970. **********People are fond of calling the Procter & Gamble Company the nation's biggest advertiser, but they should be qualifying it with ''national advertiser.'' Because if you throw in local promotion, Sears moves to the fore. **********With $599.6 million spent for national advertising in 1980, according to Advertising Age, Sears was second to P.& G. with its $649.6 million. But adding in the local stores efforts including newspaper, radio and direct mail, the total came to $707.9 million.  That's to get sales of $16.99 billion. **********The chain itself says it spent $545 million for advertising in 1980 and estimates that 1981 saw it in the range of $575 million to $600 million. **********Sears has gotten the hang of national advertising mighty fast. It only started getting into it in 1961 when it retained Ogilvy for a corporate campaign and later, with Ogilvy, pioneered its kind of store in television advertising. In 1980 it spent more than $100 million in the medium. **********It began working with J. Walter Thompson in 1966, Stern Walters in 1967, Foote, Cone in 1968 and McCann in 1970.  Thompson's long list of assignments include lawn and garden equipment, power tools, and home heating and cooling equipment.  Ogilvy has major appliances and home fashions.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/02/busin.body_text: **********The Lockheed Corporation said yesterday that it lost $360.5 million in the fourth quarter of 1981, mainly because it took a $412 million accounting loss for discontinuing its uprofitable commercial aircraft business. **********The Burbank, Calif., company's deficit for the latest three months contrasts with net earnings of $25.8 million, or $1.68 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1980, which included a loss from discontinued operations of $22.6 million. Sales rose 23.4 percent, to $1.53 billion, from $1.24 billion. **********For all of 1981, Lockheed had a net loss of $288 million, compared with earning s of $27.6 million in 1980. Sales in 1981 rose 16.4 percent, to $5.17 billion, from $4.44 billion . **********Last December, Lockheed announced plans to phase out its deficitridden L-1011 Tristar program, which had incurred losses for more than a decade. Continuing operations include military programs for antisubmarine, transport and reconnaissance aircraft; missiles; space progams; electronics, and shipbuilding. **********''The Tristar program is now being accounted for as a discontinued operation and continuing lines of business are being reported separately along with comparable restated prior-year data,'' said Roy A. Anderson, chairman and chief executive officer. **********''On a continuing operations basis, the $155 million in earnings for 1981 compares to $135 million for 1980,'' Mr. Anderson said.  ''Primary earnings per share from continuing operations were $9.27 for 1981 and $8.87 for 1980.'' **********For the fourth quarter, Lockheed reported that operating earnings rose 6.4 percent, to $51.5 million, or $3.03 a share, compared with $48.4 million, or $3.22 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1980, when there were fewer shares outstanding. United Technologies **********The United Technologies Corporation reported yesterday that net income in the fourth quarter of 1981 dropped 4.9 percent as revenues slipped 1.1 percent. **********The Hartford-based company said that net income in the latest three months fell to $97.5 million, or $1.51 a share, from $102.5 million, or $1.89 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1980. Revenues eased to $3.51 billion, from $3.55 billion. **********Harry M. Gray, chairman and president, attributed the decline in earnings in the latest three months to weakness in airline orders for engines and spare parts and price erosion in the semiconductor industry. **********Analysts said that they were not surprised by the poor showing.  ''Earnings were pretty much as expected,'' said John W. Adams, an analyst at Adams, Harkness & Hill Inc. in Boston.  For the full year, the company said that net income increased 16.3 percent, to $457.7 million, or $7.71 a share, from $393.4 million, or $7.28 a share, in 1980. Revenues rose 11.7 percent, to $13.76 billion, from $12.32 billion. **********United Technologies is a major manufacturer of commercial and military aircraft engines through its Pratt & Whitney Aircraft subsidiary. Other products include Otis elevators and escalators; Carrier air-conditioning, refrigeration and heating equipment; Sikorsky helicopters, and Mostek semiconductors. Allied Corporation **********The Allied Corporation announced that net income in the fourth quarter dropped 28 percent, to $59 million, or $1.29 a share, from $82 million, or $2.27 a share, in the corresponding period in 1980.  Sales increased 17.2 percent, to $1.7 billion, from $1.45 billion. **********Edward L. Hennessy Jr., chairman of Allied, said that although the company's operating income increased in the latest three months, a nonrecurring provision and a foreign-currency exchange loss totaling $43 million after taxes reduced net income. **********Allied said that the chemicals segment of its business had slightly higher operating income in the fourth quarter. Income in fibers and plastics was sharply lower than in the strong fourth quarter of 1980, Allied said, because of the severely depressed automotive and housing markets. **********For the full year, Allied's net income increased 20.4 percent, to $348 million , or $9.17 a share, from $289 million, or $8.15 a share, in 1980. Sale s rose 16.1 percent, $6.41 billion, to $5.52 billion. Schering-Plough **********The Schering-Plough Corporation reported that foreign-exchange losses in the fourth quarter helped cause net income to drop 12.4 percent, to $36.1 million, or 66 cents a share, from $41.2 million, or 76 cents a share. **********Sales remained even at $411.6 million. For the full year, the pharmaceutical company reported that net income fell 24.4 percent, to $179.3 million, or $3.31 a share, from $237.1 million, or $4.41 a share, in 1980. Net income for the year included pretax foreign exchange losses of $21.6 million, compared with $3.9 million in 1980.  ---- Earnings tables, page D13.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/15/busin.body_text: **********The Marine Midland Bank of New York and the Fidelity Bank of Philadelphia reported yesterday that they had placed their loans to Poland in the category of ''nonperforming assets.'' **********The banks, the first in the West to announce such action, thus officially confirmed to their shareholders that Poland was not paying interest as originally scheduled. But the two institutions did not write off their loans, which were well below $100 million, as losses. **********In fact, bankers said, the fact that these loans were put in the ''nonperforming'' category and not listed as losses indicated a belief that the loans would eventually be repaid. Bankers Remain Sanguine **********The accounting steps reflected an attitude that is widespread among American bankers with loans to Poland. Although they have been frustrated in their attempts to collect overdue interest payments, the bankers say the situation does not threaten the basic soundness of the international banking structure or the soundness of any individual bank. **********No bank has officially declared Poland to be in default. But that, bankers say, is a matter of semantics and technicalities. In fact, because it has been so late in interest payments, Poland has defaulted. **********If one of Poland's many creditors were to declare the country officially in default, the legal situation would be changed. But on a practical level, this would probably make very little difference, the bankers say. American banks, for example, still would not be obliged to write off the loans as losses. Major American Creditors **********No American bankers were willing to speak for attribution. But in private conversations, they stressed that commercial bank loans to Poland that were not guaranteed by non-Communist governments amounted to only about $7.5 billion, while another $8.5 billion or so in bank loans were guaranteed by Western governments. This exposure is spread among 460 banks throughout the major industrial countries. Of the $7.5 billion, about $1.2 billion is owed to American banks. Estimates var y, but according to one source, the Bank of America is said to have the greatest exposure among American banks - about $125 million. **********Two other major lenders are said to be Citibank and the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, each of which is reported to have lent Poland about $100 million. Possible Impact on Profits **********If these loans had to be written off, which the banks are confident will not happen, it would hurt current profits but would not have a critical impact on any individual institution, bankers said. **********They asserted that the losses might be comparable to those sustained from the bankruptcy in 1975 of W.T. Grant & Company, to which several banks had lent about $100 million. The Grant losses cut into these banks' profits, but certainly were not devastating. **********According to rough estimates by banking sources, the Polish exposure of other American banks included: Chase Manhattan, $75 million; Morgan Guaranty, $75 million; Chemical Bank, $70 million; First National of Chicago, $65 million; Continental Illinois, $40 million; Bankers Trust, $40 million; Security Pacific, $15 million; First Interstate, $10 million, and Wells Fargo, $10 million. Biggest Creditors Are German **********The biggest creditors to Poland are reported to be West German banks. And although the impact of a Polish default could have a severe impact on some individual institutions, none is thought to be so vulnerable that its solvency would be threatened. **********American banking sources say that a large part of German banks' loans to Poland are guaranteed by the Bonn Government, and that only about $2.5 billion lack government guarantees. The largest nonguaranteed exposure of an individual German bank is estimated to be about $300 million, the American bankers estimate. **********European and American bankers are confident, however, that their Polish loans eventually will be repaid in full.  Unlike a company, a country cannot disappear, they say. Moreover, any country that depends on foreign trade cannot conduct its international business without the cooperation of banks. And, as the bankers warn, no additional loans will be granted to Poland until the interest that w as due in 1981 is fully paid. **********Thus, the banks say, they have powerful leverage over Poland. Total Debt Is Put at $26 Billion **********According to estimates by banking sources, Poland's total foreign debt amounts to about $26 billion. Of that, about $11.5 billion is owed to 17 major Western governments, which agreed last April to postpone repayment of about $2.4 billion of principal. **********Still another $2 billion to $2.5 billion is believed to be owed to the Eastern European countries. And more than $2 billion is said to be owed to nonindustrialized countries such as Brazil, Argentina and Thailand. **********Bankers say that Poland also owes money to some Arab countries, including Libya and Iraq, but these are described as ''political loans.'' **********A major problem in the banks' negotiations with Poland - even before the military crackdown there - is that they are uncertain about exactly how much Poland owes to whom, and when repayments are due. **********The most immediate problem, however, is the payment of about $500 million in interest that was due in 1981. Bankers generally are not particularly worried if a government cannot meet payments of principal: Even the United States Government, the bankers say, has never cleared up its debts, and no one expects it to. **********Interest is a different matter, however. Bankers say it is costly when a borrower does not pay its interest.  Often, government borrowers pay only slightly more than what the banks themselves pay for the money. Thus, banks might be paying 16 percent for their money today, while their borrowers might be paying 16 3/8 percent. If a borrower such as Poland does not pay its interest, the lenders still must pay the 16 percent to support the money that was loaned. Why Poland Is Different **********Bankers also like to feel that a country can meet its obligations, and interest payments are the acid test. Poland has failed that test but, the bankers say, that is not unusual. Each year some countries run into trouble and make headlines, but generally the problem is corrected within a few years. Similar cases include Peru and Turkey, which went through comparable problems a few years ago and which are now up to date in their paymen ts. **********A difference between Poland and most other problem cases, however, is that Poland is not a member of the International Monetary Fund.  The I.M.F. often plays an active role in restructuring a nation's debt and, as a multinational organization, is in a position to demand that certain measures be taken to improve the borrower's economy. Because of the political senstivities involved, it is difficult for individual countries or foreign banks to play this role. **********For this reason, before the imposition of martial law, a move was afoot to bring Poland into the I.M.F. Estimates of the Arrears **********American bankers vary in their estimates of just how far behind Poland is in its interest payments. **********According to one banker, however, Warsaw owed about $350 million in back interest in the October-December quarter to banks around the world. This amount has been reduced to about $250 million, this banker said. Another $150 million or so is said to be owed to other creditors. **********Last year, before martial law, Poland had agreed to pay $500 million in interest due in 1981 as one of the conditions for postponement in payments of principal. **********There have been reports that some banks might offically declare that Poland has defaulted on its loans, and that such an action would trigger automatic default clauses in most of its other loans.  But in real terms, such an event would be insignificant because most banks, especially those with the large loans outstanding, would be unlikely to take any actions beyond those already taken, the bankers say. Default Adds to Banks' Power **********An official default would give the creditors additional powers, but these are considered so drastic, and probably so costly to exercise, that at this time most major bankers say such moves are unthinkable. **********Technically, once a default is declared, a bank can seize any of the borrower's deposits that it holds. That was the case with Iran in 1979, when that country was declared to be in default after the seizure of American hostages. **********Iran, however, had huge deposits in American banks, far greater than the amount it owed, and these deposits were seized immediately.  But Poland's deposits in American banks are said to be less than $30 million. Possible Seizures of Goo ds **********An official default would also allow creditors to seek court permission around the world to seize Polish goods; the country still exports about $500 million a month to Western countries. **********But such action is considered so extreme that it is not used unless the countries involved are close to a state of war. Aside from Iran, banks took such action against Cuba when Fidel Castro declared that Cuba would not pay its foreign debts. American bankers say that since then, Cuba has had to rely almost exclusively on the Soviet Union for loans to finance trade. **********The bankers add that as long as there seems to be any hope that Poland will repay its debts, they will avoid declaring or acting on a formal default. ''That is why Poland has been making token interest payments all along,'' one New York banker said. ---- Creditor Nations Meet **********PARIS, Jan. 14 (Reuter) - Government officials from the nations to which Poland owes the most met here today to discuss the weak Polish economy, diplomatic sources said. **********But because of the decision by members of NATO to freeze negotiations on official debts, the question of deferring repayments was not discussed. A French Treasury spokesman said the talks were technical and that a communique probably would not be issued. **********The meeting, first planned before martial law was imposed in Poland, had been expected to discuss how repayment of the $2.4 billion due this year might be spread out. **********But, the sources said, France had sounded out the creditor nations and had gone ahead with the meeting at a reduced level, in preference to canceling it altogether. Polish Loss Reserve **********MONTREAL, Jan. 14 (Reuter) -The Royal Bank of Canada has set up a loan-loss reserve for its Polish loans, its chairman and chief executive offi-cer, Rowland C. Frazee, told the an-nual shareholders meeting today. **********He did not say how large either the reserves or the loans were. He said that, ''even with the worst possible scenario fo r Poland, the impact on the bank would be modest compared with past situations.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/29/busin.body_text: **********On the edge of the cluttered British Leyland auto-making complex, where Herbert Austin began one of Britain's first car companies in 1905, a sleek new building now houses one of the world's most modern body plants. **********In a bright and airy space the size of 10 soccer fields, huge automated body-framing lines and 28 dexterous robots help fashion 800 gray steel bodies a day. **********The plant, called the West Works, symbolizes the new BL P.L.C., as Britain's last major home-owned auto manufacturer is now called. From big losses and near-anarchy on the shop floor, the company has substantially improved both its financial performance and its productivity. But at the same time, its size has been sharply reduced and it has lost a share of the market in Britain. **********''Over all, the picture is of a sustained reduction of losses in spite of a slight drop in unit sales and virtually static sales revenue,'' said Frank Fitzpatrick, director of finance, in announcing midyear results recently. ''This improvement has been achieved primarily by reducing costs and increasing efficiency.'' Loss Is Reduced **********On the financial side, the company cut its loss to $189.1 million in the first six months of 1982, from $331 million in the similar period a year earlier. At the same time the company, which has received about $4.3 billion in Government support over the past five years, said that less state assistance would be required next year than had been forecast. **********Perhaps the most dramatic improvement at BL has been in productivity and labor relations. In 1978, the company counted 584 stoppages of an hour or more that together totaled 5 percent of all working time. In 1981, only five-tenths of 1 percent of work time was lost. **********Similarly, both productivity and quality have gained. Here at Longbridge, the number of cars built per worker rose from fewer than 8 in 1980 to nearly 17 just a year later, and the number of ''quality demerits'' has dropped sharply. The large new investment has played a key role, but the bulk of the improvement has resulted from better management. **********But as with many British companies, the news from BL these days is both good and bad. The slight rise in production this year followed a major contraction in the size of the company, from a peak output of 1,161,000 vehicles in 1973, to 525,000 last year. Market Share Is Down **********Perhaps even more significant, the company's share of its home market has dropped, to 16.2 percent last month, from 18 percent earlier this year and 24.3 percent in 1977. **********So small a producer has BL become that there have been suggestions that the company can no longer support the engineering and marketing arms that a large auto manufacturer needs. BL is now making a Triumph Acclaim under license from Honda and plans to develop a car jointly with Honda. **********Although BL has had big success with a new small car called the Metro, the company's product line has been virtually devoid of cars in the more lucrative middle sizes. Of the cars BL is developing in those sizes, the ''LM10'' will not begin production until early next year and the larger ''LM11'' is still further behind. **********And the company, which is 99.6 percent owned by the Government, continues to lose money at a time when car prices in Britain are as much as twice those on the Continent. Much of the reason, BL contends, is the high price of British components, which still account for 70 percent of the value of a BL car. Changes at the Top **********BL also faces a number of other uncertainties, particularly the effects of the departure of Sir Michael Edwardes last month after five years as chairman. He will be succeeded by Sir Austin Bide. **********It was Sir Michael who pared the company's work force from 195,000 at the end of 1977 to 108,000. In part, the reduction was achieved by closing 10 assembly plants and a number of smaller facilities. BL now has just two car manufacturing centers, the one here and another near Oxford. **********But within this 375-acre complex, car production has been increased by 1,000 a week, to 5,750, while the work force has been reduced from more than 18,000 workers, when Sir Michael arrived, to 9,866.  (Despite the high unemployment in Britain, the cut was achieved by voluntary departures.) **********Perhaps more important, Sir Michael developed a labor relations strategy to appeal to the rank-and-file over the heads of the more militant shop stewards, who once virtually ran the plant. In November 1979, Derek Robinson, a shop steward, was dismissed and to the surprise of many, the Longbridge work force refused to strike over it. **********Two years later, Sir Michael again went over the stewards' heads and won agreement from the workers on a 3.8 percent pay raise, at a time when inflation in Britain was 12 percent. Efficiency Bonuses **********In the course of the test of wills, all manning restrictions in the plant vanished and the sharp increase in productivity that resulted has led to efficiency bonuses so large that workers' pay has gone up by more than the rate of inflation in the past year. **********''There's extra money there for working harder,'' said Colin Taylor, a production foreman who has been with the company for 25 years. ''Now the men are willing to give anything a try.'' **********But BL has not entirely solved its labor problems. The company still builds fewer cars per worker than most of its European competitors. **********And with the signs of improving finances, there are indications that the labor force has become restive. The shop stewards have rejected a company proposal for a two-year contract, and have demanded a 20 percent pay increase next year. **********''Changes were necessary but there were other ways of making them,'' said Brian Mathers, Midlands secretary of the Transport and General Workers Union. ''The Michael Edwardes style may be the way to quick, short-term results, but the price will have to be paid in the future.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/19/world.main_headline: ISRAELIS CONCEDE AND DEFEND USE OF CLUSTER BOMB
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/19/world.print_headline: ISRAELIS CONCEDE AND DEFEND USE OF CLUSTER BOMB
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/19/world.body_text: **********Israel has officially acknowledged to the United States that it used cluster bomb weapons in its invasion of Lebanon, but has asserted that its actions were consistent with Israeli-American agreements on the use of those weapons, according to Israeli sources here familiar with the message. **********The Israeli note was delivered Friday night, and White House and State Department officials said this afternoon that it was still being reviewed. **********They said ''no final decision'' had been made on whether to go ahead with a planned delivery to Israel on Monday of 4,000 rounds of cluster munitions designed for use in 155-millimeter howitzers. **********Some Administration officials said, however, that they anticipated at least a delay since they doubted that the review would be concluded by Monday. **********Pellets Disperse Over Area **********Cluster bombs are known technically as cluster bomb units. They are generally either dropped from aircraft or fired by artillery. In both cases, they consist of a canister of explosive pellets that are dispersed over a large area when the canister opens. **********The Israeli note did not specify whether the weapons were dropped from aircraft or fired by artillery. Most reports from Israel and Lebanon have described them as having been dropped from airplanes. **********President Reagan, who returned to the White House this afternoon, declined to comment on the Israeli note. Speaking briefly to reporters after getting out of the helicopter that brought him from Camp David, Mr. Reagan said the Israeli response to American requests for information ''had just come in'' and was ''under study.'' **********The President also said the Administration was undertaking a thorough review of all aspects of its Middle East policy, including arms shipments to the region. On Saturday, in his first full day in office, Secretary of State George P. Shultz spent considerable time with the Israeli and Egyptian Ambassadors separately, and with former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger and other experts on the Middle East from within the Government. **********Some officials have said that as a result of this review, Mr.  Kissinger, who has had extensive negotiating experience in the Middle East, or some other prominent American, might be sent on a mission to the region. But they said no decisions had been made. 'George Asked Them to Come In' **********Mr. Reagan also said no decisions had been made. ''George asked them to come in and have a meeting and get their thoughts on what's going on,'' he said. **********According to those familiar with the Israeli note, the Israelis said that their agreement on cluster bombs with the United States placed two major conditions on the use of the weapons and that Israel met both criteria. The first was that they be used against organized Arab armies; the second, that they be directed against clearly defined military targets. **********The text of the 1976 agreement has never been made public. But American officials in the past have said the agreement, which was reaffirmed in 1978 by Israel after it was accused of violating the accord in an incursion into Lebanon, did limit the use of the weapons to Arab armies in conditions similar to those of the 1967 and 1973 wars. **********The Israeli message reportedly took note of the large quantity and sophisticated quality of the arms in the hands of the Syrian Army and the Palestine Liberation Organization forces in Lebanon that Israel fought during the invasion that began June 6. The Israelis argued that this met the standard for use against organized armies. **********(United Press International quoted the Israeli radio as citing Syria's role in the conflict and as saying, ''In these conditions, it had been permissible for Israel to use the cluster bombs.'') **********In their note, the Israelis reportedly said the cluster bombs had been directed against ground-to-air antiaircraft missiles and against antiaircraft and artillery guns. This met the condition that they be used against clearly defined military targets, they said. No Official Confirmation **********But the Israeli note said many of the military targets were situated in the midst of built-up civilian areas, and that if the weapons had fallen on populated areas, this was unintentional, the sources said. **********State Department officials, when asked about this account of the Israeli note, would not confirm it, but said it was consistent with what Israel has said publicly on the matter. **********Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, a long-time supporter of Israel, said today that ''technically there's been violations'' by Israel in its use of American-made cluster bombs. But he did not go into details when asked about the matter on the CBS News program ''Face the Nation.'' **********He added that as a result of the invasion of Lebanon there had been ''substantial erosion of support for Israel'' but that this was balanced by ''great admiration on the part of frustrated American citizens for the fact that when they seek to do something, they know how to do it and get it done.'' **********Mr. Jackson was critical of the Israelis for failing to consult the United States about their military actions. 'We Have to Consult' **********''If we're going to be allies, we have to consult,'' he said. If such behavior continues, Israel will lose its support in this country, he said. His view on Israel's loss of support was similar to that voiced a week ago by Senator Charles H. Percy, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, who said relations between the United States and Israel were now at an all-time low. **********Senator Alan Cranston, Democrat of California, who is also a strong supporter of Israel, said on the NBC News program ''Meet the Press'' that he would censure Israel if it turned out that the Israelis had used cluster bombs, jeopardizing civilian lives, in violation of the agreement with the United States.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/14/busin.body_text: **********OPEC's Last Waltz? **********Times have never been worse for OPEC. Oil prices keep slipping, economists keep pushing back estimates of the strength and timing of recovery in major consuming nations, and the cartel's own revenues are falling sharply. So the OPEC gathering in Vienna this week is likely to be a critical and cantankerous one. **********Much of action may take place before Friday, when the session formally begins, says Philip Verleger, an oil analyst with Booz Allen Hamilton. In order to defuse bickering about future production levels, Saudi Arabia, which has cut ouput by roughly 3 million barrels a day in the last 12 months, to 7.5 million, may announce more cuts as well as a price drop of around $2 a barrel. However, those steps may not be enough, Mr. Verleger says. **********In order to recapture control of the oil markets for the cartel, Mr. Verleger says, the Saudis would have to cut production another 2 million barrels from current levels, and keep output at that pace for at least six months. Such a sacrifice is unlikely, Mr. Verleger says. Financing the kingdom's development plan requires a production level of around 6.5 million barrels a day, and the Saudis may not be willing to drop below that level. Plunging Profits **********High interest rates and sporadic economic growth have not done much to help corporate income statements. Corporate profits in 1980, after tax, declined nearly 3 percent from year-earlier levels.  Analysts expect that when the Commerce Department announces 1981 results this week, it will be another drop. And, as the recession lingers, the outlook for 1982 is not reassuring. **********As a percentage of national income, corporate profitability in the fourth quarter may have hit a new post-war low, says Gary Wenglowski, chief economist at Goldman Sachs & Company. That would mean sliding below the results of during the 1974-1975 recession, when profits were only 7.5 percent of national income. For the year, Mr.  Wenglowski says, after-tax profits fell more than 5 percent from 1980 levels, to $154 billion. Mr. Wenglowski estimates the sagging economy could cut profits another 8 percent in the first quarter. After that, an improvement of sorts is likely, he says. At annual rates, fourthquarter earnings should be up 16 percent compared to the first quarter. In spite of the rebound, corporate profits for the year are likely to average $142 billion, down 8 percent from 1981 levels. A Silent Spring for Autos **********Spring is usually synonymous with rising car sales. However, as the auto industry enters what normally is its busiest season, analysts see little reason to expect domestic sales, which ran at a 6 millionunit annual rate last month, to show much if any increase. **********Moderating inflation and stabilizing prices have watered down the attraction of rebates, says Paine Webber auto specialist Maryann Keller. Moreover, while manufacturers have not raised sticker prices since last September, they remain stuck at very high levels. Unless auto finance companies or banks are willing to extend loan pay-back periods even further - a notion Mrs. Keller dismisses as impractical - even a sharp cut in interest rates would do little to enliven sales. **********Conditions may improve marginally during the second half of the year, Mrs. Keller says, when the stimulus of the 10 percent tax cut in July boosts pay checks - but only to an annual sales rate of 7 million units. The Appeal of Apparel **********If the debut of spring means little for Detroit, it could be good for Seventh Avenue. Although men generally curb spending on clothes during economic downturns, women's apparel makes up about two-thirds total sales. And, with a new line of low-priced spring fashions on the racks, analysts are rather sanguine about the garment trade's fortunes. **********For the twelve months ending in January, retail clothing prices rose only 3.4 percent. Consumers responded by spending an inflationadjusted $83.7 billion on clothes last year, up more than 7 percent from 1980 levels. **********While increases in disposable income may not be enough to boost sales of big ticket items like autos, clothes remain affordable even during a prolonged economic downturn, says Elizabeth Allison, an economist at Data Resources. As a result, apparel sales should rise another 1 percent this year in real terms, she says, and possibly 3 percent, if the new, shorter skirts catch on. **********Kenneth N. Gilpin

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/29/world.print_headline: POLAND FREES 800 AND EASES CURBS; CURFEW IS LIFTED
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/29/world.body_text: **********The Polish Government announced tonight that it had ordered the release of 800 internees and that a number of martial law restrictions, including the nationwide curfew from 11 P.M. to 6 A.M., would be lifted beginning Sunday. **********The announcement on the evening television news broadcast said the decision to ease the restrictions was made earlier in the day by the Military Council of National Salvation because of ''further progress in normalization of public life.'' **********At the same time, the ruling 21-member military body warned that the authorities would deal roughly with agitators and stood ready to ''reimpose the rigors of martial law should excesses and social unrest'' develop. Farm Union Leader on TV **********In a separate development, Jan Kulaj, the 24-year-old head of the suspended private farmers' union known as Rural Solidarity, appeared on television and indicated a willingness to work with the Communistcontrolled United Peasants' Party. A narrator said Mr. Kulaj had recently been released from detention. **********(In Rome, it was disclosed that the planned August visit by Pope John Paul II to Poland had been postponed indefinitely. The announcement came from Poland's Primate, Archbishop Jozef Glemp, who told reporters that he doubted that the Pope would even go to Poland next year ''unless the situation calms down.'') **********The series of measures easing the curtailment on personal liberties was the most sweeping since the military took power on Dec. 13, suspending the independent union Solidarity and halting Poland's liberalization. **********There was speculation among some Poles that the move, which had been expected in view of the general calm in the country, might also be designed to take the steam out of protests proposed for Saturday, May Day. Various underground groups have talked of staging marches in Warsaw as an alternative to the official parade celebrating the Communist workers' day. **********In addition to the 800 detainees who are to be released, 200 others will be granted ''conditional leave'' from internment, according to the Polish press agency. That is apparently a sort of probation. **********None of the detainees to be let go were identified, and so it was not known if any of Solidarity's top leaders or advisers were among them. But this appeared unlikely, since the official press has been attacking many of them and Government officials have indicated privately that most of them were resolute in their support of the suspended union. **********Nor did it appear likely that Lech Walesa, Solidarity's chairman and the hero of the workers' revolt that was born in the Gdansk shipyard in the summer of 1980, would be freed from a villa in a military complex outside Warsaw. **********After the release of the 1,000 announced today, slightly more than 2,000 will remain in the 25 detention centers and prisons around the country. Altogether, about 6,800 people were interned without charge in the first three months of martial law, according to official figures. **********Not affected will be well over 200 people who were arrested on political charges after the imposition of martial law and are serving prison sentences ranging from 2 to 10 years. **********The Polish press agency said that conduct during internment had been a factor in deciding whom to release. Those let out, it said, had shown by their behavior that their ''future conduct will be in accord with the binding legal order in the country and that they will pose no threat to social peace and state security.'' Warning by Interior Ministry **********People who are released can be rein@terned if they do not take up ''a normal life,'' a communique from the Interior Ministry warned.  As if to emphasize the threat, it disclosed that 20 people released earlier had been arrested or re-interned for illegal activities and would face penal proceedings. **********The communique also stated that ''summary justice,'' the speedy prosecution of martial law violators before military courts with no right of appeal from the defense, would be maintained. **********Mr. Kulaj, the leader of Rural Solidarity, which claimed a membership of two million of the country's three million private farmers and peasants, was taken into custody in the early hours of Dec. 13 while traveling in a car outside Gdansk. For weeks his whereabouts were unknown and his family was unable to locate or visit him. **********Mr. Kulaj, who was held in isolation in a villa outside Warsaw, is the most important figure to be released so far. He was shown on television wearing a dark suit while attending a meeting with Deputy Prime Minister Roman Malinowski, who is also chairman of the central committee of the United Peasants' Party. Need for 'Honest Work' Seen **********Interviewed by a television reporter afterward, he said that he agreed on almost all points with the Deputy Prime Minister and that the current situation called for ''honest work from the bottom'' to lift Poland out of its food crisis. **********''We discussed the possibility of my participation in the work of the United Peasants' Party,'' he said. ''For me, it's a great satisfaction.'' **********Rural Solidarity was formed partly in response to complaints from farmers that the Peasants' Party, one of the three in the Communistdominated National Unity Front, did not adequately represent their interests. The union was legally registered in May of last year, and activists had been planning to converge on Warsaw next month in an unathorized demonstration to mark the anniversary. **********In addition to lifting of the curfew, other measures included an easing of travel restrictions in certain border areas, abolition of permits required for certain specified meetings and conferences, a relaxation on the issuing of entry visas and the restoration of automatic telephone dialiing within the country, beginning May 10. As of May 15, ''certain restrictions'' on accredited foreign correspondents will be lifted, an apparent allusion to travel limitations, ---- Pope's Visit Is Postponed **********ROME, April 28 (AP) - Pope John Paul II's plans to visit Poland in August have been postponed indefinitely, three years after his return home fanned nationalist and religious fervor, Poland's Roman Catholic Primate said today. **********''I believe the Pope's trip must be postponed for a little while,'' the Primate, Archbishop Jozef Glemp, said in an unusual session with reporters in St. Peter's Square. Despite Archbishop Glemp's cautious remarks, Polish sources at the Vatican said the Primate clearly meant the visit was off. **********Just a few weeks before the Dec. 13 martial law crackdown on the Solidarity labor movement, John Paul had accepted an invitation from the Communist Government and Polish bishops to make the trip. **********Asked if the Pope would visit Poland next year, the Archbishop replied, ''No, unless the situation calms down.'' The Archbishop arrived in Rome on Monday to coordinate church strategy under military rule in Poland.

Any taxes withheld would reduce the quarterly estimated tax payments. BENJAMIN GRUND New York, Aug. 3, 1982

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/08/world.body_text: **********Guerrilla snipers firing from roofs today pinned down government garrisons in the provincial capital of Usulutan, one of the most fought-over cities of El Salvador's civil war. **********A national guard officer in Usulutan said squads of rebel sharpshooters infiltrated the city and opened fire on four local garrisons from nearby roofs after cutting power lines. **********''We are inside our garrison and the people are inside their homes,'' he said, adding that ''heavy gunfire'' had been echoing through the city of 60,000 all night and well into the morning. **********The only injury reported in the city, about 75 miles southeast of San Salvador, was a woman shot in the foot, he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/22/world.body_text: **********Somali forces repulsed an attack by several hundred Ethiopian troops Friday in renewed fighting along the border between the two countries, a Defense Ministry spokesman said today. **********In the fighting in the Balambale region of Galgadudh Province, the Ethiopian forces were backed by tanks and artillery, the spokesman said.
