https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/13/busin.body_text: **********The tiny Blue Ridge Savings and Loan Association in rural western Virginia was given conditional approval today to become a bank, permitting it to replace its stagnant mortgage loan business with more lucrative commercial and consumer loan services. **********The Virginia State Corporation Commission authorized the conversion in Floyd, Va., beginning Oct. 1, provided the fiveemployee, one-office institution with its $6.8 million in deposits and $674,450 net worth meets certain requirements. **********The conversion, the first of its type in the state, was not opposed by the Bank of Floyd, the only other lender in sparsely populated Floyd County, with $45.3 million in deposits. **********Floyd County, in the western Virginia coal country, has 11,563 residents.  The conversion would enable Blue Ridge Savings and Loan to make commercial loans and provide other services reserved for banks. Blue Ridge, which opened in 1978, would also have to give up paying customers slightly higher interest on savings. **********Savings and loans are authorized under Federal law to pay 5.5 percent interest on passbook accounts compared with 5.25 percent for commercial banks. Blue Ridge has $5.8 million in outstanding mortgages.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/19/world.main_headline: 60 POLES SAID TO BE BEATEN IN PRISON BY RIOT POLICE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/19/world.print_headline: 60 POLES SAID TO BE BEATEN IN PRISON BY RIOT POLICE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/19/world.body_text: **********Some 60 inmates were beaten - six severely enough to require hospitalization -when the police were called in to quell disorders at a detention center in northern Poland four days ago, reliable sources said today. **********The sources, from the Solidarity union and the Roman Catholic Church, said the assault by the special riot police appeared to be the single most violent action directed against internees since martial law was imposed Dec. 13. **********The incident occurred at Kwidzyn, 60 miles south of Gdansk. The detention center there is one of seven now holding more than 600 internees, including almost all of the union leaders. **********The sources said the police had been called in to put down a disturbance that erupted after prison authorities turned back families who had come for a Saturday visit. Mingled Freely in the Past **********On the previous Saturday, they said, the families were allowed in altogether and mingled freely with the inmates. One detainee escaped simply by walking out with the relatives at the end of visiting hours. Since then, the sources said, the prison commander had been replaced and a stricter regimen enforced. **********Last Saturday, when family members were refused admittance, the inmates rebelled. Some managed to leave their cells and reached the roof of the center. **********In addition to the police, firemen were ordered to join in the assault by driving water cannons but they refused, the sources said.  The water cannons were then driven by the police. **********At one point, a blast of water struck an inmate on the roof, toppling him over the side. He was reportedly hospitalized with damage to his spinal column. Others were beaten with truncheons before order was restored, the sources said. No Recent Reports of Beatings **********Although there were several reports of beatings of internees in the early months of martial law, such incidents seemed to have fallen off. The authorities are taking pains to try to depict the conditions of detainees as humane. **********The exact number still in detention is uncertain. The Government says 637 remain. But Western diplomats put the figure much higher. In addition, there are perhaps as many as 3,000 people who have been arrested and sentenced to prison terms for martial law violations. **********Meanwhile, a note of tension began creeping back into public pronouncements as the authorities braced for demonstrations on Aug.  31, the second anniversary of the Gdansk agreement that esatblished Solidarity. **********The Polish press agency today mentioned recent disturbances in Gorzow Wielkopolski, near Poznan, where two Solidarity activists were said to have been detained Monday for shouting slogans at a crowd leaving a church. There were more serious incidents in four cities on Friday, including Gdansk, where demonstrators trying to march on the local party headquarters were beaten back by volleys of tear gas and sprays from water cannons. Nightly Gathering at Floral Cross **********In Warsaw, crowds have gathered nightly around a floral cross laid out on paving stones in Victory Square. The cross, originally laid to commemorate the late Primate, Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, has become a symbol of opposition to military rule, and on several occasions the police have charged the crowd and swept the flowers away. The cross has been reconstituted within hours. **********On Tuesday the police moved in to disperse a crowd of 80 people who assembled at the nearby Hotel Victoria and heckled Polish officials who were leaving a diplomatic function. Leaflets were distributed calling for a rally at four staging areas on Aug. 31. **********In an apparent attempt to defuse the cat-and-mouse confrontations around the cross, the Government announced that permission had been granted for a permanent monument to honor Cardinal Wyszynski one block from Victory Square, near the Church of the Nuns of the Visitation on Krakowskie Przedmiescie Street.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/16/busin.main_headline: A Heinz Man Is Named President of Star-Kist
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/16/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; A Heinz Man Is Named President of Star-Kist
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/16/busin.body_text: **********Richard L. Beattie has been named president of Star-Kist Foods, the H.J. Heinz Company's largest subsidiary, and will be the first Heinztrained man to head the unit since it was acquired in 1963. **********Mr. Beattie, 47, is currently managing director of H.J. Heinz in Britain. **********On Jan. 31, he will succeed John J. Real, 65, who is retirting. One of the leaders of the tuna industry, Mr. Real has been with Star-Kist for 27 years. **********Star-Kist is the largest worldwide tuna processor in terms of volume. When the company was acquired, Heinz kept the management that had built Star-Kist into a leading position after World War II. The company has been run by Joseph J. Bogdanovich, the son of the founder; Mr. Real, and Jerry Scharer, now retired. Mr. Bogdanovich is Star-Kist's chairman and is also a senior vice president and director of the parent Heinz. **********The incoming president, Mr. Beattie, was one of the few Americans to head the British Heinz operation, which is a subsidiary of the American company. He will be replaced by a Briton, John F. Hinch, 49. **********Mr. Beattie joined Heinz in 1972 as general manager for operations planning and control. He became vice president for tomato products and condiments and then joined the Hubinger Company, a Heinz subsidiary, as president and chief executive. He moved to London in June 1981. **********Mr. Beattie holds a degree in industrial management from Carnegie-Mellon University and a master's degree in administration from Duquesne University.  Daniel F. Cuff

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/27/busin.main_headline: POSNER INDICTED BY U.S. IN FLORIDA TAX FRAUD
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/27/busin.print_headline: POSNER INDICTED BY U.S. IN FLORIDA TAX FRAUD
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/04/27/busin.body_text: **********Victor Posner, a 63-year-old financier with controlling interests in several enterprises, including the Sharon Steel Corporation, was indicted in New York yesterday on charges that he had evaded $1.25 million in Federal income taxes by inflating the value of land that he had donated to a college. **********The 12-count Federal indictment charges Mr. Posner with conspiracy, tax evasion and the filing of false tax returns for the years 1975 through 1979. He could face up to five years in prison on each of several counts if convicted. **********Mr. Posner, a Miami Beach resident who is often in the news for his efforts to acquire other companies, owns assets with a reported worth of $1 billion. He is chairman and chief executive officer of Sharon Steel, a major domestic producer of specialty steels with annual sales of about $800 million. **********Sharon, in turn, is a subsidiary of the NVF Company, a Delawarebased producer of plastics and speciality papers. Mr. Posner is also chairman and chief executive of NVF. **********In a statement denying the charges, Mr. Posner said, ''I am shocked that the Government would single me out for prosecution because of a disagreement over the value of land that I gave to a charitable cause in 1975. **********''I will vigorously defend myself against this false accusation,'' the statement said, ''and I am totally confident that when the facts are presented to a jury that I will be completely exonerated.'' **********His defense in the tax-evasion case is being handled by the Washington law firm headed by Edward Bennett Williams and by Stuart E. Seigel, a member of the Williams firm. Miami Broker Also Indicted **********The charges center on the worth of 22 acres of land that Mr.  Posner donated to Miami Christian College in 1975. William Scharrer, a Miami real estate broker who was named in four of the counts, was accused of providing Mr. Posner with inflated appraisals of the land's value. **********Efforts to reach Mr. Scharrer for comment at his office and home last evening were unsuccessful.  Kenneth V. Handal, the prosecutor in the case, said both defendants would be arraigned on May 6 in Federal District Court in Manhattan.  The indictment was filed in Manhattan, where Mr. Posner's tax returns had been prepared. **********Mr. Handal said Miami Christian College was not accused of any wrongdoing in the case.  According to the indictment, the land was worth a maximum of $1 million when it was donated to the college. Despite this, Mr. Posner used appraisals placing its value at $3 million and claimed charitable deductions based on the higher figure. **********In 1967, the indictment said, Mr. Posner paid $2,500 an acre for ''approximately 37 acres of unimproved land at S.W. 117th Avenue and 104th Street in Miami. He subsequently sold the land to a realty company for $38,000 an acre in 1974, it said, but the sale was canceled because ''it was not economically feasible to develop the property.'' Kept 15-Acre Parcel **********Mr. Posner then donated 16 acres to the college in 1975 and six acres in 1978, the indictment said. It added that he kept a 15-acre parcel that was considered to be the most valuable part of the tract. **********The first donation placed a value of $2 million on 16 acres, or about $125,000 an acre, when the defendants knew the fair market value was no more than $40,000 an acre, the indictment continued. It said the second donation valued six acres in excess of $1 million, or about $175,000 an acre, when the real value was no more than $60,000 an acre. **********The indictment said the Government's evaluations were based on an assessment of what the land would have sold for on the open market at the time of the donations. **********Mr. Posner used the inflated figures to take charitable deductions on his tax returns for 1975 through 1979, the indictment said, accusing him of evading $1.25 million in taxes. It disclosed that he had reported a taxable income of about $2 million a year for those years. **********In 1977, the indictment said, Mr. Posner was informed by Mr.  Scharrer that the college intended to sell the initital 16-acre donation for $33,000 an acre. It added that Mr. Posner sued the college to prevent the sale and settled when the college agreed not to sell the land before November 1982 without his permission. **********Mr. Posner, who began his career working in food stores that his father owned in Baltimore, built a fortune in real estate and then expanded into the acquisition of varied companies. His takeover activities resulted in some lawsuits. **********The Securities and Exchange Commission accused him in 1977 of having charged $1.7 million of family expenses to his companies, but he settled the suit by making a $600,000 repayment without admitting any wrongdoing. He later made a second payment of $700,000. ---- 'Never Been Wrong' **********Though shy of publicity, Victor Posner has been been somewhat less modest about discussing his reputation as one of the most successful stock pickers in the business. ''I've never been wrong,'' he remarked about a year ago. ''I have a 100 percent success record.'' **********In a long, highly publicized fight with Foremost-McKesson, for example, he was never able to convince the food, drug and liquor company that he was not bent on takeover. But even in defeat, Mr.  Posner last year sold a $30 million stake in the company, built over several years, for $65 million. **********Last April, he sold stock in the Bundy Corporation back to Bundy for some $400,000 more than it cost him. And recently, a British buyer took a big block of the Simplicity Pattern Company from Mr.  Posner for a pretax profit to him of $8 million -after exacting a promise from him not to buy any more Simplicity stock for 10 years. **********''We have positions in 40 or 50 companies,'' he said in a rare interview a year ago, ''and there's never a day we don't purchase more.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/27/busin.body_text: **********As a result of the seven deaths from cyanide-contaminated Tylenol capsules in September, the nation's largest food manufacturers have become just as concerned about the possibility of tampering as their counterparts in the pharmaceutical industry. Many are so worried that they would not even discuss the problem. **********Although most of the tampering incidents of the past few months have involved drugs, such as Anacin, Dristan and Excedrin in addition to Tylenol, many food manufacturers are concerned that their products could be as easy to contaminate as over-the-counter drugs. **********In addition, they are worried that the drug tamperings could serve as legal notice that such problems are foreseeable and that further safety measures should be taken. 'No Simple Answer' **********''As soon as the Tylenol thing broke, we all began saying to one another, 'What if it happened to us?' and it was a question we couldn't shuck off,'' said Craig Shulstad, director of consumer and public affairs at General Mills Inc. ''Almost everybody in the food industry is reviewing not only their packaging but their product recall procedures. We're all wrestling with the question of where our liability as manufacturers begins - and there's no simple answer.'' **********On Nov. 5, the Food and Drug Administration issued rules requiring tamper-resistant packaging for over-the-counter drugs. Even though the rules do not apply to groceries, most food manufacturers are exploring ways to make their products less vulnerable to tampering. **********General Mills, for example, is reviewing its consumer product packaging to determine the vulnerability of its 200 grocery products.  Borden has also set up a committee on consumer product packaging, but, like most of those interviewed at a number of companies, Borden officials were nervous about discussing the specific changes being considered. Feeling Vulnerable **********''We've made tamper-resistance a major criterion in new product development, and we're going through all of our existing packaging to see how much it shows off tampering,'' said James McCrory, the corporate director of public affairs at Borden. **********''Some upgrading of the packaging may already have taken place,'' he continued, ''but I would not feel comfortable discussing that.  Actually, we are desperately worried about the Borden's name being used in any discussion, because all the nuts are watching, and you don't want to give anyone any ideas. I think we're all feeling very vulnerable, whether it's food or drugs. There's a kind of paranoia that has set in.'' **********Recently, William E. LaMothe, the chairman and chief executive of Kellogg, told the Food and Drug Law Institute, ''I can assure you that virtually everyone in the industry is looking for ways to give the consumer a higher confidence level that the product purchased has not been tampered with.'' **********But Mr. LaMothe, like most others in the food industry, is hoping to avert Federal rules to mandate tamper-resistant containers for all edibles. ''The cost would put many products out of the reach of consumers,'' he said. ''And what do we do with farm produce, fruit, vegetables, bread, cheese and milk?'' **********About 100 representatives from the food industry gathered in Washington on Dec. 16 to discuss these concerns at a ''Product Contamination Workshop'' sponsored by the Grocery Manufacturers Association. Radical Changes Doubted **********''There was certainly a consensus that a problem existed,'' said Mr. Shulstad of General Mills, one of the participants. ''I think you'll see the food industry changing its packaging where it's feasible to do so, but I don't think there will be radical changes.  The longstanding criticism of the industry has been that there's too much money spent on packaging, and with the economy where it is, no one's interested in seeing prices go up. At the conference, it became clear to us that we're not as vulnerable as some other companies, like those producing fresh baked goods just wrapped in cellophane.'' **********One of the people faced with that problem is Paul Khan, the vice president for quality and food protection at the ITT Continental Baking Company. According to Mr. Khan, the tamper-proof seals and closures that might be useful for pharmaceuticals or foods packed in impermeable plastic or glass jars would be useless for baked goods. **********''It's a lot easier to protect against bacteria, insects and rodents than it is against people,'' said Mr. Khan, who estimated that the number of food-tampering incidents around Halloween was triple that of previous years. ''If you're dealing with cookies or bread - or bananas and apples - people can stick something right through them, or inject it. In 99 percent of the cases, that's what happens. I can't visualize a practical, economic solution to that problem. Punishing people for such acts, and publicizing those punishments, is the only solution I can think of. I don't think every apple should come in a metal case.'' **********The Food and Drug Administration, which developed the new rules on tamper-resistant packaging, concedes that from the tamperers' point of view, there is no difference between mouthwash or laxatives, for which new packaging will be required, and milk or orange juice, for which it will not. But, said Chris Smith, an F.D.A. spokesman, ''We don't think the danger is there as much in food.'' **********''People look more closely at their food,'' he said. ''They know what it should look like and smell like and taste like. Anyway, tamper-resistant packaging regulations for food are considered impossible in the time frame required for drugs. There are about two billion over-the-counter drug packages sold annually, compared with 338 billion food packages.'' What Cost for Safety? **********The question of whether tamper-resistant packaging should be more widely required ultimately comes down to one of costs: How much is safety worth? **********''I'm not sure people want to pay an extra two cents, or 10 cents, for every milk carton to be sealed differently,'' said Sheila Birnbaum, a products liability lawyer who teaches at New York University law school. ''We've already gone through this in airports, and there was a lot of discussion about whether the hijacking threat was so serious that we needed all the expense and bother of metal detectors. Now we've all paid for the metal detectors, we all feel a little safer, and maybe we're headed in the direction of spending more and more money to guard against the maniacs among us. But it's mighty expensive.'' **********For manufacturers, there are also legal considerations in deciding whether their packaging is adequate. Until the Tylenol deaths, they could not have been expected to anticipate lethal tampering. Now, however, they may be legally on notice that such things can happen - and, therefore, legally responsible for taking steps to prevent them. **********''If a problem is foreseeable, and if there is something reasonable to be done to prevent it, the manufacturer has a duty to do that something,'' said Miss Birnbaum. ''Generally, the legal standard of foreseeability is what is objectively reasonable to expect, not what might conceivably happen. Are we at the point where the manufacturer should expect criminal tampering? I don't think so, but the Tylenol cases are right on the cutting edge of the law.'' One Positive Result **********The new fears about tampering do have one positive effect.  According to Mr. McCrory, consumers have become more sensitive to signs of contamination. **********''One of our products has a seal with holes punched in it so that it can breathe,'' he said. ''After the Tylenol problems, people called in suspecting that the holes had been punched with a hypodermic needle. That kind of alertness is all to the good.'' **********Maybe so, but it can go too far. General Mills got a frightened call from a woman who had found a pill in a box of one of its cereals. It was only after the company representative arrived to investigate that she remembered she herself had dropped some pills into the box.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/05/busin.main_headline: Advertising; Coca-Cola TV Ads To Begin
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/05/busin.print_headline: Advertising; Coca-Cola TV Ads To Begin
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/05/busin.body_text: **********YESTERDAY, 2,000 Coca-Cola bottlers were in Atlanta to see the new advertising from McCann-Erickson that goes with the previously announced new theme line, ''Coke is it.'' **********Tonight, the client and agency estimate, 95 million Americans will see the first of the television commercials that have engaged the talents of scores of amateurs and professionals for more than a year. That's if you consider all of the painstaking consumer research to insure that Coke would receive advertising worth sinking more than $40 million into. And that sum does not include the money bottlers will be spending. **********All three networks will be carrying a spot at 9:15 P.M. That's called ''roadblocking,'' or no escape. Altogether, the agency shot eight 60-second and 30-second commercals in Houston, Santa Paula, Calif., Los Angeles, Dallas and at Grambling State University in Louisiana. **********The finished products have John F. Bergin, a convert from the Pepsi creative team who is now worldwide director of the Coke account at the agency, bubbling with enthusiasm. And at a preview, attended by Sergio Zyman, vice president for marketing operations of Coca-Cola U.S.A., Mr. Bergin talked excitedly about the new line, the music that goes with it and the ''unabashed product presence'' in the commercials. **********''The music is a piece of dynamite,'' the copywriter said. ''It's like a football fight song. Usually you get a languid ballad. We were looking for a big, bold sound, and a big, bold statement. This isn't an ipsy-pipsy drink and the music says that loud and clear.'' **********The music was composed by Ginny Redington and arranged by her husband, Tom Dawes. It was one of 18 pieces submitted by outside music suppliers that were presented to the client along with 36 proposed lines that were candidates to replace the old line, ''Have a Coke and a Smile.'' **********This collection was narrowed to five lines and six musical pieces.  Then the lines were typed separately and shown to consumers who were asked what they meant to them. Then each line was attached to an old bit of advertising art work and the question asked again. **********And then each of the lines and each of the pieces of music were added to different bits of old commercial footage and retested, but this time in group sessions. Gallup & Robinson, the research company, followed up with day-after recall tests. **********There was also what Mr. Bergin called a test for ''the quality of communication.'' On top of all that there were 200 one-on-one consumer interviews that went on for two hours or more.  All this, said Mr. Bergin, whose other title is president, McCann-Erickson U.S.A., led to the final decision on ''Coke is it.'' **********Mr. Bergin said that those three little words reflect ''the product and w hat it is in the eyes of the consumer, t he mood of the company, aggressive management and bottlers,'' adding, ''The total marketing concept, a state of mind.'' **********Later, he said: ''It means something only as we shape it to mean something. Big taste. Refreshment.'' And that is worth reflecting on. Coke has spent millions of dollars over the years imprinting the image of its bottle in our minds. With the bottle and logo having insinuated itself into every corner of American life, all that the company has to do for it to benefit is find the key phrase with the right art and music. **********Coca-Cola, which spent $184.2 million for advertising all of its products in 1980, sank $37 million behind Coke itself, a drop of 11 percent from the previous year, according to Leading National Advertisers. That figure includes all major measured media execept newspaper and spot radio.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/30/busin.main_headline: F.C.C. Changes Policy On Satellite Channels
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/30/busin.print_headline: F.C.C. Changes Policy On Satellite Channels
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/30/busin.body_text: **********In a change of policy, the Federal Communications Commission authorized the domestic satellite industry today to sell satellite channels as well as lease them. **********The decision, reached on a 6-to-1 vote, provides a satellite owner with an alternative to the requirement that all channels be leased on a first-come, first-served basis at rates set by the commission. **********The ruling is a victory for such concerns as Hughes Communications Inc., Western Union Telegraph, the Southern Pacific Communications Company and RCA American Communications Inc., all of which had requested authority to sell channels. **********Three Applications Approved **********As part of its new policy decision, the commission granted the specific applications of Hughes, Western Union and RCA to go ahead with already signed contracts covering the sale of channels on some of their satellites. In that sale, one channel sold for up to $14 million. Channel leasing brings in an average $100,000 a month. **********Under the agency's ruling, a concern that wants to build and launch a satellite must declare what type of service he intends to offer.  If he intends to provide service to any customer he can attract, he will continue to be classified as a so-called common carrier and must charge leasing rates that are approved by the F.C.C. **********If, however, the satellite builder decides there is only a limited number of potential customers with whom he wants to do business, he can escape the common carrier classification and sell a satellite channel, or transponder, at any rate he can negotiate. **********In no case, however, can the operator escape the requirement that he obtain F.C.C. permission to build and launch a satellite. The agency went out of its way today to stress it will review each satellite construction application individually, retaining the authority to reject an application for a communications satellite whose transponders are going to be sold if it thinks there is a shortage of channels for leasing. **********The agency's decision was described by several members as simply an acknowledgment that a competitive market is developing within the satellite industry for the sale of channels. **********The scarcity of channel space that has confronted customers for the last several years is being eased by the launch of new satellites, the F.C.C. said, and there is no reason to conclude that all satellite owners will want to sell channels as long as there continues to be a demand for leased channels. Those findings were challenged by Joseph R. Fogarty, F.C.C. commissioner, however, who asserted the F.C.C. was projecting an abundance of capacity instead of specifically finding that was now the case.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/17/busin.main_headline: OIL RISE A FACTOR IN JUNE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/17/busin.print_headline: PRODUCER PRICES UP 1%; OIL RISE A FACTOR IN JUNE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/17/busin.body_text: **********Pushed up by rising gasoline and oil prices, the Producer Price Index for finished goods rose by 1 percent in June after having held nearly steady or declined for four months, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. **********Although the increase from May was the largest for any month since March 1981, economists said that it represented only a temporary surge, not an acceleration of underlying inflation, which has been slowing. Several analysts, citing the recession, said they expected inflation to continue to slow this year. **********The seasonally adjusted June rise of 1 percent lifted the Producer Price Index for finished goods to a level only 3.5 percent higher than in June 1981, a comparison that Administration economists said was more meaningful than any one month's change from the preceding month. The index generally foreshadows price trends at the consumer level. **********The 1 percent figure was rounded off from an actual increase of 1.0104 percent, which results in a compound annual rate of 13.3 percent. **********Supporting the optimistic view that inflation will continue to slow were the modest changes in the indexes for prices of intermediate goods and for crude materials. For intermediate goods, such as flour, synthetic rubber and plumbing fixtures, the June rise was threetenths of 1 percent, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported.  For crude goods, such as green coffee, potash and iron ore, the index slipped by one-tenth of 1 percent, the eighth decline in 12 months. **********In the price index for finished goods, which are goods ready for sale by retailers, fuels rose by 4.1 percent and accounted for half the June rise, the report said. It noted that, because this component of the index comes in a month late, the prices used in the June index were for May, when a curtailment of crude oil production by Saudi Arabia and other exporters reversed some of the price declines of preceding months. **********Further increases in gasoline prices occurred in June, analysts said, and are likely to be reflected in the July index. But unless the renewed fighting between Iran and Iraq disrupts Persian Gulf production of crude oil, energy is unlikely to be an inflationary force in the second half of the year, Government officials said. **********The White House, going further, expressed hope for a resumption of the earlier downward trend. ''We're looking at world oil prices which have declined considerably in recent weeks so that out in the coming months we can probably see a decline in the cost of energy,'' said Larry Speakes, the deputy press secretary. **********Even with the June rise, wholesale energy prices remained 7.9 percent below the levels of a year earlier. Apart from energy, prices for other finished goods showed a rise of 4.9 percent for the 12 months. 1.9 Percent Rise for Cars **********Also pushing up the June index was a rise of 1.9 percent for new cars, compared with seven-tenths of 1 percent in May. John Steigmann, an economist at the Ford Motor Company in Dearborn, Mich., attributed the rise to the expiration of May rebates. ''May understated and June overstated'' what was happening to prices, he said. A new round of rebates took effect in July, Mr. Steigmann added, but they were smaller than the May concessions. **********More broadly, Mr. Steigmann said that the economy's ''core'' rate of inflation has declined to 6 percent and will fall further.  ''Inflation will continue to fall significantly, mainly reflecting the high and growing level of excess capacity,'' he added. **********Economists reckon that, with substantial idle factory capacity - the Federal Reserve reported today that factories were operating at only 69.8 percent of capacity - there is room for a post-recession recovery to occur without the rekindling of inflationary forces. **********The Bureau of Labor Statistics also reported that natural gas prices posted a substantial June rise of 2.9 percent, compared with 1.8 percent in May. However, these increases are unlikely to make much of a dent in consumer budgets until the next heating season. Coffee, Fruit and Eggs Up **********The index for foods ready for sale to consumers rose by fivetenths of 1 percent, a bit less than in May. Decreases occurred for roasted coffee, fresh fruits, eggs, pork and poultry. Prices rose for shortening and cooking oils, milled rice and flour-base mixes.  Moving up faster than in May were prices of beef and veal, fish, vegetables and refined sugar. **********Among other consumer goods, prices rose for boats, lawnmowers, tobacco products, leather footwear, toilet paper, household flatware and floor coverings. **********In the business equipment sector, prices rose by eight-tenths of 1 percent, the largest rise in eight months. Increases occurred for light trucks, farm machinery, office machines and other items. **********The index for finished goods stood at 279.9 for June on a 1967 base of 100. A bundle of goods that could have been purchased for $100 in 1967 would have cost $279.90 last month. For intermediate goods, the June index was 310. For crude materials, it was 325.7. **********The intermediate goods index was nine-tenths of 1 percent higher than a year ago. The crude materials index was down 20.2 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/16/busin.body_text: **********The output of the nation's factories and mines dropped in May for the ninth time in 10 months, the Government reported today. But the size of the decline - just two-tenths of 1 percent from the April level - raised new hopes the recession may be easing. **********''The corner is here,'' declared Donald Straszheim, vice president of Wharton Econometrics. He asserted that industrial production is rising this month and will continue climbing ''for months to come.'' **********Robert Ortner, the Commerce Department's chief economist, was more cautious. ''Apparently the recession continued in May,'' he said. But he characterized the May decline as ''kind of moderate,'' and added that an upturn is ''if not at hand, then close at hand.'' **********The small May decline reported by the Federal Reserve Board came after drops of eight-tenths of 1 percent in April from the March level and eight-tenths of 1 percent in March from the February level.  Consumer Durables Up 2.3% **********A surge in auto production pushed factory production of consumer durable goods up 2.3 percent from April, but output of business equipment fell 1.6 percent and production of basic metals fell seventenths of 1 percent. All consumer goods production rose eight-tenths of 1 percent after having risen by the same amount in April, the Federal Reserve said. **********In later economic data reported today, new car sales by the General Motors Corporation, the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in the June 1-10 period, marking the fourth consecutive period of positive sales results.  (Page D3.) **********The overall decline in industrial production in May meant the factory utilization for the nation's manufacturers also dropped - probably under 71 percent of capacity for the first time during this recession, analysts said. That was still above the 69 percent low of the 1974-75 recession. Factory utilization figures are to be released Wednesday. **********For months, production has been held down as the nation's businesses sold off inventory rather than increase production to meet demand. During that period of inventory liquidation, production cutbacks contributed to an unemployment rate of 9.5 percent, the highest in 41 years. Inventory Liquidation Slowing **********But Government figures have shown the inventory liquidation slowing, a development reflected in the May industrial production figure. Nevertheless, Mr. Ortner cautioned that ''manufacturers still seem intent on cutting back inventories some more.'' But he added that ''if we get a sustained pickup in retail sales, then production can follow.'' **********Details of the Federal Reserve's May production report showed these developments: **********- Production of consumer durable goods - relatively expensive and long-lasting items - increased 2.3 percent, ''reflecting a sharp rise in automotive products and little change in home goods output.'' Autos were assembled at an annual rate of 5.6 million units, up about 10 percent from April. **********- Output of business equipment -mainly heavy machinery - ''was reduced 1.6 percent further in May, following cutbacks totaling more than 10 percent over the nine preceding months. Large declines occurred in May in output of building and mining and of manufacturing equipment. **********- Military equipment production rose six-tenths of 1 percent. **********- Output of construction supplies increased four-tenths of 1 percent after sharp declines in March and April.  Breaking down the overall figure, the report said that output of factory products dropped one-tenth of 1 percent in May while production of materials fell seven-tenths of 1 percent. Output declined one-tenth of 1 percent for manufacturing and 2.4 percent for mining. **********All of the figures were adjusted for normal seasonal variations.  At 140.3 percent of the 1967 average - a benchmark year used only for measuring future changes - the industrial production index was 8.8 percent below its July 1981 level.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/03/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Egypt Says Its Border With Libya Is Still Closed
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/03/world.body_text: **********Egypt said today that it would keep its border with Libya closed and that the crossing of the frontier Monday by 27 Egyptians and their families was an exception to the policy. **********''The facilities extended to 27 Egyptian teachers and their families that allowed them to cross the border are restricted to this group only due to their special circumstances,'' a Government spokesman said. **********''The measures which were previously in force will continue.'' **********The Libyan Government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi closed the border after breaking relations with Egypt in 1979 as part of Arab efforts to isolate Egypt after it signed a peace treaty with Israel. **********But the border was briefly opened Monday to allow the 27 Egyptians and their families who work in Libya to cross into Egypt and spend a two-week vacation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/29/world.body_text: **********Foreign ministers of the Arab League convened in Casablanca today for the first Arab conference since Israel's invasion of Lebanon. **********The two-day meeting, which will adjourn to nearby Mohammedia after the opening, is expected to prepare for a summit meeting in Fez next month. **********Nearly all the members of the 22-nation Arab League are represented, except Libya, which says the meeting is designed to liquidate the Arab cause, and Egypt, whose membership in the Arab League was suspended after it signed a peace treaty with Israel in 1979. **********High on the agenda of the conference is a Saudi peace plan implicitly recognizing Israel's existence.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/24/world.body_text: **********WALESA IS MADE FOCUS OF ATTACK IN POLISH PRESS **********WARSAW, Feb. 23 (By The Associated Press) - Poland's official press agency heaped new criticism today on Lech Walesa, the detained leader of the Solidarity labor union, accusing him of having been a front for an anti-Communist crusade. **********Western diplomats said the attack might be aimed at setting a hard line for the Communist Party's Central Committee when it meets Wednesday for the first time since martial law was imposed Dec. 13. **********The attack on Mr. Walesa was in a commentary by the P.A.P. press agency, which indicated that union leaders interned under martial law might be barred from commenting publicly on the Government's proposal for future independent trade unions. **********Barred From National Debate **********''In the nationwide debate, there can be no place for the people who have led the country to the brink of civil war,'' the agency said. **********It said Mr. Walesa ''provided the front for the anti-Communist crusade and objectively deserted the interests of the working class, thereby markedly contributing to undermining the interests of the Polish state.'' **********The army newspaper, Zolnierz Wolnosci, accused Mr. Walesa on Monday of having joined other union leaders in calling for the lynching of party officials. **********Until the attacks in the last two days, the press had generally avoided criticizing Mr. Walesa by name and portrayed him as being outmaneuvered by radicals in Solidarity. **********The army newspaper followed up today by saying that Solidarity had a ''dangerous scenario'' for seizing power. It said the plan had a surprising resemblance to a 1979 book by Gen. Sir John Hackett of Britain and other NATO generals, called ''The Third World War,'' which it said spoke of plans for an insurrection in Poland. **********''In these plans, special roles were assigned in advance to people from the Confederation of Independent Poland, the Committee for Social Self-Defense, extremist Solidarity militants and some Zionist quarters bent on antagonizing Polish society,'' the paper said, listing Polish dissident groups. **********It said these forces wanted either to oust Communism and restore capitalism, or pave the way for ''Soviet military intervention in Poland regardless of the victims.'' **********This, the paper said, was part of American policy aimed at using Poland to antagonize the Soviet Union. ---- Trial of Walesa Ruled Out **********LONDON, Feb. 23 (AP) - Mieczyslaw Rakowski, a Polish Deputy Prime Minister, was quoted by The Times of London today as having said that Lech Walesa was in fine condition in a villa outside Warsaw and would not be brought to trial. **********Mr. Rakowski said that the Solidarity chairman might no longer be an effective union leader, that some leaders of the Roman Catholic Church were ''kind of tired'' of him, and that there were rumors that the church might dissociate itself from him. **********The church has been trying to mediate between the authorities and Solidarity and to defuse the tense situation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/19/busin.print_headline: INVESTING; STRATEGIES FOR THE CORPORATE BRASS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/19/busin.body_text: **********AMERICA'S top business executives are delighted these days that the s tock market's burst of enthusiasm has added millions of dollars in v alue to their corporate pension funds and that it may not be long b efore they can float a new stock offering. **********But when it comes to their own personal portfolios, many of them are less eager to participate at present. That's because two of the largest firms that provide personal financial counseling to corporate brass are waving the flag of caution. **********At Heublein Inc. last Tuesday, for instance, Guy Palmer, senior vice president of the Ayco Corporation, told senior executives, including the president, Hicks Waldron, that if they still had any money in short-term debt they should keep it there. ''Normally, we don't get that cute with market timing,'' Mr. Palmer said. ''But the magnitude and speed of the rally in stocks and bonds tempered the enthusiasm I had this summer. I expect to pull back in the next few weeks.'' **********Another adviser to corporate chieftains who is bearish on the immediate outlook for stocks is Hamilton Gregg of the firm that bears his name in Falls Village, Conn. He is advising chairmen such as John Hall of Ashland Oil, James Ferguson of General Foods, Harry Gray of United Technologies and William Anderson of NCR. to keep two-thirds of their money invested primarily in medium-term Government bonds, except for isolated special situation stocks. ''Almost any buying panic sells off to where it started,'' he said, expecting that the current rally will soon do the same. **********Ayco and Hamilton Gregg & Company are among only a handful of firms that offer major corportions a complete package of personal financial planning services, including real estate, tax and fringe-benefit planning, for their top executives. Ayco is the largest, with about 1,800 clients at 60 companies, most of which, such as Eastman Kodak, Westinghouse, A.T.& T. and General Electric, are among the largest corporations in the country. Gregg counsels 300 executives at 25 major corporations and also manages money, through subsidiaries, for wealthy individuals and pension clients. **********Other firms in the executive counseling field are the United States Trust Company, which is conducting seminars for executives at seven major corporations such as Exxon and Cigna, the giant insurance company whose individual financial services division will broaden its base from small-business owners to Fortune 500 corporations in January. **********The biggest shift in investment strategy that the counselors have called for over the past year has affected their clients' life styles as much as it has their net worth. They have been making the point that in a disinflationary environment investments in real estate and collectibles are no longer likely, as they were in the 1970's, to out-perform stocks and bonds. Said Mr. Palmer, who runs Ayco's capital planning division in Stamford, Conn., ''Since February we have been urging our clients to avoid or sell tangibles which have been grossly overbid and put their money into intangible assets. You might enjoy walking on that oriental rug and looking at that antique Connecticut highboy piece of furniture. But that's the only reason to hold on to them.'' **********Similarly, Mr. Gregg has been telling his clients to sell the condominiums they bought for investments unless they also use them regularly for second or third homes. As he explains it, ''Two years ago, it didn't cost anything to borrow at 18 percent to buy a condo.  That was 9 percent after tax and real estate was appreciating at the then double-digit rate of inflation. Now, there's a real interest rate charge because of the continued high rates and much lower inflation rate.'' MUNICIPAL bonds, on the other hand, remain a favorite of the a dvisers for high tax bracket clients. But maturity preferences d iffer. Edward Guay, chief economist of Cigna, says declining rates a nd rising prices in long-term bonds offer the best opportunities fora nother six to 12 months. Frederick Taylor, senior vice president of U .S. Trust's Personal Investment department, prefers high-quality b onds of the five- to seven-year average maturity range. He also b elieves deep discount bonds, older bonds selling well below their o riginal issue prices, are appropriate for estate planning. That way a grandparent can leave the interest portion of a bond to a son or d aughter and the principal portion, with its strong price a ppreciation at maturity, to a grandchild. **********Mr. Palmer takes the middle road on bond maturities. He prefers the 8- to 12-year range because the risk of going out longer is not worth the benefit of slightly higher rates. For the present though, he is waving clients off new bond purchases until prices settle back a bit. **********Despite the hesitancy to add further to stock positions now, most of the advisers have been bullish since before the late-August rally began. Mr. Taylor is recommending reasonably aggressive investors to put 65 percent of their discretionary assets into stocks. Some of his favorites include Abbott Labs, Dow Jones & Company, Commerce Clearing House, Teradyne, General Instrument and Superior Oil. Mr. Palmer sees a rally coming soon in the stocks of emerging growth companies because ''that's where institutions like to be.'' He leaves stock selections to the money managers that his firm recommends. **********Mr. Gregg, however, does not expect a further upward surge in stocks until bond rates move down on a broad front. Meanwhile, he believes investment portfolios should be only one-third in stocks.  Those he likes include computer technology issues such as Verbatim and Mitel, and M.C.A., primarily because of its vast real estate holdings and motion picture library. **********But one might ask, are the executives listening to their advisers?  Mr. Taylor of U.S. Trust says that they are ''less inclined'' to hold cash and have become somewhat more aggressive in the stock market as he has been suggesting. But, he adds, he doesn't presume that such a high-powered group would follow his stock picks verbatin. **********In fact, he sees a parallel in the way executives are managing their corportions these days and how they are investing. In disinflationary times, he notes, they realize that they have to run their companies with tighter cost controls and rely less on raising prices. Similarly these executives want to own stocks that can grow in a slow-growth environment. ''If we suggest the stock of a technology company, our corporate clients like it only if they view it as a productivity enhancer,'' Mr. Taylor said. ''Sometimes I wonder whether we or our customers come up with the better ideas. We have to listen to them as well.''  ---------------------------------------------------------------------  Fred R. Bleakley writes on finance from New York.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/09/busin.body_text: **********A Washington electronics engineer has patented a tethered airfoil as a source of energy from the wind. **********The apparatus for which Lloyd I. Biscomb was granted patent 4,309,006 this week will have a gas bag that lifts the airfoil. A vent is to pass through the airfoil and a turbine that produces power is aligned with it. Wind direction is sensed and, with the aid of a microcomputer, controls the ground tethers and position of the airfoil. **********The apparatus has not yet been built. Mr. Biscomb regards it as superior because it combines a gas bag with a erodynamic lift.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/17/busin.body_text: **********The Datapoint Corporation, suffering from a weak economy and irregular marketing practices, reported yesterday that it lost $23 million in its third fiscal quarter, ended April 30. **********The loss was the first in nearly a decade for the computer and office equipment manufacturer and compared with a profit of $12.9 million, or 63 cents a share, in the similar period last year.  Revenues sank to $99.4 million from $116.9 million a year earlier. **********The troubled company had predicted a loss, saying that it would have to erase ''a significant amount of sales'' from its books. The sales had been recorded by salesmen before they were really firm, resulting in what the company said yesterday was ''an unusually high'' level of product returns. **********Datapoint said that $15 million in revenues from prior quarters were being reversed and charged against the third quarter's results, contributing $4.4 million to the loss. **********Harold E. O'Kelley, chairman and chief executive of the San Antonio company, said a review of the marketing division had been conducted with the help of independent lawyers and auditors. As a result, it was decided that no additional earnings restatement would be necessary for the fiscal year 1981 or any prior quarter of the fiscal year 1982. **********As a result of the review, the company also found that its order backlog was not as large as it had thought. The backlog at the end of the third quarter was reduced by $105.9 million, to $117.1 million. **********Five vice presidents resigned from the company last month and a senior officer resigned from the board and was demoted in a shake-up of the marketing organization. Datapoint has taken other steps to cope with its financial troubles, including postponing construction of a new headquarters building, terminating 500 of approximately 9,000 employees and consolidating plant operations. **********Mr. O'Kelley said the company would change its marketing to emphasize short-term solutions to problems rather than to try to sell customers complete, futuristic office automation systems. **********Datapoint's announcement was made after the close of trading on the New York exchange. The stock closed at $11.25, down 25 cents. Earlier this year, the stock traded as high as $51.675.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/16/busin.main_headline: HURDLES LIE AHEAD FOR ALGERIAN GAS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/16/busin.print_headline: HURDLES LIE AHEAD FOR ALGERIAN GAS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/16/busin.body_text: **********Two years after Algeria abruptly cut off liquefied natural gas deliveries to its major American customer, the North African nation is prepared to start shipping again to the United States. **********This time, however, Algeria will be selling smaller quantities of gas to a different company, and few analysts believe that American utilities will be relying heavily on Algerian gas any time soon. **********Despite the fact that Algeria will get a good deal less for its gas than it had sought, the price is still high, angering some of the final consumers. Tied to Cost of Oil **********And the way the price has been calculated - by referring to the costs of crude oil - conflicts with United States Government policy.  Thus there is a feeling that Federal regulators might quash the new deal with Algeria. **********''You can be darn sure these imports are going to get some very close scrutiny at a time when large parts of the U.S. natural gas industry find it hard to absorb and market all the natural gas they're entitled to,'' said David J. Bardin, a Washington laywer and former Energy Department official. **********Last week, the Houston-based Panhandle Eastern Corporation announced that it would begin receiving liquefied gas from Algeria, with the first ship loading on Sept. 11. Contract Signed in 1975 **********Panhandle had signed its original contract with Sonatrach, Algeria's state oil and gas company, in 1975, when the United States was still mindful of the first oil embargo and determined to secure long-term supplies of substitutes. Counting on the gas shipments to begin in the autumn of 1981, Panhandle put $567 million into a terminal to reconvert the liquefied product to its gaseous state at Lake Charles, La., and another $80 million into a partnership owning two tankers. **********But Sonatrach did not deliver. The problem was price.  Algeria, whose gas reserves are among the world's largest, insisted on parity between oil and gas prices, based on their energy equivalents, and made its demands clear in April 1980. It suspended gas deliveries to its two major customers, France and the Houstonbased El Paso Company, which was the carrier for three pipeline systems in the eastern United States. At the time, Algeria accounted for 8 percent of gas consumption in France and 2 percent in the United States. **********The Carter Administration tried to mediate for the American companies, but El Paso ultimately wrote off $375 million in tankers and facilities. The three pipeline companies that El Paso served are still talking to the Algerians, but few analysts expect an agreement soon. 21 Percent Higher to French **********Last February, the French announced an agreement under which they would pay 21 percent more for the Algerian gas and buy larger quantities in exchange for stepped-up orders of machinery and goods from Algeria. **********Panhandle, saddled with its unproductive investment, took a tougher tack. In July, the company invoked a clause of its contract with Sonatrach and sought arbitration. The new agreement followed a month later. **********Under the agreement, Panhandle will seek permission from the Economic Regulatory Administration and the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, both under the Department of Energy, to adjust prices quarterly and in relation to the official posted export prices of five foreign crude oils, instead of the market price of two refined oils. **********''They certainly came a long way,'' said a State Department official who asked not to be named, referring to the Algerians.  ''That escalator tied to crude had been their objective. They did not achieve their price parity, but under this market, they couldn't have.'' 'Backing Down' Seen **********However, John Treat, president of the New York Mercantile Exchange and a former Energy Department official, noted that the price would not be tied solely to Algeria's high quality crude, as originally demanded. ''That represents a backing down in Algeria's position,'' he said. **********Panhandle will begin buying gas from Sonatrach at $3.92 per million British thermal units - way below the $6.12 that would approximate in energy-equivalent terms the posted price of $35.50 a barrel for Algerian crude oil. Panhandle plans to buy 165 billion cubic feet a year for 20 years, less than half of what the El Paso group had contracted for. **********One other American company has also been importing Algerian gas: The Distrigas Corporation of Boston buys 43 billion cubic feet a year, and recently finished its first quadrennial contract review with Sonatrach. Distrigas would not disclose the details last week, but speculation is that the terms are similar to Panhandle's. **********And it is those terms - tying gas prices to crude prices - that has some analysts wondering whether the Government will approve.  ''They just don't like deals tied to crude oil because in effect you'd never have one fuel displacing another,'' said Edward L.  Morse, a Phillips Petroleum Company official formerly in the State Department. Approval Not Needed for Months **********Panhandle, acknowledging the possible objections, noted that it did not have to seek official approval for four to six months. It also expressed hope that the Algerians would continue deliveries and be open to further negotiation if the Government ultimately rejected the new terms. **********Of more immediate concern to some of Panhandle's 130 customers - utilities that resell 6 percent of the nation's natural gas to 3 million households and businesses in the Middle West - is the forthcoming price increase. By the time Panhandle transports and reconverts the gas, it will go into the company's two pipeline systems - subject to Federal Energy Regulatory Commission approval - at $7.18 per million British thermal units. **********The result will be a 10 percent to 40 percent increase in Panhandle's prices - and possibly a drop in the business for the utilities. With gas losing its price advantage over oil, many industrial users might make the easy switch back to oil. **********Even if the Energy Department sides with Panhandle, it could face trouble in court. The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, to which the Economic Regulatory Agency's decisions can be appealed, recently overturned a ruling that pipeline companies could raise prices to make up for increases imposed on the El Paso group. The court ruled that there was no need to use this specific gas, and the Government has not filed an appeal. **********Panhandle's main argument is that it is being farsighted. ''Our framework is 20 years,'' said Stanford A. Wallace, a company spokesman. ''There's no question that, right now, there's gas production to be bought in the U.S., but it's not a substitute for an assured long-term volume.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/06/busin.body_text: **********The Government's Synthetic Fuels Corporation, which is responsible for distributing billions of dollars to encourage development of alternatives to oil and gas, has selected proposed plants in California, New Mexico and North Carolina for possible assistance totaling as much as $557 million. **********The corporation's announcement did not indicate an actual commitment of money to the three plants. **********The board voted only to sign letters of intent saying that if certain conditions were met the aid would be granted. **********The projects selected were the First Colony peat-to-methanol plant in North Carolina, the Santa Rosa oil sands project in New Mexico and the Calsyn heavy-oil conversion project in California. **********Robert Roach, a spokesman for the Environmental Policy Institute, criticized the proposed letters of intent. ''This just shows that a commercially viable synthetic fuels industry does not exist,'' Mr.  Roach said. ''These projects are small, essentially research-type plants that will yield less than 15,000 barrels a day of capacity.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/09/busin.main_headline: COSTA RICA PLANS DEBT TALKS AS AUSTERITY PROGRAM GAINS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/09/busin.print_headline: COSTA RICA PLANS DEBT TALKS AS AUSTERITY PROGRAM GAINS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/09/busin.body_text: **********Costa Rica, which only six months ago had the most serious debt problem in Latin America, has been gradually putting its finances in order and now appears ready to renegotiate its huge foreign debt. **********Two weeks ago, Costa Rica reached agreement on a $100 million credit from the International Monetary Fund, and on Thursday it will sign a $70 million loan from the United States, which had been made conditional upon I.M.F. approval of a Costa Rican austerity program. **********In addition, during President Reagan's visit here last weekend, the United States agreed to support Costa Rican efforts to restructure the debt it owes to both foreign private banks and foreign governments. Meetings with each group of creditors are to be held during the next month. **********As a result, for the first time in more than two years, confidence is beginning to stir in the depressed Costa Rican economy. Recovery of traditional growth rates may not come before 1985 or 1986, but there is a widespread sense of relief in business circles that the Government is beginning to tackle the crisis. Currency Recovering **********When President Luis Alberto Monge took office last May, the country had suspended all repayment on its $3.1 billion public foreign debt, the highest per capita in the world, and its currency was falling.  But since then, some interest payments have resumed and the colon has steadily regained ground against the dollar. **********To achieve this and the I.M.F. agreement, however, the new Government has sharply raised electricity, gasoline, water and telephone rates and it has promised to cut spending, decree new taxes and increase domestic interest rates. This year, while inflation has exceeded 100 percent, economic activity has fallen by almost 6 percent. **********''The Government concluded that it had no choice,'' one foreign diplomat here said, ''but at least it has had the courage to go through with austerity. The question is whether it will keep a tight rein - and social peace - in 1983.'' **********Before it can plan resumption of economic growth, however, Costa Rica still faces the major hurdle of its debt renegotiation, not only with 12 governments but also with a 12-bank steering committee that represents 150 private creditors. **********Although Costa Rica is only one of many developing countries seriously affected by high oil prices and low commodity prices, its financial problems were aggravated when the administration of former President Rodrigo Carazo Odio twice refused to carry out the terms of an agreement with the I.M.F. Payments Suspended **********Instead, in August 1981, with its foreign exchange reserves exhausted, the Government suspended payment of both principal and interest on its foreign debt, and then left the problem to the Monge administration. **********Last June, the new administration's economic experts met with the 12-bank steering committee, which is headed by the Chase Manhattan Bank, and offered to resume ''symbolic'' interest payments as a sign of good will, with the understanding that renegotiation would follow an agreement with the I.M.F. **********Thus during the second half of this year, Costa Rica has repaid $41.5 million in interest. But arrears in interest have still risen to $260 million, and the country must cover an additional $355 million in interest and $115 million in amortization of debts to multilateral agencies, such as the World Bank, in 1983. **********At a meeting in Washington last Nov. 23, Costa Rican officials explained to the steering committee that they could put $470 million to debt servicing next year. Excluding repayment of any principal, however, there would still be a shortfall of some $260 million. **********Earlier in the year, Costa Rica had suggested that interest arrears be included in the general debt renegotiation, but this was rejected by the banks. At the recent Washington meeting, however, Costa Rica proposed that it would repay more than $470 million if exports or other foreign exchange earnings were higher than projected. **********In response, according to officials here, the banks said they would prefer to offer a ''revolving trade facility'' -similar to a plan used with Poland earlier this year - to cover half the interest arrears, although this would still leave a shortfall of some $130 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/28/busin.body_text: **********In an attempt to stay alive in a down economy, more and more magazines are ignoring their once-inviolate rate cards and are offering individual deals to advertisers, a top New York agency executive said here today at the closing session of the 1982 Magazine Publishers Association conference. **********Kenneth E. Caffrey, senior vice president and exective director of media operations for Ogilvy & Mather, had just stepped down from the dais where he had been one of a panel that had taken a look at the magazine business from the advertiser's perspective. He had urged that ''this assembled group come forward and end the practice now, before it spreads.'' **********He voiced his agency's concern that magazines, like broadcast, were becoming a negotiated medium.  ''No one wants to be an ex-publisher or advertising director, but there have to be editorial or tactical ways to attract business besides rate manipulation, for once it begins it's like a cancer,'' he said. **********Charges of magazines ''going off'' their advertising rate cards, or using creative interpretions of the same, are not new. But Mr.  Caffrey said the practice had never been as rampant as it is today.  The practice can be found not only throughout the magazine industry, but in every medium but newspapers, he said. **********At Ogilvy, Mr. Caffrey said, it is assumed that a magazine is basing its rates on the cost of doing business, plus a modest profit to bring in a reasonable return on investment. But by settling for less for a short-term gain, he said, publishers are penalizing the magazine's long-term development. So the publisher loses and the advertising community ultimately loses. **********Mr. Caffrey explained that although the agency opposed the practice, it must, as the client's adviser, take advantage of good offers and tell other clients about them. So the practice spreads. **********And, if the practice continues to grow, his agency will have to restructure its media department and put in a negotiating team for magazines as it has for broadcast, he said. **********His remarks obviously hit home, judging from the number of questions that followed. One questioner suggested agency culpability when he asked, ''Aren't the agency's television-oriented media departments the ones that initiate the rate breaking?'' **********Mr. Caffrey turned out to be well worth the effort it took to get him to this sunny island. He was full of good advice. Before he ever got to rate cards, he was warning publishers against inflated circulation rate bases that included large numbers of disinterested subscribers obtained at above-average cost. A cost, incidentally, that is passed on to the advertiser. **********''What I'm suggesting is that publishers large and small seriously review their rate base to eliminate the least desirable subscribers,'' he said. ''If necessary from an income basis, raise subscription prices and maintain or, if you must, raise cost-perthousand, but reduce the absolute out-of-pocket cost to advertisers. We need better readers, not just more.'' **********Mr. Caffrey's fellow panelists were Alvin Hampel, chairman/New York of D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius, and Philip J. Naquin, vice president/advertising for Chanel. **********Mr. Hampel, who came up on the creative side as a copywriter, discussed the difficulty that agencies are encountering in getting top people involved in print ads. He spoke of some agencies in Chicago, where he recently did time, in which print advertising was relegated to the position of supplementary advertising, or reminder advertising, keyed to TV commercials. **********He suggested that magazines try to get closer to the agency creative people who can frequently generate print advertising for an account when no one else working on it is thinking print. And, he wondered, what about working for a closer relationship between magazines, the editorial people and agency creative folks? Or even job exchanges between the two groups? Which could be taking a good thing too far.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/09/busin.main_headline: Washington Watch; A Little Less Swiss Secrecy
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/09/busin.print_headline: Washington Watch; A Little Less Swiss Secrecy
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/09/busin.body_text: **********WASHINGTON THE Securities and Exchange Commission may be close to reaching agreement with Swiss officials, after months of secret talks, over curbing illegal insider trading channeled through secret Swiss bank accounts. **********The agreement, which may come in a meeting later this month, would make it easier for United States authorities to investigate possible securities law violations in Switzerland, sources familiar with the situation say. **********While John M. Fedders, the commission's chief enforcement official, will neither confirm nor deny the reports, he says that the agency is making considerable progress on this issue. **********Until recently, the Swiss have bristled at any attempts by foreigners to challenge their durable and highly lucrative ways of doing business. Perhaps most vexing to United States officials is the fact that insider trading - trading in stock to make a profit or limit losses on the basis of information not available to the public - is not illegal in Switzerland. **********But the bilateral talks and a spate of recent court decisions here and abroad appear to have pierced Switzerland's seemingly impregnable bank secrecy laws. **********Earlier this year, the Swiss finance ministry endorsed a proposal to make insider trading a criminal offense. If enacted into law, Swiss banks would be free under the terms of the Swiss-American Treaty on Criminal Matters to divulge information about clients being investigated by American regulatory authorities. The reason is that the treaty requires Swiss banks to surrender information when the activities being investigated would be illegal in both countries. **********''Our recent court victories, together with our negotiations with the Swiss authorities, have made the chances of getting caught using these accounts for illegal purposes much higher,'' says Barbara S.  Thomas, an S.E.C. commissioner. Fewer Interstate Bank Mergers **********Banking officials are taking a second look at the recently issued Federal Reserve guidelines for interstate bank mergers and are a great deal less enthusiastic about what they now see. **********In its ruling last month, the Federal Reserve indicated that the key issue is not ownership itself, but whether the acquiring bank could exert control over the bank being acquired. **********The Fed thus laid out guidelines to prevent that from happening, while allowing a bank holding company to acquire up to 4.9 percent of the voting shares and far larger proportions of nonvoting shares in out-of-state banks. **********Initial reaction from bank officials was favorable. ''We're ecstatic,'' said an official with the Chemical New York Corporation, the parent of Chemical Bank. Chemical plans to merge with Florida National Banks of Florida Inc., should interstate banking become legal. The Southeast Banking Corporation of Miami also wants to acquire Florida National. **********But industry analysts are no longer so sure that the ruling will lead to a flood of proposals for interstate mergers. A recent study by Keefe, Bruyette & Woods Inc., specialists in banking, said: ''The thrust of those guidelines, however, suggests to us that potential cross-border acquirers will proceed slowly, and with caution.'' **********The Fed's apparent tolerance of interstate agreements, Keefe said, ''has been sharply hedged by restrictions to avoid de facto control, thereby removing much of the incentive for those agreements in the first place.'' **********This view is shared by James Bell, general counsel of the Conference of State Bank Supervisors, who said that the number of such new agreements that were expected to be announced have dropped substantially in recent weeks. **********''The large banks that were involved had more or less claimed that the Fed's guidelines constituted some sort of victory or blueprint as to how one should set about trying to have an interstate acquisition,'' Mr. Bell said. ''This has been, to put it rather mildly, somewhat of an overstatement on the part of these banks.'' Reporting to Shareholders **********It probably comes as no surprise to shareholders of R.J. Reynolds Industries, one of the world's largest cigarette producers, that the company spent heavily to defeat an antismoking ballot initiative in Dade County, Fla., in 1980. **********But shareholders of the Procter & Gamble Company and the Ralston Purina Company might wonder, for instance, what interest was served when these companies recently made campaign contributions opposing antinuclear ballot initiatives. **********The Council on Economic Priorities, a nonprofit research organization based in New York, found in a recent survey that corporations have been spending increasing amounts of money to influence the outcome of state and local ballot issues. **********According to the council, corporations are most likely to use their muscle to fight limits on smoking, beverage-container deposits and taxes on oil profits. Corporations are spending heavily to fight local efforts to limit the use of nuclear power and control nuclear waste disposal. **********There are no uniform Federal requirements that corporations report their spending to shareholders when they contribute to campaigns not involving political candidates. The result, says the council, is that corporations tend to avoid public scrutiny of their contributions. **********The council has asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to require that publicly held corporations inform their shareholders through annual reports where and how they spend money to influence voters. **********The S.E.C. says it is considering the petition, but would have no further comment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/08/world.body_text: **********Rival militia groups battled through the day here with grenades, mortars and heavy machine guns, and police sources said that five people were killed and several were wounded. **********The fighting, which tapered off tonight, was between Amal, a Moslem Shiite group, and a Marxist faction, the Organization of Communist Action in Lebanon. **********The fighting began Wednesday night in a low-income quarter of West Beirut, which is predominantly Moslem. After a lull of several hours, in which both sides brought up reinforcements, the battle resumed and spread to other Moslem neighborhoods. Witnesses estimated that 500 militiamen were involved. **********A number of civilians were hi t by flying bullets as the streets emptied of ca rs and pedestrians and as many families rushed to shelter in ba sements. **********A large number of Syrian soldiers from the Arab deterrent force stood by to enter the battle area, which was close to the line dividing Beirut into Moslem and Christian sectors. **********Amal, which reflects the growing power of Lebanon's million Shiites, supports the Iranian revolutionary leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, a Shiite clergyman.
