https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/21/busin.main_headline: SELLING OPTIONS ON YOUR I.R.A. STOCK
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/21/busin.print_headline: SELLING OPTIONS ON YOUR I.R.A. STOCK
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/11/21/busin.body_text: **********SELLING options on stock in an Individual Retirement Account is b ecoming an increasingly popular strategy. To be sure, it's not for i nvestors who need every penny squirreled away in their I.R.A.'s or t hose who don't have stock in them. But for investors who understand t he strategy, some brokers say, it could help beef up an I.R.A.  p ortfolio's return while sheltering that income. **********Most brokerage houses now allow the use of options in I.R.A.'s.  Some, like Hutton, even allow the buying of options, even though most experts consider this dangerously speculative in an I.R.A. Other firms, such as Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, only allow I.R.A. investors to sell (write) options on shares they hold in their I.R.A.'s. **********''We point out to our customers that it's a retirement account and the goal is to have that money there at retirement,'' said Don Underwood, vice president and manager of retirement plans at Merrill. The brokerage house would not allow ''the proverbial little old lady from Dubuque,'' who may need every penny she has in the I.R.A., to use options, even in a conservative option selling program, he added. It is unlikely, he said, that such an unsophisticated investor would spend the time needed in managing the account. **********An option is a contract that gives a person the right, but not the obligation, to buy or sell 100 shares of stock at a set price (strike price) during a limited period of time, not to exceed nine months.  The seller of the option - in other words, the owner of the stock - gets money (a premium) from the buyer of the option. That premium is the stockholder's to keep whether the option expires or is exercised. In normal option trading, the premium can substantially increase the return on a stock and its dividends, but is treated, for tax purposes, as short-term income. Sheltered within an I.R.A., however, that option income is untaxed until the I.R.A. is drawn against in retirement, when the taxpayer's bracket is presumably lower. **********Let's say that an investor has had an I.R.A. for five years, and now has $15,000 worth of stock in it. One of his positions is the XYZ Corporation, which is now selling for $28 a share, and it is a stock on which there are listed options. He could sell a three-month option on 100 of his XYZ shares at a $30 strike price, for a $2-a-share premium, or $200. A six-month option might bring $300 and a ninemonth option, $400. **********If the seller of the option opts for the six-month option, the $300 premium is his to keep, as are all the dividends given off by the stock during that period. If the stock is yielding 10 percent, that $300 will substantially increase the return on his shares. If the option is not exercised, he can sell another option against the same shares. **********Should the stock rise past 30, he will have to sell the shares at 30, and will get $3,000 on top of the $300 premium that he has already received. If the stock stays below 30, the first option will expire and another option may be written. If the stock falls dramatically, say to 23, at least the investor can write more options, if not for the $30 striking price, then for $25. **********Thus, for shareholders, options present the opportunity to increase income from a stock, and also provide a buffer when stock prices decline. That is why so-called covered writing is considered a conservative strategy by many brokers. It is called ''covered'' because the investor owns the stock, as opposed to very risky ''naked'' writing, where the investor sells options without even owning stock. **********Selling options, is ''less aggressive than buying stocks,'' said Robert Schulman, director of leveraged equity at E.F. Hutton. If stocks are an appropriate investment for an investor, then writing options is a conservative way to increase an I.R.A.'s return. But investors who shouldn't be in stocks at all, or only in other income-oriented issues, should@n't go out of their way to buy stocks just so they can write options. **********Option writing can also come in handy for an investor who is looking for a way to unload some ''dogs'' in an I.R.A. portfolio.  Because investors occasionally want to switch from one stock to another, but dread the thought of selling at a loss, an option can ease the pain. **********Option writing is not without risk. ''If an investor's I.R.A. funds are the last cent he has, then we won't allow it,'' Mr. Schulman said. And there is always the chance that an investor will forfeit participation in a stock rise. That possibility is what prompts many people to ''buy back'' the options they have sold against their stock when the shares appear to be rising.IN a volatile market, the temptation to chase stocks up by buying b ack options can be almost irresistible. Caution should be the w atchword, lest the original objective - increasing return - be f orgotten. **********Suppose, for example, that the XYZ Corporation headed up past 30 and gave every indication of going to 40 and beyond. An investor might be tempted to buy back the option he sold for $300 and take his chances on the stock. If the option can be bought back for less than the $300 the investor got originally, all well and good. But sometimes the going price of options is inflated by stock action, and the investor may have to buy back the option for a lot more money, and actually lose ground on the deal. If an investor does this regularly, he can actually reduce the return in his I.R.A. **********Mr. Schulman's advice: If there is enough cash in the account and the stock is ''fundamentally good,'' buy back the option. Again, the suitability of the stock for the investor's portfolio is crucial. If there is no free money in the I.R.A. to buy back the option, Mr.  Schulman recommends against doing it because that would mean selling off part of the I.R.A. position; investors cannot add money to their I.R.A. after the annual contribution. **********There are other dangers in writing options. Specialists and other big traders who pay minuscule, if any, commissions often exercise options just to get a stock by its record date - the date that gives them possession in time to get the dividends. While specialists and big institutions deal in thousands of anonymous shares - to them - that are matched by the option exchanges, your 100- or 200-share position could be among those option positions that are exercised.  You presumably won't lose any money on the deal, but if you were counting on the dividend yourself, it may affect your return and compromise a well-thought-out option writing plan. Your broker can find out what the chances are of your option being exercised. **********I.R.A. customers who write options should also realize that commission costs are relatively steep, often amounting to 10 percent of the option premium, and can mount up in an active program.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/03/busin.main_headline: A.T. & T.'S NET IS WORLD RECORD
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/03/busin.print_headline: A.T. & T.'S NET IS WORLD RECORD
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/03/busin.body_text: **********The American Telephone and Telegraph Company reported yesterday that its net income for the year rose 13.7 percent, to $6.89 billion, or $8.55 a share, the highest profit ever reported by any company in the world. **********The increase, almost twice the 7.2 percent improvement that the phone company registered in 1980, came to a large extent as a result of higher phone rates. **********The 1981 profits compare with $6.06 billion, or $8.17 a share, earned in 1980. These numbers were restated slightly to reflect an accounting change. **********Revenues for the year climbed 14.3 percent, to a record $58.2 billion from $50.9 billion. Without rate increases, the phone company said that its revenues would have risen by 8.6 percent. **********The numbers were no surprise to the financial community, since the company recently reported the results for its corporate fourth quarter - for the three months ended Nov. 30. A.T.& T. keeps its accounts on a calendar-year basis but reports quarterly earnings for three-month periods ending in February, May, August and November, so that shareholders can review the numbers when they get their dividend checks. Includes December Results **********The full-year figures reported today restated the earlier report to include December's results. **********This will probably be the next-to-last time that A.T.& T. reports its annual profits as a unified Bell System. Last month, it settled the Government antitrust case against it by agreeing to divest itself over 18 months of its 22 local operating companies, which provide customers with basic phone service. The settlement is now being reviewed in Federal court, where it must be approved **********Commenting on the Bell S ystem's performance in 1981, Charles L.  Brown, A.T.& T.'s chairman, noted that the demand for Bell services grew, in some respects, ''at a pace short of our expectations, reflecting in part an economy that started the year strong but closedin recession.'' **********Long-distance calling volume, which is highly sensitive to the condition of the economy, grew just 6.6 percent in 1981, A.T.& T.  said. In 1980, volume rose 7.8 percent. A number of analysts who follow the phone company, however, are optimistic that long-distance volume will do better this year. Sluggish Installation Pace **********The same sluggish trend was evident in the number of new phone lines installed. Bell said that it added 2.1 million lines in 1981, down romm an increase of 2.5 million in 1980. **********However, it was a big year for the phone company in the regulatory arena. A.T.& T. said that it received rate increases during the year from state and Federal regulators totaling $4.2 billion, compared with $2 billion the previous year. The bulk of the awards came in state-approved rate increases - a total of $3.2 billion in 45 states. **********A.T.& T.'s board will be meeting in two weeks to consider whether to adjust the quarterly dividend. It was last raised in February 1980, by 8 percent, to $1.35 a share from $1.25. That marked the first increase in two years. **********Any action will be of keen interest, since A.T.& T. stock is held by some three million people, more than hold shares in any other corporation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/21/world.main_headline: ETHIOPIA SAID TO OPEN DRIVE AGAINST ERITREA REBELS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/21/world.print_headline: ETHIOPIA SAID TO OPEN DRIVE AGAINST ERITREA REBELS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/02/21/world.body_text: **********Ethiopian Government forces opened a full-scale offensive last week backed by Soviet weapons and military advisers to eradicate the 20-year-old Eritrean independence struggle, a spokesman for the Eritrean People's Liberation Front said in New York. **********The spokesman, Hagos Gebrehewet, also said in an interview Friday that the Ethiopian Government was using chemical weapons, napalm and cluster bombs against the rebel forces. **********Mr. Gebrehewet said he had received reports of people ''sneezing and vomitting'' after a battle with Ethiopian forces on Feb. 15 at Trukruk, a small village near the Sudanese border. The spokesman said Ethiopian soldiers were using mortar shells loaded with nerve gas.  According to Mr. Gebrehewet, the Eritrean People's Liberation Front believes that the Ethiopian Government stockpiles nerve gas. ''They have decided they cannot win with troops,'' he said. **********Eritrea is a former Italian colony joined to Ethiopia as an autonomous federation by the United Nations in 1952. Guerrillas have been fighting for independence since the territory was annexed by Emperor Haile Selassie's Government in 1962. The province, situated in the northwest, affords Ethiopia's only access to the Red Sea. **********In the four-front offensive that began last week, according to Mr.  Gebrehewet, Ethiopian forces are using Soviet-produced MIG-21 and MIG-23 jets, Soviet MI-24 helicopters, American-made F-5 fighterbombers and Libyan-supplied transport planes. Ninety thousand Ethiopians involved in the fighting are accompanied by 400 Soviet military personnel, Mr. Gebrehewet said. He also said that pilots from Southern Yemen were flying some of the MIG's and all of the MI-24 helicopters. **********Tesfaye Demeke, the charge d'affairs at the Ethiopian Embassy in Washington, called charges that his Government's soldiers had used chemical weapons ''absolutely baseless and malicious.'' **********''We have no intentions of using chemical weapons against our own people,'' he said. Mr. Demeke also denied that any foreign military units were involved in Eritrea. He characterized recent military activity in the region as ''a cleaning-up operation to weed the bandits from their hideouts.'' **********The target of the offensive is Nakfa, a mountain village in the north corner of Eritrea, according to Mr. Gebrehewet. On Feb. 16, the spokesman said, an Ethiopian division entered the Sudan in an effort to outflank Eritrean guerrillas. **********Mr. Demeke denied that any Ethiopian troops had crossed the border into the Sudan. Abdul Rahaman Bakheit, first secretary at the Sudanese Embassy in Washington, said he had no information on Ethiopian troops' being in his country. **********According to Mr. Gebrehewet, Eritrean People's Liberation Front units have staged pre-emptive strikes since January in an attempt to delay the latest offensive. In that time, the spokesman asserted, Eritrean guerrilla forces killed 1,398 Ethiopians and bombarded the airport at Asmara on Jan. 22, destroying an unknown number of helicopters and fighter planes. **********Mr. Demeke said those statements ''were beyond anyone's imagination.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/28/busin.main_headline: REGAN ASSAILS FED, STRESSES RATE ROLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/28/busin.print_headline: REGAN ASSAILS FED, STRESSES RATE ROLE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/01/28/busin.body_text: **********Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, criticizing the Federal Reserve Board's management of the money supply, told Congress today that lower interest rates are essential to a strong economic recovery and to the success of President Reagan's economic policies. **********In testimony before the Joint Economic Committee, Secretary Regan predicted that rates would ''gradually recede'' in 1982, but he indicated some uncertainty about this forecast by emphasizing the Administration's view that the Federal Reserve must avoid ''erratic'' or ''volatile'' money growth. **********Mr. Regan went beyond previous Administration suggestions to the Federal Reserve - which have caused some people at the central bank to feel that its prized independence was being publicly compromised - by saying that the Administration wanted money growth in 1982 ''in the upper one-third of the Federal Reserve's tentative'' target range. For the basic money supply, that range is 2 1/2 percent to 5 1/2 percent. **********Intensification of a Debate **********The Secretary's extended discussion of his view of the Fed's shortcomings came in his prepared statement, in colloquy with committee members and later at a White House news conference. It intensified an emerging debate, if not a quarrel, between the central bank and the Administration. This afternoon Edwin Meese 3d, counselor to the President, endorsed Secretary Regan's advice to the Fed. ''We would certainly be in agreement - that's where the Fed should be,'' he told a reporter. **********Only yesterday Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, emphasized before the same committee his view that the prospect of large Federal budget deficits has been a driving force behind high interest rates. He delivered a similar message Monday to the National Association of Home Builders. **********By contrast, Secretary Regan, joined last week by President Reagan, has tied high interest rates to the Federal Reserve's management of the money supply. The Secretary has been hammering at the Fed for what he described today as ''volatile money growth,'' meaning that the money supply does not expand at a steady pace throughout the year. Federal Reserve officials have said that a smooth path, as advocated by the Treasury, is virtually impossible to follow except, perhaps, at the cost of far more volatile swings in interest rates.  Such swings, the Fed argues, would inhibit business activity. Secretary Cites Statistics **********Secretary Regan declared that the money supply grew at a 13 percent annual rate in November and December following seven months of no growth, which in turn followed three months of growth at a 13.3 percent rate. **********''Such volatile money growth has very damaging effects on the economy,'' he said in his opening statement to the committee. ''It destroys the credibility of long-run monetary controls, adds to uncertainty and risk and thereby helps keep interest rates high as lenders seek to protect their principal.'' **********Democratic members of the committee peppere d the Secretary with questions that implied the flavor of the comi ng election-year debate. Representative Frederick W. Richmond of Brooklyn challenged Mr. Regan to support his prediction that an e conomic recovery would begin as early as the second quarter of 1982.  The Secreta r y cited the10 percent tax cut that will occur July 1. **********With respect to prospective budget deficits, the Secretary found himself on the defensive in light of President Reagan's rejection of the advice of the Secretary and other economic advisers that he seek excise tax increases to shrink the deficits. ''There is no evidence that huge deficits, as a percent of the gross national product, cause high interest rates,'' Mr. Regan said. Hopes of a Balanced Budget **********To Representative Chalmers P. Wylie, Republican of Ohio, who said, ''I'm a balanced-budget devotee,'' Mr. Regan replied: ''That is still the goal of the President. As a matter of fact, he'd like to go beyond that and actually have a surplus and pay down some of the national debt.'' **********The Secretary gave no indication when the White House thought a balanced budget might be achieved.  Mr. Regan, rejecting complaints that the three-stage tax cut sponsored by the President is responsible for the prospect of large deficits, said the basic cause was ''the sluggish econmic performance of 1980-81'' as well as the ''continued rapid growth of Government spending,'' which the Administration has been trying to retard. **********The Secretary argued that the Administration could not be blamed for the recession. He said the spending cuts and tax cuts were enacted after the recession had already begun last July. **********When an Ohio Republican, Representative Clarence J. Brown, asked about the feasibility of the fine-tuning urged by Mr. Regan, the Secretary prefaced his answer with a disclaimer of expertise. He was, he said, ''speaking as a practicing financier, not a theoretical economist,'' and so it might seem, he continued, that ''my advice is gratuitous.'' He went on to say of the Federal Reserve, ''I do think they can have more precise controls.'' He added, ''They don't seem to be able to be very precise about what they are doing.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/08/28/world.body_text: **********France was reported today to have sent a delegation to Peking to discuss the sale of Mirage 2000 jet fighters to China. **********China has been pressing for some time to buy the Mirage, but French officials have consistently said that there were no plans to sell the planes to Peking. **********However, the French Defense Minister, Charles Hernu, was reported in the French press to have said that France was now ready to sell the Mirage 2000 to China. This statement was confirmed by a ministry aide early today. **********Later in the day, however, the Defense Ministry denied that Mr.  Hernu had made the statement. No explanation for the confusion was given. **********China has for some years been eager to update its aging air force.  Most of its fighter-bombers are Soviet-built MIG-17's and 19's, 20 years old and obsolete in terms of modern warfare. **********By contrast, the Mirage is equipped with the latest in aviation electronics and is capable of carrying a variety of ordinance, including the Exocet surface-skimming missile that proved so effective in Argentine hands against the British Navy in the Falkland conflict. **********In the statement reported by the French press, Mr. Hernu was quoted as saying that the potential deal included the transfer of technology and possible joint production. **********There was no indication of the number of aircraft involved.  China has also expressed interest in the Crotale antiaircraft and Milan antitank missiles, but there was no indication that these items were being discussed in Peking.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/16/busin.main_headline: UNITED TECHNOLOGIES IN PEACE BID TO BENDIX
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/16/busin.print_headline: UNITED TECHNOLOGIES IN PEACE BID TO BENDIX
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/09/16/busin.body_text: **********Breaking a long silence, the United Technologies Corporation told the Bendix Corporation yesterday that it was prepared to increase its current $75-a-share offer for a controlling interest in Bendix to $85 if the two could reach an agreement to merge on friendly terms. **********Harry J. Gray, chairman of United Technologies, proposed the increase in a letter to William M. Agee, chairman of Bendix, as a way to resolve what he called the ''intolerable situation'' created by efforts of Bendix and the Martin Marietta Corporation to take over each other. **********With Bendix free to buy control of Marietta after midnight tonight, the proposal was viewed as an 11th-hour effort to head off a situation in which Bendix buys Marietta and then Marietta gets control of Bendix, thus touching off what many on both sides acknowledge would be ''a real mess.'' Marietta is free to buy control of Bendix after midnight on Sept. 22. **********Some professionals said, nevertheless, that this could happen and that United Technologies might then try to take over both or, possibly, wait for a more propitious time and try again to arrange a friendly deal. **********The United Technologies chairman told Mr. Agee that his proposal would enable Marietta to remain an independent company. All three corporations have substantial aerospace operations, but Mr. Gray said that ''with the cooperation of all three companies, there would be no antitrust issues and the merger of Bendix and United Technologies would be completed in a short period of time.'' **********Bendix said it would have no comment, but Wall Street professionals said they felt that while United Technologies' latest proposal might apply considerable pressure on Bendix to accept, they did not expect Bendix's response to be favorable - unless Mr. Agee and Mr. Gray, both exceptionally strong personalities, could find a way to resolve their individual needs. **********One leading professional said that while he had no direct information, he reasoned that Mr. Gray, who will be 63 in November, could be so eager to land Bendix that he might be willing to make a deal with Mr. Agee, who is only 44, for the Bendix chief to become an important executive in United Technologies and possibly even its head once Mr. Gray stepped down. Bendix Employee Stock **********In a related development, Marietta sued Bendix and Citibank in Federal court in Manhattan, contending that Bendix, with Citibank's cooperation, deprived some 15,000 Bendix employees in a company stock plan of an opportunity to tender their stock to Marietta at $75 a share. **********Bendix had told employees, who own about 4.6 million shares or 23 percent of Bendix's shares outstanding, that they could not withdraw the stock from the plan until Sept. 30, too late to be sent to Marietta. **********Bendix subsequently revised the rules so that individual employees could ask Citibank, as trustee for the employee stock plan, to tender their shares. It then adopted an order for Citibank to withdraw the 4.6 million shares it had tendered last week and not tender them without instructions from individual shareholders. Citibank is understood to have agreed to comply. Bendix then asked its employees not to tender their shares. **********Citibank said yesterday, however, that it had not yet been asked to withdraw the shares and had not withdrawn them. John J. Maloney, a spokesman for the bank, said the procedure Bendix proposed called for Citibank to withdraw the shares from Marietta by the Sept. 22 withdrawal deadline unless instructed otherwise by individual employees. Effect on Tender Response **********Thus, Marietta's Sept. 10 announcement that it had received 14.5 million Bendix shares in response to its tender offer for 11.9 million became somewhat clouded. If Bendix succeeds in exempting 4.6 million, Marietta might have substantially fewer than it sought - unless, as expected, it has received additional shares in the last week that have not yet been announced. If Marietta succeeds in keeping the shares, it would have far more than it currently wants. **********The issue could become moot if Marietta withdrew its bid for Bendix in the event United Technologies' proposal is accepted. But as of now, those who have tendered to Marietta would be able to sell 100 percent of their Bendix stock to Marietta at $75 a share if Citibank withdrew employee tenders. That is because they were tendered before the Sept. 9 proration deadline, which guarantees purchase in cash of all shares submitted so long as the shares do not exceed the 50.3 percent of Bendix stock sought by Marietta. **********If employees are allowed to tender and Marietta thus receives more shares than it sought, all of those who tendered by the proration deadline would be assured of selling only part of their shares for cash. The balance would be returned to be swapped later for stock. New Proposal Worth $67.50 **********Pending a reply to United Technologies' proposal, Marietta and United kept open their almost parallel offers to pay $75 a share for 51 percent of Bendix. In a second step to come later, United would swap one share of its stock for each of Bendix's, a phase of its offer unchanged in its $85-a-share proposal. Marietta would swap $55 in securities for each remaining Bendix share. **********Withdrawal date under United Technologies' first offer is Sept. 28. Analysts, who valued the first offer at $62.50 a share, said yesterday's proposal was worth $67.50. They valued the Marietta offer at $65 a share, but many professionals said that Marietta's apparent inability to get as many shares as it wanted by deadline would mean that they would be able to sell all of their stock at $75 a share, more than they could sell to United at $85, should the offer be accepted. Antitrust Trade-Offs **********Mr. Gray's proposal that all three companies work together to resolve antitrust problems implied that United Technologies' previously reported agreement with Marietta would remain in effect: Marietta would pay $600 million in cash to United in exchange for specific properties of Bendix that would create antitrust problems for United, and it would also be sold other Bendix properties that the Department of Justice might insist upon as a condition for permitting United to take over Bendix. Negotiations between United and the Justice Department have been under way since United made its first offer on Sept. 8. **********Marietta, to lessen confusion, stressed that the United Technologies proposal did not affect the $75-a-share offers from United or itself and said that should Bendix and United agree to merge, arrangements would be made for shareholders who have tendered to Marietta to switch to United. **********Bendix advanced $2.50 on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, to $59.75, in cautiously light trading. Marietta advanced 12 1/2 cents, to $35.625, while United Technologies fell 75 cents, to $49.25.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/13/busin.main_headline: CONSULTANT WILL LEAD DIVISION OF DAN RIVER
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/13/busin.print_headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; CONSULTANT WILL LEAD DIVISION OF DAN RIVER
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/13/busin.body_text: **********William M. Fine, who operates a corporate consulting concern in New York, is joining Dan River Inc. on Jan. 3 as president of its home fashions division. **********Mr. Fine, 56, will replace Anthony V. DeLuca, 57, who had asked for early retirement, the company said. Dan River, which has its headquarters in Danville, Va., is a big textile maker that is fighting a takeover bid from Carl C. Icahn, a New York financier. On Friday, Federal District Judge Jackson L. Kiser, in Lynchburg, Va., refused without comment a request by Mr. Icahn to block Dan River from taking possession of $15 million of its own stock. Lawyers for Mr. Icahn contended that the action by Dan River constituted an unannounced and illegal tender offer. **********Mr. Fine has had a varied career. From 1957 to 1968 he was publishing director of Harper's Bazaar and other Hearst magazines. He then became president and chief executive of Bonwit Teller and in 1973 was named president of Wamsutta Mills. **********In 1977 Mr. Fine and other investors bought Frances Denney Inc. Mr. Fine was chairman and chief executive until the group sold the cosmetic company to Delalande S.A. of France for $5 million. Mr. Fine then opened the W.M.F. Fund, his consulting concern. **********Last summer, Mr. Fine and others sued Delalande over the final payment and Delalande filed a countersuit. Mr. Fine said that the two sides currently ''are fairly close to a settlement.'' **********Mr. Fine said he would put his consulting concern into the hands of his wife, who will continue wtih one or two clients. At Dan River, his assignment will be to move the home furnishings. **********''They're hiring old guys because the young guys haven't worked in a recession,'' Mr. Fine said jokingly. But he added that he thinks home furnishings - sheets, towels, bedspreads, curtains, draperies - are going into an upward cycle and will ''bust open in the next six to eight months with the formation of new housing units.'' **********Dwellings of the future are going to be smaller, however, he warned. ''The king-size bed is going to disappear one of these days,'' he said. **********Mr. Fine said he thought the heyday of the designer name is over.  ''The name should say something about quality and value - not just a name slapped on a sheet package,'' he said.  Daniel F. Cuff

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/01/world.main_headline: FOR CAIRO'S POOREST, HOME IS WHERE THE SPACE IS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/01/world.print_headline: FOR CAIRO'S POOREST, HOME IS WHERE THE SPACE IS
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/01/world.body_text: **********Hassanein Farouk Ibrahim, a 26-year-old carpenter, was evicted from a rooftop hovel he had erected on a Cairo building.  Despairing of finding other accommodations, he set fire to himself and died. **********Three elderly people inhabiting a dilapidated and condemned building in a Cairo slum died recently when the building collapsed from sheer fatigue. **********Some time ago, a man who had just moved into a jerry-built but new building on the road to the Pyramids went out to buy a newspaper.  When he returned the structure had disappeared and his wife and son were killed. The building had collapsed because the owner skimped on structural and engineering standards. **********These are three of the grimmer realities about Cairo's, and Egypt's, desperate need for housing, a need that prompts owners to add stories to old buildings, frequently without consultation on whether the foundations can bear the added burden. Families, Chickens and Goats **********It is also a need that has forced Egyptians, by the hundreds of thousands, to erect makeshift dwellings on rooftops. Frequently in slum areas these tiny shelters contain large families as well as chickens and goats. **********It is a need that has forced hundreds of thousands to live in sepulchers in the city's vast necropolis, the city of the dead.  Poor people live in lean-tos along the banks of the Nile. Some make their homes on oversized rowboats, some families of construction workers live in incomplete buildings only to have to relocate when the buildings, usually of the luxury class, are completed. **********Lack of housing, a concomitant problem of Egypt's extraordinarily high birth rate of one million every 10 months, is one of the major problems facing President Hosni Mubarak as he attempts to revamp and revitalize the country's faltering economy. **********There is evidence of new high-rise construction everywhere in Cairo.  There are tall buildings destined to be hotels or office towers or apartments for the upper middle class and the rich. The noise of pile drivers is a commonplace addition to the city's normal din. 'The Fastest-Growing Segment' **********But the vast majority of the new building is not destined for the hundreds of thousands of Egyptians living marginal existences.  According to data compiled by the economic section of the United States Embassy here, ''the construction industry is the fastest-growing segment of the Egyptian economy.'' But the builders say there is no profit margin in erecting low-cost housing. **********It is not just a problem affecting the country's lowest income sector.  Many middle-class families, civil servants, teachers and the like whose marginal salaries prompt many of them to take second jobs, are packed into dwellings passed on to them by their parents.  For this sector, there is a crying need for more space and scant chance of getting it because of the skyrocketing costs of rentals and cooperatives here. **********Although the construction industry may be one of the more solid parts of the shaky Egyptian economy, experts here estimate that only about 130,000 new units are built each year.  This figure is estimated to be a sixth of the actual need. A Surge in Population **********In recent years, the greater Cairo metropolitan area has experienced a tremendous surge in population.  The United States Embassy puts the figure at about 14 million for a city whose 1930-ish foundation was designed to handle about 2 million. **********The migration from the countryside, along with the soaring birth rate, has sorely taxed this foundation and thousands of buildings have been put up by outflanking the officials and with little concern for providing appropriate sewer and power systems. **********A major example is the road leading from downtown Cairo to the Pyramids. A few years ago, the area was a combination of desert and farmland. Today it is an unplanned warren of apartment dwellings and the road is clotted with traffic and scurrying pedestrians. **********A form of rent control exists in Cairo's older apartment buildings, some of them fine examples of Art Deco. A family who moved in 30 years ago may well pay the same rent it did on moving day. This, say landlords, is a disincentive to maintain the buildings and accounts for the fact that while an individual apartment may be a splendid airy abode, the hallway and the front may be crumbling to pieces and filthy. Calls for a Permit System **********The situation is dire enough so that some editorial writers here have called for some sort of permit system to limit the number of people who can settle in the country's two major metropolitan areas, Cairo and Alexandria. **********But so far no attempts have been made to do this and people continue to flock to both places.The rapid rate of construction, while still not fast enough to keep up with demands, has created another problem besides unplanned urban sprawl. The building boom has used up considerable amounts of Egypt's limited agricultural lands, a circumstance that further increases the nation's enormous dependence on foreign food imports.  Mr. Mubarak, like President Anwar el-Sadat, has called for greater selfsufficiency in producing Egypt's food requirements. But only 4 percent of the country, the land along the Nile, is arable. Parks and Villas Disappear **********The craving for dwellings has also been merciless on the oases of green that used to lend Cairo a certain grace. Many parks and villas with gardens and grounds have been replaced by high rises. There is much talk of land reclamation projects here - programs that combine the creation of new dwellings with the cultivation of desert lands. The few projects that do exist have been enormously expensive, and the Government's present fiscal state does not bode well for major new initiatives in the near future. **********One such project in the desert outside Cairo is called Salhiya, an ambitious private venture being erected with borrowed Government funds. **********The plan is to replace the sandy wastes with 50,000 acres of farmland, enough to provide food for 1.2 million people, according to the project director, Ismail Osman. **********Mr. Osman says Salhiya is destined to have a population of 100,000 some day. Buildings to house 6,000 families are nearly completed. A Reluctance to Forsake the City **********One of the problems facing the planners anxious to develop projects away from Cairo and the narrow overpopulated strip along the Nile has been a reluctance by Egyptians to forsake either the city or the ancient farmlands along the river. **********In places like the Kharga Oasis in the vast Western Desert bordering on Libya, large pools of underground water have been found. The area is remote and most Egyptians have never heard of it, much less seen it. Those who do live there raise bumper crops and have livestock and, in general, live a life that is more comfortable than the Cairene's. But efforts to spur a large migration to places like Kharga have met with little success. **********In a recent article in an issue of The Journal of Arab Affairs, written by Prof. Malcolm H. Kerr, an authority on Egypt, tried to assess the Cairo of the year 2000 based on what is - or is not - happening today. **********In a section related to housing, Professor Kerr wrote of ''a deepening gulf between a large, increasingly cosmopolitan and affluent business-based upper and upper-middle class, inhabiting a smart, new, well-paved cleaned-up downtown Cairo with a skyline of hotels and office skycrapers, and an ever-growing mass of underemployed and disaffected wretches inhabiting one of the world's largest slums, watched carefully by the police and the army.'' **********This sobering assessment is shared by others here as Mr. Mubarak's Government, faced with formidable obstacles blocking a stable economy, attempts to implement his pledge for a greater and more equitable distribution of the nation's resources.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/07/13/world.body_text: **********Striking train engineers today ignored a final appeal by British Rail to return to work, forcing management to consider shutting the national network and dismissing the strikers. **********Only 718 of British Rail's 17,000 daily trains ran by noon today, the ninth day of the strike, which is costing the state-run railroad $14 million a day. **********''These figures are certainly not enough to justify keeping the network open next week,'' a British Rail spokesman said. A decision on whether to close the system will be made at a board meeting tomorrow. **********The strike, by 25,000 members of the Associated Society of Locomotive Engineers and Firemen, is over British Rail's attempt to replace a guaranteed eight-hour working day with more flexible schedules in order to improve services and cut heavy losses.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/17/world.body_text: **********Bernardo Mora, a construction worker savoring oysters in the Mercado Central here, said Argentina would have attacked Chile had it not seized the Falkland Islands instead.  ''It was either them or us,'' he said. **********As a man with a guitar and a song of lost love strolled past, Luisa Parra, whose family has owned the oyster stand for seven decades, heartily concurred. ''The Argentines are never satisfied with what they have - they always want another bite, another bite, another bite,'' she said. **********The exchange symbolizes the thinking of both leaders and citizens of this nation. They believe, first, that Argentina's action to take the Falklands from the British was part of a broader plan calling for a subsequent assault on Chile's Beagle Islands; the Falklands were attacked first only because stiff British resistance seemed doubtful. **********Second, Chileans are deeply worried that Argentina may still have violent designs on the Beagle Islands, a remote group of rocky islands populated by a handful of fishermen, sheepherders and kelpers, particularly if Buenos Aires emerges from defeat feeling humiliated and vengeful. 'Only the Beginning' **********''The situation is very dangerous,'' a well-placed Chilean Government official said. ''What happens after capitulation?'' Indications of an ominous answer are plentiful. After Argentine troops moved on the Falklands, President Leopoldo Galtieri gave an emotional midnight speech claiming, ''This is only the beginning of the reaffirmation of Argentina's right to assert territories.'' Chilean officials have no doubt about his implication. **********Moreover, Argentina over the past year has been regularly sending its ships into Chile's South Atlantic waters without asking permission, spurring Santiago to lodge two or three diplomatic protests a month, officials here say. Also, Buenos Aires in January renounced a treaty between the two countries requiring them to use peaceful means, such as arbitration, to settle disputes. **********This follows Argentina's refusal to abide by the results of binding arbitration of the territorial dispute five years ago and its decision thus far not to accept suggestions made by Pope John Paul II 18 months ago for solving the issue. Four years ago, the countries came close to war over the Beagles before the Pope stepped in to mediate. Refurbishing Argentina's Image **********Much will obviously depend on the nature of postwar Argentina. A Western political analyst suggests that while defeat might be ''a sobering experience'' for Buenos Aires, it will more likely result in ''a wounded Galtieri, a new Galtieri or a new Peron - none of whom are likely to be more rational or accommodating toward Chile.'' **********Accordingly, the expert predicts ''a wounded Argentina on the prowl for any opportunity to refurbish its image.'' A major consequence has been repetition by policy makers here of the hard-line policy toward Argentine attacks. Chile explicitly says that it will treat any aggression as complete war, and will retaliate by sea, ground and air anywhere along the country's 2,000-mile border, as well as anywhere else in Argentina. **********''That's the only deterrent we have -our willingness to go to total war,'' a Chilean Government analyst said. ''So, the cost to Argentina will be a very high one.'' **********The cost of war to Chile - currently mired in a severe recession - would also be huge. All three of Chiles's three neighbors, Argentina, Peru and Bolivia, harbor revanchist designs on Chilean land. Additionally, Peru and Argentina, which have been cooperating more and more closely as the Falklands war progressed, have bigger and more advanced armed forces, military experts say. Air Setback Temporary **********Moreover, Argentina's large loss of aircraft and pilots over the Falklands, while clearly advantageous for Santiago, is generally thought to be temporary. A particular nightmare in this fiercely anti-Communist country is that Argentina will turn to Moscow for aircraft and other weapons. Peru already possesses $1 billion in sophisticated Soviet arms acquired by the previous Government.Deepening the problem has been Washington's reluctance to move ahead with weapons sales to Santiago when it has banned such sales to rival Buenos Aires. **********Perhaps as a result, there is a marked reluctance to upset the Argentines. Government officials categorically deny reports that they are cooperating with London, or even that they have been asked to do so. Foreign intelligence officials tend to believe them, with the possible, but largely unsubstantiated, exception of the occasional passing on of military intelligence by telephone. **********''If Argentina had factual proof that this Government is helping the British, it would make life hell for years and years,'' a foreign expert pointed out. The sensitivity of the issue was apparent several weeks ago when a British Sky King helicopter crashed on Chilean territory, sparking widespread speculation that it was part of a commando operation aimed at Argentina's military bases on the mainland. **********London's rather facile explanation, made in the face of repeated reports in the British press that commandos had conducted raids on the Argentine mainland, that the helicopter was an errant intelligence aircraft was immediately accepted by embarrassed Chilean officials. Strict Neutrality Avowed **********Chile's avowed position on the war is one of strict neutrality, although officials concede they would have liked to be more pro-Argentine, particularly to avoid ostracism by the vast majority of South American nations, who favor Buenos Aires. Santiago has helped its neighbor in such humanitarian ways as providing a ship to rescue Argentine crewmen from the sunken cruiser Belgrano, and in such nonmilitary ways as providing access to its civilian ports. **********A widely circulated rumor here is that Santiago offered to support Buenos Aires totally if it would accept the Pope's mediation of the Beagles issue. **********The results of that mediation, announced in 1980, have been accepted by Chile, but virtually ignored by Argentina. The findings, widely known although not formally released, support Chile's right to the Beagles, as well as the channel linking the Atlantic and Pacific. **********Buenos Aires in the past several years has developed a new justification for its position, which it maintains is based on century-old treaties and understandings. In what has become an immensely tangled legal dispute, the Argentines have formulated a policy they call ''the bi-oceanic principle,'' under which they now contend they should be sovereign over all territory on the Atlantic side of the Strait of Magellan and Cape Horn, while Chile would maintain control over the Pacific side.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/03/world.print_headline: U.N. CHIEF ACKNOWLEDGES FAILURE IN ATTEMPT TO WIN FALKLAND TRUCE
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/03/world.body_text: **********Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar acknowledged to the Security Council today that he had again failed to win a cease-fire between Argentina and Britain in the Falkland war. **********His report to the Security Council was his second admission of failure in 12 days. In his latest report, Mr. Perez de Cuellar said he would continue his efforts, but he offered no sign of hope. **********''It is my considered judgment that the positions of the two parties do not offer the possibility of developing at this time terms for a cease-fire which would be mutually acceptable,'' the Secretary General said. ''I shall nevertheless maintain close contact with the parties in the event an opportunity can be found in which the exercise of my good offices can contribute to bringing this tragic crisis to an end.'' **********His effort last month came close to bridging the gap, but then, he said, both sides hardened their positions and the attempt failed.  That precipitated the British landing on East Falkland Island. **********Mr. Perez de Cuellar did not describe the positions of the two sides or what he had proposed. But it is known that he has been urging the British to slow their advance on Stanley, the islands' capital, enabling the Argentine troops to evacuate with their weapons. **********The British say Argentina has not responded to his proposal.  And in Washington, Reagan Administration officials, in an attempt to persuade Argentina to withdraw its troops at once, said there was no reason for Britain to accept a cease-fire until Argentina agreed to that condition. (Page A14.) **********In any event, it is unclear whether London would break off a final offensive. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has reportedly been told by military advisers that any slowdown in the advance could imperil the lives of British soldiers. U.N. Role Is Considered **********Diplomats here believe that diplomacy has been sidelined and must await the events on the ground. The prevailing view is that Britain will take Stanley in a few days. **********If this happens, or if Argentine resistance stiffens and the British become bogged down, the way would again be clear for diplomatic action. Mr. Perez de Cuellar has begun considering what role the United Nations can play in providing peacekeeping forces and administrators if Britain retakes the islands. **********After his peacemaking efforts collapsed last month, Mr. Perez de Cuellar was instructed by the Council to make another attempt. He agreed, but complained that the Council had given neither him nor the combatants guidelines specific enough to be useful. He predicted that, with the war in full swing, his task would be extremely difficult, a forecast that has proved correct. **********Enrique Ros, Argentina's Under Secretary for Foreign Affairs, described the gap between the two sides to the Council this evening.  Argentina, its forces suffering from the British assault, wants an immediate cease-fire, Mr. Ros said. Then, he said, it proposes to negotiate a withdrawal by the forces of both sides. **********But Sir Anthony Parsons, the British delegate to the United Nations, has said that Britain would stop hostilities only when Argentina alone begins withdrawing its troops. Mr. Ros said the British had adhered to this stance in the private talks with the Secretary General and so Britain must ''bear the responsibiliy for continuation of the military action which is resulting in the loss of so many lives.'' **********Mr. Ros also confirmed the report Tuesday that Britain seeks to replace its troops with an international force that would include soldiers from the United States. The Argentine diplomat warned Washington that any such ''dangerous adventure'' would ''deepen the breach in the hemisphere.'' **********In London today, Prime Minister Thatcher said that Britain hoped ''to have a multinational force with us'' in the Falklands. ''You know,'' she added, ''when the Americans asked us to join them in a multinational force in Sinai, I said yes, because it helped peace in that area. And I'm sure we'd have just exactly the same response from them.'' **********After Mr. Ros's address, Spain and Panama promptly introduced a resolution tailored to Argentine needs. It calls on Britain and Argentina to establish an immediate cease-fire. **********Sir Anthony told the Council he would veto the document because it does not tie a cease-fire to the pullout of Argentine troops. The only resolution Britain could support, he said, is one that renews the Council's April 3 demand that Argentine forces leave and adds that ''watertight arrangements'' shall be made for their ''withdrawal with dignity.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/30/busin.body_text: **********THERE is more to Zenith Radio than meets the eye and ear. Though mired in the unprofitable color television market, Zenith is diversifying rapidly. The company is convincing fans that it will be important in some growing high-technology areas by the mid-1980's. **********That's the positive side of a story that has negative aspects today.  The situation is bad enough so that Zenith slipped into the red in the first quarter of 1982 -having failed to make its usual recession inroads against competitors in the color TV market. Zenith earned 82 cents a share in 1981 and is widely expected to earn 50 cents a share in all of 1982. **********Zenith still gets 62 percent of revenues from color television sets - down from 76 percent in 1978. Production costs, meantime, have risen steadily while prices have been essentially static since 1967.  In fact, some say profits on this key element of Zenith's business have dwindled to the vanishing point. William Nail, director of public relations for Zenith, says that is too strong but adds that profits are ''inadequate.'' **********For years Zenith has complained about Japanese competition. In 1971, the United States International Trade Commission ruled that Japanese companies had ''dumped'' their color television sets in the American market - selling them at substantially lower prices here than in Japan. **********Dumping penalties were set, but little has been collected, according to Mr. Nail. He added that Zenith was trying to prevent a settlement of 10 cents on the dollar on some $600 million in penalties. **********Regardless of the future of the market for color television sets, Zenith has moved forward in other markets and with impressive results. Last month, Zenith made its entry into the budding component television market. Component television offers high-fidelity stereo systems - a video version of radio systems made up of separate speakers, amplifiers and tuners. **********Many believe component television will be a $100 million market by the mid-1980's. One Zenith booster, an account executive at a leading brokerage firm with many clients in the shares, argues that component television will be less subject to discounting than are television sets. Customers for stereo systems use components to get better performance, he argues, and will thus pay more. Others do not agree. **********James Magid follows Zenith for L.F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin.  He stresses another aspect of components. Zenith's equipment - like that of the competition - will allow users to display computer data on separately mounted television screens. **********Mr. Magid said that the high point of Zenith's component television is the controller that manages input from a videotape recorder, personal computer, games, and so forth - ''a masterpiece of design.'' He is also impressed with Zenith's new Z100 microcomputer, which uses advanced microprocessors and offers more computing power than many competitors. The result, Mr. Magid added, is an impressive and flexible machine with color capability. One model in particular can store the equivalent of 1.000 single-spaced pages. **********Mr. Magid, who likes Zenith in the long term, is cool to Zenith's stock at present prices. In the last 12 months, it has traded as high as 20 1/2 but recently has fallen into the 11 range on the New York Stock Exchange. Yet patient investors may be rewarded through high-technology businesses, he said. He noted that Zenith's computer business had revenues of $71 million in 1981 and he looks for $120 million this year. **********Mr. Magid added that the company is a leader in ''addressable decoders'' that allow cable subscribers to add or drop services without a visit by service personnel, a formidable advantage over competitors. **********Like others, Mr. Magid discounts talk of a possible takeover.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/13/world.main_headline: Women in England Rally Against Missiles
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/13/world.print_headline: AROUND THE WORLD; Women in England Rally Against Missiles
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/12/13/world.body_text: **********Thousands of women linked arms today to form an unbroken nine-mile chain around a British air base to protest plans to site 96 cruise nuclear missiles there. **********The unused Greenham Common base being taken over by 1,300 United States servicemen has been chosen as the site for 96 of the 572 cruise and Pershing 2 missiles to be deployed in Western Europe by NATO starting in December 1983. **********In West Germany, thousands of antinuclear demonstrators held protest rallies throughout the country and blocked the gates of about 20 United States and Canadian military bases. Protesters also blocked the entrance to the headquarters of United States military forces in Europe at Stuttgart. **********The big British protest was the prelude to the start of a new campaign Monday by women to blockade the gates of Greenham Common base to hinder preparations for receiving the missiles.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/09/busin.body_text: **********Some of the big names on Wall Street - all major stockholders in the Marathon Oil Company - are lining up on opposite sides of the fence on the question of whether Marathon should complete a $6 billion merger with the United States Steel Corporation. **********Marathon's stockholders are scheduled to meet Thursday in the company's Findlay, Ohio, headquarters, to vote on the merger, and a spot-check of leading shareholders showed yesterday that the outcome is far from certain. **********Even whether the meeting will be held is a cliffhanger. Judge Carl Rubin of United States District Court in Cincinnati is reviewing 11 class-action suits by Marathon stockholders, including the Dreyfus Fund, which controls 700,000 shares, seeking to block the meeting on the ground that the merger terms are too low. Whether Judge Rubin will hold up the meeting is still in doubt. **********Morgan Guaranty's Position **********The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, which holds some 1.3 million shares of Marathon for clients, has reached what it called a ''tentative conclusion'' to vote its shares against the merger. **********Sedco Inc., the big Texas oil services company, with some 2 million Marathon shares, has decided to vote its block of stock in favor of the merger. Other large stockholders are believed to include the Prudential Insurance Company of America, the Mellon Bank of Pittsburgh, the Provident National Bank of Philadelphia and the National City Bank of Cleveland. **********For the last month, dissident holders, led by what is known as the Marathon Shareholders Committee, have staged a strong campaign to defeat the merger. It has already held information meetings for stockholders in Boston, New York, Fort Lauderdale, Houston and Los Angeles. **********Last night, in addition to a meet-ing in New York, where 25 shareholders gathered, the committee was scheduled to meet in Robinson, Ill., the site of a Marathon refinery. Today, it will meet in Cleveland and again tomorrow in Findlay. **********At the New York meeting, Frances A. Armstrong of Washington, D.C., who owns 200 shares and is acting chairman of the committee, said that it had received ''in excess of 100,000'' votes in opposition to the merger and that there was ''a high probability'' that the merger would proceed. **********As a result, she said, the committee was urging shareholders to vote against the merger or to abstain to qualify for appraisal rights for their stock if the merger is approved. Under complex Ohio law, shareholders who object to the terms of a merger can go to court to seek fair market value. **********Yolanda Collinson of Cliffside Park, N.J., who said she owned 133 Marathon shares, asked, ''If you wage this appraisal battle, how long will it take and if you do, what makes you think we'll be successful in getting more for our stock?'' **********Miss Armstrong, a Government lawyer, replied, ''While we can't promise success in the face of little success in the past in appraisal suits, we feel that the court has wide latitude in determining what fair cash value is and we think it's worth a shot.''  Fair Price at Issue **********At issue is whether the second half of U.S. Steel's controversial merger plan will give Marathon's stockholders a fair price for their shares. **********Last November, after the Mobil Corporation made a hostile offer to buy Marathon for $85 a share, Marathon's executives accepted a friendly deal offered by U.S. Steel to buy 51 percent of the company for $125 a share and the rest for 12 1/2 percent notes then valued at about $86 each. **********Viewed in its entirety, the offer was valued at $106 a share, more than double the $45 price of Marathon before takeover fever pushed it to $64 last fall and just before Mobil made its unwelcome bid of $85. In fact, $106 a share is what Marathon officers will get for their shares in the company, if the merger is approved. **********As a consequence, U.S. Steel's $125 price for the first half of the deal won overwhelming reception, so much so that to be fair to all of the stockholders wanting to sell, it accepted only about 56 of each 100 shares offered, returning the rest so that they could be swapped later for U.S. Steel's notes. Stronger Bond Market **********Before long, however, interest rates began rising and U.S. Steel's 12 1/2 percent notes plunged to about $75 each, prompting some stockholders to file suit. The bond market has strengthened somewhat in the meantime, however, and if it continues to improve, U.S.  Steel's notes, now valued about $78, may look more attractive.  Marathon stock pays only $2 a year in dividends while U.S. Steel's notes yield $12.50 annually in interest. **********U.S. Steel's offer to stockholders, Dreyfus charged in its suit, ''falsely represents that the terms of the merger are fair to the shareholders.'' It said, ''In truth, Marathon and U.S. Steel know full well that the value of the notes to be received by shareholders in exchange for each share of Marathon common stock is less than the true value of Marathon's stock and is grossly inadequate.'' **********Moreover, Dreyfus maintained, U.S. Steel's offer was ''false and misleading'' in calling the proposal fair because the basis for that assertion was in considering both parts of the offer as one when, according to Dreyfus, such was not the case. **********Nearly two weeks ago, David M. Roderick, chairman of U.S. Steel, said that the company ''will not alter the terms'' of its offer and warned that if the merger were defeated, U.S. Steel might go into the open market and buy enough additional Marathon stock to force a merger. 9 Million More Shares Needed **********U.S. Steel already owns 30 million shares, or 51 percent, of the stock, which it will vote for itself. It needs two-thirds of the 58.7 million shares outstanding to get approval to merge, or roughly 9 million additional shares. The opposition, however, needs some 17 million votes to deprive U.S. Steel of enough votes to win. **********Wall Street arbitragers, who control about 3 million shares, are expected to vote in favor of the deal, fearing that defeat could make Marathon shares plummet to somewhere near $50 a share. **********Stanley Schiff, senior vice president and chief arbitrager of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., which has a ''several-million-dollar position'' in Marathon, said he would vote for the merger and that those that do not ''will rue the day'' because the stock ''will sell considerably lower than now if the deal is defeated.'' **********If the meeting proceeds - unless the vote is overwhelmingly one way or the other on Thursday, a circumstance viewed as unlikely - Marathon's management is expected to adjourn the proceedings without announcing the outcome so that election inspectors can authenticate each ballot and eliminate duplicate votes. Fiduciary Responsibility **********Some investors may have a problem in deciding how to vote, particularly those with fiduciary responsibility on behalf of shareholders they represent. For example, Fayez Sarofim, president of the investment advisory firm bearing his name, had said in Houston earlier that he intended to vote an estimated $35 million position against the deal but did not return repeated telephone calls to confirm Wall Street reports that he had changed sides. **********With the merger vote only 48 hours away, Sedco has given no indication that it might change its vote but Morgan Guaranty said it was ''continuing to review'' its position. **********Indeed, with Marathon, U.S. Steel and a dissident stockholders' committee all soliciting votes for their case, a spot-check of some of the biggest Marathon stockholders showed that many were not expected to decide how to vote until just before 10 A.M. Thursday, when - unless the court decides otherwise - the meeting will convene. **********And, based on experience, many small stockholders have probably voted several times on both sides of the question. In such cases, the most recently dated vote is the one that counts. **********If the merger is eventually approved, as many Wall Street analysts expect, those who object to the terms can sue for better ones although the procedure is regarded as long and difficult. If the merger is defeated, as U.S. Steel reiterated in recent full-page ads, not only would it not improve the terms but it also might wait for the right time and then buy the stock it needs to force a merger.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/03/30/busin.body_text: **********The Midwest Stock Exchange said today that it had asked the Securities and Exchange Commission for approval to become the first exchange to trade industry stock groups as a unit. **********Kenneth Rosenblum, executive vice president and general counsel of the exchange, said exchange officials mailed the proposed rules change on Friday. **********The exchange's proposal would allow an investor to buy a unit consisting of stock of several companies in the same industry, such as computers, chemicals or oils. **********Mr. Rosenblum said the proposed trading was a ''companion'' to proposals made by options exchanges that they be allowed to trade in options on industry stock groups. Thus, he said, his exchange's proposal would allow people to buy or sell industry stock groups to cover positions held in a stock group option. **********The exchange said present plans foresaw five stock issues in each industry group, with each unit consisting of 100 shares of each of the component companies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/08/world.main_headline: A VISIT TO WINDSOR CAPS MONTHS OF PREPARATION
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/08/world.print_headline: A VISIT TO WINDSOR CAPS MONTHS OF PREPARATION
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/06/08/world.body_text: **********During his brief visit to Britain, President Reagan will be spending most of his time - as well as his two nights - at Windsor Castle, a rambling stone fortress that was begun more than 900 years ago. **********As they repose some 20 miles from the center of London, the Reagans may have difficulty discerning the stately calm that usually pervades the castle and the equally venerable town of Windsor that has existed since Saxon times. On few occasions since William the Conqueror established a fortress at Windsor as part of the perimeter of his defenses has the royal residence and bordering town seen so much activity. **********For months, White House advance teams have been at work, checking security, planning ''photo opportunities'' and insuring that the accommodations will meet with the Reagans' approval. Such efforts have bemused British officials accustomed to a far more modest level of preparations, even for their sovereign. **********570 in Reagan Entourage **********The British leaders, who travel in small planes or in a motorcade of just a few cars, were astonished to learn that the Reagan entourage would include 4 large planes, 6 helicopters, 2 armored cars, 200 aides, 220 journalists and 150 Secret Service agents. **********The size of the entourage was eventually accepted but several White House requests were turned down by Buckingham Palace officials.  Efforts to include the President's food coordinators were rebuffed with the comment that if the castle kitchens were suitable for Queen Elizabeth, then they should be suitable for President Reagan, as one British official recounted the incident. **********At another point, American planners suggested that the President and the Queen be accompanied on their horseback ride in the private, 740-acre Windsor Home Park by other senior American officials and that the Queen and the President set off toward the camera positions. Buckingham Palace rebuffed both requests. Castle Built About 1070 **********In staying with Queen Elizabeth at Windsor, Mr. Reagan will be visiting what is among the monarchy's most venerable sites and a residence with far more history than its in-town counterpart, Buckingham Palace. The largest inhabited castle in the world, Windsor Castle itself covers about 24 acres, on a hill overlooking the River Thames. **********The original castle - a fortified earthwork surrounded by a moat - was probably built around 1070 but this structure was largely replaced and extended by later sovereigns. It was from Windsor Castle that Richard the LionHearted rode out to the Crusades and from Windsor that King John, his brother and successor, went to nearby Runnymede to sign Magna Carta in 1215. **********Outside, the castle presents an almost seamless medieval facade; inside, the rooms are a mixture of styles and periods that reflect the frequent alterations. While some parts, such as the Grand Staircase, continue a Gothic motif, others such as the Waterloo Chamber, the imposing banquet hall, have been imbued with gilded opulence. An Infatuation With Horses **********In the horseback riding as well as in the visit to Windsor, President Reagan will be participating in a royal tradition. Horses, and dogs, have always played a central role in the British royal family, much the way the animals are revered members of British society as a whole. **********Within the family of the current sovereign, the infatuation with horses is particularly prominent. In addition to riding for fun and on ceremonial occasions, the Queen owns horses that are raced and are entered in cross-country competitions, often by her daughter, Princess Anne. **********The Queen's husband, Prince Philip, played polo until about 10 years ago and now drives horses in competition. The son and heir, Prince Charles, has continued the polo tradition and is also an avid fox hunter. Only the Princess of Wales has an aversion to horses. **********The Queen and her family use Windsor Castle for weekends and they normally stay for all of April, as well as for a week in June at the time of the Royal Meeting at Ascot Race Course.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/23/world.main_headline: SOVIET BUILDS BRIDGE QUICKLY ON THE AFGHAN BORDER
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/23/world.print_headline: SOVIET BUILDS BRIDGE QUICKLY ON THE AFGHAN BORDER
https://www.nytimes.com/1982/05/23/world.body_text: **********The Soviet Union has strengthened supply lines to its forces in Afghanistan by rushing to completion the first rail and road bridge across the broad river separating the two countries. **********The bridge across the Amu Darya, opened to traffic after two and a half years of construction, eliminates a bottleneck in provisioning the approximately 90,000 Soviet troops operating with Afghan Government forces against Islamic insurgents. It will ease traffic especially to the forces stationed in eastern Afghanistan, including Kabul, the capital, and the Pakistani border zone. **********In the past, supplies had to be ferried with some difficulty across the Amu Darya, a rapidly flowing, sediment-laden river made treacherous by shifting channels. With its headstream, the Panj, the Amu Darya forms some 600 miles of the Soviet-Afghan border. **********The new bridge carries a single railroad track embedded in a twolane roadway so that motor traffic must wait when a train crosses.  The urgency of the bridge project was pointed up by President Babrak Karmal of Afghanistan, who presided over the inaugural ceremony on May 12 with Sharaf R. Rashidov, the chief of the Communist Party of Uzbekistan, one of the Soviet Union's Central Asian republics bordering on Afghanistan. Bridge Will Help Trade, Too **********Apparently alluding to the military aid from Moscow, Mr. Karmal said, ''The construction of the bridge and its completion a whole year ahead of schedule are a reflection of the genuinely internationalist policy of the Soviet state.'' **********Although military requirements were behind the project, the bridge will also speed the flow of Soviet-Afghan trade, which has tripled since the Communists seized power in Afghanistan in April 1978. The Soviet Union supplies the Afghans with industrial equipment, trucks and oil products, and receive, in addition to the pipeline transmission of natural gas, substantial cotton, wool, hides and raisins. **********The Soviet press, in contrast to its reticence about military activities in Afghanistan, has given wide publicity to the bridge.  Its length has not been disclosed but is believed to be close to a mile. **********Work started about the time the first Soviet troops moved into Afghanistan in December 1979. The Uzbekistan newspaper Pravda Vostoka of Tashkent, without mentioning the military intervention, said this month that construction began ''at the end of 1979.'' The Speed of Construction **********Under normal conditions, the paper said, it would have taken four and a half years to complete such a project. President Karmal's remark suggested that initial plans allotted three and a half years.  A second year was evidently saved in the actual construction. **********The bridge links the city of Termez, on the Soviet side of the river, with a new Afghan town whose name is given as Khairaton in the Soviet press and as Jeyretan on American maps. **********Termez, a railhead with a population of 60,000 and reputedly a place where some of the the highest summer temperatures in the Soviet Union are recorded, has become a key base for military operations in Afghanistan. **********Except for priority equipment airlifted directly to Kabul and other Soviet-held airfields in Afghanistan, much of the materiel destined for Soviet forces has been transferred from the railroad at Termez to barges and ferried either directly across to Khairaton or some 100 miles upstream to another river landing, at Shir Khan. From Shir Khan, a modern highway leads through the Soviet-built Salang Tunnel in the Hindu Kush mountain range to Kabul. **********The bridge enables the Soviet Union to deliver goods either by truck or by rail directly to the Khairaton terminal on the Afghan bank. **********A rail siding has been in operation for some years in northwest Afghanistan, at Turagundi, also spelled Towraghondi, just across the land border from the Soviet railhead of Kushka. Except for these two short extensions of the Soviet rail system, there are no railroads in Afghanistan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1982/10/26/busin.body_text: **********The New York Times Company reported yesterday that its third-quarter net income rose 4 percent, to $10.8 million, or 86 cents a share, from $10.4 million, or 84 cents a share, in the same period last year. **********The company's revenue was $221.2 million, up 8 percent from $205.6 million in the 1981 quarter.  ''The quarter's gains from operations were almost entirely offset by a decline in the equity in earnings of our associated forestproducts companies,'' said Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, chairman and chief executive officer. ''The decline in the equity earnings was due to several factors, among them sharply lower investment tax credits.'' **********Mr. Sulzberger said that the recession is affecting some areas of business - such as advertising in the newspaper group - and added that the company's rate of growth for the remainder of the year may continue to be slower than in the first half. **********''Nevertheless,'' he added, ''I am confident that 1982 will be our year of highest earnings.'' Gains Led by Newspaper Group **********The quarter's operating gains were led by the newspaper group, which consists of The New York Times and 18 newspapers in small cities in the Southeast. Increased advertising rates and circulation volume, coupled with lower costs, led to the group's $14 million operating profit for the quarter, a 48 percent gain from the same period last year. **********During the period, the company announced agreements in principle to acquire 12 more newspapers, including The Sarasota (Fla.) Herald Tribune, the largest acquisition. **********The magazine group's operating profit rose 22 percent in the third quarter, to $5.6 million, led by Golf Digest and Tennis.  The books, information and education group recorded an operating profit of $1.5 million for the quarter, against a loss of $325,000 in the same quarter last year, when costs were incurred in the reduction and change of operations at Arno Press. Arno's assets since have been sold. **********The broadcasting/cable television group showed a drop in operating profits, to $203,000 from $630,000 in the 1981 quarter. At the end of September, the company's cable television system in southern New Jersey had 95,000 basic subscribers, a gain of 20 percent from 79,000 in September 1981. **********For the six months ended Sept. 30, the company said, the average circulation of The New York Times was 905,700 copies weekdays and 1,498,900 copies Sundays, a gain of 18,500 copies and 37,200 copies, respectively, from the corresponding period of 1981.
